en: CHAPTER I.
vi: Chapter I
tr: First Chapter
es: Chapter I

en: You don’t know about me without you have read a book by the name of The Adventures of Tom Sawyer; but that ain’t no matter. That book was made by Mr. Mark Twain, and he told the truth, mainly. There was things which he stretched, but mainly he told the truth. That is nothing. I never seen anybody but lied one time or another, without it was Aunt Polly, or the widow, or maybe Mary. Aunt Polly—Tom’s Aunt Polly, she is—and Mary, and the Widow Douglas is all told about in that book, which is mostly a true book, with some stretchers, as I said before.
vi: Perhaps you won't know me if you haven't read the book called "The Adventures of Tom Sawyer"; but that's alright. The author of that book is Mr. Mark Twain, and in it, he mostly tells the truth. There are some parts where he exaggerates a bit, but the majority of the stories are true. I've never seen anyone lie repeatedly like Aunt Polly, or the widow, or maybe even Mary. Aunt Polly is Tom's aunt, then there's Mary, and the widow Douglas; all of these people appear in the aforementioned book, and, as I said, it is mostly a true book, except for a few slight exaggerations.
tr: If you haven't read the book titled The Adventures of Tom Sawyer, you wouldn't know me, but it doesn't matter. That book was written by Mr. Mark Twain, and he mostly tells the truth. He exaggerated some things, but what he said is mostly true. What does it matter anyway. One way or another, I haven't met anyone who doesn't lie, except Aunt Polly, and the widow lady, maybe Mary too. Aunt Polly – that is, Tom's Aunt Polly – and Mary, and also the Widow Douglas are mentioned in that book; as I said earlier, mostly true things are said in the book, but there are also exaggerated parts.
es: YOU WON'T KNOW WHO I AM if you haven't read a book titled The Adventures of Tom Sawyer, but it doesn't matter. That book was written by Mr. Mark Twain and he told the truth, most of the time. Some things he exaggerated, but most of the time he told the truth. That is nothing. I've never seen anyone who didn't lie at some point, except Aunt Polly, or the widow, or maybe Mary. About Aunt Polly — she is Tom's Aunt Polly — and Mary and Widow Douglas, everything is told in that book, which is mostly true, with some exaggerations, as I said before.

en: Now the way that the book winds up is this: Tom and me found the money that the robbers hid in the cave, and it made us rich. We got six thousand dollars apiece—all gold. It was an awful sight of money when it was piled up. Well, Judge Thatcher he took it and put it out at interest, and it fetched us a dollar a day apiece all the year round—more than a body could tell what to do with. The Widow Douglas she took me for her son, and allowed she would sivilize me; but it was rough living in the house all the time, considering how dismal regular and decent the widow was in all her ways; and so when I couldn’t stand it no longer I lit out. I got into my old rags and my sugar-hogshead again, and was free and satisfied. But Tom Sawyer he hunted me up and said he was going to start a band of robbers, and I might join if I would go back to the widow and be respectable. So I went back.
vi: Aunt Polly is Tom's aunt, then there's Mary, and the widow Douglas; all of these people appear in the aforementioned book, and, as I said, it is mostly a true book, except for a few slight exaggerations. The book has the following content: Tom and I, one day, stumbled upon a stash of money hidden by robbers in a secret cellar, and suddenly we became very rich. Divided up, each of us got as much as six thousand dollars, all in gold. Piling up that amount of gold was quite intimidating. Then Judge Thatcher immediately took our money and lent it out at interest: as for us, every few days he gave each of us a dollar, and it went on like that all year round. Widow Douglas treated me as if I were her own son, and she took it upon herself to civilize me. But I thought living around in that house was miserable, because I had to force myself to comply with all her rules and regulations. So, when I couldn't stand it anymore, I had to figure out a way to escape. I put on my old, tattered clothes again, and took my jar of candy with me, so I set off and was free and happy once more. But somehow Tom Sawyer tracked me down and said that he was about to form a gang of robbers and could let me join, but now he advised me to go back to the widow and behave well first. So I went back again.
tr: At the end of that book, the situation was like this: Tom and I had found the money the robbers hid in the cave and had become rich. Each of us had six thousand dollars – all in gold. When you piled up the money somewhere, you couldn't take your eyes off it. Judge Thatcher took the money and invested it at interest, so we earned a dollar every day throughout the year – so much money that one wouldn't know where to spend it. Miss Douglas adopted me like her own child and thought she could make a gentleman out of me, but staying at home all the time was not easy at all, moreover, the widow was so meticulous and proper in every way that it was enough to drive a person crazy; so when I couldn't stand it any longer, I ran away. I returned to my old rags and my sugar barrel; now I was free, I was happy. But Tom Sawyer tracked me down and found me and said he was going to form a robbery gang. If I went back to the widow and became respectable, I could join too. So I went back.
es: Well, the book ends like this: Tom and I found the money that the thieves had hidden in the cave and we became rich. We each got six thousand dollars: all in gold. The truth is, it was impressive to see all that money piled up. Well, Judge Thatcher took charge of it and invested it at interest and gave us a dollar a day, all year long: so much that one wouldn't know what to spend it on. Widow Douglas adopted me as her son and said she was going to civilize me, but it was hard to live in the house all the time, because the widow was horribly normal and respectable in everything she did, so when I couldn't take it anymore, I put on my old clothes again and took my sugar skin and felt free and happy. But Tom Sawyer came looking for me and said he was going to organize a band of thieves and that I could join if I went back to the widow and was respectable. So I went back.

en: The widow she cried over me, and called me a poor lost lamb, and she called me a lot of other names, too, but she never meant no harm by it. She put me in them new clothes again, and I couldn’t do nothing but sweat and sweat, and feel all cramped up. Well, then, the old thing commenced again. The widow rung a bell for supper, and you had to come to time. When you got to the table you couldn’t go right to eating, but you had to wait for the widow to tuck down her head and grumble a little over the victuals, though there warn’t really anything the matter with them,—that is, nothing only everything was cooked by itself. In a barrel of odds and ends it is different; things get mixed up, and the juice kind of swaps around, and the things go better.
vi: The widow saw me return and burst into tears, she told me I was a poor lost bird, then called me by all sorts of strange names, but she really didn't mean any harm. She made me wear new clothes, the kind that made me sweat and feel like I was being tied up. Well, the old scenes in this house started to repeat themselves. The widow rang the bell to call for dinner, and you had to make sure to be on time. Even after sitting at the table, you couldn't eat right away, you had to wait for her to arrive and ramble on about the dishes, which really weren't worth talking about. Because the food was always the same, just leftovers mixed together and poured around some kind of sauce.
tr: When the widow saw me, she opened her arms with tears in her eyes, called me a poor lost lamb, and gave me many other names, but there was no malice in it. She dressed me in new clothes again. I sweated and sweated, and moreover, I couldn't move. Thus, our old life started again. The widow would ring a bell for dinner, and you had to be on time for the meal. When you sat at the table, you couldn't start eating right away; you had to wait for the widow to bow her head and mutter something about the meal; although there was nothing wrong with the meal. In fact, each dish was cooked separately. However, if you threw them all into one pot over the fire, it wouldn't be the same; everything would mix together, and the juices would blend with everything; that's what I call a meal.
es: The widow started crying when she saw me and told me I was a poor little lamb and called me a bunch of other things, but without any bad intention. She put the new clothes back on me and all I could do was sweat and sweat and feel tight in them. Then the same thing happened as before. The widow rang a bell at dinner time and you had to be on time. When you got to the table, you couldn't just start eating, you had to wait for the widow to bow her head and mumble something over the food, although there was nothing wrong with it; well, except that everything was cooked separately. When everything is put together, the flavors mix and the juices combine and things taste better.

en: After supper she got out her book and learned me about Moses and the Bulrushers, and I was in a sweat to find out all about him; but by-and-by she let it out that Moses had been dead a considerable long time; so then I didn’t care no more about him, because I don’t take no stock in dead people.
vi: After eating and drinking, she taught me about Moses... I thought hard but still couldn't understand who Moses was; but gradually I came to understand that Moses had been dead for a very long time. So I gave up, not bothering to care about Moses anymore, because why should I be interested in stories about dead people?
tr: After the meal, he would take out his book and teach me the story of Moses and the Reeds. I was working diligently to learn everything about Moses, but then he let slip that Moses had died quite some time ago; so I lost all interest in him, because I don't concern myself with the affairs of the dead.
es: After dinner, he would take out the book and tell me the story of Moses and the reeds, and I was eager to learn all about that story, but eventually, he let slip that Moses had been dead for many years, so I no longer cared, because I am not interested in the dead.

en: Pretty soon I wanted to smoke, and asked the widow to let me. But she wouldn’t. She said it was a mean practice and wasn’t clean, and I must try to not do it any more. That is just the way with some people. They get down on a thing when they don’t know nothing about it. Here she was a-bothering about Moses, which was no kin to her, and no use to anybody, being gone, you see, yet finding a power of fault with me for doing a thing that had some good in it. And she took snuff, too; of course that was all right, because she done it herself.
vi: Later, when I wanted to smoke, I asked the widow for permission to smoke. She absolutely refused. She said it was a bad habit and not clean, and she tried hard to persuade me to quit smoking. There are people like that, they get involved in things they know nothing about. Just like she worried about Moses, who wasn't related to her and didn't benefit anyone, since Moses had been dead for ages. Yet she still tried to make me learn from him, thinking it was very good. But she herself smoked, of course she thought it was fine, because she was the one smoking.
tr: After a while, I craved some tobacco and asked the widow for permission. She was adamant and wouldn't budge. She said it was a bad habit, that it made the surroundings dirty, and that I should make an effort to quit. Some people are just like that. They criticize what they don't understand. She was fixated on Moses, even though the man wasn't a relative or anything, he was of no use to anyone, he had passed away; yet she found all sorts of faults in me for engaging in a somewhat virtuous activity. Moreover, she herself used snuff, but of course, that was fine because she was the one doing it.
es: Then I would feel like smoking and would ask the widow for permission. But she wouldn't give it to me. She said it was an ugly and dirty habit and that I had to try to quit. That's what happens to some people. They have a grudge against things they know nothing about. As for her, she was very interested in Moses, who wasn't even a relative of hers, and who was of no use to anyone because he was already dead, right? But she thought it was very bad that I did something I liked. And besides, she took snuff; of course, that seemed fine to her because she was the one taking it.

en: Her sister, Miss Watson, a tolerable slim old maid, with goggles on, had just come to live with her, and took a set at me now with a spelling-book. She worked me middling hard for about an hour, and then the widow made her ease up. I couldn’t stood it much longer. Then for an hour it was deadly dull, and I was fidgety. Miss Watson would say, “Don’t put your feet up there, Huckleberry;” and “Don’t scrunch up like that, Huckleberry—set up straight;” and pretty soon she would say, “Don’t gap and stretch like that, Huckleberry—why don’t you try to behave?” Then she told me all about the bad place, and I said I wished I was there. She got mad then, but I didn’t mean no harm. All I wanted was to go somewheres; all I wanted was a change, I warn’t particular. She said it was wicked to say what I said; said she wouldn’t say it for the whole world; she was going to live so as to go to the good place. Well, I couldn’t see no advantage in going where she was going, so I made up my mind I wouldn’t try for it. But I never said so, because it would only make trouble, and wouldn’t do no good.
vi: Her sister, Miss Watson, was an old lady, quite thin, with white glasses, who had just come to live in the house with the widow. Now it was Miss Watson's turn to trouble me with the spelling book. She taught me with great effort, and every hour the widow would give her a break, and I couldn't endure it any longer. During that hour, I was bored to death and couldn't sit still. Miss Watson would constantly say: Huck, don't prop your feet up like that, then: Huck, don't twist around like that, sit up straight, or: Huck, don't yawn and stretch like that, why don't you sit properly? Then she said that I would end up in miserable places. I said that I wanted that, and she got really mad. But I really didn't mean to tease her. I just wanted to go somewhere, I just wanted a change, I didn't ask for anything special. She said my words were nonsense, she just wanted to live in a way that would lead to a good place. But I thought her way wasn't good, so I didn't care. But I didn't say it out loud, because I was afraid it would cause more trouble.
tr: He also had a sister, Miss Watson. Miss Watson, an elderly, never-married, very thin woman who wore huge glasses, had recently come to live with him, and this time she stood over me with a spelling book in her hand. After making me work diligently for nearly an hour, the widow told her to take a break. Otherwise, I wouldn't have been able to endure it any longer. The next hour was so stifling that I couldn't sit still anymore. Miss Watson kept saying, "Don't put your feet there, Huckleberry," and "Don't slouch, Huckleberry... sit up straight," and after a while, she started saying, "Don't yawn and stretch, Huckleberry... why don't you try to sit properly?" Then she told me everything about the bad place, and I said I wanted to be there. When I said that, she went crazy, but I didn't mean any harm. All I wanted was to go somewhere; I just wanted a change, it wasn't about going to a specific place. She said it was a sin to say that, that she would never say such a thing in this world; she intended to live in a way that she could go to the good place. Well, I couldn't see any good in going where she was going, so I decided not to bother trying for it. But I didn't say that, because it would only get me into trouble.
es: Her sister, Miss Watson, was a rather skinny spinster who wore glasses, had just come to live with her, and had gotten it into her head to teach me the alphabet. She made me work quite hard for an hour and then the widow would tell her that was enough. I couldn't stand it any longer. Then I would spend an unbearably boring hour and I would get nervous. Miss Watson would say, "Don't put your feet there, Huckleberry" and "Don't slouch like that, Huckleberry; sit up straight," and then she would say, "Don't yawn and stretch like that, Huckleberry; why don't you try to behave?" Then she would tell me all the details about the bad place and say she wished I were there. It was because she got angry, but I didn't mean to offend. All I wanted was to go somewhere, to get a change of scenery. I didn't care where. She said that what I said was bad; she said she wouldn't say it for anything in the world; she was going to live to go to the good place. Well, I didn't see any advantage in going where she was, so I decided not to even try. But I never said it because it would only create problems and it wouldn't be worth it.

en: Now she had got a start, and she went on and told me all about the good place. She said all a body would have to do there was to go around all day long with a harp and sing, forever and ever. So I didn’t think much of it. But I never said so. I asked her if she reckoned Tom Sawyer would go there, and she said not by a considerable sight. I was glad about that, because I wanted him and me to be together.
vi: She said that going to that place, people would spend all day wandering around singing. I didn't care about that either, but I didn't bother to say it. I asked her if Tom Sawyer could go to that good place, and she said he couldn't. Hearing that made me happy, because I wanted the two of us to stay together, not go anywhere.
tr: Now that he had started talking, he began to tell everything he knew about the good place. According to him, the only thing a person had to do there was to wander around all day, playing the harp and singing songs, forever, without ever stopping. So, it didn't seem like a place worth going to. But I definitely didn't express this. I asked if Tom Sawyer could go there too, and it seemed he definitely couldn't. I was happy about this because I didn't want us to ever be separated.
es: Then she would start telling me all about the good place. She said that the only thing they did there was spend the day singing with a harp, always the same thing. So it didn't seem like a big deal to me. But I didn't say anything. I asked her if she thought Tom Sawyer would go there and she said not at all, and I was glad, because I wanted to be in the same place as him.

en: Miss Watson she kept pecking at me, and it got tiresome and lonesome. By-and-by they fetched the niggers in and had prayers, and then everybody was off to bed. I went up to my room with a piece of candle, and put it on the table. Then I set down in a chair by the window and tried to think of something cheerful, but it warn’t no use. I felt so lonesome I most wished I was dead. The stars were shining, and the leaves rustled in the woods ever so mournful; and I heard an owl, away off, who-whooing about somebody that was dead, and a whippowill and a dog crying about somebody that was going to die; and the wind was trying to whisper something to me, and I couldn’t make out what it was, and so it made the cold shivers run over me. Then away out in the woods I heard that kind of a sound that a ghost makes when it wants to tell about something that’s on its mind and can’t make itself understood, and so can’t rest easy in its grave, and has to go about that way every night grieving. I got so down-hearted and scared I did wish I had some company. Pretty soon a spider went crawling up my shoulder, and I flipped it off and it lit in the candle; and before I could budge it was all shriveled up. I didn’t need anybody to tell me that that was an awful bad sign and would fetch me some bad luck, so I was scared and most shook the clothes off of me. I got up and turned around in my tracks three times and crossed my breast every time; and then I tied up a little lock of my hair with a thread to keep witches away. But I hadn’t no confidence. You do that when you’ve lost a horseshoe that you’ve found, instead of nailing it up over the door, but I hadn’t ever heard anybody say it was any way to keep off bad luck when you’d killed a spider.
vi: Miss Watson kept pestering me like that, it was really annoying, but right after that, they called the black servants in, and everyone prayed and then went to bed. I also returned to my room, carrying a candle to place on the table. I plopped down on the chair by the window, trying to think of something fun, but I couldn't think of anything. At that moment, I felt so lonely and wished that I could just die. In the sky, the stars were twinkling. The sound of rustling leaves in the forest was incredibly mournful. I heard the distant hoot of an owl as if it were calling out to someone who had passed away, then the cry of a forest bird or a dog howling about someone who was about to die, and the wind seemed to whisper something to me that I couldn't figure out what it was trying to say. Thinking that, I shivered and felt a chill run through my body. Then after a while, from the distant forest came a sound like a ghost trying to express its worries but couldn't make anyone understand; it seemed like it couldn't rest peacefully in its grave and had to wander mournfully every night like that. Thinking that made me even more terrified, and at that moment, I wished there was someone sitting next to me. Suddenly, a spider jumped onto my shoulder from somewhere, crawling on my shirt, I quickly flicked it off with my hand, and it shot straight into the burning candle, and before I could pull it out, it was dead. At that moment, I didn't need anyone to tell me that it was a bad omen and that I would face misfortune, I was already very scared and frantically shook my clothes. I jumped up, spun around three or four times, and then made the sign of the cross many times. Then I took a string and tied up my hair to make a charm to ward off evil spirits. But then I didn't believe it either. This was the custom when someone lost something, after finding it, they were supposed to tie a bow at the front door; but I had never heard anyone say that doing so would prevent bad luck after killing a spider.
tr: While Mrs. Watson was listing her advice and scoldings one after another, I felt increasingly exhausted and lonely. Soon after, they brought in the black slaves and started praying, then everyone retired to their beds. I took a candle and went to my room, placing the candle on the table. I sat on a chair by the window and tried to think of something cheerful, but it didn't work at all. I felt so utterly alone that I wished I were dead. The stars were shining brightly and the leaves in the forest were rustling mournfully, I heard an owl hooting in the distance; it was saying puuu-huuu for someone who had died; also, a whip-poor-will and a dog were howling to announce that someone nearby was going to die; the wind was trying to whisper something to me, but I couldn't understand what it was, so a cold shiver ran down my spine. Then, from the depths of the forest, I heard a sound like that made by ghosts who, unable to convey their troubles, leave their graves in despair and wander around every evening in torment. I was so demoralized and so scared that I wished someone were with me. Soon after, a spider started climbing up my shoulder, and when I flicked it, it fell onto the candle; before I could even move, it was scorched. No one needed to tell me that this was a terribly bad omen and would bring me bad luck, I started trembling like a leaf out of fear. I stood up and turned around three times, making the sign of the cross each time; then I tied a piece of string to a lock of my hair to keep the witches away. But I still didn't feel at ease. You know how when you find a horseshoe but lose it before you can nail it above the door, you do this, but I had never heard of anything you could do to ward off bad luck when you kill a spider.
es: One day Miss Watson wouldn't stop picking on me, and I started to get tired and feel lonely. Then they called the slaves to say prayers and everyone went to bed. I went to my room with a piece of candle and put it on the table. Then I sat in a chair by the window and tried to think of something cheerful, but it was useless. I felt so lonely that I almost wanted to die. The stars were shining and the leaves of the trees were rustling with a very sad sound; far away an owl was hooting because someone had died and a whippoorwill and a dog were crying that someone else was going to die, and the wind was trying to tell me something and I couldn't understand what it was, so I got chills. Then, out in the forest, I heard that noise ghosts make when they want to say something they're thinking and can't make themselves understood, so they can't rest in the grave and have to stay up all night. I felt so discouraged and scared that I wanted company. Then a spider climbed up my shoulder and I brushed it off and it fell into the candle, and before I could reach out, it was already all burned up. No one needed to tell me that this was very bad luck and that it was going to bring me misfortune, so I got scared and almost tore my clothes off. I got up and walked three circles making the sign of the cross each time, and then I tied a lock of my hair with a thread so that witches wouldn't come near me. But I wasn't sure at all. That's what you do when you've lost a horseshoe you found, instead of nailing it above the door, but I had never heard anyone say it was the way to keep bad luck away when you had killed a spider.

en: I set down again, a-shaking all over, and got out my pipe for a smoke; for the house was all as still as death now, and so the widow wouldn’t know. Well, after a long time I heard the clock away off in the town go boom—boom—boom—twelve licks; and all still again—stiller than ever. Pretty soon I heard a twig snap down in the dark amongst the trees—something was a stirring. I set still and listened. Directly I could just barely hear a “me-yow! me-yow!” down there. That was good! Says I, “me-yow! me-yow!” as soft as I could, and then I put out the light and scrambled out of the window on to the shed. Then I slipped down to the ground and crawled in among the trees, and, sure enough, there was Tom Sawyer waiting for me.
vi: I sat down on the chair again, feeling restless and uneasy. I took out a cigarette to smoke, because by now the house was as silent as death, and the widow had no idea what was going on. Then after a while, quite a long time, I heard the distant clock chime - bong - bong - bong, striking twelve times, and then everything was quieter than ever. After a moment, I suddenly heard the sound of a dry branch breaking in the dark bushes - it seemed like something was moving. I sat silently and immediately heard clearly the sound of a meow coming from that direction. Great! I softly responded with a meow, then extinguished the candle, climbed out the window, headed towards the darkness, quickly slid down to the ground, and slipped into the bushes. It was indeed Tom Sawyer waiting for me there.
tr: Shivering violently, I sat down again and took out my pipe to smoke; because now there was a deathly silence in the house, and not even the spirit of the widow would hear me smoking. Anyway, after a long time, I heard the town clock strike twelve with a tonk-tonk-tonk, and then silence fell again, the surroundings were even quieter than before. Shortly after, I heard a branch break in the darkness among the trees – something was stirring. I sat quietly and listened intently. From below, a faint “Meow! Meow!” sound was heard. That was good! I also said as quietly as possible, “Meow! Meow!”, then blew out the candle and stepped out onto the veranda through the window. Slipping down from the veranda, I started crawling among the trees and, of course, found Tom Sawyer waiting for me there.
es: I sat down again, all trembling, and took out the pipe to smoke, because the house was now quieter than a tomb, so the widow wouldn't find out. Well, after a long time I heard the town clock start to chime: boom... boom... boom... twelve strokes and everything remained just as calm, quieter than ever. Shortly after, I heard a branch snap in the darkness among the trees: something was moving. I straightened up and listened. Soon I barely heard a "meow! meow!" down there. Great! I went and said "meow! meow!" as low as I could and then turned off the light and climbed down the window to the shed. Then I dropped to the ground and crawled among the trees, and of course, there was Tom Sawyer waiting for me.

en: CHAPTER II.
vi: Chapter II
tr: Second Chapter
es: Chapter 2

en: We went tiptoeing along a path amongst the trees back towards the end of the widow’s garden, stooping down so as the branches wouldn’t scrape our heads. When we was passing by the kitchen I fell over a root and made a noise. We scrouched down and laid still. Miss Watson’s big nigger, named Jim, was setting in the kitchen door; we could see him pretty clear, because there was a light behind him. He got up and stretched his neck out about a minute, listening. Then he says:
vi: The two of us tiptoed along the small path under the trees at the corner of the widow's garden, and had to bend down to avoid hitting our heads on the branches. When passing by the kitchen door, I tripped over a tree root, making a noise. The two of us quickly lay flat on the ground, completely silent. The big black man working for Miss Watson, named Jim, was sitting at the kitchen door at that moment. We could see Jim very clearly because there was a light behind him. Hearing the noise, Jim jumped up, stuck his head out to listen for a while, then asked:
tr: We dove into a path winding to the back through the trees to exit the old lady's garden, bending low to avoid getting our heads caught in the branches, and tiptoeing to avoid making any noise. As we passed by the kitchen, I tripped over a root, making a bit of noise. We immediately crouched down and stayed completely still. Mrs. Watson's big, burly black slave named Jim was sitting on the threshold of the kitchen door; we could see him clearly because the light was shining behind him. He stood up and stretched his neck to listen around for a while. Then he called out:
es: WE TIPTOED along a path between the trees at the end of the widow's garden, bending down so the branches wouldn't hit our heads. When we passed by the kitchen, I tripped over a root and made a noise. We crouched down and stayed silent. Miss Watson's big black man, named Jim, was sitting at the kitchen door; we could see him very clearly because he had the light behind him. He stood up, stretched his neck for a minute listening, and then said:

en: “Who dah?”
vi: - Who is it?
tr: “Who is there?”
es: —Who is it?

en: He listened some more; then he come tiptoeing down and stood right between us; we could a touched him, nearly. Well, likely it was minutes and minutes that there warn’t a sound, and we all there so close together. There was a place on my ankle that got to itching, but I dasn’t scratch it; and then my ear begun to itch; and next my back, right between my shoulders. Seemed like I’d die if I couldn’t scratch. Well, I’ve noticed that thing plenty times since. If you are with the quality, or at a funeral, or trying to go to sleep when you ain’t sleepy—if you are anywheres where it won’t do for you to scratch, why you will itch all over in upwards of a thousand places. Pretty soon Jim says:
vi: Listening for a while and hearing nothing, he tiptoed down and stood right between the two of us. Just by reaching out, we could touch him. For a long time, it seemed like several minutes passed without a single sound, and the three of us were right next to each other like that. At that moment, my ankle felt itchy, then my back, right between my shoulder blades. It felt like if I couldn't scratch it at that moment, I would die. Right then, Jim spoke up:
tr: He listened a little more; then he came on tiptoe and stood right between the two of us, we could touch him if we reached out, that's how close he was. The three of us stayed there, so close together, for maybe minutes without a sound. A spot near my ankle started to itch, but I couldn't risk scratching it, then my ear started to itch; then an itch appeared right in the middle of my back, between my shoulder blades. If I didn't scratch, I would almost die right there. Such things had happened to me many times before. If you're around polite people, at a funeral, or trying to sleep even though you're not sleepy – in short, if you're in a place where it's not appropriate to scratch, thousands of places on your body start to itch. A little later, Jim called out again:
es: He stayed listening for a while; then he tiptoed out and stood between the two of us; we could almost have touched him. Well, I bet minutes and minutes passed without a sound being heard, even though we were very close together. My ankle started to itch, but I didn't dare scratch it, and then my ear started to itch, and then my back, right between my shoulders. I thought I was going to die if I didn't scratch. Since then I've noticed it many times. If you're with refined people, or at a funeral, or trying to fall asleep when you're not sleepy, if you're anywhere where it's not appropriate to scratch, then you itch all over, in more than a thousand places. And then Jim goes and says:

en: “Say, who is you? Whar is you? Dog my cats ef I didn’ hear sumf’n. Well, I know what I’s gwyne to do: I’s gwyne to set down here and listen tell I hears it agin.”
vi: - Hey, where are you? Strange, I clearly heard some noise here. Alright, I have a plan. I'll just sit here until I hear the noise again.
tr: “Who is there? Where are you? If I haven't heard anything, let me be damned. Alright, I know what to do. I'll sit here and wait to hear it again.”
es: —Hey, who is it? Where are you? May I die if I didn't hear something. Well, I know what I'm going to do: I'm going to sit here and listen to see if I hear it again.

en: So he set down on the ground betwixt me and Tom. He leaned his back up against a tree, and stretched his legs out till one of them most touched one of mine. My nose begun to itch. It itched till the tears come into my eyes. But I dasn’t scratch. Then it begun to itch on the inside. Next I got to itching underneath. I didn’t know how I was going to set still. This miserableness went on as much as six or seven minutes; but it seemed a sight longer than that. I was itching in eleven different places now. I reckoned I couldn’t stand it more’n a minute longer, but I set my teeth hard and got ready to try. Just then Jim begun to breathe heavy; next he begun to snore—and then I was pretty soon comfortable again.
vi: After saying that, he plopped right down on the ground, between me and Tom. He leaned his back against the tree trunk, stretched out his legs, and almost touched me with his feet. My nose started to itch again. That torment lasted for six or seven minutes and seemed even longer. Now, I felt itchy in a total of eleven places on my body. I thought I couldn't endure it for another minute, but I gritted my teeth and prepared to bear it. Just then, I heard Jim panting, followed by his snoring. Immediately, I felt relieved.
tr: Thus, he collapsed to the ground between Tom and me. He leaned his back against a tree and stretched his legs out so far that they almost touched one of mine. My nose started to itch. It itched so much that my eyes watered. But I couldn't muster the courage to scratch it. Then an itch started inside my nose. Next thing I knew, my lower parts were itching. I didn't know how I was going to keep still without moving. This ordeal must have lasted six or seven minutes; but it felt much longer to me. By now, eleven different parts of my body were itching. I felt like I couldn't endure another minute, but I gritted my teeth and prepared to hold on a bit longer. Just then, Jim's breathing grew heavier; then he started to snore – and with that, I scratched myself freely.
es: So he sat on the ground between Tom and me. He leaned his back against a tree and stretched his legs until one of them almost touched me. My nose started to itch. It itched so much that tears came to my eyes. But I didn't dare scratch it. Then it started to itch inside. Then below. I didn't know how to keep sitting without doing anything. That torture lasted at least six or seven minutes, but it seemed much longer. Now I was itching in eleven different places. I thought I couldn't stand it for another minute, but I gritted my teeth and prepared to try. Just then Jim started breathing very regularly, and I immediately felt comfortable again.

en: Tom he made a sign to me—kind of a little noise with his mouth—and we went creeping away on our hands and knees. When we was ten foot off Tom whispered to me, and wanted to tie Jim to the tree for fun. But I said no; he might wake and make a disturbance, and then they’d find out I warn’t in. Then Tom said he hadn’t got candles enough, and he would slip in the kitchen and get some more. I didn’t want him to try. I said Jim might wake up and come. But Tom wanted to resk it; so we slid in there and got three candles, and Tom laid five cents on the table for pay. Then we got out, and I was in a sweat to get away; but nothing would do Tom but he must crawl to where Jim was, on his hands and knees, and play something on him. I waited, and it seemed a good while, everything was so still and lonesome.
vi: Tom signaled to me and I responded by quietly clearing my throat. The two of us crawled away again. About ten steps away from there, Tom whispered in my ear that he wanted to tie Jim to a tree for fun, but I told him not to, in case Jim woke up and made a fuss, then the people in the house would know I wasn't there. Tom then said that there were no candles, and he wanted to sneak into the kitchen to get some. I didn't want him to do that, I told him that if Jim woke up and ran in, what would we do then. But Tom was determined to take the risk; so we sneaked in and grabbed three candles, then Tom left five cents on the table to pay for them. Then we stepped out, I was anxious to run away immediately, but for some reason, Tom crawled back to where Jim was, and I saw him bending over as if he was messing with something above Jim's head. I had to wait for quite a while. Everything around was still and quiet.
tr: Tom gave me a signal – he made a soft sound with his mouth – then we began to crawl away on our hands and knees. After moving three or four meters away, Tom whispered that he wanted to tie Jim to a tree for fun; but I said no; he could wake up and make a noise, and they would realize I wasn't inside. Then Tom said he didn't have enough candles with him and suggested quietly going into the kitchen to get some more. I didn't want him to attempt such a thing. I said Jim could wake up and come. But Tom wanted to take the risk; so we slipped inside and took three candles. Tom left five cents on the table for the candles. When we got outside, I wanted to get away as soon as possible, but it was impossible to stop Tom. He crawled on his hands and knees to where Jim was and did something to him. The surroundings were so quiet and deserted that it felt like I had waited for quite a long time.
es: Tom made a signal to me —a sort of little noise with his mouth— and we started crawling on all fours. When we were about ten feet away, Tom whispered to me that it would be fun to tie Jim to the tree. But I told him no; he could wake up and make a racket, and then they would see that I wasn't at home. Tom said that he didn't have enough candles and that he was going to sneak into the kitchen to get more. I didn't want him to try. I said that Jim could wake up and come in. But Tom preferred to take the risk, so we crawled in and took three candles, and Tom left five cents on the table to pay for them. Then we went out, and I was dying to leave, but Tom was determined that he had to crawl over to where Jim was and play a prank on him first. I waited and it seemed like a long time passed, with everything so quiet and so lonely.

en: As soon as Tom was back we cut along the path, around the garden fence, and by-and-by fetched up on the steep top of the hill the other side of the house. Tom said he slipped Jim’s hat off of his head and hung it on a limb right over him, and Jim stirred a little, but he didn’t wake. Afterwards Jim said the witches bewitched him and put him in a trance, and rode him all over the State, and then set him under the trees again, and hung his hat on a limb to show who done it. And next time Jim told it he said they rode him down to New Orleans; and, after that, every time he told it he spread it more and more, till by-and-by he said they rode him all over the world, and tired him most to death, and his back was all over saddle-boils. Jim was monstrous proud about it, and he got so he wouldn’t hardly notice the other niggers. Niggers would come miles to hear Jim tell about it, and he was more looked up to than any nigger in that country. Strange niggers would stand with their mouths open and look him all over, same as if he was a wonder. Niggers is always talking about witches in the dark by the kitchen fire; but whenever one was talking and letting on to know all about such things, Jim would happen in and say, “Hm! What you know ’bout witches?” and that nigger was corked up and had to take a back seat. Jim always kept that five-center piece round his neck with a string, and said it was a charm the devil give to him with his own hands, and told him he could cure anybody with it and fetch witches whenever he wanted to just by saying something to it; but he never told what it was he said to it. Niggers would come from all around there and give Jim anything they had, just for a sight of that five-center piece; but they wouldn’t touch it, because the devil had had his hands on it. Jim was most ruined for a servant, because he got stuck up on account of having seen the devil and been rode by witches.
vi: Waiting for Tom to return, we ran along the small path around the garden fence, then after a while ran up the hill on the other side of the house. Tom said he had lifted the hat off Jim's head and hung it on a branch right above where he was sleeping; Jim stirred a bit but did not wake up. Later on, Jim himself spread the story that a ghost had taken his soul, led him wandering all over the place, and another time he recounted this story, Jim said that the ghost had led him down to New Orleans. Another time, each time he retold this story, he added a bit more, gradually until he said that the ghost had taken him all over the world, making him nearly dead tired, and his back was swollen all over. Jim was very proud of this story, which made him pay less attention to the other black folks. People would travel five or six miles to hear Jim retell this ghost story, gradually in the area, Jim became more respected than the others. Black folks from afar would gape at Jim all over, considering him a wonder. Black folks often waited until night, sitting by the fire talking about ghosts and spirits; whenever someone started talking about such things and acted like they knew all about ghosts, suddenly Jim would show up and say: Huh! What do you know about ghosts? And the other person would immediately fall silent and move to the back to make room for him. Jim always had two five-cent coins tied to a string around his neck, boasting that it was a charm given to him by spirits themselves, telling him that he could use it to heal people; and that he could summon ghosts anytime, just by whispering a few words to the coins. But he never told anyone what he would say to the charm. Black folks in the area would bring anything to Jim just to see those five-cent coins. But no one dared to touch them because they feared the spirits' hands had been on them. It was truly dangerous for Jim, being a servant, to boast about having met spirits and being led around by ghosts everywhere.
tr: As soon as Tom returned, we set off, circled the garden fence, and then climbed to the steep summit of the hill on the other side of the house. Tom told me that Jim had taken off his hat and hung it on a branch right above him. Jim had stirred a little, but he hadn't woken up. Later, Jim said that witches had cast a spell on him and made him pass out. They had ridden on his back all around the State; they brought him back under the trees and hung his hat on a branch to show him who had done it. The next time, Jim said they had taken him all the way to New Orleans: In his later recountings, he said he went farther each time, and finally, he started saying they had ridden him all around the world until he was dead tired and had sores on his back. Jim was immensely proud of all that had happened, and he even looked down on the other black people because of it. Black people came from miles away to listen to Jim's story, and he had become the most respected black slave in the area. Black people who saw him for the first time stared in amazement with their mouths open, scrutinizing him from head to toe as if he were a miracle. Black people liked to talk about witches by the stove in the kitchen when it got dark, but now whenever someone started talking about it and claimed to know everything, Jim would immediately interrupt and ask, "Huh! What do you know about witches?" and that black person couldn't continue and had to back down. Jim also wore the five cents we had left him on a string around his neck and said that the devil had given it to him with his own hand. With this charm, he could heal anyone he wanted and summon witches with a single word whenever he wished; but, of course, he never said what that word was. Black people came from all around and gave Jim whatever they had just to see the five cents; but they couldn't touch it, because the devil's hand had touched it. Jim had almost become unable to serve, because he was so puffed up with pride for having seen the devil and carried witches on his back.
es: As soon as Tom returned, we started running down the path, rounded the fence, and finally reached the top of the hill on the other side of the house. Tom said he had taken Jim's hat and hung it on a branch above his head, and that Jim had moved a little but hadn't woken up. Later, Jim would say that the witches had enchanted him and put him in a trance, and that they had ridden him all over the state and then placed him back under the trees and hung his hat on a branch to show who had done it. And the next time he told it, Jim said they had taken him to New Orleans, and each time he told it, he lengthened the journey, until finally he said they had made him travel the whole world and almost killed him from exhaustion, and that his back was covered with boils. Jim was so proud that he hardly paid attention to the other blacks. There were blacks who traveled miles and miles to hear what he had to say, and they respected him more than any other black in the area. There were blacks who came from afar and stood with their mouths open, staring at him as if he were a wonder. Blacks spend their lives talking about witches in the dark, by the fireplace, but when one of them started talking and suggested that he knew a lot about these things, Jim would come and say: "Well! And what do you know about witches?" and that black was done for and had to keep quiet. Jim always wore that five-cent coin tied with a string around his neck and said it was a talisman given to him by the devil himself, telling him that he could cure anyone with it and call the witches whenever he wanted if he said some words, but he never told what he had to say. Blacks from all around would come and give Jim whatever they had, just to see that five-cent coin, but they didn't want to touch it because the devil had held it in his hands. Jim was practically no longer useful as a servant because he was too proud of having seen the devil and of the witches having ridden him.

en: Well, when Tom and me got to the edge of the hilltop we looked away down into the village and could see three or four lights twinkling, where there was sick folks, maybe; and the stars over us was sparkling ever so fine; and down by the village was the river, a whole mile broad, and awful still and grand. We went down the hill and found Jo Harper and Ben Rogers, and two or three more of the boys, hid in the old tanyard. So we unhitched a skiff and pulled down the river two mile and a half, to the big scar on the hillside, and went ashore.
vi: When Tom and I reached the hillside, looking towards the hill, we saw three or four flickering fires; perhaps someone there was ill. The late-night stars above us were still twinkling beautifully. Down there, near the village, was a river almost a mile wide, silently flowing in a terrifying manner. As we descended the hill, we saw Joe Harper, Ben Rogers, and two other boys hiding in the old tannery. We untied a small boat and then rowed downstream for more than two miles. We only went ashore when we reached a large mound on the hillside.
tr: Anyway, when Tom and I reached the top of the hill, we turned and looked at the town and saw three or four lights on. There were probably sick people around there; also, the stars were shining a tremendous light from above. The river started below the town. The river, almost two kilometers wide, was as smooth as a sheet and unbelievably magnificent. When we descended the hill, we found Jo Harper, Ben Rogers, and two or three of the other boys hiding in the old tannery. We all untied a small boat, got in, and went down the river, traveling four kilometers until we reached that big rock on the hillside, and then we went ashore again.
es: Well, when Tom and I reached the edge of the hill, we looked down from up there towards the town and saw three or four lights flickering, where there might have been sick people, and above the stars shone wonderfully, and next to the town ran the river, which was a whole mile wide and flowed grandly in silence. We came down from the hill and met up with Joe Harper and Ben Rogers and two or three more boys, who were hiding in the old tanneries. So we untied a boat and went two and a half miles down the river, where the great gap between the hills was, and disembarked.

en: We went to a clump of bushes, and Tom made everybody swear to keep the secret, and then showed them a hole in the hill, right in the thickest part of the bushes. Then we lit the candles, and crawled in on our hands and knees. We went about two hundred yards, and then the cave opened up. Tom poked about amongst the passages, and pretty soon ducked under a wall where you wouldn’t a noticed that there was a hole. We went along a narrow place and got into a kind of room, all damp and sweaty and cold, and there we stopped. Tom says:
vi: We went to a dense thicket, and Tom made us all swear to keep it a secret. Then he pointed to a hole on the hill, right at the thickest part of the thicket. We lit candles and then crawled on. After about two hundred yards, we reached the cave entrance. Tom fumbled around for a way, and then suddenly he slipped under a wall where no one would have guessed there was a hole. We squeezed through a very narrow passage and came to a place that looked like a room, damp and cold. Then everyone stopped there. Tom said:
tr: We went over to a clump of bushes, and after Tom made everyone swear to keep it a secret, he showed them the hole that went into the hill where the bushes were thickest. We lit the candles and crawled inside. After moving forward for about two hundred meters, the cave widened. After checking some passages, Tom disappeared from sight by going under a wall that didn't appear to have a hole from the outside. We also passed through a narrow passage and emerged into a very damp, airless, cool chamber and stopped. Tom began to speak:
es: We went to a thicket of bushes and Tom made everyone swear to keep the secret, and then he showed them a hole in the hill, right in the middle of the thickest part of the bushes. Then, we lit the candles and crawled in on all fours. We went about two hundred yards and then the cave opened up. Tom studied the passages and immediately went under a wall where it wasn't noticeable that there was a hole. We passed through a very narrow spot and came out into a sort of room, all damp, sweaty, and cold, and there we stopped. Then Tom goes and says:

en: “Now, we’ll start this band of robbers and call it Tom Sawyer’s Gang. Everybody that wants to join has got to take an oath, and write his name in blood.”
vi: - Now, let's start forming a gang here and call it Tom Sawyer's gang. Anyone who wants to join must swear an oath and sign their name in blood.
tr: “Alright, brother, we are now forming this gang of robbers, and we will name it Tom Sawyer's Gang. Everyone who wants to join must take an oath and write their name in blood.”
es: —Now we are going to form a band of thieves that will be called Tom Sawyer's Gang. Anyone who wants to join has to take an oath and write their name in blood.

en: Everybody was willing. So Tom got out a sheet of paper that he had wrote the oath on, and read it. It swore every boy to stick to the band, and never tell any of the secrets; and if anybody done anything to any boy in the band, whichever boy was ordered to kill that person and his family must do it, and he mustn’t eat and he mustn’t sleep till he had killed them and hacked a cross in their breasts, which was the sign of the band. And nobody that didn’t belong to the band could use that mark, and if he did he must be sued; and if he done it again he must be killed. And if anybody that belonged to the band told the secrets, he must have his throat cut, and then have his carcass burnt up and the ashes scattered all around, and his name blotted off of the list with blood and never mentioned again by the gang, but have a curse put on it and be forgot forever.
vi: Anyone who hears it will like it. Tom took out a piece of paper on which he had written the oath and read it aloud. The oath stated that all those who joined the group must remain loyal and not disclose any secrets; and if anyone harmed a member in any way, that member would be ordered to kill the offender and their entire family, and must carry out the order; and they would not be allowed to eat or sleep until they had killed them and marked their chest with a cross, which was the group's unique symbol. Anyone not in the group was not allowed to use that symbol. If someone else used it, they would be prosecuted, and if they reoffended, they would be executed. If anyone in the group disclosed a secret, they would be beheaded, their body would be burned, their name would be erased from the list with blood, and they would never be mentioned again, they would be cursed and forever forgotten.
tr: Everyone was already willing since yesterday. Tom took out the paper on which he had written the oath and began to read. According to what was written, each child would remain loyal to the gang and would not tell their secrets to anyone; if someone harmed one of the children in the gang, the child who was given the order would have to kill the person who caused the harm and their family, and it was forbidden to eat or sleep without carving the cross mark, which was the gang's symbol, on their chests after killing them all. No one who did not belong to the gang could use this cross mark; if they did, they would be sued, and if they used it again, they would have to be killed. If any member of the gang revealed the secrets, their throat would be cut, their body would be burned, and after their ashes were scattered in all directions, their name on the list would be covered in blood. No one from the gang would ever mention their name again, they would be cursed and forgotten forever.
es: Everyone wanted to. Then Tom took out a sheet of paper on which he had written the oath and read it aloud. Each of the boys swore to be loyal to the gang and never to reveal any of its secrets, and if someone did something to any boy in the gang, the boy who was ordered to kill that person and their family had to do it, and could not eat or sleep until he had killed them all and marked a cross on their chest with a knife, which was the gang's symbol. No one who did not belong to the gang could use that symbol, and if they did, they had to be reported, and if they did it again, they had to be killed. And if someone who belonged to the gang revealed the secrets, their throat had to be cut and then their body burned, the ashes scattered everywhere, and their name erased from the list with blood, and no one in the gang could ever mention their name again, as they would be cursed and had to be forgotten forever.

en: Everybody said it was a real beautiful oath, and asked Tom if he got it out of his own head. He said, some of it, but the rest was out of pirate-books and robber-books, and every gang that was high-toned had it.
vi: All of them said that such an oath was really great and asked if it was Tom himself who came up with it. He said that he thought of part of it, and the rest he took from books about robbers, and all the famous robbers did the same.
tr: Everyone said the oath was really beautiful and some asked if Tom had made it up himself. He had made up part of it, but the rest came from books about pirates and outlaws, and every distinguished gang had such an oath.
es: Everyone said it was a great oath and asked Tom if he had come up with it himself. He said that only part of it, but the rest he had taken from pirate and thief books and that all high-class gangs had an oath.

en: Some thought it would be good to kill the families of boys that told the secrets. Tom said it was a good idea, so he took a pencil and wrote it in. Then Ben Rogers says:
vi: There was another kid in the group who thought that if anyone revealed the secret, killing their entire family might be a good idea. Tom said that was a good idea, so he took out a pencil and wrote it down immediately. Ben Rogers asked:
tr: There were those who thought it would be good to also kill the families of the children who revealed the secrets. Tom said it was a good idea, took a pen, and added it immediately. Then Ben Rogers said, "But Huck Finn is also here, he has no family...
es: Some thought it would be fine to kill the families of the boys who told the secrets. Tom said it was a good idea, so he took out a pencil and wrote it down. Then Ben Rogers goes and says:

en: “Here’s Huck Finn, he hain’t got no family; what you going to do ’bout him?”
vi: - What about Huck Finn here, he doesn't have a family, so what will he do?
tr: So what are we going to do with him?" he asked.
es: —But there's Huck Finn, who has no family; what would we do with him?

en: “Well, hain’t he got a father?” says Tom Sawyer.
vi: - So, why isn't there a dad? - Tom asked.
tr: “Doesn't he have a father?” said Tom Sawyer.
es: —Well, doesn't he have a father? —asked Tom Sawyer.

en: “Yes, he’s got a father, but you can’t never find him these days. He used to lay drunk with the hogs in the tanyard, but he hain’t been seen in these parts for a year or more.”
vi: - Yes, it has a father, but currently, its father cannot be found anywhere. Its father is always drunk with the filthy people in that tannery, and for more than a year now, its father hasn't been seen around this area.
tr: “Yes, his father was around; but these days it's impossible to find him. He used to drink and pass out among the pigs at the tannery, but he hasn't been seen around here for over a year.”
es: —Yes, he has a father, but lately no one can find him. He used to always be drunk with the pigs in the tanneries, but no one has seen him for a year or more.

en: They talked it over, and they was going to rule me out, because they said every boy must have a family or somebody to kill, or else it wouldn’t be fair and square for the others. Well, nobody could think of anything to do—everybody was stumped, and set still. I was most ready to cry; but all at once I thought of a way, and so I offered them Miss Watson—they could kill her. Everybody said:
vi: They discussed for a long time and then decided to kick me out of the group. Because they said that everyone had to have a family or someone to kill, otherwise it wouldn't be fair. Then no one could think of any other way. Everyone was stumped, sitting silently. I was on the verge of tears. But then I came up with an idea, I suggested to them that we could kill Miss Watson. They exclaimed: oh Miss Watson, we can kill her.
tr: It was debated at length, they almost excluded me from the gang because they said every child should have a family or an elder to be killed. Otherwise, this condition of the oath wouldn't be fair to the others. No one could think of a solution – everyone had run out of ideas and were sitting around dejectedly. I was on the verge of tears too, but suddenly a solution came to my mind and I suggested Mrs. Watson to them – they could kill her. “Ah, of course that will do,” everyone said.
es: They continued talking about the matter, and they were going to leave me out of the gang because they said that each boy had to have a family or someone to kill, otherwise it wouldn't be fair to the others. Well, no one could think of anything to do; everyone was quiet and thoughtful. I was about to start crying, but then I quickly thought of a way out and offered Miss Watson: they could kill her. Everyone said:

en: “Oh, she’ll do. That’s all right. Huck can come in.”
vi: They exclaimed: oh Miss Watson, we can kill her. Great... Let Huck join the group.
tr: “Ah, of course that will do,” everyone said. “Alright then. Huck can join too.”
es: —Ah, great. That's very good. Huck can enter.

en: Then they all stuck a pin in their fingers to get blood to sign with, and I made my mark on the paper.
vi: Each child pricked their fingertip with a needle to draw blood and signed their name; I also wrote my name on that piece of paper.
tr: Then everyone pricked their finger with a needle to draw blood for the signature, and I also placed my mark on the paper.
es: Afterwards, everyone pricked a finger with a pin to draw blood for the signature, and I left my mark on the paper.

en: “Now,” says Ben Rogers, “what’s the line of business of this Gang?”
vi: Ben Rogers asked: - So, how are we planning to act now?
tr: “Now,” said Ben Rogers, “In which area will this gang operate?”
es: —Well —Ben Rogers goes and says—, what is this band going to do?

en: “Nothing only robbery and murder,” Tom said.
vi: - It's just about robbing and killing people - Tom replied.
tr: “Nothing, just robbery and murder,” said Tom.
es: —Nothing but thefts and murders —said Tom.

en: “But who are we going to rob?—houses, or cattle, or—”
vi: - But who should we rob now? Should we rob houses, or cattle, or...
tr: “Alright, but whom are we going to rob? The houses… the cattle… or…” "No way!
es: —But, what are we going to steal? Houses or livestock, or... —Bah!

en: “Stuff! stealing cattle and such things ain’t robbery; it’s burglary,” says Tom Sawyer. “We ain’t burglars. That ain’t no sort of style. We are highwaymen. We stop stages and carriages on the road, with masks on, and kill the people and take their watches and money.”
vi: Tom Sawyer interrupted: - Taking cattle and things like that is not robbery, it's just petty theft. We are not thieves. That's not our style. We are bandits; on the main road, we stop vehicles, wear masks, kill people, and rob passengers of their watches and money.
tr: Stealing cattle and similar things is not robbery, it's theft," said Tom Sawyer. "We are not thieves. Theft is against the code. We are highwaymen. We put on our masks, stop mail and stagecoaches, kill people and take their watches and money."
es: Stealing cattle and those things isn't real stealing; those are rustlers —says Tom Sawyer—. We are not rustlers. That's not elegant. We are highwaymen. We stop stagecoaches and carriages on the road, with masks on, and kill people and take their watches and money.

en: “Must we always kill the people?”
vi: - But is it really necessary to kill someone?
tr: "Do we always have to kill people, brother?"
es: —Do people always have to be killed?

en: “Oh, certainly. It’s best. Some authorities think different, but mostly it’s considered best to kill them—except some that you bring to the cave here, and keep them till they’re ransomed.”
vi: - Yes, there is. That's the best way. Some well-known guys think differently, but most believe that killing is better, except for those whom we bring back to this cave to hold until they are ransomed.
tr: “Of course, definitely. This is the best. Some of the experts speak otherwise; but it is generally said that the best is to kill them. However, we can bring some of them to the cave and keep them here until the ransoms we want are paid.”
es: —Well, of course. It's the best. Some authorities do not agree, but in general it is considered best to kill them all... except for a few that can be brought here to the cave and kept until they are rescued.

en: “Ransomed? What’s that?”
vi: - Redeem? What does that mean?
tr: “Ransom? What is that?”
es: —Rescued? What is that?

en: “I don’t know. But that’s what they do. I’ve seen it in books; and so of course that’s what we’ve got to do.”
vi: - I don't know either. But I see people still doing it that way. I read in a book that it says so. And of course, we have to do it that way too.
tr: "I don't know. But that's what robbers do. It's written in almost all the books.
es: —I don't know. But that's what they do. I've seen it in books, so of course that's what we have to do.

en: “But how can we do it if we don’t know what it is?”
vi: - But if I don't know what it is, how can I do it? - What?
tr: So, this is what we should do too."
es: —But how are we going to do it if we don't know what it is?

en: “Why, blame it all, we’ve got to do it. Don’t I tell you it’s in the books? Do you want to go to doing different from what’s in the books, and get things all muddled up?”
vi: Never mind, we absolutely have to do it this way. I told you that the book says so. Are you planning to do something different from what the book says? Are you planning to mess everything up?
tr: “So how will we do it if we don't know what it is?” “Ah, but you're annoying, we have to do it, didn't I tell you that's what the book says? Do you want to do things differently from what's written in the book and then mess everything up?”
es: —Well, damn it, we have to do it. Haven't I told you it's in the books? Do you want to do it differently from the books and have everything turn out wrong?

en: “Oh, that’s all very fine to say, Tom Sawyer, but how in the nation are these fellows going to be ransomed if we don’t know how to do it to them?—that’s the thing I want to get at. Now, what do you reckon it is?”
vi: - Hey Tom Sawyer, all that sounds great, but we really don't know what redeeming means. We don't know what to do with them that would be called redeeming? That's exactly what we want to understand. So, do you understand what redeeming means?
tr: “Huh, easy to say, Tom Sawyer, but can you tell me how we are going to get a ransom without knowing how to do it? That's what I'm trying to get to. Now, what do you think this ransom thing is?”
es: —Well, Tom Sawyer, that's all very well to say, but how the devil are those guys going to get rescued if we don't know how it's done? That's what I would like to know. What do you think it is?

en: “Well, I don’t know. But per’aps if we keep them till they’re ransomed, it means that we keep them till they’re dead.”
vi: - I don't know. But maybe it's like if we detain them until they are redeemed, meaning detain them until they die, right?
tr: "We said we don't know. But if we are to keep them here until the ransom is paid, it means we will keep them until they die."
es: —Well, I don't know. But maybe if we stay with them until they are rescued, it means we have to stay with them until they have died.

en: “Now, that’s something like. That’ll answer. Why couldn’t you said that before? We’ll keep them till they’re ransomed to death; and a bothersome lot they’ll be, too—eating up everything, and always trying to get loose.”
vi: - Roughly, it's like that. Isn't it done then? So why didn't you make it clear earlier? It means we will detain them until they are ransomed or until they die; oh, and there's a whole bunch of other troubles, like providing food and drink, and they always try to escape!
tr: “Now that's a meaningful statement. I can't say anything against that. Would it have killed you to say it earlier? We will keep them here until they die and their ransoms are paid… Although we will be in trouble, because they will consume everything we have and constantly try to escape.”
es: —Well, something is something, it's an answer. Why couldn't you have said it before? We keep them until they die from a rescue, and what a nuisance they are going to be: eating everything and trying to escape all the time.

en: “How you talk, Ben Rogers. How can they get loose when there’s a guard over them, ready to shoot them down if they move a peg?”
vi: - Ben Rogers, you're talking strange. How could they escape? We had our men guarding them, ready to shoot them dead at the slightest movement.
tr: “Don't talk nonsense, Ben Rogers! How would they try to escape if we posted a guard who would shoot them the moment they moved a hair?””
es: —What things you say, Ben Rogers. How are they going to escape when there's a guard watching them, ready to shoot them if they move a finger?

en: “A guard! Well, that is good. So somebody’s got to set up all night and never get any sleep, just so as to watch them. I think that’s foolishness. Why can’t a body take a club and ransom them as soon as they get here?”
vi: - There are guards? Ah, that's good. That means someone has to sit there all night to watch them and not sleep. I think that's really crazy. So why doesn't someone just grab a stick and give them a good beating as soon as they bring them here? - Why?
tr: “It means a guard. This is good. So someone will stay up all night and keep an eye on them without sleeping. I think this is foolish. Why don't we just grab a stick and release them for ransom as soon as we bring them here?”
es: —A guard! That's a good one. So someone has to sit all night without sleeping at all, just to watch over them. It seems foolish to me. Why can't we just knock them out and have them rescued as soon as we bring them?

en: “Because it ain’t in the books so—that’s why. Now, Ben Rogers, do you want to do things regular, or don’t you?—that’s the idea. Don’t you reckon that the people that made the books knows what’s the correct thing to do? Do you reckon you can learn ’em anything? Not by a good deal. No, sir, we’ll just go on and ransom them in the regular way.”
vi: Because the book doesn't mention it, that's why. Hey Ben Rogers, I'm asking you if you want to do everything by the book or not - that's all. Do you think that the person who wrote those books doesn't know what's right? Do you think you can teach people anything? No way. No, sir, you just have to do it like that and redeem them according to the rules.
tr: “Because that's not how it's written in the books... that's why. Ben Rogers, my brother, do you want to do this by the book or not? That's the issue. Do you think the people who write the books don't know what's right and what's wrong? Are you going to teach them their job? I don't think so. No, my dear, we will do it by the rules and take a ransom to release them.”
es: —Because it's not what the books say, that's why. Come on, Ben Rogers, do you want to do things right or not? That's what it's about. Don't you think the people who wrote the books know what is right to do? Do you think you're going to teach them something? Not at all. No, sir, we're going to rescue them as it's supposed to be done.

en: “All right. I don’t mind; but I say it’s a fool way, anyhow. Say, do we kill the women, too?”
vi: - Fine, I don't need it. But anyway, I still say that it's crazy. Hey, so do you guys kill women too?
tr: “Alright. It's not that big of a deal, but if you ask me, it's utter stupidity, anyway. By the way… are we going to kill the women too?”
es: —Alright. I don't care; but anyway, I say it's nonsense. Hey, should we kill the women too?

en: “Well, Ben Rogers, if I was as ignorant as you I wouldn’t let on. Kill the women? No; nobody ever saw anything in the books like that. You fetch them to the cave, and you’re always as polite as pie to them; and by-and-by they fall in love with you, and never want to go home any more.”
vi: - Hey, Ben Rogers, if I were as ignorant as you, I wouldn't talk anymore. Kill women? No, I've never seen that mentioned in any book. We take them back to the cave, and we always have to treat them very sweetly; gradually, they will fall in love with us and won't want to return home anymore.
tr: "If I were as ignorant as you, I wouldn't open my mouth so much, Ben Rogers. Killing women, huh? No; no one has ever seen anything like that written in books until now. You take them to the cave, always treat them very politely; over time, they fall in love with you and never want to go back home."
es: —Look, Ben Rogers, if I were as ignorant as you, I would try to hide it. Kill the women? No; no one has seen anything like that in the books. You bring them to the cave and treat them in the finest manner possible, and little by little they fall in love with you and no longer want to return to their homes.

en: “Well, if that’s the way I’m agreed, but I don’t take no stock in it. Mighty soon we’ll have the cave so cluttered up with women, and fellows waiting to be ransomed, that there won’t be no place for the robbers. But go ahead, I ain’t got nothing to say.”
vi: - Ah, if that's the case, then I agree; but I don't care about that matter. Because soon enough, this cave of ours will be bustling with women, with those waiting to be ransomed, and then there won't be any space left to accommodate our gang of thieves. But anyway, just go on, I won't ask anything else.
tr: “If that's the case, it's fine by me, but I still wouldn't trust its accuracy if I were you. In a short time, the cave would be filled with women and men waiting for their ransom to be paid, leaving no room for the robbers. But go ahead, continue, I have nothing more to say.”
es: —Well, if that's the case, I agree, but it doesn't tell me much either. Soon we will have the cave so full of women and guys waiting to be rescued that there won't be any room left for the thieves. But go ahead, I have nothing to say.

en: Little Tommy Barnes was asleep now, and when they waked him up he was scared, and cried, and said he wanted to go home to his ma, and didn’t want to be a robber any more.
vi: Little Tommy Barnes, being young, had fallen fast asleep earlier, and when the group woke him up, he burst into tears out of fear, wanting to go home to his mother, and said he didn't want to be a robber anymore.
tr: Little Tommy Barnes had fallen asleep, and when they woke him up, he got scared, started crying, said he missed his home and his mother, and that he no longer wanted to be a robber.
es: Little Tommy Barnes had already fallen asleep, and when they woke him up, he was scared, started crying, and said he wanted to go back home to his mom and that he didn't want to be a bandit anymore.

en: So they all made fun of him, and called him cry-baby, and that made him mad, and he said he would go straight and tell all the secrets. But Tom give him five cents to keep quiet, and said we would all go home and meet next week, and rob somebody and kill some people.
vi: The whole group saw this and teased him even more, calling him a crybaby, which made him furious and he said he would quit immediately and reveal all the secrets. But Tom gave him five cents to keep quiet, then told everyone to go home and meet again next week, when they would rob or kill someone.
tr: Everyone made fun of him, calling him a crybaby. Upon this, he got very angry and immediately said he would go and reveal all the secrets. But Tom gave him five cents to keep quiet and said that we would all go home now, and next week we would meet again to rob someone and kill a few people.
es: So everyone laughed at him a lot, and when they called him a crybaby, he got angry and said he was going to tell all the secrets. But Tom went and gave him five cents to keep quiet and said that we were all going home and would meet next week to rob someone and kill some people.

en: Ben Rogers said he couldn’t get out much, only Sundays, and so he wanted to begin next Sunday; but all the boys said it would be wicked to do it on Sunday, and that settled the thing. They agreed to get together and fix a day as soon as they could, and then we elected Tom Sawyer first captain and Jo Harper second captain of the Gang, and so started home.
vi: Ben Rogers said that he wasn't allowed to leave the house except on Sundays, so he wanted to start the next Sunday. But the group said that if they did it on Sunday, they would be punished by the spirits. So that was a no-go. Then the group agreed to decide on a date as soon as they could meet again. Then, they elected Tom Sawyer as the first commander of the group, and Joe Harper as the second commander. After that, the group went home.
tr: Ben Rogers said that he couldn't go out very often, but he was available on Sundays. Therefore, he wanted us to start next Sunday; but when the other children reminded him that doing such things on Sunday was a sin, that idea was also abandoned. They decided to get together at the first opportunity to set a date, then we set off home after electing Tom Sawyer as the captain of the gang and Jo Harper as the second captain.
es: Ben Rogers said he couldn't go out much, only on Sundays, so he wanted to start next Sunday; but all the boys said it would be very bad to do it on Sunday, and the discussion ended. They decided to meet to determine the date as soon as they could and then we chose Tom Sawyer as first captain and Joe Harper as second captain of the band and went home.

en: I clumb up the shed and crept into my window just before day was breaking. My new clothes was all greased up and clayey, and I was dog-tired.
vi: I climbed over the roof of the stable and slipped through the window just as dawn was breaking. My new clothes were covered in filthy dirt, and I was out of breath.
tr: Just before dawn, I climbed up the veranda and slipped inside through the window. My brand-new clothes were covered in oil and mud, and I was utterly exhausted.
es: I crawled up the shed to my window just before dawn. My new clothes were all covered in mud stains, and I was as tired as a dog.

en: CHAPTER III.
vi: Chapter III
tr: Chapter Three
es: Chapter 3
