en: “They lie—that’s how.”
vi: - They are lying, there's no such thing.
tr: “Liars… they are lying.”
es: —It's a lie... that's how it happened.

en: “Looky here—mind how you talk to me; I’m a-standing about all I can stand now—so don’t gimme no sass. I’ve been in town two days, and I hain’t heard nothing but about you bein’ rich. I heard about it away down the river, too. That’s why I come. You git me that money to-morrow—I want it.”
vi: - Hey, watch your mouth when you talk to me. Everything I could have done, I always dared to do, so don't try to deceive me. I've been out of town for the past two days. Even down by the river, people were saying the same thing. That's why I came here. Tomorrow, you have to give me that money; I need it.
tr: “Look at me… speak to me properly. I'm already at the end of my patience, I don't want any nonsense. I've been in town for two days and everyone is talking about your wealth. I heard the story all the way down by the river. That's why I came. Tomorrow, you will give me that money…
es: —Look, be careful how you talk to me. I've been tolerating you too much already, so don't get insolent. I've been in the village for two days and the only thing everyone has told me is that you're rich. And I've also heard it said by the river. That's why I came. Tomorrow you bring me that money: I want it.

en: “I hain’t got no money.”
vi: - I don't have any money
tr: All of it.” "I have no money."
es: —I don't have any money.

en: “It’s a lie. Judge Thatcher’s got it. You git it. I want it.”
vi: - Speak, old man. Judge Thatcher took that money. You have it. I need that money.
tr: “Liar. It's with Judge Thatcher. You will go and get it. You will give it all to me.”
es: —Liar. Judge Thatcher has it. Yes, you have it. And I want it.

en: “I hain’t got no money, I tell you. You ask Judge Thatcher; he’ll tell you the same.”
vi: - I'm telling the truth, I don't have any money. Just go ask Judge Thatcher, he will tell you the same thing.
tr: “I told you, I have no money at all. Go ask Judge Thatcher; he’ll tell you the same.”
es: —I don't have any money. I'm telling you. Ask Judge Thatcher and he'll tell you the same.

en: “All right. I’ll ask him; and I’ll make him pungle, too, or I’ll know the reason why. Say, how much you got in your pocket? I want it.”
vi: - Okay, then I'll ask him, I'll talk to him to see what's going on. Hey, how much do you have in your pocket right now? Give it to me, I need it.
tr: “Alright then, I'll go and ask. Then I'll tell them to take it all apart, and if they can't, I'll understand why. How much money do you have in your pocket now? Give it all to me.”
es: —Very well. I'm going to ask him and make him cough up, and if not, I'll find out why. Hey, how much do you have in your pocket? Give it to me.

en: “I hain’t got only a dollar, and I want that to—”
vi: - I only have one dollar. I was planning to...
tr: “But I only have one dollar; I was going to do something with it…””
es: —I only have a dollar and I want it for...

en: “It don’t make no difference what you want it for—you just shell it out.”
vi: - Whatever you intend to do, I don't care, I don't need to know, just hand it over.
tr: “What you will do is none of my business... go ahead, spill it.”
es: —It doesn't matter what you want it for... Just give it to me and that's it.

en: He took it and bit it to see if it was good, and then he said he was going down town to get some whisky; said he hadn’t had a drink all day. When he had got out on the shed he put his head in again, and cussed me for putting on frills and trying to be better than him; and when I reckoned he was gone he come back and put his head in again, and told me to mind about that school, because he was going to lay for me and lick me if I didn’t drop that.
vi: He immediately grabbed the coin and bit it to see if it was good; then he said he was going downtown to get some whiskey, claiming he hadn't had a drop all day. As he stepped out into the darkness, he turned back and warned me not to act like I was better than him. When I thought he was gone, he came back, stuck his head in, and warned me to be careful with that school, or he would come and give me a beating if I didn't quit.
tr: He took the dollar and bit the edge to see if it was real. Then he said he would go to town to buy some whiskey, as he hadn't had a drop all day. After stepping out onto the veranda from the window, he poked his head back inside and blamed me for my airs and graces and for trying to be superior to him. Just when I thought he had left, his head appeared in the window again, and he warned me to drop out of school, or else he would corner me and beat me until the cows came home.
es: I gave it to him and he bit it to see if it was good, and then he said he was going to the town center to have a whiskey; that he hadn't drunk all day. When he went out to the shed, he stuck his head back through the window and cursed me for having airs and trying to be better than him, and when I thought he had already left, he stuck his head back through the window and told me to be careful with that school, because he would be very watchful and would thrash me if I didn't stop going.

en: Next day he was drunk, and he went to Judge Thatcher’s and bullyragged him, and tried to make him give up the money; but he couldn’t, and then he swore he’d make the law force him.
vi: The next day, he was completely drunk, stumbled to old chief Thatcher's house, intending to force him to hand over all the money. But it was useless; then he swore he would bring the old chief to justice.
tr: The next day, with a drunken mind, he went to Judge Thatcher's door and tried to scare him into giving the money, and when that didn't work, he swore he would sue him.
es: The next day he was drunk and went to see Judge Thatcher, to bother him trying to get him to give him the money, but he didn't succeed, and then he swore he was going to make the law force him.

en: The judge and the widow went to law to get the court to take me away from him and let one of them be my guardian; but it was a new judge that had just come, and he didn’t know the old man; so he said courts mustn’t interfere and separate families if they could help it; said he’d druther not take a child away from its father. So Judge Thatcher and the widow had to quit on the business.
vi: The village chief and the widow went to court to get me out of my father's hands and to have the court assign one of them as my guardian. But there was a new judge who had just arrived, who didn't know what kind of person my father was, and said that the court had no right to interfere in separating families, but rather should reunite them, and certainly couldn't force a child to be away from their father. So, the village chief Thatcher and the widow had to give up.
tr: The judge and the widow lady applied to the court to rescue me from him and to appoint one of them as my legal guardian; but at that time a new judge had been appointed and he did not know my father: Therefore, he said that it was not right for the courts to intervene and separate families unless absolutely necessary. He did not want to deprive a child of his father. Judge Thatcher and the widow lady had to reluctantly give up on this matter.
es: The judge and the widow went to court to have the custody taken away and for one of them to become my guardian, but a new judge had arrived and he didn't know my old one, so he said that the courts should not intervene to separate families if they could avoid it; he said he preferred not to separate a child from his father. So Judge Thatcher and the widow had to give up the matter.

en: That pleased the old man till he couldn’t rest. He said he’d cowhide me till I was black and blue if I didn’t raise some money for him. I borrowed three dollars from Judge Thatcher, and pap took it and got drunk, and went a-blowing around and cussing and whooping and carrying on; and he kept it up all over town, with a tin pan, till most midnight; then they jailed him, and next day they had him before court, and jailed him again for a week. But he said he was satisfied; said he was boss of his son, and he’d make it warm for him.
vi: That made my father so delighted that he couldn't sit still. He said he would beat me black and blue if I didn't give him the money. I borrowed three dollars from old Judge Thatcher and gave it to him, and he went off to get drunk; then he wandered around town, talking nonsense and causing trouble everywhere; carrying an iron pot and roaming until midnight. Then they arrested him and put him in jail for a week. But he said that it was all worth it; he was very pleased because he had asserted his authority over me.
tr: Our old man couldn't stay still from excitement. He said that if I didn't give him money, he would beat me until I was bruised all over. I borrowed three dollars from Judge Thatcher. My father took the money and immediately started drinking heavily, then began wandering around town, shouting and cursing. He grabbed a pan and clanged it around almost until midnight. They locked him up; the next day he went to court and got a week's sentence. But he was very pleased with himself; he was saying that he could now control his son and that he would make his life miserable from now on.
es: The old man was happier than a clam. He said he was going to keep beating me until I was covered in bruises if I didn't get him some money. I borrowed three dollars from Judge Thatcher, and father took them, got drunk, and caused a ruckus everywhere with his swearing, shouting, and scandals, and he kept at it throughout the town, banging on a pan until almost midnight; then they jailed him and the next day took him to court and put him back in jail for a week. But he said he was happy, that he was the one in charge of his son, and that he would settle the score with me.

en: When he got out the new judge said he was a-going to make a man of him. So he took him to his own house, and dressed him up clean and nice, and had him to breakfast and dinner and supper with the family, and was just old pie to him, so to speak. And after supper he talked to him about temperance and such things till the old man cried, and said he’d been a fool, and fooled away his life; but now he was a-going to turn over a new leaf and be a man nobody wouldn’t be ashamed of, and he hoped the judge would help him and not look down on him. The judge said he could hug him for them words; so he cried, and his wife she cried again; pap said he’d been a man that had always been misunderstood before, and the judge said he believed it. The old man said that what a man wanted that was down was sympathy, and the judge said it was so; so they cried again. And when it was bedtime the old man rose up and held out his hand, and says:
vi: When he got out of prison, the new judge who had just been transferred said he would teach my father to become a proper person. The judge took my father to his private home, dressed him in clean, beautiful clothes. Morning, noon, and evening, he let my father eat with his family, treating him very kindly. Something like that. After dinner, the judge sat and talked to my father about how to live properly in various ways, to the point that my father cried, saying he had been foolish and had ruined his life. My father promised that from now on he would change his behavior and become a person that no one would be ashamed of anymore. He also hoped that the judge would help him and not despise him. The judge said that hearing such words from my father was truly heartening. So both the judge and his wife cried too. My father said that he had always been misunderstood. The judge said he also believed that was the case. My father then said that what a person needs deep in their heart is affection. The judge said: exactly. So both sides cried again. When it was time to go to bed, my father stood up, spread his arms, and said:
tr: After getting out of prison, the new judge said he would straighten him out. He took my father into his own home, dressed him up in fine clothes, and, as the saying goes, treated him like an old friend, giving him breakfast, lunch, and dinner at his family's table. After dinner, he gave such a speech to make him quit drinking that our old man burst into tears, saying he had been foolish until then and had wasted his life; now he would turn over a new leaf and become a man no one would be ashamed of, and he hoped the judge would help him and not look down on him. When the judge heard these words, he almost wanted to embrace him. He too started crying, and his wife also burst into tears. My father said he had always been misunderstood until that day, and the judge said he believed him. Our old man said all he wanted was to be shown empathy; the judge agreed with him, and they started crying again. When it was time to go to bed, our old man stood up, extended his hand to them, and said:
es: When he left, the new judge said he was going to turn him into another man. So he took him to his house, gave him good and clean clothes, and invited him to have breakfast, lunch, and dinner with the family, and he behaved like a brother to him, so to speak. And after dinner, he talked to him about temperance and things like that until the old man started to cry and said he had been an idiot and had wasted his life on foolishness, but now he was going to change completely and be a man that no one would be ashamed of, and he hoped the judge would help him and not despise him. The judge said that made him want to hug him, and even he and his wife started to cry; father said he had been a man whom no one had understood until then, and the judge said he believed it. The old man said that what a fallen man needed was solidarity, and the judge said that was true; so they started crying again. And when it was time to go to bed, the old man got up, extended his hand, and said:

en: “Look at it, gentlemen and ladies all; take a-hold of it; shake it. There’s a hand that was the hand of a hog; but it ain’t so no more; it’s the hand of a man that’s started in on a new life, and’ll die before he’ll go back. You mark them words—don’t forget I said them. It’s a clean hand now; shake it—don’t be afeard.”
vi: - Here, ladies and gentlemen, look at me. Please take my hand and let me shake hands with you. This is a hand that used to be like a pig's hoof; but now it is not anymore; this is the hand of a person who has started to step into a new life. If I ever go back to the old ways, I would rather die. Ladies and gentlemen, please remember these words well, and do not forget that it was I who said them. Now this is a clean hand, so please shake hands without fear.
tr: “Take a good look at this hand, gentlemen and ladies. Hold this hand. Squeeze this hand. The owner of this hand used to be a swine, but not anymore; now it's the hand of a man starting a new life, the hand of someone who would rather die than go back. Listen carefully to my words… always remember that I said these things. This is now a clean hand; squeeze this hand… don't be afraid.”
es: —Look at it, ladies and gentlemen; take it in yours, give them yours. This hand used to be a pig's, but it is no longer; it is the hand of a man who has started a new life and who will die before returning to the old one. Remember these words: do not forget that I have said them. Now it is a clean hand; give me yours, do not be afraid.

en: So they shook it, one after the other, all around, and cried. The judge’s wife she kissed it. Then the old man he signed a pledge—made his mark. The judge said it was the holiest time on record, or something like that. Then they tucked the old man into a beautiful room, which was the spare room, and in the night some time he got powerful thirsty and clumb out on to the porch-roof and slid down a stanchion and traded his new coat for a jug of forty-rod, and clumb back again and had a good old time; and towards daylight he crawled out again, drunk as a fiddler, and rolled off the porch and broke his left arm in two places, and was most froze to death when somebody found him after sun-up. And when they come to look at that spare room they had to take soundings before they could navigate it.
vi: One by one, people came to shake hands, and then everyone cried. The judge's wife even bent down to kiss that hand. Then my father made a solemn vow. The judge said that it was truly the most sacred moment, or almost so. Then they took my father to a splendid room, which was a private room. At night, when my father was extremely thirsty, he climbed over the gate roof, clung to a column, slid down to the ground, took the coat they had just given him to exchange for a bottle of liquor, then climbed back to the room and drank to his heart's content until dawn, when he crawled out, drunk, crashing into the gate so hard that his left hand got injured in several places. In the morning, when someone found him, he was nearly frozen to death. When everyone entered that private room, they saw that the furniture was all in disarray.
tr: Thus, crying, he shook hands with each one of them. The judge's wife even took his hand and kissed it. Then our old man had a contract written up and signed it. The judge said something about it being the most sacred moment up to that day. They placed our father in a very nice room where no one else stayed. After everyone went to bed, he couldn't stand the thirst, climbed out the window onto the veranda roof, slid down a support beam, and sold his jacket for a bottle of the hardest liquor. Then he climbed back into the room and had a grand old time. In the early morning, unable to see an inch in front of him, he climbed out the window again, rolled off the veranda roof, fell, and broke his left arm in two places. When someone found him after the sun had risen, he was on the verge of freezing to death. When they went up to the room where he had been sleeping, they struggled to make sense of the damage he had caused.
es: So everyone shook his hand, one after another, and cried. The judge's wife kissed it. Then the old man signed a promise: he made his mark. The judge said it was the most sacred moment he could remember, or something like that. Then they made the old man lie down in a very nice room, which was the guest room, and that same night, a while later, he got very thirsty and climbed down the porch roof, down one of the columns, and traded his new jacket for a jug of rat poison whiskey and went back to the room and had a great time, and towards dawn he went out again, drunk as a skunk, and rolled down the porch roof and broke his left arm in two places, and had almost frozen to death when someone found him after the sun came up. And when they went in to see what was in that guest room, they had to find a pilot to show them the way.

en: The judge he felt kind of sore. He said he reckoned a body could reform the old man with a shotgun, maybe, but he didn’t know no other way.
vi: The chief judge was very sad. He said that perhaps only a gunshot could help my father change his ways, as there was no other way.
tr: The judge was furious. He said that our old man could only be reformed at gunpoint, that no other way was possible.
es: The judge felt a bit bitter. He said that he figured someone might be able to reform the old man with a shotgun, maybe, but that he didn't know any other way.

en: CHAPTER VI.
vi: Chapter VI
tr: Chapter Six
es: Chapter 6

en: Well, pretty soon the old man was up and around again, and then he went for Judge Thatcher in the courts to make him give up that money, and he went for me, too, for not stopping school. He catched me a couple of times and thrashed me, but I went to school just the same, and dodged him or outrun him most of the time. I didn’t want to go to school much before, but I reckoned I’d go now to spite pap. That law trial was a slow business—appeared like they warn’t ever going to get started on it; so every now and then I’d borrow two or three dollars off of the judge for him, to keep from getting a cowhiding. Every time he got money he got drunk; and every time he got drunk he raised Cain around town; and every time he raised Cain he got jailed. He was just suited—this kind of thing was right in his line.
vi: Then, right after that, my father got up again, walked around, went to Mr. Thatcher's house to make him return the money, and then came to me asking why I hadn't quit school yet. He held onto me for a long time and beat me. But I still kept going to school as usual. All day long, I had to avoid him and run away. Before, I didn't really want to go to school, but now I thought I had to go to school to show my father. The legal proceedings were so slow. It seemed like they hadn't even started yet. Occasionally, I had to borrow a few dollars from Mr. Thatcher to give to my father to avoid being beaten. Every time he had money, he would get drunk, and every time he got drunk, he would cause trouble in town, and every time he caused trouble, he would end up in jail. It became a habit, a routine.
tr: Before long, our father recovered and started wandering around. He filed a lawsuit against Judge Thatcher to get the money, and because I didn't stop going to school, he started chasing after me. He caught me a few times and beat me terribly, but I continued going to school and mostly either stayed out of his sight or lost him by running faster. Actually, I didn't really want to go to school before, but I guess I started going just to spite my father. The court was progressing quite slowly, and as far as I could tell, it hadn't even started yet. So, to avoid getting beaten by my father, I occasionally borrowed two or three dollars from the judge for him. As soon as he got his hands on some money, he would drink like a fish, and every time he drank, he would cause a commotion in the town. Naturally, they would throw him in jail every time. He was living a life that suited him perfectly; this behavior was just his style.
es: WELL, the old man soon recovered and then he got involved with Judge Thatcher in the courts to force him to give him that money, and then with me for not stopping going to school. He grabbed me a couple of times and thrashed me, but anyway I kept going to school and most of the time I either hid from him or outran him. Before, I didn't have much desire to go to school. But now I thought I would go just to spite my father. The lawsuit was going very slowly: it seemed like it was never going to start; so from time to time I borrowed two or three dollars from the judge to give to him and avoid a beating. Every time he had money he got drunk, and every time he got drunk he caused a commotion in town, and every time he caused a commotion they put him in jail. And he was so happy: that kind of life was what he liked.

en: He got to hanging around the widow’s too much and so she told him at last that if he didn’t quit using around there she would make trouble for him. Well, wasn’t he mad? He said he would show who was Huck Finn’s boss. So he watched out for me one day in the spring, and catched me, and took me up the river about three mile in a skiff, and crossed over to the Illinois shore where it was woody and there warn’t no houses but an old log hut in a place where the timber was so thick you couldn’t find it if you didn’t know where it was.
vi: My father kept hanging around the widow, and the widow said if he didn't go find food somewhere else, she would make trouble for him. Well, I don't know if he's crazy or not; he even said he would show everyone who has the right to know who has authority over Huck Finn. Then one spring day, he somehow caught me, took me down to a boat, and went upriver about three miles; then rowed up to the Illinois shore, in a place with dense trees, where there wasn't a single house except an old cabin hidden by thick foliage, and anyone who didn't know the place wouldn't be able to find it.
tr: He started hanging around the widow a lot. Finally, the widow told him that if he showed up again, he would be in big trouble. Upon hearing this, he went completely mad. He said he would show him who Huck Finn's boss was. One day in spring, he set a trap by the creek and caught me, put me in a boat, and took me about three miles up the river. From there, he took me across to the Illinois side of the river. This side was forested and had nothing but an old wooden cabin. The trees were so dense that it was impossible to find the cabin without knowing its exact location.
es: He started spending too much time hanging around the widow's house, so she finally told him that if he didn't stop hanging around there, he was going to get into some trouble. Man, did he get mad. He said he was going to show who was in charge of Huck Finn. So one day he waited for me at the spring, grabbed me, and took me three miles upriver in a boat and crossed over to the Illinois side, where there were forests and no houses except for an old log cabin in a place with so many trees that you couldn't find it unless you already knew the way.

en: He kept me with him all the time, and I never got a chance to run off. We lived in that old cabin, and he always locked the door and put the key under his head nights. He had a gun which he had stole, I reckon, and we fished and hunted, and that was what we lived on. Every little while he locked me in and went down to the store, three miles, to the ferry, and traded fish and game for whisky, and fetched it home and got drunk and had a good time, and licked me. The widow she found out where I was by-and-by, and she sent a man over to try to get hold of me; but pap drove him off with the gun, and it warn’t long after that till I was used to being where I was, and liked it—all but the cowhide part.
vi: Day and night, he kept me close by his side, I had no way to escape to go to school. So the two of them lived in that hut. My father locked the door all day; at night he kept the key at the head of his bed. He had a gun that I guessed he had stolen from somewhere. The two of them went fishing and hunting, living like that day after day. Occasionally, he would lock the door, trapping me inside, then go down to a store three miles away, at the ferry to trade birds and fish for whiskey, come back drunk at night, and beat me. Later, the widow found out where I was, and sent someone to spy and take me back. But my father chased them away with his gun. Living like that for a while, I got used to the place and even came to like it. I liked everything except for the beatings.
tr: Since he never let me out of his sight, I never had a chance to escape even once. We were living in that old cabin, and at night he always locked the door and put the key under his pillow. Somehow, he had managed to steal a rifle. We were getting by through hunting and fishing there. From time to time, he would lock me inside, jump into the boat, and go to a store three miles down to trade the fish he caught or the animals he hunted for whiskey. When he came back home, he would drink and get drunk, then beat me. The widow eventually found out where I was and sent a man to bring me back, but my father chased him away with a gun. Before long, I got used to the place and even started to like life there, except for the frequent beatings.
es: He always took me with him and I never had the chance to escape. We lived in that cabin and he always locked the door; at night, he would go to bed with the key under his pillow. He had a shotgun that I think he had stolen and he would take me fishing and hunting, which is what we lived on. From time to time he would leave me locked up and go to the store, which was three miles away, where the ferry passed, and he would trade fish and game for whiskey, and he would bring it home and get drunk, have a great time, and give me a beating. The widow found out where I was and after a while sent a man to try to take me away, but father chased him off with the shotgun and it didn't take long for me to get used to being where I was, and I liked it... except for the beatings part.

en: It was kind of lazy and jolly, laying off comfortable all day, smoking and fishing, and no books nor study. Two months or more run along, and my clothes got to be all rags and dirt, and I didn’t see how I’d ever got to like it so well at the widow’s, where you had to wash, and eat on a plate, and comb up, and go to bed and get up regular, and be forever bothering over a book, and have old Miss Watson pecking at you all the time. I didn’t want to go back no more. I had stopped cussing, because the widow didn’t like it; but now I took to it again because pap hadn’t no objections. It was pretty good times up in the woods there, take it all around.
vi: It was a kind of laziness that was quite pleasant. All day long, just relaxing, smoking, fishing, no books and no studying at all. About two months later, my clothes were dirty and tattered. I didn't think that when I was living with the widow, I ever liked it as much as this. Because there, I had to wash clothes. I had to eat with bowls and plates, comb my hair, go to bed and get up on time, always worry about books and notebooks, and listen to Miss Watson's nagging all day long. I didn't feel like going back to that place anymore. Before, I had stopped using bad language because the widow didn't like it. But now, I started again because my father didn't forbid it at all. Living in the forest was truly enjoyable, everywhere was just as delightful.
tr: Spending the whole day smoking tobacco and fishing, lying around without studying at all, both made a person lazy and brought them joy. After about two months, all the clothes I had on turned into filthy rags. I no longer knew why I loved the widow's house so much, where I constantly washed, ate from a plate, combed my hair, went to bed and got up on time, constantly dealt with books, and was always scolded by our Miss Watson. I didn't want to go back. I had stopped swearing because the widow didn't like it, but I had started again since my father didn't object. To be honest, I was having quite a good time in the forest.
es: Everything was very peaceful and it was enjoyable, lying around all day, smoking and fishing, without books or studies. Two months or more passed and all my clothes became tattered and dirty, and I didn't understand how I had liked being at the widow's house, where you had to wash yourself and eat from a plate and comb your hair and go to bed and get up at fixed times and spend your life with a boring book while old Miss Watson was always nagging at you. I no longer wanted to go back. I had stopped cursing because the widow didn't like it, but now I started cursing again because father didn't see anything wrong with it. All things considered, I had a pretty good time there in the forest.

en: But by-and-by pap got too handy with his hick’ry, and I couldn’t stand it. I was all over welts. He got to going away so much, too, and locking me in. Once he locked me in and was gone three days. It was dreadful lonesome. I judged he had got drownded, and I wasn’t ever going to get out any more. I was scared. I made up my mind I would fix up some way to leave there. I had tried to get out of that cabin many a time, but I couldn’t find no way. There warn’t a window to it big enough for a dog to get through. I couldn’t get up the chimbly; it was too narrow. The door was thick, solid oak slabs. Pap was pretty careful not to leave a knife or anything in the cabin when he was away; I reckon I had hunted the place over as much as a hundred times; well, I was most all the time at it, because it was about the only way to put in the time. But this time I found something at last; I found an old rusty wood-saw without any handle; it was laid in between a rafter and the clapboards of the roof. I greased it up and went to work. There was an old horse-blanket nailed against the logs at the far end of the cabin behind the table, to keep the wind from blowing through the chinks and putting the candle out. I got under the table and raised the blanket, and went to work to saw a section of the big bottom log out—big enough to let me through. Well, it was a good long job, but I was getting towards the end of it when I heard pap’s gun in the woods. I got rid of the signs of my work, and dropped the blanket and hid my saw, and pretty soon pap come in.
vi: But gradually, when my father became too familiar with this forest, I began to feel that I couldn't stand it anymore. I kept getting beaten all the time. He often went far away and locked me in the house. Once, he locked the door and kept me inside for three whole days. I felt terribly lonely. I thought that if he drowned somewhere, I would be stuck here, unable to get out. I was so scared and thought to myself that I definitely had to find a way to escape. I had tried several times but failed. There wasn't a single window big enough for a dog to squeeze through. The chimney was also too narrow to crawl through. The door was thick, made entirely of very sturdy ebony planks. My father was careful not to leave a knife or any other object in the house whenever he went away. I figured I had searched the house hundreds of times, always thinking of ways to escape, and spent all my time on that, but it was still to no avail. But this time, I found something. I found an old, rusty saw blade without a handle, wedged under the roof crevice. I cleaned it and started working. There was a piece of felt used to pad the saddle, nailed to the crumbling part of the wall in the corner of the house, right behind the table, to block the wind from blowing through the gaps and extinguishing the lamp. I crawled under the table, lifted the piece of felt, and sawed a hole just big enough for me to squeeze through. It was quite a time-consuming task, but I tried my best to see it through. In the midst of it, I heard my father's gunshot in the forest. I erased all traces, let the felt fall back down, and hid the saw. Just as I finished, my father stepped in.
tr: But after a while, my father increased the beatings so much that I couldn't bear it anymore. Every part of my body was covered in bruises and wounds. Moreover, he frequently left, locking me inside. Once, he locked the door and didn't come back for three days. I felt terribly lonely. I thought he had drowned somewhere and that I would never be able to get out. I was very scared. I decided to find a way to escape from there. Previously, I had tried very hard to get out of the cabin but couldn't find a way. The windows were so small that even a dog couldn't fit through. I tried the chimney, but it was too narrow as well. The door was made of thick oak planks. My father was careful not to leave any knives or such in the house when he was outside. I searched every corner of the cabin maybe a hundred times. In fact, I had no other job than to explore the surroundings, because it was the only way to pass the time. But this time, I finally managed to find something. It was a rusty, handleless saw wedged between the roof beam and the ceiling planks. I oiled the saw and started working. There was an old horse blanket nailed to the wood behind the table at the back of the cabin to prevent the wind from blowing out the candle through the cracks in the wall. I crawled under the table, lifted the edge of the blanket, and started working to cut the lowest log to create a hole big enough for me to pass through. This took quite a long time, but I was about to finish when I heard my father's gunshot in the forest. I immediately cleaned up the sawdust around, hung the blanket back in place, and hid my saw. Soon after, my father appeared at the door.
es: But little by little, father started to get too fond of beating me, and I couldn't take it anymore. I was covered in bruises. He also started spending a lot of time away, and he would leave me locked up. Once he locked me up and disappeared for three whole days. I felt horribly alone. I thought he had drowned and that I would never get out of there again. I was scared. I decided to find a way to leave. I had tried to leave that cabin many times, but I couldn't find a way. There wasn't a window big enough for even a dog to get through. I couldn't go out through the chimney because it was too narrow. The door was thick, made of solid oak planks. Father was very careful and never left a knife or anything in the cabin when he left; I suppose I had searched around there at least a hundred times; well, the truth was that I spent all my time looking, because it was the only way to keep myself entertained. But once, I finally found something; I found an old rusty saw without a handle; it was stuck between a beam and the tiles above. I cleaned it and got to work. There was a horse blanket nailed to the logs at one end of the cabin, behind the table, so the wind wouldn't come through the cracks and blow out the candle. I got under the table, lifted the blanket, and started sawing a section of the big log below, big enough for me to fit through. Well, it took me a long time but I was almost finished when I heard father's shotgun in the forest. I hid the traces of my work, let the blanket and the saw fall, and father arrived immediately.

en: Pap warn’t in a good humor—so he was his natural self. He said he was down town, and everything was going wrong. His lawyer said he reckoned he would win his lawsuit and get the money if they ever got started on the trial; but then there was ways to put it off a long time, and Judge Thatcher knowed how to do it. And he said people allowed there’d be another trial to get me away from him and give me to the widow for my guardian, and they guessed it would win this time. This shook me up considerable, because I didn’t want to go back to the widow’s any more and be so cramped up and sivilized, as they called it. Then the old man got to cussing, and cussed everything and everybody he could think of, and then cussed them all over again to make sure he hadn’t skipped any, and after that he polished off with a kind of a general cuss all round, including a considerable parcel of people which he didn’t know the names of, and so called them what’s-his-name when he got to them, and went right along with his cussing.
vi: He didn't seem very happy at that moment. Besides, it had always been like that. He said he had just returned from the province, and the work was a complete mess. The lawyer told my father that he would win the lawsuit and get money if they brought the matter to trial. But then they found ways to prolong the matter, and old Judge Thatcher was very skilled at this sort of thing. Then he said that people outside the province were hoping for another trial to get me away from my father and bring me back to the widow so she could take care of me, and they believed that this time they would definitely succeed. That made me very confused, because I didn't want to go back to the widow to be bound and civilized as I used to say. After that, my father started cursing, cursing everything and everyone. He cursed anyone he thought of. He cursed and cursed to show that he wouldn't spare anyone, and after he had cursed everyone, he made a summary curse, including a lot of people whose names he didn't even know. That meant those people whom he had to refer to as "that guy... what's his name" whenever he cursed them. After getting tired of cursing, he started cursing from the beginning again.
tr: His mood wasn't very good – in other words, it was as usual. He said he went down to the town and everything was going badly. His lawyer told him that if the trials could start, he would win the case and get the money, but there were ways to delay it and Judge Thatcher knew all of them very well. Also, another case had been filed to take me from my father and appoint the widow as my legal guardian to place me in her care, and it seemed like they were going to win this time. I felt uneasy when I heard this because I no longer wanted to go to the widow's house, be restricted, and "become a man." Our old man started cursing, he cursed everything and everyone that came to his mind, then to make sure he didn't miss anyone, he cursed them all again, and finally, he gave a thorough cursing to everything in general as a final touch. When it came to some of the last things he cursed, he didn't even know their names, so he would say "whatever its name is" and then continue.
es: Father was not in a good mood, which is to say, he was as usual. He said he had gone to the town center and that everything was going badly for him. His lawyer had told him that he estimated he would win the lawsuit and get the money if the trial ever started, but that there were always ways to keep postponing it, and Judge Thatcher knew all of them. He said that according to people, there was going to be another trial to separate me from him and make the widow my guardian, and they estimated that this time she would win. That made me very nervous, because I no longer wanted to go back to the widow’s house and to so much discipline and civilization, as they called it. Then the old man started cursing everything and everyone he could think of, and then cursed them again to make sure he hadn't forgotten anyone, and ended with a sort of general curse against everyone, even a bunch of people whose names he didn’t know, so when he got to them he would say whatever their name is, and kept on cursing.

en: He said he would like to see the widow get me. He said he would watch out, and if they tried to come any such game on him he knowed of a place six or seven mile off to stow me in, where they might hunt till they dropped and they couldn’t find me. That made me pretty uneasy again, but only for a minute; I reckoned I wouldn’t stay on hand till he got that chance.
vi: He said he would see how the widow planned to take me back. He would guard me carefully, and if they tried to trick him, there was a place six or seven miles from here where he would hide me, and they could search all they wanted, but they would never find me. That made me uneasy. But only for a moment. Because I had already decided that I wouldn't be here by the time he did that.
tr: If that man tries to take me, he said he would make him regret it. He would constantly watch them, and if they tried to play tricks on him, he knew another place six or seven miles away to hide me. Even if they searched there until they died of exhaustion, they wouldn't be able to find me. When I heard this, I got worried again, but only for a minute; right after, I made my decision, I certainly wasn't going to sit and wait for him to do it.
es: He said he would like to see how the widow would take me away. He said he was going to be watchful and that if they tried to pull that trick on him, he knew a place six or seven miles away where he could hide me, and where they could search until they dropped dead without finding me. That made me nervous again, but only for a minute; I figured that by then I wouldn't be around there anymore.

en: The old man made me go to the skiff and fetch the things he had got. There was a fifty-pound sack of corn meal, and a side of bacon, ammunition, and a four-gallon jug of whisky, and an old book and two newspapers for wadding, besides some tow. I toted up a load, and went back and set down on the bow of the skiff to rest. I thought it all over, and I reckoned I would walk off with the gun and some lines, and take to the woods when I run away. I guessed I wouldn’t stay in one place, but just tramp right across the country, mostly night times, and hunt and fish to keep alive, and so get so far away that the old man nor the widow couldn’t ever find me any more. I judged I would saw out and leave that night if pap got drunk enough, and I reckoned he would. I got so full of it I didn’t notice how long I was staying till the old man hollered and asked me whether I was asleep or drownded.
vi: He ordered me to go out to the boat to fetch the letters he had just brought back. There was a bag of flour weighing about more than twenty pounds, a piece of lard, bullets, and four large bottles of whiskey, along with an old book and two newspapers for cleaning, and a few other miscellaneous items. I carried everything, stepped out to the bow of the boat, and then sat down to rest. I kept thinking to myself, planning that when I escaped, I would take the gun and some fishing rods and run into the forest. I planned not to stay in one place but to travel all over the country, moving at night, hunting and fishing to survive. In this way, I would go so far that my father and the widow would never be able to find me again. I thought I would saw through the piece of wood and escape that very night if my father was already drunk, and I guessed he would be. I thought so much about it that I didn't know how long I had been sitting there. Until my father yelled, asking if I was asleep or had drowned there.
tr: My father sent me to the boat to carry the materials he brought. On the boat, there was a twenty-five-kilogram sack of corn, pork bacon, ammunition, a sixteen-liter barrel of whiskey, an old book to make tinder, two newspapers, and some rope. I carried some of it and took it away, then went back and lay down at the front of the boat to rest. Before leaving the cabin, I would take the rifle and the fishing gear and escape through the forest. I wouldn't stay in one place, but would wander from place to place. I would generally travel at night, hunt and fish to survive, and get so far away that neither my father nor the widow would ever find me. If my father drank enough and passed out, which he most likely would, I thought I could cut the rest of the plank and get out at night. I was so lost in these thoughts that I forgot how time passed. Finally, I heard him calling and asking if I had fallen asleep or drowned.
es: The old man made me go to the boat to fetch what he had brought. There was a fifty-pound sack of corn oats and a quarter of streaky bacon, ammunition, a four-gallon jug of whiskey, an old book and two newspapers to fill gaps, as well as some tow. I carried a load and then went back to sit at the bow of the boat to rest. I thought it all over again and decided to escape with the shotgun and some fishing lines, and when I escaped I would go to the woods. I thought I wouldn't stay in one fixed place, but rather go from one side of the country to the other, mostly at night, hunting and fishing for food, until I got so far that neither the old man nor the widow could ever find me. I figured I could finish sawing and leave that night if father got drunk enough, as I supposed he would. I got so excited that I didn't realize how much time had passed until the old man started shouting and asked if I had fallen asleep or drowned.

en: I got the things all up to the cabin, and then it was about dark. While I was cooking supper the old man took a swig or two and got sort of warmed up, and went to ripping again. He had been drunk over in town, and laid in the gutter all night, and he was a sight to look at. A body would a thought he was Adam—he was just all mud. Whenever his liquor begun to work he most always went for the govment, this time he says:
vi: I carried everything into the tent. By then, it was almost dark. While I was preparing dinner, he downed another glass of wine, warmed up, and then went to cause trouble again. Previously, in the province, he was already dead drunk, sleeping on the roadside every night, looking very miserable, people might have thought he was Adam. Covered in mud, when the alcohol kicked in, he often sought out the authorities. This time he spoke.
tr: By the time I had carried everything inside, it was almost dark. While I was cooking dinner, our old man had a few drinks and then started cursing again. He had gotten drunk in town and ended up lying in a ditch, quite a sight to see indeed. He was so covered in mud that one could have mistaken him for Adam himself. Whenever he got drunk, he would always curse the government. He started again:
es: I took all the things to the cabin and then it got dark. While I was cooking dinner, the old man had a couple of drinks to warm up and started making a fuss again. He had already gotten drunk in town and spent the night in the ditch, and he was truly a sight to see. Anyone would think he was Adam: you couldn't see anything of him but mud. When he was quite drunk, he almost always picked on the government. That time he goes and says:

en: “Call this a govment! why, just look at it and see what it’s like. Here’s the law a-standing ready to take a man’s son away from him—a man’s own son, which he has had all the trouble and all the anxiety and all the expense of raising. Yes, just as that man has got that son raised at last, and ready to go to work and begin to do suthin’ for him and give him a rest, the law up and goes for him. And they call that govment! That ain’t all, nuther. The law backs that old Judge Thatcher up and helps him to keep me out o’ my property. Here’s what the law does: The law takes a man worth six thousand dollars and up’ards, and jams him into an old trap of a cabin like this, and lets him go round in clothes that ain’t fitten for a hog. They call that govment! A man can’t get his rights in a govment like this. Sometimes I’ve a mighty notion to just leave the country for good and all. Yes, and I told ’em so; I told old Thatcher so to his face. Lots of ’em heard me, and can tell what I said. Says I, for two cents I’d leave the blamed country and never come a-near it agin. Them’s the very words. I says look at my hat—if you call it a hat—but the lid raises up and the rest of it goes down till it’s below my chin, and then it ain’t rightly a hat at all, but more like my head was shoved up through a jint o’ stove-pipe. Look at it, says I—such a hat for me to wear—one of the wealthiest men in this town if I could git my rights.
vi: - Huh! And you call that a government? Let's see what it has done. This is the law. The law is ready to take people away, huh? People have to work hard and worry so much to raise their stepchildren. Yes, that's right, people raise their children to grow up, and when they are about to start working to earn something to support their parents, this is what happens. The law is made to help people. And you call that a government! It's not a government at all. The law supports that old Thatcher and helps him take all my property? Here, this is what the law does; the law takes six thousand dollars from people and forces them into an old trap in a house like this, making them wander around in clothes not even fit for pigs. And you call that a government. With a government like this, people have no rights at all. Sometimes I think it's better to just leave this place for good. Yes, I told everyone that, I said it straight to Thatcher's face. Many people heard me say that and can confirm that I said it. I said just give me two cents and I would leave this cursed place immediately and never come back. And everyone says the same thing. Here, look at my hat - if you can even call it a hat, the top pops off, and the rest falls down to my chin. How can you call that a hat anymore? Putting my head in the hat is like sticking it into a chimney. Here, look, this is how my hat fits. If I had all my rights, I would be one of the richest people in the province...
tr: “Such a government should not exist! Just standing still and looking is enough to see what it is. This so-called law is ready to take a man's son away from him – his own son, whom he has endured countless troubles and hardships to raise. When the poor man finally thinks he has raised his child, and expects to find a job and take care of him, and perhaps find some peace for himself, the laws suddenly stand against him. Is this what a government should be like! No, it shouldn't be like this. The law supports our Judge Thatcher and helps him take my property away from me. This is what the laws are good for. Their so-called law strips a man worth six thousand dollars to the bone and stuffs him into such old shacks, making him wear clothes that even pigs wouldn't wear. Is this a government! Who can seek their rights in this government? Sometimes I think of leaving this country and never coming back. I told them this too. I even told it to our Thatcher's face. Several men heard me, they all witnessed it. I said I would even pay money to leave this country and never come back. That's exactly what I said. Look at this hat of mine, I said… can this even be called a hat… its top opens up and it comes down to my chin. It's no longer a hat, it's as if my head is stuck in a stove pipe. Look here, I said, this is the kind of hat you make me wear, one of the richest men in town. Oh, if only I could get my rights.
es: —And they call this a government! Just look around to see what it really is. They make a law to take a man's son away from him: his own son, with all the work, worries, and expenses it took to raise him. Yes, and just when that man has finally raised his son to the age where he can start working and doing something for him so he can rest, the law comes and takes him away. And they call that a government! And that's not all. The law sides with that old Judge Thatcher and helps him take away my property. Look at what the law does: the law grabs a man who has six thousand dollars or more and locks him up in an old cabin like this and lets him wear clothes that aren't even fit for a pig. And they call that a government! With a government like that, there's no way a man can have rights. Sometimes I'm tempted to leave the country for good. Yes, and I've said it; I've said it to old Thatcher's face. Lots of people heard me, and they can say I said it. I go and say: "For two cents I'd leave this damned country and never come back even if they paid me." That's exactly what I said; "Look at this hat—if you can even call it a hat—it lifts up at the top and falls down until it slips under my chin and it's not even a hat anymore, but more like they stuck my head in a chimney pipe. Look at it," I go and say: "What a hat for a guy like me, one of the richest men in this town if my rights were recognized."

en: “Oh, yes, this is a wonderful govment, wonderful. Why, looky here. There was a free nigger there from Ohio—a mulatter, most as white as a white man. He had the whitest shirt on you ever see, too, and the shiniest hat; and there ain’t a man in that town that’s got as fine clothes as what he had; and he had a gold watch and chain, and a silver-headed cane—the awfulest old gray-headed nabob in the State. And what do you think? They said he was a p’fessor in a college, and could talk all kinds of languages, and knowed everything. And that ain’t the wust. They said he could vote when he was at home. Well, that let me out. Thinks I, what is the country a-coming to? It was ’lection day, and I was just about to go and vote myself if I warn’t too drunk to get there; but when they told me there was a State in this country where they’d let that nigger vote, I drawed out. I says I’ll never vote agin. Them’s the very words I said; they all heard me; and the country may rot for all me—I’ll never vote agin as long as I live. And to see the cool way of that nigger—why, he wouldn’t a give me the road if I hadn’t shoved him out o’ the way. I says to the people, why ain’t this nigger put up at auction and sold?—that’s what I want to know. And what do you reckon they said? Why, they said he couldn’t be sold till he’d been in the State six months, and he hadn’t been there that long yet. There, now—that’s a specimen. They call that a govment that can’t sell a free nigger till he’s been in the State six months. Here’s a govment that calls itself a govment, and lets on to be a govment, and thinks it is a govment, and yet’s got to set stock-still for six whole months before it can take a hold of a prowling, thieving, infernal, white-shirted free nigger, and—”
vi: Ah, yes, yes, this government is really very good. There, try to see. There was a free black man from Ohio who came, he was almost white, nearly like a white person. He wore the whitest shirt anyone had ever seen, and the most stylish hat. No one in this province had clothes better than his; then he had a gold watch, with a gold chain, and a silver-tipped cane, truly a millionaire, with gray hair, the most formidable in this land. What do you think? People say he is a university professor, able to speak various languages, knowledgeable about everything. And that’s not even the worst of it. They also say that he can vote just by sitting at home. Ah, who can tolerate that? I wonder what will become of this country? On election day, I was about to go vote - if I wasn’t drunk and could go - then I suddenly heard that in this country there’s a state where they don’t let black people vote, so I immediately withdrew my vote. I said that I would never bother to vote, let the country say what it wants about me. As long as I live, I will definitely not vote. Just look at the indifferent attitude of that black man, he wouldn’t be ready to give up his seat for me unless I pushed him aside. I told everyone why not auction off that black man? That’s all I needed to know. Do you know what they answered me? What else, they said that he hasn’t been in this land for six months yet so he can’t be auctioned off. Ah, so this is a government that considers itself a government, and insists that it is a government, thinking that’s what makes a government; yet it stays silent for six months before daring to touch a black man who robs, horrendous; wearing a white shirt and being free, and then...
tr: Yeah, what a fine government, what a fine one. Listen to me carefully. There is a free black man from Ohio there, but he is a mulatto, almost as white as the whites. He walks around in the whitest shirt you can see; he wears the finest hat. There is no one in town who dresses as well as he does. He has a gold pocket watch and a cane with a silver knob. The most pompous, the oldest, the richest dandy in the state. And do you know what they say? They say he is a professor at a university, speaks every language, and knows everything. As if all this were not enough... He can even vote in the state he lives in. What insolence! I said, what will become of this country... On election day, I was just about to go to the ballot box, I mean, I would have gone if I hadn't been too drunk to walk, when they told me there is a state in this country where blacks can vote. I turned back right there. I said I would never vote again. I said exactly that, and they all heard it anyway. Let the country burn for all I care... I will never vote again in my life. You should have seen the airs of that black guy… if I hadn't pushed him aside and passed, he wouldn't have even given way. Why don't they put this black guy up for auction and sell him… tell me why, I said. Do you know what they answered? Apparently, he can't be sold until he has been in the state for six months, and it hasn't been six months yet, sir. Here's another example for you. They call a government that can't sell a free black guy before he's been in the state for six months a government. He himself calls it my government, continues his work, and thinks he is the government; the vagabond, thief, disgusting, waits for six months without lifting a finger to catch and sell a free black man in a white shirt...”
es: »Ah, yes, this government is wonderful, wonderful and you just have to see it. I saw a free black man from Ohio: a mulatto, almost as white as a white man. He wore the whitest shirt you've ever seen in your life and the shiniest hat, and in the whole town, there's no one who has clothes as good as his, and he carried a gold watch with its chain and a cane with a silver handle: he was the most impressive white-haired nabob in the state. And, what do you think?» They said he was a university professor, and that he spoke lots of languages and knew everything. And that's not the worst part. They said that in his state he could vote. That was already too much. I say: «What's happening with this country? If it were election day and I thought about going to vote if I wasn't too drunk to get there, when they told me that there was a state in this country where they let that black man vote, I wouldn't go». And I go and say: «I'm not going to vote again». That's what I said, word for word; everyone heard me, and as far as I'm concerned, the country can rot: I'm not going to vote again in my life. And the airs that black man gave himself: but if he didn't get out of the way, I would have given him a shove. And I go and tell people: «Why don't they auction off this black man and sell him? I'd like to know». And, do you know what they said? Well, they said he couldn't be sold until he had been in the state for six months and he hadn't been there that long yet. But anyway, just so you see. And they call that a government when you can't sell a free black man until he's been in the state for six months. Well, what a government that says it's a government and acts like it's a government and believes it's a government and then has to stay calm for a whole six months before laying hands on a free black man who's lurking around, stealing, infernal, with his white shirts, and... »

en: Pap was agoing on so he never noticed where his old limber legs was taking him to, so he went head over heels over the tub of salt pork and barked both shins, and the rest of his speech was all the hottest kind of language—mostly hove at the nigger and the govment, though he give the tub some, too, all along, here and there. He hopped around the cabin considerable, first on one leg and then on the other, holding first one shin and then the other one, and at last he let out with his left foot all of a sudden and fetched the tub a rattling kick. But it warn’t good judgment, because that was the boot that had a couple of his toes leaking out of the front end of it; so now he raised a howl that fairly made a body’s hair raise, and down he went in the dirt, and rolled there, and held his toes; and the cussing he done then laid over anything he had ever done previous. He said so his own self afterwards. He had heard old Sowberry Hagan in his best days, and he said it laid over him, too; but I reckon that was sort of piling it on, maybe.
vi: My father was talking while walking around like that, not even noticing that his old but still flexible legs were taking him somewhere. Suddenly, he fell headfirst into a barrel of salted meat, scraping both his shins. So, the end of his speech turned into a very lively language - mostly still talking about the black man and the government - while he angrily kicked the barrel around the house. He hopped on one leg around the room, holding one shin, then let it down and held the other leg, then suddenly kicked the barrel very hard. But unfortunately, one of his shoes had a hole with some toes sticking out. He hit the barrel; he let out a blood-curdling scream; then he rolled on the ground, holding his toes. Now, I don't know when he started cursing me. Later, he himself said the same thing. He had heard of Mr. Sowberry Hagan in his glorious days and said that he had influenced him. But I think that was probably just something my father made up.
tr: My father kept talking non-stop, not paying attention to where his trembling legs were taking him. He tripped over the hog-salting tub and fell headfirst, hitting both of his shins somewhere, and his subsequent speech turned into a dreadful curse – mostly hurling insults at that black man and the government, but the tub also got its share of the swearing. Inside the cabin, he hopped first on one foot, then on the other, and then he kicked the tub. But he made a mistake, because the toe of the boot on that foot was torn, and two of his toes were sticking out. He started howling so much that it made my hair stand on end. Then he began rolling around in the dust, clutching his aching toes in pain. Meanwhile, he was cursing even more vehemently than before. When he finished, he didn't forget to mention that he had outdone himself this time. He had listened to Sowberry Hagan in his golden age, but now he was leaving even him in the dust, though it seemed to me he was exaggerating a bit.
es: Father was so angry that he didn't realize where his legs were taking him, so he tripped over the barrel of salted pork and skinned his ankles, and the rest of his speech was a series of the most terrible insults, mostly against the black man and the government, although he also directed some at the barrel, interspersed from time to time. He was jumping around the cabin like a madman, first on one leg and then on the other, grabbing first one ankle and then the other, and finally he suddenly kicked the barrel with his left foot. But he didn't do it right, because he hit it with the boot through which two of his toes were sticking out, so he started screaming in a way that made one's hair stand on end, and he fell to the ground, rolling around grabbing his toes and uttering worse curses than all the previous ones. He himself said later: he had heard old Sowberry Hagan in his good times and claimed that he had surpassed him, but it seems to me that he might have been exaggerating a bit.

en: After supper pap took the jug, and said he had enough whisky there for two drunks and one delirium tremens. That was always his word. I judged he would be blind drunk in about an hour, and then I would steal the key, or saw myself out, one or t’other. He drank and drank, and tumbled down on his blankets by-and-by; but luck didn’t run my way. He didn’t go sound asleep, but was uneasy. He groaned and moaned and thrashed around this way and that for a long time. At last I got so sleepy I couldn’t keep my eyes open all I could do, and so before I knowed what I was about I was sound asleep, and the candle burning.
vi: After finishing dinner, my father grabbed the bottle of liquor again, saying there was enough for two regular drinks and one really drunk session. He always said that. I had planned that within about an hour he would be so drunk he wouldn't know anything, and then I would either steal the key or saw through the piece of wood to get out; one of the two ways. My father kept drinking steadily and then lay down on the bed a while later. But I really wasn't lucky at all. It wasn't that my father was sound asleep, he was just tired. He mumbled, muttered, turned this way and that for a long time. Finally, I waited so long that I got too sleepy to keep my eyes open. So, before I knew what was happening, I had fallen fast asleep while the candle was still burning.
tr: After dinner, my father looked at the barrel and said he had enough whiskey to get drunk twice and to completely pass out once. He always said that. I had calculated that he would be dead drunk within about an hour, and after that, I would either steal the key or cut the planks. He drank and drank, and finally collapsed on the blankets, but my luck had not favored me. Instead of falling into a deep sleep, he kept tossing and turning. For a long time, he continued to make snoring and groaning sounds, turning from side to side. Eventually, I got so sleepy that I couldn't keep my eyelids open. At some point, I must have completely fallen asleep, and it didn't even occur to me to extinguish the candle.
es: After dinner, father handed him the jug, saying that there was enough whiskey for two drunks and a delirium tremens. It was what he always said. I thought he would be completely drunk within an hour, and then I would either steal the key or escape, one of the two things. He kept drinking and drinking, and after a while, he lay down on top of the blankets; but I had no luck. He didn't fall completely asleep, but woke up from time to time. He spent a long time moaning and complaining and tossing and turning. Finally, I got so sleepy that I couldn't keep my eyes open, and without realizing it, I fell completely asleep, with the candle still lit.

en: I don’t know how long I was asleep, but all of a sudden there was an awful scream and I was up. There was pap looking wild, and skipping around every which way and yelling about snakes. He said they was crawling up his legs; and then he would give a jump and scream, and say one had bit him on the cheek—but I couldn’t see no snakes. He started and run round and round the cabin, hollering “Take him off! take him off! he’s biting me on the neck!” I never see a man look so wild in the eyes. Pretty soon he was all fagged out, and fell down panting; then he rolled over and over wonderful fast, kicking things every which way, and striking and grabbing at the air with his hands, and screaming and saying there was devils a-hold of him. He wore out by-and-by, and laid still a while, moaning. Then he laid stiller, and didn’t make a sound. I could hear the owls and the wolves away off in the woods, and it seemed terrible still. He was laying over by the corner. By-and-by he raised up part way and listened, with his head to one side. He says, very low:
vi: I don't know how long I had been asleep; but suddenly a scream startled me awake. I saw my father, his face very angry, running around from corner to corner, shouting that there was a snake. He said the snake had crawled up his leg and then suddenly jumped up screaming, saying that one had bitten his cheek. I didn't see any snake at all, but he kept running around the house, shouting: Catch it! Catch it! It bit my neck right here! Never had I seen anyone with such fierce eyes. After a while, he was so exhausted that he collapsed, gasping for breath; then he moved very quickly, his legs hitting all the furniture in the house, his hands flailing in the air, his mouth still screaming, saying that some ghosts had come to take him away. Gradually, too tired, he lay still for a while, but his mouth still groaned. Then he lay completely still, with no more sound. I faintly heard the sound of owls hooting and wolves howling in the distant forest; and at that moment the silence was terrifying. My father still lay motionless in the corner of the house. A moment later, he sat up, tilted his head to one side to listen, then whispered:
tr: I don't know how long I slept, but suddenly a terrifying scream woke me up. My father was running around like crazy, shouting, "There's a snake! Snake!" He said one was climbing up his leg, then he let out another scream and jumped into the air, saying one had bitten his cheek – but I couldn't see any snake around. He was running around the cabin shouting, "Get it off me, get it off me, now it bit my neck!" I'd never seen a man's eyes open so wide. Soon he became exhausted and collapsed to the ground, gasping for breath. Then he started rolling on the ground, kicking in all directions, slapping and punching at something in the air. He was shouting that demons had taken over him. But then he got really tired and lay still, moaning for a while. Finally, he became completely motionless, his voice fell silent. I could hear owls hooting and wolves howling in the distant parts of the forest, and a terrifying silence filled the cabin. My father had collapsed in a corner. After a while, he got up and started listening intently. He began to speak in a low voice:
es: I don't know how long I had been asleep, but suddenly a horrible scream sounded and I woke up. It was father, who seemed crazy and was jumping from one place to another, shouting that there were snakes there. He said they were crawling up his legs, and then he would jump and scream and say that one had bitten him on the cheek, but I didn't see any snakes. He started running around the cabin, shouting: "Get it off me! Get it off me! It's biting my neck!" I've never seen anyone with such a crazy look. He quickly got exhausted and fell to the ground panting; then he started spinning around at full speed, kicking everywhere and hitting the air and grabbing it with his hands, shouting and saying that the devils were taking him away. Little by little he began to tire and stayed quiet for a while, moaning. Then he stayed still and didn't make a sound. In the distance, in the forest, you could hear the owls and the wolves and everything seemed to be in a terrible silence. He was lying in a corner. After a while, he partially got up to listen, with his head tilted to one side. And then he says, in a very low voice:

en: “Tramp—tramp—tramp; that’s the dead; tramp—tramp—tramp; they’re coming after me; but I won’t go. Oh, they’re here! don’t touch me—don’t! hands off—they’re cold; let go. Oh, let a poor devil alone!”
vi: - Clop - clop, clop - clop; the dead are passing through here; clop - clop, clop - clop; they are chasing me, but I am not going anywhere. Oh, oh, they have arrived here already! Don't touch me! Don't! Don't! Go away, their hands are so cold! Let me go! Oh! oh! Please spare this wretched man!
tr: “Rap… rap… rap; the dead are rising; rap… rap… rap; it's coming from behind me; but I won't go… Aah, here they come! Don't touch… Move away! Take your hands off… Your hands are so cold; leave me… Aah, don't bother this poor soul!”
es: —Boom... Boom... Boom...; it's the dead, boom... boom...; they come to get me, but I'm not going. Ah, there they are! Don't touch me... no! Get those hands off... they are cold; let go of me. Leave this poor devil alone!

en: Then he went down on all fours and crawled off, begging them to let him alone, and he rolled himself up in his blanket and wallowed in under the old pine table, still a-begging; and then he went to crying. I could hear him through the blanket.
vi: Then he knelt on all fours, crawling and bowing to be forgiven, then curled himself up in a blanket, then when he got close to the old table made from a pine stump; his mouth kept begging, begging until he was tired, then he cried. Through the blanket, I could hear every single word clearly.
tr: He crawled forward, begging them on his knees to leave. Wrapping himself in his blanket, he continued to beg as he crawled under the old pine table and started to cry there. I could hear him sobbing under the blanket.
es: Then he got on all fours and crawled away, asking them to leave him alone, and wrapped himself in the blanket and got under the pine table as best as he could, while he kept begging them, and then he started to cry. You could hear him from under the blanket.

en: By-and-by he rolled out and jumped up on his feet looking wild, and he see me and went for me. He chased me round and round the place with a clasp-knife, calling me the Angel of Death, and saying he would kill me, and then I couldn’t come for him no more. I begged, and told him I was only Huck; but he laughed such a screechy laugh, and roared and cussed, and kept on chasing me up. Once when I turned short and dodged under his arm he made a grab and got me by the jacket between my shoulders, and I thought I was gone; but I slid out of the jacket quick as lightning, and saved myself. Pretty soon he was all tired out, and dropped down with his back against the door, and said he would rest a minute and then kill me. He put his knife under him, and said he would sleep and get strong, and then he would see who was who.
vi: Then a little later, he threw off the blanket and stood up straight. His face looked even more ferocious, staring intently at me and stepping closer. He chased me around the house, holding a pocket knife, calling me the Grim Reaper, and saying he would kill me. So I couldn't get close to him. I begged, telling him that I was just Huck. But he let out a terrifying laugh, roared curses back, and kept chasing me. I ran, then suddenly turned around and slipped under his arm, somehow he managed to grab the back of my shirt. I thought to myself that I was done for. But as quick as lightning, I slipped out of my shirt and escaped. After a while, he got so tired that he collapsed, leaning against the door, and said he would rest for a minute before killing me. He tucked the knife into his waistband, saying he would take a nap to regain strength and then show me what he could do.
tr: After a while, he came out from under the table, sprang to his feet in a frenzy, saw me, and immediately walked towards me. He was chasing me with a switchblade in his hand; while I was running around the cabin, he was shouting that I was the Angel of Death, that he would kill me, and thus I would never come to take him again. I begged him, told him that I was just poor Huck; but he let out a terrible, shrill laugh, continued to chase me, roaring and cursing. Once, when I suddenly turned and tried to slip under his arm, he grabbed me by the collar of my jacket. I thought I was done for, but then I slipped out of the jacket like lightning and saved myself. Soon after, he became exhausted again, leaned against the door to catch his breath, and said that after resting there for a while, he would kill me. Then he leaned back completely, hid the knife underneath him, and said he would take a nap to regain his strength, and then show me who was who.
es: Then he rolled out and jumped to his feet with a crazed look, saw me, and lunged at me. He chased me all over the cabin with a switchblade, calling himself the Angel of Death and saying he was going to kill me, and I wouldn't be able to come back for him anymore. I begged him; I told him I was just Huck, but he laughed with a screeching laugh and didn't stop roaring, cursing, and chasing me. Once, when I stopped suddenly and was about to dodge under his arm, he grabbed me by the jacket between the shoulders, and I thought that was the end of me, but I quickly slipped out of the jacket like lightning and saved myself. He soon got exhausted again and collapsed backward against the door, saying he was going to rest for a moment before killing me. He hid the knife where he was sitting and said he was going to sleep to regain his strength, and then we would see who was who.

en: So he dozed off pretty soon. By-and-by I got the old split-bottom chair and clumb up as easy as I could, not to make any noise, and got down the gun. I slipped the ramrod down it to make sure it was loaded, then I laid it across the turnip barrel, pointing towards pap, and set down behind it to wait for him to stir. And how slow and still the time did drag along.
vi: Then he nodded off to sleep. A moment later, I slipped under the seat, quietly crawled up, without making a sound, and took down the gun. I pulled out the magazine to check if it was loaded, then placed the gun on the crate of radishes, aiming it directly at my father. Then I sat there quietly, waiting to see if he would move. At that moment, time seemed to pass so slowly and silently.
tr: He soon fell completely asleep. I quietly and slowly pulled the old chair with the broken seat as best as I could, climbed on it, and took the rifle down from the wall. I checked if it was loaded with the ramrod, and upon realizing it was, I pointed the barrel at my father, placed it on the turnip barrel, and sat behind the barrel, waiting for him to move. Time was passing so slowly, and it was so quiet around.
es: So he fell asleep very quickly. Then I took out the old chair that had the broken seat and climbed onto it very calmly, so as not to make any noise, and took down the shotgun. I inserted the ramrod to make sure it was loaded and then placed it on top of the barrel of turnips, pointing at father, and sat behind it until he moved. And time passed very slowly, always in silence.

en: CHAPTER VII.
vi: Chapter VII
