tr: Chapter Seven
es: Chapter 7

en: “Git up! What you ’bout?”
vi: - Wake up! What do you think you're doing?
tr: "Get up! What are you doing here?"
es: —GET UP! What are you doing?

en: I opened my eyes and looked around, trying to make out where I was. It was after sun-up, and I had been sound asleep. Pap was standing over me looking sour and sick, too. He says:
vi: I opened my eyes wide and looked around, trying to think where I was. At that moment, the sun had risen, and I had just had a deep sleep. My father was standing in front of me, looking sad and tired. My father asked:
tr: I opened my eyes and looked around, trying to understand where I was. The sun had risen high, and I had fallen asleep. My father was standing over me, looking irritable and quite pale. He continued:
es: I opened my eyes and looked around, trying to see where I was. The sun had already risen and I had slept like a log. Father was standing next to me, with a sour face and looking like he felt unwell. He goes and says:

en: “What you doin’ with this gun?”
vi: - Why did you bring the gun here?
tr: “What is this rifle doing here?”
es: —What are you doing with that shotgun?

en: I judged he didn’t know nothing about what he had been doing, so I says:
vi: I guess my father didn't know anything about what he had done the night before, so I said:
tr: I realized that he didn't remember what he did at night, so I said:
es: I thought he didn't know anything about what had happened, so I went and told him:

en: “Somebody tried to get in, so I was laying for him.”
vi: - It seems like someone intends to enter the house, so I have to sit here and keep watch.
tr: “Someone tried to get in, so I took it down.”
es: —Someone tried to get in, so I was keeping watch.

en: “Why didn’t you roust me out?”
vi: - Why didn't you call me to wake me up?
tr: “Why didn't you wake me up?”
es: —Why didn't you wake me up?

en: “Well, I tried to, but I couldn’t; I couldn’t budge you.”
vi: - Yes, I called Dad to wake him up but it didn't work. I shook him for a long time but he wouldn't wake up.
tr: “I tried to lift you, but it didn't work, you didn't even budge.”
es: —Well, I tried, but I couldn't; you didn't notice.

en: “Well, all right. Don’t stand there palavering all day, but out with you and see if there’s a fish on the lines for breakfast. I’ll be along in a minute.”
vi: - Fine, stop sitting here and rambling. Go outside and check if there's any fish on the line to bring back for breakfast. I'll come out in a bit.
tr: “Alright, fine. You’re not going to chatter here all day, I suppose. Go outside and check if there are any breakfast fish on the lines. I’ll come in a bit.”
es: —Alright. Don't stay there chatting all day, go outside and see if there's any fish on the line for breakfast. I'll go in a moment.

en: He unlocked the door, and I cleared out up the river-bank. I noticed some pieces of limbs and such things floating down, and a sprinkling of bark; so I knowed the river had begun to rise. I reckoned I would have great times now if I was over at the town. The June rise used to be always luck for me; because as soon as that rise begins here comes cordwood floating down, and pieces of log rafts—sometimes a dozen logs together; so all you have to do is to catch them and sell them to the wood-yards and the sawmill.
vi: My father unlocked the door, and I dashed out to the riverbank. Seeing a few floating branches and scattered pieces of bark, I knew the water had started to rise. I thought to myself that if I were in the city right now, I would be playing and having fun. June is the season of rising water, which always brings me a lot of luck. Because whenever the water rises, driftwood and logs float down, along with pieces of rafts, sometimes dozens at a time. All I have to do is collect them and sell them to the lumber yard or sawmill.
tr: He opened the door and immediately dashed outside, walking upstream along the river. Tree branches were floating in the water, and there were also pieces of tree bark. I realized that the river was starting to rise. If I were in town, this would be very beneficial for me. The June floods always brought me good fortune, because as soon as the river started to rise, bundles of firewood and pieces of raft timber would float downstream – sometimes I would come across a dozen pieces of wood at once. I would catch them and sell them to the woodcutter or directly to the lumber mill.
es: He opened the door and I went out to the riverbank. I saw pieces of branches and other things floating downstream and some tree bark, so I understood that the river had started to rise. I thought that if I had been in town, I would have had a great time. The June flood always brought me luck, because as soon as that flood arrives, cut logs and pieces of log rafts come down: sometimes a dozen logs together; so you just have to collect them and sell them to the sawmill and the carpenters.

en: I went along up the bank with one eye out for pap and t’other one out for what the rise might fetch along. Well, all at once here comes a canoe; just a beauty, too, about thirteen or fourteen foot long, riding high like a duck. I shot head-first off of the bank like a frog, clothes and all on, and struck out for the canoe. I just expected there’d be somebody laying down in it, because people often done that to fool folks, and when a chap had pulled a skiff out most to it they’d raise up and laugh at him. But it warn’t so this time. It was a drift-canoe sure enough, and I clumb in and paddled her ashore. Thinks I, the old man will be glad when he sees this—she’s worth ten dollars. But when I got to shore pap wasn’t in sight yet, and as I was running her into a little creek like a gully, all hung over with vines and willows, I struck another idea: I judged I’d hide her good, and then, ’stead of taking to the woods when I run off, I’d go down the river about fifty mile and camp in one place for good, and not have such a rough time tramping on foot.
vi: I followed along the riverbank, heading upstream, keeping an eye on my father while also looking to see if the rising water might bring anything useful. Suddenly, a boat drifted by, a very beautiful boat, about three or four meters long, with its bow raised like a duck's beak. From the riverbank, I dove in headfirst like a frog, fully clothed, towards the boat. I guessed that there must be someone lying inside the boat, because it was common for people to lie inside and then pop their heads out to laugh at you. But this time, there was no one. It was surely an abandoned drifting boat. I climbed in and used my feet to paddle the boat towards the shore. I thought to myself that my father would be very pleased to see it - the boat was worth ten dollars - but when I reached the shore, he was still nowhere to be seen. I pushed the boat into a small inlet, overgrown with small leaves and willows, and suddenly had another idea. I planned to hide the boat well, so instead of running into the forest, I could drift down the river about fifty miles and anchor somewhere, saving time and avoiding the effort of running on foot.
tr: While looking to see if my father was coming and also investigating what the flood was bringing, I walked up the shore. Before long, I saw a canoe. It was very beautiful, about four meters long, and gliding like a duck. Without even taking off my clothes, I immediately dived headfirst into the water like a frog and swam towards the canoe. I thought someone was lying in it waiting, because people often do this as a joke. When someone gets close enough with a boat, they suddenly sit up and laugh at their reaction. But this time, it wasn't like that. It was clear that it was an abandoned canoe. I got into the canoe and brought it to the shore. I thought our old man would be happy to see the canoe – it was worth almost ten dollars. But when I reached the shore, my father was still nowhere to be seen. As I was pulling the canoe into a small creek mouth covered with ivy and willows, another idea came to my mind. I would hide the canoe well, and instead of escaping through the forest, I would go down the river about fifty miles and set up camp somewhere. That way, my feet wouldn't get sore from walking.
es: I climbed up the shore with one eye on father and the other on what the rising water might bring. Then suddenly a canoe arrives; and moreover, a splendid one, about thirteen or fourteen feet long, sailing very stiffly like a duck. I jumped headfirst into the water like a frog, clothes and all, and swam towards the canoe. I imagined there might be someone inside, because that's what some people do to trick others, and when someone is about to pull a boat to shore, they stand up and start laughing. But not this time. It was a canoe truly drifting, and I got into it and took it to the shore. I thought the old man would be happy when he saw it: it would be worth ten dollars. But when I reached the shore, father was still not in sight, and as I was taking it into a half-hidden stream, all covered with willows and vines, another idea occurred to me: I thought of hiding it well and then, instead of going into the woods when I escaped, I would go down the river about fifty miles and camp in a place forever, without the trouble of wandering around on foot.

en: It was pretty close to the shanty, and I thought I heard the old man coming all the time; but I got her hid; and then I out and looked around a bunch of willows, and there was the old man down the path a piece just drawing a bead on a bird with his gun. So he hadn’t seen anything.
vi: This place is quite close to the hut. I thought I heard my father's footsteps approaching. But I had already hidden it, and after hiding it, I looked through the willow bushes and saw my father walking down the small path, raising his gun to aim at birds. So that means he doesn't know anything yet.
tr: Since I was quite close to our cabin, I was constantly scared that our old man would come any moment. But still, I hid the canoe, and then looked towards the cabin through the willows. My father was aiming at a bird at the end of the road. So, he hadn't noticed the canoe.
es: That was very close to the hut and all the time it seemed to me that I heard the old man arriving, but I managed to hide it and then went out and looked through a group of willows and saw the old man down the path, aiming at a bird with the shotgun. So he hadn't seen anything.

en: When he got along I was hard at it taking up a “trot” line. He abused me a little for being so slow; but I told him I fell in the river, and that was what made me so long. I knowed he would see I was wet, and then he would be asking questions. We got five catfish off the lines and went home.
vi: When my father came back, I awkwardly grabbed a fishing rod. He asked me why I took so long, and I told him I had just fallen into the river, which is why it took so long. I knew he would ask when he saw my clothes were soaking wet. The two of us caught five big fish on the line and then returned to the hut.
tr: When my father came to me, I was diligently working to reel in a fishing line. He complained that I was too slow, but I told him it took so long because I had fallen into the river. Because I knew he would notice that I was wet and start asking questions. We gathered five catfish from the lines and returned home.
es: When he arrived, I was pulling with all my strength on a line set to drag. He insulted me a bit for being so slow, but I told him that I had fallen into the river and that's why I had taken so long. I knew he would notice that I was wet and then he would start asking questions. We pulled five catfish from the drag and went home.

en: While we laid off after breakfast to sleep up, both of us being about wore out, I got to thinking that if I could fix up some way to keep pap and the widow from trying to follow me, it would be a certainer thing than trusting to luck to get far enough off before they missed me; you see, all kinds of things might happen. Well, I didn’t see no way for a while, but by-and-by pap raised up a minute to drink another barrel of water, and he says:
vi: After finishing breakfast, we went back to sleep. Both of us were exhausted. I thought about how to ensure that neither my father nor the widow could pursue me anymore. Perhaps trusting in luck and going far away so they couldn't find me was the safest bet. Because who knows, maybe nothing would happen. After thinking for a long time, I couldn't come up with any solution. My father sat up for a moment, drank some water, and then said:
tr: After breakfast, a heaviness settled over both of us, and we began to doze off somewhere. Meanwhile, I was looking for a solution so that my father or the widow wouldn't come after me once I escaped. I needed to find a more certain way than just hoping to get far enough away before they noticed my absence. You never know what might happen to you. For a while, no solution came to mind, but then when my father got up to fetch some water from the barrel, he said:
es: When we took a nap after breakfast, because we were both exhausted, I started thinking that if I could manage to prevent either my father or the widow from trying to follow me, I would be safer than if I relied on luck to get very far before they missed me; you know, thousands of things could happen. Well, for a while nothing came to mind, but then father got up for a moment to drink another barrel of water, and he goes and says:

en: “Another time a man comes a-prowling round here you roust me out, you hear? That man warn’t here for no good. I’d a shot him. Next time you roust me out, you hear?”
vi: - Next time someone comes snooping around here, you have to call me out immediately, understand? That person coming here doesn't have good intentions. I'll shoot them dead. Remember to call me out next time, understand?
tr: “If someone comes near the house again, you will wake me up, do you understand? I don't think that man came with good intentions. I'll shoot him. Next time, you will wake me up, did you hear?”
es: —If another man comes to spy on us here, wake me up, do you understand? That man hasn't come for anything good. I would have shot him. Next time, wake me up, do you understand?

en: Then he dropped down and went to sleep again; but what he had been saying give me the very idea I wanted. I says to myself, I can fix it now so nobody won’t think of following me.
vi: Then he lay down again and slept. What he just said made perfect sense to me. I told myself that I could use that excuse, and from now on, no one would think about chasing me anymore.
tr: Then he lay down again and started to sleep – but his words had just helped me find the idea I was looking for. Now I think I've found a way to ensure no one follows me, I said to myself.
es: Then he lay down and went back to sleep; what he had said gave me the exact idea I wanted, so I said to myself: "I can arrange it so that no one thinks of following me."

en: About twelve o’clock we turned out and went along up the bank. The river was coming up pretty fast, and lots of driftwood going by on the rise. By-and-by along comes part of a log raft—nine logs fast together. We went out with the skiff and towed it ashore. Then we had dinner. Anybody but pap would a waited and seen the day through, so as to catch more stuff; but that warn’t pap’s style. Nine logs was enough for one time; he must shove right over to town and sell. So he locked me in and took the skiff, and started off towing the raft about half-past three. I judged he wouldn’t come back that night. I waited till I reckoned he had got a good start; then I out with my saw, and went to work on that log again. Before he was t’other side of the river I was out of the hole; him and his raft was just a speck on the water away off yonder.
vi: By around twelve noon, the two of us stepped out of the house and walked along the riverbank. The river water was rising quite quickly. Rotten branches were also floating along with the rising water. A little later, a nine-piece raft floated down. We rowed the boat out to pull it to shore. Then we went to have lunch. If it had been anyone else but my father, they would have waited there all day to see if they could pick up anything else, but my father was not like that. Those nine pieces of the raft were enough for one meal, as he could take them to town and sell them. So he locked the door, locked me in, and went out to take the small boat to tow the raft pieces. It was around three-thirty in the afternoon then. I guessed he wouldn't be back tonight. I waited until I figured he had gone before taking out the saw and continuing to saw through that wooden wall. Before my father crossed to the other side of the river, I had already crawled through the hole. Looking at my father with the raft, he was just a tiny dot on the very distant water surface.
tr: We got up around noon and went back to the shore. The river had started to flow faster, and because of the flood, a lot of tree branches and wood were being carried along. A little later, a piece of a raft came – there were nine logs tied together. We immediately took the boat and pulled the raft to the shore. Then we ate. Anyone else would have waited all day and tried to catch more things, but that wasn't my father's style. Nine logs were enough for one trip. All he had to do was take the logs to town and sell them. He locked me inside, got on the boat, and set off around three-thirty, towing the raft along. I knew he wouldn't come back that night. I waited until I was sure he was far enough away, then took out the saw and continued cutting the plank. Before my father even reached the other side of the river, I had climbed out through the hole. The boat and the raft were just two small dots far away.
es: By midday we got up and went up the riverbank. The river was rising quickly and lots of things were floating down with the water. After a while, a piece of a raft appeared: nine logs tied together. We went out with the boat and brought it to shore. Then we ate. Anyone who wasn't father would have waited to see what happened that day to bring us more things, but that wasn't his style. With nine logs he had enough for one time; he had to go to town immediately to sell them. So around three-thirty he locked me up and left with the boat and started towing the raft. I figured he wouldn't come back that night. I waited until I thought he was far enough away and then took out the saw and went back to working on that log. Before he finished crossing the river, I was already out through the hole; he and his raft were just a speck in the water, far away.

en: I took the sack of corn meal and took it to where the canoe was hid, and shoved the vines and branches apart and put it in; then I done the same with the side of bacon; then the whisky-jug. I took all the coffee and sugar there was, and all the ammunition; I took the wadding; I took the bucket and gourd; I took a dipper and a tin cup, and my old saw and two blankets, and the skillet and the coffee-pot. I took fish-lines and matches and other things—everything that was worth a cent. I cleaned out the place. I wanted an axe, but there wasn’t any, only the one out at the woodpile, and I knowed why I was going to leave that. I fetched out the gun, and now I was done.
vi: I took the bag of noodles and brought it to the hiding place, pushing aside the thick branches and placing the boat there. Then I took the fat, the bottle of whiskey, all the coffee and sugar from the house, all the bullets, the cotton stuffed with medicine, the water scoop, the wooden basin, a spoon and a metal cup, my saw, two blankets, a pot, and a coffee pot. I took the fishing rod, matches, and other things, anything worth even a penny. After that, I cleaned everything up thoroughly. I needed an axe, but there wasn't one in the house. There was only one at the woodpile, but I had already planned to leave it there. I also took the gun. That was everything.
tr: I took the sack of corn and brought it to the place where I had hidden the canoe, parted the vines and branches, and placed the sack in the canoe, then I brought the bacon. After that, I carried the whiskey barrel, took all the coffee and sugar from the house, and also brought the ammunition. I took the tinder. I took the bucket and the water container. I also took the ladle, the tin cup, the old saw, two blankets, the pan, and the coffee pot. I took the fishing line, the matches, and other things; everything that was worth money. I had swept everything clean. I also needed an axe, but there wasn't one inside, only by the woodpile, and I knew why I had to leave it there. Finally, I took the rifle; I had completed the task.
es: I grabbed the sack of cornmeal, took it to where the canoe was hidden, moved the vine leaves and branches aside, and put it in; then I did the same with the quarter of smoked bacon, and then with the jug of whiskey. I took all the coffee and sugar there was, and all the ammunition. I took the stuffing paper, the bucket, and the canteen; I took out a pot, a metal cup, my old saw, and two blankets, the frying pan, and the coffee pot. I grabbed the fishing lines, the matches, and other things: everything that was worth something. I emptied the cabin. I needed an axe but there was only the one in the woodpile and I knew why I was going to leave it there. I took out the shotgun and finished.

en: I had wore the ground a good deal crawling out of the hole and dragging out so many things. So I fixed that as good as I could from the outside by scattering dust on the place, which covered up the smoothness and the sawdust. Then I fixed the piece of log back into its place, and put two rocks under it and one against it to hold it there, for it was bent up at that place and didn’t quite touch ground. If you stood four or five foot away and didn’t know it was sawed, you wouldn’t never notice it; and besides, this was the back of the cabin, and it warn’t likely anybody would go fooling around there.
vi: Because I had to crawl through the hole to get out and move a lot of furniture through it, the ground in that spot was dug up quite a bit. So I figured that from the outside, I would cover it to hide the rough spot with sawdust. Then I put the wooden plank back in its original place. I wedged two pebbles underneath and one on top to hold the plank firmly in place, and that spot sloped down without touching the ground. If someone stood four or five steps away, they wouldn't be able to see the sawed spot and wouldn't know about it; besides, this was the back of the house, and probably no one would bother to go around there anyway.
tr: By going in and out of the shed and carrying a lot of things, I had made quite a few tracks on the ground. So, I carefully erased my tracks from the outside and cleaned up the sawdust. Then I placed the piece of plank firmly in its place, putting two stones underneath and one in front to keep it steady – because it didn't fit perfectly and didn't touch the ground. But I had placed it so well that someone standing a meter or two away, who didn't know it had been cut, wouldn't even notice it, plus this was at the back of the cabin where hardly anyone would come.
es: I had left all the ground packed down with the exit of the hole and with the transport of so many things. So I fixed it as best as I could, throwing dirt on top, which disguised the packed part and the sawdust that had fallen. Then I put the piece of log back in its place and put two stones underneath it and another one on the side so it wouldn't fall, because that part was irregular and didn't quite touch the ground. If one stayed four or five feet away, without knowing it was sawed, it couldn't be seen, and besides, that was the back of the cabin and it wasn't likely that anyone would look around there.

en: It was all grass clear to the canoe, so I hadn’t left a track. I followed around to see. I stood on the bank and looked out over the river. All safe. So I took the gun and went up a piece into the woods, and was hunting around for some birds when I see a wild pig; hogs soon went wild in them bottoms after they had got away from the prairie farms. I shot this fellow and took him into camp.
vi: From here to the hiding place, it's all grass, so there are no traces left behind. I walked around once to check again. I stood on the riverbank looking out into the distance. Everything was safe. Then I took the gun and walked a distance into the forest. Usually, when domestic pigs escape from the pen, they easily turn into wild boars. I immediately shot this pig and dragged it back home.
tr: The road up to Kanoya was covered with grass, so I hadn't left any tracks there. To be sure, I went back and forth once to check. Then I went to the shore and watched the river. Everything was fine. I took the rifle and went into the forest, looking for a bird to hunt. Instead, I encountered a wild boar. Pigs that escaped from large farms would become feral after staying in the forest for a while. I shot the boar and took it to the hut.
es: Until reaching the canoe, there was nothing but grass, so no tracks were left. I took a walk around to be sure. I stayed on the riverbank and looked upstream and downstream. There was no danger. So I grabbed the shotgun and went a little into the forest. I was looking for birds to hunt when I saw a wild pig; the pigs would quickly go wild around that area when they escaped from the prairie farms. I shot this one and took it to the camp.

en: I took the axe and smashed in the door. I beat it and hacked it considerable a-doing it. I fetched the pig in, and took him back nearly to the table and hacked into his throat with the axe, and laid him down on the ground to bleed; I say ground because it was ground—hard packed, and no boards. Well, next I took an old sack and put a lot of big rocks in it—all I could drag—and I started it from the pig, and dragged it to the door and through the woods down to the river and dumped it in, and down it sunk, out of sight. You could easy see that something had been dragged over the ground. I did wish Tom Sawyer was there; I knowed he would take an interest in this kind of business, and throw in the fancy touches. Nobody could spread himself like Tom Sawyer in such a thing as that.
vi: I took the axe and struck the door with a strong blow. It took a lot of hitting, quite a long time to break the door. I dragged the pig inside, pulled it near the table, then struck the pig's neck with an axe, leaving it on the ground for a while to let the blood flow out. I say ground because it was real ground, just compacted earth, not wood flooring, then I grabbed an old bag, filled it with large pebbles, heavy enough for me to drag, then from the pig's location, I dragged the bag of pebbles to the door, through the woods to the riverbank, and threw it down there. The bag of pebbles sank, disappearing completely. Anyone could see that something had been dragged along the ground. I wished Tom Sawyer were here at this moment because I knew he would love this kind of thing and would add more details to make it even more thrilling. For such stories, no one could boast more than Tom Sawyer.
tr: I took the axe and broke the door – I had hit it with all my strength and shattered the planks. I took the pig inside and brought it to a spot near the table, then cut its throat with the axe. I left it on the ground so the blood could drain – I say ground because there was no flooring, no planks laid, just the compacted earth beneath. Then I took an old sack and filled it with large stones – just enough that I could still drag it. I dragged the sack from where the pig was, through the door, down to the riverbank among the trees, and left it in the water there. It immediately sank and disappeared from sight. It was clear that something had been dragged on the ground. I wish Tom Sawyer had been with me... I knew very well how keen you were on such schemes, if he saw it now, who knows what cunning ideas would come to his mind. I've never seen anyone in my life whose mind worked as sharply as Tom Sawyer's in such matters.
es: I grabbed the axe and jumped over the door. I smashed it as much as I could. I brought the pig inside and dragged it almost to the table, then I cut its throat with the axe and left it on the ground to bleed; I say on the ground because it was dirt: compacted and without floorboards. Then I took an old sack and filled it with large stones —all that I could drag—, starting where the pig was, and dragged it to the door and through the woods to the river, where I threw it; it sank and disappeared. It was easy to see that something had been dragged across the ground. I thought that I wished Tom Sawyer had been there; I knew he was interested in these things and that he would add the precise details. Nobody knew how to embellish things like Tom Sawyer in a matter like this.

en: Well, last I pulled out some of my hair, and blooded the axe good, and stuck it on the back side, and slung the axe in the corner. Then I took up the pig and held him to my breast with my jacket (so he couldn’t drip) till I got a good piece below the house and then dumped him into the river. Now I thought of something else. So I went and got the bag of meal and my old saw out of the canoe, and fetched them to the house. I took the bag to where it used to stand, and ripped a hole in the bottom of it with the saw, for there warn’t no knives and forks on the place—pap done everything with his clasp-knife about the cooking. Then I carried the sack about a hundred yards across the grass and through the willows east of the house, to a shallow lake that was five mile wide and full of rushes—and ducks too, you might say, in the season. There was a slough or a creek leading out of it on the other side that went miles away, I don’t know where, but it didn’t go to the river. The meal sifted out and made a little track all the way to the lake. I dropped pap’s whetstone there too, so as to look like it had been done by accident. Then I tied up the rip in the meal sack with a string, so it wouldn’t leak no more, and took it and my saw to the canoe again.
vi: Then I pulled out some hairs, smeared blood all over the axe blade, stuck some hairs onto the axe, and threw it in the corner of the house. I picked up the pig, held it against my chest, covered it with my shirt (so that the blood wouldn't drip), and carried it to a spot behind the house to throw it into the river. At that moment, I thought of something else. I went to the boat to get a bag of flour and a saw and brought them into the house. I put the bag of flour back in its original place, used the saw to poke a hole at the bottom of the bag, because there wasn't a pocket knife around to do everything. Then I carried the bag of flour about a hundred yards past the grass field, through the willow bushes to the east of the cabin, to a shallow but wide hole about five miles long, filled with reeds that in season would also be full of ducks. There was a small stream leading to the far side of the lake, several miles away. I didn't know exactly where it went, but I was sure it didn't run into the river. The flour fell through the hole in the bag, leaving a long trail from the house to the lake. I also threw my father's whetstone there, to make it look accidental. Then I tied a string around the hole in the flour bag to stop it from spilling out. Then I took the bag of flour and the saw back to the boat.
tr: Then I pulled out a few strands of my hair, covered the axe thoroughly with blood, stuck the hair onto it, and threw the axe into a corner. Then I took the pig, wrapped it in my jacket (so the blood wouldn't drip on the ground), and pressed it against my chest. Finally, after walking downstream and getting quite far from the house, I threw the blood-stained jacket and the pig into the river. Then another idea came to mind. I took the sack of flour and the old saw from the canoe and brought them back to the house. After placing the sack in its usual spot, I made a hole in the bottom with the saw – since my father handled everything with his switchblade, there were no knives or forks in the house for cooking. I carried the sack about a hundred meters through the willows east of the house to a shallow lake that was five miles wide and covered with reeds – there were also many ducks in season. On the other side of the lake, there was a pond or stream that went on for miles. I didn't know exactly where it went, but it definitely didn't flow into the river. The flour spilling from the sack left a thin trail all the way to the lake. On the shore, I also threw down my father's whetstone; it would look like it had fallen accidentally. Then I tied the bottom of the flour sack tightly with a rope, and once I was sure it wasn't spilling anymore, I took it back to the canoe along with the saw.
es: Well, the last thing I did was pull out some of my hair, stain the axe with blood, and leave it in the back, thrown in a corner. Then I grabbed the pig and covered it against my chest with the jacket (so it wouldn't drip) until I got far away from the house, and I threw it into the river. Then I thought of something else. So I went to take the sack of flour and the old saw from the canoe and brought them to the house. I left the sack where it usually was and made a hole in the bottom with the saw, because there were no knives or forks there: father cooked everything with the pocket knife. Then I carried the sack about a hundred yards through the grass, among the willows, to the east of the house, to a shallow lake that was five miles wide and full of reeds and also ducks when it was the season. There was a stream or a brook that came out from there on the other side and ran for miles and miles, I don't know where, but it didn't go to the river. The flour kept moving and leaving a small trail all the way to the lake. There I also threw father's sharpening stone, to make it look like something accidental. Then I closed the hole in the sack of flour with a string so that no more would fall out and took it back with the saw to the canoe.

en: It was about dark now; so I dropped the canoe down the river under some willows that hung over the bank, and waited for the moon to rise. I made fast to a willow; then I took a bite to eat, and by-and-by laid down in the canoe to smoke a pipe and lay out a plan. I says to myself, they’ll follow the track of that sackful of rocks to the shore and then drag the river for me. And they’ll follow that meal track to the lake and go browsing down the creek that leads out of it to find the robbers that killed me and took the things. They won’t ever hunt the river for anything but my dead carcass. They’ll soon get tired of that, and won’t bother no more about me. All right; I can stop anywhere I want to. Jackson’s Island is good enough for me; I know that island pretty well, and nobody ever comes there. And then I can paddle over to town nights, and slink around and pick up things I want. Jackson’s Island’s the place.
vi: At this time, the sky was nearly dark. I pushed the boat downwards, to the spot where the willow trees on the shore drooped down, and I sat there waiting for the moon to rise. I tied the boat to the base of the willow, took out a piece of bread to eat, and after eating, I lay back in the boat, smoked a cigarette to think of a new plan. I told myself that they would surely follow the trail of the gravel bag to the riverbank and then along the shore to find me. Then they would follow the flour trail to the hole, and follow the stream to somewhere to find the robbers who had killed me and taken my belongings. They would scour the river with the sole task of finding my body. They will get tired of searching and won't bother thinking about me anymore. Great, I can stop wherever I want. Jackson Island is a place where I can take refuge. I know that island very well, no one ever goes there. Then at night, I can paddle up to the top, wander around, and steal whatever I need.
tr: It was about to get dark. I lowered the canoe a bit further down and went under the willows hanging over the water, and began to wait for the moon to rise. I tied the canoe to a willow trunk. Then I ate something and soon lay inside the canoe, smoking my pipe and starting to think about my plan. They would follow the stone sack to the shore and then search the river for my body. Additionally, they would follow the flour trail to the lake, and from there, they would search along the creek to find the robbers who killed me and took my belongings. They would find a lot of things in the river besides my dead body. Eventually, they would get tired and give up searching. It was all set, I could go wherever I wanted. Jackson Island was just right for me. I knew the island well and no one ever went there. At night, I could row down to the town and sneak around to take whatever I needed. Jackson Island was perfectly fine.
es: It was almost dark, so I left the canoe downstream covered by some willows that hung over the bank and waited for the moon to come out. I tied the canoe to a willow; then I ate something and after a while, I lay down in the canoe to smoke a pipe and make a plan. And I go and tell myself: "They are going to follow the trail of that sack of stones to the shore and then they will drag the river to look for me. They will follow the flour trail to the lake, search the stream that comes out of it to find the thieves who killed me and took my things. They are only going to search the river for my corpse. Then they will soon get tired and won't worry about me anymore. Very well, I can stay wherever I please. Jackson's Island is enough for me; I know it very well and no one ever comes here. And then I can go to town at night, look around and take what I need. Jackson's Island is fine."

en: I was pretty tired, and the first thing I knowed I was asleep. When I woke up I didn’t know where I was for a minute. I set up and looked around, a little scared. Then I remembered. The river looked miles and miles across. The moon was so bright I could a counted the drift logs that went a-slipping along, black and still, hundreds of yards out from shore. Everything was dead quiet, and it looked late, and smelt late. You know what I mean—I don’t know the words to put it in.
vi: At that time, I was quite tired. The first thing to do was to sleep. When I woke up, it took me a minute to realize where I was. I sat up, looked around, a bit scared. Then I remembered. The river stretched vast and wide for miles. The moon was so bright. I couldn't count all the pieces of wood drifting, black and silent, a few hundred meters from the shore. Everything was as silent as death. It seemed very late at night, I could sense it was very late. I'm sure you understand what I mean - I can't find the right words to say it properly.
tr: As I was quite tired, I fell asleep while thinking about these things. When I woke up, I couldn't remember where I was for a moment. I sat up and looked around with some anxiety. Then I remembered everything. The river seemed to be miles wide. The moon was so bright that I could distinguish the dark logs passing by from hundreds of meters away. A deathly silence had settled over everything, and it was evidently late; it even smelled late. You know what I mean – I just can't choose the right words every time.
es: I was quite tired and without realizing it, I fell asleep. When I woke up, I didn't know for a moment where I was. I sat up and looked around, a little scared. Then I remembered. The river seemed to be miles and miles wide. The moon shone so brightly that you could count the logs drifting down, black and silent, hundreds of yards from the shore. Everything was in total silence and it seemed to be late, it smelled like it was late. You know what I mean... I don't know with what words to say it.

en: I took a good gap and a stretch, and was just going to unhitch and start when I heard a sound away over the water. I listened. Pretty soon I made it out. It was that dull kind of a regular sound that comes from oars working in rowlocks when it’s a still night. I peeped out through the willow branches, and there it was—a skiff, away across the water. I couldn’t tell how many was in it. It kept a-coming, and when it was abreast of me I see there warn’t but one man in it. Think’s I, maybe it’s pap, though I warn’t expecting him. He dropped below me with the current, and by-and-by he came a-swinging up shore in the easy water, and he went by so close I could a reached out the gun and touched him. Well, it was pap, sure enough—and sober, too, by the way he laid his oars.
vi: I let out a long yawn and stretched. Just as I was about to take off my shirt and start on my way, I suddenly heard a distant sound on the water. I listened carefully and immediately recognized the creaking sound of oars grinding against the rowlocks in the stillness of the night. I poked my head out from the willow bushes and saw a boat gliding on the river. It was impossible to tell how many people were on the boat. Only when it came closer did I see that there was only one person on the boat. I guessed it might be my father, although deep down I thought he couldn't be back yet. The boat continued to drift with the current, past my hiding spot, and then after a while, it docked at the shore where the water was still. It came so close that I almost reached for my gun and aimed at him. Oh, it was indeed my father - and he wasn't drunk either, judging by the way he handled the oars.
tr: I stretched and yawned widely, and just as I was about to untie the rope and set off, I heard a sound coming from afar over the water. I immediately perked up my ears. Soon, I understood what it was. It was the regular sound of oars rubbing against the rowlocks on silent nights. When I looked through the willow branches, I saw it – there was a boat in the distance. I couldn't see how many people were inside. It was coming towards me, and when it got closer, I saw that there was only one person inside. I wasn't expecting anyone that night, but maybe it was my father. As the boat passed by me, it rippled the water, and soon after the water calmed, it continued rowing towards the shore. It had passed so close to me that I could have touched it with my rifle if I had extended it. This was definitely my father – and judging by his rowing, he was completely sober.
es: I yawned and stretched comfortably, and I was about to untie to set off when I heard a noise in the water. I listened. Immediately I understood what it was. It was that rhythmic and muffled noise that oars make in the oarlocks in the silence of the night. I looked through the branches of the willows and there it was: a boat on the river. I couldn't see how many people it carried. It kept getting closer, and when it reached in front of me it only had one man. And I go and think: "Maybe it's father," even though I wasn't expecting him. It went downstream with the current and after a while it reached the shore, where the water was calm, and passed so close that I could have touched it by extending the shotgun. Well, it was indeed father, and moreover calm, by the way he left the oars.

en: I didn’t lose no time. The next minute I was a-spinning down stream soft but quick in the shade of the bank. I made two mile and a half, and then struck out a quarter of a mile or more towards the middle of the river, because pretty soon I would be passing the ferry landing, and people might see me and hail me. I got out amongst the driftwood, and then laid down in the bottom of the canoe and let her float.
vi: I did not waste a single moment. Just a minute later, I was already gliding the boat downstream, light and fast, in the darkness close to the shore. I rowed for more than two miles, then rowed a few hundred more yards to the middle of the river. Because in just a moment, I would be passing the ferry dock, and if someone saw me, they might call out. I steered the boat through the floating logs on the river, stuffing a few pieces at the bottom of the boat to let it drift along.
tr: I didn't waste any time. A little later, I was moving silently but swiftly in the direction of the current from within the shadows on the shore. After going about two and a half miles, I moved to the middle of the river for about a quarter mile, because I would soon be passing the steamboat dock and people might see and call out to me. I dove among the drifting logs, then lay down inside the canoe, letting go of the oars.
es: I didn't waste any time. The next moment, I was going downstream, silently but quickly, in the shadow of the riverbank. I covered two and a half miles and then moved a quarter of a mile more towards the center of the river, because I was about to pass by the ferry landing and people could see me and call out to me. I got among the drifting logs and then lay down at the bottom of the canoe and let it float on its own.

en: I laid there, and had a good rest and a smoke out of my pipe, looking away into the sky; not a cloud in it. The sky looks ever so deep when you lay down on your back in the moonshine; I never knowed it before. And how far a body can hear on the water such nights! I heard people talking at the ferry landing. I heard what they said, too—every word of it. One man said it was getting towards the long days and the short nights now. T’other one said this warn’t one of the short ones, he reckoned—and then they laughed, and he said it over again, and they laughed again; then they waked up another fellow and told him, and laughed, but he didn’t laugh; he ripped out something brisk, and said let him alone. The first fellow said he ’lowed to tell it to his old woman—she would think it was pretty good; but he said that warn’t nothing to some things he had said in his time. I heard one man say it was nearly three o’clock, and he hoped daylight wouldn’t wait more than about a week longer. After that the talk got further and further away, and I couldn’t make out the words any more; but I could hear the mumble, and now and then a laugh, too, but it seemed a long ways off.
vi: I lay down to rest again, smoked a cigarette, and looked up at the clear sky without a single cloud. On a moonlit night, lying on my back and looking up at the sky, it seemed incredibly high; I had never seen the sky so high before. On such nights, one can hear the sounds on the water from very far away. I heard people talking near the ferry dock. I clearly heard every word of the folk songs. Someone said that now the days are long and the nights are short. Another person said this was not yet one of the short nights; and both laughed. Then they woke up another person to laugh again, but the other person didn't laugh and uttered a vulgar phrase to let him sleep in peace. The first person said to stop and take that to tell his old wife - she would listen. Then he said that it was nothing compared to what he had said before. I heard someone else say that it was already almost three in the morning; wishing not to have to wait more than a week for it to be morning. Then after that, the conversation gradually faded; gradually faded, I could no longer hear each word clearly. But I could still hear murmurs, occasionally a few laughs, but it seemed very distant.
tr: I rested there nicely, watching the cloudless sky and puffing on my pipe. When lying on my back in the moonlight, the sky seemed so deep; I had never noticed this before. Also, how far sounds traveled over water on such nights! Men were talking at the steamboat dock. I could hear every word they said. One of the men said that the days were getting longer and the nights shorter. The other said that this night was not one of the short ones – then they laughed heartily. He said the same thing again and they laughed once more. Then they woke up another man, told him, and laughed; but the man did not laugh. After scolding them, he told them to give him a little peace. The first man mentioned that he would tell this to his wife – she would find it very funny too. But compared to the jokes he used to make, this one was nothing. Another man said it was three o'clock and hoped that the day wouldn't take more than a week to dawn. Then the conversations gradually faded away, I could no longer make out the words, but I could still hear their murmurs. From time to time, they laughed, but their voices came from very far away.
es: There I stayed, rested well, and smoked a pipe, gazing at the sky; there wasn't a single cloud. The sky always seems so deep when you lie on your back in the moonlight; I had never noticed it until then. And how many things you can hear from afar on nights like that! I heard people talking at the landing. And I heard what they were saying: every single word. One man remarked that the long days and short nights were coming. The other said that this wasn't one of the short ones, he guessed, and then they laughed and said it again and again and laughed again; then they woke up another person and told him, laughing, but he didn't laugh; he said something very grumpily and they left him alone. The first one said he would surely tell his old lady because she would find it very funny, but he said that was nothing compared to the things he had said in his time. I heard a man say it was almost three o'clock and he hoped daylight wouldn't take more than a week to arrive. Then the conversation gradually faded away, and I could no longer distinguish the words, but I could still hear the noise and occasionally a laugh, only now everything seemed very far away.

en: I was away below the ferry now. I rose up, and there was Jackson’s Island, about two mile and a half down stream, heavy timbered and standing up out of the middle of the river, big and dark and solid, like a steamboat without any lights. There warn’t any signs of the bar at the head—it was all under water now.
vi: Now, I was far away from the ferry dock. I sat up, seeing Jackson Island, about more than two miles down the river. The island had many dense trees, lying in the middle of the river, large and dark, as steady as a big ship without lights. The way to the port was unobstructed, the mounds had sunk below the water surface.
tr: I had already passed the ferry dock. When I looked up, I saw Jackson Island two and a half miles down. It looked huge, dark, and solid with its dense trees rising from the middle of the river. It resembled a steamboat with its lights turned off. The sandy beach at the front had disappeared from sight – it was now completely underwater.
es: The ferry had already passed. I got up and there was Jackson Island, about two and a half miles downstream, full of trees and rising in the middle of the river, big, dark, and solid, like a steamboat without any lights. There wasn't a single sign on the tip bar: now all that was submerged.

en: It didn’t take me long to get there. I shot past the head at a ripping rate, the current was so swift, and then I got into the dead water and landed on the side towards the Illinois shore. I run the canoe into a deep dent in the bank that I knowed about; I had to part the willow branches to get in; and when I made fast nobody could a seen the canoe from the outside.
vi: I rowed to the place without spending much time. I turned the canoe through the whirlpool and into the calm stream, then glided it into the still water, docking on the Illinois side. I pushed the canoe into a deep pool inside the shore that I had known before. I had to part the willow bushes to push the canoe in, and I did it quickly so no one outside could see.
tr: It didn't take long for me to get there. I passed the front of the island like lightning; the current was very strong. Then I entered calm water and landed on the Illinois side. I pulled the canoe into a nook I knew on the shore. I had to part the willow branches to get inside. After tying it tightly, no one would be able to see it from the outside.
es: It didn't take me long to get there. I passed by the point at great speed, given the swiftness of the current, and then I reached the calm waters and disembarked on the side facing the Illinois shore. I put the canoe into a deep crevice in the bank that I had seen before. I had to part the willow branches to get in, and when I tied it up, no one could see it from outside.

en: I went up and set down on a log at the head of the island, and looked out on the big river and the black driftwood and away over to the town, three mile away, where there was three or four lights twinkling. A monstrous big lumber-raft was about a mile up stream, coming along down, with a lantern in the middle of it. I watched it come creeping down, and when it was most abreast of where I stood I heard a man say, “Stern oars, there! heave her head to stabboard!” I heard that just as plain as if the man was by my side.
vi: I climbed up and sat on a fallen tree at the edge of the island and looked out at the wide river. Looking at the black floating logs, then looking towards the town three miles away, I saw three or four twinkling lights. A huge raft was coming down from upstream, about a mile from where I was sitting; a light was lit in the middle of summer. I watched as a raft slowly drifted right to where I was, and someone said: Row harder! That's it! Push the edge of the paddle down! I heard the voice booming as if the person was standing right next to me.
tr: I went and sat on a log at the head of the island and started watching the big river, the drifting black logs, and the town three miles away where three or four lights were flickering. A massive lumber raft was coming from about a mile upstream. There was a lantern right in the middle of it. I watched as the raft slowly approached. When it reached right opposite me, I heard a man shout, “Oars at the stern! Turn the bow to starboard!” I heard his voice as clearly as if he were right next to me.
es: I climbed up and sat on a log at the tip of the island to contemplate the great river and the lumber that was passing by, and the town, three miles away, where three or four lights could be seen blinking. There was a huge raft of logs floating a mile upstream, coming down with a lit lantern in the middle. I watched as it slowly approached, and when it was almost in front of me, I heard a man say, "Ahoy, stern oars! Turn the bow to starboard!" I heard him just as clearly as if that man had been right next to me.

en: There was a little gray in the sky now; so I stepped into the woods, and laid down for a nap before breakfast.
vi: The sky had started to turn gray. I walked into the forest and lay down to sleep for a while before having breakfast.
tr: The color of the sky had started to lighten slightly. I went into the trees to take a nap before breakfast.
es: Now there was already some gray in the sky and I went into the forest and took a nap before breakfast.

en: CHAPTER VIII.
vi: Chapter VIII
tr: Chapter Eight
es: Chapter 8

en: The sun was up so high when I waked that I judged it was after eight o’clock. I laid there in the grass and the cool shade thinking about things, and feeling rested and ruther comfortable and satisfied. I could see the sun out at one or two holes, but mostly it was big trees all about, and gloomy in there amongst them. There was freckled places on the ground where the light sifted down through the leaves, and the freckled places swapped about a little, showing there was a little breeze up there. A couple of squirrels set on a limb and jabbered at me very friendly.
vi: When I woke up, the sun was already high in the sky, I guessed it was past eight o'clock. I lay on the grass, in the cool shade, not thinking about much, feeling rested, both reassured and content. After a few empty months, I could see the sun. All around were large trees, so the place was quite dark. There were also spots where sunlight pierced through the leaves and shone on the ground, and the sunlight there shimmered like a gentle breeze blowing through. A pair of squirrels sat on a branch, looking at me and chattering in a friendly manner.
tr: When I woke up, the sun had risen so high that I thought it was past eight o'clock. I lay down again on the grass in the cool shade and started to think. I felt rested and quite relaxed, I was content with my life. I could see the sun through a few small holes, but the top was mostly covered by large tree branches, and the part underneath was a bit dim. In a few places where the light seeped through the branches, bright spots had formed, and from the slow movement of these spots, it was clear that there was a light breeze above. Two squirrels sat on a branch and chirped something to me in a very friendly manner.
es: THE SUN WAS already so high when I woke up that I thought it would be after eight. I lay in the grass in the cool shade, thinking about things and feeling rested and very comfortable and satisfied. The sun could be seen through one or two holes, but mostly there were large trees everywhere and among them many shadows. There were dappled spots on the ground where the light filtered through the leaves, and the dappled spots changed a bit, which showed that there was a slight breeze blowing. A couple of squirrels sat on a branch and chattered at me in a very friendly manner.

en: I was powerful lazy and comfortable—didn’t want to get up and cook breakfast. Well, I was dozing off again when I thinks I hears a deep sound of “boom!” away up the river. I rouses up, and rests on my elbow and listens; pretty soon I hears it again. I hopped up, and went and looked out at a hole in the leaves, and I see a bunch of smoke laying on the water a long ways up—about abreast the ferry. And there was the ferry-boat full of people floating along down. I knowed what was the matter now. “Boom!” I see the white smoke squirt out of the ferry-boat’s side. You see, they was firing cannon over the water, trying to make my carcass come to the top.
vi: I feel so comfortable and steady here that I become lazy and don't want to get up to cook a meal. But then, as I close my eyes to sleep again, I suddenly hear a boom outside by the river. I prop myself up on my elbows, listening intently. After a while, I hear another sound. I stand up and step out, looking outside through a gap in the bushes. A cloud of smoke spreads over the water, drifting farther away—perhaps all the way to the ferry dock. Then a boat full of people is coming down this way. Now I know what is happening. Boom! A puff of white smoke comes out from the boat. They are firing cannons into the river to make my body float to the surface.
tr: A great sense of ease and laziness had settled over me; I didn't even feel like getting up to prepare breakfast. Just as I was about to fall back asleep, I heard a deep "boom" sound far off, upstream of the river. I immediately propped myself up on my elbow and listened intently. Soon, there was another boom. I quickly jumped to my feet and went to look around through a gap in the branches and leaves. High above, a small puff of smoke was rising over the water – it was level with the dock. There was the steamboat, coming down filled with people. Now I understood what was going on. "Boom!" I saw another white cloud of smoke emerge from the side of the steamboat. They were firing the cannon to make my body rise to the surface of the water.
es: I felt very lazy and comfortable: I didn't want to get up to make breakfast. Well, I was about to go back to sleep when it seemed to me that I heard a "boom!" in the distance, upriver. I wake up and prop myself on my elbow and listen; immediately I hear it again. I jumped up and went to look through a gap between the leaves, and I see a lot of smoke above the water, very far upriver: approximately in front of the ferry. And there was the ferry, full of people, floating down. Then I understood what was happening. "Boom!" I saw the white smoke coming out of the side of the ferry. So, they were firing the cannon over the water, trying to make my corpse surface.

en: I was pretty hungry, but it warn’t going to do for me to start a fire, because they might see the smoke. So I set there and watched the cannon-smoke and listened to the boom. The river was a mile wide there, and it always looks pretty on a summer morning—so I was having a good enough time seeing them hunt for my remainders if I only had a bite to eat. Well, then I happened to think how they always put quicksilver in loaves of bread and float them off, because they always go right to the drownded carcass and stop there. So, says I, I’ll keep a lookout, and if any of them’s floating around after me I’ll give them a show. I changed to the Illinois edge of the island to see what luck I could have, and I warn’t disappointed. A big double loaf come along, and I most got it with a long stick, but my foot slipped and she floated out further. Of course I was where the current set in the closest to the shore—I knowed enough for that. But by-and-by along comes another one, and this time I won. I took out the plug and shook out the little dab of quicksilver, and set my teeth in. It was “baker’s bread”—what the quality eat; none of your low-down corn-pone.
vi: I was hungry, but I couldn't start a fire at that moment because they might see the smoke. So I had to sit there watching the cannon smoke and listening to the explosions. The river was wide and even more beautiful here. If there was anything to be curious about, I would sit there for a long time to see how they would search for my dead body. I wondered why people would put mercury into loaves of bread and let them float down the river, and then those loaves would stop exactly where there was a drowned body. I told myself to stay calm and see what happens; if I didn't see those loaves floating by to find me, I would reveal myself. I walked around the island to the Illinois shore to see if there was anything there. And I wasn't too disappointed. A large loaf of bread floated by. I used a long stick to pull it in, but I slipped, and the loaf floated away again. The spot where I was standing was where the current was closest to the shore, I knew that already. A while later, another loaf floated by, and this time I managed to catch it. I pried off the stopper, shook out the mercury, and then took a bite. Wow, it was a genuine piece of bread, very valuable, not like the miserable cornbread I had been eating before.
tr: I was very hungry, but I was hesitant to light a fire because they could see the smoke. So I settled down right there and watched the cannon smoke and listened to the "boom" sounds. The river was a mile wide there and always looked very beautiful on summer mornings – so their attempt to find my remains had turned into quite a spectacle, oh if only there was something to eat. Then I remembered that they floated loaves of bread with mercury in them on the river. The loaf would always stop over the drowned body. I thought, I’ll watch to see if they’ll float a loaf after me, and if they do, I’ll find a way to get it. I went to the side of the island facing Illinois and tried my luck and wasn’t disappointed. A huge double loaf came, and with the help of a long stick, I almost caught it, but I slipped and the loaf drifted away. Of course, I was where the current was closest to the shore; I knew this very well. But a little later, another loaf came, and this time I won. I opened the top of the loaf, removed the drop of mercury inside, and then started eating. It wasn’t one of our terrible corn breads but a "baked" bread – the kind respectable people eat.
es: I was quite hungry, but it was better not to make a fire, because they might see the smoke. So I sat there watching the smoke from the cannon and listening to the "boom." The river was a mile wide there and it always looks very beautiful on a summer morning, so I had a pretty good time watching them search for my remains, and all I was missing was something to eat. Well, then it occurred to me that they always put mercury in loaves of bread and let them float, because they usually go straight to where the drowned body is and stay there. So I said to myself, "I'll keep an eye out, and if one of them floats by close to me, I'll give it a try." I moved to the side of the island facing Illinois to see how lucky I would be, and it didn't go badly. A big loaf floated by and I almost grabbed it with a long stick, but my foot slipped and it kept floating. Of course, I was where the current came closest to the shore, because I knew that was the best spot. But after a while, another one came by, and this time I hooked it. I took out the plug to remove the little piece of mercury and took a bite. It was "baker's bread": the kind that fine people eat; not cheap corn bread.

en: I got a good place amongst the leaves, and set there on a log, munching the bread and watching the ferry-boat, and very well satisfied. And then something struck me. I says, now I reckon the widow or the parson or somebody prayed that this bread would find me, and here it has gone and done it. So there ain’t no doubt but there is something in that thing—that is, there’s something in it when a body like the widow or the parson prays, but it don’t work for me, and I reckon it don’t work for only just the right kind.
vi: I went looking for a good spot in the thick woods, sat on a log, chewing on some bread while watching the boat, feeling incredibly relaxed. Suddenly, I was startled; because at that moment I thought, what if the widow, or the schoolteacher, or someone had prayed for these pieces of bread to find me? If so, then there must be something in the bread. Meaning that when the widow's family or the schoolteacher prayed, it went into the bread? But I thought it probably wouldn't matter to me. And whatever it was, it would likely be something good for me anyway.
tr: I chose a good spot among the branches, sat on a log there, and enjoyed myself eating the bread and watching the steamboat. Then suddenly something came to my mind. The widow, the preacher, or someone else had prayed for this loaf to find me, and indeed it had come and found me. So there must have been something to this loaf business. That is, when the widow or the preacher prayed, it worked, but when people like me prayed, nothing happened; apparently, only the right people were heard when they prayed.
es: I found myself a good spot among the leaves and sat on a log, chewing the bread and watching the ferry, very happy. And then something occurred to me. I go and say: "Now I suppose the widow or the parson or someone has prayed for this bread to find me, and that's what happened. So there's no doubt that there's some truth to that story: that there's some truth when someone like the widow or the parson prays, but it doesn't work with me, and I suppose it only works with certain people."

en: I lit a pipe and had a good long smoke, and went on watching. The ferry-boat was floating with the current, and I allowed I’d have a chance to see who was aboard when she come along, because she would come in close, where the bread did. When she’d got pretty well along down towards me, I put out my pipe and went to where I fished out the bread, and laid down behind a log on the bank in a little open place. Where the log forked I could peep through.
vi: I lit a cigarette, took a long drag, and then sat back looking outside. The boat continued to follow the current, and I would have a chance to see clearly who was on it when it got closer to my spot. Because it would definitely come closer, just like the piece of bread that had floated to that point. When it got really close to me, I put out the cigarette and went back to the spot where I had fished out the piece of bread earlier. I lay down flat, hiding behind a log; this spot was a bit open, so I could peek out from a crack in the log.
tr: I continued to watch, enjoying myself for a long time while smoking my pipe. The steamboat was moving downstream with the current, and as it got closer, I would be able to see who was on the deck, because it was certain to come very close to where the bread was going. When the steamboat turned towards me, I put out my pipe and approached the spot where I had caught the bread, hiding behind a log in a small opening on the shore. I could watch without showing myself through a knot on the log.
es: I lit a pipe and spent a good while smoking while I continued watching. The ferry floated downstream and I thought I would have a chance to see who was on board when it got closer, because it would stay almost beside me, just like the bread had done. When they got close enough to me, I put out the pipe and went to where I had hooked the bread and hid behind a log on the riverbank in a small clearing. I could look through the part where the log forked.

en: By-and-by she come along, and she drifted in so close that they could a run out a plank and walked ashore. Most everybody was on the boat. Pap, and Judge Thatcher, and Bessie Thatcher, and Jo Harper, and Tom Sawyer, and his old Aunt Polly, and Sid and Mary, and plenty more. Everybody was talking about the murder, but the captain broke in and says:
vi: Then the boat came closer, so close that just throwing a plank could allow one to step ashore. Everyone was on the boat; my father, old man Thatcher, then Becky Thatcher's daughter, then Joe Harper, then Tom Sawyer, then Tom's Aunt Polly, then Sid, then Mary, and a few others. Everyone was discussing the murder case. But suddenly the boat owner said:
tr: The steamboat came very close and passed so near that it wouldn't have been difficult for them to throw a plank and come ashore. Almost everyone had gathered on the deck. My father, Judge Thatcher; Bessie Thatcher, Jo Harper; Tom Sawyer; his old aunt Polly, Sid and Mary, and many other familiar faces. Everyone was talking about the murder, but the captain silenced them with his loud voice, saying:
es: After a while they arrived, and the boat came so close that they could have laid down a plank to get ashore. Almost everyone was on the boat: father and Judge Thatcher and Becky Thatcher, and Joe Harper, and Tom Sawyer and his old Aunt Polly and Sid and Mary and many more. Everyone was talking about the murder, but the captain goes and interrupts them and says:

en: “Look sharp, now; the current sets in the closest here, and maybe he’s washed ashore and got tangled amongst the brush at the water’s edge. I hope so, anyway.”
vi: - Look closely, the water flows closest to the shore here, perhaps it drifted onto the land and got caught in some bush near the water's edge. I hope so.
tr: “Now look carefully. This is the place where the current is closest to the shore. Maybe it has washed ashore and got caught in the branches of the trees by the water. I hope we find it.”
es: —Pay attention now; this is where the current comes closest and maybe it has floated to the shore and is tangled in the weeds at the water's edge. At least, that's what I hope.

en: I didn’t hope so. They all crowded up and leaned over the rails, nearly in my face, and kept still, watching with all their might. I could see them first-rate, but they couldn’t see me. Then the captain sung out:
vi: But as for me, I didn't hope for that. The whole group leaned forward, sticking out from the side of the boat, right in front of me, and everyone silently watched attentively. I could see them very clearly, but they couldn't see me. Suddenly, the boat owner shouted: - Back off.
tr: I never expected it that way. They all suddenly crowded near the railing, almost close enough to look directly into my eyes, and without moving, they began to scan the shore with all their attention. I could see them all very clearly, but they couldn't see me. Then I heard the captain's voice:
es: I did not expect it. They all crowded together to look over the railing, and they almost hit me in the face, and they did nothing but look, look with all their might. I could see them perfectly, but they couldn't see me. Then the captain shouted: "Move aside!", and the cannon fired such a blast right next to me that it left me deaf from the noise and almost blind from the smoke, and I thought I was going to die.

en: “Stand away!” and the cannon let off such a blast right before me that it made me deef with the noise and pretty near blind with the smoke, and I judged I was gone. If they’d a had some bullets in, I reckon they’d a got the corpse they was after. Well, I see I warn’t hurt, thanks to goodness. The boat floated on and went out of sight around the shoulder of the island. I could hear the booming now and then, further and further off, and by-and-by, after an hour, I didn’t hear it no more. The island was three mile long. I judged they had got to the foot, and was giving it up. But they didn’t yet a while. They turned around the foot of the island and started up the channel on the Missouri side, under steam, and booming once in a while as they went. I crossed over to that side and watched them. When they got abreast the head of the island they quit shooting and dropped over to the Missouri shore and went home to the town.
vi: Then the sound of the cannon exploded right in front of me, making my ears deaf and my eyes almost blind from the gun smoke; I almost thought I was done for. If there had been real bullets in there, they would have found the body they were looking for. Thank God, I saw that I wasn't hurt at all. The boat continued on and disappeared around the bend of the island. Occasionally, I could still hear the booming sounds getting fainter, and then about an hour later, I couldn't hear anything anymore. The island was three miles long, and I guessed they had reached the other end and given up the search. But they continued. They went around the other end of the island and then followed the narrow stretch of the river up to the Missouri shore and then turned back.
tr: “Move aside a bit!” and the cannonball exploded right in front of me with such force that I was deafened by the noise and blinded by the smoke. For a moment, I thought I was dying. If there had been a cannonball inside the cannon, they would have finally found the corpse they were looking for. But thankfully, I wasn't injured. The steamboat continued on its way and disappeared from sight after passing the tip of the island. The occasional booms that were still heard gradually faded away, and after about an hour, I could no longer hear them at all. The island was three miles long. I thought they had gone to the end of the island and finally given up. But they still hadn't given up. After reaching the end of the island, they turned and entered the strait on the Missouri side; as the steamboat moved forward, it occasionally continued to boom, sending out puffs of smoke from its chimney. I also moved to that side and watched them. When they reached the level of the head of the island, they stopped firing the cannon, scanned the Missouri shore briefly, and then headed back towards the village.
es: Then the captain shouted: "Move aside!", and the cannon fired such a blast right next to me that it left me deaf from the noise and almost blind from the smoke, and I thought I was going to die. If they had put some charge in it, I reckon they would have gotten the corpse they were looking for. Well, I saw that I wasn't injured, thank God. The ship kept floating and disappeared around the tip of the island. From time to time I heard the cannon shots, getting farther and farther away, and after a while, about an hour or so, I couldn't hear them anymore. The island was three miles long. I thought they had reached the end and were giving up; but not yet. They circled the island and steamed up the river on the Missouri side, firing cannon shots now and then as they went. I went to that side and watched them. When they reached the other end of the island, they stopped firing and headed towards the Missouri shore and returned to the town.

en: I knowed I was all right now. Nobody else would come a-hunting after me. I got my traps out of the canoe and made me a nice camp in the thick woods. I made a kind of a tent out of my blankets to put my things under so the rain couldn’t get at them. I catched a catfish and haggled him open with my saw, and towards sundown I started my camp fire and had supper. Then I set out a line to catch some fish for breakfast.
vi: Well, now it was all quiet. No one was searching for me anymore. I took my belongings from the boat, set up a nice little resting spot in the thick trees. I used a blanket to make a small tent and put my belongings inside to keep them from getting wet in the rain. I caught a fish, used a saw blade to gut it, and waited until sunset to start my campfire to cook dinner. After that, I set a fishing line in the river so that I would have fish for breakfast the next morning.
tr: I knew I had finally gotten away. No one else would come looking for me. I took my belongings out of the canoe and set up a nice camp spot in the dense forest. I made something like a tent out of my blankets so the rain wouldn't reach my things. I caught a catfish, cut its belly open with a saw; then lit my campfire at sunset and had my dinner. Afterwards, I cast a line to catch some fish for breakfast.
es: Now I understood that I was already safe. Nobody was going to come looking for me. I took the traps out of the canoe and set up a good camp in the middle of the forest. I made a sort of tent with the blankets to put my things under it so they wouldn't get wet from the rain. I caught a catfish, opened it with the saw, and towards dusk, I lit my fire and had dinner. Then I cast a line to catch something for breakfast.

en: When it was dark I set by my camp fire smoking, and feeling pretty well satisfied; but by-and-by it got sort of lonesome, and so I went and set on the bank and listened to the current swashing along, and counted the stars and drift logs and rafts that come down, and then went to bed; there ain’t no better way to put in time when you are lonesome; you can’t stay so, you soon get over it.
vi: It was completely dark, I sat by the fire smoking and felt very interested. But gradually, I also felt how lonely it was, if I went to sit by the river listening to the murmuring water, looking up at the sky counting stars, then counting the branches and rafts drifting down from above; getting bored and then going to sleep. When to kill time. Can't sit still like that forever, it has to end soon somehow.
tr: When night fell, I started puffing on my stick by my campfire, I was very content with my situation; but then I gradually began to feel lonely, so I went and sat by the shore, listened to the bubbling flow of the water; I counted the stars, the drifting logs, and the rafts going downstream, then I lay down and slept; there is no better way to pass the time when you are alone; but you won't feel lonely for too long anyway, it passes with time.
es: When it got completely dark, I sat by the campfire, smoking, and felt very satisfied; but after a while, I started to feel lonely, so I went to sit by the riverbank to listen to the splashing of the water. I counted the stars and the logs drifting by and the rafts, and then I lay down; there is no better way to pass the time when one feels lonely; you can't continue like that, and after a while, it passes.

en: And so for three days and nights. No difference—just the same thing. But the next day I went exploring around down through the island.
