I was boss of it; it all belonged to me, so to say, and I wanted to know all about it; but mainly I wanted to put in the time. I found plenty strawberries, ripe and prime; and green summer grapes, and green razberries; and the green blackberries was just beginning to show. They would all come handy by-and-by, I judged.
vi: I kept living like that for three days and nights. Nothing changed. Everything remained the same. The next day, I searched around where I lived and went down to the lower part of the island. I was the master of the island. The whole island was mine, so to speak, and I wanted to know everything about this island in detail. Actually, it was just to pass the time. I found a lot of ripe and delicious berries, and even green summer grapes; the rice fruits were also starting to sprout, and eventually, it would be time to harvest them all.
tr: So, three days and three nights passed like this. There was nothing different; I was doing the same thing all the time. But the next day, I started to explore the island. One could say I was the master of the island; it all belonged to me; that's why I wanted to learn every inch of it; although what I really wanted was to find something to keep myself busy. I found plenty of strawberries, both ripe and delicious, then I found unripe grapes and raspberries, and also the blackberries had started to grow green and fleshy. In time, they would all become edible.
es: And so three days and nights passed. No change: always the same. But the next day I went to explore the whole island. I was the master; everything was mine, so to speak, and I wanted to know it entirely, but above all, I wanted to pass the time. I found heaps of strawberries, ripe and wonderful, and green summer grapes and green blackberries, and the blackberries were just starting to come out. I thought everything would come in very handy in time.

en: Well, I went fooling along in the deep woods till I judged I warn’t far from the foot of the island. I had my gun along, but I hadn’t shot nothing; it was for protection; thought I would kill some game nigh home. About this time I mighty near stepped on a good-sized snake, and it went sliding off through the grass and flowers, and I after it, trying to get a shot at it. I clipped along, and all of a sudden I bounded right on to the ashes of a camp fire that was still smoking.
vi: Just like that, I wandered deeper into the forest until I guessed that this place wasn't far from the other end of the island anymore. I had a gun in my hand but hadn't fired a single shot. The gun was just for self-defense, and I also thought I would shoot an animal near its den. At that moment, I almost stepped on a rather large snake, which slithered into the grass and flowers to escape. I chased after it, determined to shoot the snake. While I was in hot pursuit, I suddenly stumbled upon a pile of ashes from a campfire that was still smoldering.
tr: I wandered through the dense forest until I reached a place not too far from the edge of the island. My rifle was always by my side, but I hadn't shot anything; the rifle was for my protection; although if I were near the house, I would hunt something. Meanwhile, I almost stepped on a rather large snake, which slithered away through the grass and flowers, and I chased after it, thinking I might be able to shoot it. As I moved quickly, I suddenly found myself standing over the ashes of a campfire that was still smoking.
es: Well, I was entertaining myself inside the forest until it seemed to me that I was not far from the tip of the island. I had taken my shotgun, but I hadn't shot at anything; it was for protection; I thought I would find something to hunt near home. Then I almost stepped on a good-sized snake, which went slithering through the grass and flowers, and I went after it, trying to shoot it. I was making good progress when suddenly I came across the ashes of a campfire that was still smoking.

en: My heart jumped up amongst my lungs. I never waited for to look further, but uncocked my gun and went sneaking back on my tiptoes as fast as ever I could. Every now and then I stopped a second amongst the thick leaves and listened, but my breath come so hard I couldn’t hear nothing else. I slunk along another piece further, then listened again; and so on, and so on. If I see a stump, I took it for a man; if I trod on a stick and broke it, it made me feel like a person had cut one of my breaths in two and I only got half, and the short half, too.
vi: My heart seemed to leap in my chest. I didn't wait to see anything else, I slowly lowered my gun and quietly tiptoed backward, retreating very quickly. Occasionally stopping for a second in the thick foliage and listening; but my breath was so loud that my ears couldn't hear anything. I took a deep breath, then listened again; then took another breath. Seeing a fallen tree trunk, I thought there was someone. Stepping on a dry branch that snapped with a crack, I felt as if someone had cut my breath in half, and I could only hold onto a very short half-breath.
tr: I was bewildered. I didn't linger to scout the surroundings, I cocked the rifle and tiptoed back as quickly as possible. From time to time, I would stop among the dense branches and listen around, but I was breathing so loudly from excitement that I couldn't hear anything else. After walking a bit, I stopped again to listen to the surroundings, then again, and again. If I saw a tree stump, I thought it was a man; if I stepped on a branch and it broke, it felt as if someone had cut my breath in half and left me with the shorter half.
es: My heart jumped between my lungs. I didn't wait to keep looking further; instead, I assembled the shotgun and tiptoed as fast as I could in silence. From time to time, I would stop for a moment among the leaves and listen, but I was breathing so hard that I couldn't hear anything else. I kept moving forward a bit and listened again, and so on, over and over. If I saw a stump, I thought it was a man; if I stepped on a twig and broke it, I felt as if someone had cut my breath in two and I was left with only half, and the shorter half at that.

en: When I got to camp I warn’t feeling very brash, there warn’t much sand in my craw; but I says, this ain’t no time to be fooling around. So I got all my traps into my canoe again so as to have them out of sight, and I put out the fire and scattered the ashes around to look like an old last year’s camp, and then clumb a tree.
vi: Returning to the tent, I felt uneasy. I felt that I was no longer as bold as before. But I told myself: there is no time to wander around. Then I moved all the belongings down to the boat so that no one would see them. I extinguished the fire, scattered the ashes around to make it look like an old fire from last year, then I climbed up a tree and sat.
tr: When I arrived at the camp, I had neither my vitality nor my boldness left; I had somewhat lost my former determination, but now is not the time to dawdle or get lost in thoughts, I told myself. Therefore, after packing all my belongings back into my canoe and hiding it from sight, extinguishing the fire and scattering the ashes to create the appearance of an old campsite, I climbed up a tree.
es: When I arrived at the camp, I didn't feel very calm or very brave, but I went and said: "This is no time to fool around." So I put all my traps back in the canoe so no one could see them, put out the campfire and scattered the ashes around to make it look like an old camp from last year, and then I climbed up a tree.

en: I reckon I was up in the tree two hours; but I didn’t see nothing, I didn’t hear nothing—I only thought I heard and seen as much as a thousand things. Well, I couldn’t stay up there forever; so at last I got down, but I kept in the thick woods and on the lookout all the time. All I could get to eat was berries and what was left over from breakfast.
vi: I guess I've been sitting on the tree for several hours, seeing nothing and hearing nothing else. But in my mind, it felt like I had seen and heard thousands of things. Well, I couldn't stay on the tree like that forever. After that, I slid down and remained among the dense trees, always keeping an eye out. I had only eaten a few fruits from the tree and some leftover food from breakfast.
tr: I probably stayed at the top of the tree for about two hours; but I saw nothing, I heard nothing – I only thought I saw or heard thousands of things. I couldn't stay at the top of the tree forever; so finally, I came down, but I was stuck among the dense trees and constantly watched my surroundings. There was only a bit of fruit and leftovers from breakfast as food.
es: I think I spent two hours in the tree, but I didn't see anything. I didn't hear anything; it just seemed to me that I had heard and seen at least a thousand things. Well, I couldn't stay there forever either, so I finally got down, but I remained in the center of the forest and alert the whole time. I couldn't eat anything but blackberries and what was left of breakfast.

en: By the time it was night I was pretty hungry. So when it was good and dark I slid out from shore before moonrise and paddled over to the Illinois bank—about a quarter of a mile. I went out in the woods and cooked a supper, and I had about made up my mind I would stay there all night when I hear a plunkety-plunk, plunkety-plunk, and says to myself, horses coming; and next I hear people’s voices. I got everything into the canoe as quick as I could, and then went creeping through the woods to see what I could find out. I hadn’t got far when I hear a man say:
vi: It was already night by then. My stomach was growling with hunger. Waiting until it was completely dark, I slipped out from the shore, before the moon rose, and pushed the boat towards the Illinois shore, about half a mile away. I went into the forest to cook dinner and planned to stay there all night. Suddenly, I heard a clattering sound. I told myself: there are horses coming. Then, there were voices. I quickly loaded everything back onto the boat, then went back into the forest to see if I could spot anything. After crawling a few steps, I heard someone speak:
tr: In the evening, I was very hungry. So, I waited for the darkest moment and rowed away from the shore towards the Illinois coast, a quarter mile away, before the moon rose. I went into the forest, cooked some food, and had decided to stay there all night when I heard the clattering sounds of horses approaching; soon after, I also heard human voices. After hurriedly loading everything onto the canoe, I crawled through the forest to see what was happening. Before I could go any further, I heard a man's voice:
es: When it got really dark, I was quite hungry, so when it was completely dark, I silently slipped into the water before the moon came out and paddled to the Illinois shore: about a quarter of a mile. I went into the woods, cooked myself something for dinner, and had practically decided to spend the whole night there when I heard a clip-clop and thought that horses were coming; and then I heard people's voices. I put everything in the canoe as quickly as I could and crawled through the woods to see if I could find out anything. I hadn't gone far when I heard someone say:

en: “We better camp here if we can find a good place; the horses is about beat out. Let’s look around.”
vi: - If we can find a good spot, we should stop here; the horses are very tired. Let's look around here.
tr: “If we find a good spot, let's camp here; the horses are very tired. Let's explore the surroundings.”
es: —We better camp here if we find a good spot; the horses are very tired. Let's take a look.

en: I didn’t wait, but shoved out and paddled away easy. I tied up in the old place, and reckoned I would sleep in the canoe.
vi: I no longer waited for anything, the sky receded and I immediately pushed the boat away. I tied the boat back to its old spot and intended to sleep under the boat.
tr: I didn't wait at all, I immediately set off and rowed away comfortably. I returned to my old spot, tied up the canoe, and decided that the best thing to do was to sleep inside it.
es: I didn't wait, but moved away and began to leave silently. I went back to tie up at the previous spot and figured I would sleep in the canoe.

en: I didn’t sleep much. I couldn’t, somehow, for thinking. And every time I waked up I thought somebody had me by the neck. So the sleep didn’t do me no good. By-and-by I says to myself, I can’t live this way; I’m a-going to find out who it is that’s here on the island with me; I’ll find it out or bust. Well, I felt better right off.
vi: I couldn't sleep much. Moreover, I couldn't sleep because I had to think. Every time I suddenly woke up, I felt as if someone was coming to grab my neck. So sleeping was of no use. Gradually, I told myself that I couldn't live like this, I had to find out who the person coming to live on this island with me was. I would find out, otherwise, I had to escape. I thought it would be better to do it right away.
tr: I couldn't sleep much. My thoughts were not giving me peace. Moreover, every time I woke up, I thought someone was grabbing my neck. Therefore, it can't really be said that I got enough sleep. I had slowly started to understand that I couldn't live like this anymore; I had to find out who else was on the island besides me; either I would find out or I would burst from curiosity. This firm decision brought me some relief.
es: I didn't sleep much. I don't know why, but I couldn't, because I was thinking. And every time I woke up, I thought someone was grabbing me by the neck. So the sleep was of no use to me. After a while, I go and tell myself: "I can't keep living like this; I'm going to find out who is on the island with me; either I find out or I die." Well, I immediately felt better.

en: So I took my paddle and slid out from shore just a step or two, and then let the canoe drop along down amongst the shadows. The moon was shining, and outside of the shadows it made it most as light as day. I poked along well on to an hour, everything still as rocks and sound asleep. Well, by this time I was most down to the foot of the island. A little ripply, cool breeze begun to blow, and that was as good as saying the night was about done. I give her a turn with the paddle and brung her nose to shore; then I got my gun and slipped out and into the edge of the woods. I sat down there on a log, and looked out through the leaves. I see the moon go off watch, and the darkness begin to blanket the river. But in a little while I see a pale streak over the treetops, and knowed the day was coming. So I took my gun and slipped off towards where I had run across that camp fire, stopping every minute or two to listen. But I hadn’t no luck somehow; I couldn’t seem to find the place. But by-and-by, sure enough, I catched a glimpse of fire away through the trees. I went for it, cautious and slow. By-and-by I was close enough to have a look, and there laid a man on the ground. It most give me the fan-tods. He had a blanket around his head, and his head was nearly in the fire. I set there behind a clump of bushes, in about six foot of him, and kept my eyes on him steady. It was getting gray daylight now. Pretty soon he gapped and stretched himself and hove off the blanket, and it was Miss Watson’s Jim! I bet I was glad to see him. I says:
vi: Then I pushed the boat away from the shore a bit, and just let it drift downstream. The moon was shining brightly. Except for the places with shadows, the moonlight illuminated everything as if it were daytime. I paddled the boat for about an hour; everything was silent and asleep like stones. This time, I had reached the other end of the island. A gentle, cool breeze began to blow. This meant that the night was almost over. I kicked the water with my foot, turned the boat around, and headed towards the edge of the forest. I sat down on a fallen tree trunk, looking through the leaves. The moon had disappeared, and darkness once again covered the river. But after a while, looking up through the treetops and seeing a faint light, I knew that dawn was approaching. I took my gun and quietly approached the spot where I had seen the campfire earlier. Every minute or two, I stopped to listen. But unfortunately, I couldn't find any sign of the fire. I slowly and carefully walked to that spot. When I arrived, I saw someone lying on the ground. I thought it was a ghost. The person lying there had wrapped a piece of blanket around their head and was resting right next to the fire. I stood silently behind the bushes, about a meter away from where that person was lying, and stared intently. The sky was getting light. A moment later, the person yawned, stretched, and threw off the blanket. Oh, it turned out to be Jim, the black man who worked for Miss Watson. I was really glad to see Jim here. I spoke up:
tr: So I took the paddle and moved a few steps away from the shore, then the canoe already got caught in the current and started moving through the shadows. The moon was shining and everywhere outside the shadows was lit up like daytime. I drifted for an hour, but everything was as still as a rock and in a state of complete sleep. Meanwhile, I had reached the far end of the island. A calm and cool breeze started to blow, indicating that the night was about to end. I used the paddle to turn the canoe and pressed its nose against the shore; then I got out of the canoe, took my rifle, and plunged into the forest. I sat on a log and looked at the sky through the leaves. I saw that the moon had finished its watch and the darkness was starting to cover the river like a blanket. But soon a pale line appearing at the tops of the trees indicated that the day was coming. So I took my rifle and quietly moved towards the place where I saw the campfire, stopping every two minutes to listen around. But my luck wasn't very good, I couldn't find the place where the fire was. Then, after a while, a fire burning among the trees caught my eye. I approached there very carefully and slowly. Finally, I got close enough to take a look and saw a man lying on the ground. I started trembling with fear. He had pulled the blanket over his head and his head was almost in the fire. I crouched behind the bushes about one and a half to two meters away and started watching him without taking my eyes off. The air had turned a bit gray and was gradually getting lighter. Soon the man yawned, stretched, and pulled off the blanket, it was Miss Watson's black slave Jim in front of me! I had never been so happy to see him. Jumping out from the bushes, I said, "What's up, Jim!"
es: So I grabbed the paddle and went down just one or two steps from the shore, and then let the canoe drift into the shadows on its own. The moon was shining, and where there was no shadow it was almost like daylight. I was searching for almost an hour, in a silence like a tomb, while everything slept. Well, by then I had almost reached the tip of the island. A gentle, rippling, and fresh breeze started to blow, which meant that the night was about to end. I gave a stroke of the paddle and brought the canoe to the shore; then I took out the shotgun and slipped to the edge of the forest. There I sat on a log, looking through the leaves. I saw that the moon was finishing its shift and that the river was starting to get dark. But after a while, I saw a pale strip above the trees and knew that day was coming. So I took out the shotgun and advanced to where I had found that campfire, stopping to listen every minute or two. But I don't know why I wasn't lucky; it was as if I couldn't find the place. But after a while, finally, I saw a remnant of the fire's glow among the trees. I went towards it, very carefully and calmly. Soon after, I was close enough to take a look, and there was a man lying on the ground. It almost gave me a fit. He had his head wrapped in a blanket, right next to the fire. I sat next to some bushes about six feet from him, staring at him. It was already starting to get light with the gray of dawn. Soon after, he yawned, stretched, and took off the blanket, and it was Jim, Miss Watson's Jim! Boy, was I glad to see him! I go and say:

en: “Hello, Jim!” and skipped out.
vi: - Hello Jim! Then jumped out suddenly.
tr: Jumping out from the bushes, I said, "What's up, Jim!"
es: —Hi, Jim! —and I jumped out.

en: He bounced up and stared at me wild. Then he drops down on his knees, and puts his hands together and says:
vi: Jim started and jumped up, looking at me in horror. Then he knelt down, clasped his hands, and said:
tr: Suddenly, he flinched and looked at me in horror. Then he dropped to his knees, clasped his hands together, and began to plead:
es: He stood up abruptly and looked at me with wide eyes. Then he dropped to his knees, clasped his hands, and said:

en: “Doan’ hurt me—don’t! I hain’t ever done no harm to a ghos’. I alwuz liked dead people, en done all I could for ’em. You go en git in de river agin, whah you b’longs, en doan’ do nuffn to Ole Jim, ’at ’uz awluz yo’ fren’.”
vi: - Please don't do anything to me, don't! I never harm ghosts. I always love the dead, and whatever I can do for them, I will gladly do. Please go back to the river. Where did you come from, please don't do anything to poor Jim. I've always been your friend!
tr: “Don't hurt me – please! I swear I haven't even hurt a fly. I have always loved the dead, and I did everything I could for them. Go, return to the riverbank, your home is there. Don't hurt poor Jim, he has been your friend.”
es: —Don't hurt me, please! I've never harmed a ghost. I've always been a friend to the dead and done what I could for them. Go back to the river again, which is your place, and don't do anything to old Jim, who has always been your friend.

en: Well, I warn’t long making him understand I warn’t dead. I was ever so glad to see Jim. I warn’t lonesome now. I told him I warn’t afraid of him telling the people where I was. I talked along, but he only set there and looked at me; never said nothing. Then I says:
vi: I also didn't have to spend much time explaining to him that I wasn't dead. I was so happy to meet Jim here. Now I am no longer lonely. I told him that if he went and told everyone that I was here, I wouldn't be afraid. I kept talking, but he just sat there looking at me without saying a word. Then I told him.
tr: It didn't take me long to convince him that I wasn't dead. Besides, I was so happy to see Jim that I could hardly contain myself. I no longer felt alone. I told him that I wasn't the least bit afraid of him telling people where I was. I kept talking and talking, but he just sat there watching me; he didn't say a word. So I changed the subject:
es: Well, it didn't take long for me to make him understand that I wasn't dead. He was very happy to see Jim. I no longer felt alone. I told him that I wasn't afraid of him telling people where he had seen me. I kept talking, but he continued sitting there, looking at me, without saying a single word. Then I go and say:

en: “It’s good daylight. Le’s get breakfast. Make up your camp fire good.”
vi: - It's morning already. Let's have a light meal. Light the fire. - Why start a fire?
tr: "It's getting quite bright." "Let's have breakfast." "Stoke the fire a bit.""
es: —It's already daytime. Let's go look for breakfast. Stoke the fire well.

en: “What’s de use er makin’ up de camp fire to cook strawbries en sich truck? But you got a gun, hain’t you? Den we kin git sumfn better den strawbries.”
vi: To roast some strawberries and wild herbs here? But you have a gun, don't you? We can find something better to eat than strawberries, my friend!
tr: “What good is it to light a fire when there's nothing but strawberries and grass to cook? You have a gun, right? We can eat something better than strawberries.”
es: —What good is it to stoke the fire to cook strawberries and things like that? But you have a shotgun, don't you? That way we can eat something better than strawberries.

en: “Strawberries and such truck,” I says. “Is that what you live on?”
vi: We can find something better to eat than strawberries, my friend! - Dậu with wild vegetables, oh so you live on those things?
tr: “Strawberries and grass?” I said. “Were you only eating these?”
es: —Strawberries and things like that —I go and say—. Are you living off that?

en: “I couldn’ git nuffn else,” he says.
vi: - I couldn't find anything else
tr: "I couldn't find anything else," he said.
es: —It's the only thing I can find —he says.

en: “Why, how long you been on the island, Jim?”
vi: - Oh, so how long have you been on this island?
tr: “Why, how long have you been on the island, Jim?”
es: —But, how long have you been on the island, Jim?

en: “I come heah de night arter you’s killed.”
vi: - I came here right after the night you were killed!
tr: “I came to the bull the night you died.”
es: —The night comes after they killed you.

en: “What, all that time?”
vi: - Really, since that day until now?
tr: “What, since then?”
es: —How, so long?

en: “Yes—indeedy.”
vi: - Yes, that's right
tr: “Yeah… it really is like that.”
es: —Yes, sir.

en: “And ain’t you had nothing but that kind of rubbage to eat?”
vi: - So, you must be starving to death, right?
tr: “Since that day, have you only been eating grass and berries?”
es: —And you haven't eaten anything other than those things?

en: “No, sah—nuffn else.”
vi: - So, you must be starving to death, right?
tr: “There isn't, master… there's nothing else.”
es: —No, sir; nothing else.

en: “Well, you must be most starved, ain’t you?”
vi: - So, you must be starving to death, right?
tr: "So, you must be starving now, am I wrong?""
es: —Well, you must be starving, right?

en: “I reck’n I could eat a hoss. I think I could. How long you ben on de islan’?”
vi: - If I think about it now, I can eat a lot. Alright, buddy. So, how long have you been on this island?
tr: “Honestly, I could even eat a horse. I'm that hungry. How long have you been on the island?”
es: —I reckon I could devour a horse. Really, I could. How long have you been on the island?

en: “Since the night I got killed.”
vi: - From the night I was killed
tr: "Since the night I was killed.""
es: —Since the night they killed me.

en: “No! W’y, what has you lived on? But you got a gun. Oh, yes, you got a gun. Dat’s good. Now you kill sumfn en I’ll make up de fire.”
vi: - Oh, why is that? Then what do you live on? Ah, but you have a gun. Yes, you have a gun. That's very good. Now you go shoot something, and I'll stay here and start a fire.
tr: “Wow! So, what did you eat? Burp, you have a gun. It's different with a gun, yeah. How nice. Come on, you shoot something, and I'll light the fire.”
es: —No! And, what have you lived on? But you have a shotgun. Ah, yes, you have a shotgun. That's very good. Now you kill something and I'll make a fire.

en: So we went over to where the canoe was, and while he built a fire in a grassy open place amongst the trees, I fetched meal and bacon and coffee, and coffee-pot and frying-pan, and sugar and tin cups, and the nigger was set back considerable, because he reckoned it was all done with witchcraft. I catched a good big catfish, too, and Jim cleaned him with his knife, and fried him.
vi: Both of us went to the place where the canoe was hidden. Then, while Jim started a fire on a patch of grass among the surrounding trees, I went to get the bacon and coffee, the coffee pot; the pan, then the sugar, and the tin cups. The black man was very frightened because he thought that all these things were the result of some witchcraft. I caught a big fish, and Jim used his pocket knife to clean it and then fried it.
tr: So we went to where the cannon was, and while we were lighting a fire in a grassy area among those trees, I quickly took out cornmeal, bacon, coffee, a coffee pot, a pan, sugar, and a tin cup. Jim was astonished because he thought I had done it all by magic. I also caught a big catfish, and Jim cleaned it with his knife and fried the fish.
es: So we went to where the canoe was, and while he was setting up the bonfire in a clearing in the grass among the trees, I went to get flour and bacon and coffee, and a coffee pot and a pan and sugar and some tin cups, and the black man was very astonished, because he thought I did everything by witchcraft. I also caught a good catfish and Jim cleaned it with his knife and fried it.

en: When breakfast was ready we lolled on the grass and eat it smoking hot. Jim laid it in with all his might, for he was most about starved. Then when we had got pretty well stuffed, we laid off and lazied. By-and-by Jim says:
vi: After finishing, we just lay on the grass and ate a hot breakfast. Jim ate vigorously because he was extremely hungry. Once full, we sprawled out, not wanting to do anything else. Then Jim said:
tr: When breakfast was ready, we settled on the grass and ate it hot. Jim was stuffing everything into his mouth because he was about to die of hunger. After filling our stomachs well, we lay down and relaxed. A little later, Jim asked:
es: When breakfast was ready, we lay down on the grass and ate it while it was still warm. Jim started eating with great appetite, as he was half dead from hunger. When we were full, we rested and lay down. Shortly after, Jim goes and says:

en: “But looky here, Huck, who wuz it dat ’uz killed in dat shanty ef it warn’t you?”
vi: - But hey, Huck, if it wasn't you, then who was killed in that house?
tr: "If you weren't the one who died in that cabin, then who was it, Huck?"
es: —But, hey, Huck, who did they kill in the cabin if it wasn't you?

en: Then I told him the whole thing, and he said it was smart. He said Tom Sawyer couldn’t get up no better plan than what I had. Then I says:
vi: At that moment, I recounted the whole story to him; he said it was truly ingenious. He said that even Tom Sawyer couldn't come up with a trick better than mine. I asked:
tr: I told her everything, she said it was clever. Even Tom Sawyer couldn't come up with a better plan than mine. Then I asked:
es: Then I told him the whole story and he said that I had been very clever. He said that Tom Sawyer couldn't come up with a better plan than mine. Then I go and say:

en: “How do you come to be here, Jim, and how’d you get here?”
vi: - Jim, how did you end up here, and how did you get here?
tr: “So why did you come here, Jim, and how did you get here?”
es: —And how is it that you're here, Jim, how did you get here?

en: He looked pretty uneasy, and didn’t say nothing for a minute. Then he says:
vi: He seemed puzzled for a minute, saying nothing, then he replied:
tr: First, he lost his composure and didn't know what to say. Then he spoke:
es: He seemed to get nervous and didn't say anything for a minute. Then he goes and says:

en: “Maybe I better not tell.”
vi: - Perhaps I shouldn't say anything, my friend
tr: "Maybe it's better if I don't say it.""
es: —Maybe it's better if I don't tell you.

en: “Why, Jim?”
vi: - What's wrong, Jim?
tr: "Why, Jim?"
es: —Why, Jim?

en: “Well, dey’s reasons. But you wouldn’ tell on me ef I uz to tell you, would you, Huck?”
vi: - For many reasons. But if I tell you, you mustn't tell anyone else, Huck!
tr: "Well, it's because of the reason." "But if you don't tell anyone, I'll tell you, okay?""
es: —Well, there are reasons. But you wouldn't snitch if I told you, would you, Huck?

en: “Blamed if I would, Jim.”
vi: - Jim, I swear I won't tell anyone
tr: “If I'm lying, may I lose my eyesight.””
es: —Not by these, Jim.

en: “Well, I b’lieve you, Huck. I—I run off.”
vi: - Alright, I trust you. I... I'm going to run away.
tr: “Alright, I believe you, Huck. I… ran away.”
es: —Well, I believe you, Huck. I... I have escaped.

en: “Jim!”
vi: - Jim!
tr: “Jim!””
es: —Jim!

en: “But mind, you said you wouldn’ tell—you know you said you wouldn’ tell, Huck.”
vi: - See, you said you wouldn't tell. You remember you promised not to tell anyone, Huck.
tr: “Remember, you said you wouldn't tell anyone... you know, you weren't supposed to tell anyone, Huck.”
es: —But remember you said you wouldn't tell... you know you said you wouldn't tell, Huck.

en: “Well, I did. I said I wouldn’t, and I’ll stick to it. Honest injun, I will. People would call me a low-down Abolitionist and despise me for keeping mum—but that don’t make no difference. I ain’t a-going to tell, and I ain’t a-going back there, anyways. So, now, le’s know all about it.”
vi: - Yes, I already said that. I said I wouldn't talk, and I won't talk. I will keep my promise. Even if people call me a coward, an anti-Black oppression sympathizer, and despise me for keeping my mouth shut, it's fine, it doesn't matter. I will not speak. And I won't go back there either. Now, you tell me everything.
tr: “Alright, I said. I won't tell anyone, I said, and I won't. Really, I will never go back. Everyone will say that I am a lowly anti-slavery person, they will hate me for staying silent… but it doesn't matter at all. I won't tell anyone anything, and I won't go back there anyway. Yes, now tell me everything from the beginning.”
es: —Well, it's true. I said no and I stand by it. Really, truly. People will call me a damn abolitionist and despise me for not saying anything, but I don't care. I'm not going to accuse you and anyway, I'm never going back there. So now tell me everything.

en: “Well, you see, it ’uz dis way. Ole missus—dat’s Miss Watson—she pecks on me all de time, en treats me pooty rough, but she awluz said she wouldn’ sell me down to Orleans. But I noticed dey wuz a nigger trader roun’ de place considable lately, en I begin to git oneasy. Well, one night I creeps to de do’ pooty late, en de do’ warn’t quite shet, en I hear old missus tell de widder she gwyne to sell me down to Orleans, but she didn’ want to, but she could git eight hund’d dollars for me, en it ’uz sich a big stack o’ money she couldn’ resis’. De widder she try to git her to say she wouldn’ do it, but I never waited to hear de res’. I lit out mighty quick, I tell you.
vi: Here, like this, buddy. My aunt, that is Mrs. Watson, keeps tormenting me all day and treating me terribly. But she still says she won't take me down to Orleans to sell me. But I noticed that there was a new black slave trader around here last night, and I started to get scared. Then one late night, I crawled to the door, which wasn't fully closed, and I heard her telling the widow that she would take me to Orleans to sell, but she didn't want to sell me right away because she could still get eight hundred dollars more for me. With such a large amount of money, she probably couldn't resist. The widow wanted to tell her not to do that. But at that moment, I didn't wait to hear what happened next. I ran away quickly. I'm telling you the truth.
tr: “Alright, here’s how it happened. My owner, that is, Miss Watson, was constantly scolding me and treating me badly, but she always said, ‘I won’t sell you to those folks in Orleans.’ But in recent days, I noticed a slave trader wandering around our place, and I started to get suspicious. Anyway, one night, late at night, as I was passing by a door left ajar, I heard our old master telling the widow that he was going to sell me to those folks in Orleans; he didn’t actually want to sell me, but he could get eight hundred dollars for me, which was too much money to resist. The widow tried to talk him out of it, but I didn’t stay to hear more. I ran away immediately, just like that.
es: —Well, look, it happened like this. The old maid, that is, Miss Watson, spends her time picking on me and treats me very badly, but she always said she wouldn't sell me in Orleans. But I noticed that there was a slave trader who spent a lot of time around the house, and I started to get nervous. Well, one night I go up to the door very late, and the door wasn't completely closed, and I hear the old maid telling the widow that she's going to sell me in Orleans, even though she didn't want to, but that she could get eight hundred dollars for me, and it was so much money that she couldn't resist. The widow tried to make her promise not to, but I didn't wait to hear the rest. I assure you, I left as fast as I could.

en: “I tuck out en shin down de hill, en ’spec to steal a skift ’long de sho’ som’ers ’bove de town, but dey wuz people a-stirring yit, so I hid in de ole tumble-down cooper-shop on de bank to wait for everybody to go ’way. Well, I wuz dah all night. Dey wuz somebody roun’ all de time. ’Long ’bout six in de mawnin’ skifts begin to go by, en ’bout eight er nine every skift dat went ’long wuz talkin’ ’bout how yo’ pap come over to de town en say you’s killed. Dese las’ skifts wuz full o’ ladies en genlmen a-goin’ over for to see de place. Sometimes dey’d pull up at de sho’ en take a res’ b’fo’ dey started acrost, so by de talk I got to know all ’bout de killin’. I ’uz powerful sorry you’s killed, Huck, but I ain’t no mo’ now.
vi: I ate a hearty meal and then hurried down the hill, hoping to steal a boat somewhere along the riverbank in town, but there were too many people around, so I had to hide in the old ruined tavern by the river to wait for everyone to leave. I had to wait until the end of the year. There were always people around. Around six o'clock, boats started passing by, and all I could hear was talk about your father going to town to report that you had been killed. The boats that followed were all carrying distinguished gentlemen and ladies going to the scene to investigate. Occasionally, they would dock their boats to rest for a while before continuing on. So, by listening to their conversations, I learned the whole story about the murder. When I heard you were really killed, I was heartbroken, Huck. But now, I am no longer heartbroken.
tr: I went down the slope, intending to steal a boat and then go upstream along the shore, but the surroundings were very crowded, so I hid in the old fisherman's shop by the shore and waited for everyone to leave. I stayed there all night. People were constantly running around the area. Around six in the morning, boats started crossing the river, and by eight or nine, everyone in the boats was talking about your father coming to town and saying you were dead. The last boat that passed was full of gentlemen and ladies going to see the crime scene. Some were pulling their boats ashore, resting a bit, and then setting off again; that’s how I learned everything about the ‘murder’. I was very sad because you died, Huck, but now there's no reason to be sad anymore.
es: »I dashed downhill, hoping to steal a boat on the shore somewhere upstream from the town, but there were still people awake, so I hid in the old cooper's workshop, which is half-collapsed on the shore, to wait for everyone to leave. Well, I spent the night there. There was always someone around. Around six in the morning, boats started passing by, and by eight or nine, all the boats that passed were saying that your father had come to town to say you had been killed. The last boats were full of ladies and gentlemen who were going to see the place. Sometimes they would tie up at the shore to rest before starting the crossing, and I found out about your death from what they were saying. I felt very sorry that you had been killed, Huck, but not anymore.

en: “I laid dah under de shavin’s all day. I ’uz hungry, but I warn’t afeard; bekase I knowed ole missus en de widder wuz goin’ to start to de camp-meet’n’ right arter breakfas’ en be gone all day, en dey knows I goes off wid de cattle ’bout daylight, so dey wouldn’ ’spec to see me roun’ de place, en so dey wouldn’ miss me tell arter dark in de evenin’. De yuther servants wouldn’ miss me, kase dey’d shin out en take holiday soon as de ole folks ’uz out’n de way.
vi: All day long I have to hide here like this. I'm hungry but I'm not afraid. Because I know that Mrs. Watson and the widow will go check on that right after breakfast. That will take the whole day. And they also know that during the day I am out herding cattle, so they won't see me around here, and if they ask about me, they'll have to wait until nightfall. As for the other workers, no one needs me for anything, and as soon as the owners leave the house, they also sneak off to rest.
tr: I hid and stayed in the rubble all day. My ox-cart was hungry, but I wasn't afraid, because I knew that my old master and the widow would go to the church meeting right after breakfast and wouldn't return all day, and they thought I had gone to herd the cattle early in the morning, so they didn't expect to see me around, and therefore wouldn't notice my absence until it got dark. The other servants wouldn't notice my absence either, because as soon as the old ladies left, they would all scatter and become invisible in the courtyard.
es: "I stayed hidden there all day, under the shavings and sawdust. I was hungry, but not scared, because I knew the old maid and the widow were going to the camp sermon shortly after breakfast and would be gone all day, and they knew I went out with the cattle at dawn, so they wouldn't expect to see me around the house and wouldn't miss me until after dark. The other servants wouldn't either, because they were going to go partying as soon as the old women were out of the house.

en: “Well, when it come dark I tuck out up de river road, en went ’bout two mile er more to whah dey warn’t no houses. I’d made up my mine ’bout what I’s agwyne to do. You see, ef I kep’ on tryin’ to git away afoot, de dogs ’ud track me; ef I stole a skift to cross over, dey’d miss dat skift, you see, en dey’d know ’bout whah I’d lan’ on de yuther side, en whah to pick up my track. So I says, a raff is what I’s arter; it doan’ make no track.
vi: It was dusk when I finally ventured out; I walked along the riverbank and after a few miles reached a place with no houses at all. I had already carefully planned in my mind what I was going to do. You see, if I just kept walking, dogs could track me down by scent; if I stole a boat to cross the river, they would notice the missing boat, figure out where I crossed, and then trace my footprints. So I thought using a raft would be the best option, as it wouldn't leave any traces.
tr: When the weather cleared, I went up the road along the riverbank, and about two miles up, I came to a place with no houses. After that, I made a definite decision about what to do next. I continued to run on foot, then the dogs started chasing me; if I were to steal a boat and cross to the other side, they would notice the absence of the boat and realize that I had crossed to the other side. Thus, they would find my trail.
es: "Well, when it got dark, I went up the river road, about two miles or more until there were no more houses." "I had decided what I was going to do." "I mean, if I tried to escape on foot, the dogs would find me; if I stole a boat to cross, it would be missed, you understand, and they would know I was going to the other side and where to look for my trail." "So I say: 'What I need is a raft; that leaves no tracks.'"

en: “I see a light a-comin’ roun’ de p’int bymeby, so I wade’ in en shove’ a log ahead o’ me en swum more’n half way acrost de river, en got in ’mongst de drift-wood, en kep’ my head down low, en kinder swum agin de current tell de raff come along. Den I swum to de stern uv it en tuck a-holt. It clouded up en ’uz pooty dark for a little while. So I clumb up en laid down on de planks. De men ’uz all ’way yonder in de middle, whah de lantern wuz. De river wuz a-risin’, en dey wuz a good current; so I reck’n’d ’at by fo’ in de mawnin’ I’d be twenty-five mile down de river, en den I’d slip in jis b’fo’ daylight en swim asho’, en take to de woods on de Illinois side.
vi: Then at that moment, a light shone, and I grabbed a floating plank in front of me, swimming out to the middle of the river; I blended in with the driftwood floating on the river, pulled my neck back, and kept swimming downstream for a long distance along with the floating rafts. Then I kept swimming like that, pulling in a few more logs with the plank for security. At that time, the clouds gathered and darkened the sky for a while. I climbed up and lay on the plank in the area where the light was still on and people were passing by. The river water was rising rapidly and flowing swiftly. I estimated that by around four in the morning, I would have floated twenty-five miles downstream; I would then swim to the shore before dawn. Then I went into the forest towards Illinois.
tr: Therefore, the only solution was to get on a raft, then there would be no trace left behind. I saw a light approaching from the direction I was hiding, so I immediately dived into the water and pushed a log in front of me to help me swim. In this way, I swam to the middle of the river, then I climbed onto a drifting tree branch; without ever raising my head, I swam against the current until a raft came. Then I swam to the starboard side and caught the raft. Shortly after, the moon went behind the clouds and the surroundings darkened. Taking advantage of this opportunity, I climbed onto the raft and lay down. All the men on the raft were far away, in the middle of the raft, sleeping next to the fire. The river was rising and there was quite a current; I calculated that we would reach about twenty-five miles downstream by around four in the morning. Before sunrise, I dived into the water and swam to the shore to hide in the forest on the Illinois side of the river.
es: "I saw a light passing by the tip, so I got in and pushed a log in front of me and swam more than half of the river and got in among the timber that was floating down, with my head low, and kind of swam upstream until the raft appeared." "Then I swam to the stern to grab on." "Clouds came and it was dark for a while." "So I climbed up to lie down on the planks." "The men were all in the middle, where the lantern was." "The river was rising and there was a good current, so I thought that by four in the morning I would be twenty-five miles downstream and then I would get back into the water before swimming again and getting into the woods on the Illinois side."

en: “But I didn’ have no luck. When we ’uz mos’ down to de head er de islan’ a man begin to come aft wid de lantern, I see it warn’t no use fer to wait, so I slid overboard en struck out fer de islan’. Well, I had a notion I could lan’ mos’ anywhers, but I couldn’t—bank too bluff. I ’uz mos’ to de foot er de islan’ b’fo’ I found’ a good place. I went into de woods en jedged I wouldn’ fool wid raffs no mo’, long as dey move de lantern roun’ so. I had my pipe en a plug er dog-leg, en some matches in my cap, en dey warn’t wet, so I ’uz all right.”
vi: But truly, I was unlucky. Just as I reached the edge of the island, there was a person holding a lantern behind me. Seeing that I couldn't delay, I immediately plunged into the water, leaving the island to swim elsewhere. It was terrifying; I thought I could get ashore anywhere, but no, the riverbank was steep everywhere. When I swam close to the other end of the island, I found a good spot. I went into the forest, thinking that I couldn't continue using the raft, because drifting like that, I would surely encounter the light. I had a pipe and a torn tobacco pouch with some matches in my shirt that hadn't gotten wet, so I felt reassured.
tr: But my luck did not go well. When we came to almost the other side of the island, the men took a boat and approached my side; there was no point in waiting, so I quietly slipped into the water and started swimming towards the island. Actually, I thought I could climb the rock from any part of the island, but no, the shore was very steep and rocky. I came all the way to the tip of the island to find a good place. I decided to go straight into the forest and not to get involved with any more boats, especially if there were men with guns in them, I wouldn't even approach them. I had a pipe and some tobacco with me, and there were a few matches left in my hat, my situation wasn't too bad."
es: "But I wasn't lucky." "When we had almost reached the tip of the island, a man started coming aft with the lantern." "I saw that it was useless to wait, so I let myself fall and swam to the island." "Well, I thought I could touch the bottom almost anywhere, but no; the shore was too steep." "I had to go almost to the end of the island before finding a good spot." "I went into the forest and thought I wouldn't get on any more rafts while they kept walking around with the lantern." "I had the pipe and a bit of tobacco in my cap that hadn't gotten wet, so there was no problem."

en: “And so you ain’t had no meat nor bread to eat all this time? Why didn’t you get mud-turkles?”
vi: - So, from that day until now, you haven't had any meat or cake to eat? Why don't you find some roots in the mud to eat?
tr: “So, you haven't had any meat or bread to eat since then? Why didn't you catch a turtle?”
es: —So you haven't eaten either meat or bread all this time? Why didn't you look for river turtles?

en: “How you gwyne to git ’m? You can’t slip up on um en grab um; en how’s a body gwyne to hit um wid a rock? How could a body do it in de night? En I warn’t gwyne to show mysef on de bank in de daytime.”
vi: - How can I get it? How can I retrieve it? What can I do with just a stone in my hand? And at night, how can I get it? During the day, I don't dare go to the riverbank for fear of being seen. - Ah, I see, so you have to stay in the forest all day long.
tr: “How do you catch it? If you can't catch up and grab it, how do you manage to hit it with a stone? Especially at night, how do you do it? If it's daytime, I must not show myself by the shore, oh no.”
es: —And how was I supposed to catch them? You can't just pounce on them and grab them; and, how are you supposed to kill them with a stone? How do you do that at night? And I wasn't going to let them see me on the shore during the day.

en: “Well, that’s so. You’ve had to keep in the woods all the time, of course. Did you hear ’em shooting the cannon?”
vi: That's right. Did you hear them firing cannons?
tr: “So that's how it is. Of course, you had to spend all your time in the forest. Did you hear the sound of the cannons?”
es: —Well, it's true. Of course, you had to stay in the forest the whole time. Did you hear how they fired the cannon?

en: “Oh, yes. I knowed dey was arter you. I see um go by heah—watched um thoo de bushes.”
vi: - Yes, I do. I know they are looking for you. I saw them passing by here. I hid in the bushes and watched.
tr: “Ah, yes. I understood that you were the lord. I saw you going down the river... I followed you from behind the bushes.”
es: —Ah, yes. I knew they were looking for you. I saw them pass by here... I watched them through the bushes.

en: Some young birds come along, flying a yard or two at a time and lighting. Jim said it was a sign it was going to rain. He said it was a sign when young chickens flew that way, and so he reckoned it was the same way when young birds done it. I was going to catch some of them, but Jim wouldn’t let me. He said it was death. He said his father laid mighty sick once, and some of them catched a bird, and his old granny said his father would die, and he did.
vi: A few young birds here flew over, only flying short distances of a few yards before perching again. Jim said it was a sign of rain. He said that when chicks fly erratically, it means rain is coming, so seeing birds fly like that also made him predict rain. I intended to catch a few birds, but Jim wouldn't let me. He said doing so would bring death. He said that his father once fell seriously ill, and when someone else caught birds, his father told him that doing so would cause his father to die. And indeed, he died.
tr: Young birds appeared around, flying a meter or two and landing on branches. Jim said this was a sign that it would rain. When chicks flew like this, it meant rain, so he guessed it would mean the same for other young birds as well. I wanted to catch a few, but Jim didn't allow it. He said it was akin to death. Once, his father had gotten very sick, and when someone caught a bird, his old grandmother said his father would die, and indeed, he did.
es: Some little birds passed by, flying a yard or two each time and then landing again. Jim said it was a sign that it was going to rain. He said that it meant the same thing when chicks did it, so he thought it was the same when little birds did it. I was going to hunt some, but Jim didn't let me. He said it brought death. He said that his father got very sick once and someone in his family caught a bird and his grandmother said that his father would die and that's what happened.

en: And Jim said you mustn’t count the things you are going to cook for dinner, because that would bring bad luck. The same if you shook the table-cloth after sundown. And he said if a man owned a beehive and that man died, the bees must be told about it before sun-up next morning, or else the bees would all weaken down and quit work and die. Jim said bees wouldn’t sting idiots; but I didn’t believe that, because I had tried them lots of times myself, and they wouldn’t sting me.
vi: Jim also said that one should not plan ahead what to cook for dinner, as it would bring bad luck. And shaking out the tablecloth at sunset is the same. He also said that when the sun rises the next morning, the bees would already know. If not, the bees would fall ill, refuse to work, and eventually die. Jim said that bees never sting fools. But I don't believe that, because I've tried it several times and still haven't been stung.
tr: Also, Jim said that you shouldn't count the things you eat in the evening, because it brings bad luck. The same thing happens if you shake the tablecloth after sunset. And if a man has a beehive, when that man dies, you need to inform the bees before the sun rises the next morning, otherwise all the bees will weaken, stop working, and die. Jim also said that bees don't sting fools, but I didn't believe it, because I had dealt with them many times and they hadn't stung me.
es: And Jim said that one shouldn't talk about the things one was going to cook for dinner, because it brought bad luck. The same as if one shook the tablecloth after nightfall. And he said that if a man had a beehive and that man died, one had to tell the bees before the sun rose again the next morning, because if not, the bees would get sick and stop working and die. Jim said that bees didn't sting idiots, but I didn't believe it, because I had messed with them dozens of times and they never stung me.

en: I had heard about some of these things before, but not all of them. Jim knowed all kinds of signs. He said he knowed most everything. I said it looked to me like all the signs was about bad luck, and so I asked him if there warn’t any good-luck signs. He says:
vi: Before that, I had heard about those things but hadn't heard everything. Jim knew the omens. He said he knew most of them. I said it seemed to me that all the omens were bad, so I asked Jim if there were any good omens. Jim said:
tr: Some of the things you told me I had heard before, but I hadn't heard all of them. Jim knew all kinds of signs. He said he knew almost everything. Upon this, I said that apparently all signs bring bad luck and asked if there were any signs that bring good luck. He said:
es: Some of those things I had already heard before, but not all of them. Jim knew a bunch of those signs. He said he knew almost all of them. I said that it seemed to me that all the signs brought bad luck, so I asked him if there was any sign of good luck. And he goes and says:

en: “Mighty few—an’ dey ain’t no use to a body. What you want to know when good luck’s a-comin’ for? Want to keep it off?” And he said: “Ef you’s got hairy arms en a hairy breas’, it’s a sign dat you’s agwyne to be rich. Well, dey’s some use in a sign like dat, ’kase it’s so fur ahead. You see, maybe you’s got to be po’ a long time fust, en so you might git discourage’ en kill yo’sef ’f you didn’ know by de sign dat you gwyne to be rich bymeby.”
vi: - Very little. And those things are of no use to anyone. Why do you want to know, do you want to keep it? Then Jim said again: - If you have a lot of hair on your arms and chest, it's a sign that you're about to get rich. Such an omen can be useful; the more hair you have, the luckier you are. You see, at first, you might be poor. But if you don't know in advance that it's a sign you'll become rich, you might get discouraged and commit suicide.
tr: “Very little… and even that is of no use to anyone. Why do you care so much about when luck will smile on you? Is it to keep luck away from yourself?” He also added: “If your arms and chest are hairy, then you will either soon or eventually become rich. This is such a sign that brings luck, but sometimes it can take a very long time to come. Do you understand? Maybe at first, you need to wait a long time, so you don't recognize the sign and don't know the signs that will make you rich, God forbid, you might even end up in despair and kill yourself.”
es: —Very few, and they are of no use to anyone. Why do you want to know when good luck is coming? Do you want it not to come? —and he added—: If you have hairy arms and a hairy chest, it's a sign that you are going to be rich. Well, that is worth something, because it is always for a long time in the future. You know, maybe you have to be poor for a long time first, and then you might get discouraged and kill yourself, if you didn't know from that sign that in time you are going to be rich.

en: “Have you got hairy arms and a hairy breast, Jim?”
vi: - Do you have a lot of arm hair, Jim?
tr: “Are your arms and chest hairy, Jim?”
es: —Do you have hair on your arms and chest?

en: “What’s de use to ax dat question? Don’t you see I has?”
vi: - What's the point of asking that, can't you see I'm here?.
tr: “Is this what you call cold? Can't you see that it is?”
es: —And why are you asking me that? Can't you see that I am?

en: “Well, are you rich?”
vi: - Yeah, so are you rich?
tr: “So, are you rich?”
es: —Well, are you rich?

en: “No, but I ben rich wunst, and gwyne to be rich agin. Wunst I had foteen dollars, but I tuck to specalat’n’, en got busted out.”
vi: - No, I was rich once before, and I will be rich again. Once I had fourteen dollars, but I went into speculative trading, and unfortunately lost it all.
tr: “No, but once I was rich, and I will be rich again. At one point, I had fourteen shops, I got into trading, and eventually, I went bankrupt.”
es: —No, but I was rich once and I will be again. Once I had fourteen dollars, but I got into speculating and ruined myself.

en: “What did you speculate in, Jim?”
vi: - Speculating on what, Jim?
tr: “What were you buying and selling, Jim?”
es: —What did you speculate on, Jim?

en: “Well, fust I tackled stock.”
vi: - First of all, it's about stockpiling
tr: “Well, at first I got into the business of buying and selling animals.”
es: —Well, I started with stocks.

en: “What kind of stock?”
vi: - Hoarding what?
tr: “What kind of animal?”
es: —What kind of values?

en: “Why, live stock—cattle, you know. I put ten dollars in a cow. But I ain’ gwyne to resk no mo’ money in stock. De cow up ’n’ died on my han’s.”
vi: - And what else - livestock, you know. I spent ten dollars to buy a cow. But then I almost had nothing left because as soon as I got the cow, it died.
tr: “Farm animal. Just the usual cattle and such. I invested ten dollars in a cow. But I won't risk more money in the animal business. The cow soon died.”
es: —Well, real assets: you know, livestock. I invested ten dollars in a cow. But I won't risk money on assets again. The cow went and died on me.

en: “So you lost the ten dollars.”
vi: - So you lost ten dollars, huh?
tr: “So you lost ten dollars.”
es: —So, you lost the ten dollars.

en: “No, I didn’t lose it all. I on’y los’ ’bout nine of it. I sole de hide en taller for a dollar en ten cents.”
vi: - No, I didn't lose all ten đồng, I only lost nearly nine đồng. Because I sold the cowhide for one đồng. - So you have five and a half dimes left.
tr: “No, I didn't lose all of them. I only lost about nine of them. I sold the animal's skin and fat for about ten cents.”
es: —No, I didn't lose them all. Just about nine. I sold the skin and the tail for a dollar and ten cents.

en: “You had five dollars and ten cents left. Did you speculate any more?”
vi: - So you have five and a half dimes left. Do you have anything else to speculate on?
tr: "So, you have five dollars and ten cents left." "Did you trade with this again?""
es: —You had five dollars and ten cents left. Did you keep speculating?

en: “Yes. You know that one-laigged nigger dat b’longs to old Misto Bradish? Well, he sot up a bank, en say anybody dat put in a dollar would git fo’ dollars mo’ at de en’ er de year. Well, all de niggers went in, but dey didn’t have much. I wuz de on’y one dat had much. So I stuck out for mo’ dan fo’ dollars, en I said ’f I didn’ git it I’d start a bank mysef. Well, o’ course dat nigger want’ to keep me out er de business, bekase he says dey warn’t business ’nough for two banks, so he say I could put in my five dollars en he pay me thirty-five at de en’ er de year.
vi: - Yes, of course. Do you know the black cripple who works for Mr. Bradish? He just started a bank. He says that whoever puts in one dollar can take out four dollars at the end of the year. So all the black folks are putting their money in there. But they don't have much anyway. Only the evening is the most. I put in more than four dollars, and I said if it doesn't work out, I'll start my own bank. Of course, that black guy doesn't want me to get involved because he says if there are two banks, there won't be enough to run the business. So he told me I could put in a handful of dollars and by the end of the year, he'd pay me back thirty-five dollars.
tr: “Yes. You know Old Mr. Bradish’s one-legged Negro, right? Well, he started a bank and said that whoever deposits a dollar will earn an extra four dollars by the end of the year. All the Negroes deposited their money in this bank, but they didn't have much money. I was the only one who had that much money. So I wanted to get more than four dollars in interest, otherwise I said I would start my own bank. Of course, that Negro wanted to keep me out of it, because he said there wasn't enough business for two banks, so he said if you deposit five dollars in my bank, then at the end of the year you'll get thirty-five dollars.
es: —Yes. Do you remember that black man of old Mr. Bradish who only has one leg? Well, he set up a bank and said that anyone who deposited a dollar would receive four more dollars at the end of the year. Well, all the black people deposited, but they didn't have much. I was the only one who had it. So I deposited more than four dollars and said that if he didn't give me what I was owed, I would open my own bank. Well, of course that black man didn't want me to compete with him, because he said there wasn't enough business for two banks, so he says I could put in my five dollars and he would pay me thirty-five at the end of the year.

en: “So I done it. Den I reck’n’d I’d inves’ de thirty-five dollars right off en keep things a-movin’. Dey wuz a nigger name’ Bob, dat had ketched a wood-flat, en his marster didn’ know it; en I bought it off’n him en told him to take de thirty-five dollars when de en’ er de year come; but somebody stole de wood-flat dat night, en nex day de one-laigged nigger say de bank’s busted. So dey didn’ none uv us git no money.”
vi: So I put the money in. I figured that afterward, I would invest those fifteen dollars again to grow the capital even more. There was another black man named Bob who had just acquired a wooden house that his landlord didn't know about, so I bought it from him and told him that by the end of the year, he would come to collect thirty-five dollars. But that night, someone had already stolen that house. The next day, the limping black man came and told me that the bank had also collapsed. So none of us got our money back.
tr: I also made the payment. So, after that, I was going to make thirty-five more payments and run my business. Bob, a black man, caught a chest of money and his owner didn't know about it; so I bought it from him and promised to transfer thirty-five dollars to him by the end of the year, but that night someone stole the chest of money and the next day a one-legged black man said the bank went bankrupt. So none of us got five cents.”
es: »So that's what I did. Then I thought I would invest the thirty-five dollars to keep things moving. There was a black man named Bob who had a flatboat and his master didn't know about it, and I bought it from him and told him I would give him the thirty-five dollars at the end of the year; but someone stole the boat that night and the next day the lame black man said the bank had failed, so we all ended up without the money.

en: “What did you do with the ten cents, Jim?”
vi: - So what did you do with the remaining ten cents, Jim?
tr: “So what did you do with the ten cents, Jim?”
es: —What did you do with the ten cents, Jim?

en: “Well, I ’uz gwyne to spen’ it, but I had a dream, en de dream tole me to give it to a nigger name’ Balum—Balum’s Ass dey call him for short; he’s one er dem chuckleheads, you know. But he’s lucky, dey say, en I see I warn’t lucky. De dream say let Balum inves’ de ten cents en he’d make a raise for me. Well, Balum he tuck de money, en when he wuz in church he hear de preacher say dat whoever give to de po’ len’ to de Lord, en boun’ to git his money back a hund’d times. So Balum he tuck en give de ten cents to de po’, en laid low to see what wuz gwyne to come of it.”
vi: - Well, at that moment I was about to spend those ten cents when I suddenly had a dream, and the dream told me that I should give those ten cents to a black man named Balum Balum, they called him Ass for short. He was one of the very foolish people, you know? But he often got lucky, they said so, I didn't know. As for me, I never got lucky. The dream told me that Balum would take my ten cents to invest and would make me rich. So I gave the money to Balum. When he went to church, he heard the pastor say that whoever put money into this box for God would be rewarded a hundredfold by God. So Balum took out ten cents from his pocket and put it right into the box. Then he bent down to see if there was anything in the box that would be given back to him.
tr: “Actually, I wanted to spend it, but I supposedly saw in a dream that I had to give the money to a black man named Balum – everyone just calls him Balum’s Donkey, he’s a bit slow in the head. But everyone says he’s lucky, and I’m not lucky at all. In the dream, it was said that if Balum took the ten cents, he would return the money to me. Balum took the money and went to church, and the preacher there said that whoever gives their money to the poor is actually giving it to God, and in the end, their money will return a hundredfold. So Balum gave the ten cents to the poor and started waiting for his money to return.”
es: —Well, I was going to spend it, but I had a dream and the dream told me to give it to a black man named Balum, who they call Balum's Donkey; you know, one of those half-wits, but they say he's lucky, and it was already clear that I wasn't. The dream says that Balum should invest the ten cents and make them grow. Well, Balum took the money, and when he was in church, he heard the preacher say that whoever gives to the poor lends to the Lord and in time would receive the money multiplied by a hundred. So Balum goes and gives the ten cents to the poor and waits to see what happens.

en: “Well, what did come of it, Jim?”
vi: - Well, is there anything you can give back?
tr: “So, did the money increase, Jim?”
es: —Well, and, what happened, Jim?

en: “Nuffn never come of it. I couldn’ manage to k’leck dat money no way; en Balum he couldn’. I ain’ gwyne to len’ no mo’ money ’dout I see de security. Boun’ to git yo’ money back a hund’d times, de preacher says! Ef I could git de ten cents back, I’d call it squah, en be glad er de chanst.”
vi: - There isn't, I don't see anything at all. I also don't know how to get that money back anymore. Balum also gave up. Well, I won't lend money anymore if I'm not sure. It will be returned a hundredfold the amount spent! The pastor said so! If I get those ten cents back, it's considered even, and that would already be very lucky.
tr: “No, it never happened. There was no way for me to get that money, and Balum couldn't do it either. If I were in his place, I wouldn't give my money without securing my position. The preacher said, 'You will definitely get a hundred times more money!' Even if I got my ten cents back, that would be enough, I was very happy with my luck.”
es: —Nothing happened. I couldn't get him to return that money to me at all, and neither could Balum. I'm not going to lend any more money until they give me a guarantee. And the preacher said they would return the money to you a hundred times over! If he returned the ten cents to me, we would be even and I would be so happy.

en: “Well, it’s all right anyway, Jim, long as you’re going to be rich again some time or other.”
vi: - Well Jim, it's alright, because there will be times when you'll be rich later on.
tr: “Never mind, Jim, just let it go, you are going to be rich one day anyway.”
es: —Well, Jim, it doesn't matter anyway, if you're going to be rich again sooner or later.

en: “Yes; en I’s rich now, come to look at it. I owns mysef, en I’s wuth eight hund’d dollars. I wisht I had de money, I wouldn’ want no mo’.”
vi: - Yes, now I am rich, come near my house and see. I already have my own body. My body is worth eight hundred dollars. Before, I only wished for money, but now I don't care anymore.
tr: “Yes… actually, if you look at it, I am rich now too. I own myself and I am worth exactly eight hundred dollars. If only I had that money, I wouldn't want anything else.”
es: —Yes, and I'm already rich if you think about it. I own myself and I'm worth eight hundred dollars. I wish I had the money; I wouldn't want anything more.

en: CHAPTER IX.
vi: Chapter IX
tr: Ninth Chapter
es: Chapter 9

en: I wanted to go and look at a place right about the middle of the island that I’d found when I was exploring; so we started and soon got to it, because the island was only three miles long and a quarter of a mile wide.
vi: I want to go back and see the place right in the middle of the island that I discovered while exploring. Both of us went together and found it immediately, because the island is only three miles long and a quarter mile wide.
tr: When I set out to explore the island, there was a place I found right in the middle; now I wanted to take a look at it. We set out towards this place and soon found where it was, because the island was only three miles long and a quarter mile wide.
es: I FELT LIKE GOING to find a place that was towards the center of the island and that I had seen when I was exploring, so we set off and soon arrived, because the island was only three miles long and a quarter of a mile wide.

en: This place was a tolerable long, steep hill or ridge about forty foot high. We had a rough time getting to the top, the sides was so steep and the bushes so thick. We tramped and clumb around all over it, and by-and-by found a good big cavern in the rock, most up to the top on the side towards Illinois. The cavern was as big as two or three rooms bunched together, and Jim could stand up straight in it. It was cool in there. Jim was for putting our traps in there right away, but I said we didn’t want to be climbing up and down there all the time.
vi: This place is a high mound, more than ten meters high, both long and steep. We climbed to the top of the mound with quite a bit of difficulty, because the slopes on both sides were steep and the bushes were very dense. We had to take each step around the mound, and after a while, we found a large cave in the rock face, extending all the way to the top towards the Illinois shore. The cave was as wide as two or three rooms combined, and Jim could stand upright in it. This place is very cold. Jim wanted to bring our belongings here right away, but I said there was no point in climbing up and down all day.
tr: This was quite a long and steep hill or ridge, and its height was about 12 meters. We had quite a hard time climbing the hill; the slope was very steep, and the bushes were very dense. By holding on and climbing, we explored every part of the ridge and finally found a huge cave near the top on the Illinois side. The cave was the size of two or three rooms, and Jim could stand upright inside it. It was cooler inside compared to outside. Jim immediately wanted to move the stuff there, but I said that going up and down the cave every time wouldn't be convenient for us.
es: That place was a rather long and steep hill, about forty feet high. It was hard for us to get to the top, as the sides were steep and the trees were thick. We searched everywhere and finally found a good cave in the rock, almost at the very top, on the side facing Illinois. The cave was as big as two or three rooms together, and Jim could stand up without hitting the ceiling. It was cool. Jim was in favor of storing our traps there immediately, but I told him it wouldn't be convenient to keep going up and down all the time.

en: Jim said if we had the canoe hid in a good place, and had all the traps in the cavern, we could rush there if anybody was to come to the island, and they would never find us without dogs. And, besides, he said them little birds had said it was going to rain, and did I want the things to get wet?
vi: Jim said that we had a boat hidden in a secret place, and the belongings were stored in this cave, so if anyone came to the island, we could escape into here. And if they didn't bring dogs, they wouldn't be able to find us. Jim also said that the young birds had predicted it was going to rain, so how could we let our belongings get all wet?
tr: Jim said that if we hide the canoe in a good place and move all the belongings to the cave, we can immediately hide in the cave when someone comes to the island, and without the dogs, they would never find us. Moreover, the baby birds had said it was going to rain, or did I want everything to get wet?
es: Jim said that if we had the canoe hidden in a good spot and had all the traps in the cave, we could hide in it quickly if someone came to the island, and that without dogs they would never find us. And, besides, he said that the little birds had said it was going to rain and, did I want all our things to get wet?

en: So we went back and got the canoe, and paddled up abreast the cavern, and lugged all the traps up there. Then we hunted up a place close by to hide the canoe in, amongst the thick willows. We took some fish off of the lines and set them again, and begun to get ready for dinner.
vi: So we returned to the boat, pushed it up to the shore near the cave, and carried all our belongings into the cave. Then we found a spot nearby to hide the boat, concealing it in a dense willow bush. We retrieved a few fish from the end of the line, then cast the hook back into the water and began preparing lunch.
tr: Upon this, we went back and got the canoe, paddled to the cave's level, and then carried all our belongings into the cave. Then, we searched for a nearby spot among the dense willows where we could hide the canoe. We took out a few fish from the fishing lines and cast the lines back, then started preparing dinner.
es: So we went back, took out the canoe, and arrived in front of where the cave was and brought all the traps there. Then we looked for a place nearby to hide the canoe, among the large willows. Some fish had bitten on the lines; we caught them, rebaited the hooks, and started preparing for dinner.

en: The door of the cavern was big enough to roll a hogshead in, and on one side of the door the floor stuck out a little bit, and was flat and a good place to build a fire on. So we built it there and cooked dinner.
vi: The store is quite spacious, enough to roll a large barrel of wine into it. On one side of the store, there is a flat protruding piece of land that can be used as a very good kitchen. We set up the kitchen to cook lunch.
tr: The mouth of the cave was wide enough to fit a large barrel inside, and the ledge next to the entrance was flat enough to light a fire. So we lit the fire there and cooked our meal.
es: The entrance of the cave was large enough to fit a barrel, and on one side of the entrance, the floor was a bit higher and smooth, meaning it was a good spot to light a fire. So we lit it there and prepared dinner.

en: We spread the blankets inside for a carpet, and eat our dinner in there. We put all the other things handy at the back of the cavern. Pretty soon it darkened up, and begun to thunder and lighten; so the birds was right about it. Directly it begun to rain, and it rained like all fury, too, and I never see the wind blow so. It was one of these regular summer storms. It would get so dark that it looked all blue-black outside, and lovely; and the rain would thrash along by so thick that the trees off a little ways looked dim and spider-webby; and here would come a blast of wind that would bend the trees down and turn up the pale underside of the leaves; and then a perfect ripper of a gust would follow along and set the branches to tossing their arms as if they was just wild; and next, when it was just about the bluest and blackest—fst! it was as bright as glory, and you’d have a little glimpse of tree-tops a-plunging about away off yonder in the storm, hundreds of yards further than you could see before; dark as sin again in a second, and now you’d hear the thunder let go with an awful crash, and then go rumbling, grumbling, tumbling, down the sky towards the under side of the world, like rolling empty barrels down stairs—where it’s long stairs and they bounce a good deal, you know.
vi: We spread the blanket inside to use as a mat to sit on and eat. All the easily accessible items were also kept inside. A while later, the sky darkened and it began to thunder and lightning; those birds had indeed predicted it accurately. Immediately, it started to rain heavily, pouring down like a waterfall, and I had never seen the wind blow so fiercely. It was a typical summer storm. As the sky grew darker, everything outside took on a beautiful bluish-purple hue. The rain poured down so heavily that even the tops of the tall trees became indistinct; they looked just like spider webs. Then, with each gust of wind, those trees were bent over and the pale gray color beneath the branches changed. Then another, even fiercer gust of wind came, forcing the branches to stretch out like the arms of wild animals. After that, when everything had turned completely blue and purple, suddenly - oh my; it brightened up, and during that storm, if you looked at the distant treetops, you could see them hundreds of meters farther away than before; then in just a second, it became pitch dark again; at that moment, you could hear the thunder roaring terrifyingly, followed by rumbling sounds gradually descending from above and traveling to the other side of the world, just like the sound of an empty barrel rolling down a long staircase, with the same rumbling noise.
