tr: We threw a blanket inside as a carpet and ate our meal on it. We also put everything useful at the back of the cave. Before long, it got dark, thunder started rumbling, and lightning began flashing; it seemed the birds were right. Suddenly, a downpour began, it was as if the sky had burst open, I had never seen the wind blow so hard. A full-blown summer storm had erupted. You know, it gets so dark that the outside turns into a strange navy blue, creating a magnificent scene, the rain pours down so heavily that even the trees a short distance away become blurry, as if hiding behind a spider web. Sometimes, with a strong gust, the trees bend and the light-colored undersides of the leaves are revealed. As the wind intensifies, all the tree branches sway wildly. Then everything is cloaked in the darkest navy blue, but with the sudden splitting of the sky, everything turns white. Far away, even hundreds of meters further than before, the tops of the trees can be seen flapping in the wind. Again, everything turns pitch black, then a crackling sound erupts, turning into a rumble and descending to the ground with a growl, echoing downwards as if rolling barrels down a staircase, of course, the stairs here are quite high and the barrels make a lot of noise.
es: Inside, we spread the blankets to serve as a carpet and to eat there. We placed everything else within reach at the back of the cave. Soon after, it got dark and started to thunder and lightning, meaning the birds were right. Immediately after, it began to rain heavily, and I have never seen the wind blow like that. It was one of those good summer storms. It was so dark that outside everything seemed a beautiful blue-black, and the rain fell so densely that the trees a short distance away looked like cobweb-like shadows, and gusts of wind came that bent the trees and made the leaves lift from the pale underside, and then came a fierce gust that made the branches wave their arms as if they had gone mad, and then, when it was at its bluest and blackest, whoosh! There was a glow like glory and the treetops swaying in the distance in the middle of the storm, hundreds of yards farther than what could be seen before; they turned black as sin in a second and then the thunder returned with a terrifying drumroll that continued growling, rolling, and staggering across the sky to the other side of the world, as if barrels were being rolled down stairs, you know, very long stairs where the barrels bounce a lot.

en: “Jim, this is nice,” I says. “I wouldn’t want to be nowhere else but here. Pass me along another hunk of fish and some hot corn-bread.”
vi: I said: - It's so fun, Jim! I just want to stay here and not go anywhere. Give me a piece of fish and a hot piece of bread.
tr: “Isn't it beautiful, Jim,” I said. “I wouldn't want to be anywhere else right now. Pass me another piece of fish and some of that hot cornbread.”
es: —Jim, this is very good —I said—. I wouldn't want to be anywhere else in the world. Give me another piece of fish and some hot cornbread.

en: “Well, you wouldn’t a ben here ’f it hadn’t a ben for Jim. You’d a ben down dah in de woods widout any dinner, en gittn’ mos’ drownded, too; dat you would, honey. Chickens knows when it’s gwyne to rain, en so do de birds, chile.”
vi: - You see, if it weren't for Jim, you wouldn't have come up to this cave, and you would be in that forest with nothing to eat, and you might have drowned too. Chicks know when it's about to rain, and so do baby birds.
tr: "If it weren't for Jim, you would have been in big trouble with this mistake. If you were down there now, you would have been hungry, almost drowned, you would have perished, my dear. Chickens know when the rain is coming, birds know too, my child."
es: —Well, you wouldn't be here if it weren't for Jim. You'd be out there in the forest and almost drowned; I assure you, my boy. Chickens know when it's going to rain and birds do too, boy.

en: The river went on raising and raising for ten or twelve days, till at last it was over the banks. The water was three or four foot deep on the island in the low places and on the Illinois bottom. On that side it was a good many miles wide, but on the Missouri side it was the same old distance across—a half a mile—because the Missouri shore was just a wall of high bluffs.
vi: The river water kept rising, continuously for ten to twelve days, overflowing onto the banks. The water flooded the island, reaching over a meter in low areas and at the head of the island towards the Illinois shore. On that side, the island was several miles wide, but on the Missouri side, it was about half a mile because the Missouri shore was like a large vertical wall.
tr: For twelve days, the river rose and finally overflowed its banks. In the low-lying areas of the island and at the Illinois end, the depth reached one meter. On the Illinois side, the river had reached a width of miles; but on the Missouri side, the distance was still the same – about half a mile – because the Missouri shore consisted of steep cliff walls.
es: The river kept rising for ten or twelve days until it began to flood the banks. The water was three or four feet deep on the island in the low-lying areas and on the Illinois shore. In that part, it measured many miles in width, but on the Missouri side, it was the same distance as always —half a mile— because the Missouri shore was like a wall of cliffs.

en: Daytimes we paddled all over the island in the canoe, It was mighty cool and shady in the deep woods, even if the sun was blazing outside. We went winding in and out amongst the trees, and sometimes the vines hung so thick we had to back away and go some other way. Well, on every old broken-down tree you could see rabbits and snakes and such things; and when the island had been overflowed a day or two they got so tame, on account of being hungry, that you could paddle right up and put your hand on them if you wanted to; but not the snakes and turtles—they would slide off in the water. The ridge our cavern was in was full of them. We could a had pets enough if we’d wanted them.
vi: During the day, we could paddle the boat all around the island. The weather was quite cold. In the deep forest, it was even darker, although it was still sunny outside. We maneuvered the boat between the tree trunks. In many places, grapevines hung down, obstructing the way, so we had to turn back and find another route. In places where fallen trees lay, there could be rabbits, snakes, and other animals. Whenever the island was flooded for a few days, those animals became very tame because they were too hungry. At that time, you could paddle the boat right up to them and catch them with your hand. But with snakes and turtles, it wasn't possible because they would dive to the bottom of the water. In one spot in the cave, we also had many of these creatures, and if we wanted to catch and raise them, we could get plenty.
tr: During the day, we would explore every part of the island by canoe. Despite the sun being bright and scorching, the depths of the forest were very cold and dark. We would weave in and out of the trees; sometimes the branches were so dense that we had to turn back and find another path. On every fallen rotten tree, you could see rabbits, snakes, and other animals; after the island had been submerged for a day or two, the animals had become tame from hunger, and if you wanted, you could go right up to them and touch them; of course, except for the snakes and turtles – they would slip into the water immediately. The ridge where our cave was located was filled with animals. If we wanted, we could have had a lot of domestic animals.
es: During the day, we would paddle around the island in the canoe. In the middle of the forest, it was very cool and there was always shade, even if outside the sun was burning us. We would go winding between the trees, and sometimes the vines were so thick that we had to backtrack and find another path. Well, in every old hollow tree, you could see rabbits and snakes and such things, and when the island had been flooded for one or two days, they were so tame from hunger that you could approach them and pet them if you wanted, but not the snakes or the turtles, which would slip away into the water. The hill where our cave was located was full of them. We could have had plenty of pets if we had wanted to.

en: One night we catched a little section of a lumber raft—nice pine planks. It was twelve foot wide and about fifteen or sixteen foot long, and the top stood above water six or seven inches—a solid, level floor. We could see saw-logs go by in the daylight sometimes, but we let them go; we didn’t show ourselves in daylight.
vi: One night we salvaged an entire section of a wooden raft, made entirely of pine planks. It was three meters wide, four to five meters long, and up to twenty centimeters thick. This wood is very sturdy for flooring. During the day, we also saw many pieces of wood that had been sawed off floating by, but we let them drift away; because during the day we didn't dare to go outside.
tr: One night we caught a small piece of a raft made from a tree trunk – it was beautiful pine lumber. It was six meters wide and four and a half to five meters long, with fifteen to twenty centimeters of it above the water, and its surface was flat and solid. During the day, we also saw logs coming out of the sawmill, but we let them go; we didn't show ourselves during the daytime.
es: One night we took a piece of a log raft: good pine logs. It measured twelve feet wide and fifteen or sixteen feet long, and the highest part was six or seven inches above the water: a solid and level surface. Sometimes we saw sawn logs passing by in the daylight, but we let them pass, because we never went out during the day.

en: Another night when we was up at the head of the island, just before daylight, here comes a frame-house down, on the west side. She was a two-story, and tilted over considerable. We paddled out and got aboard—clumb in at an upstairs window. But it was too dark to see yet, so we made the canoe fast and set in her to wait for daylight.
vi: One night, when we reached the edge of the island near dawn, we saw an entire wooden house from upstream drifting to the western shore. The house had an attic; it was tilted and about to collapse. We rowed the boat out, jumped on, and climbed through the attic window to get inside. We then tied the boat to it and sat waiting for daylight.
tr: One night just before dawn, while we were at the front side of the island, we saw that a wooden house was drifting on the west side. The house was two stories high and was leaning quite a bit. We quickly rowed towards the house – we climbed up to a window on the upper floor. But it was still very dark inside, so we tied the canoe to a secure spot and waited for daylight.
es: Another night, when we were at the tip of the island, just before dawn, a wooden house appeared on the west side. It had two floors and was very tilted. We rowed over and climbed aboard: we got in through one of the upstairs windows. But it was still too dark to see, so we tied up the canoe and sat waiting for dawn.

en: The light begun to come before we got to the foot of the island. Then we looked in at the window. We could make out a bed, and a table, and two old chairs, and lots of things around about on the floor, and there was clothes hanging against the wall. There was something laying on the floor in the far corner that looked like a man. So Jim says:
vi: The house drifted to the head of the island as the sky began to lighten. From outside the window, we looked in and saw a bed, a table, two old chairs, and on the attic floor, there were many other things; clothes were also hanging on the wall. There was something lying on the floor in the corner of the house that looked like a person. Jim called out:
tr: Before we reached the end of the island, it started to get light. Then we looked inside through the window. Inside, there was a bed, a table, two old chairs, and a lot of stuff scattered on the floor; we also saw clothes hanging on the wall. In the other corner of the room, something resembling a man was lying on the floor. Jim called out to him:
es: The light began to arrive before we reached the other end of the island. Then we looked out the window. We saw a bed and a table and two old chairs and piles of things scattered on the floor, and there were clothes hanging next to the wall. In the farthest corner of the floor, there was something that looked like a man. So Jim says:

en: “Hello, you!”
vi: - Hey! Hey!
tr: "Hey, sen!"
es: —Hey, you!

en: But it didn’t budge. So I hollered again, and then Jim says:
vi: There was no movement. I called again. Then Jim said:
tr: But there was no movement. This time I called out, then Jim turned to me:
es: But he did not move. So I shouted again, and then Jim says:

en: “De man ain’t asleep—he’s dead. You hold still—I’ll go en see.”
vi: - This person is not sleeping, but dead. You stay here, let me go in and check.
tr: “Adam is not sleeping… he is dead. You stay here… I will go and check.”
es: —That one is not asleep: he is dead. You stay there, I'm going to check.

en: He went, and bent down and looked, and says:
vi: Jim walked in, bent down to look, and then said:
tr: He went over to the man, leaned in, and after looking carefully, he called out:
es: He approached, bent down to look, and said:

en: “It’s a dead man. Yes, indeedy; naked, too. He’s ben shot in de back. I reck’n he’s ben dead two er three days. Come in, Huck, but doan’ look at his face—it’s too gashly.”
vi: - One person is dead. That's right, and they are naked too. They were shot in the back. I'm sure they've been dead for two or three days now. Come in, Huck, but don't look at their face, it's got many cuts, very gruesome.
tr: “The man is dead. Yes, for real, and naked too. He was shot in the back. He's probably been lying there for two or three days. Go inside Huck, but don't look at the man's face, because it's a horrible sight.”
es: —He is dead. Yes, sir; and naked. He has been shot in the back. I estimate he has been dead for two or three days. Come, Huck, but don't look at his face. It's too horrible.

en: I didn’t look at him at all. Jim throwed some old rags over him, but he needn’t done it; I didn’t want to see him. There was heaps of old greasy cards scattered around over the floor, and old whisky bottles, and a couple of masks made out of black cloth; and all over the walls was the ignorantest kind of words and pictures made with charcoal. There was two old dirty calico dresses, and a sun-bonnet, and some women’s underclothes hanging against the wall, and some men’s clothing, too. We put the lot into the canoe—it might come good. There was a boy’s old speckled straw hat on the floor; I took that, too. And there was a bottle that had had milk in it, and it had a rag stopper for a baby to suck. We would a took the bottle, but it was broke. There was a seedy old chest, and an old hair trunk with the hinges broke. They stood open, but there warn’t nothing left in them that was any account. The way things was scattered about we reckoned the people left in a hurry, and warn’t fixed so as to carry off most of their stuff.
vi: I didn't dare to look. Jim threw the torn clothes over the dead body. But why did he have to do that? I didn't want to see the dead body anyway. There was a pile of old, dirty cards scattered on the floor, some whiskey bottles, a few masks made of black cloth; and on the walls, there were scribbles and poorly written words drawn with charcoal everywhere. There were two old thick fabric shirts, a sun hat, some women's underwear hanging on the wall, and some men's pants too. We picked them all up and put them in the boat to use later. There was also a child's hat on the floor, which I picked up as well. Then there was a bottle of milk with some milk left in it, and a torn rubber baby bottle nipple. We intended to take the bottle of milk but it was already spoiled. There was an old, tattered trunk and a woven hair chest with broken hinges. Both were wide open, but inside there was nothing of value. From the way the furniture was scattered around, we guessed that someone had fled in a hurry and didn't have the presence of mind to take everything with them.
tr: I didn't look at the man at all. Jim covered the corpse with a few rags, but he didn't need to; I didn't want to see it. Worn-out, greasy playing cards were scattered on the ground, there were old whiskey bottles around, and I also saw a few masks made of black cloth; there were also crudely drawn words and pictures on the walls made with charcoal. Two old and dirty calico dresses, a sun hat, and women's underwear were hanging on the wall; there were also men's clothes. We carried everything to the canoe, it might come in handy. There was an old, dirty straw boy's hat on the ground; I took that too. There was milk in a bottle; also, a cloth stopper was made at the mouth for the baby to suck on. We were going to take the bottle, but we saw it was broken. There was an old, shabby console and a chest with broken hinges. Both were open, but there was nothing of value left inside. Judging by how things were scattered around, people had left the house in a hurry and hadn't had time to take most of their belongings.
es: I didn't look at all. Jim threw some old rags over it, but it wasn't necessary; I didn't want to see it. All over the floor were scattered piles of old, greasy playing cards, old whiskey bottles, and a couple of masks made of black cloth, and the walls were full of the clumsiest signs and drawings, made with charcoal. There were two old dresses made of dirty calico and a bonnet and some women's underwear hanging next to the wall, and also men's clothing. We put everything in the canoe: it might be useful. On the floor, I found an old straw hat for a boy; I picked it up too. And there was also a bottle with milk and a cloth stopper for a baby to suck on. We would have taken the bottle, but it was broken. There was an old, damaged dresser and an old trunk with broken locks. They were open, but there was nothing left worth taking. From the way things were scattered, we figured that the people had left in a hurry, without time to take most of their belongings.

en: We got an old tin lantern, and a butcher-knife without any handle, and a bran-new Barlow knife worth two bits in any store, and a lot of tallow candles, and a tin candlestick, and a gourd, and a tin cup, and a ratty old bedquilt off the bed, and a reticule with needles and pins and beeswax and buttons and thread and all such truck in it, and a hatchet and some nails, and a fishline as thick as my little finger with some monstrous hooks on it, and a roll of buckskin, and a leather dog-collar, and a horseshoe, and some vials of medicine that didn’t have no label on them; and just as we was leaving I found a tolerable good curry-comb, and Jim he found a ratty old fiddle-bow, and a wooden leg. The straps was broke off of it, but, barring that, it was a good enough leg, though it was too long for me and not long enough for Jim, and we couldn’t find the other one, though we hunted all around.
vi: We found an old iron lamp, a meat cleaver without a handle, and a new Barlow-style dagger, which would cost at least two dimes at any store; along with a bunch of tallow candles, an iron candlestick; an iron cup, then a blanket still usable but gnawed by mice, a small bag for sewing supplies complete with waxed needles, a hook as small as my little finger but with large hooks, a roll of buckskin, a dog collar, a horseshoe, and some bottles of medicine without any labels. Just as we were about to leave, we found a fairly good horse brush. Jim also picked up an old, broken woman's comb and a wooden leg. The leather straps were all broken, but if tied back together, they were still usable, although they were too long for me and a bit short for Jim. After searching around, we couldn't find the other leg.
tr: An old tin lantern, a butcher knife without a handle, a brand new Barlow knife that you could buy from any store for just two bits, a bunch of tallow candles, a tin candle holder, a gourd, a tin cup, an old quilt we took from the bed, a handbag containing needles, beeswax, buttons, and thread, a small hatchet and some nails, some fishing line almost as thick as my little finger and large fish hooks attached to the line, a rolled-up deer skin, a leather dog collar, a horseshoe, a few medicine bottles without labels; and just as we were leaving, a nice currycomb caught my eye. Jim also found an old violin bow and a wooden prosthetic leg. The straps of the prosthetic leg were broken, but other than that, it looked like a good leg, though it was too long for me, too short for Jim, and despite searching everywhere, we couldn't find the other leg.
es: We took an old tin lantern and a butcher knife without a handle and a brand-new Barlow knife that would be worth twenty-five cents in any store and a bunch of tallow candles; a tin candlestick and a canteen; a tin cup and an old frayed bed quilt; a sewing kit with needles and pins and beeswax and buttons and thread and all those things; an axe and some nails and a fishing line as thick as my little finger with some huge hooks; a roll of buckskin and a leather dog collar and a lock and many medicine bottles that had no labels, and when we were leaving I found a pretty good currycomb and Jim an old worn-out violin bow and a wooden leg. The suspenders had fallen off, but other than that it was a pretty good leg, although too long for me and not long enough for Jim, and we couldn't find the other one, even though we searched everywhere.

en: And so, take it all around, we made a good haul. When we was ready to shove off we was a quarter of a mile below the island, and it was pretty broad day; so I made Jim lay down in the canoe and cover up with the quilt, because if he set up people could tell he was a nigger a good ways off. I paddled over to the Illinois shore, and drifted down most a half a mile doing it. I crept up the dead water under the bank, and hadn’t no accidents and didn’t see nobody. We got home all safe.
vi: So we made a big haul and carried everything away. As we were about to leave the house, we realized we had drifted a quarter of a mile downstream from the island, and it was already daylight, so I told Jim to lie down in the boat and cover himself with a blanket. Because if Jim sat up, people would immediately recognize him as a runaway black man. I rowed the boat towards the Illinois shore, drifting another half mile further. When we reached calm waters, I started rowing back upstream. Nothing happened and there was no one around. We returned home safely.
tr: Thus, overall, we had done a good job. By the time we were ready to leave the house, we had reached about a quarter mile down the island, and it was midday; so I told Jim to lie down inside the canoe and covered him with a blanket, because if he sat up, people could tell from a long distance that he was a black man. I rowed towards the Illinois shore, but while doing so, I had drifted nearly half a mile. As I came back up from the still water along the shore, nothing happened to me, nor did I see anyone. We had returned home completely safe.
es: So, overall, we got a good load. When we were ready to leave, we were already a quarter of a mile below the island and it was broad daylight, so I had Jim lie down in the canoe and cover himself with the quilt, because if he sat up, people could see from afar that he was black. I paddled to the Illinois side and meanwhile gained half a mile drifting. I went up the still waters under the bank and had no accidents nor hurt anyone. We got home safe and sound.

en: CHAPTER X.
vi: Chapter X
tr: Tenth Chapter
es: Chapter 10

en: After breakfast I wanted to talk about the dead man and guess out how he come to be killed, but Jim didn’t want to. He said it would fetch bad luck; and besides, he said, he might come and ha’nt us; he said a man that warn’t buried was more likely to go a-ha’nting around than one that was planted and comfortable. That sounded pretty reasonable, so I didn’t say no more; but I couldn’t keep from studying over it and wishing I knowed who shot the man, and what they done it for.
vi: After finishing breakfast, I wanted to talk about the dead person in that floating house and guess why they were killed. But Jim didn't like talking about it. Jim said talking about it would bring bad luck, and moreover, the dead person might come back. Jim said that the dead who are not buried tend to come back more often than those who are properly buried. That made sense, so I didn't say anything more; but I couldn't stop thinking about it, wanting to know who shot that person and why?
tr: After breakfast, I wanted to talk about the dead man and ponder together how he was killed, but Jim objected. Such conversations would bring bad luck; moreover, the man could come and haunt us, he said that the likelihood of an unburied man haunting people was much higher compared to a properly buried man resting peacefully in his grave. There was some truth in what Jim said, so I didn't insist, but this matter continued to bother me, I was curious about who killed the man and why.
es: AFTER BREAKFAST I wanted to talk about the dead man and speculate on how he might have been killed, but Jim didn't want to. He said it brought bad luck, and besides, he said, it could come to haunt us, because a man who wasn't buried had more chances of going around as a ghost than one well planted and comfortable. That seemed quite reasonable, so I didn't say more, but I couldn't stop thinking about it or wanting to know who had shot that man and why.

en: We rummaged the clothes we’d got, and found eight dollars in silver sewed up in the lining of an old blanket overcoat. Jim said he reckoned the people in that house stole the coat, because if they’d a knowed the money was there they wouldn’t a left it. I said I reckoned they killed him, too; but Jim didn’t want to talk about that. I says:
vi: We rummaged through the clothes we brought back and found eight silver dollars sewn into the hem of an outer garment. Jim said that perhaps the person in that house stole the garment, because if they knew there was money, they wouldn't have left it behind. I said maybe they were hiding that person here, but Jim still didn't want to talk about it. I said:
tr: When we thoroughly examined the clothes we had bought, we found eight silver dollars sewn into an old coat. Jim said that the people in that house had stolen the coat because if they had known the money was there, they would have definitely taken the coat with them when they left. I said that I thought they had also killed the owner of the coat, but Jim didn't want to talk about it. Then I said:
es: We searched through the clothes we had taken with us and found eight dollars in coins sewn into the lining of an old overcoat. Jim said that he thought the people in the house had stolen the overcoat, because if they had known the money was there, they wouldn't have left it. I said that surely they had also killed him, but Jim didn't want to talk about that. I go and say:

en: “Now you think it’s bad luck; but what did you say when I fetched in the snake-skin that I found on the top of the ridge day before yesterday? You said it was the worst bad luck in the world to touch a snake-skin with my hands. Well, here’s your bad luck! We’ve raked in all this truck and eight dollars besides. I wish we could have some bad luck like this every day, Jim.”
vi: - You said it was bad luck; so what do you say about me finding a snake skin on top of the hill the day before yesterday? Didn't you say that touching a snake skin would bring the worst luck in the world? Well, here's the bad luck; we found so many things, and even got eight dollars. I wish we could have this kind of bad luck every day, Jim!
tr: “You say this will bring bad luck; but what did you say when I brought the snake skin I found on the top of your back not yesterday, but the day before? Holding a snake skin with your hand would bring the greatest misfortune in the world, you said. Well, here's your bad luck! We found a lot of things, and eight dollars to boot. I wish we had such bad luck every day.”
es: —Well, you think it brings bad luck, but what did you say when I brought the snake skin I found on the hill yesterday? You said it was the worst bad luck in the world to touch a snake skin with your hands. Well, look at the bad luck! We have brought all this and on top of that eight dollars. I wish we had such bad luck every day, Jim.

en: “Never you mind, honey, never you mind. Don’t you git too peart. It’s a-comin’. Mind I tell you, it’s a-comin’.”
vi: - Don't think so, my friend, don't think so. Don't celebrate too soon. You will see. Remember, you will see, I'm telling you the truth.
tr: "Don't worry at all, my dear, don't worry at all. This luck won't last long. Soon something will happen to us. Don't forget what I said, it's imminent."
es: —Don't think anymore, my child, don't think anymore. Don't get too excited. It will come. Remember what I tell you, it will come.

en: It did come, too. It was a Tuesday that we had that talk. Well, after dinner Friday we was laying around in the grass at the upper end of the ridge, and got out of tobacco. I went to the cavern to get some, and found a rattlesnake in there. I killed him, and curled him up on the foot of Jim’s blanket, ever so natural, thinking there’d be some fun when Jim found him there. Well, by night I forgot all about the snake, and when Jim flung himself down on the blanket while I struck a light the snake’s mate was there, and bit him.
vi: Indeed, the misfortune really came. We talked about that story on the third day. Then on the sixth day, after dinner, we were lying on the grass on the hilltop, and having run out of cigarettes, I went back to the cave to get some and suddenly saw a snake lying there. I killed the snake immediately, but I coiled it up and threw it under the blanket where Jim was lying. It was just a prank, thinking that Jim would be scared when he unexpectedly saw it, and I would get a good laugh. But at night, I had forgotten about the snake, and just as Jim crawled into the blanket and I lit the lamp, the female snake, which had been there for some time, bit Jim immediately.
tr: He really did come. It was Tuesday when we had this conversation. On Friday, while lying on the grass at the upper end of the ridge, I ran out of tobacco. When I went to the cave to get some, I encountered a rattlesnake. I killed the snake and coiled it up at the foot of Jim's blanket. I did this quite naturally, thinking we would have a laugh when Jim found it. By evening, I had forgotten about the snake, and as I was lighting the lamp, Jim threw himself onto the blanket, and the snake's mate bit him.
es: And yes, it did arrive. It was a Tuesday when we talked about it. Well, on Friday after lunch we were lying on the grass at the top of the hill and we ran out of tobacco. I went to the cave to look for something and I came across a rattlesnake. I killed it and coiled it at the foot of Jim's blanket, very naturally, thinking how much fun it would be when Jim found it. Well, at night I forgot about the snake, and when Jim lay down on the blanket while I was lighting a lantern, there was the snake's mate and it bit him.

en: He jumped up yelling, and the first thing the light showed was the varmint curled up and ready for another spring. I laid him out in a second with a stick, and Jim grabbed pap’s whisky-jug and begun to pour it down.
vi: Jim jumped up and screamed, I shone the light and saw the female snake coiling up, ready to strike again. I grabbed a stick and struck it dead with one blow, while Jim grabbed my father's whiskey bottle and poured it down his throat.
tr: Jim jumped into the air with a shout, and the first thing I saw in the light was a coiled snake ready to strike again. I killed it in one swift motion with the stick in my hand, and Jim grabbed my father's whiskey bottle and started drinking.
es: He jumped and screamed, and the first thing we saw in the light was the creature coiled and ready to strike again. I killed it in a second with a stick and Jim grabbed father's jug of whiskey and began to pour it.

en: He was barefooted, and the snake bit him right on the heel. That all comes of my being such a fool as to not remember that wherever you leave a dead snake its mate always comes there and curls around it. Jim told me to chop off the snake’s head and throw it away, and then skin the body and roast a piece of it. I done it, and he eat it and said it would help cure him. He made me take off the rattles and tie them around his wrist, too. He said that that would help. Then I slid out quiet and throwed the snakes clear away amongst the bushes; for I warn’t going to let Jim find out it was all my fault, not if I could help it.
vi: Jim was barefoot, and the snake had bitten him right on the heel. I realized how foolish I was for not remembering that after killing one snake and leaving it there, its mate would come and coil up beside it. Jim told me to cut off the snake's head and throw it far away, then skin it and roast a piece, saying that would neutralize the venom. He also told me to take the rings from the tails of both snakes and tie them around my wrist. Jim said that would make everything alright. Then he quietly went outside, threw the bodies of the two snakes far into the bushes; because I wasn't foolish enough to play with them.
tr: Because he walked barefoot, a snake had bitten him on the heel. It was all because I acted like a complete fool. Wherever you leave a dead snake, its mate will come and coil up next to it. How could I have forgotten this! Jim asked me to cut off the snake's head and then skin the rest and cook a bit of it. I did as he said, he ate the snake meat and said it would help him heal. He also had me remove the snake's rattle and tie it to his wrist. This would also work. After that, I quietly went outside and threw the snake carcasses far away into the bushes; because I was determined to do everything I could so that Jim wouldn't learn it was all my fault.
es: He was barefoot and the snake had bitten him on the heel. And all that because I had been so stupid that I didn't remember that whenever you kill a snake, its mate always appears and coils around it. Jim told me to cut off the snake's head and throw it away, then skin the body and roast a piece. That's what I did, and he ate it and said it would help cure him. He made me remove the rattles and tie them to his wrist. He said that would also relieve him. Then I went out quietly and threw the snakes far away into the bushes, because I wasn't going to let Jim find out that it was all my fault if I could help it.

en: Jim sucked and sucked at the jug, and now and then he got out of his head and pitched around and yelled; but every time he come to himself he went to sucking at the jug again. His foot swelled up pretty big, and so did his leg; but by-and-by the drunk begun to come, and so I judged he was all right; but I’d druther been bit with a snake than pap’s whisky.
vi: Jim gulped down the liquor, gulped it down again, occasionally stretching his neck, shaking his head, and howling; but after each time returning to normal, he would gulp down the liquor again. Jim's foot swelled up very quickly, then his calf too. Gradually the liquor took effect and I thought Jim would be fine. But I also thought that being bitten by a snake would be better than gulping down my father's whiskey.
tr: Jim was constantly drinking, occasionally losing control and attacking and shouting at those around him, but every time he came to his senses, he would drink a little more from the bottle. His foot was quite swollen, and his leg was in bad shape, but then gradually the alcohol took effect, so I thought he was fine; but if it were me, I would prefer to draw snake venom rather than drink my father's whiskey.
es: Jim sucked and sucked from the demijohn and occasionally he would get furious and writhe, screaming, but every time he came to, he would suck from the jug again. His foot swelled up a lot and the same happened to his leg. But after a while, he started to get drunk, so I thought he was okay, although I would have preferred to be bitten by a snake than to have my father's whiskey.

en: Jim was laid up for four days and nights. Then the swelling was all gone and he was around again. I made up my mind I wouldn’t ever take a-holt of a snake-skin again with my hands, now that I see what had come of it. Jim said he reckoned I would believe him next time. And he said that handling a snake-skin was such awful bad luck that maybe we hadn’t got to the end of it yet. He said he druther see the new moon over his left shoulder as much as a thousand times than take up a snake-skin in his hand. Well, I was getting to feel that way myself, though I’ve always reckoned that looking at the new moon over your left shoulder is one of the carelessest and foolishest things a body can do. Old Hank Bunker done it once, and bragged about it; and in less than two years he got drunk and fell off of the shot-tower, and spread himself out so that he was just a kind of a layer, as you may say; and they slid him edgeways between two barn doors for a coffin, and buried him so, so they say, but I didn’t see it. Pap told me. But anyway it all come of looking at the moon that way, like a fool.
vi: Jim lay bedridden for four days and nights. Then the swelling disappeared and Jim was able to walk again. I thought to myself that from now on, I would definitely not touch the shed snake skin anymore, because I had seen how harmful it could be. Jim said that he hoped I would believe him from now on. Then he reiterated that touching the shed snake skin was extremely unlucky, and perhaps we hadn't yet realized how harmful it could be. Jim said he would rather glance at the crescent moon over his left shoulder a thousand times than hold the shed snake skin in his hand. I felt the same way, because I also understood that looking at the crescent moon over one's left shoulder was one of the most careless and foolish things that no one ever did. Old man Huck Bunker once did that and kept boasting about it. Yet, in less than twenty years, he got drunk and fell from a high platform to the ground, lying flat like a log used to wedge a tree stump, so to speak; then they had to carry him through the window to put him in a coffin for burial. That's what they said, I hadn't seen it with my own eyes. My father said so too. Anyway, it was because the old man dared to look at the moon in such a way. Truly foolish.
tr: Jim couldn't get up for four days and nights. But then the swelling went down and he started walking around again. I decided never to hold a snake skin with my hand again, now that I knew what it could lead to. Jim said he hoped I would believe him next time. Holding a snake skin was such terrible bad luck that he expected other things to happen too. He said he would prefer to look at the new moon over his left shoulder a thousand times rather than hold a snake skin with his hand. I had started to think like him, although I always thought that looking at the new moon over your left shoulder was one of the most thoughtless and foolish things a person could do. Old Hank Bunker did it once, and even bragged about it; within two years, he got drunk one day, fell from a shot tower, and hit the ground so hard he was almost flat; they say they buried him between two big doors instead of a coffin; I didn't see it. My father told me. Anyway, this happened to him because he foolishly looked at the moon that way.
es: Jim lay down for four days and nights. Then the swelling disappeared, and he started walking again. I decided that I would never again touch a snake skin with my hands, now that I had seen what happened. Jim said he figured that next time I would believe him because touching snake skins brought so much bad luck that it might not even be over yet. He said he would rather see the new moon over his left shoulder a thousand times than touch a snake skin with his hand. Well, I was also beginning to think the same, although I have always thought that looking at the new moon over your left shoulder is one of the silliest and most absurd things you can do. Old Hank Bunker did it once and bragged a lot about it, and less than two years later he got drunk, fell from the water tower, and was so flattened that he looked like a sheet, so to speak, and they had to put him sideways between two barn doors instead of a coffin and buried him that way, they say, but I don't believe it. My father told me, but anyway, that's what happens when you look at the moon like that, like an idiot.

en: Well, the days went along, and the river went down between its banks again; and about the first thing we done was to bait one of the big hooks with a skinned rabbit and set it and catch a catfish that was as big as a man, being six foot two inches long, and weighed over two hundred pounds. We couldn’t handle him, of course; he would a flung us into Illinois. We just set there and watched him rip and tear around till he drownded. We found a brass button in his stomach and a round ball, and lots of rubbage. We split the ball open with the hatchet, and there was a spool in it. Jim said he’d had it there a long time, to coat it over so and make a ball of it. It was as big a fish as was ever catched in the Mississippi, I reckon. Jim said he hadn’t ever seen a bigger one. He would a been worth a good deal over at the village. They peddle out such a fish as that by the pound in the market-house there; everybody buys some of him; his meat’s as white as snow and makes a good fry.
vi: Day by day, the river water receded and lay between the two banks. The first thing we did was bait a big hook with a skinned rabbit. We cast the bait and caught a giant fish as big as a person, nearly two meters long and weighing almost a hundred pounds. We couldn't pull the fish up, and who knows, it might have dragged us all the way to Illinois. We had no choice but to leave it there and watch it thrash until it died. We found a bronze frame inside the fish's belly, with a ball inside, which contained a spool of wire. Jim said that it had been inside the ball all along, and they wrapped it outside to make the ball. I'm sure this is the biggest fish I've ever seen; I've never seen a fish bigger than this. If it were in the village, it would have sold for a lot of money. With a fish like this, they would cut it into many small pieces, each half a pound, and sell them at the market; everyone would want to buy a few pieces. Its meat is as white as snow and smells delicious when fried.
tr: Days later, the river receded to its old banks, and the first thing we did was bait one of the huge fishing hooks with a skinned rabbit and set a trap to catch a catfish almost as tall as a man. This fish, nearly two meters long, weighed almost ninety kilos. Of course, we couldn't hold it directly; it could have flung us all the way to Illinois. We just stood and watched it thrash and tear around until it drowned. We found a brass mallet, a perfectly round ball, and a bunch of odds and ends in the fish's stomach. When we split the ball with an axe, a spool came out of it. Jim said the spool had been in the fish's stomach for a long time, turning into a ball as it got coated over and over. It was probably the biggest fish ever caught in the Mississippi until that day. Jim said he had never seen a bigger fish either. If we were in the village, it would have fetched quite a good price. They had sold a fish this big by the kilo in the market, and everyone had bought a piece; the fish's flesh was as white as snow and made for good frying.
es: Well, the days went by and the river flowed again between its banks, and one of the first things we did was bait one of the big hooks with a skinned rabbit and cast it, and we caught a catfish as big as a man, because it measured six feet and two inches and weighed more than two hundred pounds. Of course, we couldn't pull it in, because it would have dragged us to Illinois. We sat watching it thrash and struggle until it drowned. In its stomach, we found a copper button, a round ball, and lots of other things. We split the ball with the axe and inside there was a spool. Jim said it had swallowed it a long time ago and that's why it had formed a ball around it. It was one of the biggest fish ever caught in the Mississippi, I think. Jim said he had never seen a bigger one. In town, it would have been worth a lot of money. They sell those fish by the pound at the market; everyone buys some; their skin is as white as snow and they taste very good when fried.

en: Next morning I said it was getting slow and dull, and I wanted to get a stirring up some way. I said I reckoned I would slip over the river and find out what was going on. Jim liked that notion; but he said I must go in the dark and look sharp. Then he studied it over and said, couldn’t I put on some of them old things and dress up like a girl? That was a good notion, too. So we shortened up one of the calico gowns, and I turned up my trouser-legs to my knees and got into it. Jim hitched it behind with the hooks, and it was a fair fit. I put on the sun-bonnet and tied it under my chin, and then for a body to look in and see my face was like looking down a joint of stove-pipe. Jim said nobody would know me, even in the daytime, hardly. I practiced around all day to get the hang of the things, and by-and-by I could do pretty well in them, only Jim said I didn’t walk like a girl; and he said I must quit pulling up my gown to get at my britches-pocket. I took notice, and done better.
vi: The next morning, I told Jim that I felt sad and tired, so I wanted to find some way to be a bit more active. I planned to go out to the river to see if there was anything there. Jim agreed, but told me to wait until evening to go and to be careful. He thought for a moment and then suggested that I should take off the old clothes I was wearing and disguise myself as a girl. That idea sounded good. So we took a short-cut dress, rolled up my pants to the knees, and then put the dress on. Jim used a fishhook to gather the back of the dress, making it look quite nice. I put on a wide-brimmed hat and tied the hat's string under my chin. If anyone wanted to look closely and see my face, they would have to bend down as if looking into a stove chimney. Jim said that no one would recognize me, even in broad daylight; it would be very hard to recognize me. All day long, I practiced walking to get used to it, and gradually I felt quite comfortable in that outfit; but Jim told me that my walk still didn't look like a girl's walk and that I should stop lifting the dress to put my hands in my pants pockets. I followed his advice and imitated more accurately.
tr: The next morning, I said that life was passing slowly and boringly and that I wanted a bit of action. I thought it would be good to cross the river and see what was happening. Jim agreed with me, but he said I should go in the dark and be very careful. Then, after thinking about the matter a bit more, he asked if I could go disguised as a girl using some of those old clothes. That was indeed a good idea. So we shortened one of the calico dresses, rolled up the legs of my pants to my knees, and I put on the dress. When Jim fastened the clasps at the back of the dress, it fit me perfectly. I put on the sun hat and tied its string under my chin; since the wide brim curved down on both sides, anyone wanting to see my face would have to look in like through a stovepipe. Jim said that no one would recognize me even in daylight. I practiced all day long and gradually started to move quite comfortably in the dress; according to Jim, the only thing that didn't resemble girls was my walk; he also told me to stop lifting my skirt and plunging my hand into my pocket. It got better when I paid attention to that.
es: The next morning I said that everything was getting very boring and that I wanted to see some action. I said that I thought I was going to cross the river to see what was happening. Jim liked the idea; but he said I had to go at night and be very careful. Then he kept thinking and added that I could put on some of the clothes we had and dress as a girl. That was also a good idea. So we shortened one of the calico dresses and I rolled up the legs of my pants to my knees and put it on. Jim fastened it at the back with the hooks, and it fit me well. I put on the bonnet and tied it under my chin, and if someone looked at me and saw my face it was like looking through a chimney pipe. Jim said no one would recognize me, not even during the day. I spent the whole day training to get used to it, and after a while it fit me quite well, only Jim said I didn't walk like girls, and that I had to stop lifting my skirts to put my hands in my pockets. I listened to him and it fit better.

en: I started up the Illinois shore in the canoe just after dark.
vi: It was just getting dark when I rowed the boat up to the Illinois shore.
tr: As soon as darkness fell, I set off towards the Illinois shore by canoe.
es: I went to the Illinois side in the canoe just after dark.

en: I started across to the town from a little below the ferry-landing, and the drift of the current fetched me in at the bottom of the town. I tied up and started along the bank. There was a light burning in a little shanty that hadn’t been lived in for a long time, and I wondered who had took up quarters there. I slipped up and peeped in at the window. There was a woman about forty year old in there knitting by a candle that was on a pine table. I didn’t know her face; she was a stranger, for you couldn’t start a face in that town that I didn’t know. Now this was lucky, because I was weakening; I was getting afraid I had come; people might know my voice and find me out. But if this woman had been in such a little town two days she could tell me all I wanted to know; so I knocked at the door, and made up my mind I wouldn’t forget I was a girl.
vi: I went past the provincial area, down at the ferry dock a distance, the current carried my boat to the end of the province. I got off the boat and walked along the foot of the dyke. There was a light in a small hut that seemed to have been unoccupied for a long time. I was curious to know who had come to stay here. I cautiously approached and peeked through a crack in the window. Inside the hut, a woman about forty years old was sitting by a candle placed on a pinewood table. I did not recognize her face; she must have been new here because in this province there was no one whose face I did not know. This was fortunate; earlier I had been worried that someone might recognize my voice and discover who I was. But if that woman had been in this small province for two days, she might be able to tell me everything I wanted to know. Thinking that, I knocked on the door and reminded myself not to forget that I was pretending to be a daughter.
tr: I approached the town from a bit below the ferry dock and, with the help of the current, reached the shore from the very bottom of the town. I tied up the canoe somewhere and started walking along the beach. I saw a light in a small cabin that had been uninhabited for a long time and wondered who had moved in there. I approached quietly and looked inside through the window. Inside, a woman in her forties was sitting at a pine table, knitting by candlelight. Her face didn't look familiar to me; she must have been a stranger, because there wasn't a single person in the town that I didn't know. This was what you called luck, as I had started to feel a bit regretful, fearing that someone might recognize my voice and I would get caught. But if this woman had been living in such a small town for a short time, she could tell me everything I wanted to know; that's why I knocked on the door and decided to absolutely remember that I was a girl.
es: I went towards the town from a little below the ferry landing and the current drifted me to the edge of the town. I moored and started walking along the shore. There was a light on in a cabin where no one had lived for a long time and I wondered who might be there. I approached to look through the window. There was a woman of about forty years old knitting by the light of a candle placed on a pine table. I had never seen her before; she was a stranger, because in that town there wasn't a single face I didn't know. That was fortunate, because I was starting to have doubts. I was beginning to get scared that I had come; people might recognize me by my voice. But if that woman had been in such a small town for only two days, she could tell me everything I wanted to know, so I knocked on the door and decided not to forget that I was a girl.

en: CHAPTER XI.
vi: Chapter XI
tr: Chapter Eleven
es: Chapter 11

en: “Come in,” says the woman, and I did. She says: “Take a cheer.”
vi: The woman said: - Come in. I walked in. She said: - Sit down here.
tr: "Come in," said the woman. I went inside. “Sit down.”
es: —COME IN —said the woman, and I obeyed—. Sit down.

en: I done it. She looked me all over with her little shiny eyes, and says:
vi: I sat down. She looked me over with small but very bright eyes, then asked:
tr: I sat down. With her sparkling little eyes, she examined me from head to toe.
es: I sat down. She looked at me very attentively with bright little eyes, and then she says:

en: “What might your name be?”
vi: - What is your name?
tr: “What's your name, let's see?”
es: —And, what's your name?

en: “Sarah Williams.”
vi: - Sara Willim
tr: “Sarah Williams.”
es: —Sarah Williams.

en: “Where ’bouts do you live? In this neighborhood?’
vi: - Where are you? Is it nearby?
tr: “Where do you live then? Around here?”
es: —Where do you live? Around here?

en: “No’m. In Hookerville, seven mile below. I’ve walked all the way and I’m all tired out.”
vi: Is it nearby? - No, I live in Hookerville, seven miles down from here. I walked all the way up here, and now I'm tired.
tr: “No. I’m from Hookerville, seven miles down. I walked all the way here, I’m exhausted, I swear.”
es: —No, ma'am. In Hookerville, seven miles down. I walked all the way and I am very tired.

en: “Hungry, too, I reckon. I’ll find you something.”
vi: - Surely, you must be hungry, right? Let me find something for you to eat.
tr: "You must be hungry." "Let me get you something.""
es: —And I bet you're hungry. I'm going to get something.

en: “No’m, I ain’t hungry. I was so hungry I had to stop two miles below here at a farm; so I ain’t hungry no more. It’s what makes me so late. My mother’s down sick, and out of money and everything, and I come to tell my uncle Abner Moore. He lives at the upper end of the town, she says. I hain’t ever been here before. Do you know him?”
vi: - No, I'm not hungry. Earlier, I stopped at a camp two miles from here; I was hungry then, but now I'm not hungry anymore. That's why I'm walking slowly. My mother is seriously ill, we have no money and nothing left. I'm going to find and inform my uncle, Abner Moore. My mother said my uncle is at the lower end of the province over there. I've never been to this place before. Do you know my uncle?
tr: “No, no, I'm not hungry. When I got really hungry, I stopped by a farm two miles down; that's why I'm full now. That's why I was so late anyway. My mother is very sick, we ran out of money and food, so I came to talk to my uncle Abner Moore. He lives at the upper end of this town, according to my mother. I've never been here before. Do you know my uncle?”
es: —No, ma'am. I'm not hungry. I was so hungry that I had to stop two miles down from here at a farm, so I'm not hungry anymore. That's why I'm so late. My mother is sick and has run out of money and everything, and I've come to tell my uncle Abner Moore. He lives in the upper part of town, my mother told me. I've never been here before. Do you know him?

en: “No; but I don’t know everybody yet. I haven’t lived here quite two weeks. It’s a considerable ways to the upper end of the town. You better stay here all night. Take off your bonnet.”
vi: - No, I don't know anyone yet. I've only been here for less than two weeks. From here to the end of the province, there are many dirt roads. You should stay here tonight. Take off your hat first.
tr: “No; but I don't know everyone yet. It's not even been two weeks since I moved here. The upper end of the town is quite far away. If you want, you can stay here overnight. You can also take off your hat.”
es: —No, but I still don't know everyone yet. I haven't even been here for two weeks. It's a long way from here to the upper part of the village. You'd better spend the night here. Take off your hat.

en: “No,” I says; “I’ll rest a while, I reckon, and go on. I ain’t afeared of the dark.”
vi: - No, I replied. No, I'm just resting here for a moment and then I'll go right away, I'm not afraid of the dark at all.
tr: "No need," I said, "I should continue on my way after resting a bit. I'm not afraid of heading out in the dark."
es: —No —I said—; I'm just going to rest for a while and then continue. The darkness doesn't scare me.

en: She said she wouldn’t let me go by myself, but her husband would be in by-and-by, maybe in a hour and a half, and she’d send him along with me. Then she got to talking about her husband, and about her relations up the river, and her relations down the river, and about how much better off they used to was, and how they didn’t know but they’d made a mistake coming to our town, instead of letting well alone—and so on and so on, till I was afeard I had made a mistake coming to her to find out what was going on in the town; but by-and-by she dropped on to pap and the murder, and then I was pretty willing to let her clatter right along. She told about me and Tom Sawyer finding the six thousand dollars (only she got it ten) and all about pap and what a hard lot he was, and what a hard lot I was, and at last she got down to where I was murdered. I says:
vi: She said she wouldn't let me go alone. Her husband was coming back in about an hour and a half, and she would ask him to go with me. Then she went on about her husband, and the familiar people at the river's beginning and end, about how happy things were in the old place, and how coming to this province without knowing was so long and tedious, that it would have been better to stay alone - and so on, and so on... To the point that I became scared because I had foolishly come here to ask her about things in the province. But then a moment later, she started talking about my father and the murder case. I wanted to just let her talk and listen. She talked about how Tom Sawyer and I earned twelve thousand dollars (she said twenty thousand), and everything about my father, saying my father was very stubborn, and I was very stubborn too. Then finally, she talked about the part where I was killed. I asked:
tr: He said he wouldn't let me go alone, her husband was supposed to come in about an hour and a half and could take me. Then she started talking about her husband, she talked about their relatives upriver, she talked about their relatives downriver, they used to be very well off, but they were wondering if they made a mistake by coming to this town, they wished they had stayed in the old place – and so on and so forth; I was beginning to fear that I made a mistake by coming to her to find out what was happening in the town; but then she brought up my father and the murder, and that's when I started listening to her chatter wholeheartedly. She talked about how Tom Sawyer and I found six thousand dollars (though she thought it was ten thousand), everything about my father and what a troublemaker he was, and also what a troublemaker I was; finally, she got to the part where I was killed. “Who did it?” I asked.
es: She said she wouldn't let me leave alone but that her husband would arrive later, maybe in an hour and a half, and he would tell her to accompany me. Then she started talking about her husband and her relatives upstream and her relatives downstream and how they used to live much better and that they didn't know if they had made a mistake by coming to our town, instead of settling for staying as they were, and so on, until I feared I had been wrong in thinking that she was going to give me news about what was happening in the town, but then she started talking about father and the murder and there I was indeed willing to let her keep on talking. She told me how Tom Sawyer and I had found the twelve thousand dollars (only she said it was twenty) and the whole story about father, and how bad he was and how bad I was and finally she got to the part where I was murdered, and I said:

en: “Who done it? We’ve heard considerable about these goings on down in Hookerville, but we don’t know who ’twas that killed Huck Finn.”
vi: - Who killed him? I heard people talking a lot about it in Hookerville, but I don't know who killed Huck Finn.
tr: “Who did it?” I asked. “We heard a lot of things about what happened in Hookerville, but we couldn't find out who killed Huck Finn.”
es: —Who was it? In Hookerville, there has been much talk about all those things, but we don't know who it was that killed Huck Finn.

en: “Well, I reckon there’s a right smart chance of people here that’d like to know who killed him. Some think old Finn done it himself.”
vi: - I think the people here really have many special qualities. Even I want to know who killed Huck Finn.
tr: "Actually, almost everyone here wants to know who killed him. Some think that the killer is old Finn himself."
es: —Well, I suppose there are lots of people here who would want to know who killed him. Some say it was old Finn himself.

en: “No—is that so?”
vi: - No! Really, ma'am?
tr: "No way..." "Really?""
es: —No ... do they say that?

en: “Most everybody thought it at first. He’ll never know how nigh he come to getting lynched. But before night they changed around and judged it was done by a runaway nigger named Jim.”
vi: - At first, almost everyone thought so. But then by the afternoon, people changed their minds and said that it was a runaway black man named Jim who killed Huck Finn.
tr: “At first, everyone thought that way. The man will never know how close he came to being lynched. But before nightfall, the situation changed and people concluded that a runaway black man named Jim committed the murder.”
es: —At first, that's what everyone believed. He will never know how close he came to being lynched. But soon they changed their minds and decided it was done by a runaway Black man named Jim.

en: “Why he—”
vi: Oh no - he...
tr: “Well, but he…”
es: —But if he...

en: I stopped. I reckoned I better keep still. She run on, and never noticed I had put in at all:
vi: I immediately fell silent. I thought that it was better to just sit quietly. She continued speaking, ignoring the sentence I had just interjected.
tr: I bit my lip. It would have been better if I hadn't said anything. The woman continued talking, she hadn't even noticed that I was about to interrupt.
es: I kept quiet. I figured it was better not to say anything. She kept talking and didn't realize that I had interrupted her:

en: “The nigger run off the very night Huck Finn was killed. So there’s a reward out for him—three hundred dollars. And there’s a reward out for old Finn, too—two hundred dollars. You see, he come to town the morning after the murder, and told about it, and was out with ’em on the ferry-boat hunt, and right away after he up and left. Before night they wanted to lynch him, but he was gone, you see. Well, next day they found out the nigger was gone; they found out he hadn’t ben seen sence ten o’clock the night the murder was done. So then they put it on him, you see; and while they was full of it, next day, back comes old Finn, and went boo-hooing to Judge Thatcher to get money to hunt for the nigger all over Illinois with. The judge gave him some, and that evening he got drunk, and was around till after midnight with a couple of mighty hard-looking strangers, and then went off with them. Well, he hain’t come back sence, and they ain’t looking for him back till this thing blows over a little, for people thinks now that he killed his boy and fixed things so folks would think robbers done it, and then he’d get Huck’s money without having to bother a long time with a lawsuit. People do say he warn’t any too good to do it. Oh, he’s sly, I reckon. If he don’t come back for a year he’ll be all right. You can’t prove anything on him, you know; everything will be quieted down then, and he’ll walk in Huck’s money as easy as nothing.”
vi: - The black man escaped on the very night Huck Finn was killed. They offered a reward to catch him: three hundred dollars. Then they also offered a reward to catch Finn's father: two hundred dollars. You know, he went to town the morning after the murder happened; he told the story and then went with them on the boat to search for the body. Then right after that, he also escaped. In the evening, they intended to put him on trial, but he had already escaped. The next day, the black man escaped again. They said they saw him at ten o'clock on the night of the murder. So they accused him, you know. After they were sure of it, the next day Finn's father came back, crying loudly, demanding Judge Thatcher to spend money to hunt the black man all over Illinois. The judge gave some money, and in the evening, Finn's father got drunk and lingered until midnight with two very ugly strangers, then left with them. Since then, he hasn't returned, and people haven't bothered to look for him. It's considered over now; but some people think that Finn's father killed his son and arranged things to make it look like a robbery, so he could take Huck's money without worrying about being sued. They said what he did wasn't right. Oh, but I think he was very clever. If he doesn't return within a year, then it's all settled. There's no evidence to accuse him, you understand. So at that point, everything will be fine, and he can easily spend Huck's money without any trouble.
tr: “The black man escaped the very night Huck Finn was killed. That's why they put a bounty on his head… three hundred dollars. They also put a bounty on old Finn's head… two hundred dollars. He came to town the morning after the murder and told what happened, he was on the deck while the search was conducted with the steamboat, but then he left. They wanted to lynch him before nightfall, but he was nowhere to be found. The next day it was noticed that the black man was gone, no one had seen him since ten o'clock on the night of the murder. That's why the murder was pinned on him, while people were thinking this, old Finn came back the next day and asked Judge Thatcher for money to search for the black man all over Illinois. The judge gave him some money, Finn drank until evening and wandered around with a few rather tough-looking strangers until midnight, then took them and left. He hasn't returned since then; for a while no one looked for him, but rumors spread and people now think he killed his own son and made it look like robbers did it. That way he could get hold of Huck's money without wasting time on a long trial. People think he's despicable enough to do that. I think he's a hypocrite too. If he doesn't come back by the end of the year, he'll get away with it. No one can prove anything anyway; by then things will settle down and he'll easily get Huck's money.”
es: —The black man escaped the same night Huck Finn died. So now they are offering a reward for him: three hundred dollars. There is also a reward for old Finn: two hundred dollars. Notice that he came to town the morning after the murder and reported it, and went with the others to search for him on the ferry and immediately left. Right away they wanted to lynch him, but notice that he had already disappeared. Well, the next day they found out that the black man had fled and that no one had seen him since ten o'clock on the night of the murder. So then they offered a reward for him, you understand, and when everyone was convinced the next day, old Finn came back and went crying to Judge Thatcher to ask for money to search for the black man all over Illinois. The judge gave him some and that night he got drunk and stayed until after midnight with two very shady-looking strangers and then left with them. Well, since then he hasn't returned and they don't expect him until this blows over a bit, because now people think he killed his son and arranged things so everyone would believe it was done by some robbers and that way he could take Huck's money without having to bother with a lawsuit for too long. People say it wouldn't be surprising of him. Well, I reckon he's very clever. If he doesn't come back in a year, nothing will happen to him. Nothing can be proven against him, you know; by then things will have calmed down and he can leave with Huck's money without any problem.

en: “Yes, I reckon so, ’m. I don’t see nothing in the way of it. Has everybody quit thinking the nigger done it?”
vi: - Yes, I think so too, grandma. I don't see anything difficult about that. So now no one thinks that the black man did it anymore?
tr: "You are right, ma'am. I also don't think there will be any obstacles in front of him. Does no one think anymore that the murder was committed by the black man?"
es: —Yes, I suppose so, ma'am. I don't think there will be any problems. Do people no longer believe that the black man did it?

en: “Oh, no, not everybody. A good many thinks he done it. But they’ll get the nigger pretty soon now, and maybe they can scare it out of him.”
vi: - Oh no, not everyone. Many people still think the black man did it. But soon they will catch the black man, and perhaps they will still suspect him a lot.
tr: “Of course it does. Many people think he committed the murder. But they will soon catch the black man; maybe if they scare him a little, he'll confess to the murder.”
es: —Ah, no, not everyone. Many believe it was him. But they will catch the black guy very soon and they might scare him into telling the truth.

en: “Why, are they after him yet?”
vi: - So, are they still looking to catch him?
tr: "How will they catch him; did they even start chasing him?""
es: —But, are they still looking for him?

en: “Well, you’re innocent, ain’t you! Does three hundred dollars lay around every day for people to pick up? Some folks think the nigger ain’t far from here. I’m one of them—but I hain’t talked it around. A few days ago I was talking with an old couple that lives next door in the log shanty, and they happened to say hardly anybody ever goes to that island over yonder that they call Jackson’s Island. Don’t anybody live there? says I. No, nobody, says they. I didn’t say any more, but I done some thinking. I was pretty near certain I’d seen smoke over there, about the head of the island, a day or two before that, so I says to myself, like as not that nigger’s hiding over there; anyway, says I, it’s worth the trouble to give the place a hunt. I hain’t seen any smoke sence, so I reckon maybe he’s gone, if it was him; but husband’s going over to see—him and another man. He was gone up the river; but he got back to-day, and I told him as soon as he got here two hours ago.”
vi: - Oh, how naive you are, child. It's not every day that people can easily earn three hundred dollars. Some people think that the black man hasn't fled far from here. I think so too, but I haven't told anyone. A few days ago, I talked to an old couple in the wooden house next door, and they said that few people go to that distant island called Jackson Island. I asked if there was anyone on that island. They said: no, there's no one there at all. I didn't say anything more, but I kept thinking about it. Since I live nearby, I'm sure I saw smoke rising from that direction, from the head of that island, a few days ago. I wondered if the black man might be hiding on the island. I said that anyway, it would be worth the effort to go to that island and search it. Since that day, I haven't seen any more smoke, so I think if there was a black man, he must have left by now. But my husband will go up there to check, along with another person. He went upriver and just returned today. Two hours ago, as soon as he stepped into the house, I told him about it.
tr: "Man, how naive you are! Do you think three hundred dollars are picked up from the roadside every day? Some people think the black man isn't very far from here. I'm one of them... but I haven't told anyone. A few days ago, I was talking to the old couple living in the wooden cabin next door, and they said almost no one goes to the island they call Jackson Island. I asked if no one lives there. No; no one lives there, they said. I didn't say anything else, but I started thinking. I'm almost sure I saw smoke there, it was rising from the head of the island a day or two ago. So, I said to myself, can't the black man be hiding there; in any case, it's worth going there to investigate. I haven't seen smoke since that day, maybe he's gone now, that is, if it was him: Though my husband will go and check, he'll take a man with him. He had gone up the river, but he returned today and as soon as he arrived two hours ago, I told him everything."
es: —Well, you really are innocent! Do you think three hundred dollars grow on trees every day? Some believe the black man hasn't gone very far. And neither do I... But I haven't told anyone. A few days ago, I was talking with a couple of old folks who live next door in the log cabin, and they said that almost no one goes to that island over there called Jackson Island. “And no one lives there?” I asked. “No, no one,” they said. I didn't say anything more, but I've been thinking about it. I was almost sure I had seen smoke over there, towards the tip of the island, a day or two ago, so I said to myself: “Maybe the black man is hiding there; in any case,” I said, “it's worth searching that island.” Since then, I haven't seen any more smoke, so maybe he's gone, if it was him; but my husband is going to check it out, with another person. He had to go upriver, but he came back today, and I told him as soon as he arrived two hours ago.

en: I had got so uneasy I couldn’t set still. I had to do something with my hands; so I took up a needle off of the table and went to threading it. My hands shook, and I was making a bad job of it. When the woman stopped talking I looked up, and she was looking at me pretty curious and smiling a little. I put down the needle and thread, and let on to be interested—and I was, too—and says:
vi: At this moment, I was extremely confused, unable to sit still any longer. I had to move my hands a bit, so I picked up the sewing needle on the table and threaded it. My hands were trembling, and I couldn't thread it. The woman stopped talking, looked up, and gazed at me with a somewhat strange expression, then smiled. I put the needle and thread down, pretending to be interested in the story as well, and said:
tr: I was so on edge that I couldn't stay still anymore. I needed to do something with my hands; so I took the sewing needle on the table and tried to thread it. My hands were trembling and I couldn't get the thread through the hole. The woman stopped talking, and when I looked up, I saw that she was looking at me curiously and smiling slightly. I pretended to be interested in the needle and thread; in fact, I was interested. I said:
es: I had gotten so nervous that I couldn't stay still. I had to do something with my hands, so I took a needle from the table and started threading it. My hands were shaking and I did it very poorly. When the woman stopped talking, I looked up and she was looking at me very curiously and smiling a little. I put down the needle and thread and put on an interested face —and the truth is, I was interested— and I go and say:

en: “Three hundred dollars is a power of money. I wish my mother could get it. Is your husband going over there to-night?”
vi: - Three hundred dollars, that's a lot of money. I also hope my mother can get such an amount. Is your husband going to that island tonight?
tr: “Three hundred dollars is not a small amount of money. It would be great if my mother took it. Will your husband go there tonight?”
es: —Three hundred dollars is a lot of money. I wish my mother had it. Is her husband going there tonight?

en: “Oh, yes. He went up-town with the man I was telling you of, to get a boat and see if they could borrow another gun. They’ll go over after midnight.”
vi: - Oh, yes. He is going to town with the people I just mentioned to get a boat and see if he can borrow a gun. Around midnight, they will leave.
tr: “Yes, of course. He went to the town with the man I mentioned to find a boat, and he will also try to borrow an extra rifle. They will leave after midnight.”
es: —Ah, yes. He has gone to the upper part of the town with the man I told you about, to look for a boat and see if they can borrow another shotgun. They are going to cross after midnight.

en: “Couldn’t they see better if they was to wait till daytime?”
vi: - Why not wait until daytime when it's clearer to see?
tr: “Wouldn't they see better if they waited for the daylight?”
es: —Wouldn't they see better if they waited until it was daytime?

en: “Yes. And couldn’t the nigger see better, too? After midnight he’ll likely be asleep, and they can slip around through the woods and hunt up his camp fire all the better for the dark, if he’s got one.”
vi: - Yes, but during the day the black man can also see us more easily. After midnight, the black man might be fast asleep, so you can sneak through the forest, and if he lights a fire in the dark, it will be easier to find him.
tr: “Yes. But wouldn't the black man see better then? After midnight, he would probably be asleep, so they could quietly move through the forest and search the surroundings, and if there's a fire, they would find it more easily.”
es: —Yes. And, wouldn't he also see better in the dark? After midnight, he is most likely asleep, and they can go through the forest and look for his campfire better if it's dark, if he has a campfire.

en: “I didn’t think of that.”
vi: - It's not that certain.
tr: "This had never occurred to me.""
es: —It hadn't occurred to me.

en: The woman kept looking at me pretty curious, and I didn’t feel a bit comfortable. Pretty soon she says,
vi: The woman looked at me with a tattletale expression, making me even more uneasy. She asked:
tr: The woman kept looking at me with curiosity, and I didn't feel comfortable at all. A little later, she spoke again:
es: The woman kept looking at me very curiously and I didn't feel comfortable at all. And after a moment she goes and asks:

en: “What did you say your name was, honey?”
vi: - Earlier, what did you say your name was?
tr: “What did you say my name was, sweetheart?”
es: —How did you say your name was, beautiful?

en: “M—Mary Williams.”
vi: - M - Mary William
tr: “M… Mary Williams.”
es: —M ... Mary Williams.
