en: Somehow it didn’t seem to me that I said it was Mary before, so I didn’t look up—seemed to me I said it was Sarah; so I felt sort of cornered, and was afeared maybe I was looking it, too. I wished the woman would say something more; the longer she set still the uneasier I was. But now she says:
vi: Strange, didn't I just say it was Mary? Thinking that, but I didn't look up. It seems like I said it was Sara earlier. I felt like I was being cornered, so scared that I didn't dare to look up anymore. The quieter she was, the more confused I felt. But then she asked:
tr: When she first asked, I felt like I didn't say Mary, so I couldn't lift my head to look; I think I said Sarah; that's why I felt cornered and was afraid that the woman would read it from my face. I wished the woman would say something more; the longer we sat in silence, the more uneasy I became. Finally, the woman spoke:
es: I don't know why, but it didn't seem to me that I had said it was Mary before, so I didn't look up... It seemed to me that I had said it was Sarah, so I felt cornered and was afraid that maybe it would show. I wanted the woman to say something else; the longer she stayed silent, the more uncomfortable I felt. But then she goes and says:

en: “Honey, I thought you said it was Sarah when you first come in?”
vi: - I thought you said it was Sara when you first came in?
tr: “When you first came in, I thought you said your name was Sarah, honey, isn't that right?”
es: —Beautiful, I thought you said your name was Sarah when you arrived.

en: “Oh, yes’m, I did. Sarah Mary Williams. Sarah’s my first name. Some calls me Sarah, some calls me Mary.”
vi: - Yes, that's right. Sara Mary William, Sara is my first name. Some people call me Sara, some people call me Mary.
tr: “Yes, ma'am, that's what I said. Sarah Mary Williams. Sarah is my first name. Some call me Sarah; some call me Mary.”
es: —Oh, yes, ma'am, it's true. Sarah Mary Williams. They called me Sarah as a first name. Some call me Sarah and others Mary.

en: “Oh, that’s the way of it?”
vi: - Oh, really?
tr: "Is that so?"
es: —Ah, is that what's happening?

en: “Yes’m.”
vi: I feel more at ease now.
tr: "Yes, ma'am.""
es: —Yes, ma'am.

en: I was feeling better then, but I wished I was out of there, anyway. I couldn’t look up yet.
vi: But I still hope I don't have to sit there anymore. I still can't look up.
tr: I was feeling better, but I still wanted to get out of there as soon as possible. I still couldn't lift my head to look at the woman.
es: I was already feeling better, but I still wanted to leave there anyway. I still didn't dare to lift my gaze.

en: Well, the woman fell to talking about how hard times was, and how poor they had to live, and how the rats was as free as if they owned the place, and so forth and so on, and then I got easy again. She was right about the rats. You’d see one stick his nose out of a hole in the corner every little while. She said she had to have things handy to throw at them when she was alone, or they wouldn’t give her no peace. She showed me a bar of lead twisted up into a knot, and said she was a good shot with it generly, but she’d wrenched her arm a day or two ago, and didn’t know whether she could throw true now. But she watched for a chance, and directly banged away at a rat; but she missed him wide, and said “Ouch!” it hurt her arm so. Then she told me to try for the next one. I wanted to be getting away before the old man got back, but of course I didn’t let on. I got the thing, and the first rat that showed his nose I let drive, and if he’d a stayed where he was he’d a been a tolerable sick rat. She said that was first-rate, and she reckoned I would hive the next one. She went and got the lump of lead and fetched it back, and brought along a hank of yarn which she wanted me to help her with. I held up my two hands and she put the hank over them, and went on talking about her and her husband’s matters. But she broke off to say:
vi: But then she started talking about how hard and poor life was, and how here the mice ran in and out freely as if they owned the house, and so on... At that moment, I felt more at ease, and she immediately started talking about the mice. Every now and then, a mouse would poke its snout out of a hole in the corner of the house. She said that one must always hold something in hand to throw at the mice whenever alone at home. Otherwise, the mice wouldn't let you sit still. She showed me a twisted piece of lead, like a knot, and said it was very good for throwing at mice. But just a few days ago, she sprained her hand while keeping an eye out, then suddenly threw it, but it was still far from the mouse. She cried out in pain; and her hand hurt again. Then she asked me to try throwing at the next mouse. I wanted to leave before her husband came home, but somehow I couldn't. I grabbed the piece of lead, waited for another mouse to poke its snout out, and threw it recklessly. The lead hit the mouse, and it fell over, hitting a thin mouse. She said I was really good, and thought I would throw at the next one too. She picked up the piece of lead, then brought a spool of thread and asked me to help untangle it. I held out my hands, she placed the spool of thread in them, and continued talking about her and her husband. But then she fell silent and said:
tr: Upon this, the woman began to talk about the difficulty of making a living, how they lived in poverty, mice running around as if the house belonged to them, and so on, and I started to feel more at ease. She was right about the mice. From time to time, you could see them poking their noses out of the hole in the corner. She explained that when she was alone, she kept something to throw at the mice, otherwise they wouldn't leave her in peace. She showed me a rod made of twisted lead and said that she usually threw it very accurately, but she was afraid she might miss because she had injured her arm a couple of days ago. Still, she watched for an opportunity and threw it at a mouse she saw, but the lead missed the mouse, and she held her arm saying "Ouch!" She asked me to hit the next mouse. I wanted to leave before the old man came, but of course, I couldn't just rush out. I took the lead ball in my hand and threw it at the first mouse I saw; if it had stayed where it was, it would have been in trouble. The woman said my throw was top-notch and she had no doubt I would hit the next one. She went and fetched the lead, then took out a skein of yarn and asked for my help. I extended my hands and she looped the skein over them, then continued talking about her husband's work. But she paused at one point:
es: Well, the woman started talking about how difficult times were and how poor they were and how rats were running everywhere, as if the house belonged to them, and about this and that, and I began to feel calmer. She was right about the rats. Every now and then you could see one poking its snout out of a hole in a corner. She said she had to have things on hand to throw at them when she was alone, because otherwise, they wouldn't leave her in peace. She showed me a twisted lead bar shaped like a knot and said that she generally had good aim, but that a day or two ago she had dislocated an arm and didn't know if she could aim well now. She waited for an opportunity and immediately threw the bar at a rat, but missed by a lot and said, "Oh!", that her arm hurt a lot. Then she asked me to try with the next one. I wanted to leave before her old man came back, but of course, I didn't say that. I grabbed the bar and threw it at the first rat that poked its snout out, and if it had stayed where it was, it wouldn't have felt very good. She said I threw very well and that she figured I would hit the next one. She got up to fetch the bar and brought it back along with a skein of yarn with which she wanted me to help her. I raised both hands and she placed the skein on them and continued talking about her things and her husband. But she interrupted herself to say:

en: “Keep your eye on the rats. You better have the lead in your lap, handy.”
vi: - Keep an eye on the mouse. Just hold the lead bar in your hand.
tr: "Be on guard against the mice. It's best if the bullet stays in your lap."
es: —Stay alert for the rats. You better keep the bar handy, on your lap.

en: So she dropped the lump into my lap just at that moment, and I clapped my legs together on it and she went on talking. But only about a minute. Then she took off the hank and looked me straight in the face, and very pleasant, and says:
vi: She dropped the lead ingot into the hem of my skirt just as I closed my legs to hold the ingot in place. She started talking again. But only for a moment. Then she lifted the spool, looked straight at my face with a playful expression, and asked:
tr: He threw the lead ball towards my lap while still talking, and as I clamped my legs together to avoid dropping it, he continued to speak. But he only spoke for a minute. Finally, he took the burden from my hands, looked straight into my face, and asked in a sweet voice:
es: So she threw the piece of lead into my lap right at that moment and I squeezed my legs to catch it and she kept talking. But only for a minute or so. Then she took the skein from me and looked me in the eyes and said very kindly:

en: “Come, now, what’s your real name?”
vi: - Hey, tell me the truth, what is your name?
tr: “Tell me… what is your real name?”
es: —Come on, now tell me what your real name is.

en: “Wh—what, mum?”
vi: - What did you say?
tr: "What did you say, ma'am?""
es: —Whaaat? What, ma'am?

en: “What’s your real name? Is it Bill, or Tom, or Bob?—or what is it?”
vi: - What is your real name? Is it Bin, Tom, or Bob? Or what is it?
tr: “What is your real name? Is it Bill, Tom, or Bob?.. What is it?”
es: —What is your real name? Is it Bill or Tom, or Bob? What is your name?

en: I reckon I shook like a leaf, and I didn’t know hardly what to do. But I says:
vi: I thought I was trembling like a leaf, and truly didn't know what to do. But I replied:
tr: At that moment, I started trembling like a leaf, I didn't know what to do. “Please don't make fun of a poor girl, ma'am,” I said.
es: I think I started trembling like a leaf, not knowing what to do. But I said:

en: “Please to don’t poke fun at a poor girl like me, mum. If I’m in the way here, I’ll—”
vi: - Please don't tease a miserable girl like me. If my sitting here bothers you, then I apologize...
tr: “Please don't make fun of a poor girl, ma'am,” I said. “If I am bothering you, I will immediately…””
es: —Please, do not laugh at a poor girl like me, ma'am. If I bother you, I...

en: “No, you won’t. Set down and stay where you are. I ain’t going to hurt you, and I ain’t going to tell on you, nuther. You just tell me your secret, and trust me. I’ll keep it; and, what’s more, I’ll help you. So’ll my old man if you want him to. You see, you’re a runaway ’prentice, that’s all. It ain’t anything. There ain’t no harm in it. You’ve been treated bad, and you made up your mind to cut. Bless you, child, I wouldn’t tell on you. Tell me all about it now, that’s a good boy.”
vi: - No, no, don't go anywhere. Just sit still here. I won't harm you, and I won't tell anyone about you, trust me, tell me the truth. I will keep it a secret for you, I will help you. I will even tell my husband to keep it a secret for you, if you want. Do you understand, you are just a naive young horse that ran away from the herd, nothing more. But it's okay, you were treated harshly so you decided to run away, right? It's so pitiful, I won't tell anyone about you. Now tell me everything, come on, good boy.
tr: “No, you are not going. Sit down and don't move anywhere. I won't harm you, and you can be sure that I won't betray you. Just reveal your secret, you can trust me. I can keep a secret; moreover, I might be able to help you. If you want, even my husband can help you. It's clear that you are a runaway apprentice. So what? There's nothing wrong with that. They treated you harshly, and you decided to run away. I'm thinking of your well-being, my child, why would I betray you? Come on, tell me… be a good child.”
es: —No, nothing like that. Sit down and stay where you are. I'm not going to do anything to you nor will I betray you. You tell me your secret and trust me. I'll keep it, and what's more, I'll help you. My man, the same, if you want. I understand that you are an apprentice and you have run away and nothing more. It's nothing. There's nothing wrong with it. They have treated you badly and you have decided to run away. My son, I wouldn't betray you. Now tell me everything, be a good boy.

en: So I said it wouldn’t be no use to try to play it any longer, and I would just make a clean breast and tell her everything, but she musn’t go back on her promise. Then I told her my father and mother was dead, and the law had bound me out to a mean old farmer in the country thirty mile back from the river, and he treated me so bad I couldn’t stand it no longer; he went away to be gone a couple of days, and so I took my chance and stole some of his daughter’s old clothes and cleared out, and I had been three nights coming the thirty miles. I traveled nights, and hid daytimes and slept, and the bag of bread and meat I carried from home lasted me all the way, and I had a-plenty. I said I believed my uncle Abner Moore would take care of me, and so that was why I struck out for this town of Goshen.
vi: I thought to myself that continuing to act would be futile, so I decided to confess to her and tell her everything, but she must keep her promise. Then I told her that both my parents had died, and the law had forced me to live with an old and cruel landlord in a place thirty miles away from the river. They treated me so badly that I couldn't stay there any longer. Taking advantage of the landlord's absence for a few days, I seized the opportunity to escape and stole some clothes from his daughter, traveling for three nights straight until I arrived here. I traveled by night and hid somewhere to sleep during the day. The bundle of bread and meat I brought was just enough to eat along the way. I also said that I believed my uncle, Abner Moore, would take care of me, which is why I made my way to this Goshen area.
tr: Then I said that there was no point in pretending anymore, I would act completely honestly and tell him everything, but he must not go back on his word. Then I told him that my father and mother had died, that they had given me to a mean old farmer thirty miles away from the river, and that he had treated me so badly that I could no longer bear it; he had gone on a trip for a few days, so I took the opportunity to steal some of his daughter's old clothes and ran away; I had been on the road for three nights and had come thirty miles; I was traveling at night, hiding and sleeping during the day; I had taken a bag full of meat and bread from the house, and my provisions would last longer. I thought my Uncle Abner Moore would take me in, so I had come to the town of Goshen.
es: So I said that there was no point in continuing to pretend and that I would stop lying and tell him everything, but he had to keep his promise. Then I told him that my father and mother had died and that the law had assigned me to an old and mean farmer who lived at least thirty miles from the river and treated me so badly that I couldn't stand it anymore; he had gone away for a couple of days and I took the opportunity to steal an old dress from his daughter and run away, and it had taken me three nights to cover the thirty miles. I traveled at night and hid to sleep during the day, and the bag of bread and meat I had taken with me had lasted the whole way, and I still had some left. I said that I believed my uncle Abner Moore would take care of me and that was why I had come to this town of Goshen.

en: “Goshen, child? This ain’t Goshen. This is St. Petersburg. Goshen’s ten mile further up the river. Who told you this was Goshen?”
vi: - Goshen, where are you, boy! This is not Goshen, this is Petersburg. Goshen is still ten miles up the river. Who told you this was Goshen? - Really?
tr: “Is this Goshen, my dear? This isn't Goshen. This is St. Petersburg. Goshen is ten miles up the river. Who told you this was Goshen?”
es: —Goshen, kid? This is not Goshen. This is Saint Petersburg. Goshen is ten miles upriver. Who told you this was Goshen?

en: “Why, a man I met at daybreak this morning, just as I was going to turn into the woods for my regular sleep. He told me when the roads forked I must take the right hand, and five mile would fetch me to Goshen.”
vi: But there was a person I met at dawn today, when I was about to turn into the forest to sleep, who told me to turn right at the fork, then go five more miles to reach Goshen.
tr: "This morning at dawn, before going to sleep among the trees, I met a man. He told me to turn right when I reached the fork in the road, and after five miles, I would reach Goshen."
es: —Well, a man I met at dawn this morning, just as I was about to go into the forest to sleep, as always. He told me that the roads split and that I should follow the one on the right and after five miles I would be in Goshen.

en: “He was drunk, I reckon. He told you just exactly wrong.”
vi: - He must be drunk. What he said is completely wrong.
tr: “He was probably drunk. He gave you the directions completely wrong.”
es: —He must have been drunk. He told you exactly the opposite of what it is.

en: “Well, he did act like he was drunk, but it ain’t no matter now. I got to be moving along. I’ll fetch Goshen before daylight.”
vi: - Yes, he does look drunk. But well, there's nothing we can do about it now. I have to travel a bit further. I'll reach Goshen before dawn.
tr: “No wonder, it was swaying back and forth, but that’s of no use now. I must continue on my way. I will reach Goshen before dawn breaks.”
es: —Well, he did seem drunk, but it doesn't matter anymore. I have to keep going. I'll reach Goshen before dawn.

en: “Hold on a minute. I’ll put you up a snack to eat. You might want it.”
vi: - Wait a moment, let me get you something to eat quickly. You must be hungry.
tr: “Wait a minute. Let me pack you something to eat. You can eat it on the way.”
es: —Wait a moment. I'm going to give you something to eat. Maybe you need it.

en: So she put me up a snack, and says:
vi: She gave me food and then asked:
tr: After stuffing some food into my hand, he continued:
es: So he prepared something for me to eat and said:

en: “Say, when a cow’s laying down, which end of her gets up first? Answer up prompt now—don’t stop to study over it. Which end gets up first?”
vi: - Hey, when a cow is lying on the ground, which end does it stand up from first? Answer immediately, no thinking allowed. Which end stands up first?
tr: “Tell me... when a cow is lying down, which part of it gets up first? Answer quickly, don't think about it. Which part gets up first?”
es: —Hey, when a cow lies down, which part does it get up from? Answer quickly, come on; don't stop to think about it. Which side does it get up from?

en: “The hind end, mum.”
vi: - The tail end
tr: "The back side, ma'am."
es: —Through the back, ma'am.

en: “Well, then, a horse?”
vi: - The tail end
tr: “What about the horse?”
es: —Well, how about a horse?

en: “The for’rard end, mum.”
vi: - The tail end
tr: "The front will lift, ma'am."
es: —Through the front one, ma'am.

en: “Which side of a tree does the moss grow on?”
vi: - So, which side of the tree does moss grow on?
tr: “On which side of the tree does moss grow?”
es: —On which side of a tree does moss grow?

en: “North side.”
vi: - The north
tr: “On the north side.”
es: —From the north.

en: “If fifteen cows is browsing on a hillside, how many of them eats with their heads pointed the same direction?”
vi: - If fifteen cows graze on the hill, how many face the same direction?
tr: “If fifteen cows are grazing on a hillside, how many of them have their heads turned in the same direction?”
es: —If there are fifteen cows grazing on a slope, how many of them eat with their heads facing the same direction?

en: “The whole fifteen, mum.”
vi: - All fifteen of them
tr: "All of them, ma'am."
es: —Three o'clock, ma'am.

en: “Well, I reckon you have lived in the country. I thought maybe you was trying to hocus me again. What’s your real name, now?”
vi: - Alright, so I know you were in the countryside. I thought you were going to trick me again. So what's your real name now?
tr: “Alright, it’s clear that you know farm life. I was afraid that you might be deceiving me again. What is your real name, let’s see?”
es: —Well, I suppose it's true that you've lived in the countryside. I thought maybe you were trying to deceive me again. And what's your real name?

en: “George Peters, mum.”
vi: - George Peter is old.
tr: "George Peters, ma'am.""
es: —George Peters, ma'am.

en: “Well, try to remember it, George. Don’t forget and tell me it’s Elexander before you go, and then get out by saying it’s George Elexander when I catch you. And don’t go about women in that old calico. You do a girl tolerable poor, but you might fool men, maybe. Bless you, child, when you set out to thread a needle don’t hold the thread still and fetch the needle up to it; hold the needle still and poke the thread at it; that’s the way a woman most always does, but a man always does t’other way. And when you throw at a rat or anything, hitch yourself up a tiptoe and fetch your hand up over your head as awkward as you can, and miss your rat about six or seven foot. Throw stiff-armed from the shoulder, like there was a pivot there for it to turn on, like a girl; not from the wrist and elbow, with your arm out to one side, like a boy. And, mind you, when a girl tries to catch anything in her lap she throws her knees apart; she don’t clap them together, the way you did when you catched the lump of lead. Why, I spotted you for a boy when you was threading the needle; and I contrived the other things just to make certain. Now trot along to your uncle, Sarah Mary Williams George Elexander Peters, and if you get into trouble you send word to Mrs. Judith Loftus, which is me, and I’ll do what I can to get you out of it. Keep the river road all the way, and next time you tramp take shoes and socks with you. The river road’s a rocky one, and your feet’ll be in a condition when you get to Goshen, I reckon.”
vi: - Alright, remember this, George. Before you go, make sure to tell me that you are Alexander, and then when you are outside, say that I caught you and that you are George Alexander. And don't wear those old clothes when you go to places with women. You can pretend to be a poor girl, but men will still notice. Poor you, whenever you thread a needle, don't hold the needle still and then thread it; women always do that, but men do it differently. And whenever you throw a mouse or anything else, remember to stand on tiptoe a bit, raise your hand over your head to look very awkward, and throw it a few feet away from the mouse. You have to throw in a way that looks stiff all the way from the shoulder down, as if there's a pin in your shoulder that rotates your arm, so it looks like a girl, not throwing with your wrist or elbow and spreading your arm out to one side like a boy. And also remember that when a girl moves, she spreads her knees apart, not keeping them together like you did earlier to hold the lead piece. It's no wonder, from the moment you threaded the needle, I knew you were a boy, so I tested that to be sure. Now, go find your uncle, Sara Mary William George Alexander Peter. If you run into any trouble, send word to me, Mrs. Judith Loftus. I'll do whatever I can to help you. Follow the river path, and next time you walk such a long distance, wear shoes and socks. The river path is full of pebbles; by the time you get to Goshen, your feet will hurt a lot.
tr: “Alright, try not to forget this, George. Don't forget and don't tell me your name is Elexander before you leave, and especially don't make up the lie that your name is George-Elexander when your cover is blown. Also, don't approach women in that shabby calico dress. Your imitation of a girl is quite bad, but maybe you can fool the men. For heaven's sake, child, the next time you need to thread a needle, don't try to push the needle's eye through the thread; keep the needle steady and pass the thread through the eye... Women always do it this way, but men always do the opposite. Also, if you're going to throw something at a mouse or whatever, rise up on your toes, lift your hand as awkwardly as possible over your head, and then throw it two or three meters away from the mouse. Throw directly using your shoulder, as if your arm is moving from the shoulder... Do it like girls do; don't throw like a man by bending your wrist and elbow and opening your arm to the side. And remember, a girl spreads her knees apart to catch something that falls into her lap; she doesn't keep her knees together like you did when catching the lead ball. I realized you were a boy when you first tried to thread the needle; then I had you do the others to be sure. Now go to your uncle, Sarah Mary Williams George Elexander Peters, and if you get into trouble, send word to Mrs. Judith Loftus, that is, to me, and I'll do what I can to help. Continue along the river path and don't forget to take shoes and socks with you the next time you go out. The river path is rocky, and your feet won't be in good shape by the time you reach Goshen.”
es: —Well, George, try to remember it. Don't forget and tell me it's Elexander before you leave and then try to fix it by saying it's George Elexander when I catch you. And don't go near women with that old dress. You do a pretty bad job as a girl, but maybe you can fool the men. And remember, son, when you start threading a needle, you don't have to hold the thread still and bring the needle to it: keep the needle still and pass the thread through it; that's how practically all women do it, but men always do it the other way around. And when you throw something at a rat or something like that, remember that you have to stand on tiptoe and raise your hand above your head as clumsily as you can and miss the rat by six or seven feet. Throw with a stiff arm from the shoulder, as if you had an axis, like girls do, and not with the wrist and elbow with the arm to the side, like boys do. And remember that when a girl tries to pick something up in her lap, she spreads her knees apart, not together like you did when I threw the lead bar at you. But man, I knew you were a boy as soon as you started threading the needle, and the other things I did to be sure. Now, run along to your uncle, Sarah Mary Williams George Elexander Peters, and if you get into any trouble, send a message to Mrs. Judith Loftus, who is me, and I'll do what I can to get you out of it. Always follow the river road, and next time you set out, wear shoes and socks. The river road has a lot of stones, and I figure your feet will be worn out by the time you get to Goshen.

en: I went up the bank about fifty yards, and then I doubled on my tracks and slipped back to where my canoe was, a good piece below the house. I jumped in, and was off in a hurry. I went up-stream far enough to make the head of the island, and then started across. I took off the sun-bonnet, for I didn’t want no blinders on then. When I was about the middle I heard the clock begin to strike, so I stops and listens; the sound come faint over the water but clear—eleven. When I struck the head of the island I never waited to blow, though I was most winded, but I shoved right into the timber where my old camp used to be, and started a good fire there on a high and dry spot.
vi: I walked upstream about fifty meters and then turned back, rushing to the place where the boat was, a distance below that house. I jumped into the boat, hurriedly rowing away. I went quite far upstream, all the way to the head of the island, then veered across. I took off my hat, as there was no need to disguise anymore. Earlier, when I was halfway there, I heard the bell ringing, faintly over the water but still clear, it was eleven o'clock. At the head of the island, even though the wind was blowing strong, I didn't need to take cover anymore but headed straight for the spot with the log where I had hidden when I first arrived and had once lit a fire in a dry place.
tr: I went fifty meters up along the river, then walked back on my own footprints and moved to the hidden spot below the house where my canoe was. I immediately jumped into the canoe and hurriedly moved away. After rowing against the current along the shore until I reached the head of the island, I began to cross the river. I took off the hat because I didn't want it to obstruct my view. When I reached the middle of the river, I heard the clock chime; I stopped and listened; the sound was faintly coming over the water but I heard it clearly – eleven. When I reached the head of the island, even though I was very tired, I didn't wait to catch my breath; I immediately carried some wood to the place where my old camp was and built a huge fire in a high and dry spot.
es: I went along the riverbank for about fifty yards and then retraced my steps to return to where my canoe was, quite far below the house. I jumped in and started running. I went upstream far enough to reach the tip of the island, and then I started to cross. I took off my bonnet, because I didn't want to go as if with earmuffs. When I was about halfway across, I heard the clock start to chime, so I stopped to listen; the sound was faint over the water, but clear: eleven o'clock. When I reached the tip of the island, I didn't stop to rest, even though I was out of breath; instead, I went straight to where my old camp was and lit a good fire, in a high and dry place.

en: Then I jumped in the canoe and dug out for our place, a mile and a half below, as hard as I could go. I landed, and slopped through the timber and up the ridge and into the cavern. There Jim laid, sound asleep on the ground. I roused him out and says:
vi: I rowed hard to the place where we stayed, more than a mile downstream. Then I went ashore, leaped over the log, climbed up the mound, and rushed into the cave. Jim was lying there, fast asleep on the ground. I shook him awake and said:
tr: Then I got back into the canoe and rowed about a mile and a half downstream to our main location. I landed, quickly passed through the trees, climbed the slope, and entered the cave. Jim was sleeping like a log inside. I immediately woke him up.
es: Then I jumped into the canoe and went to our spot, a mile and a half downstream, as fast as I could. I disembarked and moved through the trees to the hill and reached the cave. There was Jim, sleeping like a log on the ground. I woke him up and said to him:

en: “Git up and hump yourself, Jim! There ain’t a minute to lose. They’re after us!”
vi: - Wake up, Jim, we're doomed. We can't afford to be late by even a minute. They're hunting us down!
tr: “Get up quickly and pack, Jim! We don't have a minute to lose. They're after us!”
es: —Get up and get ready, Jim! There isn't a minute to lose. They're looking for us!

en: Jim never asked no questions, he never said a word; but the way he worked for the next half an hour showed about how he was scared. By that time everything we had in the world was on our raft, and she was ready to be shoved out from the willow cove where she was hid. We put out the camp fire at the cavern the first thing, and didn’t show a candle outside after that.
vi: Jim didn't ask anything nor did he say anything, but just by looking at his hasty manner for about half an hour, one could tell he was very scared. When the raft was ready to leave the willow thicket, where we had been hiding it. The first thing we did was extinguish the fire in the cave, and after that, we didn't light any candles either.
tr: Jim didn't ask anything, he didn't even say a word; his behavior over the next half hour was enough to show how scared he was. Now, everything we owned was on our raft, and we were ready to take it out from behind the willow curtain where we had hidden it. We had put out the fire in the cave from the very beginning and never lit even a candle outside again.
es: Jim didn't ask any questions or say a word; but from the way he worked the next half hour, it was clear that he was terrified. By then, we had everything we owned in the raft and were ready to take it out from among the willows where it was hidden. The first thing we did was put out the fire in the cave, and after that, we didn't light even a candle.

en: I took the canoe out from the shore a little piece, and took a look; but if there was a boat around I couldn’t see it, for stars and shadows ain’t good to see by. Then we got out the raft and slipped along down in the shade, past the foot of the island dead still—never saying a word.
vi: I took the boat out a bit from the shore to scout ahead. But even if there was a boat right there, nothing could be seen because it was pitch dark, with only starlight, nothing visible. Then we pushed the raft out, letting it glide down the river, through the darkness past the other end of the island, silent as death, no one uttering a word.
tr: I wanted to sail a bit away from the island to see what was happening, but even if there was a boat there, I couldn't see it; because it was impossible to distinguish anything in the shadows under the starlight. Then we launched the raft and started descending through the shadows, not moving or uttering a word as we passed the foot of the island.
es: I moved the canoe away from the shore a little and started to look; but if there was a boat around there, I couldn't see it, because the stars and shadows aren't good for seeing much. Then we took out the raft and went down among the shadows, to the foot of the island in total silence, without saying a word.

en: CHAPTER XII.
vi: Chapter XII
tr: Chapter Two
es: Chapter 12

en: It must a been close on to one o’clock when we got below the island at last, and the raft did seem to go mighty slow. If a boat was to come along we was going to take to the canoe and break for the Illinois shore; and it was well a boat didn’t come, for we hadn’t ever thought to put the gun in the canoe, or a fishing-line, or anything to eat. We was in ruther too much of a sweat to think of so many things. It warn’t good judgment to put everything on the raft.
vi: It was probably close to one in the morning when we finally reached the area below the island. It seemed like our raft was moving incredibly slowly. If any boat or ship had come by, we would have had to jump into the canoe and make a run for the Illinois shore immediately. But luckily, no boats came by, and we didn't think to put the gun, the fishing rod, or any food into the canoe either. At that moment, we were in such a rush, panicking, and didn't think everything through. Besides, putting everything onto the raft wouldn't have been practical.
tr: It was probably around one o'clock by the time we reached the lower part of the island. Don't even ask how slowly the raft was moving. If we saw a boat, we were going to immediately jump into the canoe and escape to the Illinois shore. Fortunately, no boats were in sight, because we hadn't thought to place the rifle, fishing rods, or food in the canoe. We were too drenched in sweat to think of so many things. Loading everything onto the raft was not a wise move at all.
es: IT MUST HAVE BEEN almost one o'clock when we finally passed the end of the island and the raft seemed to move very slowly. If a boat came near, the plan was to get into the canoe and head towards the Illinois shore, and it's a good thing none did, because it hadn't occurred to us to put the shotgun in the canoe, nor a fishing line, nor anything to eat. We were in too much of a hurry to think of so many things. It hadn't been very smart to put everything on the raft.

en: If the men went to the island I just expect they found the camp fire I built, and watched it all night for Jim to come. Anyways, they stayed away from us, and if my building the fire never fooled them it warn’t no fault of mine. I played it as low down on them as I could.
vi: If those two people come to the island, I'm sure they will see our campfire and wait there all night for Jim to come. Anyway, they are still farther from our place, and if our fire deceives them, it's not my fault. But the more we can trick them, the better.
tr: I thought that if the men went to the island, they would find the fire I had lit and lie in ambush, waiting for Jim to return throughout the night. Anyway, they were already far from us, and if the fire I had lit did not deceive them, it was not my fault. For this, I had made as good a plan as I could.
es: If the men went to the island, I suppose they would find the bonfire I had made and would wait all night for Jim to arrive. In any case, they did not come near us, and if that bonfire did not deceive them, it was not my fault. I had done everything possible to mislead them.

en: When the first streak of day began to show we tied up to a tow-head in a big bend on the Illinois side, and hacked off cottonwood branches with the hatchet, and covered up the raft with them so she looked like there had been a cave-in in the bank there. A tow-head is a sandbar that has cottonwoods on it as thick as harrow-teeth.
vi: When the first light of day appeared, we tied the raft to a crevice near a large beach on the Illinois side; using an axe, we cut some cottonwood branches to cover it, making it look as if there had long been a recess at this part of the riverbank. At the front was a sandbar, with dense cottonwood trees growing thickly like the teeth of a comb.
tr: As the first light of dawn began to appear, we pulled the raft to a wooded shore that caught our eye as we came to a large bend on the Illinois side. We covered the raft nicely with branches we cut from the shore, which was lined with densely packed poplar trees like the teeth of a comb. When we finished our work, it looked as if there was a natural depression among the poplars; the raft was completely invisible.
es: When the first light of day began to appear, we moored to a sandbar that was in a large curve on the Illinois side, cut cottonwood branches with the axe, and covered the raft with them so that it would look like there had been a landslide along that shore. On those sandbars, the cottonwoods are as tightly packed as the teeth of a rake.

en: We had mountains on the Missouri shore and heavy timber on the Illinois side, and the channel was down the Missouri shore at that place, so we warn’t afraid of anybody running across us. We laid there all day, and watched the rafts and steamboats spin down the Missouri shore, and up-bound steamboats fight the big river in the middle. I told Jim all about the time I had jabbering with that woman; and Jim said she was a smart one, and if she was to start after us herself she wouldn’t set down and watch a camp fire—no, sir, she’d fetch a dog. Well, then, I said, why couldn’t she tell her husband to fetch a dog? Jim said he bet she did think of it by the time the men was ready to start, and he believed they must a gone up-town to get a dog and so they lost all that time, or else we wouldn’t be here on a tow-head sixteen or seventeen mile below the village—no, indeedy, we would be in that same old town again. So I said I didn’t care what was the reason they didn’t get us as long as they didn’t.
vi: On the Illinois side, there are mountains. On the Illinois side, there are only big trees. This stretch of the river has a creek flowing towards the Illinois side, so we weren't afraid of anyone passing by here. We lay there all day, watching the rafts and steamboats going down the Illinois side, and the boats going upstream roaring in the middle of the river. I told Jim about the time I sat chatting with that woman, and Jim said she was a strange woman; if she had been the one hunting us, she wouldn't have bothered sitting by the campfire, but instead, sir, she would have led the hunt herself. I asked why she didn't suggest her husband bring the dogs. Jim said he guessed she had thought of that when her husband was about to leave, and probably the man went to town to get the dogs, which took so much time. That's why we could run to this place, sixteen or seventeen miles away from the village; otherwise, we would still be stuck in that old town. I think as long as they haven't caught us, it doesn't matter why they haven't caught us yet.
tr: On the Missouri side, there were mountains, while on the Illinois side, there were dense forests, and since the river flowed from the Missouri side, we had no fear of encountering anyone where we were. We lay there all day watching the rafts and steamers descend towards Missouri and the steamers coming up struggle with the vast river in the middle. I told Jim about the conversation I had with that woman; he said she was a cunning woman, and if she were after us, she wouldn't just sit by the campfire – no, sir, she would definitely bring a dog with her. But couldn't she have told her husband to go get a dog? Jim said that the woman had probably already thought of that before the men set out and that they were likely delayed because they went to get a dog from the upper part of the town, otherwise, we wouldn't be at this shallow spot sixteen or seventeen miles down from the village – we would find ourselves back in the old town. I said that as long as they didn't catch us, I wouldn't care why they didn't catch us.
es: We saw mountains on the Missouri side and a lot of forest on the Illinois side, and the channel, on that part, ran on the Missouri side, so we weren't afraid of running into anyone. We stayed there all day watching the rafts and steamboats going down the Missouri side and the steamboats going upriver fighting against the current in the center. I told Jim everything that had happened when I was talking to the woman and Jim said she was very smart and that if she were the one looking for us, she wouldn't just sit by a fire; no, sir, she would go with a dog. Well, then, I said, why couldn't she tell her husband to get a dog? Jim said that she would surely think of it when the men set out, and he supposed she must have gone to the upper part of the town to get a dog, so they had lost all that time, or else we wouldn't be there on the sandbar sixteen or seventeen miles below the town; no, sir, we would be back in town. So I said I didn't care why they weren't coming, as long as they didn't come.

en: When it was beginning to come on dark we poked our heads out of the cottonwood thicket, and looked up and down and across; nothing in sight; so Jim took up some of the top planks of the raft and built a snug wigwam to get under in blazing weather and rainy, and to keep the things dry. Jim made a floor for the wigwam, and raised it a foot or more above the level of the raft, so now the blankets and all the traps was out of reach of steamboat waves. Right in the middle of the wigwam we made a layer of dirt about five or six inches deep with a frame around it for to hold it to its place; this was to build a fire on in sloppy weather or chilly; the wigwam would keep it from being seen. We made an extra steering-oar, too, because one of the others might get broke on a snag or something. We fixed up a short forked stick to hang the old lantern on, because we must always light the lantern whenever we see a steamboat coming down-stream, to keep from getting run over; but we wouldn’t have to light it for up-stream boats unless we see we was in what they call a “crossing”; for the river was pretty high yet, very low banks being still a little under water; so up-bound boats didn’t always run the channel, but hunted easy water.
vi: It started to get dark, so we poked our heads out from the pile of cotton, looked around, and saw nothing. Then Jim lifted the planks on the raft and set them up into a tent so we could crawl into it when it rained or shone, and to keep our belongings from getting wet. Jim also built an additional wooden platform about thirty centimeters high on the outside so that when large waves from passing ships hit, they wouldn't splash onto our belongings. In the middle of the tent, we made a small depression, filled it with soil about a decimeter deep, and surrounded it with wood to make a fireplace for when it rained and got cold, and also to keep it inside the tent so people wouldn't see it. We erected a short stick with a notch at the top to hang an old lantern on whenever a ship was passing downstream, to avoid collisions. As for the boats going upstream, we didn't need to light the lantern unless we were crossing the river; because the surface water flowed quite strongly, and there were many hidden sandbars below, so upstream boats often didn't travel in the middle of the river but chose spots where the current was less strong.
tr: When it started to get dark, we poked our heads out from between the dense poplars and looked up, down, and across; there was nothing; so Jim took apart a few of the upper planks of the raft to make a narrow shelter to get under in the extreme heat and rain, and also to keep our belongings dry. He made space on the raft for the shelter, then raised it about half a meter above the raft's floor; this way, our blankets and traps would no longer be affected by the waves created by the steamers. We made a 15-centimeter deep hole in the middle of the shelter out of mud, and supported its perimeter with planks to prevent it from spreading; this was for making a fire in rainy or cool weather, and the shelter would block the fire from being seen from a distance. We also made an extra steering pole, because the others could get stuck somewhere and break. We set up a short forked stick to hang the old tattered lantern, because when you see a steamer coming down the river, you must light the lantern so it doesn't hit you; but if we weren't at one of those places they call "crossings," there was no need to light the lantern for steamers going upriver. The river was still quite high, and the low-lying banks were still underwater; so the ships going upriver could prefer places with less current instead of using the usual channel.
es: When it started to get dark, we poked our heads out among the poplars and looked up and down and to the sides but saw nothing, so Jim took some of the logs off the top of the raft and built a very comfortable wigwam for us to take shelter in when it got very hot or rained and to keep things dry. Jim made a floor for the wigwam and raised it a foot above the level of the raft, so that the blankets and traps were out of reach of the steamboat waves. Right in the middle of the wigwam, we put a layer of dirt five or six inches thick and surrounded it with a frame to keep it from spilling out; it was for making a fire when it rained or got cold; with the wigwam, it wouldn't be visible. We also prepared a spare rudder, because one of the ones we had could break or get caught or whatever. We set up a pole with a fork to hang the old lantern from, because we would always have to light it when we saw a steamboat coming downstream, so it wouldn't miss us, but we didn't have to light it for the ones going upstream unless we found ourselves in what they call "between currents," because the river was still very high and the low banks were still submerged, so the boats going upstream didn't always go through the channel but looked for easier waters.

en: This second night we run between seven and eight hours, with a current that was making over four mile an hour. We catched fish and talked, and we took a swim now and then to keep off sleepiness. It was kind of solemn, drifting down the big, still river, laying on our backs looking up at the stars, and we didn’t ever feel like talking loud, and it warn’t often that we laughed—only a little kind of a low chuckle. We had mighty good weather as a general thing, and nothing ever happened to us at all—that night, nor the next, nor the next.
vi: On the second night, we traveled for about seven or eight hours, on the fast-flowing water that moved at four miles per hour. We caught fish, chatted, and occasionally jumped into the water for a quick swim to stay awake. Traveling on this large and quiet river felt solemn somehow. We lay on our backs looking at the stars in the sky, never daring to speak loudly, and rarely laughed. We just kept our mouths shut, making a few puffing sounds. Overall, the weather was very nice; that night, the next night, and the night after that, nothing happened.
tr: On the second night, we traveled for another seven or eight hours, thanks to the current, we were probably going faster than four miles per hour. We fished, chatted, and when we got sleepy, we tried to wake up by swimming a bit. Drifting on the wide and calm river while lying on our backs and watching the stars felt a bit gloomy, we didn't want to speak loudly at all, nor did we laugh much – occasionally we would let out short, muffled laughs. Generally, the weather was very good and nothing happened to us – neither that night, nor the next, nor the night after that.
es: The second night we sailed for seven or eight hours, with a current that went more than four miles per hour. We fished and chatted and occasionally went for a swim to avoid falling asleep. It was quite solemn to drift down the great silent river, lying on our backs and looking at the stars, and we didn't feel like speaking loudly or laughing much, just an occasional low chuckle. Overall, we had very good weather and nothing happened to us, neither that night nor the next nor the one after.

en: Every night we passed towns, some of them away up on black hillsides, nothing but just a shiny bed of lights; not a house could you see. The fifth night we passed St. Louis, and it was like the whole world lit up. In St. Petersburg they used to say there was twenty or thirty thousand people in St. Louis, but I never believed it till I see that wonderful spread of lights at two o’clock that still night. There warn’t a sound there; everybody was asleep.
vi: Every night we passed through places with towns, sometimes the town was on a distant hillside, only visible as a long streak of light without clear sight of the houses. On the fifth night, we passed through St. Louis, which looked like an entire world lit up. In Petersburg, they always said that St. Louis had up to twenty or thirty thousand people, but I didn't believe it until we passed by at two in the morning and saw such brilliant lights, then I believed it was true. Inside the city, there was not a sound, everyone had gone to sleep.
tr: Every night we passed by towns, some of which were on dark slopes in the distance, and all you could see were clusters of bright lights, you couldn't distinguish a single house. On the fifth night, we passed St. Louis, it was as if the whole world was illuminated. St. The people in St. Petersburg used to say that twenty to thirty thousand people lived in St. Louis, but I didn't believe it until I saw the beautiful flood of lights covering the entire slope on that still night. There was no sound, everyone was in a deep sleep.
es: Every night we passed by villages, some of them far away on black hills, without seeing anything more than the glow of a few lights, and not a single house. On the fifth night we passed by Saint Louis and it was as if the entire world was illuminated. In Saint Petersburg, they said that Saint Louis had twenty or thirty thousand inhabitants, but I never believed it until I saw that wonderful amount of lights at two on a silent night. Not a sound was heard: everyone was asleep.

en: Every night now I used to slip ashore towards ten o’clock at some little village, and buy ten or fifteen cents’ worth of meal or bacon or other stuff to eat; and sometimes I lifted a chicken that warn’t roosting comfortable, and took him along. Pap always said, take a chicken when you get a chance, because if you don’t want him yourself you can easy find somebody that does, and a good deed ain’t ever forgot. I never see pap when he didn’t want the chicken himself, but that is what he used to say, anyway.
vi: Every night, I usually go ashore at ten o'clock, go to a small village to buy ten or fifteen cents worth of bread or meat or something to eat, sometimes I catch and bring back a chicken that refuses to stay in its coop. My father used to say that whenever there was a chance to catch a chicken, just catch it, because that way you never forget an act of kindness. I've never actually seen my father not care about chickens, but he always said that.
tr: Every night around ten o'clock, I would secretly go to the shore near a small village; I would buy flour, pastrami, or some other food worth ten or fifteen cents; sometimes I would steal a chicken, but cooking it was difficult and took a long time. My father always used to say, if you come across a chicken, don't miss the opportunity; because even if you didn't eat it yourself, you could always find someone who would, and kindness never went unrewarded. I never saw my father not eat the chicken himself, but he would still say that.–
es: Every night I would go to the shore near some village and buy ten or fifteen cents worth of flour or salted bacon or other things to eat, and sometimes I would borrow a chicken that did not seem to feel comfortable. Father always said that you should take a chicken when you have the chance, because if you don't want it, it's easy to find someone who does, and a good deed is never forgotten. I never saw a single time that father didn't want it, but in any case, that's what he said.

en: Mornings before daylight I slipped into cornfields and borrowed a watermelon, or a mushmelon, or a punkin, or some new corn, or things of that kind. Pap always said it warn’t no harm to borrow things if you was meaning to pay them back some time; but the widow said it warn’t anything but a soft name for stealing, and no decent body would do it. Jim said he reckoned the widow was partly right and pap was partly right; so the best way would be for us to pick out two or three things from the list and say we wouldn’t borrow them any more—then he reckoned it wouldn’t be no harm to borrow the others. So we talked it over all one night, drifting along down the river, trying to make up our minds whether to drop the watermelons, or the cantelopes, or the mushmelons, or what. But towards daylight we got it all settled satisfactory, and concluded to drop crabapples and p’simmons. We warn’t feeling just right before that, but it was all comfortable now. I was glad the way it come out, too, because crabapples ain’t ever good, and the p’simmons wouldn’t be ripe for two or three months yet.
vi: There were times when, at the break of dawn, I would sneak into the fields to borrow a melon or a pumpkin, or some corn or sweet potatoes. My father often said that borrowing something from someone with the intention of returning it later is not a bad thing. But the widow said that it was nothing more than a euphemism for stealing, and respectable people don't do such things. Jim thought that both the widow and my father were somewhat right. So, it was better to take a few things and then tell them that we wouldn't take anything next time. And Jim thought that doing so would make it okay to borrow other things in the future. So we discussed whether to take melons, pumpkins, or other things. But by morning, we resolved the matter and decided to take wild apples and wild pears. Before that, we were worried that we were doing something wrong, but now we felt at ease. Personally, I was also satisfied with this resolution, partly because wild apples weren't very tasty, and wild pears wouldn't ripen for another few months.
tr: In the mornings, before the break of dawn, I would sneak into the cornfields and borrow a watermelon, melon, pumpkin, or fresh corn. My father used to say that if you intend to pay for something later, there's no harm in borrowing it; but the widow said that this was just dressing up theft and that an honest person would never steal. According to Jim, the widow was somewhat right, and my father was somewhat right too; so the best thing was to cross off a few items from our list and say we wouldn't borrow those again – then there would be no harm in borrowing the others. One night, while drifting down the river, we talked at length about the matter and tried to decide whether to cross off the watermelon, the melon, or something else from the list. By dawn, we had both thought enough about the matter and decided to cross off wild apples and dates from the list. Before that, we weren't sure if we were doing the right thing, but now we both felt at ease. It didn't matter much to me anyway, because wild apples weren't very good and the dates wouldn't be ripe for another two or three months.
es: In the mornings, before dawn, I would go into the cornfields and borrow a watermelon, or a melon, or a pumpkin, some new corn or things like that. Father always said that there was nothing wrong with borrowing things if you intended to pay for them someday; but the widow said that it was nothing but stealing, no matter how you dressed it up with words, and that decent people didn't do it. Jim said he figured the widow was partly right and dad was partly right, so the best thing would be to pick two or three things from the list and not borrow them again, and then he figured it wouldn't be wrong to borrow the others. So we spent a whole night talking about it, while we went down the river, trying to decide whether to eliminate the watermelons, the cantaloupes, the melons, or what. But by dawn we had everything satisfactorily resolved and concluded that we would eliminate the reinettes and the persimmons. We hadn't felt quite right before, but now we were at ease. I was glad we resolved it that way, because reinettes are never good and the persimmons wouldn't be ripe for another two or three months.

en: We shot a water-fowl, now and then, that got up too early in the morning or didn’t go to bed early enough in the evening. Take it all round, we lived pretty high.
vi: Occasionally, we would shoot a lone animal that was out foraging early in the morning or late at night before it had found a place to sleep. At those times, our life became quite lively.
tr: If we occasionally saw a waterfowl that had either woken up very early in the morning or had not gone to bed early enough at night, we would shoot it. Considering all of it together, it can be said that we were quite comfortable.
es: Every now and then we would kill a waterfowl that got up too early in the mornings or didn't go to bed early enough in the evenings. Overall, we lived very well.

en: The fifth night below St. Louis we had a big storm after midnight, with a power of thunder and lightning, and the rain poured down in a solid sheet. We stayed in the wigwam and let the raft take care of itself. When the lightning glared out we could see a big straight river ahead, and high, rocky bluffs on both sides. By-and-by says I, “Hel-lo, Jim, looky yonder!” It was a steamboat that had killed herself on a rock. We was drifting straight down for her. The lightning showed her very distinct. She was leaning over, with part of her upper deck above water, and you could see every little chimbly-guy clean and clear, and a chair by the big bell, with an old slouch hat hanging on the back of it, when the flashes come.
vi: By Thursday, down below St Louis, we encountered a big storm around past midnight, with thunder rumbling and rain pouring down heavily. We crawled into the tent and let the raft drift. When the lightning flashed, we could see a vast stretch of river and high rocky cliffs on both sides. Suddenly I called out: Jim, look over there. It was a steamboat that had crashed into a rocky outcrop. We steered the raft directly to the spot. The lightning lit up everything clearly. The boat was leaning over, with part of its bow already submerged. Each time the lightning flashed, we could see every small column gleaming, a chair in the pilot's cabin with a hat hanging behind it.
tr: St. On the fifth night after descending below St. Louis, a great storm broke out after midnight; thunder was rumbling; lightning was flashing, and it was pouring rain. We went inside the shelter and let the raft drift aimlessly. When the lightning flashed, we could see the wide river stretching straight ahead of us and rocky cliffs on both sides. At one point, I called out, “Hey, Jim, look ahead!” There was a steamboat wrecked on the rocks ahead of us. We were drifting directly towards the boat. We could see the boat very clearly in the lightning's light. It was lying on its side, part of its upper deck was above water, we could see the ship's smokestacks clearly, there was a chair next to the big bell, and when another lightning flashed, I saw an old wide-brimmed hat hanging on the back of it.
es: The fifth night, downstream from Saint Louis, there was a great storm after midnight, with lots of thunder and lightning, and the rain fell like a sheet. We stayed in the wigwam and let the raft steer itself. When the lightning flashed, we saw the huge and straight river ahead and great cliffs on both sides. And once I go and say: —Wow, Jim, look over there! It was a steamboat that had wrecked against a rock. We were heading straight towards it. With the lightning, it was very clear. It was all listed, with part of the upper deck above the water, and you could see each of the chimney cables very clearly and a chair next to the big bell, with an old hat hanging on the backrest, when the lightning struck.

en: Well, it being away in the night and stormy, and all so mysterious-like, I felt just the way any other boy would a felt when I see that wreck laying there so mournful and lonesome in the middle of the river. I wanted to get aboard of her and slink around a little, and see what there was there. So I says:
vi: On a stormy night like this, going far from home, everything seems so mysterious; I think any other kid would feel the same as I did when seeing the wrecked ship lying there, as sad as death in the middle of the river. I wanted to climb up the wrecked ship to look around a bit to see if there was anything. I said.
tr: Breathing in all that mysterious air in the middle of the storm at night and seeing the wreck lying so sorrowful and all alone in the middle of the river made me feel the things that every boy would feel. I wanted to get on the ship and wander inside, to see what was there.
es: Well, since it was so late, there was that storm, and everything seemed so mysterious, I thought the same thing any other boy would when I saw that ship stranded so sad and lonely in the middle of the river. I wanted to board it and explore a bit to see what was inside. So I said:

en: “Le’s land on her, Jim.”
vi: - Climb up, Jim
tr: “Let's get on the ship, Jim,” I said.
es: —Let's tackle it, Jim.

en: But Jim was dead against it at first. He says:
vi: At first, Jim remained silent and said nothing, but then he replied: - I'm not climbing onto that wrecked ship. We've already committed a sin, so it's better not to commit another, as the book says.
tr: Jim didn't want to at first. “What are we doing in the wreckage in this weather?
es: But at first Jim was totally against it. He goes and says:

en: “I doan’ want to go fool’n ’long er no wrack. We’s doin’ blame’ well, en we better let blame’ well alone, as de good book says. Like as not dey’s a watchman on dat wrack.”
vi: What if there's a guard on that ship? I said: - What watch? There's no watch, nobody is guarding anything here.
tr: It says in the good book, you live and let live, why should we poke around beyond that? What's your problem? Besides, there might be guards at the wreckage.”
es: —I don't want to go poking my nose into a dead ship. We're doing very well, and it's better to let it stay that way, as the Book says. I'm sure there's a watchman on that ship.

en: “Watchman your grandmother,” I says; “there ain’t nothing to watch but the texas and the pilot-house; and do you reckon anybody’s going to resk his life for a texas and a pilot-house such a night as this, when it’s likely to break up and wash off down the river any minute?” Jim couldn’t say nothing to that, so he didn’t try. “And besides,” I says, “we might borrow something worth having out of the captain’s stateroom. Seegars, I bet you—and cost five cents apiece, solid cash. Steamboat captains is always rich, and get sixty dollars a month, and they don’t care a cent what a thing costs, you know, long as they want it. Stick a candle in your pocket; I can’t rest, Jim, till we give her a rummaging. Do you reckon Tom Sawyer would ever go by this thing? Not for pie, he wouldn’t. He’d call it an adventure—that’s what he’d call it; and he’d land on that wreck if it was his last act. And wouldn’t he throw style into it?—wouldn’t he spread himself, nor nothing? Why, you’d think it was Christopher C’lumbus discovering Kingdom-Come. I wish Tom Sawyer was here.”
vi: Do you think anyone is foolish enough to stay here and guard the engine room and the cockpit on a stormy night like this, especially when we don't know when the ship will break apart and sink to the bottom of the river. Jim didn't know what to say, so he gave up. I continued: - Besides, we can temporarily borrow something valuable from the captain's cabin. Cigars, you know, each cigar is worth five cents, definitely. Captains on riverboats are always rich, earning up to sixty dollars a month, and they never hesitate to buy whatever they want. Take a candle out of the bag, Jim, I can't sit still until we've rummaged through there. Do you think if Tom Sawyer were here he would sit still? No way, I bet you he wouldn't. He would call this an adventure, that's right; and eventually, he would have to climb up to that wrecked ship. And wouldn't he add all sorts of thrilling stories, make up all kinds of things? Just go up and see, Jim, and you'll feel like Columbus discovering a new continent. Go up. I just wish Tom Sawyer were here right now.
tr: “What guard would be there,” I said. “What else is left to guard besides the upper cabin; moreover, who would risk their life on such a night for a ship that could break apart and drift down the river at any moment?” Jim couldn't find a response to this, so he remained silent. “Besides,” I said, “we might find something valuable to borrow from the captain's cabin. I bet there are cigars... each worth at least five cents. Steamboat captains are rich; they earn sixty dollars a month; so if they want something, they don't mind the cost. Put a candle in your pocket, I won't feel at ease without searching the ship, Jim. Do you think Tom Sawyer would pass by this wreck? He definitely wouldn't. He would say this is an adventure... Yes, he would call it an adventure; even if it was the last thing he did, he would climb onto the wreck. And wouldn't he do it in style? He would be so full of swagger. You'd think he was Christopher Columbus setting out to discover the Kingdom of God. I wish Tom Sawyer were here!”
es: —Watchman, your grandma —I said—; there's nothing to watch over except the wheelhouse and the upper cabins, and do you think anyone is going to risk their life for a wheelhouse and some cabins on a night like this, when it's most likely to break in two and go down the river at any moment? Jim couldn't respond to that, so he didn't try. —And besides —I said—, we could borrow something worthwhile from the captain's cabin. I'm sure there are cigars, the kind that cost five cents each in hard cash. Steamboat captains are always rich and earn sixty dollars a month, and they don't care what things cost, you know, if they feel like it. Put a candle in your pocket, Jim; I can't wait until we've searched it. Do you think Tom Sawyer would just leave a place like this? No way. He would say it was an adventure, that's what he would say, and he would board that ship even if it was the last thing he did in his life. And he would surely do it in style; don't you think he would organize a great one? Man, you would think he was Christopher Columbus discovering the New World. I wish Tom Sawyer were here.

en: Jim he grumbled a little, but give in. He said we mustn’t talk any more than we could help, and then talk mighty low. The lightning showed us the wreck again just in time, and we fetched the stabboard derrick, and made fast there.
vi: Jim grumbled a bit, but then he complied. He said we should stop talking, and if we must speak, to do so very quietly. Lightning flashed just as we caught sight of the wrecked ship and approached it. We searched for the mast to tie our raft to.
tr: Jim grumbled a bit more, but finally gave in. He said we absolutely shouldn't talk unless we had to, and if we did, we should whisper. The lightning once again showed the wreck just in time, and we caught the dock on the starboard side and tied the raft.
es: Jim grumbled a bit, but he gave in. He said we didn't have to talk more than necessary, and that in a very low voice. The lightning showed us the wrecked ship just in time again, and we grabbed the starboard davit and tied up there.

en: The deck was high out here. We went sneaking down the slope of it to labboard, in the dark, towards the texas, feeling our way slow with our feet, and spreading our hands out to fend off the guys, for it was so dark we couldn’t see no sign of them. Pretty soon we struck the forward end of the skylight, and clumb on to it; and the next step fetched us in front of the captain’s door, which was open, and by Jimminy, away down through the texas-hall we see a light! and all in the same second we seem to hear low voices in yonder!
vi: The side of the ship was high here. In the darkness, we carefully felt our way along the side of the ship to the cabin door; it felt like our feet were moving too slowly. We reached out in front of us to avoid bumping into posts, as it was pitch black and we couldn't see a thing. Gradually, our eyes adjusted to the dim light of the night, and we managed to climb up. One more step and we would reach the captain's cabin door. The door was already open. Standing next to Jim, I looked down into the engine room and saw a faint light, and at that moment, it seemed we also heard murmuring voices coming from that direction.
tr: The deck was well above the water level. We boarded the ship from the dock and proceeded towards the captain's cabin. We were feeling the ground with our feet, advancing with our arms outstretched to avoid tripping over the ropes, because it was so dark that we couldn't see anything. Soon, we reached the skylight and climbed on top of it; a step later, we had reached the open door of the captain's cabin. Just then, we saw a light in the cabin and heard someone speaking in a low voice!
es: The deck was very high on that side. We slowly descended the slope towards port, in the darkness, towards the high cabins, feeling our way very slowly with our feet and with our arms wide open to push aside the ropes, because it was so dark that we couldn't see anything. Soon we reached the front part of the skylight and climbed onto it, and with the next step we found ourselves in front of the captain's door, which was open, and, what the devil, at the other end of the cabins we saw a light! And at the same moment, it seemed that we heard low voices in the distance!

en: Jim whispered and said he was feeling powerful sick, and told me to come along. I says, all right, and was going to start for the raft; but just then I heard a voice wail out and say:
vi: Jim leaned into my ear and whispered that he was very scared, telling me to leave. I said okay, and was about to head back to the raft when I heard a shout.
tr: Jim whispered that he was feeling bad and wanted to go back. I agreed with him and was preparing to return to the raft, but just then I heard someone inside moaning: "Please don't, boys; I swear I won't tell anyone!"
es: Jim whispered to me that he felt very bad and told me that we should leave. I said okay, and we were about to return to the raft when I heard a whining voice saying:

en: “Oh, please don’t, boys; I swear I won’t ever tell!”
vi: - Oh, please, I beg you, don't, I swear I won't tell.
tr: I agreed with him and was preparing to return to the raft, but just then I heard someone inside moaning: "Please don't, boys; I swear I won't tell anyone!"
es: —Oh, please, no, guys! I swear I will never say it!

en: Another voice said, pretty loud:
vi: The voice of another person was louder:
tr: Another person answered loudly:
es: Another voice said, very loudly:

en: “It’s a lie, Jim Turner. You’ve acted this way before. You always want more’n your share of the truck, and you’ve always got it, too, because you’ve swore ’t if you didn’t you’d tell. But this time you’ve said it jest one time too many. You’re the meanest, treacherousest hound in this country.”
vi: - You are lying, Jim Turner. You have done this before. You always demand more than your share, and every time you get it because you threaten to expose us if you don't. This time you are saying the same thing. You are the most despicable, deceitful dog in this place.
tr: “You are lying, Jim Turner. You have done this before. You always want more than your share and every time you get it by threatening to snitch on us if we don't give it to you. But this time you have pushed us too far. You are the vilest, most treacherous dog in this country.”
es: —It's a lie, Jim Turner. You've done the same thing before now. You always want more than your share of the loot, and you've always taken it, because you swore that if not, you would betray us. But now you've said it one time too many. You are the most disgusting and treacherous dog in this country.

en: By this time Jim was gone for the raft. I was just a-biling with curiosity; and I says to myself, Tom Sawyer wouldn’t back out now, and so I won’t either; I’m a-going to see what’s going on here. So I dropped on my hands and knees in the little passage, and crept aft in the dark till there warn’t but one stateroom betwixt me and the cross-hall of the texas. Then in there I see a man stretched on the floor and tied hand and foot, and two men standing over him, and one of them had a dim lantern in his hand, and the other one had a pistol. This one kept pointing the pistol at the man’s head on the floor, and saying:
vi: At this moment, Jim had already gone to the raft. As for me, my curiosity kept me there, and I told myself; if it were Tom Sawyer, he wouldn't leave now. So I thought, I should stay too, to see what was going on here. I crouched down and crept into the dark, making my way to the captain's cabin. I peeked in and saw a man lying on the floor, tightly bound hand and foot, with two other men standing over him, one holding a dim lantern and the other holding a pistol. The man with the pistol pointed it at the head of the man on the ground and said:
tr: At that moment, Jim had moved away to go to the raft. But I couldn't go anywhere out of curiosity. I told myself that Tom Sawyer wouldn't turn his back and leave in such a situation, so I wouldn't either; I would find out what was happening there. I started crawling through the narrow passage in the dark; finally, there was only one passenger cabin left between me and the captain's cabin. When I poked my head out, I saw a man lying on the ground with his hands and feet tied, two men standing over him, one holding a dimmed lantern and the other holding a gun. The one with the gun had the barrel pointed at the man on the ground's head and was saying:
es: By then, Jim had gone to the raft. I was boiling with curiosity. And I told myself that Tom Sawyer wouldn't back down now, so neither would I, and that I was going to see what was happening. So I got down on all fours in the hallway and moved forward in the dark until there was only one cabin between the cross-section of the cabins and me. Then I saw a man lying on the floor, tied hand and foot, and two others over him, one of them holding a dark lantern and the other with a gun. The latter kept pointing the gun at the head of the one on the floor and said:

en: “I’d like to! And I orter, too—a mean skunk!”
vi: - Better that way. I want to shoot you dead, you skunk.
tr: “I won't show any mercy! I shouldn't anyway... You despicable man!”
es: —I would like to, and that's what I should do, you filthy snitch!

en: The man on the floor would shrivel up and say, “Oh, please don’t, Bill; I hain’t ever goin’ to tell.”
vi: The person lying on the floor craned their neck and said: - Oh, I beg you, don't, Bill, I swear I will never say:
tr: The man on the ground was trembling violently. "Please, don't do it, Bill. I won't tell anyone."
es: The man on the ground was shrinking, saying: —Oh, please, no, Bill; I will never betray you.

en: And every time he said that the man with the lantern would laugh and say:
vi: Each time it happened, the person holding the lantern would laugh:
tr: Whenever the man on the ground said this, the man with the lantern would laugh and say:
es: And every time he said that, the man with the lantern laughed and said:

en: “’Deed you ain’t! You never said no truer thing ’n that, you bet you.” And once he said: “Hear him beg! and yit if we hadn’t got the best of him and tied him he’d a killed us both. And what for? Jist for noth’n. Jist because we stood on our rights—that’s what for. But I lay you ain’t a-goin’ to threaten nobody any more, Jim Turner. Put up that pistol, Bill.”
vi: - Are you really not going to talk? You have never been more truthful than this, right? Listen to him begging you! If we don't find a way to tie him up, he'll kill us all. And what are you planning to kill us for? You won't gain anything. We just want to protect our own interests. But I won't let you scare anyone anymore, you hear me, Jim Turner. Put the gun down, Bill.
tr: “No doubt about it! You've never said anything this true before.” At one point, he said: “Look how he's begging! But if we hadn't acted first and tied him up, he would have killed both of us. And for what? For a whole lot of nothing. Just because we're defending our own rights… for this. But from now on, you won't be able to threaten anyone, Jim Turner. Put down that gun, Bill.”
es: —Of course not! In your life, you have never spoken a greater truth, I assure you —and once he said—: Listen to how he begs! But if we didn't have him subdued and tied up, he would have killed us both. And why? For nothing. Just because we defended our rights, that's why. But I bet you, Jim Turner, that you won't threaten anyone again. Put down that gun, Bill.

en: Bill says:
vi: Bill said:
tr: Put down that gun, Bill.”
es: Bill says:

en: “I don’t want to, Jake Packard. I’m for killin’ him—and didn’t he kill old Hatfield jist the same way—and don’t he deserve it?”
vi: - I don't want that, Jake Packark. I want to kill him. Didn't he kill old Hatfield like that before? Isn't it worth killing him now?
tr: "I can't lower it, Jake Packard. I'm determined to kill him... just like he shot poor Hatfield... Doesn't he deserve it?"
es: —I don't feel like it, Jake Packard. I'm okay with killing him, didn't he kill old Hatfield like that, and doesn't he deserve it?

en: “But I don’t want him killed, and I’ve got my reasons for it.”
