vi: - But I don't want it to die, and I already have my plan. The person lying on the ground is crying and wailing.
tr: “But I don't want him to die, listen to me first.”
es: —But I don't want to kill him, and I have my reasons.

en: “Bless yo’ heart for them words, Jake Packard! I’ll never forgit you long’s I live!” says the man on the floor, sort of blubbering.
vi: - Please, spare Jack Packard! As long as I live, I will never forget you.
tr: "Don't be absent, Jake Packard! As long as I live, I will never forget you!" said the man lying on the ground, amidst sobs.
es: —Bless you for those words, Jake Packard! I won't forget them as long as I live! —says the man on the ground, as if stuttering.

en: Packard didn’t take no notice of that, but hung up his lantern on a nail and started towards where I was there in the dark, and motioned Bill to come. I crawfished as fast as I could about two yards, but the boat slanted so that I couldn’t make very good time; so to keep from getting run over and catched I crawled into a stateroom on the upper side. The man came a-pawing along in the dark, and when Packard got to my stateroom, he says:
vi: Packard didn't pay attention to those words, hung the lamp on a nail, and walked towards the spot where I was hiding in the dark and called Bill to come out as well. I hurriedly crawled quickly for a few yards, but the ship was swaying, so I couldn't get far. To avoid being stepped on and caught, I crawled back up towards the cockpit. The person leading the way groped in the darkness, reaching the cockpit right next to where I was hiding; then said:
tr: Packard didn't care at all, he hung his lantern on a nail and started walking towards the place where I was waiting in the dark and signaled Bill to follow him. I crawled back about two meters as fast as I could, but since the ship was listing, I hadn't moved quickly enough; so I retreated towards an upper passenger cabin to avoid being caught. The man advanced in the dark by feeling his way and when he reached the level of the cabin where I was, he called out behind him:
es: Packard paid no attention, but hung the lantern on a nail and advanced towards where I was in the darkness and gestured to Bill to come closer. I retreated about two yards as quickly as I could, but the ship was so tilted that I couldn't go very fast, so to avoid him stumbling upon me and catching me, I hid in a cabin on the upper part. The man groped in the darkness, and when Packard reached my cabin he said:

en: “Here—come in here.”
vi: - Here, come in.
tr: “Come… Let's go in here.”
es: —Here, come here.

en: And in he come, and Bill after him. But before they got in I was up in the upper berth, cornered, and sorry I come. Then they stood there, with their hands on the ledge of the berth, and talked. I couldn’t see them, but I could tell where they was by the whisky they’d been having. I was glad I didn’t drink whisky; but it wouldn’t made much difference anyway, because most of the time they couldn’t a treed me because I didn’t breathe. I was too scared. And, besides, a body couldn’t breathe and hear such talk. They talked low and earnest. Bill wanted to kill Turner. He says:
vi: He was let in, and Bill followed. But before the two of them fully entered, I had already managed to slip up onto the hanging bed above and curl up in a corner. Regretting in my gut that I had foolishly crawled to this spot. They stood right next to me, holding onto the bed frame and talking. I couldn't see the two clearly, but I could tell where they were standing because their breath reeked of whiskey. Fortunately, I don't drink whiskey; but that didn't make much difference; they still couldn't know I was lying there because I wasn't breathing. I was too scared. Besides, if I breathed, I wouldn't be able to hear their conversation. They spoke very softly and slowly. Bill wanted to know about Turner right away. He said:
tr: Packard entered, and Bill followed him. But by the time they arrived, I had climbed to the top bunk, huddled in the corner, and was writhing in regret for coming there. Then they stood there and started talking, leaning their hands on the edge of the bunk. I couldn't see them, but I could tell where they were from the smell of whiskey on their breath. I was glad I didn't drink whiskey, but it didn't really matter, because they couldn't notice me since I wasn't even breathing. I was very scared. Besides, one can't both breathe and listen to them at the same time. They were speaking in hushed and angry tones. Bill's intention was to kill Turner. He said:
es: And there he went in, with Bill behind him. But before they entered, I had climbed up to the top bunk, cornered and regretting having gone. Then they stayed there with their hands on the edge of the bunk, talking. I couldn't see them, but I knew where they were by the smell of the whisky they had drunk. I was glad I didn't drink whisky, although it wouldn't have mattered much, because it was almost impossible for them to smell me since I wasn't breathing. I was too scared. And besides, one couldn't breathe while listening to that. They spoke in low voices and very seriously. Bill wanted to kill Turner. He says:

en: “He’s said he’ll tell, and he will. If we was to give both our shares to him now it wouldn’t make no difference after the row and the way we’ve served him. Shore’s you’re born, he’ll turn State’s evidence; now you hear me. I’m for putting him out of his troubles.”
vi: - It said it would tell, so it will definitely tell. If we have to give it our share, it still wouldn't be any better, especially after all the hard work and the way we've been serving it. Everything we've done, it will report it all; do you hear me? I'll get rid of it, and that'll be the end of it.
tr: “He said he would betray us, and he will do exactly that, I have no doubt. Even if we both give him our shares now, it won't make any difference after what we've done. I know for sure that he will snitch on us. He will testify against us. Listen to me. Let's just end all his troubles once and for all.”
es: —He said he would betray us, and he will. If we gave him our shares now, it wouldn't matter after the fight and what we've done to him. You can be sure he would testify against us; now, listen to me. I'm in favor of removing his troubles forever.

en: “So’m I,” says Packard, very quiet.
vi: Packard calmly said:
tr: “I think so too,” Packard whispered.
es: —And me too —said Packard, very calmly.

en: “Blame it, I’d sorter begun to think you wasn’t. Well, then, that’s all right. Le’s go and do it.”
vi: - I thought the same. - You monkey. I thought you didn't want that. If so, that's great. Alright, let's get to it.
tr: “Damn it, I was beginning to think you had something else on your mind. Alright then. Let's go finish this job.”
es: —Damn it, I had started to believe it wasn't going to happen. Well, then there's no problem. Let's go with it.

en: “Hold on a minute; I hain’t had my say yit. You listen to me. Shooting’s good, but there’s quieter ways if the thing’s got to be done. But what I say is this: it ain’t good sense to go court’n around after a halter if you can git at what you’re up to in some way that’s jist as good and at the same time don’t bring you into no resks. Ain’t that so?”
vi: - Wait a minute, I haven't finished talking. Listen here, shooting is fine but there are quieter ways if we need to kill it. I think this: if we hang it, we'll feel guilty wherever we go later.
tr: “Wait a minute, I haven't finished what I have to say yet. Now you listen to me. If necessary, we will strike, but there are quieter ways to resolve this issue. This is what I say: There's no point in sticking our necks out when there's another way that has no risk but will have the same effect. Am I wrong?”
es: —Wait a moment; I haven't said my part yet. Listen to me. It's fine to shoot him, but there are more discreet ways if it needs to be done. But what I'm saying is this: there's no point in looking to get a noose around our necks when we can achieve the same thing without any risk. Isn't that right?

en: “You bet it is. But how you goin’ to manage it this time?”
vi: If there's a way like that without any worries and also not dangerous for us, we should do it, don't you think? - Yes, but what else can be done at this moment?
tr: “You are absolutely right. Okay, but how are we going to handle this job this time?”
es: —Surely yes. But, how are you going to manage this time?

en: “Well, my idea is this: we’ll rustle around and gather up whatever pickins we’ve overlooked in the staterooms, and shove for shore and hide the truck. Then we’ll wait. Now I say it ain’t a-goin’ to be more’n two hours befo’ this wrack breaks up and washes off down the river. See? He’ll be drownded, and won’t have nobody to blame for it but his own self. I reckon that’s a considerble sight better ’n killin’ of him. I’m unfavorable to killin’ a man as long as you can git aroun’ it; it ain’t good sense, it ain’t good morals. Ain’t I right?”
vi: - No, I think we should look around here, pick up the things we find in the cockpit, and hide them on the shore first. Then we'll see. I'm sure that in just over two hours, this ship will break apart and sink to the bottom. Do you hear? It will drown, and it won't be able to blame anyone, only itself. I think killing it this way is the best option. I don't want to kill someone and then be haunted by it forever. That's not good, and it's not ethical. Isn't it?
tr: “I have an idea: We'll search the area thoroughly again and check if there's anything we missed in the cabins, then we'll row to the shore and hide everything. After that, we'll wait. If you ask me, this wreck will break apart within two hours and drift down the river. Do you understand? The man will drown and there will be no one else to blame but himself. I think doing something like this is much better than shooting him. Shooting a man when there's another way doesn't sound good at all. It's neither wise nor does it preserve our morals. Am I wrong?”
es: —Well, I've thought of the following: we search everywhere and gather what we might have forgotten in the cabins, we go to the shore and hide the loot. Then we wait. I say it won't be more than two hours before this wreck splits in two and floats down the river. Do you understand? He will drown and won't be able to report anyone. I think it's much better than killing him. I'm not in favor of killing someone if it can be avoided; it doesn't make sense and it's not moral. Am I right or not?

en: “Yes, I reck’n you are. But s’pose she don’t break up and wash off?”
vi: - Yeah, I think you might be right. But what if the ship doesn't break or sink?
tr: “Yes, you are right. But what if the wreckage doesn't break apart and disappear?”
es: —I suppose so. But, what if it doesn't break and floats down?

en: “Well, we can wait the two hours anyway and see, can’t we?”
vi: - Well, anyway, let's wait for two hours and see what happens
tr: “Alright, we can still wait for two hours and see, can't we?”
es: —Well, anyway, we can wait two hours to see what happens, right?

en: “All right, then; come along.”
vi: - Alright, let's go!
tr: “Alright then, let's go.”
es: —Alright; let's go.

en: So they started, and I lit out, all in a cold sweat, and scrambled forward. It was dark as pitch there; but I said, in a kind of a coarse whisper, “Jim!” and he answered up, right at my elbow, with a sort of a moan, and I says:
vi: Two people stepped out, and I slipped out after them, cold sweat covering my body. I crawled forward. It was pitch dark. I softly called out: Jim, right next to my arm, Jim's voice responded, sounding like a moan. I said:
tr: So they set to work; I, drenched in cold sweat, crawled out of the cabin and made my way to the bow. It was pitch dark there, but still, I whispered, "Jim!" and a groan came from right beside my elbow.
es: So they set off and I took off, drenched in cold sweat, staggering to the bow. It was pitch dark but I said in a sort of hoarse whisper: "Jim!" He responded right next to me with a sort of groan and I said:

en: “Quick, Jim, it ain’t no time for fooling around and moaning; there’s a gang of murderers in yonder, and if we don’t hunt up their boat and set her drifting down the river so these fellows can’t get away from the wreck there’s one of ’em going to be in a bad fix. But if we find their boat we can put all of ’em in a bad fix—for the Sheriff ’ll get ’em. Quick—hurry! I’ll hunt the labboard side, you hunt the stabboard. You start at the raft, and—”
vi: - Hurry up, Jim. There's no time for nonsense and lamenting anymore. There are some robbers in there. If we find their boat and let it drift away so they can't escape from this wrecked ship, one of them will be doomed. And if we find their boat, we can ensure that all of them are caught because the sheriff will come and arrest them. Now hurry up, I'll go to the side of the pilot's cabin, and you run to the other side. You go to the raft then... Oh, my God, the raft?
tr: “Hurry up, Jim, we don't have time to dawdle or moan; there's a gang of murderers inside, and if we don't find their boat and untie it to trap them here, they'll be stranded and one of them will be killed. If we find the boat, they'll all be stranded... The sheriff can come and catch them too. Hurry up... hurry! I'll check the starboard side, you check the port side. Go and start from there with the raft...”
es: —Quick, Jim, there's no time to waste with complaints; there's a gang of murderers over there, and if we don't find their boat and push it into the river so they can't leave the ship, one of them is going to be in big trouble. But if we find the boat, we can leave them all in big trouble: the sheriff will find them. Quick... hurry! I'll search the port side and you search the starboard side. Start with the raft, and...

en: “Oh, my lordy, lordy! Raf’? Dey ain’ no raf’ no mo’; she done broke loose en gone I—en here we is!”
vi: Where is the raft? It has broken loose and drifted away - well, we're stuck here now!
tr: “Oh, Tanğım, Tanğım! Is it gone? There is no raft or anything on the river, the rope has come undone, it's gone... we are stranded on this shore!”
es: —Oh, my lord, my lord. Raft? There is no raft left. It has broken or disappeared!

en: CHAPTER XIII.
vi: Chapter XIII
tr: Chapter Thirteen
es: And we are here! Chapter 13

en: Well, I catched my breath and most fainted. Shut up on a wreck with such a gang as that! But it warn’t no time to be sentimentering. We’d got to find that boat now—had to have it for ourselves. So we went a-quaking and shaking down the stabboard side, and slow work it was, too—seemed a week before we got to the stern. No sign of a boat. Jim said he didn’t believe he could go any further—so scared he hadn’t hardly any strength left, he said. But I said, come on, if we get left on this wreck we are in a fix, sure. So on we prowled again. We struck for the stern of the texas, and found it, and then scrabbled along forwards on the skylight, hanging on from shutter to shutter, for the edge of the skylight was in the water. When we got pretty close to the cross-hall door, there was the skiff, sure enough! I could just barely see her. I felt ever so thankful. In another second I would a been aboard of her, but just then the door opened. One of the men stuck his head out only about a couple of foot from me, and I thought I was gone; but he jerked it in again, and says:
vi: I was breathless, almost about to collapse. Being stuck on a wrecked ship with a bunch of pirates like this! But no, there’s no time to sit and lament. We had to find a way to get something out of there and escape. We walked while shaking the ship's sides, but why did it feel so slow, as if it would take a week just to reach the stern. There was no sign of any boat. Jim said he wasn't sure if he could walk anymore, he was so scared that he had no strength left to walk - that's what he said. But I urged him to keep going, if we got stuck on this wrecked ship, we would surely die. We continued to grope our way forward. We managed to reach the stern, clinging to the window frame, but the window was almost submerged. When we got to the main door to go to the passenger cabin, we saw a small boat there. It's definitely a boat, I can see it clearly. Oh my God! There is no greater joy than this. I was just about to climb up when the door suddenly opened. A person stuck their head out, just about half a meter away from me. I thought I was done for, but then the person pulled their head back in and said:
tr: My breath got stuck in my throat, I almost fainted. Being trapped in the same wreck with such a gang! But it was no time to get emotional. We had to find that boat immediately… we were going to use it ourselves. So, trembling with fear, we started to move towards the dock, progressing very slowly; it felt like it took a week to reach the stern. There was no trace of the boat. Jim said he couldn't go any further – he was so scared that he had no strength left. But I explained to him that if we stayed in this wreck, we would be in big trouble. So we started walking again. We passed behind the captain's cabin, then reached for the skylight, holding onto the covers as part of the window was underwater. As we got closer to the corridor door, we finally located the boat! I could barely see its silhouette. I didn't know how to thank God. A second later, I would have jumped onto the boat, but just then the door opened. One of the men poked his head out just a few steps away from me! At that moment, I thought I was done for, but he pulled his head back in and called out:
es: WELL, I jumped and fainted. Trapped on a shipwreck with a band of murderers! But there was no time for whining. Now we had to find the boat and take it for ourselves. We went down trembling and shivering on the starboard side and it took a long time: it seemed like a week passed before we reached the stern. There was no sign of the boat. Jim said he didn't think he had the strength to go on: he was so scared he couldn't take it anymore, he said. But I told him: "Come on, if we stay here, we're sure to have a bad time." So we kept looking. We went to the stern of the upper deck and found it; then we climbed up through the skylight as best we could, grabbing onto every iron, because the edge of the skylight was already in the water. When we were quite close to the lobby, we found the boat, at last! I barely saw it. I felt very happy. One more second and I would have boarded, but just then the door opened. One of the men stuck his head out just a couple of feet from me and I thought my final hour had come, but he pulled it back in and said:

en: “Heave that blame lantern out o’ sight, Bill!”
vi: - Lift the lamp up a bit so we can see, Bill!
tr: "Get that damn lantern out of sight, Bill!"
es: —Bill, hide that damn lantern!

en: He flung a bag of something into the boat, and then got in himself and set down. It was Packard. Then Bill he come out and got in. Packard says, in a low voice:
vi: He threw some kind of bundle into the ship's hold, then stepped in following the steps down. That was Packard. Then Bill followed in as well. Packard whispered:
tr: He threw a full bag into the boat, then got in and sat down himself. This was Packard. Then Bill appeared and boarded the boat. Packard whispered:
es: He threw a sack with something into the boat and then got in and sat down. It was Packard. Then Bill came out and got into the boat. Packard goes and says:

en: “All ready—shove off!”
vi: - It's all done, push it
tr: “Everything is ready... Row the oars!”
es: —Ready... push!

en: I couldn’t hardly hang on to the shutters, I was so weak. But Bill says:
vi: - I couldn't swing up to the door, because I was too weak. Bill said:
tr: I was so exhausted that I was about to let go of the lid I was holding onto. But Bill hesitated:
es: I could barely hold onto the bars, I felt so weak. But Bill goes and says:

en: “Hold on—’d you go through him?”
vi: - Hold on to it, have you thoroughly checked it yet?
tr: “Wait a moment... Did you search him?”
es: —Wait... have you searched him?

en: “No. Didn’t you?”
vi: - Not yet, did you check again?
tr: “No. Didn't you call?”
es: —No.

en: “No. So he’s got his share o’ the cash yet.”
vi: - No, but it hasn't taken its share yet.
tr: “No. Then your share of the cash is still on you.”
es: And you? —No. So, he still has his share of the money.

en: “Well, then, come along; no use to take truck and leave money.”
vi: - Alright, that's enough, go, you don't need to take your belongings or leave any money behind.
tr: “What are we waiting for, let's take it immediately; there's no point in taking the goods and leaving the money.”
es: —Alright, let's go then. It doesn't make sense to take the things and leave the money.

en: “Say, won’t he suspicion what we’re up to?”
vi: - But hey, could it be suspected that I went up to do something?
tr: “Shouldn't she understand what we are going to do to her?”
es: —Hey, do you think he suspects what we're preparing?

en: “Maybe he won’t. But we got to have it anyway. Come along.”
vi: - Maybe not. But anyway, I've already got it in the bag. Let's go.
tr: “He probably won't understand. Besides, what does it matter, let's take them all. Come on, let's go.”
es: —Maybe not. So they disembarked and went back in.

en: So they got out and went in.
vi: Then they went out.
tr: They got out of the boat and boarded the ship again.
es: So they disembarked and went back in.

en: The door slammed to because it was on the careened side; and in a half second I was in the boat, and Jim come tumbling after me. I out with my knife and cut the rope, and away we went!
vi: The door slammed shut because it was on the side that closed in. In just a split second, I had jumped into the small boat. Jim shakily jumped in after me, and I pulled out my pocket knife to cut the rope. And then we were off.
tr: Since he was on the upper side of the ship, he bumped into the backs of doors; within half a second, I was in the boat, and Jim came tumbling after me. I took out my knife, cut the rope, and we set off!
es: The door slammed shut because it was on the tilted side, and half a second later I found myself in the boat and Jim stumbled in behind me. I took out the knife, cut the rope, and we were off!

en: We didn’t touch an oar, and we didn’t speak nor whisper, nor hardly even breathe. We went gliding swift along, dead silent, past the tip of the paddle-box, and past the stern; then in a second or two more we was a hundred yards below the wreck, and the darkness soaked her up, every last sign of her, and we was safe, and knowed it.
vi: We did not touch a single paddle, did not speak nor whisper, not even daring to breathe heavily. Letting the boat glide silently, as quiet as death, passing by the ship's wheel, then passing by the stern, and a few seconds later, we were nearly a hundred meters away from the wrecked ship. The darkness had completely obscured everything, and we could no longer see the ship. And we knew that we had escaped.
tr: We did not touch the oars, we did not speak at all, we did not even whisper, we did not dare to breathe. We were rapidly moving away without making any noise, narrowly missing the wheel, separating from the stern, and a few seconds later we were about a hundred meters away from the wreckage, which had completely sunk into darkness, with not the slightest trace left, we were safe now.
es: We did not touch a single oar nor did we speak or whisper, and we almost didn't even breathe. We slid down very quickly, in total silence, past the drum of the wheel and the stern, and then, in a second or two more, we were a hundred yards below the ship and the darkness hid it without a trace; we were safe and we knew it.

en: When we was three or four hundred yards down-stream we see the lantern show like a little spark at the texas door for a second, and we knowed by that that the rascals had missed their boat, and was beginning to understand that they was in just as much trouble now as Jim Turner was.
vi: When we had gone about three or four hundred meters away, I looked back and saw the light flicker for a moment at the engine room door for about a second. We knew that those guys couldn't leave the ship and were just as confused as Jim Turner, who was tied up.
tr: After going down the river for about three to four hundred meters, a lantern flickered like a spark at the door of the captain's cabin; the bandits had noticed that the boat was leaving and realized that they were in at least as much trouble as Jim Turner.
es: When we were three or four hundred yards downstream, we saw the lantern like a little spark at the door of the upper deck for a second and knew from that that the bandits had seen that they were left without the boat and were beginning to understand that they themselves had as much trouble as Jim Turner.

en: Then Jim manned the oars, and we took out after our raft. Now was the first time that I begun to worry about the men—I reckon I hadn’t had time to before. I begun to think how dreadful it was, even for murderers, to be in such a fix. I says to myself, there ain’t no telling but I might come to be a murderer myself yet, and then how would I like it? So says I to Jim:
vi: Then Jim took the oar, and we quickly rowed the boat to find our raft. At this point, I began to think about those guys, because honestly, earlier I didn't have the heart to worry about them at all. I started to think that, even for murderers, being trapped to death in such a situation is truly horrifying. I told myself that I couldn't talk about becoming a murderer, so how could I possibly want them to be like that. I told Jim:
tr: Then Jim took to the oars and we started following our raft. For the first time, I began to worry about the men – I guess I hadn't had the time before. I started to think about how terrifying it must be to be in such a situation, even for killers. Who knows, maybe one day I myself would become a killer, would I like it then? So I turned to Jim:
es: Then Jim took to the oars and we started looking for our raft. It was then that I began to worry about the men: I guess I hadn't had time before. I started to think how terrible it was, even for murderers, to be in such a situation. I told myself that I didn't know if I would ever become a murderer and then how I would feel about it. So I go and say to Jim:

en: “The first light we see we’ll land a hundred yards below it or above it, in a place where it’s a good hiding-place for you and the skiff, and then I’ll go and fix up some kind of a yarn, and get somebody to go for that gang and get them out of their scrape, so they can be hung when their time comes.”
vi: - Whenever we see a place with lights, we will dock about a hundred meters from there, find a spot where you can hide this small boat, and I will go find someone who came to the shipwreck earlier to rescue those pirates.
tr: "Let's land a hundred meters below or above the first light we see, and after arranging a good hiding place for both you and the boat, I'll go find someone. Let them save that gang of murderers, and when the time comes, let them hang them."
es: —The first light we see, we disembark a hundred yards below or above it, in a place where you and the boat can hide well, and then I'll go and tell them some story and get someone to go fetch that gang and get them out of their situation, so they can be hanged when the time comes.

en: But that idea was a failure; for pretty soon it begun to storm again, and this time worse than ever. The rain poured down, and never a light showed; everybody in bed, I reckon. We boomed along down the river, watching for lights and watching for our raft. After a long time the rain let up, but the clouds stayed, and the lightning kept whimpering, and by-and-by a flash showed us a black thing ahead, floating, and we made for it.
vi: But that idea couldn't be carried out, because just as it was mentioned, the storm came again, and this time it was even more terrifying. The rain poured down without any lightning. I think at this moment everyone was asleep. We kept rowing the boat along the river, looking for lights, looking for our raft. After a very long time, the rain stopped but the sky was still heavy with clouds, then there was a rumbling thunder and a flash of lightning, we saw something black floating ahead, and we rushed forward to chase it.
tr: But I couldn't realize this idea; because a worse storm than the last one started shortly after. It was pouring rain and not a single light was visible; presumably, everyone was asleep. We continued down the river, searching for lights and our raft. After a while, the rain lightened, but the sky was still cloudy and the thunder continued; at one point, when lightning struck, we saw a black object floating ahead of us and steered towards it.
es: But the idea failed, because the storm started again immediately, and this time worse than before. The rain was pouring down in torrents and not a light was to be seen; I guess everyone was in bed. We went down the river looking for lights and keeping an eye on our raft. After a long while, the rain stopped but it remained cloudy and lightning continued to flash, and one of them showed us something black floating ahead, so we headed there.

en: It was the raft, and mighty glad was we to get aboard of it again. We seen a light now away down to the right, on shore. So I said I would go for it. The skiff was half full of plunder which that gang had stole there on the wreck. We hustled it on to the raft in a pile, and I told Jim to float along down, and show a light when he judged he had gone about two mile, and keep it burning till I come; then I manned my oars and shoved for the light. As I got down towards it, three or four more showed—up on a hillside. It was a village. I closed in above the shore light, and laid on my oars and floated. As I went by, I see it was a lantern hanging on the jackstaff of a double-hull ferry-boat. I skimmed around for the watchman, a-wondering whereabouts he slept; and by-and-by I found him roosting on the bitts, forward, with his head down between his knees. I gave his shoulder two or three little shoves, and begun to cry.
vi: That is the raft. We were extremely delighted and climbed back on. On the right bank, a little below us, we suddenly saw a light. I decided to go there. The boat was still full of the belongings that the robbers had taken and loaded in. We hauled a pile of them onto the raft. I told Jim to let the boat drift further downstream. I pointed out to him the light that he thought was nearly two miles away, but the light kept flickering until we got closer. I took up the paddle and pushed the boat towards the light. The closer I got, the more I saw three or four more lights flashing on the hillside. It turned out to be a village. I moved towards the light closest to the shore, keeping the paddle in place to let the boat drift gently. When I got there and looked closely, it turned out to be a lantern hanging on the mast of a wrecked ship. I stepped up to find the guard and saw a guy sleeping there, his head leaning forward and his knees tucked in as he slept. I gently tapped him on the shoulder twice and then spoke in a tearful tone.
tr: We had found it on Tuesday and were very happy when we got back on it. We had seen a light on the right side, on the shore. I suggested going there. The boat was half-filled with the odds and ends the gang had stolen from the wreck. We stacked everything on the raft and told Jim to keep going downstream, light a lamp after about two miles, and keep it lit until I got there; then I took the oars and started rowing towards the light. As I got closer to the light, three or four more lights appeared – they were all on the hillside. So, this was a village. I pulled the oars out of the water just above the light on the shore and continued with the current. As far as I could see, this light was coming from a lantern hung on the mast of a double-hulled ferry. I searched around to find where the watchman was sleeping and finally found him curled up on the deck bollard at the bow, sleeping. I nudged his shoulder two or three times and started crying.
es: It was the raft, and we were very happy to get back on it. Then we saw a light down on the shore, to the right. So I said we should go there. The boat was half full of the loot that the gang had stolen from the wrecked ship. We piled it all onto the raft and I told Jim to drift downstream and light a signal when he thought he had gone two miles and to keep it lit until I arrived; then I took the oars and headed towards the light. When I got closer, I saw three or four more lights on a hill. It was a town. I went straight to the light on the shore, stopped rowing, and kept floating. As I passed, I saw it was a lantern hanging from the mast of a double-hulled ferry. I started looking for the watchman, wondering where he might be sleeping, and after a while, I saw him leaning against the bow bitt, with his head resting on his knees. I gave him two or three taps on the shoulder and started to cry.

en: He stirred up, in a kind of a startlish way; but when he see it was only me, he took a good gap and stretch, and then he says:
vi: He startled awake, looked out and saw only me, then yawned, stretched, and said:
tr: Adam was startled for a moment, but then, seeing that it was just a boy in front of him, he stretched and yawned.
es: He started to stretch as if alarmed, but when he saw it was only me, he yawned and stretched well, and then said:

en: “Hello, what’s up? Don’t cry, bub. What’s the trouble?”
vi: - Huh, what's going on? Don't cry, little brother. What's wrong, what's wrong?
tr: “What's the matter, child? Don't cry, come on. What's your trouble?”
es: —Hey, what's wrong? Don't cry, boy. What's happening to you?

en: I says:
vi: I replied:
tr: “My father, my mother, my sister, and…””
es: And I say:

en: “Pap, and mam, and sis, and—”
vi: - My father, my mother, and my sister, and...
tr: “My father, my mother, my sister, and…””
es: —Father and mother and my little sister...

en: Then I broke down. He says:
vi: Then I stopped. He asked:
tr: Then I started crying again.
es: And I started crying again. Then he goes and says:

en: “Oh, dang it now, don’t take on so; we all has to have our troubles, and this’n ’ll come out all right. What’s the matter with ’em?”
vi: - Oh, don't worry. Just relax. Everyone has difficulties, but it all works out in the end. So, what's wrong with them?
tr: “Pull yourself together, don't let yourself go like this; we all have problems, yours will be solved too. Come on, tell me, what happened to them?”
es: —Come on, damn it, don't be like that; we all have our problems and this one will get sorted out. What's wrong with them?

en: “They’re—they’re—are you the watchman of the boat?”
vi: - They... uh - they... but are you the train guard?
tr: “They... they... are you the guardian of the ship?”
es: —They... they... are you the ship's watchman?

en: “Yes,” he says, kind of pretty-well-satisfied like. “I’m the captain and the owner and the mate and the pilot and watchman and head deck-hand; and sometimes I’m the freight and passengers. I ain’t as rich as old Jim Hornback, and I can’t be so blame’ generous and good to Tom, Dick and Harry as what he is, and slam around money the way he does; but I’ve told him a many a time ’t I wouldn’t trade places with him; for, says I, a sailor’s life’s the life for me, and I’m derned if I’d live two mile out o’ town, where there ain’t nothing ever goin’ on, not for all his spondulicks and as much more on top of it. Says I—”
vi: - Yes - He answered with a delighted voice. I am the captain, the owner of the ship, the assistant, the helmsman, the watchman, the commander on deck, sometimes I am the cargo, and the passenger on the ship too. I am not as wealthy as old Jim Hornback, and I cannot get along well with Tom, Dick, and Harry like old Jim does, but I have vouched many times that I would not trade places with him, because listen here, my life is the life of a sailor, and if I live two miles away from the city, I would be very bored, because there is nothing interesting in this place; I am not here for his money, I say I don't need it... I interjected:
tr: “Yes,” he said, with an air of pride. “I am the captain, the owner, the first mate, the helmsman, the watchman, and the chief deckhand; sometimes I am also the cargo and the passenger. I am not as rich as our Jim Hornback, so I cannot hand out generous tips to everyone who comes, nor can I throw money around like him; I have said it many times, I never want to be in his place; because for me, life means the life of a sailor, even if they laid all the riches of the world at my feet, I could not live two miles outside of town, in a place where there is nothing exciting. I said...”
es: —Yes —he says, with a very satisfied air—. I am the captain and the owner and the second mate and the pilot and the lookout and the chief sailor, and sometimes I am the cargo and the passengers. I am not as rich as Jim Hornback and I can't be as generous with everyone and throw money around like him, but I have told him many times that I wouldn't trade places with him; because, I say, mine is the life of a sailor, and hang me if I would live two miles from town, where nothing ever happens, with all his money and much more he might have. I say...

en: I broke in and says:
vi: I interjected:
tr: I immediately interrupted:
es: I interrupt him and say:

en: “They’re in an awful peck of trouble, and—”
vi: - They are about to die and...
tr: “They are in big trouble and…”
es: —They are in a horrible situation, and...

en: “Who is?”
vi: - Oh?
tr: “Whose?”
es: —Who?

en: “Why, pap and mam and sis and Miss Hooker; and if you’d take your ferry-boat and go up there—”
vi: - And who else, father, mother, sister, and Miss Hooker, if you can take this boat to that place...
tr: “My father, my mother, my sister, and Mrs. Hooker; if you can reach them by going up with the ferry…”
es: —Well, father and mother and my little sister and Miss Hooker, and if you were there with your ferry...

en: “Up where? Where are they?”
vi: - Where, where are they?
tr: “Where up? Where are they?”
es: —Where? Where are they?

en: “On the wreck.”
vi: - on the sinking ship
tr: “They are in the wreckage.”
es: —On the ship that has wrecked.

en: “What wreck?”
vi: - Which ship sank? - Which train?
tr: "Which wreckage?""
es: —What ship?

en: “Why, there ain’t but one.”
vi: There's only one.
tr: “There is only one wreck.”
es: —Well, it's the only one there is.

en: “What, you don’t mean the Walter Scott?”
vi: - Huh! Are you talking about the Walter Scott ship?
tr: “So, are you talking about Walter Scott?”
es: —What? You don't mean Walter Scott, do you?

en: “Yes.”
vi: - Yes
tr: “Yes.”
es: —Yes.

en: “Good land! what are they doin’ there, for gracious sakes?”
vi: - Oh my God, what on earth are they doing here?
tr: "Oh my God! For the love of God, what are they doing there?"
es: —Heavens! What are they doing there, for the love of God?

en: “Well, they didn’t go there a-purpose.”
vi: - It's not that they want to go there
tr: “They probably didn't step on it on purpose!”
es: —Well, they weren't on purpose.

en: “I bet they didn’t! Why, great goodness, there ain’t no chance for ’em if they don’t git off mighty quick! Why, how in the nation did they ever git into such a scrape?”
vi: - I know! It's really bad, if they don't get out quickly, it will be very dangerous. But how could they be so unlucky?
tr: “That's right, why would they leave! My God, if they don't leave there soon, they won't stand a chance! Wow, how did they get themselves into such a complicated situation?”
es: —Surely not! But, my God, they don't have a chance if they don't leave at full speed! But, how on earth did they get into that?

en: “Easy enough. Miss Hooker was a-visiting up there to the town—”
vi: But how could they be so unlucky? - It's nothing, probably just Hooker planning to head up to the province
tr: "Don't even ask. Mrs. Hooker had come to visit the town, you know..."
es: —It's very easy. Miss Hooker was visiting there in the town...

en: “Yes, Booth’s Landing—go on.”
vi: - Yes, and then what?
tr: “Hah, that place near Çardaklı Pier… keep going.”
es: —Yes, at Booth's landing... go on.

en: “She was a-visiting there at Booth’s Landing, and just in the edge of the evening she started over with her nigger woman in the horse-ferry to stay all night at her friend’s house, Miss What-you-may-call-her I disremember her name—and they lost their steering-oar, and swung around and went a-floating down, stern first, about two mile, and saddle-baggsed on the wreck, and the ferryman and the nigger woman and the horses was all lost, but Miss Hooker she made a grab and got aboard the wreck. Well, about an hour after dark we come along down in our trading-scow, and it was so dark we didn’t notice the wreck till we was right on it; and so we saddle-baggsed; but all of us was saved but Bill Whipple—and oh, he was the best cretur!—I most wish’t it had been me, I do.”
vi: - She intended to take that route to Booth Landing, and somehow by nightfall, she ended up going with a black servant who planned to take a horse ferry to a friend's house and stay there overnight. I can't quite remember the name of that friend, but then somehow they lost the oar while rowing, and the boat turned sideways and drifted downriver, the stern leading the way for nearly two miles, and then crashed right into a wrecked ship. Both the boatman and the black servant went missing. As for Miss Hooker, she managed to cling to the wrecked ship. About an hour after dusk, we rowed along searching, but it was too dark to see the wrecked ship, so we ended up crashing into it as well, and our boat capsized. All of us made it out, except for Bill Whipple. Oh my God, Bill was such a smart person.
tr: “You see, he had come there to visit an acquaintance, and as evening fell, he and the black woman boarded the horse ferry and went to his friend's place to spend the night… the woman's name slips my mind… but then they lost control of the tiller, drifted about two miles downstream, and ran aground on some wreckage, capsizing. The ferryman, the black woman, and all the horses were swept away, but Mrs. Hooker clung to the wreckage and then climbed on top of it. About an hour after dark, we arrived there with our sailboat, and it was so dark that we didn't notice the wreck until we hit it; we capsized too, but all of us except Bill Whipple were saved… oh poor thing, he never harmed anyone… I wish he had been saved instead of me…”
es: —She was there visiting Booth's landing and right in the middle of the afternoon she set off with her black woman on the horse ferry to spend the night at her friend's house, Miss whatever her name is—I don't remember—and they lost the rudder and started spinning around and floated down, stern first, and got caught on the wrecked ship, and the ferry guy, the black woman, and the horses were lost, but Miss Hooker grabbed on and climbed onto the ship. Well, about an hour later we arrived in our goods barge and it was so dark that we didn't see the ship until we crashed into it and got stuck, but we all survived except Bill Whipple, as good as he was... I almost would have preferred it to be me, really.

en: “My George! It’s the beatenest thing I ever struck. And then what did you all do?”
vi: I keep thinking, why didn't I die instead of Bill! - Uncle George, I've truly never heard of such a painful thing before! So what happened to you all after that?
tr: "Bite your tongue, my child! I've never heard such a crazy story. So, what did you do next?"
es: —By God! That's the strangest thing I've ever heard in my life. And then, what did you do?

en: “Well, we hollered and took on, but it’s so wide there we couldn’t make nobody hear. So pap said somebody got to get ashore and get help somehow. I was the only one that could swim, so I made a dash for it, and Miss Hooker she said if I didn’t strike help sooner, come here and hunt up her uncle, and he’d fix the thing. I made the land about a mile below, and been fooling along ever since, trying to get people to do something, but they said, ‘What, in such a night and such a current? There ain’t no sense in it; go for the steam ferry.’ Now if you’ll go and—”
vi: - We shouted loudly, but the river was too wide, no one could hear us. Then my father said someone should go ashore and call for help. Only I knew how to swim, so I went immediately. Ms. Hooker told me that if I couldn't quickly find someone to help, I should come back right away and call her uncle so he could figure out a solution. I went nearly a mile searching, hoping to find someone to help, but everyone said: Oh my, it's night, with the river like this, how can we rescue anyone? We need to find a ferry boat. So, now please go and...
tr: “We also clung to the wreckage and climbed on top of it, shouting for help, but the river was so wide that no one could hear us. Then my father said that someone needed to go to the shore and get help. I was the only one who could swim, so I volunteered, and Mrs. Hooker also asked me to come here and find her uncle if I couldn't find help before, saying he would solve the problem. I landed about a mile downstream and have been shuttling between houses ever since, trying to get people to do something; but they all said, ‘What, in this darkness and storm? It's impossible, try the steam ferry,’ they said. If you go and...”
es: —Well, we shouted and made a lot of noise, but the river is so wide there that no one could hear us. So father said that someone had to go to the shore to get help. I was the only one who knew how to swim, so I came, and Miss Hooker said that if I couldn't find help sooner, I should come here to find her uncle, who would sort everything out. I reached the shore a mile downstream and have been walking since then, trying to get people to do something, but everyone says: "What? On a night like this and with this current? It makes no sense; go get the steam ferry." If you would like to go and...

en: “By Jackson, I’d like to, and, blame it, I don’t know but I will; but who in the dingnation’s a-going’ to pay for it? Do you reckon your pap—”
vi: - Well, I want to, but damn it, I don't know if I should. And who is going to pay me? Is it your father?
tr: “My God, of course I'll go, I don't know how I'll go but I will go; but who will pay for it? Do you think your father has money…”
es: —By God, I would like to, and darn it, I don't know if I'm going to go, but, who the devil is going to pay for it? Do you think your dad...?

en: “Why that’s all right. Miss Hooker she tole me, particular, that her uncle Hornback—”
vi: - What? Of course. Miss Hooker told me that, especially since her uncle is Mr. Hornback...
tr: "Don't worry about that. Miss Hooker specifically told me, her uncle Hornback..."
es: —Bah, that's settled. Miss Hooker said that her uncle Hornback...

en: “Great guns! is he her uncle? Looky here, you break for that light over yonder-way, and turn out west when you git there, and about a quarter of a mile out you’ll come to the tavern; tell ’em to dart you out to Jim Hornback’s, and he’ll foot the bill. And don’t you fool around any, because he’ll want to know the news. Tell him I’ll have his niece all safe before he can get to town. Hump yourself, now; I’m a-going up around the corner here to roust out my engineer.”
vi: - Goodness, is he her uncle? Here, let me tell you, go around that place with the light over there, then turn west, walk about a quarter of a mile and you'll reach an inn, ask them to show you the way and Jim Hornback will sign the paper to pay for it. And don't dawdle, because he's waiting for news. Tell him that I'll ensure his niece's safety before he goes to the city. Now, run as fast as you can. I'll stay around here to find the mechanic.
tr: “There are a thousand deck cannons! His uncle? Now look, run upstairs, go to that light over there, and when you get there, turn west. After a quarter mile, you'll reach a tavern; ask them to take you to Jim Hornback, he will pay the bill. Just don't dawdle, because he will want to be informed as soon as possible. Tell him that his nephew will safely reach the shore before he arrives in town. Now get going; I'll turn this corner and wake up the engineer.”
es: —Damn! Is that your uncle? Look, go to that light you see over there and turn west when you get there, and about a quarter of a mile later you'll reach the tavern; tell them to take you quickly to Jim Hornback's house and that he will pay for everything. And don't waste time, because he will want to have the news. Tell him that I will have his niece safe before he can get to town. Now go quickly; I'm going around the corner to wake up my engineer.

en: I struck for the light, but as soon as he turned the corner I went back and got into my skiff and bailed her out, and then pulled up shore in the easy water about six hundred yards, and tucked myself in among some woodboats; for I couldn’t rest easy till I could see the ferry-boat start. But take it all around, I was feeling ruther comfortable on accounts of taking all this trouble for that gang, for not many would a done it. I wished the widow knowed about it. I judged she would be proud of me for helping these rapscallions, because rapscallions and dead beats is the kind the widow and good people takes the most interest in.
vi: I went around to the place with the light, but waited until he had just gone to the corner, then I turned back and jumped into my small boat to escape straight away. I let the boat go along the shore where the water was still for about six hundred meters, then I hid among the wooden boats docked there to watch, because I wasn't at ease until I saw the patrol boat leave the dock. But all in all, I felt relieved because I had struggled with those robbers while many others wouldn't have done the same. I hope the widow knows about this. I'm sure she will be proud of me for helping those unruly men because those unruly, useless people are the ones the widow and respectable people often care about.
tr: I started running towards the light, but as soon as the man turned the corner, I went back, got into my boat, and pushed it into the water. Then, I rowed about five hundred and fifty meters upstream in the calm waters and hid among the wooden boats when I found a suitable spot; because I wouldn't be at ease until I saw the ferry move. But when I thought about what I had done, the fact that I had gone through so much trouble for that gang made me feel at ease, many people wouldn't go to such lengths. I wished the widow would hear about it. She would probably be proud of me for helping these notorious criminals, because the widow and good people are most interested in rascals and pests.
es: I went out into the light, but as soon as he turned around, I stepped back, got into the boat, bailed out the water, and then entered the calm part of the river about six hundred yards away and hid among some wooden boats, because I couldn't relax until I saw the ferry start moving. But, overall, I felt pretty good for having cared so much about the gang, even though many people wouldn't have. I wish the widow had known. I thought she would be proud of me for helping those scoundrels, because scoundrels and cheats are the people the widow and good folks care about the most.

en: Well, before long, here comes the wreck, dim and dusky, sliding along down! A kind of cold shiver went through me, and then I struck out for her. She was very deep, and I see in a minute there warn’t much chance for anybody being alive in her. I pulled all around her and hollered a little, but there wasn’t any answer; all dead still. I felt a little bit heavy-hearted about the gang, but not much, for I reckoned if they could stand it, I could.
vi: Then after a long while, I saw the wrecked ship approaching, dark and looming, slowly drifting down. When I saw it, a cold feeling made me startle. It looked truly massive, and for a moment I thought that if anyone were inside, it would be very difficult to survive. I pushed the boat closer and called out softly, but there was no response, everything was deathly silent. I felt a bit sad about the pirates, but not too much, because I thought if the world could be indifferent, then so could I.
tr: Soon I saw the wreckage, it was rapidly sliding down as a dark mass! For a moment, a cold shiver ran through my whole body, then I immediately grabbed the oars and approached. It had sunk very deep, and I realized shortly after that there was no chance of anyone being alive inside. I circled around and called out, but no one answered; everything was engulfed in silence. My heart ached a little for the gang, but not too much, after all, if they could endure it, so could I.
es: Well, soon the shipwrecked boat appeared, all dark and lifeless, drifting along. A cold sweat ran through my body and I headed towards it. It was very sunken, and after a moment I saw that there weren't many chances that anyone was still alive on board. I circled it completely and shouted a bit, but no one responded; there was a sepulchral silence. I felt a bit sad for the crew, although not much, since I figured that if they could endure it, so could I.

en: Then here comes the ferry-boat; so I shoved for the middle of the river on a long down-stream slant; and when I judged I was out of eye-reach, I laid on my oars, and looked back and see her go and smell around the wreck for Miss Hooker’s remainders, because the captain would know her uncle Hornback would want them; and then pretty soon the ferry-boat give it up and went for the shore, and I laid into my work and went a-booming down the river.
vi: Then I saw the ferryboat coming. I immediately rowed out to the middle of the river to a spot with an undercurrent, and once I was sure I was out of sight, I rested my oars, turned around, and watched the ferryboat follow, releasing a cloud of smoke that completely obscured the damaged boat ahead, which had Miss Hooker's body that the captain earlier was convinced was inside and thought he could bring back to old Hornback. A little while later, the ferryboat let the other boat go on its way, while it turned into the dock. Then I returned to my work and pushed the boat downstream.
tr: Soon the ferry appeared; I rowed towards the fast-flowing middle of the river, and when I realized I had reached a place where I could no longer be seen, I gathered the oars and turned around to watch the ferry circle around the wreck, looking for Mrs. Hooker's body; Captain Hornback knew that at least Uncle would want to see the body; but soon the ferry gave up and headed to the shore, and I started to move downstream in the roaring waters.
es: Then the ferry appears, so I went to the middle of the river, in a long drift downstream, and when it seemed to me that I could no longer be seen, I lifted the oars to look back and saw that the ferry was circling and searching around the boat for the remains of Miss Hooker, because the captain would know that her uncle Hornback would want to see them, and then immediately the ferry gave up and headed to the shore; I got to my work and sped down the river.

en: It did seem a powerful long time before Jim’s light showed up; and when it did show, it looked like it was a thousand mile off. By the time I got there the sky was beginning to get a little gray in the east; so we struck for an island, and hid the raft, and sunk the skiff, and turned in and slept like dead people.
vi: It took a long time before I saw Jim's light, and when it flashed, it looked like it was thousands of miles away. At this moment, the horizon had already lightened with a grayish-blue color, so we went back to the island, hid the raft, sank the small boat, and then went back to sleep like the dead.
tr: It felt like a very long time had passed before Jim's light appeared; when I first saw it, it seemed to be burning a thousand miles away. By the time we arrived, the sky in the east had started to turn slightly gray, so we landed on an island, hid the raft, sank the boat, and then lay down and slept like the dead.
es: It seemed to me that an enormous amount of time passed before I saw Jim's light, and when it finally appeared, it felt like it was a thousand miles away. When I arrived, the sky was starting to turn a bit gray towards the east, so we headed to an island and hid the raft, sank the boat, lay down, and fell asleep like logs.

en: CHAPTER XIV.
vi: Chapter XIV
tr: Chapter Fourteen
es: Chapter 14

en: By-and-by, when we got up, we turned over the truck the gang had stole off of the wreck, and found boots, and blankets, and clothes, and all sorts of other things, and a lot of books, and a spyglass, and three boxes of seegars. We hadn’t ever been this rich before in neither of our lives. The seegars was prime. We laid off all the afternoon in the woods talking, and me reading the books, and having a general good time. I told Jim all about what happened inside the wreck and at the ferry-boat, and I said these kinds of things was adventures; but he said he didn’t want no more adventures. He said that when I went in the texas and he crawled back to get on the raft and found her gone, he nearly died; because he judged it was all up with him, anyway it could be fixed; for if he didn’t get saved he would get drownded; and if he did get saved, whoever saved him would send him back home so as to get the reward, and then Miss Watson would sell him South, sure. Well, he was right; he was most always right; he had an uncommon level head, for a nigger.
vi: When we woke up, we opened the bundle of things the robbers had taken from the wrecked ship to see what was inside. There were shoes, blankets, clothes, and all sorts of other things, a set of books, a pair of binoculars, and three boxes of cigars. We had never been so rich in our lives. The cigars were of the finest quality. We spent the whole afternoon lying in the forest talking. I read books, which was very enjoyable. I recounted to Jim everything that had happened on the wrecked ship and at the ferry, and then I told him that those were adventures. But Jim said he didn't like such adventures anymore. He said that when I was curious and went into the ship's cabin, he crawled back to the raft only to find it had drifted away. He was almost paralyzed with fear and thought it was the end of his life, that he wouldn't escape from there, and if no one came to rescue him, he would drown. And if someone did rescue him, they would take him back for a reward, and Miss Watson would sell him down South. That was certain. He was right. He usually made sense when he spoke. He had an unusually sharp mind for a black man.
tr: When we started investigating what the gang had stolen from the wreck after waking up, we found boots, blankets, clothes, and a lot of other things; there were also many books, a binocular, and three boxes of cigars. Neither of us had ever been this rich before. The cigars were top-notch. In the afternoon, we lay among the trees, chatted a lot, I read the books, and we generally had a good time. I told Jim everything that happened in the wreck and on the ferry and said that these kinds of things were adventures; but Jim said he didn't want any more adventures. When I went to the pilot house, he had gone back to get on the raft and was shocked to find it gone, because no matter how things turned out, it would affect him; if no one saved him, he would drown, and if someone did save him, they would take him to town to claim the reward, and Miss Watson would definitely sell him to the South. He was really right; he was almost always right anyway; he had an unusual intelligence for a black man.
es: AFTERWARDS, when we got up, we looked at what the loot that the gang had stolen from the wrecked ship consisted of and found boots and blankets and clothes and all kinds of different things, a bunch of books and a spyglass and three boxes of cigars. Neither of us had ever been this rich in our lives. The cigars were top-notch. We spent the whole early afternoon in the woods, chatting, and I reading the books and generally having a good time. I told Jim everything that had happened on the ship and on the ferry and he said those things were adventures, but he didn't want any more. He said that when I got onto the upper deck and he crawled back to the raft and saw that it had disappeared, he almost died, because he thought that whatever happened, it was all over for him, because if he didn't save himself, he would drown, and if he did save himself, whoever saw him would take him back home to collect the reward and then Miss Watson would surely sell him in the South. Well, he was right; he was almost always right; he had the most reasonable head for a black man.

en: I read considerable to Jim about kings and dukes and earls and such, and how gaudy they dressed, and how much style they put on, and called each other your majesty, and your grace, and your lordship, and so on, ’stead of mister; and Jim’s eyes bugged out, and he was interested. He says:
vi: I read to Jim quite a lot about kings, dukes, counts, etc... how they dressed in luxurious and splendid attire with all sorts of styles, addressing each other with terms like: "Your Majesty," "Your Grace," "Your Highness," etc... instead of calling each other "sir." Jim sat listening, his eyes wide open, very attentive. He said:
tr: I told Jim about the kings, dukes, counts, and the like that I had read a lot about, how fancily they dressed, the airs they put on, how they called each other "your majesty" instead of "sir," referred to each other as "your excellency," "your highness," etc.; Jim's eyes were wide open because the matter interested him.
es: I read to Jim many things about kings and dukes and counts and all that, and how well they dressed and how elegant they looked and how they called each other "your majesty," "your lordship," "your excellency," and all that, instead of "mister," and Jim's eyes were wide open and he was very interested. He goes and says:

en: “I didn’ know dey was so many un um. I hain’t hearn ’bout none un um, skasely, but ole King Sollermun, onless you counts dem kings dat’s in a pack er k’yards. How much do a king git?”
vi: - I don't know why they have so many of them. In the past, I only heard of one king, and even then, it was rarely mentioned, that is, King Solomon, but I had no idea you had to count those kings like counting cows and horses. So how much money does each king get??
tr: “I didn't know there were so many kings,” he said. “Actually, I hadn't heard of any king other than old King Solomon, and besides him, I only saw a king on a playing card. How much does a king earn?”
es: —I didn't know there were so many. I had almost never heard of them, except for that old one of King Solomon, not counting the kings in the deck of cards. How much does a king earn?

en: “Get?” I says; “why, they get a thousand dollars a month if they want it; they can have just as much as they want; everything belongs to them.”
vi: - Can they? Those guys can get a thousand dollars a month if they want; whatever they want, they get. Everything belongs to them.
tr: “Earn?” I said. “If he wants, he can earn a thousand dollars a month, he can take as much as he wants; everything already belongs to him.”
es: —Get paid? —I say—; well, at least a thousand dollars a month if they want; they can take whatever they want; everything is theirs.

en: “Ain’ dat gay? En what dey got to do, Huck?”
vi: - Oh, that's interesting, isn't it? So what are those gentlemen doing, Huck?
tr: "It's good, right? So, what will we do with it to make money?"
es: —Great, isn't it? And what do they have to do, Huck?

en: “They don’t do nothing! Why, how you talk! They just set around.”
vi: - They don't do anything at all. Why are you so foolish? They just sit there.
tr: “They do nothing! Your words are just talk… They just sit on the throne.”
es: —They do nothing! What things you say! They are there and nothing more.

en: “No; is dat so?”
vi: -Nonsense! Really?
tr: "Ha! Is there such a thing?""
es: —No; really?

en: “Of course it is. They just set around—except, maybe, when there’s a war; then they go to the war. But other times they just lazy around; or go hawking—just hawking and sp— Sh!—d’ you hear a noise?”
vi: - Of course, that's how it is. They just sit there. Maybe except in cases like going to war, then they go to the battlefield. But at other times, they just lounge around, or go hunting, and... shh... Jim, did you hear something?
tr: “Of course, it can happen. They just sit on the throne. If a war breaks out, they might get up, then they go to war. But other than that, they lie around or hunt birds… they just hunt birds and… Shh!.. did you hear a sound?”
es: —Well, of course. They do nothing but stay there, except maybe when there's a war; then they go to war, or if not, they go hunting. Yes, with falcons and all that... Shhh! Didn't you hear a noise?

en: We skipped out and looked; but it warn’t nothing but the flutter of a steamboat’s wheel away down, coming around the point; so we come back.
vi: We quietly stepped out to look, but there was nothing, only the clattering sound of a train heading downstream, passing by. The two of us then returned to our spot.
tr: We went to check immediately, but it was nothing more than the sound of a steamboat paddle coming from the bend below; so we turned back.
es: We came out of the forest to look, but there was nothing except the paddling of a steamboat's wheel in the distance, rounding the point, so we went back.

en: “Yes,” says I, “and other times, when things is dull, they fuss with the parlyment; and if everybody don’t go just so he whacks their heads off. But mostly they hang round the harem.”
vi: I continued speaking: - Yes, at other times, like when they are sad, they look at the parliament, if anyone doesn't comply, they hit them on the head, but mostly those kings just linger around in the harem.
tr: "Yes," I said. "At other times, when things get very boring, they quarrel with the parliament; if everyone doesn't do as they say, they behead them. But usually, they hang out in the harem."
es: —Yes —I said—, and other times, when things are boring, they mess with Parliament, and if they don't do things the way they want, they cut off their heads. But where they spend the most time is in the harem.

en: “Roun’ de which?”
vi: - In what?
tr: "What are you stuck on?""
es: —In what?

en: “Harem.”
vi: - Female palace
tr: "In the harem."
es: —In the harem.

en: “What’s de harem?”
vi: - What is the female palace?
tr: "What is this?""
es: —What is the harem?

en: “The place where he keeps his wives. Don’t you know about the harem? Solomon had one; he had about a million wives.”
vi: - It's the place where those men keep their wives. Don't you understand what a harem is? King Solomon also had a harem like that in the past, and he had up to a million wives.
tr: "The place where he keeps his wives. Don't you know the harem? Solomon had one too; he had almost a million wives."
es: —Where they keep their women. Don't you know what a harem is? Solomon had one with at least a million women.

en: “Why, yes, dat’s so; I—I’d done forgot it. A harem’s a bo’d’n-house, I reck’n. Mos’ likely dey has rackety times in de nussery. En I reck’n de wives quarrels considable; en dat ’crease de racket. Yit dey say Sollermun de wises’ man dat ever live’. I doan’ take no stock in dat. Bekase why: would a wise man want to live in de mids’ er sich a blim-blammin’ all de time? No—’deed he wouldn’t. A wise man ’ud take en buil’ a biler-factry; en den he could shet down de biler-factry when he want to res’.”
vi: - Ah, that's right, that's right. I forgot about it. The harem is like a house full of people, I'm sure of it. It's probably like the chaos in an orphanage, isn't it? I'm sure when those wives fight with each other, it must be something to see! It's bound to be chaotic. And then they say that King Solomon was the wisest man on earth. I don't believe that. Why? If he was wise, why would he live in such a messy situation like that? No, he definitely wasn't wise. A wise person would set up a food factory, and when he wanted to rest, he would just close the factory.
tr: “Yes, right; I… I had completely forgotten about it. It was always noisy like his house. There was quite a bit of noise coming from the children's room, right? They were always arguing, the noise would rise up at that time. However, everyone says that Solomon is the wisest man who has ever lived until today. But I never believe them. Why? Would a wise man constantly want to live in such noise and commotion? No... he wouldn't want that in his life. A wise man would go and open a factory, and then when he wants to rest, he would close the factory.”
es: —Well, it's true; I... I had forgotten. A harem is a boarding house, I suppose. I'm sure there's a lot of commotion in the children's room. And I'm sure the women fight a lot, so there's even more commotion. But they say that Solomon was the wisest man who ever lived. I can't quite believe it, because why would such a wise guy want to live in the middle of all that racket? No... definitely not. A wise man would have a boiler factory built and then he could shut everything down whenever he wanted to rest.

en: “Well, but he was the wisest man, anyway; because the widow she told me so, her own self.”
vi: - But anyway, he used to be the wisest person, because even the widow told me so.
tr: “But still, Solomon was the wisest man; because the widow lady told me this, and she said it with her own mouth.”
es: —Well, but in any case he was the wisest man in the world, because the widow told me so, no less.

en: “I doan k’yer what de widder say, he warn’t no wise man nuther. He had some er de dad-fetchedes’ ways I ever see. Does you know ’bout dat chile dat he ’uz gwyne to chop in two?”
vi: - I don't know what that widow said, but King Solomon was definitely not a wise man. He had ways of judging people that I had never seen before. Do you know the story of the baby that he intended to cut in half?
tr: “So what if he said it! I have never heard of a more incompetent man than him. He almost split a child in two, did you hear that?”
es: —I don't care what the widow said; he wasn't that wise. He came up with some of the strangest ideas I've ever heard in my life. Do you know about the child he wanted to split in two?

en: “Yes, the widow told me all about it.”
vi: - Yes, the widow also told me about this matter
tr: “Yes, the widow told me every detail.”
es: —Yes, the widow told me.

en: “Well, den! Warn’ dat de beatenes’ notion in de worl’? You jes’ take en look at it a minute. Dah’s de stump, dah—dat’s one er de women; heah’s you—dat’s de yuther one; I’s Sollermun; en dish yer dollar bill’s de chile. Bofe un you claims it. What does I do? Does I shin aroun’ mongs’ de neighbors en fine out which un you de bill do b’long to, en han’ it over to de right one, all safe en soun’, de way dat anybody dat had any gumption would? No; I take en whack de bill in two, en give half un it to you, en de yuther half to de yuther woman. Dat’s de way Sollermun was gwyne to do wid de chile. Now I want to ast you: what’s de use er dat half a bill?—can’t buy noth’n wid it. En what use is a half a chile? I wouldn’ give a dern for a million un um.”
vi: - There! See! Isn't that the most bitter thing in life? Just think about it. That matter is so complicated, on one side is a woman, you hear me, for example, you are another woman; I am Solomon, and this dollar bill is the child. Both sides demand to take it. So what should I do? Should I go ask the neighbors whose dollar bill it is, and then give it to the one who has the whole bill intact; all practical-minded people would do that, right? But instead, I go and tear the dollar bill in half and give one half to you, and the other half to the other woman. That's what Mr. Solomon did with a child. Now let me ask you: what can you do with half a dollar bill? You can't buy anything. So what can you do with half a child? I think that even if a million kings did that, it still wouldn't be worth a penny.
tr: “Then listen carefully! Isn't this the strangest idea you've ever heard in the world? Think about it for a moment. Do you see that tree? One of those women is the tree; and you are the root. I am Solomon; and this torn banknote is the child. Both of you want the money. What do I do? To find out who the money belongs to, wouldn't I ask all your neighbors and give the money to the right person? Any sensible person would do that. But no. Instead, I split the money in two, giving half to you and half to the other woman. Solomon thinks of doing the same with the child. Now I ask you: What use is a torn banknote? You can't buy anything with it. What use is a split child? Honestly, I wouldn't take such a child even if you gave me a million.”
es: —Well then! Don't you think it's the most idiotic idea in the world? You just need to think about it for half a minute. That log over there, that's one of the women; that's you, the other log; I am Solomon, and that one-dollar bill is the child. Both of you want it. What do I do? Do I go around the neighbors to see whose bill it is and give it to the rightful owner, as is normal, as anyone with the slightest sense would do? No; I go and tear the bill in two and give you one half and the other half to the woman. That's what Solomon was going to do with the child. And what I'm telling you: What's the use of half a bill to anyone? You can't buy anything with that. What's the use of half a child? I wouldn't give anything for a million half children.

en: “But hang it, Jim, you’ve clean missed the point—blame it, you’ve missed it a thousand mile.”
vi: - Stop it, Jim, you're completely wrong, nonsense, you're off by thousands of miles.
tr: “But wait a minute, Jim, you haven't understood the essence of the matter... you haven't even come close.”
es: —But, damn it, Jim, you don't understand anything... Damn it, you just don't get it.

en: “Who? Me? Go ’long. Doan’ talk to me ’bout yo’ pints. I reck’n I knows sense when I sees it; en dey ain’ no sense in sich doin’s as dat. De ’spute warn’t ’bout a half a chile, de ’spute was ’bout a whole chile; en de man dat think he kin settle a ’spute ’bout a whole chile wid a half a chile doan’ know enough to come in out’n de rain. Doan’ talk to me ’bout Sollermun, Huck, I knows him by de back.”
vi: - Oh, me? Please. Don't talk about your measurements with me. I know that when I see something clearly, I understand its meaning right away. And the meaning of this cannot be confused with that. Arguing like this is not about winning half of the child, but the whole child, and anyone who thinks they can resolve the argument by giving each side half of the child is like someone walking in the rain without knowing how to avoid getting wet. So, don't talk to me about Solomon anymore, Huck, I know even the back of his head.
tr: “Who? Me? Come on, son. Tell me the truth and don't lie. When I see something sensible, I understand it immediately. There's no common sense in this matter. It was like a man trying to solve a child's problem by asking a woman, who wouldn't even think to find shelter in the rain. Don't talk to me about Solomon, Huck, I know his kind.”
es: —Who? Me? Come on. Don't come telling me that I don't understand it. I think I understand what common sense is and what it isn't. And doing something like that doesn't make sense. The fight wasn't over half a child; the fight was over a whole child, and the man who thinks he can solve a fight over a whole child with half a child doesn't know what life is. Don't talk to me about that Solomon, Huck. I've seen plenty like him.

en: “But I tell you you don’t get the point.”
vi: - But I told you that you're speaking out of turn!
tr: “But I'm telling you, you haven't understood the real issue.”
es: —But I tell you that you don't understand it.

en: “Blame de point! I reck’n I knows what I knows. En mine you, de real pint is down furder—it’s down deeper. It lays in de way Sollermun was raised. You take a man dat’s got on’y one or two chillen; is dat man gwyne to be waseful o’ chillen? No, he ain’t; he can’t ’ford it. He know how to value ’em. But you take a man dat’s got ’bout five million chillen runnin’ roun’ de house, en it’s diffunt. He as soon chop a chile in two as a cat. Dey’s plenty mo’. A chile er two, mo’ er less, warn’t no consekens to Sollermun, dad fatch him!”
vi: - Ignore that measurement of yours. What I know is what I know. You have to understand that the container for measuring the truth can go even deeper. Whether it's right or wrong lies in the judgment of Mr. Sollermun, doesn't it? Try taking the example of a person with one or two children, would that person dare to sacrifice their children? No, there's no such thing. That person would know the value of children. But if you take someone who has about five million children at home, then it's different. He would be ready to cut a child in half like cutting a cat. Because he has many. One or two children, more or less, what does that mean to Sollermun?
tr: “What good would it do if I understood? I know what I know. Besides, the real issue is much more than this. It's about Süleyman's upbringing. For example, think of a man with one or two children, can he easily neglect his children? No, he cannot neglect them, he can't afford to. He knows the value of a child. But if a man has five million children running around his house, then the situation changes. He would treat one child like a cat because he has other children. There are always more anyway. One or two children don't matter to Süleyman. Damn him!”
es: —There you go again with "I don't understand it!" I understand what I understand. And, get this, what you really need to understand is more complicated; much more complicated. It's how Salamón was raised. Think about it: a man has only one or two children; is that man going to go around splitting them in half? No, no way; he can't afford to. He knows how to appreciate them. But a man who has five million children all over the house, that's different. To him, splitting a child in half is the same as splitting a cat in half. There are plenty more. One or two more or less children didn't matter at all to Salamón, damn him!

en: I never see such a nigger. If he got a notion in his head once, there warn’t no getting it out again. He was the most down on Solomon of any nigger I ever see. So I went to talking about other kings, and let Solomon slide. I told about Louis Sixteenth that got his head cut off in France long time ago; and about his little boy the dolphin, that would a been a king, but they took and shut him up in jail, and some say he died there.
vi: - I have never seen a black man like that. If he has an idea in his head, it's impossible to make him give it up. He is the black man who has blasphemed Sollermun the most, and now I know he is one. So I had to talk about other kings, putting the story of Sollermun aside. I talked about King Louis XVI of France, who had been beheaded a long time ago, and mentioned his young son, the crown prince, who was supposed to become king but was imprisoned, and some say he died there.
