tr: I had never seen a black man like this. Once an idea got into his head, it was never possible to change it. He was more furious at Süleyman than any other black man I knew. So, I left Süleyman aside and talked about other kings. I told him about Louis XVI, who was beheaded in France a long time ago; I added that his heir, his son, would have become king, but they captured him, imprisoned him, and according to some, he died there.
es: I've never seen a black man like that. Once he got something into his head, there was no way to get it out. I've never seen a black man who had such a grudge against Solomon. So I started talking about other kings and left that one alone. I told him about Louis XVI, who was beheaded in France a long time ago, and about his young son, the dauphin, who would have been king, but they took him away and put him in prison, and some say he died there.

en: “Po’ little chap.”
vi: - Poor, unfortunate boy!
tr: "Poor little child," said Jim.
es: —Poor thing.

en: “But some says he got out and got away, and come to America.”
vi: - But there are also people who say that he escaped death and has gone to America.
tr: “But some say that he escaped from prison and fled the country, coming to America.”
es: —But others say that he escaped and came to America.

en: “Dat’s good! But he’ll be pooty lonesome—dey ain’ no kings here, is dey, Huck?”
vi: - That's great! But surely he doesn't have a place to make a living, right?
tr: “That's good then! Although he was quite alone in this town.
es: —That's good! But he will feel very lonely... There are no kings here, right, Huck?

en: “No.”
vi: But surely he doesn't have a place to make a living, right?
tr: There's no one in this town, right?” "No."""
es: —No.

en: “Den he cain’t git no situation. What he gwyne to do?”
vi: But surely he doesn't have a place to make a living, right? What does he plan to do?
tr: "Then he cannot find a throne for himself. What can he do in this situation?"
es: —Then he can't get a job. What is he going to do?

en: “Well, I don’t know. Some of them gets on the police, and some of them learns people how to talk French.”
vi: - Who knows. Among those kings, some became police officers, and some became French teachers.
tr: "I don't know." "Some become police officers; others teach French to people.""
es: —Well, I don't know. Some become police officers and others teach people to speak French.

en: “Why, Huck, doan’ de French people talk de same way we does?”
vi: - Oh, so the French don't speak like us, Huck?
tr: “Why, Huck, don't the French talk like us?”
es: —But, Huck, don't the French speak like us?

en: “No, Jim; you couldn’t understand a word they said—not a single word.”
vi: - No, Jim, if you listen to what people say, you won't understand a single sentence, not even a word.
tr: "No, Jim; you won't understand a single word they say... not a single word.""
es: —No, Jim; you wouldn't understand a single word of what they're saying... not a single word.

en: “Well, now, I be ding-busted! How do dat come?”
vi: - Oh, then I am really foolish. So what should I do?
tr: “No way, how did it happen! How am I supposed to understand that?”
es: —Well, hang me! Why?

en: “I don’t know; but it’s so. I got some of their jabber out of a book. S’pose a man was to come to you and say Polly-voo-franzy—what would you think?”
vi: - I don't know either. But that's how it is. I saw a few of their words in the book. For example, if someone comes and asks you: "Parlez-vous français?" what would you think?
tr: “I don't know, but you just wouldn't understand. I had learned something about their conversation from a book. Let's say a man comes up to you and says parle-vu-franse... what would you think?”
es: —I don't know, but it's true. I've seen some of the things they say in a book. Imagine a man comes up to you and says "parlé vu fransé"; what would you think?

en: “I wouldn’ think nuff’n; I’d take en bust him over de head—dat is, if he warn’t white. I wouldn’t ’low no nigger to call me dat.”
vi: - I don't think anything of it. I would hit him on the head, that is, if he were not a white man. If he were black, I wouldn't allow anyone to call me that.
tr: “I don't think about anything, I just shoot one in the middle of his forehead. That is, if he's not white. I would never allow a black man to talk to me like that.”
es: —I wouldn't think anything; I would break his face; well, if he wasn't white. I wouldn't let a black person call me that.

en: “Shucks, it ain’t calling you anything. It’s only saying, do you know how to talk French?”
vi: - Go away, that's not calling you. That's just asking if you know how to speak French.
tr: "But he didn't say anything to you. He just asked if you could speak French."
es: —Damn, I wouldn't be calling you anything. I would just be asking if you know how to speak French.

en: “Well, den, why couldn’t he say it?”
vi: - Well, why couldn't he just say it straight out like that?
tr: “Haa, okay, but why isn't it cooling properly?”
es: —Well, then, why don't you say it?

en: “Why, he is a-saying it. That’s a Frenchman’s way of saying it.”
vi: - He himself said it like that. That is the way the French speak. - Oh, that is really bizarre, strange.
tr: “But she's asking, you see. That's how the French ask.”
es: —But that's what he's saying. That's how the French say it.

en: “Well, it’s a blame ridicklous way, en I doan’ want to hear no mo’ ’bout it. Dey ain’ no sense in it.”
vi: But anyway, I don't want to hear about it anymore. It doesn't make any sense at all.
tr: "But this is very absurd, I don't want to hear anything else." "It doesn't make any sense.""
es: —Well, it's a ridiculous way of saying it and I don't want to keep talking about it. It doesn't make sense.

en: “Looky here, Jim; does a cat talk like we do?”
vi: - Here, Jim, I ask if the cat speaks like us?
tr: “Listen now, Jim; do cats talk like us?”
es: —Look, Jim; do cats speak the same way we do?

en: “No, a cat don’t.”
vi: - No, which cat said that
tr: “No, cats don't talk like that.”
es: —No, not the cats.

en: “Well, does a cow?”
vi: - Ah, what about the cow?
tr: “What about the cow?”
es: —Well, what about the cows?

en: “No, a cow don’t, nuther.”
vi: - Not even crawling
tr: “No, cows don't talk either.”
es: —No, not the cows either.

en: “Does a cat talk like a cow, or a cow talk like a cat?”
vi: - Does the cat speak like the cow? Or does the cow speak like the cat?
tr: “Do cats talk like cows or do cows talk like cats?”
es: —Do cats speak the same as cows or do cows speak the same as cats?

en: “No, dey don’t.”
vi: - No
tr: “No, it can't be.”
es: —No.

en: “It’s natural and right for ’em to talk different from each other, ain’t it?”
vi: - So it's natural and correct for one child to speak differently from another, right?
tr: “It's perfectly natural for the two of them to speak differently from each other, isn't it?”
es: —The natural and normal thing is that they speak differently, right?

en: “’Course.”
vi: - Of course
tr: “Of course.”
es: —Of course.

en: “And ain’t it natural and right for a cat and a cow to talk different from us?”
vi: - And the cat, the cow speaking differently from us, is that also natural and correct?
tr: “Well, isn't it normal and correct for the cat and the cow to speak differently from us?”
es: —And isn't it natural and normal that cats and cows speak differently from us?

en: “Why, mos’ sholy it is.”
vi: - Oh, it definitely is like that
tr: “Of course, sure.”
es: —Man, of course.

en: “Well, then, why ain’t it natural and right for a Frenchman to talk different from us? You answer me that.”
vi: - Ah, so why do the French speak differently from us, saying it's incorrect and unnatural. Try answering me.
tr: “Then isn't it normal and right for a French person to speak differently from us? Answer this, let's see.”
es: —Well, then, why isn't it natural and normal for a French person to speak differently from us? Answer me that.

en: “Is a cat a man, Huck?”
vi: - Is the cat someone else, Huck?
tr: “Is a cat a human, Huck?”
es: —Huck, are cats the same as men?

en: “No.”
vi: - No
tr: “No.” “So, do you really think so?
es: —No.

en: “Well, den, dey ain’t no sense in a cat talkin’ like a man. Is a cow a man?—er is a cow a cat?”
vi: - Ah, then the cat can't talk like a human. So is the cow a human - is the cow a cat?
tr: Why would a cat speak like a human? Well, is a cow a human? Or is a cow a cat?”
es: —Well, then, it doesn't make sense for cats to talk the same way as men. Are cows the same as men? Or are cows the same as cats?

en: “No, she ain’t either of them.”
vi: - No, none of them are cats.
tr: "No; none of them.""
es: —No, neither of the two things.

en: “Well, den, she ain’t got no business to talk like either one er the yuther of ’em. Is a Frenchman a man?”
vi: - Ah, that's really strange, why can't he speak like a human?
tr: “Then he won't speak like the others from this place. A French person?”
es: —Well, then they don't have to talk like men or cats. Are the French men?

en: “Yes.”
vi: - Ah, that's really strange, why can't he speak like a human?
tr: “Yes.”
es: —Yes.

en: “Well, den! Dad blame it, why doan’ he talk like a man? You answer me dat!”
vi: - Ah, that's really strange, why can't he speak like a human? Can you try to answer me?
tr: “Alright then! Damn it, why doesn't this Frenchman speak like a normal person? You answer him, come on!”
es: —Well then! Damn it, why don't they speak the same as men? You answer me that one.

en: I see it warn’t no use wasting words—you can’t learn a nigger to argue. So I quit.
vi: I find that sitting and talking like this is just a waste of words. I can't possibly learn the way black people reason. So I stopped.
tr: There was no point in wasting my breath any longer... You can't teach a black person to argue. So I gave up.
es: I saw that it made no sense to keep wasting my breath: you can't teach black people to argue. So I gave up.

en: CHAPTER XV.
vi: Chapter XV
tr: Fifteenth Chapter
es: Chapter 15

en: We judged that three nights more would fetch us to Cairo, at the bottom of Illinois, where the Ohio River comes in, and that was what we was after. We would sell the raft and get on a steamboat and go way up the Ohio amongst the free States, and then be out of trouble.
vi: We calculated that in just three more nights we would reach Cairo, which is at the southern tip of Illinois, where the Ohio River flows in, and that is exactly where we intended to go. We would sell the raft and board a steamboat to travel up the Ohio River through the free states, so there would be nothing to worry about anymore.
tr: We were calculating that if we went three more nights, we would reach Cairo, at the very bottom of Illinois, at the mouth of the Ohio River, which was exactly where we wanted to go. We would sell the raft, board a steamboat, and go up the Ohio to the free states, and then our troubles would be over.
es: WE CALCULATED THAT in three nights we would arrive in Cairo, at the end of Illinois, where the waters of the Ohio River meet, and that was what we were looking for. We would sell the raft and take a steamboat up the Ohio to the free states, and there we would no longer have any problems.

en: Well, the second night a fog begun to come on, and we made for a tow-head to tie to, for it wouldn’t do to try to run in a fog; but when I paddled ahead in the canoe, with the line to make fast, there warn’t anything but little saplings to tie to. I passed the line around one of them right on the edge of the cut bank, but there was a stiff current, and the raft come booming down so lively she tore it out by the roots and away she went. I see the fog closing down, and it made me so sick and scared I couldn’t budge for most a half a minute it seemed to me—and then there warn’t no raft in sight; you couldn’t see twenty yards. I jumped into the canoe and run back to the stern, and grabbed the paddle and set her back a stroke. But she didn’t come. I was in such a hurry I hadn’t untied her. I got up and tried to untie her, but I was so excited my hands shook so I couldn’t hardly do anything with them.
vi: On the second night, the fog suddenly became so thick that we had to find a ravine to tie the raft. Because it was not wise to recklessly continue in the fog. But while I was rowing the boat upstream, carrying a hook pole, I couldn't find a place to hook it as there were only small reeds. I cast the fishing line to wrap it around a reed on the water's edge, but this spot had such a strong current that it uprooted the reed and it kept drifting away. The fog grew heavier, making me so scared that I couldn't move for half a minute. Without the raft here, I couldn't see more than twenty meters ahead. I jumped to the back of the boat, grabbed the paddle, and pushed back once. But the boat didn't budge. It turned out I was in such a hurry that I hadn't untied the rope. I stood up to untie the rope, but I was so nervous that my hands were shaking and I couldn't do anything.
tr: The second night, the fog set in and we pulled up to a shore to tie the raft, because there was no point in trying to escape in the fog; but as I rowed ahead with the canoe tied to the raft to speed up, I found nothing to throw the rope at except for thin saplings. I threw the rope and tied it to a sapling on the shore, but the current was so strong that the raft, which was a bit behind, passed me and pulled the rope so fast that it uprooted the sapling and drifted away. The fog was getting denser and denser. I felt terrible, I was so scared that I couldn't move a finger for almost half a minute… then I lost sight of the raft, it was impossible to see even twenty meters ahead. I jumped back into the canoe and went to the stern, grabbed the oars, but the canoe didn't move. I had been in such a hurry that I forgot to untie the oar's rope. I immediately got up and tried to untie the rope, but I was so excited that my hands were trembling and I couldn't do anything.
es: Well, around the second night, the fog started to come down, and we went to look for a sandbar to moor because it was useless to go on with the fog; but when I went ahead with the canoe, rowing with the rope to tie up, there were only some small logs. I threw the rope to one of them, right next to the edge of the shore, but the current was so strong there that the raft was moving so fast it uprooted it and kept going. I saw the fog getting denser and felt so bad and scared that I couldn't move for almost half a minute, or so it seemed to me, and then the raft was no longer visible; you couldn't see beyond twenty yards. I jumped into the canoe and ran to the stern, grabbed the paddle, and gave a stroke, but it didn't move. I was in such a hurry that I hadn't untied it. I stood up and tried to untie it, but I was so nervous that my hands were trembling so much I could hardly do anything with them.

en: As soon as I got started I took out after the raft, hot and heavy, right down the tow-head. That was all right as far as it went, but the tow-head warn’t sixty yards long, and the minute I flew by the foot of it I shot out into the solid white fog, and hadn’t no more idea which way I was going than a dead man.
vi: As soon as I untied the rope, I immediately rowed to find the raft, the cozy raft carrying our heavy belongings right at the head of that creek. I found it right away because it was only sixty yards away. Just as I got close, I ran into an even thicker fog, unable to find my way out; it was as if I were completely dead.
tr: I followed the raft down the river by keeping close to the shore. As long as I didn't stray from the shore, there was no problem, but the islet was only sixty meters long, and a few seconds after reaching its end, I found myself in a blinding white mist, with no idea where I was going.
es: As soon as I managed to get going, I started chasing the raft at full speed, directly towards the sandbar. That was well thought out, but the bar wouldn't measure even sixty yards long, and as soon as I left it behind, I got into the middle of that white and dense fog without having the slightest idea of where I was going.

en: Thinks I, it won’t do to paddle; first I know I’ll run into the bank or a tow-head or something; I got to set still and float, and yet it’s mighty fidgety business to have to hold your hands still at such a time. I whooped and listened. Away down there somewheres I hears a small whoop, and up comes my spirits. I went tearing after it, listening sharp to hear it again. The next time it come, I see I warn’t heading for it, but heading away to the right of it. And the next time I was heading away to the left of it—and not gaining on it much either, for I was flying around, this way and that and t’other, but it was going straight ahead all the time.
vi: I think perhaps we shouldn't row the boat anymore; first, let's get closer to the shore or land somewhere. I had to sit still and let the boat drift, and having to sit still with my hands tied at that moment was very distressing. I cleared my throat and listened. Far below, I heard a faint sound echoing back, which reassured me. I moved closer to hear more clearly. Getting even closer, it was on the left side. Then I heard nothing more, and I didn't search further because I had to keep turning the boat in all directions; instead, I just kept heading straight ahead.
tr: It occurred to me that rowing would be useless; I could crash into the shore or shallow water as soon as I started; I had to stay still and go with the current. In such a situation, it was really hard not to move your hands. I called out ahead and waited for a response. My spirits lifted when I heard someone faintly calling out from somewhere in the distance. I immediately started moving towards the sound, while also straining my ears to hear it again. When I heard it the second time, I realized I was going to the right of where the sound was coming from, not directly towards it. The next time, I was heading to the left of where the sound was coming from – and I hadn't gotten much closer, because I was rowing either to the right or the left, but the sound was coming straight from ahead.
es: I thought it wasn't worth rowing; I knew that at the first sign of trouble I would run aground on the shore or on a sandbar or something like that; I stayed still letting the canoe drift, but one gets very nervous when they have nothing to do with their hands in a moment like that. I shouted and listened. In the distance, I don't know where, I heard another muffled shout and I felt somewhat encouraged. I went there at full speed, listening carefully in case I heard it again. The next time I heard it, I saw that I wasn't heading towards it, but to its right, and the next time to its left, and I wasn't making much progress either, because I was going around in circles, while that voice was going straight down the whole time.

en: I did wish the fool would think to beat a tin pan, and beat it all the time, but he never did, and it was the still places between the whoops that was making the trouble for me. Well, I fought along, and directly I hears the whoop behind me. I was tangled good now. That was somebody else’s whoop, or else I was turned around.
vi: At that moment, I wished that someone would just bang on a pot and bang it rhythmically so it would be easier to know where to look. But no one was banging, and the silence, punctuated by a few coughs, only made me more confused. I went further up, and suddenly I heard a howl behind me. Well, I was really surrounded. It was definitely the howl of someone else. I was definitely surrounded.
tr: I hoped that our foolish Jim would think of hitting something like a pan, he should have kept hitting it continuously; but since he didn't do that, the silences between his calls became a problem for me. I rowed forward with all my strength and soon heard the sound behind me. By now, I was completely bewildered. Either someone else was calling out or I was going in the wrong direction.
es: What I wanted was for the very fool to think of starting to bang repeatedly on a pan, but he didn't think of it, or maybe he did, and what worried me were the silences between the screams. Well, I kept going and immediately heard the scream behind me. Now I was really confused. Either there was another person screaming or I had turned all the way around.

en: I throwed the paddle down. I heard the whoop again; it was behind me yet, but in a different place; it kept coming, and kept changing its place, and I kept answering, till by-and-by it was in front of me again, and I knowed the current had swung the canoe’s head down-stream, and I was all right if that was Jim and not some other raftsman hollering. I couldn’t tell nothing about voices in a fog, for nothing don’t look natural nor sound natural in a fog.
vi: I threw the paddle down. Again, I heard the howling sound still behind me, but from a different place. It crept closer, it changed places, it answered itself, occasionally falling silent and then resounding in front of me; I knew that the current had already turned my boat downstream, and if it was Jim and not some other ferryman howling, I would be at ease. In the fog, nothing seen by the eyes or heard by the ears seems natural anymore.
tr: I threw the oar into the boat. I heard the voice again, it was behind me once more but in a different place; the voice kept coming and kept changing places, and I kept responding; finally, I started hearing the voice in front of me again and realized that the current had turned the canoe's head downstream and things were falling into place, of course, if the person calling out to me was indeed Jim and not someone else. I absolutely couldn't distinguish the sounds coming through the mist; because nothing looks natural in the mist, and the sounds don't seem natural either.
es: I put down the oar. I heard the shout again; it was still behind me, but in a different place; it sounded over and over and always changed location, and I kept responding, until finally it was ahead of me again, and I realized that the current had turned the canoe around as it moved downstream and that I was going the right way if it was Jim and not another raftsman shouting. I couldn't understand any of the voices in the fog, because in a fog nothing seems or sounds natural.

en: The whooping went on, and in about a minute I come a-booming down on a cut bank with smoky ghosts of big trees on it, and the current throwed me off to the left and shot by, amongst a lot of snags that fairly roared, the currrent was tearing by them so swift.
vi: The howling continued, and about a minute later, I crashed right into a clearing with several large trees looming like ghosts, then the current pushed me to the left and I crashed into the bank again, amidst a pile of floating rotten wood that creaked when it hit the boat. And the water continued to quietly meander through the pile of wood.
tr: The sound continued and about a minute later, I was gliding along a steep shore where the ghostly forms of large trees loomed within the mists. The current grabbed me and flung me to the left, and as I passed through the water plants, the water roared and the current battered the plants.
es: The screams continued and after a minute or so I found myself rushing down at full speed in front of a steep bank filled with blurry ghosts of large trees, and the current threw me to the left and kept going, dragging a bunch of logs that thundered down, due to the speed at which the current broke them.

en: In another second or two it was solid white and still again. I set perfectly still then, listening to my heart thump, and I reckon I didn’t draw a breath while it thumped a hundred.
vi: Later, the fog became even denser. Even quieter. I sat completely still, listening to the pounding of my heart. I thought if my heart beat reached a hundred, I wouldn't be able to breathe anymore.
tr: A few seconds later, everything turned completely white again and the sounds ceased. I was listening to my heartbeat without moving, it must have beaten a hundred times until I took another breath.
es: After one or two seconds, nothing could be seen but a white mass, and everything had fallen silent. Then I sat still, completely motionless, listening to the beats of my heart, and I think I didn't breathe even once in a hundred beats.

en: I just give up then. I knowed what the matter was. That cut bank was an island, and Jim had gone down t’other side of it. It warn’t no tow-head that you could float by in ten minutes. It had the big timber of a regular island; it might be five or six miles long and more than half a mile wide.
vi: I had to give up. And I know why it turned out this way. This stormy mass is an island, and Jim has drifted to the other side. There is no creek that can be crossed in about ten minutes. This island also has large trees like any other island; it is probably about five or six miles long and half a mile wide.
tr: Then I gave up trying. I had understood what the matter was. The shore we had just seen belonged to an island, and Jim was on the other side of the island. This was not a shore you could pass by in ten minutes. It had big trees like normal islands; it was five or six miles long and at least half a mile wide.
es: Then I gave up. I knew what was happening. That steep shore was an island, and Jim had crossed to the other side of it. It wasn't like a sandbar that you could cross in ten minutes. It had big trees like a normal island; it could be five or six miles long and more than half a mile wide.

en: I kept quiet, with my ears cocked, about fifteen minutes, I reckon. I was floating along, of course, four or five miles an hour; but you don’t ever think of that. No, you feel like you are laying dead still on the water; and if a little glimpse of a snag slips by you don’t think to yourself how fast you’re going, but you catch your breath and think, my! how that snag’s tearing along. If you think it ain’t dismal and lonesome out in a fog that way by yourself in the night, you try it once—you’ll see.
vi: I remained still, listening intently for fifteen minutes. Of course, the boat continued to drift, at about five or six miles per hour. But deep inside, I didn't dare to hope for such a thing. It felt as if I were lying unconscious on the water. If no piece of wood floated by, it would be impossible to tell how fast or slow I was drifting. But I just held my breath, thinking and watching the piece of wood float by. If anyone has never experienced the loneliness and desolation of being alone in the fog late at night, they should try it once to understand.
tr: Without making a sound, I listened intently for fifteen minutes. Meanwhile, I was of course moving at four or five miles per hour, but I wasn't even thinking about it. No, it felt like you weren't moving at all on the water; if a passing branch caught your eye, you wouldn't think about how fast you were going; you'd hold your breath and think, wow, how fast that branch is moving. If you think you won't worry or feel lonely when you get lost alone in the fog at night, try it once – then you'll see.
es: I remained silent, with my ear attentive, for about fifteen minutes, I estimate. Naturally, I kept floating downstream at four or five miles per hour, but one never thinks about that. No, one believes they are completely still in the water, and if some sticks pass by, one doesn't think about how fast they are going, but rather takes a breath and says: "Wow! How fast those sticks are going." If anyone thinks that being alone at night in the middle of such a fog is not one of the saddest and most terrible things, let them try it just once and they will find out.

en: Next, for about a half an hour, I whoops now and then; at last I hears the answer a long ways off, and tries to follow it, but I couldn’t do it, and directly I judged I’d got into a nest of tow-heads, for I had little dim glimpses of them on both sides of me—sometimes just a narrow channel between, and some that I couldn’t see I knowed was there because I’d hear the wash of the current against the old dead brush and trash that hung over the banks. Well, I warn’t long loosing the whoops down amongst the tow-heads; and I only tried to chase them a little while, anyway, because it was worse than chasing a Jack-o’-lantern. You never knowed a sound dodge around so, and swap places so quick and so much.
vi: Then about half an hour later, I occasionally let out a scream. After that, I heard a distant reply, tried to follow it but couldn't, and I guessed that I had wandered into a place full of many intertwined streams. I looked at both banks and saw only darkness. Sometimes I clearly saw each small canal, sometimes I could only guess because I heard the sound of water hitting the banks. I didn't even bother to call out in this maze of uneven land anymore, but just walked a bit further, because it was worse than chasing will-o'-the-wisps. Never before had I heard echoes that lingered and shifted places so quickly.
tr: Then, for half an hour, I called out from time to time; finally, I heard someone shouting back from afar and tried to follow the voice, but I couldn't manage it. At that moment, I realized I had entered the sandbanks, because I could vaguely see sandbanks on either side of me, sometimes with only a narrow channel in between, and even when I couldn't see the sandbanks, I knew they were there because I could hear the current hitting dead branches and debris piled up on the shore. Soon, I lost the voices among the sandbanks, which I had only tried to follow for a short while anyway, because it was worse than trying to follow will-o'-the-wisps in the marsh. I had never thought that a voice could come from so many places and change location so frequently.
es: Afterward, for about half an hour or so, I kept shouting from time to time, until I finally heard a response far away, and I tried to follow it, but I couldn't, and immediately I thought I had gotten myself into the middle of a labyrinth of sandbars, because I saw them blurry on both sides: sometimes with only a narrow channel in the middle, and other times I couldn't see them but knew they were there because I heard the current crashing against old dry logs and debris on the banks. Well, it didn't take long before I stopped hearing the shouts among the sandbars and only tried to follow them for a little while, in any case, because it was worse than chasing a will-o'-the-wisp. In my life, I had never heard a noise so difficult to follow nor that changed places so many times and so quickly.

en: I had to claw away from the bank pretty lively four or five times, to keep from knocking the islands out of the river; and so I judged the raft must be butting into the bank every now and then, or else it would get further ahead and clear out of hearing—it was floating a little faster than what I was.
vi: Four or five times, I had to take it down to avoid getting stuck on the shore and to prevent it from hitting the rocks in the river. I was sure the raft had also hit the shore many times; otherwise, it would have moved on and we could have heard it somewhere. The raft still drifted faster than the boat.
tr: I had to push off from the sandy shores four or five times with all my strength, because I didn't want to hit the islands here and there in the river; surely the raft must have been getting stuck in some places on the shore from time to time, otherwise it would have already gone down the river and become too far away to hear – it was just moving a little faster than me.
es: Four or five times I had to push myself away from the shore to avoid bumping into it, so I figured that the raft must be hitting the shore from time to time, because otherwise, it would keep moving and you wouldn't be able to hear it anymore; it was floating a bit faster than I was.

en: Well, I seemed to be in the open river again by-and-by, but I couldn’t hear no sign of a whoop nowheres. I reckoned Jim had fetched up on a snag, maybe, and it was all up with him. I was good and tired, so I laid down in the canoe and said I wouldn’t bother no more. I didn’t want to go to sleep, of course; but I was so sleepy I couldn’t help it; so I thought I would take jest one little cat-nap.
vi: Then, it seems like I might have crashed into the river again, but I still haven't heard any howling sounds. I guess Jim must have crashed into some pile of wood, and maybe that's the end of it. I was so tired, I lay down in the boat and told myself not to care about it anymore. I thought maybe I should take a little nap.
tr: It seemed that I had once again reached a freely flowing part of the river, but I couldn't hear anyone calling from around. Maybe Jim had gotten caught on a branch or something, which would mean he was done for. I was now thoroughly exhausted and felt like lying down in the canoe and letting everything take its course. Of course, I didn't want to sleep, but I was so sleepy that I couldn't help it, so I decided to take a little nap.
es: Well, after a while it seemed like I was in open river again, but there wasn't a sound anywhere. I figured that maybe Jim had gotten caught on a log and that it was all over for him. I was extremely tired, so I lay down at the bottom of the canoe and said I wasn't going to bother anymore. Of course, I didn't want to fall asleep, but I was so sleepy that I couldn't help it, so I thought I would just take a little nap.

en: But I reckon it was more than a cat-nap, for when I waked up the stars was shining bright, the fog was all gone, and I was spinning down a big bend stern first. First I didn’t know where I was; I thought I was dreaming; and when things began to come back to me they seemed to come up dim out of last week.
vi: But it turned out it wasn't just a blink of an eye, because when I woke up, there were twinkling stars in the sky, the fog had cleared; I had taken a long nap at the stern. At first, I didn't know where I was. I thought I was still dreaming, but upon reflection, it gradually felt like the events that had just happened were from a week ago.
tr: It seems my sleep lasted longer than a nap, because when I woke up, stars were twinkling above me, the fog had completely lifted, and I had entered a wide bend of the river with my canoe in reverse. At first, I couldn't understand where I was; I thought I was dreaming; then I slowly began to remember what had happened before I fell asleep, but I could only vaguely recall it, as if it had happened not just a moment ago, but last week.
es: But I figure it was more than a nap, because when I woke up the stars were shining brightly, the fog had disappeared, and I was drifting backward down a large bend of the river. At first, I didn't know where I was. I thought I was dreaming, and when I started to remember things, it seemed like everything had happened a week ago.

en: It was a monstrous big river here, with the tallest and the thickest kind of timber on both banks; just a solid wall, as well as I could see by the stars. I looked away down-stream, and seen a black speck on the water. I took after it; but when I got to it it warn’t nothing but a couple of sawlogs made fast together. Then I see another speck, and chased that; then another, and this time I was right. It was the raft.
vi: This part of the river is terrifyingly wide, with tall star-like trees lining both banks. I looked down at the river and saw something dark on the surface of the water. I approached it and found out it was just two rotten logs tied together. Then I saw another object, chased it, and it wasn't what I thought either. Then another time, and this time it was indeed our raft.
tr: The river was incredibly wide here, and on both banks, there were very tall and dense trees; as far as I could see in the starlight, they stood like a straight wall. When I looked downstream, I saw a black spot on the water. I immediately moved towards it, but when I got closer, I saw that it was nothing but a few logs tied together. Then I saw another spot and chased after it, then followed another one, and this time I had come to the right place. The raft was in front of me.
es: There the river was monstrously large, with very tall and tightly packed trees on both banks; like a solid wall, as far as one could see by the light of the stars. I looked downstream and saw a black spot in the water. I went towards it, but when I got there it was nothing more than a couple of tied logs. Then I saw another spot and chased it; then another, and that time I was right: it was the raft.

en: When I got to it Jim was setting there with his head down between his knees, asleep, with his right arm hanging over the steering-oar. The other oar was smashed off, and the raft was littered up with leaves and branches and dirt. So she’d had a rough time.
vi: When we arrived, we saw Jim sitting slumped, his head tucked between his knees, sleeping, with his right hand resting on the steering oar. The oar was broken, and the surface was covered with leaves, branches, and debris. The raft had gone through a tough ordeal.
tr: When I boarded the raft, Jim was sitting with his head between his knees, sleeping, and his right hand was resting on the steering oar. The other oar had broken off and the raft was covered all over with branches, leaves, and mud. It was clear that he had also gone through very difficult moments.
es: When I arrived, Jim was sitting with his head between his knees, asleep, with his right arm hanging over the steering oar. The oar had broken and the raft was full of leaves, branches, and dirt. So he had had a hard time.

en: I made fast and laid down under Jim’s nose on the raft, and began to gap, and stretch my fists out against Jim, and says:
vi: I tied the boat to the raft, then lay down right next to Jim, started yawning, stretched out my legs to kick Jim, and said:
tr: Without wasting any time, I lay down on the raft right under Jim's nose and turned towards Jim, starting to yawn and stretch my fists.
es: I moored and lay down on the raft right next to Jim, and I started yawning and stretching my arms beside him, and I go and say:

en: “Hello, Jim, have I been asleep? Why didn’t you stir me up?”
vi: - Hey Jim, was I sleeping? Why didn't you wake me up!
tr: “Hi, Jim, I fell asleep, didn't I? Why didn't you wake me up?”
es: —Hello, Jim, did I fall asleep? Why didn't you wake me up?

en: “Goodness gracious, is dat you, Huck? En you ain’ dead—you ain’ drownded—you’s back agin? It’s too good for true, honey, it’s too good for true. Lemme look at you chile, lemme feel o’ you. No, you ain’ dead! you’s back agin, ’live en soun’, jis de same ole Huck—de same ole Huck, thanks to goodness!”
vi: - Oh my God, is that you, Huck? Haven't you died yet, haven't drowned yet, and you're back here? I'm so glad, Huck, so glad. Really unexpected. Let me look at you, let me touch you. Yes, you're not dead, you're still alive and back here, it's really you, Huck, it's Huck. Oh my God, so glad!
tr: “Dear God, is that you, Huck? And you're not dead... you haven't drowned... have you come back? No way, it can't be this good to be true. Let me see you, son, let me touch you. No, you're not dead! You've come back again, your voice is just like our Huck's voice, and you look just like him... our Huck, thank God!”
es: —My holy God, is it you, Huck? And you haven't died, you haven't drowned, have you come back? It's too beautiful to be true, my boy, it's too beautiful to be true. Let me look at you, boy, let me touch you. No, no, you haven't died! You have come back again, safe and sound, the same Huck as always... the same Huck as always, thank God!

en: “What’s the matter with you, Jim? You been a-drinking?”
vi: - What's wrong with you, Jim? Have you been drinking??
tr: “What's wrong with you, Jim? Have you been drinking?”
es: —What’s wrong, Jim? Have you been drinking?

en: “Drinkin’? Has I ben a-drinkin’? Has I had a chance to be a-drinkin’?”
vi: - Drinking alcohol? Me, drinking alcohol? Have I ever drunk alcohol?
tr: “Drinking? Me, drinking? So, was there even an opportunity to drink?”
es: —Drunk? Have I been drinking? Have I had even a moment to drink?

en: “Well, then, what makes you talk so wild?”
vi: - Uh, so why are you saying such strange things?
tr: “Okay, but then why are you saying such crazy things?”
es: —Well, then, why do you say such strange things?

en: “How does I talk wild?”
vi: - How am I strange?
tr: “How crazy, man?”
es: —What strange things do I say?

en: “How? Why, hain’t you been talking about my coming back, and all that stuff, as if I’d been gone away?”
vi: - What else could it be. Why do you keep talking about things that make me feel like I'm coming back with all those weird things. It's as if I'm dead!
tr: “How so? You were talking about me coming back and other things, as if I didn't exist!”
es: —Which ones? But you keep talking about how I've come back and all that, as if I had left...

en: “Huck—Huck Finn, you look me in de eye; look me in de eye. Hain’t you ben gone away?”
vi: - Huck, Huck Finn, look straight into my eyes. Look straight into my eyes. Did you go away?
tr: “Huck… Huck Finn, look me in the eye; look me in the eye. Hadn't you already gone?”
es: —Huck... Huck Finn, look me in the eyes, look me in the eyes. Haven't you left?

en: “Gone away? Why, what in the nation do you mean? I hain’t been gone anywheres. Where would I go to?”
vi: - Gone? Strange, I don't understand what you mean by that? I haven't gone anywhere. And where would I go anyway? - No, listen to me.
tr: “Leave? What do you mean, for God's sake? I haven't gone anywhere. Where would I go?”
es: —Me? Gone? But, what the devil are you talking about? I haven't gone anywhere, where would I go?

en: “Well, looky here, boss, dey’s sumf’n wrong, dey is. Is I me, or who is I? Is I heah, or whah is I? Now dat’s what I wants to know.”
vi: There must be something wrong. Am I really myself? Or who am I? Am I here or somewhere else? I want to know that.
tr: “Hey, look at the bull, boss, something strange is happening. Am I me, or who am I? Am I in the bull, if not in the bull, where am I? This is what I need to know.”
es: —Well, look, boss, something's going on here. Am I me, or who am I? Am I here, or who is the one that is here? That's what I want to know.

en: “Well, I think you’re here, plain enough, but I think you’re a tangle-headed old fool, Jim.”
vi: - Oh, I thought you were here, completely intact, but I suppose you might be out of your mind or something, Jim
tr: "I think it's quite clear that you are here, but I must add that you are a completely confused fool, Jim."
es: —Well, I think you're here, no doubt, but I think you're an old crackpot.

en: “I is, is I? Well, you answer me dis: Didn’t you tote out de line in de canoe fer to make fas’ to de tow-head?”
vi: - I'm here, right? Alright, then answer this for me: did you jump into the boat earlier to tie the raft to the mouth of the creek?
tr: “I am, right? Okay, answer this: You took the rope and paddled away with the canoe, tied the canoe to a shallow spot, right?”
es: —Ah, so you did? Well, answer me this: didn't you take the end of the canoe to tie it to the sandbar?

en: “No, I didn’t. What tow-head? I hain’t see no tow-head.”
vi: - No, not at all. Which raft head? I don't see any gap at all.
tr: “There is no such thing. What shallowness? I didn't see any shallowness.”
es: —No. What sandbar? I haven't seen any sandbar.

en: “You hain’t seen no tow-head? Looky here, didn’t de line pull loose en de raf’ go a-hummin’ down de river, en leave you en de canoe behine in de fog?”
vi: - Can't you see any gap? Here, is it like the raft's rope broke and drifted down the river, leaving you alone with the boat in the fog?
tr: “So, you didn't hit any shallows? Look at the ox, when the rope snapped, it went down the river, and didn't you get stuck in the fog with the canoe?”
es: —Haven't you seen any sandbars? Look, didn't the raft's cable come loose and go buzzing down the river, leaving you in the canoe behind, in the fog?

en: “What fog?”
vi: - Which fog? - There's no more fog.
tr: “Is it us, really?” “Here is the fog.
es: —What fog? —Well, the fog!

en: “Why, de fog!—de fog dat’s been aroun’ all night. En didn’t you whoop, en didn’t I whoop, tell we got mix’ up in de islands en one un us got los’ en t’other one was jis’ as good as los’, ’kase he didn’ know whah he wuz? En didn’t I bust up agin a lot er dem islands en have a turrible time en mos’ git drownded? Now ain’ dat so, boss—ain’t it so? You answer me dat.”
vi: The fog covered the whole night, didn't it? Didn't you call out and I answered? Then we got lost all over this island and no one knew where anyone was, right? Then I got stuck in a dense storm, struggling and almost drowned! Isn't that right? Or is it not? Answer me
tr: The fog that didn't lift all night. You called out to me, I called out to you, in the end, we got lost between the sandy shore and the islands, and we lost each other, neither of us knew where the other was, so we were lost. Then I crossed the islands again, had a very difficult time, and almost drowned. Isn't that right, boss… ha, isn't that right? Tell me!”
es: The fog we've had all night. And weren't you shouting and I was too, until we stumbled upon one of the islands and one of us got lost and the other as if he were lost, because he didn't know where he was? And wasn't I looking through a bunch of those islands and had a terrible time and almost drowned? Tell me it's not true, boss, isn't it? Answer me that.

en: “Well, this is too many for me, Jim. I hain’t seen no fog, nor no islands, nor no troubles, nor nothing. I been setting here talking with you all night till you went to sleep about ten minutes ago, and I reckon I done the same. You couldn’t a got drunk in that time, so of course you’ve been dreaming.”
vi: - Oh, then I give up, Jim. I don't see anything at all. Fog, then the island, then all sorts of things, I don't see anything at all. I've been sitting here talking to you all night until you went to bed ten minutes ago, and I think I also fell asleep. You probably drank alcohol, so you slept so deeply.
tr: “Alright, but they all came more than once, Jim. I didn't see any fog, I didn't see the islands, and we weren't in any trouble. We sat here and chatted all night, and you fell asleep ten minutes ago, I think I did the same. Since you couldn't get drunk in such a short time, I have no doubt you were dreaming.”
es: —Well, this is too much for me, Jim. I haven't seen any fog, nor any island, nor had any problem, nor anything. I've been sitting talking with you all night until you fell asleep about ten minutes ago and I think I did too. In that time you couldn't have gotten drunk, so what happened is that you were dreaming.

en: “Dad fetch it, how is I gwyne to dream all dat in ten minutes?”
vi: - Nonsense, how could I have dreamed all those things in just ten minutes?
tr: “That can't be? How did I see that much of a dream in ten minutes?”
es: —Damn it, how am I going to dream all that in ten minutes?

en: “Well, hang it all, you did dream it, because there didn’t any of it happen.”
vi: - Stop talking. It's true that you were dreaming, because nothing happened at all.
tr: “It doesn't matter, you saw it in your dream, because none of these things happened.”
es: —Well, we're in trouble, but you did dream it, because none of that happened.

en: “But, Huck, it’s all jis’ as plain to me as—”
vi: - But clearly I saw all of that, Huck
tr: "But Huck, it's all so muddled in my head...""
es: —But, Huck, I see it as clearly as...

en: “It don’t make no difference how plain it is; there ain’t nothing in it. I know, because I’ve been here all the time.”
vi: - Clear or not clear, I don't know, but there is nothing at all. I know it is true, because I have been here the whole time since then.
tr: “But what difference does it make if it's clear, it has nothing to do with reality. I'm sure of it, because I've always been here.”
es: —It doesn't matter that you see it clearly; that's not what happened. I know because I've been here the whole time.

en: Jim didn’t say nothing for about five minutes, but set there studying over it. Then he says:
vi: Jim was silent for five minutes, saying nothing, just sitting there thinking. Then he said:
tr: Jim didn't say anything for five minutes, he was trying to put the pieces together in his mind. “So it seems I supposedly died, Huck,” he said finally.
es: Jim didn't say anything for about five minutes, but just sat there thinking about it. Then he goes and says: —Well, then, I reckon I dreamed it, Huck; but hang me if it wasn't the most real dream I've ever seen in my life.

en: “Well, den, I reck’n I did dream it, Huck; but dog my cats ef it ain’t de powerfullest dream I ever see. En I hain’t ever had no dream b’fo’ dat’s tired me like dis one.”
vi: - Alright, let's just assume I was sleepwalking, Huck, but I swear I've never sleepwalked as intensely as this. And never have I felt as tired after sleepwalking as I do this time.
tr: “If I didn't die the bloodiest and liveliest supposed death, I'm not a man. Also, no other supposed death has ever worn me out this much.”
es: Then he goes and says: —Well, then, I reckon I dreamed it, Huck; but hang me if it wasn't the most real dream I've ever seen in my life. And I've never had a dream that left me as tired as this one.

en: “Oh, well, that’s all right, because a dream does tire a body like everything sometimes. But this one was a staving dream; tell me all about it, Jim.”
vi: - Oh, it's nothing, a dream always makes one tired. But this dream is said to be interesting; tell me about it, Jim.
tr: “Alright dear, such things happen; sometimes dreams can also tire a person. But this time it was a wonderful dream... Tell me all about it, Jim.”
es: —Well, it's normal, because sometimes dreams tire you out like the devil. But this has been a scary dream; tell me the whole thing, Jim.

en: So Jim went to work and told me the whole thing right through, just as it happened, only he painted it up considerable. Then he said he must start in and “’terpret” it, because it was sent for a warning. He said the first tow-head stood for a man that would try to do us some good, but the current was another man that would get us away from him. The whoops was warnings that would come to us every now and then, and if we didn’t try hard to make out to understand them they’d just take us into bad luck, ’stead of keeping us out of it. The lot of tow-heads was troubles we was going to get into with quarrelsome people and all kinds of mean folks, but if we minded our business and didn’t talk back and aggravate them, we would pull through and get out of the fog and into the big clear river, which was the free States, and wouldn’t have no more trouble.
vi: So Jim began to recount everything from that moment, exactly as it had happened, and Jim also embellished it quite a bit. Then Jim said we had to figure it out this way, because it was divine retribution. He said that the first stream head was someone trying to help us, but the current was a second person wanting to cut us off from the first. The occasional howls we heard were warnings to us, and if we didn't try to understand them, we could avoid them. A bunch of other streams represented the difficulties showing that we were about to clash with troublemakers and all other bad people. But if we paid careful attention to our work, didn't tell anyone about it, and didn't complicate things, we could avoid disaster, escape the fog, reach the clear river, and that would be freedom; from there, we wouldn't encounter any more calamities.
tr: Jim started right away and told everything as it was from beginning to end, but he embellished it quite a bit. Then he said he needed to start interpreting the dream, because the dream was a warning. The first islet was someone who would try to do us good, but the current was another man who would pull us away from him. The calls were a warning of what could happen to us at any moment, and if we didn't try hard to understand them, they would bring us bad luck instead of protecting us from it. A lot of sandbars meant we would get into trouble with quarrelsome people and all sorts of lowly individuals; but if we minded our own business and didn't respond or provoke them, we would get away and escape the fog, reaching the big clear river which was the free states. Then we would have no more troubles at all.
es: So Jim set to the task and told me everything from beginning to end, just as it had happened, only he embellished it a lot. Then he said he had to "interpret it," because it was a warning. He said that the first sandbar represented a man who would try to do us some good, but the current was another man who wanted to keep us away from him. The shouts were warnings that would come to us from time to time, and if we didn't try with all our might to understand them, then they would bring us bad luck instead of keeping us away from it. The maze of sandbars was for problems we were going to have with ill-tempered people and all kinds of bad people, but if we minded our own business and didn't respond to them or make them angry, then we would get through and free ourselves from the fog and enter the big, clear river, which were the free states, and we would no longer have any problems.

en: It had clouded up pretty dark just after I got on to the raft, but it was clearing up again now.
vi: By the time I returned to the raft, dark clouds were gathering quite a bit, but now the sky was clearing up. I said:
tr: After I got on the bus, the weather had become cloudy and it had gotten quite dark around, but now the clouds were dispersing.
es: After my return to the raft, it had gotten very dark, but now it was getting light again.

en: “Oh, well, that’s all interpreted well enough as far as it goes, Jim,” I says; “but what does these things stand for?”
vi: - Very good, you guessed it right, Jim. But where should we put these things?
tr: “Alright, you interpreted it very well, Jim,” I said. “Okay, but what do these mean; can you tell me?”
es: —Well, now everything is interpreted until the end, Jim —I say—, but what do those things represent?

en: It was the leaves and rubbish on the raft and the smashed oar. You could see them first-rate now.
vi: I said while pointing at the piles of leaves, debris, and the broken paddle on the raft. Now those things are even more visible.
tr: I was pointing out the leaves, debris, and broken oar on the raft. Now everything was clearly visible.
es: They were the leaves and the remnants that were on the raft and the broken oar. Now they could be seen perfectly.

en: Jim looked at the trash, and then looked at me, and back at the trash again. He had got the dream fixed so strong in his head that he couldn’t seem to shake it loose and get the facts back into its place again right away. But when he did get the thing straightened around he looked at me steady without ever smiling, and says:
vi: Jim looked at the debris, then looked at me, and then looked back at the debris. He was so strongly haunted by the dream that he seemed unable to shake it off and properly look at the things around him. But after he had carefully examined those things, he stared at me, not smiling, and said:
tr: Jim looked at them, then at me, then back at them again. He was so convinced he was dreaming that he couldn't shake off the idea, unable to put the facts back in place. But then, when he had everything sorted out in his mind, he looked at me straight without a smile.
es: Jim looked at that trash and then looked at me and then back at the trash again. He was already so convinced that it had been a dream that he couldn't seem to free himself from it and put things back in their place. But when he finally understood what reality was, he looked at me very intently without smiling at all and said:

en: “What do dey stan’ for? I’se gwyne to tell you. When I got all wore out wid work, en wid de callin’ for you, en went to sleep, my heart wuz mos’ broke bekase you wuz los’, en I didn’ k’yer no’ mo’ what become er me en de raf’. En when I wake up en fine you back agin, all safe en soun’, de tears come, en I could a got down on my knees en kiss yo’ foot, I’s so thankful. En all you wuz thinkin’ ’bout wuz how you could make a fool uv ole Jim wid a lie. Dat truck dah is trash; en trash is what people is dat puts dirt on de head er dey fren’s en makes ’em ashamed.”
vi: - What for? Then I'll tell you this. After I was so tired from messing around there and calling you forever without seeing you, I went to sleep, and in my heart, I was extremely pained because I had lost you. I didn't even care what would happen to me and the raft anymore. When I woke up and saw you had returned intact, I shed tears, I could have knelt down and kissed your feet because I was so overwhelmingly happy. Yet you could make up lies to tell this Jim. Those people are wood, are trash, and those are the filthy things that people put into your mind to make you feel ashamed.
tr: “What does it mean? I'll tell you. Calling out and looking for you on Tuesday exhausted me, I was devastated because you were lost. I no longer cared about myself or the search. When I finally woke up and saw you safe and sound, my eyes filled with tears, I was so grateful that I was ready to kneel and kiss your feet. But your only thought was to lie to poor Jim and deceive him. This is the wreckage of your game; wreckage is what you call someone who plays dirty tricks on their friend, making them ashamed.”
es: —What do they represent? I'm going to tell you. When I got exhausted from working so much and calling out to you and I fell asleep, my heart almost broke because you were lost and I no longer cared what happened to me on the raft. And when I woke up and saw you again, safe and sound, tears came to my eyes and I could have gotten on my knees and kissed your feet, I felt so grateful. And all you could think of was how to make old Jim look ridiculous with a lie. What you see there is trash, and trash is what people are who put stupid ideas in their friends' heads and make them feel ashamed.

en: Then he got up slow and walked to the wigwam, and went in there without saying anything but that. But that was enough. It made me feel so mean I could almost kissed his foot to get him to take it back.
vi: Then Jim quietly stood up and walked into the tent, not saying another word. That's more than enough. I felt so guilty that I almost wanted to kneel down and kiss Jim's feet to make him come back.
tr: Then, slowly, he got up and went into the shelter. He didn't say anything else. But that was enough anyway. I was so ashamed and regretful that I could have fallen at his feet at that moment to take back what I had done.
es: Then he got up very slowly and went towards the wigwam and entered it without saying more. But that was enough. It made me feel so mean that I almost could have kissed his feet to make him change his mind.

en: It was fifteen minutes before I could work myself up to go and humble myself to a nigger; but I done it, and I warn’t ever sorry for it afterwards, neither. I didn’t do him no more mean tricks, and I wouldn’t done that one if I’d a knowed it would make him feel that way.
vi: It took me fifteen minutes to get up, to apologize in front of a black man. But after doing that, I never had to feel remorse or regret again. Later on, I didn't dare to play such inappropriate jokes on Jim, and regarding this matter, if I had known that Jim felt that way, I wouldn't have dared to joke.
tr: It took me about fifteen minutes to convince myself to humble myself to win the favor of a black man – but in the end, I did it and I never regretted it. I never played such mean tricks on him again, and if I had known he would feel this way, I wouldn't have done such things the first time either.
es: It took me fifteen minutes to decide to humble myself before a black man, but I did it and I never regretted it afterwards. I kept playing tricks on him, and I wouldn't have played that one if I had known he would feel that way.

en: CHAPTER XVI.
vi: Chapter XVI
tr: Chapter Six
es: Chapter 16

en: We slept most all day, and started out at night, a little ways behind a monstrous long raft that was as long going by as a procession. She had four long sweeps at each end, so we judged she carried as many as thirty men, likely. She had five big wigwams aboard, wide apart, and an open camp fire in the middle, and a tall flag-pole at each end. There was a power of style about her. It amounted to something being a raftsman on such a craft as that.
vi: We slept for most of the day, and at night we followed a large raft that was as long as a procession. At the four corners of the raft were four large and long oars, and we guessed the raft must carry about thirty to forty people. On the raft, there were five large tents with an open-air kitchen in the middle, and at each end of the raft, there was a very tall flagpole. This raft looked truly majestic. On such large rafts, the raft operators must be very valuable.
tr: We slept almost all day and set out again at night; we were following a long and huge raft like a ceremonial procession. There were four long oars at each end of the raft, so we estimated that there were about thirty people on it. There were five separate shelters spaced apart on the raft, and we also saw an open campfire in the middle and a long flagpole at each end. This raft looked quite majestic. Working on such a watercraft must have been something to be proud of.
es: WE SPENT ALMOST the entire day sleeping and set off at night, a little behind a monstrously long raft that took as long to pass as a procession. It had four long oars at each end, so we thought that probably no fewer than thirty men would travel on it. It had five large wigwams on board and an open fire in the center, with a large flagpole at each end. It was very elegant. Being a rafter on such a vessel meant something.

en: We went drifting down into a big bend, and the night clouded up and got hot. The river was very wide, and was walled with solid timber on both sides; you couldn’t see a break in it hardly ever, or a light. We talked about Cairo, and wondered whether we would know it when we got to it. I said likely we wouldn’t, because I had heard say there warn’t but about a dozen houses there, and if they didn’t happen to have them lit up, how was we going to know we was passing a town? Jim said if the two big rivers joined together there, that would show. But I said maybe we might think we was passing the foot of an island and coming into the same old river again. That disturbed Jim—and me too. So the question was, what to do? I said, paddle ashore the first time a light showed, and tell them pap was behind, coming along with a trading-scow, and was a green hand at the business, and wanted to know how far it was to Cairo. Jim thought it was a good idea, so we took a smoke on it and waited.
vi: We rowed on and followed the river to a vast, expansive area. At night, the clouds rose high, and the sky began to heat up intensely. The river was very wide, and both banks were densely packed with large trees; it seemed as if there was no place for sunlight to penetrate through. We talked to each other about Cairo, wondering when we would finally reach and see Cairo. I said it seemed like we wouldn't get there, because I heard that there were only about a dozen houses there, and if they didn't light up at night, how would we know we had passed by? Jim said that the place where two large rivers meet is the right spot. But I said maybe we were circling around the head of an island and then returning to the old river or something. That made Jim worried - and me too, for the whole evening. So the question was: What do we do now? I said that whenever we saw lights, we should immediately turn to the shore, tell people that my father was following with a merchant ship, and since he was new to the job, he wasn't sure how far Cairo was. Jim thought that was a good idea. So we sat and smoked, waiting.
tr: We started to navigate around a big bend, the weather became cloudy and it started to warm up. The river was very wide and dense trees on both banks formed almost a wall; you couldn't see a single open spot or light. We started talking about Cairo and pondered how we would know when we arrived there. Most likely, we wouldn't realize when we got there, because I had heard that there were only about a dozen houses there, and if their lights weren't on as we passed by, how would we know we had passed through a town? Jim said we would know when we got there because two large rivers converged there. But I replied that we might think we had just passed the tip of an island and continued on the same river. Upon this, Jim started to waver... and so did I. So what would we do then? I said I would go ashore with the canoe at the first place we saw lights, and tell the people there that my father was coming behind us with a freight boat, and since he was new to this, he wanted to know how far Cairo was. Jim liked this idea, we lit our pipes and started to wait.
es: We drifted down a large curve, the night became cloudy and it started to get very hot. The river was very wide and was surrounded by very dense forests on both sides; there was not a clearing or even a light to be seen in them. We talked about Cairo and wondered if we would recognize it when we arrived. I said no, because I had heard that there were only about a dozen houses, and if they didn't have lights, how would we know we were passing by a town? Jim said that if the two great rivers met there, that would indicate it to us. But I replied that we might think we were passing by the end of an island and returning to the same river as always. That worried Jim, and me too. So the question was, what to do? I said to row, row to the shore as soon as we saw the first light and tell them that father was coming behind in a merchant skiff, and that he was a novice at these things and wanted to know how far it was to Cairo. Jim thought it was a good idea, so we started smoking to celebrate it and set about waiting.

en: There warn’t nothing to do now but to look out sharp for the town, and not pass it without seeing it. He said he’d be mighty sure to see it, because he’d be a free man the minute he seen it, but if he missed it he’d be in a slave country again and no more show for freedom. Every little while he jumps up and says:
vi: At this moment, there was nothing to do but to carefully watch out for the town to avoid passing by without noticing it. Jim said that we would definitely see it, because if we did, we would have to live in a land of slavery again and would not be able to find freedom anymore. Suddenly, a moment later, he jumped up and said:
tr: Now all we had to do was keep our eyes wide open and spring into action when we saw a town. Jim said that when we got near a town, he would definitely see it, because the moment he saw the town, he would be a free man, but if he missed it, he would still be in the land of the blacks and would not reach freedom. He often jumped up and said, "There it is!"
es: Now there was nothing left to do but be very attentive to the town and not pass by without seeing it. Jim said he was absolutely sure he would see it, because as soon as he saw it, he would be a free man, but if he didn't see it, it meant he was back in the zone of slavery and would never reach freedom. At every moment he would jump to his feet and shout:

en: “Dah she is?”
vi: - Look over there!
tr: He often jumped up and said, "There it is!"
es: —There it is!

en: But it warn’t. It was Jack-o’-lanterns, or lightning bugs; so he set down again, and went to watching, same as before. Jim said it made him all over trembly and feverish to be so close to freedom. Well, I can tell you it made me all over trembly and feverish, too, to hear him, because I begun to get it through my head that he was most free—and who was to blame for it? Why, me. I couldn’t get that out of my conscience, no how nor no way. It got to troubling me so I couldn’t rest; I couldn’t stay still in one place. It hadn’t ever come home to me before, what this thing was that I was doing. But now it did; and it stayed with me, and scorched me more and more. I tried to make out to myself that I warn’t to blame, because I didn’t run Jim off from his rightful owner; but it warn’t no use, conscience up and says, every time, “But you knowed he was running for his freedom, and you could a paddled ashore and told somebody.” That was so—I couldn’t get around that noway. That was where it pinched. Conscience says to me, “What had poor Miss Watson done to you that you could see her nigger go off right under your eyes and never say one single word? What did that poor old woman do to you that you could treat her so mean? Why, she tried to learn you your book, she tried to learn you your manners, she tried to be good to you every way she knowed how. That’s what she done.”
vi: But it wasn't. It was just a will-o'-the-wisp or a firefly. Then he sat down again, intently watching as before. Jim said that when he got close to the land of freedom, he felt himself trembling like he had a fever. As for me, I can say that it made me tremble feverishly just hearing Jim say that. Because I also began to feel that in his mind, he was the freest man. And who was responsible for that? It was me, of course. In my consciousness, I couldn't understand how or why that was? It made me so restless that I couldn't sit still, couldn't stand still in one place. Before, I was never familiar with that idea, but now I was thinking about it. Now, it haunted me, gripped my hands, and made me increasingly restless. I tried to tell myself that it wasn't my fault, because it wasn't me who made Jim run away from his rightful owner. But there was nothing I could do, always conscious of waking up and saying: you must know that Jim ran away for freedom, and you can't go ashore and tell anyone about it. That's it, I couldn't avoid that thought. And that's exactly where it appeared. Consciousness told me again: What did Miss Watson ever do to you that you could calmly watch her black man run away and not say a word? How did that poor woman treat you that you would treat her so badly? She taught you, fed you, and treated you well in every way. Isn't that so?
tr: But she was mistaken. The lights she saw turned out to be either swamp fire or fireflies; then she would sit back down and continue watching with her eyes wide open just like before. Jim said that being so close to freedom made him tremble violently and his heart start to beat rapidly. I must say that listening to him also made me tremble violently and my heart beat rapidly, because it was beginning to dawn on me that he would indeed soon taste freedom – and who was to blame for that? It was me. No matter how hard I tried, I couldn't silence my conscience. I was so restless that I couldn't relax at all, I couldn't stay still. I had never felt the meaning of what I was doing so deeply before. But now I felt it; moreover, it had settled inside me and was burning my heart more and more. I tried to convince myself that it wasn't my fault, because I wasn't the one who helped Jim escape from his owner; but it was no use, because my conscience would stand up each time and say: “But you knew he wanted to be free and you could have gone ashore and told someone.” This was true – no matter how much I wanted to, I couldn't deny it. And that was what hurt the most. My conscience kept asking the same questions: “What did poor Miss Watson ever do to you that you watch her slave escape right before your eyes and don't say a word? What wrong did the poor woman do to you that you do such a despicable thing to her? She tried to teach you the book, she tried to teach you manners, she tried to do good to you in her own way. She has no other fault.”
es: But he wasn't there. They were will-o'-the-wisps or fireflies, so he sat back down and watched just like before. Jim said that being so close to freedom made him tremble and feel feverish. Well, I can say that listening to him made me tremble and feel feverish too, because I was starting to realize that I was almost free, and who was to blame? Well, me. I couldn't get it off my conscience, no matter what I did. It worried me so much that I couldn't rest; I couldn't stay calm in one place. Until then, I had never realized what I was doing. But now I did, and I couldn't stop thinking about it and it irritated me more and more. I tried to convince myself that it wasn't my fault because I wasn't the one who made Jim escape from his rightful owner, but it was no use, because my conscience kept coming back and saying every time: "But you knew he was running away in search of freedom and you could have rowed to the shore and told someone." It was true: there was no way to deny it. That's where it hurt. My conscience said to me: "What had poor Miss Watson done to you that you saw her negro escape right in front of you and didn't say a single word? What had that poor old woman done to you to treat her so badly? Well, she had tried to get you to learn your book, she had tried to teach you manners, she had tried to make you good by all the means she knew. That's what she had done."

en: I got to feeling so mean and so miserable I most wished I was dead. I fidgeted up and down the raft, abusing myself to myself, and Jim was fidgeting up and down past me. We neither of us could keep still. Every time he danced around and says, “Dah’s Cairo!” it went through me like a shot, and I thought if it was Cairo I reckoned I would die of miserableness.
vi: I suddenly felt so cowardly, so vile, and just wanted to die. I paced restlessly on the raft, scolding myself; and Jim was also nervously pacing like me. Neither of us could stay silent. Every now and then, he would turn abruptly and say: There's Cairo! The words shot through me like a bullet. And I also thought that if it was Cairo, I might die a miserable death.
tr: I felt so vile and despicable that I wished God would take my life and save me from this misery. While I was pacing back and forth on the raft, blaming myself in distress, I kept running into Jim, who was pacing just like me. Neither of us could stay still. Every time Jim started to dance with joy, saying, "There's Cairo!" I felt like I had been struck in the head, and if that really was Cairo, I thought I would die from my torment.
es: I felt so bad and so miserable that I almost wished I had died. I paced up and down the raft, cursing myself inwardly, and Jim paced up and down in front of me. Neither of us could stay still. Every time he jumped and said, "That's Cairo!" it was like getting shot, and I thought that if it was Cairo, I was going to die of horror.

en: Jim talked out loud all the time while I was talking to myself. He was saying how the first thing he would do when he got to a free State he would go to saving up money and never spend a single cent, and when he got enough he would buy his wife, which was owned on a farm close to where Miss Watson lived; and then they would both work to buy the two children, and if their master wouldn’t sell them, they’d get an Ab’litionist to go and steal them.
vi: While I was questioning myself, Jim kept talking loudly. He said that after reaching a free land, the first thing he would do is open a savings account and never spend a penny. When he had enough money, he would buy his wife, who is currently working at a farm near where Ms. Watson lives. Then the couple would work to buy back their two children, and if the owner refused to sell them, they would hire someone to steal them back.
tr: While I was keeping everything to myself, Jim was openly expressing all his thoughts. He said that his first task upon reaching one of the free states would be to start saving money. With the money he saved without spending a single cent, he would first buy his wife. Jim’s wife belonged to a farmer living near Mrs. Watson’s house. Then, working together, they would buy their two children; if the owners were unwilling to sell the children, they would pay some abolitionists to steal them.
es: Jim spoke out loud all the time while I spoke alone. According to him, the first thing he would do when he reached a free state would be to save money and not spend a cent, and when he had enough, he would buy his wife, who was a slave on a farm near where Miss Watson lived, and then they would both work to buy their two children, and if the owner of the children didn't want to sell them, they would get an abolitionist to steal them.

en: It most froze me to hear such talk. He wouldn’t ever dared to talk such talk in his life before. Just see what a difference it made in him the minute he judged he was about free. It was according to the old saying, “Give a nigger an inch and he’ll take an ell.” Thinks I, this is what comes of my not thinking. Here was this nigger, which I had as good as helped to run away, coming right out flat-footed and saying he would steal his children—children that belonged to a man I didn’t even know; a man that hadn’t ever done me no harm.
vi: I heard that and felt a chill run down my spine. Never before had he dared to speak of such things. Just try to imagine the moment when he felt he was about to be free, how different it was from before. It was exactly like the proverb people often say: Give a black man an inch and he will take a mile. I thought, this is because I didn't think it through beforehand. This is a black man whom I helped escape, and now he is determined to say that he will go and take back his child, whose child I don't even know; a black man who has never done anything to harm me at all.
tr: Hearing him talk like that chilled my blood. He would never have dared to say such things before. How much he had changed the moment he felt he was approaching freedom. Just like the old saying goes, "give a Negro your hand and he'll take your arm." This is the result of thoughtlessness, I was saying to myself. Here was the Negro I almost helped escape, now openly talking about committing a new crime by stealing children, and not just any children, but those of a man I didn't know and who had never done me any harm.
es: Hearing those things almost froze my blood. Before, he would never have dared to say all that. That's how he had changed as soon as he thought he was almost free. It's like the saying goes: "Give an inch and they'll take a mile." I thought: "This is what happens to me for not thinking." There he was, that black man, whom I had practically helped to escape, saying with a straight face that he was going to steal children: children who belonged to a man I didn't even know; a man who had never done me any harm.

en: I was sorry to hear Jim say that, it was such a lowering of him. My conscience got to stirring me up hotter than ever, until at last I says to it, “Let up on me—it ain’t too late yet—I’ll paddle ashore at the first light and tell.” I felt easy and happy and light as a feather right off. All my troubles was gone. I went to looking out sharp for a light, and sort of singing to myself. By-and-by one showed. Jim sings out:
vi: I am very sorry to hear Jim speak like that. It was truly cowardly. My consciousness returned to its size, and I became more agitated. Until I responded to my consciousness: Okay, leave it to me, it's never too late. Seeing the lights, I will immediately row the boat to shore and speak out.
