After answering, I felt comfortable, happy, as light as a floating feather. All the restlessness disappeared. I turned to attentively look at the light, feeling secretly joyful inside. A moment later, a light flashed. Jim shouted;
tr: Jim saying such things was upsetting me greatly, he had fallen from my favor. My conscience started to ache so much that I finally gave in and said to myself: "This is enough... it's not too late yet... I'll go ashore at first light and report him." Suddenly, I felt relieved, cheerful, as light as a feather. It was as if all my troubles had ended. I started scanning the shore with wide eyes to see if there was any light and began to hum a tune to myself. After a while, the first light appeared. Jim was shouting:
es: I regretted hearing that from him, because he was lowering himself. My conscience started to hurt more than ever until I finally said to him: "Leave me alone... it's not too late yet; as soon as day breaks, I'll go ashore and tell." Immediately, I felt calm and happy and light as a feather. All my problems had disappeared. I looked again very carefully to see if there was a light, humming to myself. After a while, one appeared. Jim shouted:

en: “We’s safe, Huck, we’s safe! Jump up and crack yo’ heels! Dat’s de good ole Cairo at las’, I jis knows it!”
vi: - Don't worry, Huck, jump on, jump on. This is really our Cairo, I knew it.
tr: "We're safe, Huck, we made it! Come on, hey, we finally reached Cairo.
es: —We are safe, Huck, we are safe! Get up and jump for joy! At last, it's Cairo, I'm sure!

en: I says:
vi: I said:
tr: This time I have no doubt!"
es: And I go and say:

en: “I’ll take the canoe and go and see, Jim. It mightn’t be, you know.”
vi: - Let me take it down and have a look, Jim. But it's not certain, you know, Jim?
tr: "Let me go and take a look, Jim. Maybe it's not the place;" I said.
es: —Well, I'm going to go check with the canoe. You know, maybe it isn't.

en: He jumped and got the canoe ready, and put his old coat in the bottom for me to set on, and give me the paddle; and as I shoved off, he says:
vi: He ran out to prepare the boat, took off his old shirt to lay it down for me to sit on, and then handed me the paddle. As I was leaving, he called after me:
tr: Jim jumped up, went to prepare the canoe, spread his old jacket inside for me to sit on, and handed me the paddle. As I was moving away, he called out after me:
es: With a leap, he prepared the canoe and placed his old cloak at the bottom for me to sit on, handed me the paddle, and as I left, he said to me:

en: “Pooty soon I’ll be a-shout’n’ for joy, en I’ll say, it’s all on accounts o’ Huck; I’s a free man, en I couldn’t ever ben free ef it hadn’ ben for Huck; Huck done it. Jim won’t ever forgit you, Huck; you’s de bes’ fren’ Jim’s ever had; en you’s de only fren’ ole Jim’s got now.”
vi: - Soon I will be able to shout with joy, and I will say: It's all thanks to you, Huck. I am a free man, and if it weren't for Huck, I could never be free; it was Huck who created that freedom for me. Jim, I will never forget you, Huck, you are the best friend I have ever had, and now, you are Jim's only friend.
tr: “Soon I will jump for joy and say it’s all thanks to Huck. Now I am a free man and I couldn’t have made it without Huck; I owe everything to Huck. Jim will never forget you, Huck; you are Jim’s best friend ever, and now you are poor Jim’s only friend.”
es: —Soon I will be shouting with joy and I will say that it is all thanks to Huck; I am a free man and I never could have been if it hadn't been for Huck; it was Huck. Jim will never forget it, Huck; you are the best friend Jim has ever had in his life and you are the only friend old Jim has now.

en: I was paddling off, all in a sweat to tell on him; but when he says this, it seemed to kind of take the tuck all out of me. I went along slow then, and I warn’t right down certain whether I was glad I started or whether I warn’t. When I was fifty yards off, Jim says:
vi: I rowed the boat away, anxious to reveal this matter, but when I heard him say those words, it felt as if my insides were turned inside out. I rowed slowly, and I couldn't tell whether I was willing or unwilling to go. About fifty meters away, Jim spoke again:
tr: I was rowing with all my might to report him as soon as possible, but when I heard these things, I suddenly became paralyzed. I gradually slowed down; I was no longer so sure if I was pleased with having embarked on this task. When I was about fifty meters away, Jim called out again:
es: I was rowing as fast as I could to betray him; but when he said that, it seemed to take all my strength away. I started to go slower and wasn't very sure I felt so happy about having set out. When I was five hundred yards away, Jim goes and says:

en: “Dah you goes, de ole true Huck; de on’y white genlman dat ever kep’ his promise to ole Jim.”
vi: - You truly are Huck, you are the only white person who has kept their promise to Jim.
tr: “Come on, put some strength in your arm, my friend Huck, the only white master who kept his promise to poor Jim.”
es: —There goes my faithful Huck; the only white gentleman who has kept his promises to old Jim.

en: Well, I just felt sick. But I says, I got to do it—I can’t get out of it. Right then along comes a skiff with two men in it with guns, and they stopped and I stopped. One of them says:
vi: I feel heartbroken. But I tell myself: I have to do it, I can't stand still. At that moment, a boat carrying two people approached, holding guns. They stopped, I also stopped. One person asked:
tr: No, my stomach couldn't handle this tattling. But still, I thought, I must do it, I couldn't back out anymore. Just then, a boat appeared, with two men holding rifles inside. When they saw me, they stopped; I also stopped.
es: Well, I almost got sick. But I told myself: "I have to do it; I can't stop doing it." Just then a boat appeared with two men carrying shotguns, and they stopped, and so did I. One of them goes and says:

en: “What’s that yonder?”
vi: - What is over there?
tr: "What's that over there?" someone asked.
es: —What is that over there?

en: “A piece of a raft,” I says.
vi: I answered - That's right
tr: “Give me a ride,” I said.
es: —Well, a raft —I replied.

en: “Do you belong on it?”
vi: - Is that raft yours?
tr: "Are you coming from the hall?"
es: —Are you going on it?

en: “Yes, sir.”
vi: - That's right
tr: “Yes, sir!”
es: —Yes, sir.

en: “Any men on it?”
vi: - Is there anyone up there?
tr: “Is there another man?”
es: —And are there men in it?

en: “Only one, sir.”
vi: - Yes, there is only one person
tr: “There is one more man; sir.”
es: —Only one, sir.

en: “Well, there’s five niggers run off to-night up yonder, above the head of the bend. Is your man white or black?”
vi: - There were five black men who just ran away up there, at the head of the river. Is your person white or black?
tr: “Tonight, five black men escaped just above the bend. Is the man on the raft white or black?”
es: —Well, there are five black men who escaped tonight from up there, where the curve is. Your man, is he white or black?

en: I didn’t answer up prompt. I tried to, but the words wouldn’t come. I tried for a second or two to brace up and out with it, but I warn’t man enough—hadn’t the spunk of a rabbit. I see I was weakening; so I just give up trying, and up and says:
vi: I couldn't answer right away. I intended to answer but couldn't speak out. For a moment or two, I was flustered and couldn't make up my mind, didn't go outside anymore, didn't have the courage of a rabbit. I felt that I had become too weak. I had no choice but to stop thinking like I did earlier and said:
tr: I couldn't respond immediately. I tried, but the words just wouldn't come to mind. For a few seconds, I tried to pull myself together, but I couldn't act like a man; it was as if I had the heart of a rabbit. I felt myself losing more and more, and finally, I stopped trying and responded...
es: I did not respond immediately. I tried, but the words wouldn't come out. I struggled for a second or two to muster the strength and say it, but I wasn't man enough: I was more cowardly than a rabbit. I saw that I didn't have the strength, so I stopped trying, and I go and say:

en: “He’s white.”
vi: - White skin
tr: “White.”
es: —It's white.

en: “I reckon we’ll go and see for ourselves.”
vi: - Let them go see for themselves
tr: “I guess it would be better if we go and check ourselves.”
es: —I think we are going to see it ourselves.

en: “I wish you would,” says I, “because it’s pap that’s there, and maybe you’d help me tow the raft ashore where the light is. He’s sick—and so is mam and Mary Ann.”
vi: I said: - Yes, please go and see, because that is my father up there. And perhaps you could help push the raft to the place with the light. He is sick, and so are my mother and Mary Anne.
tr: “That would be great; because the man over there is my father. Maybe you could help me move the boat to where the light is. My father is a bit unwell… so are my mother and Mary Ann.”
es: —I hope so —I said—, because it's my father who is there and maybe you can help me tow the raft to the shore where that light is. He's sick, and the same goes for mother and Mary Ann.

en: “Oh, the devil! we’re in a hurry, boy. But I s’pose we’ve got to. Come, buckle to your paddle, and let’s get along.”
vi: - Oh, damn it, we're still in a hurry here. But maybe we should help a little. Dim, grab the oar.
tr: “Hey, you devil! We're in a hurry, kid. But it would still be good to help you. Come on, turn back so we can get to work.”
es: —What the hell! We're in a hurry, kid. But I suppose it's our duty. Come on, grab the oar and let's go.

en: I buckled to my paddle and they laid to their oars. When we had made a stroke or two, I says:
vi: I held the paddle and pushed the boat forward. They also went. After a few strokes, I said:
tr: As I turned back, they also started rowing. After moving forward a bit, I started again:
es: I grabbed the paddle and they grabbed their oars. After a couple of strokes, I said to them:

en: “Pap’ll be mighty much obleeged to you, I can tell you. Everybody goes away when I want them to help me tow the raft ashore, and I can’t do it by myself.”
vi: - My father will be very grateful to you. Everyone who was asked to help push it to the shore just left, and I couldn't do it alone.
tr: “My father will be grateful to you. Everyone I asked for help to pull the boat ashore on Tuesday is running away, and I am not strong enough to do this job alone.”
es: —Father will be very grateful to you, that's for sure. When I ask someone to help me tow the raft to shore, everyone leaves and I can't do it alone.

en: “Well, that’s infernal mean. Odd, too. Say, boy, what’s the matter with your father?”
vi: - Oh, it's always like that. Really bad. Hey, kid, how's your dad's illness?
tr: "The world is full of scoundrels, my child. But it's strange, really. Tell me, what is wrong with your father?"
es: —Well, what a bunch of mean people; but, how strange. Hey, kid, what's wrong with your father?

en: “It’s the—a—the—well, it ain’t anything much.”
vi: - uh... uh... it's not that dangerous
tr: “Uh… well, there's not much actually.”
es: —It... uh... well, it's nothing serious.

en: They stopped pulling. It warn’t but a mighty little ways to the raft now. One says:
vi: They stopped. There was only a short distance left to the shore. One person said:
tr: They stopped rowing. We had very little distance left to the raft. One of them looked at me with a frown.
es: They stopped rowing. We were already very close to the raft. One goes and says:

en: “Boy, that’s a lie. What is the matter with your pap? Answer up square now, and it’ll be the better for you.”
vi: - Kid, you're lying. What's wrong with your dad? Answer truthfully or don't blame me
tr: "Don't lie, my son. What's wrong with your father? It will be better for you if you give me the correct answer."
es: —Kid, you're lying. What's wrong with your father? Answer truthfully, it's in your best interest.

en: “I will, sir, I will, honest—but don’t leave us, please. It’s the—the—gentlemen, if you’ll only pull ahead, and let me heave you the headline, you won’t have to come a-near the raft—please do.”
vi: - Yes, I... sir, I'm telling the truth... but please don't abandon us. Because... because it's... please, you go ahead, let me follow and then throw the end of the rope, please don't come near the raft, please wait!
tr: “I swear to tell the truth, sir... but please, don't go. His illness... and if you just pull from the front, that's enough, I'll hand you the rope and you won't need to approach the boat... please.”
es: —Yes, sir, really..., but please don't abandon us. It's the... theee... gentlemen, if you come a little closer and let me throw you the rope, you don't have to come near the raft; please.

en: “Set her back, John, set her back!” says one. They backed water. “Keep away, boy—keep to looard. Confound it, I just expect the wind has blowed it to us. Your pap’s got the small-pox, and you know it precious well. Why didn’t you come out and say so? Do you want to spread it all over?”
vi: - Back the boat, John, back it up - Someone said. They rowed the boat backward. Stay away, kid - move aside, hurry up. You little monkey, the wind might blow that thing onto us. Your father has smallpox, you probably know that already. Why didn't you say so right away? Do you want the disease to spread?
tr: “Back off, John, back off!” said the other. They started rowing backwards. “Stay away, kid… stay behind. Damn it, it must have reached us with the breeze. Your father has come down with smallpox and you know it very well. Why didn't you say it from the beginning? Do you want everyone to get infected?”
es: —Let's go back, John, let's go back! —said one of them. They retreated—. Don't get close, boy; stay downwind. Damn it, the last thing we need is for the wind to have brought it to us. Your father has smallpox and you know it well. Why didn't you say it from the start? Do you want everyone to get infected?

en: “Well,” says I, a-blubbering, “I’ve told everybody before, and they just went away and left us.”
vi: I stammered in reply: - No, no, before I already told everyone, they ignored it, they abandoned us.
tr: I started to stutter. "I... I... I told the ones before you, but they left immediately."
es: —Well —I replied, whining—, it's what I've told everyone before and they left and abandoned us.

en: “Poor devil, there’s something in that. We are right down sorry for you, but we—well, hang it, we don’t want the small-pox, you see. Look here, I’ll tell you what to do. Don’t you try to land by yourself, or you’ll smash everything to pieces. You float along down about twenty miles, and you’ll come to a town on the left-hand side of the river. It will be long after sun-up then, and when you ask for help you tell them your folks are all down with chills and fever. Don’t be a fool again, and let people guess what is the matter. Now we’re trying to do you a kindness; so you just put twenty miles between us, that’s a good boy. It wouldn’t do any good to land yonder where the light is—it’s only a wood-yard. Say, I reckon your father’s poor, and I’m bound to say he’s in pretty hard luck. Here, I’ll put a twenty-dollar gold piece on this board, and you get it when it floats by. I feel mighty mean to leave you; but my kingdom! it won’t do to fool with small-pox, don’t you see?”
vi: - Oh dear, there must be something wrong. We feel so sorry for you, but we... Never mind, let's not talk anymore, we don't want to catch smallpox, you hear? Look, I told you not to come ashore, if you do, you'll spread the disease everywhere. Row your boat about twenty miles down there and you'll reach a town on the left bank. By then it will be morning. Ask someone to guess if it's smallpox, you hear? Alright, now we'll help you with something. Just follow along here and sail down there, you're a good kid. Don't come ashore where there's light, it's just a wooden shed. Hey, maybe your dad is very poor, he must have had a lot of bad luck. Look, I'm leaving a gold coin worth two dollars on this plank here, when it floats to you, reach out and take it. Leaving you would be terrible, but dear God, I'm afraid of catching smallpox, you understand? That person said again:
tr: “Oh poor thing, it's not your fault either. We felt very sorry for your situation, but we… damn it, we don't want to catch smallpox, kid. Now let me tell you what to do. Don't try to pull the raft ashore by yourself, or you'll tear it to pieces. After going about twenty miles, you'll see a town on the left side of the river. By then, it will probably be noon. Also, when asking for help, just say that your folks are shivering and have a fever. This time, don't be foolish and let people guess what the illness is themselves. We're trying to do you a favor, kid. Listen to us and get at least twenty miles away from us. There's no point in landing where the light is… it's just a lumberyard. Your father must be a poor man… and it seems he hasn't had any luck either. I'm putting twenty dollars in gold on this board, you can take it once you're away from us. It's very cruel to leave you on your own, but for God's sake! Smallpox is no joke, child.”
es: —Poor devil, you are not wrong. We are very sorry for you, but... well, damn it, we don't want to catch smallpox, understand? Look, I'm going to tell you what you can do. Don't try to dock alone or you'll ruin everything. Keep floating downstream about twenty miles and you'll reach a town on the left side of the river. By then it will be fully daylight, and when you ask for help, tell them your entire family has chills and fever. Don't be foolish again and let people guess what's going on. We are trying to do you a favor, so be good and go twenty miles further. It wouldn't do you any good to dock where the light is: it's just a sawmill. Hey, I figure your father is poor and certainly having bad luck. Look, I'm going to put a twenty-dollar gold coin on this board and when it floats to you, pick it up. It's not that I like leaving you, but what the hell!, you don't mess around with smallpox, understand?

en: “Hold on, Parker,” says the other man, “here’s a twenty to put on the board for me. Good-bye, boy; you do as Mr. Parker told you, and you’ll be all right.”
vi: - Wait a minute, Packer. Hey, put the twenty-dollar bill on the plank for me. Alright, goodbye kid, just do as Mr. Packer told you and you'll be fine.
tr: "Wait a moment, Parker," said the other man. "Put a twenty on the board from me too. Goodbye, my dear, if you listen to Mr. Parker, everything will be fine."
es: —Wait, Parker —said the other—, take another twenty to put on the board as well. Goodbye, kid; do what Mr. Parker told you and everything will surely go well for you.

en: “That’s so, my boy—good-bye, good-bye. If you see any runaway niggers you get help and nab them, and you can make some money by it.”
vi: - That's right. Goodbye now, goodbye. If you see any black person running away, call someone to catch them, and you'll get money for it.
tr: "Yes, son... stay safe, stay safe. If you see runaway black people, call for help and have them caught, you can also make money this way."
es: —Exactly, boy; goodbye, goodbye. If you see runaway slaves, find someone to help you catch them and you'll make some money.

en: “Good-bye, sir,” says I; “I won’t let no runaway niggers get by me if I can help it.”
vi: I replied: - Yes, goodbye gentlemen. If I see any black man, I won't let him get away.
tr: “Goodbye, gentlemen,” I said. “If I have the strength, I will not let any black person pass.”
es: —Goodbye, sir —I replied—; I will not let any runaway slave escape if I can help it.

en: They went off and I got aboard the raft, feeling bad and low, because I knowed very well I had done wrong, and I see it warn’t no use for me to try to learn to do right; a body that don’t get started right when he’s little ain’t got no show—when the pinch comes there ain’t nothing to back him up and keep him to his work, and so he gets beat. Then I thought a minute, and says to myself, hold on; s’pose you’d a done right and give Jim up, would you felt better than what you do now? No, says I, I’d feel bad—I’d feel just the same way I do now. Well, then, says I, what’s the use you learning to do right when it’s troublesome to do right and ain’t no trouble to do wrong, and the wages is just the same? I was stuck. I couldn’t answer that. So I reckoned I wouldn’t bother no more about it, but after this always do whichever come handiest at the time.
vi: They left, and I returned to the raft, feeling despicable and cowardly, because I knew very well that I had done something wrong. I realized that for me, even if I learned to do the right thing, it would be useless, because a person who doesn't practice doing the right thing when young won't amount to anything when grown up. Later, during difficult times, there would be no one to help or support me, and I might even be beaten. I thought for a minute, then told myself: if earlier I hadn't done the wrong thing by bringing Jim out, would I feel more at ease now? But then I said: No. If that were the case, I would feel troubled, just as I am feeling troubled now. Then I told myself: what's the point of learning to do the right thing when doing the right thing brings distress and doing the wrong thing doesn't cause any discomfort? And aren't the benefits the same either way? I felt stuck, unable to answer that question. In the end, I thought there was no point in worrying about it anymore. However, it still kept lingering in my mind afterward.
tr: The men left, and I jumped into the skiff; I was feeling terrible because I knew very well that what I had done was wrong, and I realized that trying to learn to do the right thing was in vain; a person who hasn't been well-mannered and hasn't learned the ways when young, no matter how much they try, it's futile. When it comes down to it, they are doomed to failure because they have nothing to rely on or to help them persevere. Then I thought a little, wait a minute, I said to myself, let's say you did the right thing and turned Jim in, would you feel better than you do now? No, I said, I would feel bad – just as I feel bad now. So what's the use of learning to do the right thing? Doing the right thing gets you into trouble; when you do the wrong thing, no one gets hurt, and in both cases, you feel bad. When I got to this point, I was stuck. I had no answer to give. So I decided not to worry about this matter anymore and to do whatever seemed most appropriate at the time when the moment came.
es: They left, and I got back on the raft, feeling bad and traitorous, because I knew very well that I had done wrong, and I saw that it was useless to try to learn to do things right; when someone doesn't start off well when they are young, there's nothing to be done: when the time comes, they have nothing to lean on and support them, so they always lose. Then I thought about it for a minute and said to myself: "Wait a minute; suppose you had done right and turned Jim in, would you feel better than now? No," I said to myself, "I would feel bad, I would feel just as I do now. Well, then," I said to myself, "what's the use of learning to do things right when you have problems if you do them right and no problems if you do them wrong and the result is always the same?" I was trapped. I couldn't answer that. So I thought I wouldn't worry about it anymore, and from then on, I always do what seems best to me at the moment.

en: I went into the wigwam; Jim warn’t there. I looked all around; he warn’t anywhere. I says:
vi: I stepped into the tent. Jim wasn't there. I looked around, but didn't see him. I called out:
tr: I entered the shelter, Jim was not there. I looked everywhere, he was nowhere to be found. I called out:
es: I entered the wigwam; Jim was not there. I looked around and did not see him anywhere. I shouted:

en: “Jim!”
vi: - Jim!
tr: “Jim!”
es: —Jim!

en: “Here I is, Huck. Is dey out o’ sight yit? Don’t talk loud.”
vi: - I'm here, Huck. Have they gone far? Don't speak loudly.
tr: “I'm here, Huck. Did he get far enough away? Don't raise your voice, though!”
es: —Here I am, Huck. Can you still see them? Don't speak loudly.

en: He was in the river under the stern oar, with just his nose out. I told him they were out of sight, so he come aboard. He says:
vi: It turns out Jim was hiding under the river, beneath the oar at the back, with only his nose sticking out above the water. I told him they had gone far away, and only then did he climb up. Jim said:
tr: He was in the river, had gone under the rudder oar, and only his nose was above the water. I told him that the men had disappeared from sight, and he got onto the raft. “I heard everything you said,” said Jim.
es: He was in the water, under the bow oar, with only his nose out. I told him that they couldn't be seen anymore, so he climbed aboard. He told me:

en: “I was a-listenin’ to all de talk, en I slips into de river en was gwyne to shove for sho’ if dey come aboard. Den I was gwyne to swim to de raf’ agin when dey was gone. But lawsy, how you did fool ’em, Huck! Dat wuz de smartes’ dodge! I tell you, chile, I ’speck it save’ ole Jim—ole Jim ain’t going to forgit you for dat, honey.”
vi: - I listened to the whole story, then I slipped down to the river and planned to swim to shore if they got on the raft. But after seeing them leave, I turned back. But how did you manage to fool them so well, Huck? You're really good at it. That means you saved Jim once again. Jim will never forget that, Huck.
tr: “I immediately dove into the river without hesitation and made a plan: If they went up to the deck, I would secretly swim to the shore. When they left, I swam back to the raft again. How cleverly you tricked them, Huck! I have never seen a more cunning act than this until today! Poor Jim was saved by your cleverness. Big Jim will never forget this, my heart’s corner.”
es: —I was listening to that conversation and I got into the water and was going to go to the shore if they came up. Then I was going to return to the raft when they had left. But, sir, how you fooled them, Huck! You were so clever! I tell you, boy, I'm sure you've saved old Jim... Old Jim will never forget it, my boy.

en: Then we talked about the money. It was a pretty good raise—twenty dollars apiece. Jim said we could take deck passage on a steamboat now, and the money would last us as far as we wanted to go in the free States. He said twenty mile more warn’t far for the raft to go, but he wished we was already there.
vi: Then we discussed money matters. It was quite a large sum, twenty dollars. Jim said now we could get a boat ticket, and that amount would be enough to reach free territories. He said traveling a few dozen miles by raft wouldn't take long, but he wanted to get there even faster.
tr: Then we talked about the money issue. We had twenty dollars each. Jim said we could now buy a ticket on a steamboat, and it would be more than enough for both of us until we reached the free states. Going another twenty miles by raft wasn't much, but Jim wanted to be there as soon as possible.
es: Then we talked about the money. It wasn't bad at all: twenty dollars each. Jim said that now we could take deck passage on a steamboat and the money would last us as far as we wanted to go in the free states. He said that twenty more miles wasn't much distance for the raft, but he wished we had already arrived.

en: Towards daybreak we tied up, and Jim was mighty particular about hiding the raft good. Then he worked all day fixing things in bundles, and getting all ready to quit rafting.
vi: At dawn, we tied the raft and Jim went to find a very clever hiding spot. Then, all day long, he diligently tied the belongings into bundles and got ready to leave the raft.
tr: When morning came, we tied the raft to a place, and Jim worked hard this time to hide the raft well. Then he spent the whole day organizing our belongings into bundles.
es: Towards dawn, we moored and Jim acted very carefully to hide the raft well. Afterwards, he worked all day organizing things into packages and preparing everything to move forward without the raft.

en: That night about ten we hove in sight of the lights of a town away down in a left-hand bend.
vi: Around ten o'clock that night, we headed towards the town lights on the left bank of the river.
tr: We moved towards the lights we saw around ten in the evening where the river bends on the left side.
es: That night, around ten, we came within sight of the lights of a village on a curve to the left side.

en: I went off in the canoe to ask about it. Pretty soon I found a man out in the river with a skiff, setting a trot-line. I ranged up and says:
vi: I got off the boat and rowed out to ask for information. After a while, I met a person who was taking a small boat out to the river to set up fishing lines. I approached and asked:
tr: I left the raft with the canoe to ask for directions. Soon, I encountered a man casting a fishing line into the river from his boat. I approached and called out:
es: I went in the canoe to ask. Immediately, I met a man who had gone out to the river with a boat and was preparing some fishing lines. I approached him and asked:

en: “Mister, is that town Cairo?”
vi: - Grandpa, is that town over there Cairo? - Where is Cairo?
tr: "Is this Cairo, sir?"" “Is it Cairo?
es: —Sir, is that town Cairo?

en: “Cairo? no. You must be a blame’ fool.”
vi: No! Are you crazy?
tr: No way. Are you stupid or what!”
es: —Cairo? No. You must be a complete idiot.

en: “What town is it, mister?”
vi: - What is that, sir?
tr: "Which town is this, sir?"
es: —What is the name of that town, sir?

en: “If you want to know, go and find out. If you stay here botherin’ around me for about a half a minute longer you’ll get something you won’t want.”
vi: - If you want to know, then go there and ask. If you stay here bothering me for even half a minute more, don't blame me.
tr: "If you're so curious, go and see for yourself. But if you keep nagging me, things you won't like at all will happen to you."
es: —If you want to find out, go ask about it. If you stay here bothering me for half a minute more, you're going to get a slap.

en: I paddled to the raft. Jim was awful disappointed, but I said never mind, Cairo would be the next place, I reckoned.
vi: I returned to the raft, Jim was extremely disappointed, but I told him it was okay, the place we were heading to could be Cairo.
tr: I returned to the room. Jim was very disappointed, but I told him not to dwell on it; Cairo was probably the next town.
es: I rowed back to the raft. Jim felt very disappointed, but I told him it didn't matter, that according to my calculations, Cairo would be the next town.

en: We passed another town before daylight, and I was going out again; but it was high ground, so I didn’t go. No high ground about Cairo, Jim said. I had forgot it. We laid up for the day on a tow-head tolerable close to the left-hand bank. I begun to suspicion something. So did Jim. I says:
vi: We passed through another town before dawn. And I ventured out again, but this place only had mountains, so I didn't go any further. Jim said there are no mountains or hills in Cairo. I forgot about it too. During the day, we rested in a hollow on the bank above the river. I started to suspect something. So did Jim. I said:
tr: We passed another town before sunrise, but I didn't go there because it was a high place. Jim reminded me that there were no steep places around Cairo. However, I had forgotten that. We spent the daylight hours on a small island that could be considered close to the left shore. A possibility started to come to my mind. Jim was also getting suspicious. “Maybe we passed Cairo on that foggy night,” I said.
es: We passed another town before dawn, and I was going to ask again, but it was very high, so I didn't go out. "Cairo is not high," said Jim. I had forgotten. We stayed the whole day on a grassy islet quite close to the left shore. I began to suspect something. Jim did too. I said:

en: “Maybe we went by Cairo in the fog that night.”
vi: - Or maybe we already passed through Cairo on that foggy night, Jim.
tr: “Maybe we passed Cairo on that foggy night,” I said.
es: —Maybe we passed by Cairo that foggy night.

en: He says:
vi: - Don't talk about that anymore, Huck.
tr: “Maybe we passed Cairo on that foggy night,” I said.
es: And he replied:

en: “Doan’ le’s talk about it, Huck. Po’ niggers can’t have no luck. I awluz ’spected dat rattlesnake-skin warn’t done wid its work.”
vi: - Don't talk about that anymore, Huck. Poor black people never get lucky, do they? I still think that the snake skin hasn't brought its curse yet.
tr: “Don’t say such things, Huck. The poor black man never had any luck anyway. I was also afraid that touching the rattlesnake skin would continue to bring us bad luck.”
es: —Let's not talk about that, Huck. We poor Black folks never have luck. I've always suspected that rattlesnake skin hadn't finished its work.

en: “I wish I’d never seen that snake-skin, Jim—I do wish I’d never laid eyes on it.”
vi: - If only we hadn't looked at that snake skin before, wouldn't it have been better, Jim? I think it would have been better if we hadn't looked at it.
tr: "I wish I had never seen that snake skin, Jim... I wish it had never caught my eye."
es: —I wish I had never seen that snake skin, Jim... I wish I had never laid eyes on it.

en: “It ain’t yo’ fault, Huck; you didn’ know. Don’t you blame yo’self ’bout it.”
vi: - That's not your fault, Huck. It's because you didn't know. Don't blame yourself like that.
tr: “It’s not your fault, Huck; how could you have known. Don’t blame yourself for this.”
es: —It's not your fault, Huck; you didn't know. Don't blame yourself for that.

en: When it was daylight, here was the clear Ohio water inshore, sure enough, and outside was the old regular Muddy! So it was all up with Cairo.
vi: The sky is clear. This is indeed the green water of the Ohio River flowing inward here, and out there is the Muddy shore. So, the plan to go to Cairo is ruined.
tr: When the sun rose, we clearly saw the clear Ohio water flowing from the shore, while farther out, the muddy water we knew was flowing! So, there was nothing left to argue about regarding Cairo.
es: When dawn broke, we saw the clear water of the Ohio next to the shore, without a doubt, and beside it came the great river as always. So nothing to do with Cairo.

en: We talked it all over. It wouldn’t do to take to the shore; we couldn’t take the raft up the stream, of course. There warn’t no way but to wait for dark, and start back in the canoe and take the chances. So we slept all day amongst the cottonwood thicket, so as to be fresh for the work, and when we went back to the raft about dark the canoe was gone!
vi: We discussed it with each other for a long time. It wasn't advisable to go ashore now. Of course, pushing the raft upstream was not possible. There was no other way, we just had to wait until night, get into the boat, and go back to see if anything had happened. So we spent the whole day sleeping in the dense forest to regain our strength. By dusk, when we returned to the place where we had hidden the raft, we found that the boat had disappeared.
tr: We started talking to find a way. There was no point in approaching the shore; we certainly weren't going to take the raft against the current. We had no choice but to wait for darkness to fall and try our luck with the canoe. So we slept all day among the dense trees to gather energy, but when we returned to the raft as it got dark, we saw that the canoe had vanished without a trace!
es: We talked about the matter. It was pointless to go ashore; naturally, we couldn't take the raft upstream. There was nothing to do but wait until nightfall, return with the canoe, and see if we got lucky. So we spent the day sleeping among the cottonwoods, to be rested for the work, and when we returned to the raft at dusk, the canoe had disappeared.

en: We didn’t say a word for a good while. There warn’t anything to say. We both knowed well enough it was some more work of the rattlesnake-skin; so what was the use to talk about it? It would only look like we was finding fault, and that would be bound to fetch more bad luck—and keep on fetching it, too, till we knowed enough to keep still.
vi: We fell silent for a moment, not saying a word. There was nothing left to say. Both of us understood that it was the snake's skin bringing bad luck, so there was no point in talking about it anymore. At that moment, it truly felt like we had done something wrong, and we thought that more misfortune would come our way. We kept thinking and remained silent.
tr: For a long time, neither of us could utter a word. We had nothing to say. We knew this was one of the misfortunes brought by the rattlesnake skin; so what was there to say? It would seem as if we were blaming it, and this would bring even more misfortune – until we finally shut our mouths, misfortune would not leave us alone.
es: We didn't say a word for a good while. There was nothing to say. We both knew perfectly well that it was once again about the rattlesnake skin, so what was the point of talking about it? That would just be like looking for something to blame, and it would undoubtedly bring us even more bad luck, and it would keep bringing it until we understood that the best thing was not to talk about it.

en: By-and-by we talked about what we better do, and found there warn’t no way but just to go along down with the raft till we got a chance to buy a canoe to go back in. We warn’t going to borrow it when there warn’t anybody around, the way pap would do, for that might set people after us.
vi: But then, after a while, we discussed with each other how to proceed. And we couldn't find any other way but to keep paddling the raft downstream until we hopefully acquired a boat, then we would return. We didn't want to borrow a boat, because there was no one around. If it were my father, he would have borrowed one, but borrowing like that would make people aware and they would chase us.
tr: After a while, we started discussing what to do and decided that we had no choice but to continue on the raft until we found a place to buy a canoe to return. We wouldn't borrow one when no one was around, as my father would, because we couldn't risk people coming after us.
es: After a while, we talked about what we would have to do and saw that there was no other choice but to continue with the raft until we could buy a canoe to retrace our steps in it. We were not going to borrow it when no one was around, as father would do, because then someone might chase us.

en: So we shoved out after dark on the raft.
vi: When it was already dark, we crawled back onto the raft.
tr: When darkness fell, we untied the rope and set off on our way.
es: So after it got dark, we went out on the raft.

en: Anybody that don’t believe yet that it’s foolishness to handle a snake-skin, after all that that snake-skin done for us, will believe it now if they read on and see what more it done for us.
vi: Those who still do not believe that touching a shed snake skin is extremely foolish and that the snake skin will bring harm afterwards, will now have to believe it if they see our current situation.
tr: If there is anyone who does not believe that touching a snake's skin is foolish, they will believe it when they see what the snake's skin has done to us; especially if they continue reading and learn what else has happened to us, they may choose not to believe it.
es: And anyone who still doesn't believe that it's foolish to handle snake skins after everything that snake skin did to us will believe it now if they keep reading and see what it continued to do to us.

en: The place to buy canoes is off of rafts laying up at shore. But we didn’t see no rafts laying up; so we went along during three hours and more. Well, the night got gray and ruther thick, which is the next meanest thing to fog. You can’t tell the shape of the river, and you can’t see no distance. It got to be very late and still, and then along comes a steamboat up the river. We lit the lantern, and judged she would see it. Up-stream boats didn’t generly come close to us; they go out and follow the bars and hunt for easy water under the reefs; but nights like this they bull right up the channel against the whole river.
vi: The place where you can buy a boat is only near where there are many rafts gathered by the riverbank. But we didn't see any place with many rafts gathered, so we had to continue for more than three hours. Night had begun to turn a faint gray, and that was a sign that fog was about to set in again. It was impossible to see the uneven riverbank clearly, and we couldn't see far anymore. It was very late at night and quiet. At that moment, a steamboat suddenly appeared, going upstream. We lit a lamp and thought that the steamboat would see us. Steamboats going upstream usually never go close to us; they stay far out and follow places where the water below isn't too swift. But on foggy nights like this, they just go straight ahead.
tr: In the shores where rafts are pulled ashore, canoes for sale are usually found as well. But since we couldn't see any rafts pulled ashore, we continued on our way for another three hours. Meanwhile, gray and dense clouds covered the night sky, which was probably the worst thing after the fog. One couldn't calculate the shape of the river, nor could they see their surroundings. It was very late and there was no sound at all, then we noticed a steamboat coming directly towards us from upstream. We immediately lit our lantern so that they could see us. Boats going upstream usually don't come close to us; they follow the shallows; they prefer the calm waters beneath the reefs. However, on foggy nights like this, they go straight up the river; they don't stop for anything.
es: The place to buy canoes is where there are rafts docked on the riverbank. But we didn't see any docked rafts, so we continued on for three hours or more. Well, the night turned gray and the air became very dense, which is the worst thing that can happen after fog. You can't see the shape of the river or gauge the distance. It got very late in the midst of the silence, and then, suddenly, a steamboat appeared upstream. We lit the lantern and thought it would see us. The boats going upstream generally didn't come close to us; they were looking for sandbars in search of easy water under the reefs; but on nights like this, they go up the middle of the channel facing the entire river.

en: We could hear her pounding along, but we didn’t see her good till she was close. She aimed right for us. Often they do that and try to see how close they can come without touching; sometimes the wheel bites off a sweep, and then the pilot sticks his head out and laughs, and thinks he’s mighty smart. Well, here she comes, and we said she was going to try and shave us; but she didn’t seem to be sheering off a bit. She was a big one, and she was coming in a hurry, too, looking like a black cloud with rows of glow-worms around it; but all of a sudden she bulged out, big and scary, with a long row of wide-open furnace doors shining like red-hot teeth, and her monstrous bows and guards hanging right over us. There was a yell at us, and a jingling of bells to stop the engines, a powwow of cussing, and whistling of steam—and as Jim went overboard on one side and I on the other, she come smashing straight through the raft.
vi: We could clearly hear the clattering sound but couldn't see the ship clearly until it got closer. The ship seemed to be heading straight towards us. They usually do this to see how close they can get without slowing down. Sometimes their paddle wheel breaks someone's oar, and then the helmsman sticks his head out and laughs, thinking it's quite amusing. As the ship approached, we thought it might hit us, and it didn't seem to be veering away at all. The ship was very large and moving quickly, looking like a big dark cloud bristling with paddle wheels and surrounded by fireflies. But then suddenly it swerved, looming menacingly, with a row of lit windows resembling a large set of red teeth, and its paddles and oars seemed ready to crash down on us. There were shouts, then a bell rang to slow the engine, followed by curses, the sound of the engine screeching, and just as Jim jumped to one side and I jumped to the other, the ship's paddle wheel smashed our raft to pieces.
tr: We could hear the sound of the ship, but we didn't see it until it got really close. It was coming straight at us. They often do this and want to show how close they can pass without hitting; sometimes they hit the edge of the boat and the helmsman sticks his head out and laughs; he thinks he's very clever. Here it was coming, we thought it would just graze us, but it seemed like it wouldn't change its course even a little. It was a big steamer, coming fast; it looked like a huge cloud surrounded by fireflies; then suddenly it was upon us, with its wide-open furnace mouths glowing like red-hot teeth, its massive prow and stanchions above our heads, it was enormous and terrifying. I heard someone shouting at us, bells rang to stop the engine, I heard the hiss of steam; but it was too late, as Jim jumped to one side and I to the other in a desperate attempt to escape, the ship struck the boat right in the middle.
es: We could hear its engine, but we didn't see it clearly until it got closer. It was coming straight towards us. Many times they do that and try to see how close they can get without touching you; sometimes the wheel rips off a plank, and then the pilot sticks his head out and laughs, thinking he's very clever. Well, here it comes, and we decided it was going to try to shave us, but it didn't seem to veer off even a little. It was big and coming at full speed, like a black cloud with rows of fireflies on the sides; but suddenly it came fully into view, enormous and frightening, with a long row of open furnace doors glowing like red-hot teeth and with monstrous sides and railings right above us. Someone shouted at us, and there was a sound of bells to stop the engines, a bunch of curses and the hiss of steam, and just as Jim jumped to one side and I to the other, it crashed into the raft and smashed it to pieces.

en: I dived—and I aimed to find the bottom, too, for a thirty-foot wheel had got to go over me, and I wanted it to have plenty of room. I could always stay under water a minute; this time I reckon I stayed under a minute and a half. Then I bounced for the top in a hurry, for I was nearly busting. I popped out to my armpits and blowed the water out of my nose, and puffed a bit. Of course there was a booming current; and of course that boat started her engines again ten seconds after she stopped them, for they never cared much for raftsmen; so now she was churning along up the river, out of sight in the thick weather, though I could hear her.
vi: I plunged into the water and dived deep to the riverbed, because the large wheel, which was about eight or nine meters in diameter, could potentially hit my head, and I needed to stay far away from it. I could stay underwater for up to a minute, but this time I thought I had been at the bottom for about a minute and a half. Then I surfaced, as I was nearly out of breath. I raised my hand to rub the water out of my nose, snorting a few times. Of course, in this spot, the water was swift, and the ship would start its engine as usual after about ten seconds, as they never cared about the fate of those on small boats. At that moment, the ship chugged away and disappeared into the fog, although I could still hear the engine's sound echoing back.
tr: I dived – I even wanted to go all the way to the bottom, because the 10-meter diameter wheel was going to pass over me and I needed to make room for it. Normally, I can stay underwater for about a minute, but I think this time I stayed for almost a minute and a half. Then I surfaced with all my speed, because my lungs were about to burst. I almost rose up to my armpits and blew out the water that had filled my nose, then took deep breaths. There was a tremendous, roaring current, and moreover, the ship started its engines again ten seconds later, because they never care about the raftsmen; the ferry was once again moving upstream, spewing foam, disappearing into the mist, but I could still hear its sound.
es: I jumped and aimed to reach the bottom, because a thirty-foot wheel was going to pass over me and I wanted to have plenty of room. I have always been able to hold my breath underwater for a minute; I think that time I held it for a minute and a half. Then I quickly surfaced, because I was about to burst. I stuck my head out quite a bit and blew the water out of my nose, panting a little. Naturally, there was a huge current, and naturally that ship started up again ten seconds after stopping the engines, because they never cared much about the rafters, so I kept paddling upstream, invisible in the midst of that dense air, although you could still hear the noise it made.

en: I sung out for Jim about a dozen times, but I didn’t get any answer; so I grabbed a plank that touched me while I was “treading water,” and struck out for shore, shoving it ahead of me. But I made out to see that the drift of the current was towards the left-hand shore, which meant that I was in a crossing; so I changed off and went that way.
vi: I called out to Jim dozens of times, but there was no response. Then I grabbed onto a nearby plank, kicked the water with my feet, and swam towards the shore, pushing the plank ahead of me. But suddenly I realized the water was pulling me towards the left bank, meaning I was going the wrong way, so I turned around and swam with the current.
tr: I called out to Jim at least ten times, but there was no response. While struggling in the water, I grabbed hold of a plank that came into my hand and, holding it in front of me, kicked my feet to swim towards the shore. But then I realized that the current was pushing me towards the left shore, which meant I had reached one of the junctions, so I changed my course and went to the left.
es: I called Jim half a dozen times, but without receiving a response; so I grabbed a plank that came my way while I was pedaling in the water and headed towards land, holding on to it tightly. But I managed to see that the current was carrying towards the left bank, which meant that I was in the middle of a cross current, so I changed course and followed that way.

en: It was one of these long, slanting, two-mile crossings; so I was a good long time in getting over. I made a safe landing, and clumb up the bank. I couldn’t see but a little ways, but I went poking along over rough ground for a quarter of a mile or more, and then I run across a big old-fashioned double log-house before I noticed it. I was going to rush by and get away, but a lot of dogs jumped out and went to howling and barking at me, and I knowed better than to move another peg.
vi: The river was about two miles wide, very far, and it took a long time to cross. I reached the riverbank safely, then climbed up onto the shore. In front of me, I saw only a small path, but I kept trudging along the rough ground for nearly half a mile, passing an old-style building with two wings, without even noticing when I had done so. I was just about to run past when a pack of dogs came out of nowhere and started barking loudly at me. I knew I was in danger again.
tr: This was a long, sloping, two-mile junction point; that's why it took me quite a long time to reach the shore. I safely set foot on land and started climbing up from the shore. I could hardly see ahead; I advanced about a quarter mile by feeling my way through the rugged terrain and finally found myself in front of a large, old-fashioned, two-winged wooden house. I was about to change my path and move away immediately, but when a bunch of dogs came barking and surrounded me, I realized that the smartest thing to do was not to move at all.
es: It was one of those long, regular crossings of two miles; so it took me a long time to get through it. I made it to land safely and climbed up the shore. I could only see a very short distance, but I groped my way over rocky ground for a quarter of a mile or more, and then I stumbled upon one of those old-fashioned log houses that I had never seen before. I was about to run far away from there, but a pack of dogs came out and started howling and barking at me, and I realized it was better not to move.

en: CHAPTER XVII.
vi: Chapter XVII
tr: Chapter Seventeen
es: Chapter 17

en: In about a minute somebody spoke out of a window without putting his head out, and says:
vi: About a minute later, there was a voice from the window without anyone sticking their head out:
tr: Before half a minute had passed, someone called out from a window without showing their head:
es: AFTER A minute someone said through the window, without sticking their head out:

en: “Be done, boys! Who’s there?”
vi: - What are you doing? Who's there?
tr: “Alright, that's enough children! Who is there?”
es: —Enough, kids! Who's going?

en: I says:
vi: I replied:
tr: “It's mine.”
es: And I replied:

en: “It’s me.”
vi: - I'm here
tr: “It's mine.”
es: —It's me.

en: “Who’s me?”
vi: - Who are you?
tr: “Who are you?”
es: —Who am I?

en: “George Jackson, sir.”
vi: - Sir, I am George Jackson
tr: “Mr. George Jackson.””
es: —George Jackson, gentleman.

en: “What do you want?”
vi: - What do you want?
tr: “What do you want?”
es: —What do you want?

en: “I don’t want nothing, sir. I only want to go along by, but the dogs won’t let me.”
vi: - I don't want anything, sir. I just want to pass through, but these dogs won't let me.
tr: "I don't want anything, sir. I just want to go on my way, but the dogs won't let me."
es: —I don't want anything, sir. I was just passing by, but the dogs won't let me.

en: “What are you prowling around here this time of night for—hey?”
vi: - What are you doing here, fumbling around in the middle of the night?
tr: “Why are you sneaking around my house in the middle of the night?””
es: —And what are you doing lurking around here at this hour of the night, huh?

en: “I warn’t prowling around, sir, I fell overboard off of the steamboat.”
vi: - Sir, I wasn't fumbling around at all. I was on the ship and just fell into the river.
tr: “I wasn't walking, sir; I fell into the water from the deck of a steamship.”
es: —I wasn't lurking, sir; I fell off the steamboat.

en: “Oh, you did, did you? Strike a light there, somebody. What did you say your name was?”
vi: - Oh, really? Can someone light the lamp a bit. What did you say your name was?
tr: “Did you fall into the water? Turn on a light. What was your name?”
es: —Really? Don't tell me! Can someone turn on a light, what did you say your name was?

en: “George Jackson, sir. I’m only a boy.”
vi: - George Jackson, sir. I'm just a boy.
tr: "Mr. George Jackson." "I am just a child.""
es: —George Jackson, gentleman. I am a boy.

en: “Look here, if you’re telling the truth you needn’t be afraid—nobody’ll hurt you. But don’t try to budge; stand right where you are. Rouse out Bob and Tom, some of you, and fetch the guns. George Jackson, is there anybody with you?”
vi: - Hey, just tell the truth, there's nothing to be afraid of. No one will hit you. But don't move. Stay right where you are. Bod, Tom, someone get up and bring the gun here. George Jackson, is there anyone else with you?
tr: “If you are telling the truth, you have nothing to fear… No one will harm you. But don’t even think about moving from your spot, stay where you are. One of you lift Bob and Tom, and one of you bring the rifles. Is there anyone with you, George Jackson?”
es: —Look, if you tell the truth, you have nothing to fear: no one is going to do anything to you. But don't try to move; stay where you are. Someone wake up Bob and Tom and bring the weapons. George Jackson, is there anyone with you?

en: “No, sir, nobody.”
vi: - No, there is no one.
tr: “No, sir, there is no one.”
es: —No, sir, no one.

en: I heard the people stirring around in the house now, and see a light. The man sung out:
vi: I heard the sound of someone rummaging in the house, then saw a light turn on. The person from earlier said:
tr: I heard people moving inside the house, a light turned on. The man's anxious voice was heard:
es: Now I could hear people moving around the house and I saw a light. The man shouted:

en: “Snatch that light away, Betsy, you old fool—ain’t you got any sense? Put it on the floor behind the front door. Bob, if you and Tom are ready, take your places.”
vi: - Move the lamp farther away, Betsy, how stupid, you don't know anything. Put the lamp on the floor, right behind the door. Bod, Tom, are you both ready? Sit down.
tr: “Move that light away quickly, Betsy, you fool... Have you lost all your sense? Leave it on the ground behind the front door. Bob, you and Tom take your positions if you're ready.”
es: —Move that light, Betsy, you old fool... don't you have any common sense? Put it on the floor behind the front door. Bob, if you and Tom are ready, to your positions.

en: “All ready.”
vi: - Ready all
tr: “We are all ready.”
es: —Ready.

en: “Now, George Jackson, do you know the Shepherdsons?”
vi: - So, George Jackson, do you know the Shepherdson family?
tr: “Tell me, George Jackson, do you know the Shepherdsons?”
es: —And now, George Jackson, do you know who the Shepherdsons are?

en: “No, sir; I never heard of them.”
vi: - No, sir, I have never heard of that name before
tr: “No; sir. I've never heard of it.”
es: —No, sir, I have never heard of them.

en: “Well, that may be so, and it mayn’t. Now, all ready. Step forward, George Jackson. And mind, don’t you hurry—come mighty slow. If there’s anybody with you, let him keep back—if he shows himself he’ll be shot. Come along now. Come slow; push the door open yourself—just enough to squeeze in, d’ you hear?”
vi: - Alright, maybe you haven't heard of it, or maybe you have. Okay, everything is ready. Step up, George Jackson. Be careful, don't rush, step very slowly. If someone is with you, make them stay back, if they step up, they will die. Now move forward, slowly. Push the door open yourself, just enough to slip through, understand?
tr: “Alright, maybe you're telling the truth, maybe you're not. Yes, everyone is ready. Come closer, George Jackson. But don't move quickly… Come very slowly. If there's someone with you, they should stay back; if they show themselves, they'll be shot. Come on then. Be slow; open the door carefully… But only open it enough for you to pass through, do you hear me?”
es: —Well, maybe you're telling the truth and maybe you're lying. Now, everyone get ready. Take a step forward, George Jackson. And be careful, no rush... very slowly. If there's someone with you, they should stay there; if we see them, we'll shoot them. Now, go ahead. Come slowly; open the door yourself. ... just enough to get in, do you hear me?

en: I didn’t hurry; I couldn’t if I’d a wanted to. I took one slow step at a time and there warn’t a sound, only I thought I could hear my heart. The dogs were as still as the humans, but they followed a little behind me. When I got to the three log doorsteps I heard them unlocking and unbarring and unbolting. I put my hand on the door and pushed it a little and a little more till somebody said, “There, that’s enough—put your head in.” I done it, but I judged they would take it off.
vi: I did not hastily step up, even if I wanted to, I couldn't. Each time, I only took one slow step without any noise, only hearing my heart beating. The dogs were as silent as the people, they followed me a little behind. Reaching the threshold, I heard the sound of unlocking, lifting the door bar, and pulling the latch. I placed my hand on the door, gently pushed a little, little by little. Then there was a voice: - That's it, alright, stick your head in. I put my head in, but I was still worried inside, afraid they might cut off my head.
tr: I never hurried, and even if I wanted to, I couldn't have. As I took each step, I heard nothing but the beating of my own heart. The dogs had become as quiet as the people and were following me right behind. When I reached the three-step ladder made of logs, I heard the locks opening and the bolts being drawn inside. Then I started to slowly push the door with my hand. “Okay, that's enough,” said someone from inside, “stick your head in.” I did as he said, but I was thinking they would probably behead me now.
es: I didn't run; I couldn't even if I had wanted to. I took one slow step after another and there wasn't a sound, only that it seemed to me that I could hear the beating of my heart. The dogs were as quiet as the people, but they were on my heels. When I reached the three log steps, I heard them removing the bolt and the bar from the door. I put my hand on the door, pushed a little and then a little more until someone said: "Okay, that's enough; show us your head." I did it, but thinking they were going to tear it off.

en: The candle was on the floor, and there they all was, looking at me, and me at them, for about a quarter of a minute: Three big men with guns pointed at me, which made me wince, I tell you; the oldest, gray and about sixty, the other two thirty or more—all of them fine and handsome—and the sweetest old gray-headed lady, and back of her two young women which I couldn’t see right well. The old gentleman says:
vi: The candle was placed on the floor, and they were all standing around it. They looked at me, and I looked at them for nearly half a minute: three large men holding guns pointed at me, making me shiver, truly. The oldest person, with slightly gray hair, was about sixty; the second one was around thirty or a bit older, both looking handsome and composed. And a woman stood there, with graying hair and a small face. Standing behind the woman were two young women whom I couldn't see very clearly. The elderly man spoke:
tr: In the light of the candle on the ground, I saw them all; for a quarter of a minute, they looked at me, and I looked at them. The three hulking men who had their guns pointed at me were truly intimidating; the oldest one looked to be in his sixties and had gray hair, the other two were in their thirties or a bit older – all of them were healthy and handsome – there was also a gray-haired woman with a sweet gaze and two young girls whom I couldn't see very well in the back.
es: The candle was on the floor, and there they all were, looking at me, and I at them, and we stayed like that for a quarter of a minute: three big men pointing their weapons at me, which I assure you gave me chills; the oldest was gray-haired and about sixty years old, and the other two were thirty or older (all of them very refined and very handsome) and an elderly lady with gray hair and the kindest appearance, who had behind her two young women whom I couldn't see well. The older gentleman said:

en: “There; I reckon it’s all right. Come in.”
vi: - Okay, fine. Come in
tr: "Alright, no problem. Come inside," said the old man.
es: —Okay; I suppose it's fine. Come in.

en: As soon as I was in the old gentleman he locked the door and barred it and bolted it, and told the young men to come in with their guns, and they all went in a big parlor that had a new rag carpet on the floor, and got together in a corner that was out of the range of the front windows—there warn’t none on the side. They held the candle, and took a good look at me, and all said, “Why, he ain’t a Shepherdson—no, there ain’t any Shepherdson about him.” Then the old man said he hoped I wouldn’t mind being searched for arms, because he didn’t mean no harm by it—it was only to make sure. So he didn’t pry into my pockets, but only felt outside with his hands, and said it was all right. He told me to make myself easy and at home, and tell all about myself; but the old lady says:
vi: As soon as I stepped in, that person immediately locked the door tightly, barring it with a horizontal latch, then told the young man to bring the gun. The whole group stepped into the next room, which had a new carpet laid out, then huddled in a corner near the window facing the street, and no one remained standing there anymore. Then they picked up the candle, looked at me carefully, and said: - Oh, it's not the Shepherdsons. It doesn't look like the Shepherdsons at all. Then the older man told me not to worry about letting them search for any weapons - not because they meant any harm to me, but just to be sure. He didn't put his hands in my pockets but just felt around the outside, then said: all right. He told me to make myself at home now, and talked about all sorts of things about sin too. But the middle-aged woman said:
tr: As soon as I entered, the elderly gentleman locked and bolted the door, then told the young men to approach with their rifles. In the large room with a brand-new carpet laid on the floor, everyone gathered in the corner outside the range of the front windows – there were no windows on the side wall. They brought the candle closer and examined me from head to toe. Then they all started talking at once: "No, not a Shepherdson... No; doesn't look like a Shepherdson at all." Then the old man said he hoped I wouldn't mind being searched for weapons, as he had no ill intentions... He just wanted to be sure. So he didn't put his hand in my pockets, he just felt from the outside and said it was fine. He told me to relax and consider myself at home; then he asked me to tell everything about myself, but the old woman interrupted:
es: As soon as I entered, the elderly gentleman closed the door and bolted and barred it, told the young men to come in with their shotguns, and everyone went to the large living room that had a new cloth carpet and gathered in a corner away from the front windows: there were none on the sides. They grabbed the candle, looked at me closely, and all said: "Well, he's not a Shepherdson, no; he doesn't have anything of a Shepherdson." Then the old man said he hoped I wouldn't mind if they searched me to see if I was carrying any weapons, because they didn't mean any harm; it was just to be sure. So he didn't put his hands in my pockets, but only touched my sides with his hands and assured that everything was fine. He told me to make myself comfortable and feel at home and to tell them about myself, but the old lady said:

en: “Why, bless you, Saul, the poor thing’s as wet as he can be; and don’t you reckon it may be he’s hungry?”
vi: - Oh dear, Mr. Saul, the boy is soaking wet like this. And perhaps he's still hungry too?
tr: "For God's sake, Saul, don't you see the poor thing is soaking wet? Maybe he's hungry too."
es: —But, man, Saul, poor thing; he's soaked to the bone and, don't you think he might be hungry?

en: “True for you, Rachel—I forgot.”
vi: - Yes, that's right, Rachel, I forgot.
tr: “You are right, Rachel, I forgot.”
es: —You're right, Rachel; I forgot.

en: So the old lady says:
vi: The woman said:
tr: Upon this, the elderly lady said:
es: So the old woman says:

en: “Betsy” (this was a nigger woman), “you fly around and get him something to eat as quick as you can, poor thing; and one of you girls go and wake up Buck and tell him—oh, here he is himself. Buck, take this little stranger and get the wet clothes off from him and dress him up in some of yours that’s dry.”
vi: - Betsy (this is a black woman), ran to find something for him to eat, poor boy, while another girl went to wake Buck up, telling him, oh never mind, here he is. Buck, take this boy and change his wet clothes, and put some of your dry clothes on him.
tr: “Betsy (he was addressing the black woman), run quickly and bring him something to eat, poor thing; girls, one of you go and wake Buck and tell him that…” “Ah, here he comes already.” “Buck, take this little stranger; take off his wet clothes and give him some of your dry ones.””
es: —Betsy (she was a black woman), run and bring something to eat quickly, poor thing; and one of you girls, go wake up Buck and tell him... ah, here he comes. Buck, take this little boy and remove his wet clothes and give him something of yours that is dry to wear.

en: Buck looked about as old as me—thirteen or fourteen or along there, though he was a little bigger than me. He hadn’t on anything but a shirt, and he was very frowzy-headed. He came in gaping and digging one fist into his eyes, and he was dragging a gun along with the other one. He says:
vi: Buck was about my age, thirteen or fourteen, though he was a bit bigger than me. He was only wearing a shirt, and his hair was very dirty. He walked over, yawning and rubbing his eyes with one hand, while dragging a gun with the other. He asked:
tr: Buck looked to be around my age – either thirteen or fourteen, but he was a bit bigger than me. He had come with just a shirt on and still seemed like he hadn't fully woken up. He was yawning on one hand; on the other, he was rubbing his eyes with his fist. In his other hand, he had a rifle.
es: Buck seemed to be about the same age as me: thirteen or fourteen years old, although he was a bit taller. He was only wearing a shirt, and his hair was all messy. He arrived yawning and rubbing his eyes with one hand, holding a shotgun in the other. He replied:

en: “Ain’t they no Shepherdsons around?”
vi: - There aren't any Shepherdsons out there, are there?
tr: “Aren't they the Shepherdsons?” he asked.
es: —Is there no Shepherdson around here?

en: They said, no, ’twas a false alarm.
vi: The whole group said: - No, it's just a false alarm It said:
tr: No, false alarm, they said.
es: They said no, that it was a false alarm.

en: “Well,” he says, “if they’d a ben some, I reckon I’d a got one.”
vi: - I thought if there were any of them, I would have caught one
tr: "If they had come, I would have at least taken one of them down, I guess," he said.
es: —Well —he says—, if they had come, I surely would have taken one down.

en: They all laughed, and Bob says:
vi: Everyone laughed. Bod said:
tr: They all laughed out loud.
es: Everyone burst out laughing, and Bob says:

en: “Why, Buck, they might have scalped us all, you’ve been so slow in coming.”
vi: - Hey, Buck, but you're too late, they might catch all of us.
tr: “They probably would have scalped all of us by now, Buck,” said Bob. “You are coming so slowly.”
es: —But Buck, they could have scalped all of us with how long it took you to get here.

en: “Well, nobody come after me, and it ain’t right I’m always kept down; I don’t get no show.”
vi: - After dark, there's no one left? That's not acceptable. I'm always left behind like this, never getting to see anything.
tr: “But no one lifted me up, this is unfair. You always leave me behind. You don't give me a chance to show myself.”
es: —Well, it's just that no one has informed me, and that's not right. You never tell me anything; you don't let me do anything.

en: “Never mind, Buck, my boy,” says the old man, “you’ll have show enough, all in good time, don’t you fret about that. Go ’long with you now, and do as your mother told you.”
vi: Don't worry, Buck my child - The old man said. Then you will be free, don't worry. Now go, do as your mother told you.
tr: “Don't worry, Buck,” said the old man. “In time, you will have plenty of opportunities to prove yourself. Don't be upset about this. Come on now, do what your mother says.”
es: —It doesn't matter, Buck, my son —says the old man—, you will be able to do enough in due time, don't worry about that. Now go do what your mother told you.

en: When we got up-stairs to his room he got me a coarse shirt and a roundabout and pants of his, and I put them on. While I was at it he asked me what my name was, but before I could tell him he started to tell me about a bluejay and a young rabbit he had catched in the woods day before yesterday, and he asked me where Moses was when the candle went out. I said I didn’t know; I hadn’t heard about it before, no way.
vi: We went upstairs, into the room with Buck, he started to get dressed. After getting dressed, he asked me what my name was, before I could answer, he showed me a blackbird and a rabbit he had just caught in the forest the day before yesterday, then asked me where Moses was when the candle went out. I said I didn't know and had never heard of that before.
tr: When we went up to Buck's room, he gave me a thick shirt, a short jacket, and pants. While I was getting dressed, he asked my name, but before I had a chance to tell him, he started talking about the blue jay and the baby rabbit he had caught in the forest the day before yesterday. Then, when the candle went out, he asked where Moses was. I said I didn't know; I had really never heard anything about it before.
es: When we climbed the stairs to his room, he gave me a thick shirt, a jacket, and some pants, and I put everything on. Meanwhile, he asked me what my name was, but before I could tell him, he started to tell me that the day before yesterday he had caught a starling and a little rabbit in the forest and asked me where Moses was when the candle went out. I said I didn't know; I had never heard it before, really.

en: “Well, guess,” he says.
vi: He said: - So, try to guess
tr: "Then guess," he said.
es: —Well, then suppose —he suggested.

en: “How’m I going to guess,” says I, “when I never heard tell of it before?”
vi: I answered: - How could I have guessed, since I had never heard of it before
tr: “How should I guess, man?” I said. “This is the first time in my life I'm hearing about this.”
es: —How am I supposed to guess —I replied— when no one has ever told me before?

en: “But you can guess, can’t you? It’s just as easy.”
vi: - But you can guess, it's very easy I asked:
tr: “But you can throw something, right? It's very easy.”
es: —But you can guess, can't you? It's just as easy.

en: “Which candle?” I says.
vi: - Which candle?
tr: “Which candle?” I said.
es: —What candle? —I asked.

en: “Why, any candle,” he says.
vi: - Which candle?
tr: “It doesn't matter, just any candle.”
es: —Well, any candle —he replied.

en: “I don’t know where he was,” says I; “where was he?”
vi: I don't know where it is.
tr: “But I don't know where it is,” I said; “where was it?”
es: —I don't know where I was —I replied—; where was I?

en: “Why, he was in the dark! That’s where he was!”
vi: Where? - Oh, it's in my place, where else
tr: “Of course, it was in the dark! It was in the dark, indeed!”
es: —Man, I was in darkness! That's where I was!

en: “Well, if you knowed where he was, what did you ask me for?”
vi: - Oh, if you already know where it is, then why do you still need to ask me?
tr: “If you know where it is, why did you ask me?”
es: —Well, if you already knew where it was, why are you asking me?

en: “Why, blame it, it’s a riddle, don’t you see? Say, how long are you going to stay here? You got to stay always. We can just have booming times—they don’t have no school now. Do you own a dog? I’ve got a dog—and he’ll go in the river and bring out chips that you throw in. Do you like to comb up Sundays, and all that kind of foolishness? You bet I don’t, but ma she makes me. Confound these ole britches! I reckon I’d better put ’em on, but I’d ruther not, it’s so warm. Are you all ready? All right. Come along, old hoss.”
vi: - Damn it, it's a riddle, don't you see? Hey, how long do you plan to stay here? You have to stay here forever. We can go hunting as much as we want, now we don't have to go to school anymore. Do you have any dogs? I have a dog, I take it to the river, if I throw something into the river, it will swim out and retrieve it. Do you like exploring on Sundays? And running around playing with things like that? You probably don't like it, but I love it. Put these on too. Maybe I'll put some more on too. But never mind, it's too hot. Are you done? Alright, let's go, my friend. The bread was cold, and the beef was also cold.
tr: “Don't drive me crazy, man, I asked you a riddle, didn't you understand? How long are you going to stay here? I think you shouldn't leave at all. We would have a great time... There's no school these days anyway. Do you have a dog? I have one... It fetches the sticks you throw into the river just like that. Do you like combing your hair and doing other silly things on Sundays? I'm sure you don't; but my mom makes me do it. I hate these pants, I have to wear them, but if it were up to me, I wouldn't wear them in this heat. Okay, are you ready now? Let's go, bro.”
es: —But man, it's a riddle, don't you understand? Hey, how long are you going to stay? You have to stay forever. We can have a great time... There's no school now. Do you have a dog? I have a dog that knows how to go into the river to fetch the things you throw. Do you like that stuff about combing your hair on Sundays and all those silly things? I assure you I don't, but mother makes me. Darn pants! I suppose I'll have to wear them, but I'd rather not, with this heat. Are you ready? Okay. Come down with me, buddy.

en: Cold corn-pone, cold corn-beef, butter and buttermilk—that is what they had for me down there, and there ain’t nothing better that ever I’ve come across yet. Buck and his ma and all of them smoked cob pipes, except the nigger woman, which was gone, and the two young women. They all smoked and talked, and I eat and talked. The young women had quilts around them, and their hair down their backs. They all asked me questions, and I told them how pap and me and all the family was living on a little farm down at the bottom of Arkansaw, and my sister Mary Ann run off and got married and never was heard of no more, and Bill went to hunt them and he warn’t heard of no more, and Tom and Mort died, and then there warn’t nobody but just me and pap left, and he was just trimmed down to nothing, on account of his troubles; so when he died I took what there was left, because the farm didn’t belong to us, and started up the river, deck passage, and fell overboard; and that was how I come to be here. So they said I could have a home there as long as I wanted it. Then it was most daylight and everybody went to bed, and I went to bed with Buck, and when I waked up in the morning, drat it all, I had forgot what my name was. So I laid there about an hour trying to think, and when Buck waked up I says:
vi: Then there was butter and milk bread. They had prepared those things for me. And it was much better than what I had eaten before. Buck, his mother, and the whole family smoked with small pipes, except for the black woman from earlier and the two young women. The whole family smoked and talked. I ate and talked as well. The two young women sat among the spools of thread, their hair falling down their backs. Everyone asked me questions. I told them that my father and family lived on a small farm at the far end of Arkansas. My sister Mary Ann got married and we lost contact with her. Then Bill went to find my sister and her husband but never returned with any news. Tom and Mort had died; later, it was just my father and me, but my father fell into hard times and had nothing left; so after he died, I gathered what little was left and left. Since the farm wasn't ours, I went to the river to catch a boat, but somehow I fell into the river and ended up here. They told me to consider this place my home and stay as long as I wanted.
