By then it was nearly morning, everyone went to sleep, and I slept with Buck. When I woke up, it was late, and I had completely forgotten my own name, can you believe it? I lay there for an hour, trying to remember. When Buck woke up, I asked:
tr: Cold cornbread, canned beef, butter, and skimmed milk – they had brought these out for me to eat, and it felt like I had never eaten such a wonderful meal before. Buck, his mother, and everyone else were smoking corn cob pipes; only the black woman and the two young women who were not around were not smoking. They were all smoking and chatting, and I was answering them while eating my meal. The young women were wrapped in blankets, and their loose hair fell down to their waists. They all asked me questions. I told them that my father, the rest of my family, and I lived on a small farm in the southernmost part of Arkansas. My sister Mary Ann had eloped, and we had never heard from her again; Bill had gone to look for them, and we hadn't heard from him either; Tom and Mort had died, and finally, there was no one left but my father and me. My father had become skin and bones due to all the troubles he had faced; when he died, since the farm did not belong to us, I had set off upriver with the remaining belongings, but I had fallen off the deck at night. That was the story of how I came here. They told me I could stay with them as long as I wanted and consider the place my home. It was almost dawn, everyone went to their rooms, and I lay down next to Buck; when I woke up in the morning, damn it, I realized I had forgotten my new name. I spent an hour trying to remember it, and finally, when Buck woke up, I said:
es: Cold cornbread, cold salted meat, butter, and milk with plenty of cream: that's what they had prepared for me downstairs, and I've never eaten anything better in my life. Buck and his mother and everyone else were smoking corn cob pipes, except for the black woman, who had left, and the two young women. Everyone was smoking and talking, and I was eating and talking. The two young women were wrapped in quilts and had their hair down. Everyone was asking me questions, and I told them that father and I and the whole family lived on a small farm over on the other side of Arkansas and that my sister Mary Ann had run away to get married and we hadn't heard from her again, and that Bill went to look for them and we hadn't heard from him either, and that Tom and Mort had died and there was no one left but me and father, and that he had wasted away with so many troubles, so when he died I took what was left, because the farm wasn't ours, and I started up the river with deck passage and had fallen overboard and that's why I was there. Then they told me that I had a home there as long as I wanted. Then it was almost daylight and everyone went to bed and I went with Buck, and when I woke up in the morning, damn it, I had forgotten what my name was. So I lay there for an hour trying to think of it, and when Buck woke up I asked him:

en: “Can you spell, Buck?”
vi: - Buck, can you spell?
tr: “Buck, can you spell out the letters of your name?”
es: —Are you good at spelling, Buck?

en: “Yes,” he says.
vi: - Okay, it replied
tr: “Of course, I can list them,” he said.
es: —Yes —he replied.

en: “I bet you can’t spell my name,” says I.
vi: - I bet you can't even spell my name, I said. It replied:
tr: “But I bet you can't spell out the letters of my name,” I said.
es: —I'm sure you don't know how to write my name —I told him.

en: “I bet you what you dare I can,” says he.
vi: - I told you, whatever you dare to do, I can do it too
tr: “But I bet you can't spell out the letters of my name,” I said.
es: —I bet you anything that it will —he replied.

en: “All right,” says I, “go ahead.”
vi: - Okay, let's see you try to spell it out for me
tr: "Not at all, I can list them all at once."" "Alright then," I said, "let's see you list them."
es: —Okay —I said—; let's go see it.

en: “G-e-o-r-g-e J-a-x-o-n—there now,” he says.
vi: - G-e-o-r-g-e. J-a-c-k-s-o-n, see for yourself
tr: “G-e-o-r-g-e J-a-x-o-n…” “Is that wrong?””
es: —G-e-o-r-g-e J-a-x-o-n, just so you know —he said.

en: “Well,” says I, “you done it, but I didn’t think you could. It ain’t no slouch of a name to spell—right off without studying.”
vi: - Good, that's right. I thought you couldn't spell it. That name isn't too cumbersome to spell, you can read it right away without having to think about it.
tr: “Alright, you got it right, but I never would have guessed. It's not a name that can be spelled out in one go without any effort.”
es: —Okay —I replied—, you did know it, but I didn't believe it. Don't think it's an easy name to write just like that, without studying it.

en: I set it down, private, because somebody might want me to spell it next, and so I wanted to be handy with it and rattle it off like I was used to it.
vi: I remember it carefully in my mind, so that if someone asks me to spell it later, I can quickly say it, acting as if I am very familiar with my own name.
tr: When I was alone, I sat down and started working because someone else might ask me to write my name, and I would need to write it quickly as if I were very accustomed to it.
es: I wrote it down secretly, because maybe someone wanted me to be the one to write it, so I wanted to do it all at once, and present it as if I were already very used to it.

en: It was a mighty nice family, and a mighty nice house, too. I hadn’t seen no house out in the country before that was so nice and had so much style. It didn’t have an iron latch on the front door, nor a wooden one with a buckskin string, but a brass knob to turn, the same as houses in town. There warn’t no bed in the parlor, nor a sign of a bed; but heaps of parlors in towns has beds in them. There was a big fireplace that was bricked on the bottom, and the bricks was kept clean and red by pouring water on them and scrubbing them with another brick; sometimes they wash them over with red water-paint that they call Spanish-brown, same as they do in town. They had big brass dog-irons that could hold up a saw-log. There was a clock on the middle of the mantelpiece, with a picture of a town painted on the bottom half of the glass front, and a round place in the middle of it for the sun, and you could see the pendulum swinging behind it. It was beautiful to hear that clock tick; and sometimes when one of these peddlers had been along and scoured her up and got her in good shape, she would start in and strike a hundred and fifty before she got tuckered out. They wouldn’t took any money for her.
vi: This is quite a kind family. And this house is also very charming. I have not seen any house in this area as beautiful and stylish as this one. On the front door, there is no iron or wooden latch tied with a deer leather strap, but instead, there is a brass knob to turn, just like the houses in the city. In the living room, besides the bed, there is nothing else used as a bed. There are many such rooms in the province where they place beds. There is a large fireplace, with tiles laid underneath, and the surrounding tiles are very clean and bright red because they pour water on them and scrub them with other tiles. Sometimes people paint a red coat, commonly called Spanish brown, just like the houses in the city. There are large brass dogs that can support entire house columns. In the middle of the fireplace mantel, there is a clock, a cityscape painting on the lower half of the glass, and a round hollow in the middle to represent the sun, through which you can see the pendulum swinging back and forth. The clock chimes beautifully, and occasionally, a traveling repairman passes by, comes in to clean it, and adjusts it correctly, making it chime continuously for one hundred and ten times until it is taken apart. The homeowner is not easy to sell it at any price.
tr: They were truly a nice family, and their house was really beautiful. Until that day, I had never seen such a beautiful and elegant house in the countryside. There was no iron latch or wooden latch opened with a leather strap on the front door; instead, there was a brass handle like the ones in town houses, which you turned to open. There was no bed in the living room, not even anything resembling a bed; whereas almost all the living rooms in town had beds. There was a large hearth with bricks laid at the bottom, and they kept the bricks clean and red by pouring water on them and rubbing them together; sometimes they also dipped the bricks in a red paint called Spanish-coffee, as was done in town. The brass fittings in the house's fireplace were large enough to hold big logs. In the middle of the mantelpiece, I saw a clock, and below the glass of the clock's lower half, there was a picture of a town; the empty space in the middle of the clock symbolized the sun, and you could see the pendulum swinging right behind it. It was very nice to listen to the ticking of this clock; sometimes when one of the traveling repairmen cleaned and reset it, the clock could chime one hundred and fifty times before the spring fully unwound. Moreover, the repairmen never charged any money for the clock.
es: It was a very nice family, and the house was also great. I had never seen such a good house with so much style. It didn't have an iron latch on the main door, nor a wooden one with a leather cord, but a brass knob to turn, just like the houses in the city. In the living room, there were no beds or signs of them, although there are plenty of living rooms in the cities where you can see beds. There was a very large fireplace, lined with bricks at the bottom, which they kept clean by using water and scrubbing them with another brick; sometimes they washed them with a red water paint called Spanish earth, just like in the city. They had some bronze fireplace irons with which you could grab an entire log. In the middle of the mantelpiece, there was a clock with a painting of a village on the bottom part of the glass cover, and a round opening in the middle for the dial, and behind it, you could see the pendulum swinging. It was a pleasure to hear the ticking of that clock, and sometimes when a tinker passed by and cleaned and tuned it, it would start ringing and give a hundred and fifty chimes before getting tired. They wouldn't have sold it for anything in the world.

en: Well, there was a big outlandish parrot on each side of the clock, made out of something like chalk, and painted up gaudy. By one of the parrots was a cat made of crockery, and a crockery dog by the other; and when you pressed down on them they squeaked, but didn’t open their mouths nor look different nor interested. They squeaked through underneath. There was a couple of big wild-turkey-wing fans spread out behind those things. On the table in the middle of the room was a kind of a lovely crockery basket that had apples and oranges and peaches and grapes piled up in it, which was much redder and yellower and prettier than real ones is, but they warn’t real because you could see where pieces had got chipped off and showed the white chalk, or whatever it was, underneath.
vi: Then on either side of the clock, there were very strange-looking parrots, made of something like makeup, painted in bright colors. Next to the parrot on one side, there is a porcelain cat, and on the other side, there is a porcelain dog; every time you press its head, it lets out a squeak, but it doesn't open its mouth, nor does it show any signs of anger or joy. It squeaks from its bottom. Because there are two fans made from pheasant wings installed at the back. On the table in the middle of the room, there is a very beautiful porcelain bowl, filled with apples, oranges, peaches, and grapes, looking red and yellow and more beautiful than usual fruits; but they are not real fruits and you can see spots where the outer layer has peeled off, exposing the white clay inside.
tr: On each side of the clock, there was a showy parrot; made from something like chalk and painted in gaudy colors. Next to one of the parrots was a clay cat, and next to the other was a clay dog; if you pressed on the cat and dog, they would squeak, but their mouths wouldn't open, their appearance wouldn't change; they wouldn't react. They squeaked from their undersides. Behind these items, a pair of large fans made from wild turkey feathers were hanging. On a table in the middle of the room, there was also a very nice clay basket; filled with apples, oranges; peaches, and grapes that looked much redder, yellower, and more delicious than the real ones, but it was obvious they weren't real because in some places the white chalk or whatever the material was underneath was showing.
es: And on each side of the clock there was a very strange parrot made as if from chalk and painted in many colors. Next to one of the parrots there was a porcelain cat and next to the other a porcelain dog, and when they were pressed they squeaked, but they did not open their mouths nor did they seem different or interested. Behind them there were two fans made of wild turkey feathers. On the table, in the middle of the room, there was a kind of beautiful porcelain basket that had apples, oranges, peaches, and grapes, all piled up, and much redder and yellower and prettier than real fruit, but it wasn't real because you could see where pieces had chipped off and underneath the white chalk or whatever it was.

en: This table had a cover made out of beautiful oilcloth, with a red and blue spread-eagle painted on it, and a painted border all around. It come all the way from Philadelphia, they said. There was some books, too, piled up perfectly exact, on each corner of the table. One was a big family Bible full of pictures. One was Pilgrim’s Progress, about a man that left his family, it didn’t say why. I read considerable in it now and then. The statements was interesting, but tough. Another was Friendship’s Offering, full of beautiful stuff and poetry; but I didn’t read the poetry. Another was Henry Clay’s Speeches, and another was Dr. Gunn’s Family Medicine, which told you all about what to do if a body was sick or dead. There was a hymn book, and a lot of other books. And there was nice split-bottom chairs, and perfectly sound, too—not bagged down in the middle and busted, like an old basket.
vi: On the table covered with an oilcloth tablecloth, beautiful, in the middle of the cloth is painted a blue and red eagle, with a border painted around it. They said that the cloth was brought back from Philadelphia. There were also a few books, carefully arranged in the corners of the table. One book was a Bible with many illustrations. Another book was "The Pilgrim's Progress," about a man who left home without saying why. Occasionally, I still read this story. But the words in it are quite good, though a bit rough. Another book was "Sacrifice for Friends," which had many good stories and poems, but I don't read poetry. One book was "The Speeches of Henry Clay," and another was "Gunn's Domestic Medicine," which talked about everything we need to do when someone in the house is sick or dies. Then there was a book about hymns, and a bunch of other books. There were also some very cute little chairs, with legs splayed out, and very sturdy to sit on, the seat not sagging or sunken like an old basket.
tr: On the beautiful oilcloth cover that was neatly laid on the table, a red and blue eagle with its wings spread was drawn within a colorful frame. They said this cover came all the way from Philadelphia. There were also books carefully stacked on each corner of the table. One of them was a large Holy Bible filled with pictures, suitable for family reading. Another one was "On the Pilgrimage," about a man who left his home and family for an unspecified reason. I occasionally picked up this book and read quite a bit of it. The sentences were interesting but of a kind that was hard to understand. There was also a book called "The Gifts of Friendship" filled with beautiful writings and poems; but I did not read the poems. Besides a book titled "Speeches of Henry Clay," there was also Dr. Gunn's "Family Medicine," which explained everything to do if someone gets sick or dies. There was a Hymn Book and many other books. We were also sitting on very beautiful woven wicker chairs, and they were very sturdy – not like old baskets with sagging centers and broken bottoms.
es: That table had a beautiful oilcloth tablecloth, with a red and blue eagle and a painted border all around. They said it had come from Philadelphia. There were also some books, in very neatly arranged piles at each corner of the table. One of them was a large family Bible full of illustrations. Another was The Pilgrim's Progress, about a man who left his family, but it didn't say why. From time to time, I would read a bunch of pages. What it said was interesting, but difficult. Another was The Offering of Friendship, full of very beautiful things and poems, but I didn't read the poetry. Another was the Speeches of Henry Clay and another was Dr. Gunn's Family Medicine, which said everything to do if someone got sick or died. There was a hymn book and a bunch of other books. And there were some very beautiful cane chairs, and also very sturdy, not sunken in the middle and broken, like an old basket.

en: They had pictures hung on the walls—mainly Washingtons and Lafayettes, and battles, and Highland Marys, and one called “Signing the Declaration.” There was some that they called crayons, which one of the daughters which was dead made her own self when she was only fifteen years old. They was different from any pictures I ever see before—blacker, mostly, than is common. One was a woman in a slim black dress, belted small under the armpits, with bulges like a cabbage in the middle of the sleeves, and a large black scoop-shovel bonnet with a black veil, and white slim ankles crossed about with black tape, and very wee black slippers, like a chisel, and she was leaning pensive on a tombstone on her right elbow, under a weeping willow, and her other hand hanging down her side holding a white handkerchief and a reticule, and underneath the picture it said “Shall I Never See Thee More Alas.” Another one was a young lady with her hair all combed up straight to the top of her head, and knotted there in front of a comb like a chair-back, and she was crying into a handkerchief and had a dead bird laying on its back in her other hand with its heels up, and underneath the picture it said “I Shall Never Hear Thy Sweet Chirrup More Alas.” There was one where a young lady was at a window looking up at the moon, and tears running down her cheeks; and she had an open letter in one hand with black sealing wax showing on one edge of it, and she was mashing a locket with a chain to it against her mouth, and underneath the picture it said “And Art Thou Gone Yes Thou Art Gone Alas.” These was all nice pictures, I reckon, but I didn’t somehow seem to take to them, because if ever I was down a little they always give me the fan-tods. Everybody was sorry she died, because she had laid out a lot more of these pictures to do, and a body could see by what she had done what they had lost. But I reckoned that with her disposition she was having a better time in the graveyard. She was at work on what they said was her greatest picture when she took sick, and every day and every night it was her prayer to be allowed to live till she got it done, but she never got the chance. It was a picture of a young woman in a long white gown, standing on the rail of a bridge all ready to jump off, with her hair all down her back, and looking up to the moon, with the tears running down her face, and she had two arms folded across her breast, and two arms stretched out in front, and two more reaching up towards the moon—and the idea was to see which pair would look best, and then scratch out all the other arms; but, as I was saying, she died before she got her mind made up, and now they kept this picture over the head of the bed in her room, and every time her birthday come they hung flowers on it. Other times it was hid with a little curtain. The young woman in the picture had a kind of a nice sweet face, but there was so many arms it made her look too spidery, seemed to me.
vi: They even have paintings hanging on the walls - especially paintings of Washingtons and Lafayettes depicting battles, depicting the Mary plateau, and a painting called The Signing of the Declaration. There are some paintings they call sketches, one of which depicts one of the daughters of this family who has passed away; she drew it herself when she was just fifteen years old. These paintings are different from any paintings I had seen before - they are mostly darker than usual paintings. One depicts a woman in a thin black dress, cinched under the arms, with cabbage-like flares at the wrists, wearing a bonnet with a black veil falling down, with two white ankles wrapped in black ribbons, wearing black shoes as small as blades; the woman in the painting is leaning down sorrowfully beside a tombstone on the right, under a weeping willow, holding a white handkerchief in one hand and a woven basket in the other; under the painting, it is written: Alas, I shall never see you again! Another painting depicts a young woman with all her hair combed up to the top of her head, tied in a knot in front with a comb that looks like the back of a chair, she is crying, face buried in a handkerchief, with a dead bird lying on its back in her other hand, legs upturned, and under the painting, it is written: Alas, I shall never hear you sing again! Then there is another painting of a young woman sitting by a window looking at the moon, tears streaming down her cheeks: one hand holding an open letter with a black seal on one side, lifting a small framed picture to her mouth with a string; under the painting, it is written: Is it true that you are leaving, oh my love! All those paintings are beautiful, I am sure, but somehow I do not like them much. Because whenever I am sad, they make me feel even heavier. Everyone regretted that she died, because she was planning to paint many more such paintings. Everyone felt that she had gained something while everyone else had lost something. But I think that with her temperament, it was better for her to rest in the cemetery. She only prayed to live long enough to finish that painting, but she still did not survive. It was a painting of a young woman in a long white dress, standing by the bridge, about to jump into the river, hair flowing down her back, face turned up looking at the moon, tears streaming down, arms crossed in front of her chest, with two other arms reaching forward, and two more arms reaching up towards the moon - the idea was to see which pair of arms was better, and the others would be erased. But as I mentioned earlier, she died before making a final decision; and now they still keep that painting hanging over her bed in her room. Every year on her birthday, they decorate that painting with flowers. There used to be a curtain covering it. The young woman in the painting has a small and pretty face, but because of the many arms, she looks like a spider, that's how I see it.
tr: There were paintings hanging on the walls – mostly Washingtons and Lafayettes, wars, Highland Marys, and also "The Signing of the Declaration of Independence". There were also pencil drawings, one of which was made by one of their deceased daughters when she was just fifteen years old. These were different from all the pictures I had seen so far; they were darker in color than all of them. In one of them, there was a woman in a thin black dress. The dress was cinched at the armpits with a belt, the cuffs were puffed up like cabbage, and there was a black veil in front of the shovel-like brimmed hat on her head, black ribbons were tied around her white thin wrists, and she wore small black slippers resembling chisels on her feet. The woman was standing pensively with her right elbow resting on a tombstone, under a weeping willow, and in her other hand hanging by her side, a white handkerchief and a handbag could be seen, and beneath the picture, it said, "Alas, I Shall Never See You Again. " In another picture, there was a young woman with her hair beautifully done up in a bun on top of her head, with a comb resembling a chair back attached behind the bun. She was crying, holding a handkerchief to her face with one hand, and in her other hand lay a dead bird with its claws up; beneath this picture, it said, "Alas, I Shall Never Hear Your Sweet Song Again. "In another picture, a young lady was looking at the moon through a window, with tears streaming down her cheeks; in one hand, she held an open letter sealed with black, and with the other hand, she was bringing a medallion on a chain to her lips. The inscription beneath this picture read: "Ah, You Are Gone, Alas, You Are Gone." These were probably beautiful pictures, but they weren't quite to my taste; because whenever I felt a bit down, looking at these pictures made me feel even worse. Everyone was very sad about the girl's death because she could have made many more of these pictures, and people realized what they had missed by looking at what she had done. But judging by the tendency in the pictures, she probably had a better time in the cemetery. They said that when she fell ill, she was working on her greatest piece and prayed day and night to stay alive until she finished it, but she never got the chance to complete it. This picture was of a young woman in a long white dress; she was standing ready to jump over the railings of a bridge, her hair let loose, looking at the moon with tears streaming down her face. She had her arms crossed over her chest, her arms extended forward, and she was reaching both towards the moon – she would later erase the other arms, deciding which looked better; but as I said, she died before making a decision, and now they keep this picture at the head of her bed in her room; they hung flowers on the picture on her every birthday. At other times, they covered it with a small curtain. The young woman in the picture had a beautiful and sweet face, but having so many arms made her look a bit like a spider to me.
es: On the walls, they had hung pictures mostly of Washington and Lafayette and battles and Mary, Queen of Scots, and another one called The Signing of the Declaration. There were some called pastels, made by one of the daughters, who had died when she was only fifteen years old. They were different from all the pictures I had seen before: almost all darker than what you usually see. One was of a woman in a tight black dress, with a belt under her armpits and bulges like a cabbage in the middle of the sleeves and a large black hat shaped like a coif, with a black veil and thin white ankles bandaged with a black ribbon and very small black slippers, like spatulas, and she was leaning thoughtfully on a cemetery slab, resting on her right elbow, under a weeping willow, with the other hand hanging down to one side holding a white handkerchief and a reticule, and under the picture, a sign said "I will never see you again, alas. " Another was of a young lady with her hair all styled in a pompadour and made into a bun and tied at the back with a large comb like the back of a chair, crying into a handkerchief, and in the other hand, she held a dead bird on its back with its legs up, and under the picture, it said "I will never hear your sweet trill again, alas. " There was another where a young lady was looking at the moon through a window, and tears were streaming down her cheeks, and in one hand, she held an open letter with a black wax seal on the edge, and she was bringing a locket with a chain to her mouth, and under the picture, it said "And you are gone, yes, you are gone, alas. "I guess those pictures were of great merit, but I don't know why I didn't like them, because when I was feeling a bit down, they always gave me the creeps. Everyone was very sad because she had died, because she had many more pictures left to paint, and from the ones she had already painted, you could see what they had lost. But I figured that with that state of mind, she would be much better off in the cemetery. She was painting what they said was going to be her best picture when she got sick, and every day and every night she prayed to stay alive until she finished it, but she didn't get the chance. It was a picture of a girl in a long white dress, standing on the railing of a bridge and ready to jump, with her hair loose down her back looking at the moon, her face bathed in tears, with two arms crossed over her chest, two arms extended in front, and two arms reaching towards the moon, and the idea was to see which pair of arms would look best and then erase all the others, but as I was saying, she died before deciding, and now they had that picture above the head of the bed in her room, and every time her birthday came, they put flowers all around it. The rest of the time, it was covered with a curtain. The girl in the picture had a kind and pleasant face, but to me, it seemed that so many arms gave her a bit of a spider-like look.

en: This young girl kept a scrap-book when she was alive, and used to paste obituaries and accidents and cases of patient suffering in it out of the Presbyterian Observer, and write poetry after them out of her own head. It was very good poetry. This is what she wrote about a boy by the name of Stephen Dowling Bots that fell down a well and was drownded:
vi: This young woman, when she was alive, had a notebook in which she kept pressed leaves and often copied stories or confessions of the sick from the Presbyterian Observer magazine, then wrote poems inspired by her own thoughts beneath them. The poems were quite remarkable. Below is a poem she wrote about a boy named Stephen Dowling Bost who fell into a well and died:
tr: While the same young girl was alive, she kept a notebook, pasting old obituaries, accident reports, and articles about enduring suffering with patience from the Presbyterian Observer newspaper into it. She also wrote poems she made up herself for the articles she pasted. These were very good poems. The poem she wrote for a boy named Stephen Dowling Bots, who fell into a well and drowned, was as follows:
es: When the girl was alive, she had been making a scrapbook in which she pasted obituaries, accidents, and cases of patient suffering that had appeared in the Presbyterian Observer, along with poems that these had inspired in her and which she wrote with her own imagination. They were very good poems. This is the one she wrote about a boy named Stephen Dowling Bots, who fell into a well and drowned:

en: ODE TO STEPHEN DOWLING BOTS, DEC’D
vi: the poem mourning Stephen Dowling Bost who has died.
tr: DECEASED STEPHEN DOWLING BOTS'S ROOM
es: ODE TO STEPHEN DOWLING BOTS, DECEASED

en: And did young Stephen sicken,
vi: Is Stephen sick?
tr: Has little Stephen fallen ill?
es: Was it Stephen and did he get sick?

en: And did young Stephen die?
vi: Did Stephen die?
tr: Is little Stephen dead?
es: Is that what Stephen died of?

en: And did the sad hearts thicken,
vi: Do sad hearts grow heavier
tr: Have sorrowful hearts been constricted,
es: Did your heart suffer?

en: And did the mourners cry?
vi: Are those the people who made you cry?
tr: Have the mourners shed tears?
es: Did the people become sad?

en: No; such was not the fate of
vi: No, it's not fate.
tr: No; this was not his fate
es: No; that was not the fate

en: Young Stephen Dowling Bots;
vi: Stephen Dowling Bost's belongings.
tr: Young Stephen Dowling Bots’;
es: by Stephen Dowling Bots;

en: Though sad hearts round him thickened,
vi: Even though the hearts around you are heavy
tr: Perhaps sorrowful hearts burned,
es: although his sad death grieved many of us,

en: ’Twas not from sickness’ shots.
vi: It's not because of illness either, dear.
tr: But it wasn't because of illness.
es: it was not the illness that took him.

en: No whooping-cough did rack his frame,
vi: No sobbing sound can mend your image.
tr: It wasn't whooping cough that ravaged his body,
es: It was not whooping cough that took him from us,

en: Nor measles drear with spots;
vi: Nothing can erase the pain.
tr: It was unexpected with a hopeless measles;
es: neither was the horrible measles to blame;

en: Not these impaired the sacred name
vi: Nothing can make up for your name.
tr: It was not these that overshadowed the blessed name
es: none of them yielded

en: Of Stephen Dowling Bots.
vi: Oh Stephen Dowling Bost.
tr: With the death of Stephen Dowling Bots.
es: a Stephen Dowling Bots.

en: Despised love struck not with woe
vi: Despite the pain, love remains unbroken.
tr: Love's torment did not burn
es: Nor was it the sorrow of an unshared love

en: That head of curly knots,
vi: The head still has a full set of hair.
tr: Oh, curly-headed one with bangs,
es: the one who wrinkled her forehead in anger and pain;

en: Nor stomach troubles laid him low,
vi: Despite the pain in my gut, it made me fall down.
tr: It was not a stomach ache that laid one down on the bed,
es: it was not the anxieties of poor digestion

en: Young Stephen Dowling Bots.
vi: I am still Stephen Dowling Bost.
tr: Poor Stephen Dowling Bots.
es: the ones that ended Stephen Dowling Bots forever.

en: O no. Then list with tearful eye,
vi: Oh, no! Look with tearful eyes.
tr: None of them. Listen with tears in your eyes,
es: Oh, no! Listen attentively, as tearful as I am,

en: Whilst I his fate do tell.
vi: When we hear stories about your fate.
tr: While I was narrating his unfortunate fate.
es: the horrible fate that poor man suffered.

en: His soul did from this cold world fly
vi: The soul flies up to the cold world.
tr: Left with an indifferent farewell
es: How his soul abandoned the cold and sad world

en: By falling down a well.
vi: When you fall into the well.
tr: From the bottom of a well, this cruel world.
es: because our boy fell into a deep well.

en: They got him out and emptied him;
vi: Lift me up and drain the water from my body.
tr: Ah, they pulled it out of the well and emptied its contents;
es: Then they proceeded to drain his lung,

en: Alas it was too late;
vi: But it was already too late for me.
tr: But alas, it was already too late;
es: but it was already too late, alas, for the poor heart;

en: His spirit was gone for to sport aloft
vi: My soul has flown to a place unseen.
tr: His soul had already gone to run and play
es: his soul rose in three clouds of cotton

en: In the realms of the good and great.
vi: where, good, great?
tr: To the realm of nobility and goodness.
es: where the celestial Gathering is celebrated.

en: If Emmeline Grangerford could make poetry like that before she was fourteen, there ain’t no telling what she could a done by-and-by. Buck said she could rattle off poetry like nothing. She didn’t ever have to stop to think. He said she would slap down a line, and if she couldn’t find anything to rhyme with it would just scratch it out and slap down another one, and go ahead. She warn’t particular; she could write about anything you choose to give her to write about just so it was sadful. Every time a man died, or a woman died, or a child died, she would be on hand with her “tribute” before he was cold. She called them tributes. The neighbors said it was the doctor first, then Emmeline, then the undertaker—the undertaker never got in ahead of Emmeline but once, and then she hung fire on a rhyme for the dead person’s name, which was Whistler. She warn’t ever the same after that; she never complained, but she kinder pined away and did not live long. Poor thing, many’s the time I made myself go up to the little room that used to be hers and get out her poor old scrap-book and read in it when her pictures had been aggravating me and I had soured on her a little. I liked all that family, dead ones and all, and warn’t going to let anything come between us. Poor Emmeline made poetry about all the dead people when she was alive, and it didn’t seem right that there warn’t nobody to make some about her now she was gone; so I tried to sweat out a verse or two myself, but I couldn’t seem to make it go somehow. They kept Emmeline’s room trim and nice, and all the things fixed in it just the way she liked to have them when she was alive, and nobody ever slept there. The old lady took care of the room herself, though there was plenty of niggers, and she sewed there a good deal and read her Bible there mostly.
vi: If Miss Emmeline Grangerford could write such poems at the age of fourteen, one wonders what she might have accomplished later on. Buck said that she could scribble out a poem as easily as playing. She was always thinking. He said she would jot down a line, and if she couldn't find another line to rhyme with it, she would erase it immediately and come up with another one, and so on. She had a particular liking for something, could write anything she chose, and if you asked her to write something, she would. But it had to be sad poetry. Whenever someone died, whether a man, woman, or child, she would write something to mourn the deceased before the body turned cold. She called these eulogies. The neighbors said that in order, it was first the doctor, then Emmeline, and they would arrive at the same time. Then she would enthusiastically come up with a rhyme for the deceased's name, calling it a Whistler. Later on, she gradually changed, never complained, but she kept wasting away and couldn't live any longer. It's so sad, many times I went up to the room where she used to work, took out her notebook to look at, and seeing the pictures she drew made me feel sad and pity her. I loved this family, even the deceased, all of them, and I didn't let anything happen. Poor Miss Emmeline, when she was alive, she wrote poems about the dead, but no one wrote any poems about her. So, I tried to rack my brain to think of a few lines, but I couldn't come up with anything. This family kept Miss Emmeline's room very clean and tidy, and everything was left as she liked it when she was alive, and no one slept there. Her mother herself cleaned and took care of this room, even though there were many black servants in the house. She would go into this room to sew and often read prayers there.
tr: If Emmeline Grangerford could write such poetry before she was fourteen, it was hard to imagine what she could write in the future. According to Buck, she could easily make up a poem in one go. She didn't even need to stop and think. He said that if she wrote a line and couldn't find a rhyme, she would immediately erase that line and write another one, and continue like that. Moreover, she wasn't fixated on a single topic; whatever you told her to write about, she could write on that topic, as long as it was sorrowful. Whenever a man, woman, or child died, she would come up with a piece expressing her love and respect for that person before the funeral had even cooled down. According to the neighbors, when someone died, first the doctor, then Emmeline, and then the undertaker would come; the undertaker had only once arrived before Emmeline. As a result, Emmeline, who was shaken by this, had delayed writing for the deceased person named Whistler. After that, the girl was never the same; she never complained, but she wasted away day by day and didn't live much longer. Poor thing; many times when her pictures disturbed me and I started to think of her less, I forced myself to go to the little room that used to be hers, and took out her wretched notebook to read what she had written. I loved everyone in the family, dead or alive, and I wouldn't allow anything to come between us. Poor Emmeline had written poems about all the dead while she was alive, and now that she was gone, it didn't seem right to me that no one would write anything for her; so I tried to write a few verses, but somehow I just couldn't manage it. They always kept Emmeline's room clean and tidy, everything inside was just as she liked it when she was alive, and no one slept in that room. Despite having a lot of black servants, the old woman cleaned the room herself, sewed a lot there, and usually read her Holy Bible there as well.
es: If Emmeline Grangerford was capable of writing poetry like that before she turned fourteen, God knows what she could have done with time. Buck said that poetry came to her with complete ease. She didn't even have to stop to think. He said she would write a line and if she couldn't find anything that rhymed, she would cross it out and write another and keep going. She wasn't picky at all; she could write about anything someone gave her as a topic, as long as it was sad. Every time a man, or a woman, or a child died, there she was with her "tribute" before the corpse had even cooled down. She called them tributes. The neighbors said that first the doctor arrived, then Emmeline, and then the undertaker; the undertaker only beat Emmeline once, and that was because she couldn't find a way to rhyme with the name of someone named Whistler. From then on, she was never the same; she never complained, but she started to become melancholic and didn't live much longer. Poor thing; I would often go up to the little room that had been hers and take out her poor scrapbook and read it when her pictures had irritated me and I felt a bit angry with her. I liked that whole family, the dead and all, and I wasn't going to let anything come between us. Poor Emmeline wrote poetry for all the dead when she was alive, and it didn't seem right to me that there was no one to write one for her now that she was dead; so I tried to write one or two for her, but I don't know why they didn't come out. They always kept Emmeline's room tidy and clean, with everything exactly as she liked it when she was alive, and no one ever slept there. The old lady took care of the room herself, even though there were many black servants, and she spent a lot of time sewing and reading the Bible, mostly.

en: Well, as I was saying about the parlor, there was beautiful curtains on the windows: white, with pictures painted on them of castles with vines all down the walls, and cattle coming down to drink. There was a little old piano, too, that had tin pans in it, I reckon, and nothing was ever so lovely as to hear the young ladies sing “The Last Link is Broken” and play “The Battle of Prague” on it. The walls of all the rooms was plastered, and most had carpets on the floors, and the whole house was whitewashed on the outside.
vi: Quyen, I am talking about the living room. There are many windows here, white curtains with drawings of ancient castles, grapevines around the walls with herds of cows and horses drinking water. There is a small old piano, which I am sure contains pots and pans. Whenever the ladies in the house sing the song "The Last Ties Have Broken" or play "The Battle of Prague," nothing could be more delightful. The walls around the rooms are all plastered, and almost every room has carpets on the floor. And the entire house is whitewashed on the outside.
tr: Anyway, I was describing the living room. There were very beautiful curtains on the windows: They were white curtains depicting castles with ivy-covered walls and cattle by the water. There was also an old small piano in the living room; I think there were pans and such inside it. Nothing could be as beautiful as the young ladies singing "The Last Ring Broke" and playing the "Battle of Prague" at this piano. All the walls of the rooms were plastered, most had carpets on the floor, and the exterior of the house was completely painted.
es: Well, as I was saying about the living room, there were some very beautiful curtains on the windows: white, with paintings of castles with ivy all over the walls and cattle going to drink. There was also a small and old piano that sounded like a rattle, and we had a great time when the young ladies sang "The Last Link is Broken" and played "The Battle of Prague" on it. All the rooms had plastered walls and almost all of them had carpets, and the whole house was whitewashed on the outside.

en: It was a double house, and the big open place betwixt them was roofed and floored, and sometimes the table was set there in the middle of the day, and it was a cool, comfortable place. Nothing couldn’t be better. And warn’t the cooking good, and just bushels of it too!
vi: It is a house with two kitchens. The space between the two kitchens is covered and carefully wooden-floored. Sometimes at noon, placing a table there to sit is very cool and very enjoyable. There is nothing better than that. And if the meals are delicious, it would be wonderful, nothing could compare.
tr: This was a two-winged house, and a roof was built over the wide open space in between, with a floor underneath. From time to time, a table was set there for lunch; it was indeed a very cool and comfortable place. Anything better would be a blessing. The food was not only very delicious but also plentiful!
es: It was a double house, and the large open space between the two parts had a roof and was floored; sometimes they would set the table there at noon, and it was a cool and pleasant place. It was the best thing in the world. And on top of that, they cooked very well and there were heaps of everything!

en: CHAPTER XVIII.
vi: Chapter XVIII
tr: Chapter Eighteen
es: Chapter 18

en: Col. Grangerford was a gentleman, you see. He was a gentleman all over; and so was his family. He was well born, as the saying is, and that’s worth as much in a man as it is in a horse, so the Widow Douglas said, and nobody ever denied that she was of the first aristocracy in our town; and pap he always said it, too, though he warn’t no more quality than a mudcat himself. Col. Grangerford was very tall and very slim, and had a darkish-paly complexion, not a sign of red in it anywheres; he was clean shaved every morning all over his thin face, and he had the thinnest kind of lips, and the thinnest kind of nostrils, and a high nose, and heavy eyebrows, and the blackest kind of eyes, sunk so deep back that they seemed like they was looking out of caverns at you, as you may say. His forehead was high, and his hair was black and straight and hung to his shoulders. His hands was long and thin, and every day of his life he put on a clean shirt and a full suit from head to foot made out of linen so white it hurt your eyes to look at it; and on Sundays he wore a blue tail-coat with brass buttons on it. He carried a mahogany cane with a silver head to it. There warn’t no frivolishness about him, not a bit, and he warn’t ever loud. He was as kind as he could be—you could feel that, you know, and so you had confidence. Sometimes he smiled, and it was good to see; but when he straightened himself up like a liberty-pole, and the lightning begun to flicker out from under his eyebrows, you wanted to climb a tree first, and find out what the matter was afterwards. He didn’t ever have to tell anybody to mind their manners—everybody was always good-mannered where he was. Everybody loved to have him around, too; he was sunshine most always—I mean he made it seem like good weather. When he turned into a cloudbank it was awful dark for half a minute, and that was enough; there wouldn’t nothing go wrong again for a week.
vi: Colonel Grangerford was an aristocrat, you see. He was an aristocrat in every way: so was his whole family. He came from a noble background, as people often say, and that is as valuable for a person as it is for a horse; as Widow Douglas used to say, and no one could deny that she was the top aristocrat in the province. My father used to say the same thing, although my father was no more valuable than a stray cat. Colonel Grangerford was tall but slender. He had a dusky, oily complexion, and his whole face lacked any rosy hue. Every morning, he shaved his entire gaunt face smooth. He had the thinnest lips, the smallest nostrils, a prominent nose, bushy eyebrows, the blackest eyes set so deep it seemed as if they were looking at you from a dark cavern, so to speak. His forehead was high, his hair grizzled, straight, and hanging down to his shoulders. His hands were both thin and long. Throughout his life, each day he wore a white undershirt and a suit made entirely of white flannel, dazzling to the eyes. Then on Sundays, he added a blue tailcoat with brass buttons. He carried a peachwood cane with a silver handle. He never appeared careless in the slightest, nor did he ever show anger towards anyone. He tried to be good to everyone, and you could feel that, which made you trust him. Occasionally, he smiled, and it was truly charming. But when he stood up straight like the Statue of Liberty, and a gleam began to shine from beneath his eyebrows, you might want to find a tree to climb up immediately, knowing something was about to happen. He didn't need to tell people to behave - yet wherever he went, everyone was obedient. Everyone liked having him around - he was like sunlight - I mean to say, it was like encountering good weather. When the sun went behind a cloud, it darkened for half a minute, and that was all. Then for about a week, nothing happened at all.
tr: Colonel Grangerford was a true nobleman. He was a gentleman from head to toe; the other members of the family were no less. He came from a noble family, and just as with horses, nobility increases the value of people. Mrs. Douglas used to say this, and no one could deny that she was the head of the aristocracy in our town. My father always said the same thing, but he himself was no more noble than a catfish. Colonel Grangerford was very tall and slender, with a dark-pale complexion that showed not the slightest hint of redness. He shaved every part of his thin face every morning; his lips were very thin, his nostrils were very thin, he had a button nose, thick eyebrows, and his jet-black eyes were so deeply set that one almost thought he was looking out of two caves. His forehead was broad, and his black, straight hair reached down to his shoulders. His hands were long and thin; he wore a clean shirt every day and walked around in a snow-white linen suit; the suit was so white it dazzled the eyes. On Sundays, however, he wore a navy blue frock coat with brass buttons. He carried a mahogany cane with a silver knob. There was not a trace of frivolity in his demeanor, not at all; he was never seen raising his voice. A person could not be more kind-hearted – you felt this and trusted him. Sometimes he would smile, and seeing this smile made one feel very good; but sometimes he would stand as erect as a flagpole symbolizing freedom, and glare so fiercely from under his eyebrows that you felt like climbing a tree first and then asking what the matter was. He never needed to remind anyone of manners – everyone behaved politely in his presence. Moreover, everyone enjoyed having him around; he was almost always sunny – that is, you always felt like the weather was nice when he was around. When he clouded over, however, it would be pitch dark for half a minute, and that was enough; no one would do anything wrong for a week.
es: COLONEL GRANGERFORD was a gentleman, you understand? He was a gentleman in everything, and the same was true of his family. He was of good stock, as they say, and that counts as much in a man as in a horse, as Widow Douglas used to say, and no one denied that she was of the first aristocracy of our town, and father always said it too, although he himself was no better bred than a stray cat. Colonel Grangerford was very tall and thin and had a pale brownish skin, without a single red spot; every morning he shaved his entire face, which was very thin, just like his lips and the nostrils of his nose; he had a very high nose and thick eyebrows and very black eyes, so deep-set that it seemed, as if to say, that he was looking at you from the bottom of a cave. He had a high forehead and gray, straight hair that reached down to his shoulders. He had long, thin hands, and every day he wore a clean shirt and a full linen suit so white it hurt your eyes to look at it, and on Sundays, a blue frock coat with copper buttons. He carried a mahogany cane with a silver knob. He was not at all frivolous, not one bit, and he never shouted. He was very kind and it showed, so you could trust him. Sometimes he smiled and it was a pleasure to see, but when he stood stiff as a flagpole and started shooting lightning from his eyes, you first thought of climbing a tree and then finding out what was going on. He never had to tell anyone to have good manners: where he was, everyone always behaved well. And everyone loved having him around; he was almost always like a ray of sunshine: I mean, with him it seemed like the weather was always good. When he turned into a storm cloud, it darkened for half a minute and that was enough; in a week no one would do anything wrong again.

en: When him and the old lady come down in the morning all the family got up out of their chairs and give them good-day, and didn’t set down again till they had set down. Then Tom and Bob went to the sideboard where the decanter was, and mixed a glass of bitters and handed it to him, and he held it in his hand and waited till Tom’s and Bob’s was mixed, and then they bowed and said, “Our duty to you, sir, and madam;” and they bowed the least bit in the world and said thank you, and so they drank, all three, and Bob and Tom poured a spoonful of water on the sugar and the mite of whisky or apple brandy in the bottom of their tumblers, and give it to me and Buck, and we drank to the old people too.
vi: In the morning, when he and his wife came downstairs, everyone stood up to greet them. Before they came down, no one in the house dared to sit. Then Tom and Bod went to the liquor cabinet, mixed several types of alcohol together, and brought it to him. He took it in his hand, waited for Tom and Bod to finish pouring everything, and after both of them bowed and said: "Please, father and mother," and greeted in every possible way, then expressed their thanks, everyone finally drank together. After that, Tom and Bod poured a spoonful of water into the sugar, added a bit of sugar to the whiskey or brandy at the bottom of the glass, handed it to me and Buck, and then it was our turn to drink and toast the couple as well.
tr: When the Colonel and the matron came downstairs in the morning, the whole family would stand up and greet them with a good morning, and they would not sit down until the Colonel and the matron were settled. Then Tom and Bob would go to the sideboard where the pitcher was, pour a drink made from herbs and roots, and hand it to him. Colonel Grangerford would wait with his hand in the air until Tom and Bob had prepared their own drinks. Then the young men would bow and say, "Respectfully, sir and madam," to which the elders would respond with a slight nod and a thank you. Then all three of them would down their drinks. Afterwards, Bob and Tom would pour a little whiskey or apple brandy over the sugar at the bottom of their glasses, add a spoonful of water, and hand the glasses to Buck and me. We would drink to the health of the elders. The biggest was Bob, and Tom was one size smaller than him.
es: When he and the elderly lady came down in the morning, the whole family would rise from their chairs to greet them and would not sit down again until they had taken their seats. Then Tom and Bob would go to the sideboard where the glass jar was kept and pour a glass of herbal liqueur and give it to him, and he would hold the glass in his hand, waiting until Tom and Bob served themselves, and they would bow and say, "To your health, sir and madam," and they would also bow slightly and thank them and the three of them would drink, and Tom and Bob would pour a spoonful of water into the sugar and the little bit of whiskey or apple liqueur left at the bottom of their glasses and give it to Buck and me, and we would also drink to the health of the elders.

en: Bob was the oldest and Tom next—tall, beautiful men with very broad shoulders and brown faces, and long black hair and black eyes. They dressed in white linen from head to foot, like the old gentleman, and wore broad Panama hats.
vi: Bob is the eldest. Then comes Tom, both of them tall, handsome, broad-shouldered, with tanned faces, black long hair, and black eyes as well. Both of them wore white woolen clothes, from head to toe, just like that upper-class old man, and wide-brimmed straw hats.
tr: They were broad-shouldered, dark-faced, tall men; they had long black hair and jet-black eyes. Just like the big boss, they would dress in white linen from head to toe and wear wide-brimmed straw hats.
es: Bob was the eldest and then came Tom: two tall and handsome men with very broad shoulders and weathered faces, long black hair, and black eyes. They were dressed in white linen from head to toe, just like the elderly gentleman, and wore wide Panama hats.

en: Then there was Miss Charlotte; she was twenty-five, and tall and proud and grand, but as good as she could be when she warn’t stirred up; but when she was, she had a look that would make you wilt in your tracks, like her father. She was beautiful.
vi: Then it was Charlotte's turn. She was twenty-five years old, tall, and proud; whenever she wasn't losing her temper, she tried to be kind. But when she did lose her temper, she could make you tremble in your boots, just like her father. She was quite beautiful.
tr: Then came Miss Charlotte; she was twenty-five years old, tall, proud, and magnificent, but extremely kind when not provoked; when she was angry, just like her father, she would give such a look that it would make your knees buckle. She was a beautiful girl.
es: Then came Miss Charlotte; she was twenty-five years old and was tall, proud, and stunning, but very kind when she wasn't angry; although when she was, she would give looks that left one frozen, just like her father. She was very beautiful.

en: So was her sister, Miss Sophia, but it was a different kind. She was gentle and sweet like a dove, and she was only twenty.
vi: As for her younger sister, Sophia, she was completely different from her. She was very gentle and as pleasant as a dove. She was only twenty years old.
tr: Her sister Miss Sophia was also beautiful, but she had a different kind of beauty. She was gentle and sweet like a dove; she was only twenty.
es: His sister, Miss Sophia, was also the same, but of a different type. She was calm and peaceful like a dove, and she was only twenty years old.

en: Each person had their own nigger to wait on them—Buck too. My nigger had a monstrous easy time, because I warn’t used to having anybody do anything for me, but Buck’s was on the jump most of the time.
vi: Each person in the house had their own black servant. Even young Buck had one. The black servant they assigned to me had plenty of free time, because I never wanted anyone to do anything for me. But young Buck was always ordering people around, yelling all the time.
tr: Everyone had a black servant who took care of them – Buck had one too. My black servant had it easy, really, because I wasn't used to having someone else do things for me, whereas Buck's black servant was working hard.
es: Each person had their own black servant, and Buck did too. My black servant had a great time because I wasn't used to having anyone do things for me, but Buck's spent his time running around.

en: This was all there was of the family now, but there used to be more—three sons; they got killed; and Emmeline that died.
vi: Those are all the people present in the family. There should have been more, but the three eldest sons were all killed, and Miss Emmeline has also passed away.
tr: This was all that was left of the family now; there used to be more – three more sons; but they had been killed and Emmeline had died on her own.
es: That was the family that remained, but before there were more: three children who had been killed and Emmeline, who had died.

en: The old gentleman owned a lot of farms and over a hundred niggers. Sometimes a stack of people would come there, horseback, from ten or fifteen mile around, and stay five or six days, and have such junketings round about and on the river, and dances and picnics in the woods daytimes, and balls at the house nights. These people was mostly kinfolks of the family. The men brought their guns with them. It was a handsome lot of quality, I tell you.
vi: This upper-class old man has several farms with over a hundred black people working. Occasionally, a group of people would come there, riding horses from a place ten to fifteen miles away. They would stay for five or six days, eating and drinking abundantly on the river or around the house, dancing, and frolicking in the woods during the day. Then at night, they would come into the house and dance again. Most of these people were relatives of the family. They also brought guns with them. And it must be said that these were all high-quality and beautiful guns.
tr: The old gentleman had many farms and a hundred black slaves. Sometimes people would come in groups on horseback from ten or fifteen miles away and stay for five or six days; they would have fun around the house and the river, dance, have picnics in the forest during the day, and hold festivities at the house in the evening. Most of these people were relatives of the family. The men would bring their rifles with them. It was quite a distinguished crowd, indeed.
es: The elderly gentleman had a lot of farms and more than a hundred slaves. Sometimes a bunch of people would arrive on horseback, from ten or fifteen miles around, and they would stay for five or six days, spending the whole time having fun in the river or nearby, with dances and picnics in the woods during the day and dances in the house at night. Almost all of them were relatives of the family. The men arrived with their weapons. I assure you that those were distinguished people.

en: There was another clan of aristocracy around there—five or six families—mostly of the name of Shepherdson. They was as high-toned and well born and rich and grand as the tribe of Grangerfords. The Shepherdsons and Grangerfords used the same steamboat landing, which was about two mile above our house; so sometimes when I went up there with a lot of our folks I used to see a lot of the Shepherdsons there on their fine horses.
vi: There was another noble family nearby, about five or six families mostly bearing the surname Shepherdsons. They were also renowned, also of noble lineage, wealthy, and as grand as the Grangerfords, all sharing a steamboat landing about two miles from our house. Occasionally, I would go there with some people from this house, and often saw a group of Shepherdsons riding very beautiful horses passing by.
tr: There was another aristocratic family in the vicinity – they consisted of five or six families, and most of their last names were Shepherdson. They were also noble, wealthy, and magnificent like the Grangerford clan. The Shepherdsons and the Grangerfords used the same steamboat landing about two miles upstream from our house; so when I went there with a bunch of our people, I would see a lot of Shepherdsons on their fine horses.
es: Nearby there was another clan of aristocrats—five or six families—almost all of them called Shepherdson. They were of as good a lineage and as refined, rich, and grand as the Grangerford tribe. The Shepherdson and the Grangerford used the same dock, which was about two miles upstream from our house, so sometimes when I went there with many of ours, I would see a bunch of Shepherdson who had already arrived with their thoroughbred horses.

en: One day Buck and me was away out in the woods hunting, and heard a horse coming. We was crossing the road. Buck says:
vi: One day Buck and I went into the forest to hunt, when suddenly we heard the sound of a horse approaching. We were crossing the road when Buck said:
tr: One day, while Buck and I were hunting in the forest, we heard a horse approaching. It would pass by the road shortly. “Quick, quick!
es: One day Buck and I were in the hunting woods and we heard a horse approaching. We were crossing the path, and Buck goes and shouts:

en: “Quick! Jump for the woods!”
vi: - Quickly, jump into the forest!
tr: “Quick, quick! Let's hide behind the trees!” said Buck.
es: —Quick! Run through the trees!

en: We done it, and then peeped down the woods through the leaves. Pretty soon a splendid young man come galloping down the road, setting his horse easy and looking like a soldier. He had his gun across his pommel. I had seen him before. It was young Harney Shepherdson. I heard Buck’s gun go off at my ear, and Harney’s hat tumbled off from his head. He grabbed his gun and rode straight to the place where we was hid. But we didn’t wait. We started through the woods on a run. The woods warn’t thick, so I looked over my shoulder to dodge the bullet, and twice I seen Harney cover Buck with his gun; and then he rode away the way he come—to get his hat, I reckon, but I couldn’t see. We never stopped running till we got home. The old gentleman’s eyes blazed a minute—’twas pleasure, mainly, I judged—then his face sort of smoothed down, and he says, kind of gentle:
vi: We jumped into the forest, hiding in the bushes and peering through the leaves outside. A moment later, a young, handsome man rode a horse in this direction, sitting firmly on the horse like a skilled cavalryman. He had a gun strapped to the front of his saddle. I had met him once before. It was Harney Shepherdsons. Suddenly, a gunshot from Buck whizzed past my ear, and Harney's hat flew off his head. He quickly grabbed his gun and charged his horse towards the source of the shot. But we didn't wait. We leaped through the forest and ran away. The forest wasn't very dense, so I could run while glancing back to avoid bullets. Twice I saw Harney aim his gun at Buck but then he lost sight of him. We ran straight back home. The old gentleman looked at us, his eyes brightening a bit, seemingly pleased, I guessed. But then his face fell, and he spoke in a gentle tone:
tr: We immediately hid and started observing the road through the leaves. Soon, a majestic young man galloping at full speed appeared at the end of the road. He looked very comfortable on the horse and resembled a soldier. He had placed his rifle on the saddle horn. I had seen him before. It was young Harney Shepherdson. Buck's rifle went off right next to my ear, and Harney's hat flew off his head. He immediately grabbed his weapon and headed towards where we were hiding. But we didn't stop to wait at all. We immediately started running through the forest. The forest wasn't very dense, so I kept turning and looking back over my shoulder to dodge the bullets. Twice I saw Buck right in Harney's line of fire. Then Harney turned back, probably to get his hat; I couldn't see that part very well. But we kept running until we reached home. When he heard what happened, sparks flashed in the old gentleman's eyes – it was essentially out of joy, as far as I could tell – but then his face fell, and he slowly said:
es: We started running and then looked through the leaves of the trees. Soon a splendid young man arrived, galloping down the road, very steady in the saddle and with a soldierly air. He carried the shotgun crossed over the pommel of the saddle. I had seen him before. He was young Harney Shepherdson. I heard Buck fire the shotgun next to my ear and Harney's hat fell off his head. He grabbed his weapon and headed straight to where we were hiding. But we didn't wait. We ran into the forest. The forest wasn't very dense, so I looked over my shoulder in case he fired, and twice I saw Harney aiming at Buck with the shotgun and then turning around, I suppose to pick up the hat, but I couldn't see him. We didn't stop running until we got home. The old man's eyes flashed for a minute —I think mostly with pleasure— and then he softened his expression a bit and said in a kind voice:

en: “I don’t like that shooting from behind a bush. Why didn’t you step into the road, my boy?”
vi: - I don't like the way you shoot from the bushes like that. Why don't you stand in the middle of the road and shoot?
tr: “I didn't like you shooting from among the trees. Why didn't you come out directly to the road, my child?”
es: —I don't like that you shot from behind a tree. Why didn't you come out to the road, son?

en: “The Shepherdsons don’t, father. They always take advantage.”
vi: -The Shepherdsons are the same, Dad. They always look for an advantageous position.
tr: "But the Shepherdsons aren't coming out either, father. They are always laying ambushes for us."
es: —The Shepherdsons don't do it, father. They always take advantage.

en: Miss Charlotte she held her head up like a queen while Buck was telling his tale, and her nostrils spread and her eyes snapped. The two young men looked dark, but never said nothing. Miss Sophia she turned pale, but the color come back when she found the man warn’t hurt.
vi: Miss Charlotte listened to Buck recount the story, raising her head like a queen, her nostrils flaring and her eyes twinkling. The two sons had darkened expressions but said nothing. Miss Sophia turned pale, but when she heard that the other person was not hit, she returned to her usual self.
tr: As Buck was telling his story, Mrs. Charlotte straightened her neck like a queen; her nostrils flared and her eyes sparkled. The faces of the two young men fell, but they didn't say a word. Mrs. Sophia, on the other hand, turned pale for a moment, but then the color returned to her face when she heard that the man was unharmed.
es: Miss Charlotte had kept her head high like a queen while Buck told his story, with her nostrils flaring, and now she blinked. The two younger men had a somber air, but they said nothing. Miss Sophia turned pale, but regained her color when she learned that the man was not injured.

en: Soon as I could get Buck down by the corn-cribs under the trees by ourselves, I says:
vi: Later, I took Buck down to the mill, sat under the shade of a tree, and had a private conversation. I asked:
tr: When we arrived under the trees by the granary, I asked:
es: As soon as I could take Buck to where the corn was stored and we were alone under the trees, I asked him:

en: “Did you want to kill him, Buck?”
vi: - At that moment, were you really planning to kill him? Buck?
tr: "Did you want to kill him, Buck?"
es: —Did you want to kill him, Buck?

en: “Well, I bet I did.”
vi: - Are you really sure?
tr: “Of course I wanted to.”
es: —Man, of course.

en: “What did he do to you?”
vi: - So what did it do to you?
tr: “What did he do to you?”
es: —What had he/she done to you?

en: “Him? He never done nothing to me.”
vi: - It? It has never done anything to me.
tr: “Is it him? He hadn't done anything to me?”
es: —Him? He has never done anything to me.

en: “Well, then, what did you want to kill him for?”
vi: - Uh, so why do you intend to kill it?
tr: “But then why do you want to kill him?”
es: —Well, then, Buck, why did you want to kill him?

en: “Why, nothing—only it’s on account of the feud.”
vi: - Uh, so why do you intend to kill it?
tr: "Just... because of a blood feud."
es: —Well, it's nothing, it's just for the blood revenge.

en: “What’s a feud?”
vi: - What is a plantation?
tr: “What is a blood feud?”
es: —What is a blood feud?

en: “Why, where was you raised? Don’t you know what a feud is?”
vi: - Oh my, where did you grow up that you don't know what a plantation is?
tr: "Where did you grow up, my brother? How do you not know about blood feuds?"
es: —But where were you raised? Don't you know what a blood feud is?

en: “Never heard of it before—tell me about it.”
vi: - I've never heard of that before. Try telling me about it.
tr: “I had never heard it before... Tell me about it.”
es: —I had never heard of that... tell me what it is.

en: “Well,” says Buck, “a feud is this way. A man has a quarrel with another man, and kills him; then that other man’s brother kills him; then the other brothers, on both sides, goes for one another; then the cousins chip in—and by-and-by everybody’s killed off, and there ain’t no more feud. But it’s kind of slow, and takes a long time.”
vi: Buck said - This is how it is, a plantation is like this: One person has a conflict with another person, then kills them. Then the siblings of the person who was killed take revenge. Then the siblings of this person kill the other person. Both sides keep killing each other like that endlessly. Eventually, even their relatives get involved, and gradually everyone gets killed, so there is no more plantation. But that is a long story.
tr: “Alright,” said Buck, “a blood feud is something like this: A man fights with another man, kills him in the fight; then the dead man's brother comes and kills him; then the brothers from both sides start killing each other; then the cousins get involved – in the end, everyone dies and the blood feud ends like that. But it is a slow thing; it takes a very long time.”
es: —Well —said Buck—, a blood feud is something like this: a man fights with another and kills him, then the brother of the other man kills him; after that, the other brothers from each family start looking for each other, then the cousins get involved and after a while everyone is dead and the blood feud is over. But it's very slow and takes a lot of time.

en: “Has this one been going on long, Buck?”
vi: - So, how long has this been going on, Buck?
tr: “So, how long has this blood feud been going on; Buck?”
es: —And has this been going on for a long time, Buck?

en: “Well, I should reckon! It started thirty year ago, or som’ers along there. There was trouble ’bout something, and then a lawsuit to settle it; and the suit went agin one of the men, and so he up and shot the man that won the suit—which he would naturally do, of course. Anybody would.”
vi: - Yeah, I think it's probably been a long time. It's been thirty years now, or maybe even more. There was some complicated matter, then there was some lawsuit that needed to be resolved, and the court sentenced one of the people involved. So this person stood up and shot the one who was sued, and that was natural, anyone would do that.
tr: “I know as much as they told me! It started some thirty years ago or so. When an issue arose, they went to court; the case was decided against one of the men, so he got up and shot the man who won the case – naturally, that's what he would do. Everyone would do the same.”
es: —Of course! It started about thirty years ago or so. There was a fight over something and then a lawsuit to resolve it, and one of the men won the lawsuit, so the other went and killed the one who had won it, which is naturally what he had to do, of course. What anyone would do.

en: “What was the trouble about, Buck?—land?”
vi: - What's the trouble, Buck? Is it the land?
tr: “So what was the issue about, Buck?.. Was it a land matter?”
es: —And, what was the problem, Buck? Was it about land?

en: “I reckon maybe—I don’t know.”
vi: - Maybe so, I don't really know either
tr: “Maybe it is so… I don't know for sure.”
es: —I suppose it would be... I don't know.

en: “Well, who done the shooting? Was it a Grangerford or a Shepherdson?”
vi: - So, who shot at that time? Someone from my family found out.
tr: “So, who pulled the trigger? Was it Grangerford or Shepherdson?”
es: —Well, who killed whom? Was it a Grangerford or a Shepherdson?

en: “Laws, how do I know? It was so long ago.”
vi: Someone from my family found out. It was a long time ago.
tr: “Oh come on, how should I know that? It happened a very long time ago.”
es: —How the hell am I supposed to know? It was a long time ago.

en: “Don’t anybody know?”
vi: - So no one knows?
tr: “Is there anyone who knows?”
es: —Doesn't anyone know?

en: “Oh, yes, pa knows, I reckon, and some of the other old people; but they don’t know now what the row was about in the first place.”
vi: - Oh, yes, my father knows, I'm sure of it, and the people in this house know too. But now they don't know how the fight started from the beginning.
tr: “Yes, my father probably knows, some of the elders surely know; but none of them remember what the initial problem was about.”
es: —Ah, yes, father knows, I suppose, and some of the other old folks; but they no longer know why the first fight happened.

en: “Has there been many killed, Buck?”
vi: - Have many people been killed yet, Buck?
tr: "Were many people killed, Buck?"
es: —Have there been many deaths, Buck?

en: “Yes; right smart chance of funerals. But they don’t always kill. Pa’s got a few buckshot in him; but he don’t mind it ’cuz he don’t weigh much, anyway. Bob’s been carved up some with a bowie, and Tom’s been hurt once or twice.”
vi: - Yes, many times we almost had to hold a funeral. But it's not always possible to shoot him dead. My father also has a few bullets in him, but he doesn't mind, because they are just small bullets. Bod was stabbed with a hunting knife, and Tom has also been shot a few times.
tr: “Yes… Quite a few funerals have been held, to be honest. Though it doesn’t always end in death. My father has a few pellets in his body; but he never minds them, they aren’t very serious anyway. Bob was stabbed and Tom also has a couple of wounds.”
es: —Yes; there have been many funerals. But they don't always kill. Father has some shrapnel inside, but he doesn't mind because it doesn't weigh much anyway. Bob has one or two hunting knife cuts and Tom has been wounded once or twice.

en: “Has anybody been killed this year, Buck?”
vi: - So, did anyone get killed this year, Buck?
tr: "Has anyone been killed this year?"
es: —Has anyone died yet this year, Buck?

en: “Yes; we got one and they got one. ’Bout three months ago my cousin Bud, fourteen year old, was riding through the woods on t’other side of the river, and didn’t have no weapon with him, which was blame’ foolishness, and in a lonesome place he hears a horse a-coming behind him, and sees old Baldy Shepherdson a-linkin’ after him with his gun in his hand and his white hair a-flying in the wind; and ’stead of jumping off and taking to the brush, Bud ’lowed he could out-run him; so they had it, nip and tuck, for five mile or more, the old man a-gaining all the time; so at last Bud seen it warn’t any use, so he stopped and faced around so as to have the bullet holes in front, you know, and the old man he rode up and shot him down. But he didn’t git much chance to enjoy his luck, for inside of a week our folks laid him out.”
vi: - Yes, on our side we killed one person, and on their side, they also killed one person. About three months ago, my cousin Bud, who was only fourteen years old, was riding a horse in the forest across the river. He didn't carry any weapons with him, which was so foolish. While he was in a deserted spot, he heard the sound of a horse behind him. Turning around, he saw old Baldy Shepherdson chasing him, holding a gun, with his white hair blowing in the wind. Instead of jumping aside and running into the forest, Bud just kept riding his horse forward. So the two of them kept chasing each other for more than five miles. The old man kept trying to get ahead but couldn't. Finally, Bud saw that it was useless, so he stopped his horse so that if he had to take a bullet, it would be from the front, you understand.
