So the old man got ahead and shot him dead. But then the old man wasn't lucky for long, because within a week, the people from our side sent him to his maker.
tr: “Yes, one from us, one from them. About three months ago, my fourteen-year-old cousin Bud was crossing the forest on the other side of the river on horseback. The damn fool didn’t even take a weapon with him. In a desolate place, he heard a horse coming from behind and when he looked back, he realized that old Baldy Shepherdson, with his white hair flying in the wind, was chasing him with a rifle in his hand; instead of dismounting and hiding in the bushes, he spurred his horse, calculating that he could escape; they started going like this, for about five miles, but the old man was getting closer; finally, Bud was desperate and, thinking he might as well take the bullet from the front, stopped and turned his horse around. The old man caught up with him and shot him from behind. But he didn’t get a chance to rejoice in his fate, because within a week, our folks took care of him too.”
es: —Yes; we scored one and they scored another. About three months ago my cousin Bud, who was fourteen years old. He was going through the forest on the other side of the river and he wasn't carrying any weapons, which is foolish, and when he was in a lonely place he heard a horse coming from behind and saw old Baldy Shepherdson chasing him with a shotgun in his hand and his white hair flowing in the wind, and instead of jumping off the horse and running, Bud thought he could go faster, so the chase continued for five miles or more and the old man was gaining more ground each time; finally Bud saw that it wasn't worth it and he stopped and faced him so the wounds would be from the front, you know, and the old man caught up to him and killed him. But he didn't have much time to enjoy his luck, because in less than a week ours killed him.

en: “I reckon that old man was a coward, Buck.”
vi: - I made that old man a coward, Buck
tr: “That old man was a coward, Buck.”
es: —For me, that old man was a coward, Buck.

en: “I reckon he warn’t a coward. Not by a blame’ sight. There ain’t a coward amongst them Shepherdsons—not a one. And there ain’t no cowards amongst the Grangerfords either. Why, that old man kep’ up his end in a fight one day for half an hour against three Grangerfords, and come out winner. They was all a-horseback; he lit off of his horse and got behind a little woodpile, and kep’ his horse before him to stop the bullets; but the Grangerfords stayed on their horses and capered around the old man, and peppered away at him, and he peppered away at them. Him and his horse both went home pretty leaky and crippled, but the Grangerfords had to be fetched home—and one of ’em was dead, and another died the next day. No, sir; if a body’s out hunting for cowards he don’t want to fool away any time amongst them Shepherdsons, becuz they don’t breed any of that kind.”
vi: - No, he's not a coward. Just look at him and you'll know. Among the Shepherdsons, there's no one who's cowardly. And in the Grangerford family, there's no one who's cowardly either. You know, one day that old man fought against four Grangerford men for half an hour and in the end, he won the battle. They were all on horseback, he jumped off his horse and hid behind a pile of wood, using his horse as a shield. The Grangerford men stayed on their horses, surrounding him and aiming to shoot. He shot back at them too. After that, both he and his horse managed to get home, covered in blood, limping; but the Grangerford men had to be carried back. One died immediately, and another died the next day. No, sir, if the battlefield were filled with cowards, they would never dare to confront the Grangerfords; and no one would keep such people around either.
tr: “No, brother, I don't think he was a coward at all. No one can say that about him. There are no cowards among the Shepherdsons – not a single one. There are no cowards among the Grangerfords either. That old man fought three Grangerfords for half an hour in a skirmish and won. They were all on horseback; the old man got off his horse and took cover behind a small pile of wood, using his horse as a shield against the bullets; but the Grangerfords stayed on their horses and circled around him, shooting at him, and he fired back. Both he and his horse returned bleeding and injured, but the Grangerfords had to be carried home on stretchers – one of them was dead and the other died the next day. No sir, if you're looking for a coward, I say don't waste any time trying to find one among the Shepherdsons, because you'll never find a coward or a weakling among them.”
es: —Well, to me he wasn't a coward. Not at all. There isn't a single Shepherdson who is a coward; not one. And there isn't a single Grangerford who is a coward either. But once that old man held his own in a half-hour fight against three Grangerfords and he won. They were all on horseback; he dismounted and took cover behind some wood and put his horse in front so the bullets would hit it instead of him; but the Grangerfords kept circling the old man on horseback, shooting at him and he shooting back at them. He and his horse came home pretty banged up and full of holes, but the Grangerfords had to be carried home, one of them dead, and another died the next day. No, sir; if anyone is looking for cowards, they shouldn't waste their time with the Shepherdsons, because they don't breed those.

en: Next Sunday we all went to church, about three mile, everybody a-horseback. The men took their guns along, so did Buck, and kept them between their knees or stood them handy against the wall. The Shepherdsons done the same. It was pretty ornery preaching—all about brotherly love, and such-like tiresomeness; but everybody said it was a good sermon, and they all talked it over going home, and had such a powerful lot to say about faith and good works and free grace and preforeordestination, and I don’t know what all, that it did seem to me to be one of the roughest Sundays I had run across yet.
vi: That Sunday, we went to church, which was about three or five miles from home. Everyone went on horseback. Each person carried a gun, including Buck. Buck kept his gun on his thigh or leaned it against the wall within arm's reach. But the Shepherdsons did the same. It was really just outward prayer, talking about loving each other like brothers, and other phrases like that, which made me sick to hear, but then everyone said that praying like that was very good, and even on the way back home, they kept saying the same, talking a lot about loyalty, goodness, and other things I didn't even understand. And I felt that this was one of the most boring Sundays I had ever experienced.
tr: Next Sunday, we all rode horses to the church about three miles away. The men took their rifles with them, and Buck went with his gun too. They all kept their rifles between their knees or leaned them against the wall nearby. The Shepherdsons did the same thing. The sermon was quite ordinary – the preacher kept talking about brotherly love and such, but everyone liked the sermon. On the way home, the sermon was discussed; everyone had a lot to say about faith, doing good deeds, grace, predestination by God, and many other topics. It felt like one of the hardest Sundays I had ever spent.
es: The following Sunday we all went to church, about three miles away, all on horseback. The men took their shotguns, and Buck did too, and they kept them between their knees or left them handy leaning against the wall. The Shepherdsons did the same: it was a most ordinary sermon: all about brotherly love and nonsense like that; but everyone said it was a good sermon and talked about it on the way back, and they had so much to say about faith and good works and sanctifying grace and predestination and I don't know what else that it seemed to me one of the worst Sundays of my life.

en: About an hour after dinner everybody was dozing around, some in their chairs and some in their rooms, and it got to be pretty dull. Buck and a dog was stretched out on the grass in the sun sound asleep. I went up to our room, and judged I would take a nap myself. I found that sweet Miss Sophia standing in her door, which was next to ours, and she took me in her room and shut the door very soft, and asked me if I liked her, and I said I did; and she asked me if I would do something for her and not tell anybody, and I said I would. Then she said she’d forgot her Testament, and left it in the seat at church between two other books, and would I slip out quiet and go there and fetch it to her, and not say nothing to nobody. I said I would. So I slid out and slipped off up the road, and there warn’t anybody at the church, except maybe a hog or two, for there warn’t any lock on the door, and hogs likes a puncheon floor in summer-time because it’s cool. If you notice, most folks don’t go to church only when they’ve got to; but a hog is different.
vi: About an hour after lunch, everyone dispersed. Some sat on chairs, some went to their private rooms, and the atmosphere was really dull. Buck, with a dog, lay sprawled on the porch sleeping under the sun. I also went up to my room and thought I should take a nap. Teacher Sophia, kind-hearted, was standing at the door next to our room. She pulled me into her private room, gently closed the door, and asked if I liked her. I said I did. She asked me to do her a favor and not to tell anyone. I said okay. Then she said she had left the Bible on the church bench along with two other books, and asked me to quietly go out and fetch them for her; and remember not to tell anyone. I said okay, I'll go get them for you. I sneaked out of the house and ran straight there. There was no one in the church, maybe just a few pigs. Because the church door was not closed, and in the summer, pigs liked the high wooden floor in the church, which was cooler. If you pay attention, you'll see; many people only stop going to church when they absolutely can't, but pigs are different.
tr: About an hour after the meal, while some were dozing in their armchairs and others in their rooms, I felt a deep sense of boredom. Buck and a dog had sprawled out on the grass under the sun and had fallen into a deep sleep. I decided to go up to our room and take a nap. I saw sweet Miss Sophia at the door of her room, which was right next to ours; she took me into her room and, after very slowly closing the door, asked if I liked her. Of course, I did; if that was the case, could I do something for her and keep my mouth shut? Of course, I could. Then she said she had forgotten her Holy Bible, which was left between two other books at the place where she sat in church. She wanted me to go there quietly, retrieve the book, and bring it to her without telling anyone. I said I would go and get the book. I slipped out quietly and set off. There was no one left in the church, only a couple of pigs, because there was no lock on the door and pigs like to lie on the wooden floor in the summer because it's cool. If you notice, people don't go to church unless they have to, but pigs are not like that.
es: About an hour after eating, everyone was taking a nap, some in their chairs and others in their rooms, and it was all very boring. Buck and a dog were lying on the grass in the sun, sleeping like logs. I went up to our room thinking about taking a nap too. I saw the lovely Miss Sophia standing at her door, which was next to ours, and she made me come into her room, closed the door quietly and asked me if I loved her, and I answered yes, and she asked me if I would do her a favor without telling anyone and I said yes. Then she told me that she had forgotten the New Testament and had left it on the church pew between two other books, and if I would quietly go out and fetch it for her without telling anyone. I said yes. So I quietly walked down the path and in the church there was no one, except maybe a pig or two, because the door had no lock and pigs like the packed dirt floors in summer, because they are cool. If you notice, almost no one goes to church except when it's mandatory, but pigs are different.

en: Says I to myself, something’s up; it ain’t natural for a girl to be in such a sweat about a Testament. So I give it a shake, and out drops a little piece of paper with “Half-past two” wrote on it with a pencil. I ransacked it, but couldn’t find anything else. I couldn’t make anything out of that, so I put the paper in the book again, and when I got home and upstairs there was Miss Sophia in her door waiting for me. She pulled me in and shut the door; then she looked in the Testament till she found the paper, and as soon as she read it she looked glad; and before a body could think she grabbed me and give me a squeeze, and said I was the best boy in the world, and not to tell anybody. She was mighty red in the face for a minute, and her eyes lighted up, and it made her powerful pretty. I was a good deal astonished, but when I got my breath I asked her what the paper was about, and she asked me if I had read it, and I said no, and she asked me if I could read writing, and I told her “no, only coarse-hand,” and then she said the paper warn’t anything but a book-mark to keep her place, and I might go and play now.
vi: I told myself that there must be something going on. A girl getting all worked up about forgetting a Bible like this is not natural. I shook the book, and a small piece of paper with pencil writing fell out, reading "Two thirty." I searched again, but found nothing else. I couldn't figure out what it was, so I put the piece of paper back. When I returned home, I went upstairs and saw Sophia still waiting for me at the door. She pulled me in, closed the door, then found the piece of paper in the book, and after reading it, she seemed delighted. Suddenly, before I could think of anything, she grabbed my hand and told me I was the best boy in the world, and asked me not to tell anyone. She blushed for a moment, her eyes brightened, and at that moment, she looked incredibly beautiful. I was surprised, but after calming down, I asked what the piece of paper was about. She asked if I had read the writing, I said no, I had just started learning to write, and she said that the piece of paper was just a bookmark for where she had left off reading, then told me I could go outside and play.
tr: I had realized something was going on – it wasn't natural for a girl to get so worked up over a Holy Bible; when I shook the book, a small piece of paper fell out. On the paper, written in pencil, were the words "half past two." I thoroughly flipped through the book, but found nothing else. I didn't understand anything, so I put the paper back into the book; when I reached home and climbed the stairs, I saw Sophia waiting for me at the door. She immediately pulled me inside and closed the door; then she started flipping through the Holy Bible and was delighted when she found the paper; before I could say anything, she hugged me tightly and said I was the best kid in the world, then reminded me again not to tell anyone. For a moment, she turned bright red and her eyes sparkled, truthfully, she had become very beautiful. I was all flustered, but then managed to catch my breath and asked what was written on the paper. She then asked me if I had read what was written on the paper, I said no, and then she asked if I could read handwriting, I said I could only read newspaper print; she then said there was nothing important on the paper, that she had just put it in the book to keep the page, and that I could go play now.
es: I said to myself: "Something's up; it's not natural for a girl to be so concerned about a New Testament," so I shook it and a small piece of paper with a pencil-written note fell out: "At half-past two." I kept looking but didn't find anything else. That didn't tell me anything, so I put the paper back in the book and when I got home and went up the stairs, Miss Sophia was at her door waiting for me. She made me come in and closed the door; then she searched the New Testament until she found the paper, and as soon as she read it, she seemed very happy; and before one could realize it, she grabbed me and gave me a hug saying that I was the best boy in the world and that I shouldn't tell anyone. Her face turned very red for a moment, her eyes lit up, and she looked very pretty. I was very astonished, but when I caught my breath, I asked her what the paper said, and she asked if I had read it, and when I said no, she asked if I knew how to read manuscripts and I replied that I could only read print, and then she said that the paper was just to mark how far she had read and that I could go play now.

en: I went off down to the river, studying over this thing, and pretty soon I noticed that my nigger was following along behind. When we was out of sight of the house he looked back and around a second, and then comes a-running, and says:
vi: I went down to the riverbank, thinking about this matter. Suddenly, I saw my black friend following behind. When we reached a hidden spot out of sight from the house, he turned back for a second, then ran to me and said:
tr: As I was thinking about this issue and heading towards the river, I realized that my black man had followed me. Once the house was out of sight, he looked around for a moment, then ran up to me and said:
es: I went down to the river thinking about all that, and right away I realized that my black man was following me. When we lost sight of the house, he looked back and all around for a second, and then he came running and said to me:

en: “Mars Jawge, if you’ll come down into de swamp I’ll show you a whole stack o’ water-moccasins.”
vi: - George, if you go down to the pond over there, I'll show you a bunch of otters.
tr: "Master Geooge, you come with me to the swamp, I show you a very poisonous snake.""
es: —George, if you come to the swamp, I'll show you a bunch of water snakes.

en: Thinks I, that’s mighty curious; he said that yesterday. He oughter know a body don’t love water-moccasins enough to go around hunting for them. What is he up to, anyway? So I says:
vi: I thought to myself, how strange, he mentioned that yesterday. He also knows that no one really likes otters and no one hunts them either. But why did he say that? I asked;
tr: This was very strange, because he had said the same thing yesterday. He should have understood that I wasn't curious enough about poisonous snakes to go looking for them. I wonder what his true intention was? “Okay, let's go,” I said.
es: It seemed very curious to me; he had said the same thing yesterday. He had to know that one doesn't like water snakes enough to go see them. What could he be looking for? So I said to him:

en: “All right; trot ahead.”
vi: - Alright, you go ahead
tr: “Okay, let's go,” I said.
es: —Alright; you go ahead.

en: I followed a half a mile; then he struck out over the swamp, and waded ankle deep as much as another half-mile. We come to a little flat piece of land which was dry and very thick with trees and bushes and vines, and he says:
vi: I followed him for half a mile, then turned towards the pond, having to wade through ankle-deep water for another half mile: we reached a flat area that was both high and dry, with many trees, bushes, and even some grass. He said:
tr: I followed him for about half a mile, then we entered the swamp and walked for another half mile through water that reached our ankles. He led me to a small clearing covered with dry and dense trees and bushes.
es: I followed him for half a mile; then he reached the swamp and waded through it with water up to his ankles for another half mile. We arrived at a piece of flat, dry land, full of trees, bushes, and ivy, and he said to me:

en: “You shove right in dah jist a few steps, Mars Jawge; dah’s whah dey is. I’s seed ’m befo’; I don’t k’yer to see ’em no mo’.”
vi: - George, please step a few steps further inside. It's in there. I've seen it before, I don't need to look again now.
tr: “Just go that way, taking a few steps is enough, Master George, it's all there, I've seen it before, even if I haven't seen it alone.”
es: —Take a few steps in there, George; that's where they are. I've already seen enough of them.

en: Then he slopped right along and went away, and pretty soon the trees hid him. I poked into the place a-ways and come to a little open patch as big as a bedroom all hung around with vines, and found a man laying there asleep—and, by jings, it was my old Jim!
vi: After speaking, he immediately ran away and disappeared behind a cluster of trees. I stepped inside, to an open space about the size of a room, surrounded by grape leaves, and suddenly saw someone sleeping there. Oh my God, it turned out to be my Jim!
tr: Then he continued on his way and moved away, and a little later he disappeared behind the trees. When I proceeded to the place he mentioned, I discovered a clearing the size of a bedroom, completely surrounded by bushes and vines, where a man was sleeping – guess who it was, none other than our big Jim!
es: Then he moved away and was immediately covered by the trees. I wandered around there until I reached an open spot, about the size of a bedroom, all surrounded by ivy, and there I saw a man who was asleep; and by all the devils, it was my old Jim!

en: I waked him up, and I reckoned it was going to be a grand surprise to him to see me again, but it warn’t. He nearly cried he was so glad, but he warn’t surprised. Said he swum along behind me that night, and heard me yell every time, but dasn’t answer, because he didn’t want nobody to pick him up and take him into slavery again. Says he:
vi: I woke Jim up, and I guessed that when he saw me, he would be terrified again. But no. He was just so happy he was nearly crying, without being surprised at all. He recounted that that night he swam after me and heard me call out a few times but didn't respond, because he was afraid someone would recognize him and take him back to be a slave again. He said:
tr: When I woke him up, I thought he would be astonished to see me, but that was not the case at all. He was almost about to cry, he was very happy, but he was definitely not astonished. That night he told me that he swam behind me and heard me calling, but he didn't respond because he didn't want anyone to rescue him and enslave him again. “My throat was a bit sore, so I couldn't swim fast,” he said, “I stayed quite far behind you.
es: I woke him up and thought he would be very surprised to see me, but he wasn't. He almost cried with joy, but he wasn't surprised. He said he had swum behind me that night and had heard all my screams, but he hadn't dared to respond because he didn't want anyone to pick him up and return him to slavery. And he continued saying:

en: “I got hurt a little, en couldn’t swim fas’, so I wuz a considable ways behine you towards de las’; when you landed I reck’ned I could ketch up wid you on de lan’ ’dout havin’ to shout at you, but when I see dat house I begin to go slow. I ’uz off too fur to hear what dey say to you—I wuz ’fraid o’ de dogs; but when it ’uz all quiet agin, I knowed you’s in de house, so I struck out for de woods to wait for day. Early in de mawnin’ some er de niggers come along, gwyne to de fields, en dey tuk me en showed me dis place, whah de dogs can’t track me on accounts o’ de water, en dey brings me truck to eat every night, en tells me how you’s a-gitt’n along.”
vi: - I was in a bit of pain so I couldn't swim fast, and you left me far behind. When you got ashore, I thought I could catch up with you on land without having to call out. But when I saw that building, I started to slow down. I stood far away so I couldn't hear what they were saying to you; I was also afraid of the pack of dogs. When everything went quiet, I knew you had gone inside that house. So I went out into the forest and waited for you all day. Early the next morning, some black people going to work in the fields found me and showed me this hiding spot. This place has a water pond separating it from the inside, so the dogs can't catch the scent. Every night, they bring me some food, and they tell me about how you are doing in there.
tr: Since you climbed onto the rock, I thought I could catch up to you without calling out, but when I saw that house, I immediately slowed down. I couldn't hear what they said to you, because I was far away… and I was also afraid of the dogs… but eventually the situation calmed down and I realized you had gone into the house. I waited inside the bushes for the dawn to break. Some black people were going to the fields early in the morning, they signaled to me and showed me the well. Because there was water in the well, the dogs couldn't find me; at night, the black people brought me food and told me in detail how you were doing.”
es: —I hurt myself a bit and couldn't swim fast, so towards the end I was already very far from you; when you reached the shore, I calculated that I could catch up to you without having to shout, but when I saw that house, I started to go slower. I was too far away to hear what they were saying to you; I was scared of the dogs, but when everything went quiet again, I understood that you were in the house, so I went to the forest to wait for dawn. Early in the morning, some of the black people who were going to the fields arrived and took me with them and brought me here, where the dogs can't find me thanks to the water, and they bring me food every night and tell me how you are doing.

en: “Why didn’t you tell my Jack to fetch me here sooner, Jim?”
vi: - Why didn't you tell Jack to bring me out here earlier, Jim?
tr: “Jim, why didn't you tell my nigger Jack to bring me here earlier?” I said.
es: —But why didn't you tell my Jack to bring me earlier, Jim?

en: “Well, ’twarn’t no use to ’sturb you, Huck, tell we could do sumfn—but we’s all right now. I ben a-buyin’ pots en pans en vittles, as I got a chanst, en a-patchin’ up de raf’ nights when—”
vi: - Didn't want to bother you, Huck. You said you couldn't do anything, but now I'm relieved. I've bought pots, pans, and enough food.
tr: "There was no need to bother you, Huck. We couldn't do anything anyway. But now things have changed. Whenever I get the chance, I buy pots, pans, and food, and at night I fix the raft..."
es: —Well, it wasn't worth bothering you, Huck, until we could do something, but now it's fine. I've been buying gadgets and food whenever I could and fixing the raft at night when...

en: “What raft, Jim?”
vi: How fortunate. Every night I sneak out to patch up the raft, I... - Well, Jim?
tr: "Which raft, Jim?"
es: —What raft, Jim?

en: “Our ole raf’.”
vi: - Our old pond
tr: "Come here, my little lamb.""
es: —Our old raft.

en: “You mean to say our old raft warn’t smashed all to flinders?”
vi: - So, does that mean our raft didn't get destroyed?
tr: “No way, I mean didn't our raft break into pieces?”
es: —Are you going to tell me that our old raft didn't end up in pieces?

en: “No, she warn’t. She was tore up a good deal—one en’ of her was; but dey warn’t no great harm done, on’y our traps was mos’ all los’. Ef we hadn’ dive’ so deep en swum so fur under water, en de night hadn’ ben so dark, en we warn’t so sk’yerd, en ben sich punkin-heads, as de sayin’ is, we’d a seed de raf’. But it’s jis’ as well we didn’t, ’kase now she’s all fixed up agin mos’ as good as new, en we’s got a new lot o’ stuff, in de place o’ what ’uz los’.”
vi: - No, not at all. It only broke partially. One end is still intact, nothing happened to it. If we hadn't dived too deep, if that night we had been a bit braver instead of scared as the saying goes, we could have kept the raft. But don't worry, because now it's almost as good as new, and we have a bunch of other things too, right where we lost them.
tr: “No, it didn't work. A lot of things broke, one side was very bad, but there wasn't a big damage, just almost all of our belongings are gone. We dived very deep, then swam very far underwater, also it was very dark that night, we were very scared and a bit foolish, otherwise we would have already been saved. Actually, it was better that we didn't get saved, the raft is now brand new and we got a lot of new things instead of the ones we lost.”
es: —No, after that. It was quite damaged on one end, but nothing serious happened, we just lost almost all the traps. And if we hadn't dived so much and swum so far underwater, if the night hadn't been so dark, we wouldn't have been so scared or so nervous, as they say, we would have seen the raft. But it's better this way, because now it's all fixed and practically new and we have lots of new things instead of the ones we lost.

en: “Why, how did you get hold of the raft again, Jim—did you catch her?”
vi: - How did you manage to find the raft, Jim, did you chase after it?
tr: “So how did you find the raft again, Jim... Did you pull it to shore yourself?” “There was no need to catch him, he was already in the forest.
es: —But, how did you manage to get the raft back, Jim? Did you go to catch it?

en: “How I gwyne to ketch her en I out in de woods? No; some er de niggers foun’ her ketched on a snag along heah in de ben’, en dey hid her in a crick ’mongst de willows, en dey wuz so much jawin’ ’bout which un ’um she b’long to de mos’ dat I come to heah ’bout it pooty soon, so I ups en settles de trouble by tellin’ ’um she don’t b’long to none uv um, but to you en me; en I ast ’m if dey gwyne to grab a young white genlman’s propaty, en git a hid’n for it? Den I gin ’m ten cents apiece, en dey ’uz mighty well satisfied, en wisht some mo’ raf’s ’ud come along en make ’m rich agin. Dey’s mighty good to me, dese niggers is, en whatever I wants ’m to do fur me, I doan’ have to ast ’m twice, honey. Dat Jack’s a good nigger, en pooty smart.”
vi: - How could I chase after it while lying in this forest? No, my friend, some of the guys found it stuck in a nearby field. They hid it in a hollow under a willow bush, then they argued and debated for a long time about whose raft it was. Just at that moment, I came over and told them that the raft didn't belong to anyone, but to you and me. I asked if they intended to take the property of an upper-class white man by hiding it like that. Then I gave each of them a dime; everyone was very satisfied. Then I told them that if any other rafts floated by, they would get more money. They treated me very well, my friend! But those black guys, you know. Whenever I needed their help, I didn't have to ask twice, my friend. That guy Jack is a good black man, and he's quite quick too.
tr: A few of the blacks found him stuck in the trees by the bend below, and then they hid him in a cave by the willow grove. They argued so much about who the raft belonged to that eventually I heard about it, and I decided that the raft didn’t belong to any of them, but to you and me. I asked them what it meant to take and then hide a white man's property. Then I gave each of them ten cents, they were all very happy and wished that more rafts would get stuck in the trees, so they could get rich too. These blacks treated me very well, they didn’t refuse me anything, my dear. That Jack is also a very good black man, and very smart too.”
es: —How am I going to catch it if I'm in the forest? No; some of the black men found it stuck between some rocks there at the bend and hid it in a stream among the willows, and they argued so much about who was going to keep it that I found out right away, so I solved the problem by telling them it wasn't any of theirs, but yours and mine; and I asked them if they were going to keep the property of a young white gentleman, only to get a few lashes. Then I gave each of them ten cents and they were very satisfied, thinking they hoped more rafts would come so they could get rich again. These black men treat me very well, and when I want them to do something I don't have to ask them twice, my boy. That Jack is a good black man, and smart.

en: “Yes, he is. He ain’t ever told me you was here; told me to come, and he’d show me a lot of water-moccasins. If anything happens he ain’t mixed up in it. He can say he never seen us together, and it’ll be the truth.”
vi: - Yes, he's good. He never told me that you were here. He told me to come here so he could show me the otters. If anything happens, he won't be implicated. He can say that he has never seen us together, and people will believe it.
tr: “It really is so. He didn't even tell me you were here; he just told me to come, that he would show me a bunch of poisonous snakes. If any trouble arises, he can easily say he had no part in it. If he says he never saw them together, he wouldn't be lying.”
es: —Yes, it's true. He never told me that you were here; he told me to come and that he would show me a bunch of water snakes. If something happens, he has nothing to do with it. He can say that he has never seen us together, and he will be telling the truth.

en: I don’t want to talk much about the next day. I reckon I’ll cut it pretty short. I waked up about dawn, and was a-going to turn over and go to sleep again, when I noticed how still it was—didn’t seem to be anybody stirring. That warn’t usual. Next I noticed that Buck was up and gone. Well, I gets up, a-wondering, and goes down stairs—nobody around; everything as still as a mouse. Just the same outside. Thinks I, what does it mean? Down by the wood-pile I comes across my Jack, and says:
vi: I don't want to talk much about what happened the next day. I'll just briefly recount it like this: I woke up at dawn, intending to go back to sleep when I suddenly noticed it was very quiet, as if no one was stirring at all. That was a bit unusual. Then I saw that Buck had gotten up and left at some point. I jumped up, feeling strange, and went downstairs. There was no one there. Everything was silent. It was the same outside. I didn't understand what was going on. Stepping out to the woodpile, I went to ask Jack:
tr: I don't want to say too much about the next day. It's probably best to keep it short. I woke up at dawn, intending to turn over and go back to sleep, but suddenly I noticed how quiet everything was – there was no sign of movement. I was not used to this at all. I saw that Buck had also gotten up and left. So I got up and went downstairs, wondering what was going on – there was no one around; not a sound from anywhere. It was the same outside. I wondered what this could mean. I ran into our Jack by the woodpile.
es: I don't want to say much about the next day. I think I'm going to summarize it. I woke up around dawn and was about to turn over to go back to sleep when I noticed that there wasn't a sound; it was as if nothing was moving. That wasn't normal. Then I saw that Buck had gotten up and left. Well, then I got up, puzzled, and went down the stairs, and there was no one; everything was quieter than a grave. The same outside. I thought: "What does this mean?" Where the firewood was, I found my Jack and asked him:

en: “What’s it all about?”
vi: - What's going on?
tr: “What is happening?” I asked.
es: —What's happening?

en: Says he:
vi: He replied:
tr: "Don't you know, Master George?" he said.
es: He answered me:

en: “Don’t you know, Mars Jawge?”
vi: - You don't know?
tr: “No, I don't know.”
es: —Don't you know, Mr. George?

en: “No,” says I, “I don’t.”
vi: - Yes.
tr: “No, I don't know.”
es: —No. I don't know anything.

en: “Well, den, Miss Sophia’s run off! ’deed she has. She run off in de night some time—nobody don’t know jis’ when; run off to get married to dat young Harney Shepherdson, you know—leastways, so dey ’spec. De fambly foun’ it out ’bout half an hour ago—maybe a little mo’—en’ I tell you dey warn’t no time los’. Sich another hurryin’ up guns en hosses you never see! De women folks has gone for to stir up de relations, en ole Mars Saul en de boys tuck dey guns en rode up de river road for to try to ketch dat young man en kill him ’fo’ he kin git acrost de river wid Miss Sophia. I reck’n dey’s gwyne to be mighty rough times.”
vi: Miss Sophia, she has run away. She really has run away. She ran away in the middle of the night, no one knew. She ran away to marry that guy Harney Shepherdsons, you know. That's what people are saying. The family just found out about half an hour ago, maybe less, and they rushed off immediately. This time it was a real rush, with guns and horses clattering like never before. The men have gone around notifying all the relatives. Old man Saul and some of the guys took guns to the riverbank to kill that guy, because it's very likely he took Miss Sophia across the river. I guess there might be a lot of trouble coming up.
tr: “Sophia has run away! Yes, she eloped. She ran away at night, but no one knows the exact time. And she ran away with that young Harney Shepherdson... At least that's what they say. The family noticed it about an hour ago – maybe a little earlier – and didn't waste any time. They all grabbed their rifles like lightning and mounted their horses! The women went to inform the neighbors, and old man Saul and his sons took their rifles and went after the runaways along the river. They want to catch up with the young man and Miss Sophia while they are still on this side of the river and kill the young man. It looks like all hell is going to break loose soon.”
es: —Well, Miss Sophia has run away! It's the honest truth. She ran away last night and nobody knows at what time; she ran away to marry that young Harney Shepherdson, you know... at least that's what they believe. The family found out about half an hour ago, maybe a bit more, and I assure you they haven't wasted any time; you've never seen such a rush to grab guns and horses in your life! The women have gone to fetch relatives, old Mr. Saul and the boys have taken the guns and hit the road to try to catch that young man and kill him before he can cross the river with Miss Sophia. I think very bad times are coming.

en: “Buck went off ’thout waking me up.”
vi: - Why didn't Buck wake up and call me?
tr: “Buck left without waking me up.”
es: —And Buck left without telling me anything.

en: “Well, I reck’n he did! Dey warn’t gwyne to mix you up in it. Mars Buck he loaded up his gun en ’lowed he’s gwyne to fetch home a Shepherdson or bust. Well, dey’ll be plenty un ’m dah, I reck’n, en you bet you he’ll fetch one ef he gits a chanst.”
vi: - I'm sure he did it on purpose. They don't want you to get involved in this matter. Buck loaded his gun and said he was going to catch a Shepherdson. There are a lot of them on the other side, I'm sure of it. Do you think he might manage to capture one?
tr: “Eh, they did it!” “They didn’t want you to get involved in this job.” “Mr. Buck loaded his gun and said he would rather die than bring a Shepherdson home while going.” “Honestly, if he had the chance, he might have really brought one of the Shepherdsons.””
es: —Man, of course! They weren't going to involve you in that. Mr. Buck loaded the shotgun and said he would come back home with a dead Shepherdson. Well, surely there will be many of them and he will bring one if he gets the chance.

en: I took up the river road as hard as I could put. By-and-by I begin to hear guns a good ways off. When I come in sight of the log store and the woodpile where the steamboats lands, I worked along under the trees and brush till I got to a good place, and then I clumb up into the forks of a cottonwood that was out of reach, and watched. There was a wood-rank four foot high a little ways in front of the tree, and first I was going to hide behind that; but maybe it was luckier I didn’t.
vi: I ran quickly to the riverbank. After a while, I heard gunshots all around. When I reached the wooden shack near the ferry dock, I looked around the trees for a hidden spot to hide, then I climbed up a tree branch out of gun range to observe. There was a pile of wood stacked nearly two meters high nearby, and I planned to run there to hide behind it, thinking it might be safer.
tr: I ran at full speed towards the river road. After a while, I heard gunshots from afar. When I saw the log depot where the steamships docked and the piles of wood, I found a good spot for myself by hiding among the trees and bushes, then climbed up a poplar tree and sat on a fork high enough to be unreachable from below, and started watching what was happening. A little further from the tree, there was a pile of wood about a meter high, and at first, I thought of hiding there; maybe it was better that I didn't.
es: I started running along the river path as fast as I could. Soon I began to hear gunshots quite far away. When I reached the log warehouse and the pile of firewood where the steamboats dock, I started moving under the trees and bushes until I found a good spot, and then I climbed up a poplar cross where the bullets couldn't reach, and I looked. There was wood piled four feet high a little ahead of my tree, and at first I was going to hide behind it, but maybe it was lucky that I didn't.

en: There was four or five men cavorting around on their horses in the open place before the log store, cussing and yelling, and trying to get at a couple of young chaps that was behind the wood-rank alongside of the steamboat landing; but they couldn’t come it. Every time one of them showed himself on the river side of the woodpile he got shot at. The two boys was squatting back to back behind the pile, so they could watch both ways.
vi: Four or five horsemen were galloping around the open ground in front of the wooden shack. They were cursing and shouting, trying to catch two young men hiding behind the pile of wood along the ferry dock. But they couldn't get to them. Every time one of the horsemen poked out towards the river, just a bit beyond the pile of wood, someone from the pile would shoot at them. The two young men were crouching, leaning against the back of the pile of wood, so they could control both the entrance and exit.
tr: Four or five mounted men were wandering around the open area in front of the timber depot, cursing and shouting; they were trying to get two young men hiding behind a stack of wood near the ship dock to come out, but the young men were not coming out. As soon as one of the young men showed himself on the river side of the wood stack, the men would start shooting. The boys were crouched back to back behind the stack, and in this way, they could see both sides.
es: In the open field in front of the log warehouse, there were four or five men circling on their horses, cursing and shouting, and trying to reach a couple of boys who were behind the pile of wood next to the landing, but they couldn't get there. Every time one of them peeked out from the river side of the woodpile, they got shot. The two boys stood back to back behind the wood, so they could shoot in all directions.

en: By-and-by the men stopped cavorting around and yelling. They started riding towards the store; then up gets one of the boys, draws a steady bead over the wood-rank, and drops one of them out of his saddle. All the men jumped off of their horses and grabbed the hurt one and started to carry him to the store; and that minute the two boys started on the run. They got half way to the tree I was in before the men noticed. Then the men see them, and jumped on their horses and took out after them. They gained on the boys, but it didn’t do no good, the boys had too good a start; they got to the woodpile that was in front of my tree, and slipped in behind it, and so they had the bulge on the men again. One of the boys was Buck, and the other was a slim young chap about nineteen years old.
vi: After a while, they stopped running around and shouting. They headed towards the warehouse. Immediately, a boy stood up and fired a shot from the pile of wood, hitting one of the group who fell off his horse. They quickly jumped off their horses to pick up the injured person and take him back to the warehouse, just as the other two boys started to run away. The two boys had run halfway from there to where I was hiding when suddenly the others saw them and immediately mounted their horses to give chase. They almost caught up, but it was no use; the two boys ran very fast and quickly slipped into the pile of wood right in front of the tree where I was hiding. That gave them an advantage over the others. One of the two boys was Buck, while the other was a skinny boy about nineteen years old.
tr: After a while, the men stopped shouting and yelling around. They rode their horses towards the warehouse; at that moment, one of the boys stood up, took aim from the top of the woodpile, and shot one of the riders. The men immediately dismounted and dragged the wounded one by the arm towards the warehouse; just then, two boys started to run away. The boys did not attract attention until they were halfway to the tree I was sitting on. Then the men saw them, jumped on their horses, and chased after them. The men were coming fast, but they still couldn't catch up, because the boys were too far away; they reached the woodpile in front of my tree and took cover behind it again. One of the boys was Buck, and the other was a slender young man around nineteen years old.
es: A while passed and the men stopped circling and shouting. They started running towards the warehouse, and then one of the boys aimed steadily over the wood and knocked one of them off his horse. All the men dismounted from their horses, grabbed the injured man, and began carrying him towards the warehouse, and at that moment the two boys started running. They were halfway to the tree where I was before the men noticed. Then they saw them and jumped on their horses and raced after them. They were gaining ground on the boys, but it didn't help because the boys had a good lead; they reached the pile of wood in front of my tree and hid behind it, so they were protected from the men again. One of the boys was Buck and the other was a thin boy about nineteen years old.

en: The men ripped around awhile, and then rode away. As soon as they was out of sight I sung out to Buck and told him. He didn’t know what to make of my voice coming out of the tree at first. He was awful surprised. He told me to watch out sharp and let him know when the men come in sight again; said they was up to some devilment or other—wouldn’t be gone long. I wished I was out of that tree, but I dasn’t come down. Buck begun to cry and rip, and ’lowed that him and his cousin Joe (that was the other young chap) would make up for this day yet. He said his father and his two brothers was killed, and two or three of the enemy. Said the Shepherdsons laid for them in ambush. Buck said his father and brothers ought to waited for their relations—the Shepherdsons was too strong for them. I asked him what was become of young Harney and Miss Sophia. He said they’d got across the river and was safe. I was glad of that; but the way Buck did take on because he didn’t manage to kill Harney that day he shot at him—I hain’t ever heard anything like it.
vi: Those people rummaged around for a while and then left. As soon as they were out of sight, I called out to Buck. At first, he came out. He was surprised and scared. Then he told me to keep a close watch and let him know if those people came back. He said those people had some sort of scheme and would definitely come back. I wanted to leave this tree, but I didn't dare to. Suddenly, Buck burst into tears and said that he and his cousin Joe (the one who ran with him) would have to keep hiding all day. He said his father and two brothers were all killed, and that two or three people on the enemy's side were also killed. He said the Shepherdsons had set up an ambush. He said his father and two brothers fought while waiting for their relatives to arrive, but the Shepherdsons were too strong. I asked what had happened to Harney and Miss Sophia. He said the two had crossed the river to the other side and were safe. I was very happy to hear that. But Buck wasn't; he was very upset thinking about how he couldn't kill Harney the other day in the forest. I had never seen anything like that before.
tr: The men wandered around the area a bit more, then they left. As soon as they disappeared from sight, I informed Buck. At first, he couldn't understand why my voice was coming from a tree. He was very surprised. He told me to keep my eyes wide open and to inform him if I saw the men again; they were certainly up to something – they wouldn't stay away for long. I wished I wasn't at the top of the tree, I thought, but I didn't dare to come down either. Buck started to cry and lament, while also venting his anger; he said that he and his cousin Joe (that is, the other boy) would settle today's account. His father and two brothers had died, and they had taken care of two or three of the enemy. It turned out that the Shepherdsons had lain in ambush waiting for them. According to Buck, his father and brothers should have waited for their relatives – the Shepherdsons had turned out to be too strong. I asked what had happened to young Harney and Miss Sophia. They had crossed the river and were safe. I was glad about that; but Buck was grumbling that he hadn't finished Harney off when he fired that day – I had never heard him talk like that before.
es: The men circled for a while and then left. As soon as they were out of sight, I called Buck to see me. At first, he didn't understand why my voice was coming from a tree. He was very surprised. He told me to stay very alert and to let him know when the men reappeared; he said they were up to something and wouldn't take long. I preferred to leave that tree, but I didn't dare to come down. Buck started shouting and cursing, and swore that he and his cousin Joe (who was the other boy) would get revenge that very day. He said they had killed his father and two brothers and that two or three of the enemies had died. He said the Shepherdsons had ambushed them. Buck added that his father and brothers should have waited for their relatives because the Shepherdsons were too many for them. I asked him what was going to happen to young Harney and Miss Sophia. He replied that they had already crossed the river and were safe. I was glad, but Buck was furious for not having killed Harney the day he shot at him; in my life, I have never heard anyone say such things.

en: All of a sudden, bang! bang! bang! goes three or four guns—the men had slipped around through the woods and come in from behind without their horses! The boys jumped for the river—both of them hurt—and as they swum down the current the men run along the bank shooting at them and singing out, “Kill them, kill them!” It made me so sick I most fell out of the tree. I ain’t a-going to tell all that happened—it would make me sick again if I was to do that. I wished I hadn’t ever come ashore that night to see such things. I ain’t ever going to get shut of them—lots of times I dream about them.
vi: Bang! Bang! Bang! Three or four gunshots rang out. Both of them abandoned their horses and ran through the forest, sneaking up behind from who knows when. Both of them ran out and jumped into the river. Both of them were injured. And while the two of them swam downstream, the others ran to the riverbank and shot at them, shouting "Kill them, kill them." I was so pained by what I heard that I almost fell from the tree. I dare not recount what happened afterward because it is too heartbreaking to speak of. I think it would have been better if I hadn't gone to the riverbank that night to avoid witnessing those scenes. Later, I could never forget it; many times, I would dream about them in my sleep.
tr: Suddenly, bam! bam! bam! three or four rifles fired at once – the men had circled around us, gotten behind us, dismounted from their horses, and approached quietly! The children immediately jumped into the river – both were wounded. As they swam downstream, the men ran along the shore shooting at them, shouting, “Kill them, kill them!” I felt so bad that I almost fell from the tree. I won’t tell you everything that happened – otherwise, I’ll feel bad again. I keep thinking to myself, if only I hadn’t gone ashore that night, if only I hadn’t seen these things. The memory of them will never leave my mind – I’ve had many dreams about them.
es: Suddenly, bang! bang! bang!, three or four shotguns went off. The men had advanced together through the trees and were coming from behind with their horses! The boys ran towards the river (both wounded), and while they swam downstream, the men ran along the bank shooting at them and shouting: "Kill them, kill them!" I felt so bad that I almost fell out of the tree. I'm not going to tell everything that happened because if I did, I would get sick again. I would have preferred never to have reached the shore that night to see such things afterward. I'm never going to forget them: I still dream about them many times.

en: I stayed in the tree till it begun to get dark, afraid to come down. Sometimes I heard guns away off in the woods; and twice I seen little gangs of men gallop past the log store with guns; so I reckoned the trouble was still a-going on. I was mighty downhearted; so I made up my mind I wouldn’t ever go anear that house again, because I reckoned I was to blame, somehow. I judged that that piece of paper meant that Miss Sophia was to meet Harney somewheres at half-past two and run off; and I judged I ought to told her father about that paper and the curious way she acted, and then maybe he would a locked her up, and this awful mess wouldn’t ever happened.
vi: I stayed up in the treetop until dusk, too scared to climb down. Occasionally, I still heard gunshots in the distant forest, and twice I clearly saw groups of armed horsemen passing by the wooden hut, and I guessed that the trouble was still ongoing. I was so terrified that I resolved never to return to that house again, and I thought that I wouldn't be blamed anyway. I guessed that the piece of paper meant that Miss Sophia was meeting Harney somewhere at half-past two to elope. I felt that I should have told her father about that piece of paper and her somewhat strange behavior, so he could have locked her up, and then these horrible murders wouldn't have happened.
tr: I stayed in the tree until it started to get dark; I was afraid to come down. From time to time, I heard gunshots in the forest, far away; I also saw groups of horsemen passing by the log depot twice with rifles in their hands, so I thought the conflict was still ongoing. My heart was breaking, and I decided never to go near that house again because I thought it was my fault. I had realized that the piece of paper meant that Sophia and Harney would meet somewhere at two-thirty; if I had told her father about that paper and mentioned that his daughter was acting strangely, maybe he would have locked her in her room, and these terrible events would never have happened.
es: I stayed in the tree until it started to get dark because I was scared to come down. Sometimes I heard gunshots in the distance, in the forest, and twice I saw groups of men galloping by the log warehouse with shotguns, so I figured the fight was still going on. I felt so discouraged that I decided not to go near that house again because I thought that somehow it was my fault. I thought that piece of paper meant that Miss Sophia had to meet Harney somewhere at half-past two to run away, and that I should have told her father about the paper and the strange way she was acting, and then maybe he would have locked her up and all that horror would never have happened.

en: When I got down out of the tree, I crept along down the river bank a piece, and found the two bodies laying in the edge of the water, and tugged at them till I got them ashore; then I covered up their faces, and got away as quick as I could. I cried a little when I was covering up Buck’s face, for he was mighty good to me.
vi: After climbing down from the tree, I crawled along the riverbank for a while and saw two bodies lying on the water's edge. I mustered all my strength to pull the two bodies further inland and turned them over to see their faces, then I ran away as fast as I could. When I saw Buck's face, I cried for a long time because he was so kind to me.
tr: After climbing down from the tree, I carefully and quietly advanced along the riverbank and found two bodies floating very close to the shore. I pulled them to the land, covered their faces with something, and left as quickly as possible. While covering Buck's face, I shed a few tears because he had treated me very well.
es: When I got down from the tree, I slid along the shore for a while, found the two corpses at the water's edge, and dragged them until they were on dry land; then I covered their faces and left as quickly as I could. I cried a little while covering Buck, because he had treated me very well.

en: It was just dark now. I never went near the house, but struck through the woods and made for the swamp. Jim warn’t on his island, so I tramped off in a hurry for the crick, and crowded through the willows, red-hot to jump aboard and get out of that awful country. The raft was gone! My souls, but I was scared! I couldn’t get my breath for most a minute. Then I raised a yell. A voice not twenty-five foot from me says:
vi: Then the sky turned completely dark. I didn't dare go near the house, but went through the forest to find the swamp. Jim was no longer there. I hurriedly weaved through the willow trees, eager to jump on the boat and escape this terrifying place. The raft was gone too. Oh my God, I was so scared! For more than a minute, I was breathless. Then I let out a scream. Just a few meters from where I stood, a voice suddenly spoke:
tr: It was almost dark now. I didn't head home; instead, I plunged into the forest and reached the swamp. I couldn't find Jim on his island, so I moved towards the creek where the raft was, near the willows, ready to jump on board and leave this dreadful place – the raft was gone! My God, I was so scared! For almost a minute, I couldn't pull myself together. Then I called out. Immediately, a response came from about ten meters away…
es: It had just gotten dark. I didn't go back to the house, but went through the forest to the swamp. Jim wasn't on his island, so I ran to the stream and hid among the willows, ready to jump aboard and leave that horrible place. The raft was gone! My God, what a fright I got! I was out of breath for almost a minute. Then I managed to scream. A voice, less than twenty-five feet from me, says:

en: “Good lan’! is dat you, honey? Doan’ make no noise.”
vi: - Thank goodness, oh my, is that you? Keep it down
tr: "My God! Is that you, the corner of my heart? Don't make any noise."
es: —Wow! Is that you, my boy? Don't make noise.

en: It was Jim’s voice—nothing ever sounded so good before. I run along the bank a piece and got aboard, and Jim he grabbed me and hugged me, he was so glad to see me. He says:
vi: That was Jim's voice. I had never heard a voice that made me feel so reassured. I jumped over the water's edge and onto the raft. Jim hugged me tightly. Seeing how happy I was, Jim said:
tr: This was Jim's voice – probably no other voice has ever sounded so beautiful to me in my life. I immediately ran from the shore and jumped onto the raft, Jim hugged me tightly as soon as he caught me, he was very happy to see me. “Oh, may you live long, my dear, I was just afraid that you had died again. Jack was in the field and said that you might have been shot, because you hadn't come home.
es: It was Jim's voice, and I had never heard anything so pleasant. I ran a bit along the shore and climbed aboard; Jim grabbed me and hugged me, so happy to see me, and says:

en: “Laws bless you, chile, I ’uz right down sho’ you’s dead agin. Jack’s been heah; he say he reck’n you’s ben shot, kase you didn’ come home no mo’; so I’s jes’ dis minute a startin’ de raf’ down towards de mouf er de crick, so’s to be all ready for to shove out en leave soon as Jack comes agin en tells me for certain you is dead. Lawsy, I’s mighty glad to git you back agin, honey.”
vi: - Lucky, buddy, I was down here thinking you were dead again. Jack came here and said maybe you got shot or something since you didn't return home. I was planning to push the raft down there to carry it, and if Jack came back and confirmed you were dead, I would leave immediately. So now that you're back, I'm so happy.
tr: I was going to take the news to the authorities. Jack turned around and until he confirmed that you were definitely dead, I said I would be ready to set out. How happy I am to see you again, my heart's corner.” “Alright then…
es: —God bless you, child, I was sure you had died again. Jack has been here and says he thought you had been shot because you hadn't come home, so at this moment I was going to take the raft down the stream to be ready to leave as soon as Jack came back and told me for sure that you had died. My God, how glad I am that you have returned, my child.

en: I says:
vi: I said:
tr: This is very good; they will think I was killed and my body drifted down the river because they won't be able to find me…
es: And then I go and say:

en: “All right—that’s mighty good; they won’t find me, and they’ll think I’ve been killed, and floated down the river—there’s something up there that’ll help them think so—so don’t you lose no time, Jim, but just shove off for the big water as fast as ever you can.”
vi: - Great, then that's even better. That way, they won't look for me anymore because they think I've been killed and my body has floated down the river. There's a corpse up there, which might make them think that way. Let's go quickly, Jim, push us out to the middle of the river.
tr: There are enough reasons for them to think that up there… So let's not waste any time, Jim, let's act immediately and get to the river quickly.”
es: —All right; it's very good; they won't find me and will believe that I have died and floated down the river... Up there, there's something that will help them believe it, so don't waste time, Jim, let's find the big water as quickly as you can.

en: I never felt easy till the raft was two mile below there and out in the middle of the Mississippi. Then we hung up our signal lantern, and judged that we was free and safe once more. I hadn’t had a bite to eat since yesterday, so Jim he got out some corn-dodgers and buttermilk, and pork and cabbage and greens—there ain’t nothing in the world so good when it’s cooked right—and whilst I eat my supper we talked, and had a good time. I was powerful glad to get away from the feuds, and so was Jim to get away from the swamp. We said there warn’t no home like a raft, after all. Other places do seem so cramped up and smothery, but a raft don’t. You feel mighty free and easy and comfortable on a raft.
vi: Until our raft had gone upstream for a few miles downstream and reached the middle of the Mississippi River, we were not at ease. Then we hung up the signal light, thinking that once again we had escaped danger and were free. Since yesterday, I hadn't had anything to eat. Jim took out some fried bread; milk cakes, and there was even meat and green vegetables. There is nothing more delicious in the world than eating something hot like this. I ate and chatted with Jim very happily. I was glad to have escaped the plantation; and Jim was also glad to have escaped the swamp. We told each other that ultimately, nowhere was better than our raft. Other places are cramped and suffocating. But on the raft, it's not like that. On the raft, you feel completely free, comfortable, and secure.
tr: I couldn't feel at ease until we were two miles down and reached the middle of the Mississippi. Then we lit the signal lantern and had no doubt that we were once again free and safe. I hadn't put a single bite in my mouth since yesterday; Jim soon brought out cornbread, skimmed milk, pork sausage, cabbage, and greens – when prepared by an expert, no meal could match its taste. We chatted while I ate and had a great time. I was very happy to have escaped the blood feuds, and Jim was glad to have gotten out of the swamp. There was nothing like having your own raft. Everywhere else felt cramped and suffocating, but not the raft. On the raft, one feels completely free; carefree and comfortable.
es: I didn't feel at ease until the raft had drifted two miles down the center of the Mississippi. Then we hung our signal lantern and figured we were free and safe again. I hadn't eaten anything since yesterday, so Jim brought out some corn muffins and milk with cream, and pork with cabbage and greens (there's nothing better in the world when it's well-cooked) and while I had dinner, we chatted and had a good time. I was very glad to get away from the blood feuds, and Jim from the swamp. We said there was no home like a raft, after all. Other places may seem crowded and stifling, but not a raft. On a raft, one feels very free and at ease.

en: CHAPTER XIX.
vi: Chapter XIX
tr: The Ninth Chapter
es: Chapter 19

en: Two or three days and nights went by; I reckon I might say they swum by, they slid along so quiet and smooth and lovely. Here is the way we put in the time. It was a monstrous big river down there—sometimes a mile and a half wide; we run nights, and laid up and hid daytimes; soon as night was most gone we stopped navigating and tied up—nearly always in the dead water under a tow-head; and then cut young cottonwoods and willows, and hid the raft with them. Then we set out the lines. Next we slid into the river and had a swim, so as to freshen up and cool off; then we set down on the sandy bottom where the water was about knee deep, and watched the daylight come. Not a sound anywheres—perfectly still—just like the whole world was asleep, only sometimes the bullfrogs a-cluttering, maybe. The first thing to see, looking away over the water, was a kind of dull line—that was the woods on t’other side; you couldn’t make nothing else out; then a pale place in the sky; then more paleness spreading around; then the river softened up away off, and warn’t black any more, but gray; you could see little dark spots drifting along ever so far away—trading scows, and such things; and long black streaks—rafts; sometimes you could hear a sweep screaking; or jumbled up voices, it was so still, and sounds come so far; and by-and-by you could see a streak on the water which you know by the look of the streak that there’s a snag there in a swift current which breaks on it and makes that streak look that way; and you see the mist curl up off of the water, and the east reddens up, and the river, and you make out a log-cabin in the edge of the woods, away on the bank on t’other side of the river, being a woodyard, likely, and piled by them cheats so you can throw a dog through it anywheres; then the nice breeze springs up, and comes fanning you from over there, so cool and fresh and sweet to smell on account of the woods and the flowers; but sometimes not that way, because they’ve left dead fish laying around, gars and such, and they do get pretty rank; and next you’ve got the full day, and everything smiling in the sun, and the song-birds just going it!
vi: A few more days and nights passed; I think it can be said that I passed those nights, gliding through them, in a peaceful, gentle, and poetic manner. Here, we passed those days and hours like this. The river was both large and wide - in some places up to a mile, a mile and a half. We traveled day and night looking for a secluded spot to sleep. Near the end of the night, we would stop rowing, find a calm spot near a creek to tie the raft, then cut some wildflower branches or willow branches to cover the raft, and cast the fishing line. Then we would jump into the river to bathe, refreshing and invigorating ourselves. Then we would sit and wait on some sandy bank with water up to our knees, waiting for the daylight to come. All around, there was not a sound, complete tranquility, as if the entire world was asleep. Occasionally, we might hear the croaking of frogs. The first thing seen on the other side of the water was just a long, silent row of trees, nothing else could be seen. Then a faint light appeared in the sky, gradually spreading, making the river seem even wider; it was no longer black but grayish. In the distance, we could see black dots floating downstream, drifting endlessly, perhaps sailboats or something, long black objects from the rafts. Sometimes we could hear the splash of oars or the murmur of voices. It was so quiet that the sounds echoed far away. Occasionally, we would see a streak on the water; looking closely, we could recognize it as a tree uprooted and drifting, appearing like that, then mist would roll into coils on the water. In the east, the sky began to redden, then the river, and perhaps the wooden hut on the edge of the forest across the river, maybe a wooden basket of some sort, if suspected of containing something, a dog could be sent in to sniff around. Then a cool breeze would blow, feeling refreshing, gentle, with a fragrant scent of wood and forest flowers. But sometimes, instead, there would be the smell of dead fish around, rising up, pungent and strong. After that, it would be fully daylight. Everything seemed to smile under the sun, and the birds chirped merrily.
tr: Two or three more days and nights passed; or perhaps I should say flowed by, meaning they passed so quietly, smoothly, and pleasantly. Let me tell you how the time passed. As we went downstream, the river reached an immense width – in some places it was about a mile and a half; we traveled at night and stopped to hide during the day; in the last moments of darkness, we would move out of the current and tie up the raft. Almost every time, we would pull up to an island in the still water, then hide the raft nicely with poplar saplings and willow branches. Then we would cast our fishing lines. We would go into the river and swim a bit, thus both cleaning and cooling ourselves; we would watch the sunrise from a sandy spot where the water came up to our knees. There was not a sound around – complete silence – it was as if the whole world was asleep, only occasionally interrupted by the sound of frogs. When you looked at the horizon over the water, the first thing you saw was a dull line – this was the line of the forest on the opposite shore – nothing else could be distinguished; a pale band appeared in the sky above it; then it spread upward; then the color of the river lightened; it gradually turned from black to gray; you could see small black dots drifting away, continuously moving farther – these were barges and similar things; and there were long black streaks – rafts; sometimes we would hear the creak of an oar or indistinct conversations; it was so quiet that sounds from very far away would reach us; after a while, lines would start to appear on the water, and by looking at the position of the lines, you could tell that there were trees under the water with a fast current passing over them; you could also see the mist gathering and lifting off the surface of the water, the eastern side turning red, the river turning red, and you could make out a log cabin at the edge of the forest, most likely a wood depot on the other side of the river. Then a fresh breeze would come up and cool you, bringing the pleasant scents of the forest and flowers to your nose; but sometimes it wasn't so nice, because it would expose dead garfish or other fish, and as they rotted, they would smell really awful; then the day would fully break; everything would be smiling in the sunlight and the birds would start chirping madly!
es: Two or three days and nights passed; I think I could say they swam by, so calm, smooth, and wonderful they slipped away. I'm going to tell you how we spent our time. The river was monstrously large there: in some places, it was a mile and a half wide; we navigated at night and rested and hid during the day; as soon as the night was about to end, we stopped navigating and moored, almost always in the still water under a landing place, and then we cut young poplars and willows and hid the raft underneath. Then we cast the fishing lines. Later, we would go into the river to swim for a while, to wash and refresh ourselves; then we would sit on the sandy bottom, where the water reached our knees, and wait for daylight to come. There wasn't a sound anywhere, everything was in absolute silence, as if the whole world had fallen asleep, except perhaps sometimes the croaking of frogs. The first thing you saw, if you looked over the water, was a kind of blurry line that was the forests on the other side; nothing else could be distinguished; then a pale spot in the sky and more paleness appearing, and then the river, soft and distant, which was no longer black but gray; you could see black spots drifting far away: barges and other boats, and long black lines that were rafts; sometimes you heard the creak of an oar, or voices mingled in the silence that made sounds carry from very far away; and after a while, you saw a line in the water, and by its color, you knew there was a current under the surface breaking it and making that line appear; and then you saw the mist floating as it rose from the water and the East turned red, and the river, and you saw a log cabin at the edge of the forest, over there on the other side of the river, which was probably a sawmill, and next to it, piles of wood with gaps made by some vagabonds, so a dog could pass through; then a nice breeze came from the other side, fresh and gentle, smelling very good because it came from the forest and flowers; but sometimes it wasn't like that because someone had left dead fish lying around, pikes and all that, and they smelled a lot, and then full daylight came and everything smiled at the sun, and the birds began to sing.

en: A little smoke couldn’t be noticed now, so we would take some fish off of the lines and cook up a hot breakfast. And afterwards we would watch the lonesomeness of the river, and kind of lazy along, and by-and-by lazy off to sleep. Wake up by-and-by, and look to see what done it, and maybe see a steamboat coughing along up-stream, so far off towards the other side you couldn’t tell nothing about her only whether she was a stern-wheel or side-wheel; then for about an hour there wouldn’t be nothing to hear nor nothing to see—just solid lonesomeness. Next you’d see a raft sliding by, away off yonder, and maybe a galoot on it chopping, because they’re most always doing it on a raft; you’d see the axe flash and come down—you don’t hear nothing; you see that axe go up again, and by the time it’s above the man’s head then you hear the k’chunk!—it had took all that time to come over the water. So we would put in the day, lazying around, listening to the stillness. Once there was a thick fog, and the rafts and things that went by was beating tin pans so the steamboats wouldn’t run over them. A scow or a raft went by so close we could hear them talking and cussing and laughing—heard them plain; but we couldn’t see no sign of them; it made you feel crawly; it was like spirits carrying on that way in the air. Jim said he believed it was spirits; but I says:
vi: At this moment, even if a little smoke rises, no one can see it. We lifted a few fish at the end of the line to make a hot meal. Then we sat back down to watch the deserted river. People started to get tired, and we lay down to sleep. From time to time, we woke up and looked outside to see if there was anything. Perhaps it was a boat laboriously climbing upstream on the far side of the river; from a distance, it was impossible to tell if it was a stern-wheeler or had paddle wheels on both sides. Then another hour passed, with nothing to see or hear, just silence. Later, a raft drifted by on the outer edge. Perhaps there was a guy on the raft chopping wood, because they often chop wood right on the raft. From inside here, they could see the glint of the axe being raised, and just as the axe was lifted above his head, there was a thud, a sound that took a moment to travel over the water before reaching our ears. Then we lay back down, listening to the quiet return. Once, in thick fog, boats and rafts had to clang pots and pans to avoid being hit by steamships. A ferry or raft or something passed by us, so close that we could clearly hear them talking, swearing, and laughing loudly, even though we couldn't see anything, as if we were blindfolded; it really felt like ghostly voices drifting through the air. Jim said maybe they really were ghosts. I said:
tr: We were preparing a warm breakfast with some of the fish caught on the lines, thinking a little smoke wouldn't attract attention anymore. Then we would watch the solitude of the river for a while; laze around; gradually get drowsy and eventually fall asleep. Then we would wake up to a noise and see a steamboat coughing its way upriver, but it would be on the other side of the river and so far away that it was impossible to tell whether its paddle wheel was on the side or the stern. Then for about an hour, nothing else would be heard or seen – just solitude. Then you would see a raft passing in the distance, perhaps with an inexperienced raftsman cutting wood on it, because such types always cut wood on the raft; you would see the axe glint as it rises and falls – but you wouldn't hear anything; then the axe rises again; as it reaches above the man's head, you hear the thud! sound, it takes that long for the sound to reach you over the water. That's how we spent the day, lazing around, listening intently to the silence. Once, a thick fog descended, and people on rafts and barges were clanging pots and pans to avoid being hit by steamboats as they moved along. A barge or raft passed so close to us that we could hear the people inside cursing and laughing – we could clearly understand what they were saying; but we couldn't see them for even a moment; this sent chills down our spines, as if we were listening to the voices of spirits gliding through the air. Jim even said he believed they were spirits.
es: At that hour, it didn't matter to make a little smoke because it couldn't be seen, so we took the fish off the lines and prepared a hot breakfast. And then we would contemplate the solitude of the river and laze around, and little by little we would fall asleep. We would wake up, and when we looked to find out why, sometimes we saw a steamboat puffing upriver, so far on the other side that the only thing you could see was whether it had the wheel at the stern or on the sides; then, for an hour there was nothing to hear or see: only solitude. Then we would see a raft gliding in the distance, and sometimes one of the guys on board chopping wood, because that's what they almost always do on rafts, and you could see the axe shining and coming down, but you couldn't hear anything; you would see the axe rise again, and when it was above the man's head, then you would hear the chop, which had taken all that time to cross the water. And so we spent the day, lazing around, listening to the silence. Once a dense fog came down, and the rafts and everything that passed by made noise with pans so that the steamboats wouldn't overlook them.
