A skiff or a raft would pass so close that we could hear what the people on board were saying, their curses and their laughter, we could hear them perfectly, but we couldn't see any sign of them; it was a very strange feeling, as if they were spirits talking in the air. Jim said he thought they were, but I said:

en: “No; spirits wouldn’t say, ‘Dern the dern fog.’”
vi: - No, if it were, it would have said: the fog has lifted.
tr: But I had objected, "No soul would say 'damn this accursed fog'."
es: —No; the spirits would not say: "Damn the damn fog."

en: Soon as it was night out we shoved; when we got her out to about the middle we let her alone, and let her float wherever the current wanted her to; then we lit the pipes, and dangled our legs in the water, and talked about all kinds of things—we was always naked, day and night, whenever the mosquitoes would let us—the new clothes Buck’s folks made for me was too good to be comfortable, and besides I didn’t go much on clothes, nohow.
vi: Then it wouldn't be long before night came again, and we would set off once more. Once the raft reached the middle of the river, we let it drift, letting the current take us wherever it wanted. We lit our cigarettes, dangled our feet in the water, and talked about all sorts of things. All day and all night, we went shirtless, not caring about the mosquitoes. The outfit that Mrs. Buck's family made for me was so nice that it became inconvenient to wear. Besides, I didn't pay much attention to clothes anyway.
tr: Before long, it got dark and we had moved away from the shore. When we reached the middle of the river, we stopped rowing and the raft continued to float downstream with the current; then we lit our pipes, stretched our feet into the water, and started chatting about this and that. Whenever we got a break from the mosquitoes, we were always naked; the clothes Buck's family gave me were so high-quality that I couldn't feel comfortable in them, and besides, I don't really like fussing over my clothes.
es: As soon as it was night, we would head to the river; when we had the raft approximately in the center, we would do nothing and let it float wherever the current took it; then we would light our pipes and dip our legs in the water and talk about all sorts of things; we were always naked, day and night, when the mosquitoes allowed us; the new clothes that Buck's family had made for me were too good to be comfortable; anyway, I didn't really like wearing clothes much either.

en: Sometimes we’d have that whole river all to ourselves for the longest time. Yonder was the banks and the islands, across the water; and maybe a spark—which was a candle in a cabin window; and sometimes on the water you could see a spark or two—on a raft or a scow, you know; and maybe you could hear a fiddle or a song coming over from one of them crafts. It’s lovely to live on a raft. We had the sky up there, all speckled with stars, and we used to lay on our backs and look up at them, and discuss about whether they was made or only just happened. Jim he allowed they was made, but I allowed they happened; I judged it would have took too long to make so many. Jim said the moon could a laid them; well, that looked kind of reasonable, so I didn’t say nothing against it, because I’ve seen a frog lay most as many, so of course it could be done. We used to watch the stars that fell, too, and see them streak down. Jim allowed they’d got spoiled and was hove out of the nest.
vi: Sometimes it feels like this whole river belongs to us. Looking across the water, far away on the other side is the riverbank, and the island, and perhaps there is a light, a candle flame in the window frame. Sometimes there are also a few lights on the water's surface. Those are the lights on the rafts or ferries, and perhaps we can even hear the sound of a violin or singing echoing out. Living on a raft or a float, how interesting it is. Above us, there is only the high sky, dotted with stars, and we often lie on our backs looking up at the sky, debating with each other about who made those stars, and I just say they exist on their own. I said if someone made that many stars, it would surely take a lot of time. Jim said the moon gave birth to those stars. Well, it makes sense, so I couldn't say anything to refute that theory. And since I've seen frogs lay a lot of eggs, it could be that the moon gave birth to those stars. We also often look at shooting stars, watching their trails stretch down to the horizon. Jim said those are the bad stars, flying away from their nest.
tr: Sometimes there would be no one else on the river for a very long time except us. We would see the shores and islands ahead; maybe a spark – a candle seen from a cabin window – would catch our eye; sometimes we would see one or two sparks on the water – on a raft or a barge; sometimes we would hear the sound of a violin or someone singing from one of the river vessels. Living on the raft was very beautiful. The sky above would be speckled with stars, and we would lie on our backs and watch the stars, debating whether they were made or if they appeared suddenly – according to Jim, they were made, but I thought they appeared suddenly; in my opinion, there were too many of them to be made one by one. Jim had said that the moon might have laid them; well, since this seemed reasonable, I didn't object, because I had seen a frog with as many offspring as there were stars, so this was something that could happen. We would also see shooting stars and watch them descend. According to Jim, these were the rotten ones and that's why they were picked out and fell from the nest.
es: Sometimes we had the whole river to ourselves for very long stretches. In the distance, we could see the banks and the islands on the other side of the water, and sometimes a spark that was a light in the window of a cabin, and sometimes in the middle of the water, we saw a spark or two: you know, a raft or a skiff, and you could hear a violin or a song coming from one of those boats. It's wonderful to live on a raft. Above us, we had the sky, all speckled with stars, and we would lie on our backs, look at them, and discuss whether someone had made them or if they had just appeared on their own. Jim always said that they had been made, but I maintained that they had just appeared; it seemed to me it would take too long to make so many. Jim said that the moon might have put them there; well, that seemed quite reasonable, so I didn't say anything against it, because I've seen frogs lay almost as many eggs, so it was certainly possible. We also watched the falling stars and saw the trail they left behind. Jim said it was because they had misbehaved and had been thrown out of the nest.

en: Once or twice of a night we would see a steamboat slipping along in the dark, and now and then she would belch a whole world of sparks up out of her chimbleys, and they would rain down in the river and look awful pretty; then she would turn a corner and her lights would wink out and her powwow shut off and leave the river still again; and by-and-by her waves would get to us, a long time after she was gone, and joggle the raft a bit, and after that you wouldn’t hear nothing for you couldn’t tell how long, except maybe frogs or something.
vi: A few times during the dark hours, we would encounter passing ships, occasionally they would emit a whole sky full of sparks from their chimneys, and then those sparks would fall like rain onto the river, looking incredibly beautiful. Then it would turn to another direction, its twinkling lights gradually fading, its chugging sounds also quieting down, and the river would return to silence. A moment later, when the ship had gone far away, its waves would reach us, causing the raft to bob slightly; then we wouldn't hear anything anymore, and it was impossible to tell how long it had been. Perhaps only a few sounds of frogs or something else remained.
tr: Every night, we would see a steamship moving in the dark once or twice, spewing countless sparks from its chimney, and as the sparks descended burning onto the river, it would create a magnificent view; then, as the ship turned a corner, its lights would disappear from sight, its noise would cease, and the river would become silent again; long after it had vanished, its waves would slowly reach us and gently rock the raft, and then you would hear nothing, there would be a long silence of indeterminate length, interrupted only by frogs or similar sounds.
es: At night we would see one or two steamboats passing in the darkness, and every now and then they would send out a whole world of sparks from one of the chimneys, which fell into the river and looked beautiful; then the boat would round a bend and the lights would wink and the noise of the boat would disappear, leaving the river silent again, and then the waves it had raised would reach us, long after the boat had disappeared, causing the raft to move a little, and then nothing could be heard for who knows how long, except maybe the frogs or things like that.

en: After midnight the people on shore went to bed, and then for two or three hours the shores was black—no more sparks in the cabin windows. These sparks was our clock—the first one that showed again meant morning was coming, so we hunted a place to hide and tie up right away.
vi: Past midnight, the people on both sides of the river were all asleep, and the riverbanks were pitch dark for several hours. There was no longer any light in the windows. Those lights were our clocks. When the first light appeared, it signaled that dawn was approaching, so we would find a place to hide and immediately tie up the raft.
tr: After midnight, the people living by the shore would go to bed, and for the next two or three hours, the beaches would be shrouded in darkness – no sparks would flicker in the cabin windows. Those sparks marked our time – when we started to see them again, we knew that morning was approaching, and we would immediately tie up the raft and start looking for a place to hide.
es: After midnight, the people of the coast went to bed, and for two or three hours the shores were in darkness: there were no more sparks in the windows of the cabins. Those sparks were our clock: the first one that reappeared meant that dawn was arriving, so we immediately looked for a place to hide and moor.

en: One morning about daybreak I found a canoe and crossed over a chute to the main shore—it was only two hundred yards—and paddled about a mile up a crick amongst the cypress woods, to see if I couldn’t get some berries. Just as I was passing a place where a kind of a cowpath crossed the crick, here comes a couple of men tearing up the path as tight as they could foot it. I thought I was a goner, for whenever anybody was after anybody I judged it was me—or maybe Jim. I was about to dig out from there in a hurry, but they was pretty close to me then, and sung out and begged me to save their lives—said they hadn’t been doing nothing, and was being chased for it—said there was men and dogs a-coming. They wanted to jump right in, but I says:
vi: One morning, just as the sun was rising, I found a boat, rowed through a swift current to reach the main shore, only a few hundred yards away. Then I rowed about half a mile further to a spot with bushes near a pine forest to see if I could find any berries. As I reached a narrow path just wide enough for cattle to pass through, suddenly two people came running out from that small path. I thought to myself, this is trouble, because if anyone is looking for someone here, it could only be me or Jim. I was about to slip away when those people ran up close, calling me and begging me to save them. They said they hadn't done anything wrong, yet people were chasing them. Then they said that people with dogs were about to catch up to them. They wanted to jump right into my boat, but I said:
tr: One morning, just as dawn was breaking, I found a canoe and entered a swift current – it was only about two hundred meters – and reached the riverbank. Then, I went up a creek among the cypress trees for about a mile to find some berries. Just as I was passing a place where the creek cut across a wide path, didn't two men come running for their lives! Ah, this time I'm done for, I said to myself; because whenever I saw someone running, I thought they were chasing me – or Jim. I was about to grab the oars to get away quickly, but they were already very close, calling out to me and asking me to save their lives – according to them, they hadn't done anything and were being chased for no reason – there were men and dogs behind them. They immediately wanted to jump into the canoe, but I stopped them:
es: One morning, around dawn, I saw a canoe and I crossed a channel to the main shore (it was no more than two hundred yards) and rowed a mile towards a stream among the cypresses, to see if I could get some blackberries. Just as I was passing a spot where a sort of cow path crossed the stream, a pair of men appeared running as fast as they could. I thought my time had come, because whenever someone was looking for someone, it seemed to me that it was for me, or maybe for Jim. I was about to leave in a hurry, but they were already very close to me, and they shouted and asked me to save their lives: they said they hadn't done anything and that's why they were being chased, that men with dogs were coming. They wanted to get directly into my canoe, but I told them:

en: “Don’t you do it. I don’t hear the dogs and horses yet; you’ve got time to crowd through the brush and get up the crick a little ways; then you take to the water and wade down to me and get in—that’ll throw the dogs off the scent.”
vi: - Don't do that, it's just starting. I didn't hear any horse sounds. You have enough time to crawl through that bush, follow the small path down to the water, then wade around here before getting into the boat. That way, the dogs won't be able to track you.
tr: “Do not mount here. I do not hear the sounds of the dogs and horses yet; you still have time to go a bit upstream through the bushes; then you can enter the water, come downstream to me, and then you can mount... That way, the dogs won't catch your scent.”
es: —No, not now. I still don't hear the horses and the dogs; you have time to go through the bushes and climb a little up the stream; then get into the water and wade down to where I am and come over; that way the dogs will lose the trail.

en: They done it, and soon as they was aboard I lit out for our tow-head, and in about five or ten minutes we heard the dogs and the men away off, shouting. We heard them come along towards the crick, but couldn’t see them; they seemed to stop and fool around a while; then, as we got further and further away all the time, we couldn’t hardly hear them at all; by the time we had left a mile of woods behind us and struck the river, everything was quiet, and we paddled over to the tow-head and hid in the cottonwoods and was safe.
vi: They followed; as soon as they stepped onto the boat, I rowed quickly back to where we hid the raft. About fifty minutes later, we heard the sound of dogs and people shouting and yelling. We heard that they had reached the bushes, but we couldn't see them. It seemed like they stopped there and searched around for a while. We went farther away and couldn't hear anything anymore. After traveling a distance of nearly a mile through the forest and reaching the big river, everything was quiet. We turned into a creek and hid in the cotton fields; and thus, we felt completely at ease.
tr: They did as I said; right after they got into the canoe, I set off towards our little island; within five to ten minutes, we heard the dogs and men passing by, shouting and yelling. We could hear them coming towards the creek, but we couldn't see them. It seemed to me that they lingered around there for a while. After that, we didn't hear their voices again because we were constantly moving away. We moved in silence until we left the forest about a mile behind and reached the river, then we rowed to our little island, hid among the poplars; we were safe now.
es: That was what they did, and as soon as they were on board, I headed towards our mooring; after five minutes we heard the dogs and the men shouting in the distance. We heard them go towards the stream, but we couldn't see them; they seemed to leave it and wander around for a while, and then, as we kept moving away all the time, we could hardly hear them anymore; when we left the forest a mile behind and reached the river, everything was calm and we rowed to the sandbar and hid among the poplars, now safe.

en: One of these fellows was about seventy or upwards, and had a bald head and very gray whiskers. He had an old battered-up slouch hat on, and a greasy blue woollen shirt, and ragged old blue jeans britches stuffed into his boot-tops, and home-knit galluses—no, he only had one. He had an old long-tailed blue jeans coat with slick brass buttons flung over his arm, and both of them had big, fat, ratty-looking carpet-bags.
vi: An elderly man of about seventy years or more, bald with graying sideburns. He wore an old wide-brimmed hat, a grayish-blue undershirt, and old, torn blue pants with the cuffs tucked into his boots. Over his arm, he carried a blue coat with shiny brass buttons. Both men carried large, heavy, and dirty bags.
tr: One of the men was seventy or older; his head was bald and his sideburns were quite gray. He had an old, tattered hat on his head, and a blue wool shirt covered in grease on his back; he had tucked the frayed cuffs of his blue jeans into his boots; he had homemade suspenders – no, more precisely, he had a single suspender. He had slung an old long denim jacket with makeshift brass buttons over his arm; additionally, he had a swollen, dirty-looking kilim bag in each hand.
es: One of those guys was about seventy years old or more, and he was bald with a very gray beard. He wore an old wide-brimmed hat and a greasy blue wool shirt, with old blue jeans tucked into his boots, with homemade suspenders; but no, he only had one left. He carried an old blue fabric overcoat over his arm, with shiny copper buttons, and they both carried large, half-worn travel bags.

en: The other fellow was about thirty, and dressed about as ornery. After breakfast we all laid off and talked, and the first thing that come out was that these chaps didn’t know one another.
vi: The other person was about thirty years old, dressed modestly. After finishing breakfast, we lay down to rest, chatted, and the first thing that dawned on us was that the two other people didn't know each other at all.
tr: The other man was in his thirties and was as shabbily dressed as the other. After breakfast, we all lay down where we were and started talking, and the first thing we noticed was that these men did not know each other.
es: The other guy was about thirty years old and was dressed just as plainly. After breakfast, we all lay down to chat, and the first thing that came up was that those guys didn't know each other.

en: “What got you into trouble?” says the baldhead to t’other chap.
vi: The bald old man told the other guy:
tr: "How did you get yourself into trouble?" asked the bald one to the other.
es: —What problem have you had? —asked the bald man to the other.

en: “Well, I’d been selling an article to take the tartar off the teeth—and it does take it off, too, and generly the enamel along with it—but I stayed about one night longer than I ought to, and was just in the act of sliding out when I ran across you on the trail this side of town, and you told me they were coming, and begged me to help you to get off. So I told you I was expecting trouble myself, and would scatter out with you. That’s the whole yarn—what’s yourn?
vi: - What happened that you have to run away? - I sell a product used to remove black stains on teeth, but it doesn't remove the stains and instead removes the enamel. I stayed an extra night and was planning to sneak away when I met him running towards me on the road. He told me they were coming and asked me to help him escape. I told him that I was also about to get into trouble, so we ran together. That's all there is to it, so what's your story?
tr: “I was selling a material that removes dental calculus… It really does remove it, but it usually takes the tooth enamel with it. I stayed one night longer than I should have, and just as I was preparing to flee, I met you on the road on this side of the town. You said they were after you and asked me to help you escape. At that point, I told you I was in trouble too and started running away with you. That's all there is to it… What was your problem?”
es: —Well, I was selling a product to remove tartar from teeth, and it's true that it removes it, and generally also the enamel, but I stayed one night longer than I should have and was about to leave when I met you on the path on this side of town, you told me they were coming and asked me to help you escape. So I told you that I was also expecting trouble and that I would leave with you. That's all. And you?

en: “Well, I’d ben a-runnin’ a little temperance revival thar, ’bout a week, and was the pet of the women folks, big and little, for I was makin’ it mighty warm for the rummies, I tell you, and takin’ as much as five or six dollars a night—ten cents a head, children and niggers free—and business a-growin’ all the time, when somehow or another a little report got around last night that I had a way of puttin’ in my time with a private jug on the sly. A nigger rousted me out this mornin’, and told me the people was getherin’ on the quiet with their dogs and horses, and they’d be along pretty soon and give me ’bout half an hour’s start, and then run me down if they could; and if they got me they’d tar and feather me and ride me on a rail, sure. I didn’t wait for no breakfast—I warn’t hungry.”
vi: - Me? I'm doing an advertisement stunt to quit drinking. It's been a week, and everyone likes it, especially the women. This stunt is also making money. Look, each person pays a dime to watch, children and black people are free, and each night I make five to six dollars. This stunt was on the rise, but suddenly last night someone went around saying I was just a fraud and that I was secretly selling alcohol. This morning, a black man came to wake me up and said people were quietly gathering, bringing dogs and horses to catch me for punishment, and they might beat me up badly, or they might tar and feather me, shave all my hair and beard, and drag me on the railroad tracks, who knows. I didn't even have time for breakfast, and I wasn't hungry either.
tr: “I had been holding small meetings against the sale and consumption of alcohol for a week. I had won the love of all the women, big and small, because I was giving the drunks a hard time. I was making about five or six dollars a night – I was charging ten cents per head, it was free for children and black people – business was good, and the number of attendees was increasing. But last night, a rumor started out of nowhere: Apparently, I was secretly taking swigs from a hidden jug. This morning, a black man came and woke me up and said that people were starting to gather quietly. They would be here soon with their dogs and horses, and after giving me a half-hour head start, they would chase me; when they caught me, they would tar and feather me and ride me on a rail. I couldn't stay for breakfast – I had lost my appetite.”
es: —Well, I had been preaching sermons about temperance for a week and getting along very well with the women, both old and young, because I was making it hard for the drinkers, I assure you, and I was making at least five or six dollars a night, at ten cents a head, children and blacks free, and business was growing more and more, when somehow, last night, they started saying that I didn't mind spending some time alone with a jug. A black man woke me up this morning and told me that people were gathering quietly, with dogs and horses, and that they were going to come soon, give me a half-hour head start and then try to catch me, and that if they caught me they planned to tar and feather me and run me out of town on a rail. So I didn't wait for breakfast... I wasn't hungry.

en: “Old man,” said the young one, “I reckon we might double-team it together; what do you think?”
vi: The other person said: - My old friend, I think maybe the two of us could do business together, what do you think?
tr: “Dad, I see that we could make a good team,” said the younger one. “What do you think?”
es: —Old man —said the young man—, it seems to me that we could form a team; what do you think?

en: “I ain’t undisposed. What’s your line—mainly?”
vi: - For me, it's easy. But what is your main occupation?
tr: "I have no objections." "What is your profession... I mean generally?""
es: —I don't think it's bad. What do you do, mainly?

en: “Jour printer by trade; do a little in patent medicines; theater-actor—tragedy, you know; take a turn to mesmerism and phrenology when there’s a chance; teach singing-geography school for a change; sling a lecture sometimes—oh, I do lots of things—most anything that comes handy, so it ain’t work. What’s your lay?”
vi: - Printing newspapers. That's my main profession. Occasionally, I make some medicines. A stage actor specializing in tragedy, you know. Sometimes, when convenient, I switch to hypnosis or treating mental illnesses. And if I change professions again, I teach singing, geography; sometimes I give a few lectures. Oh, I do many things. Whatever comes my way, I do it, so I don't stick to anything for long. So, what do you do for a living?
tr: “I am a master printer who grew up in the trade; I know a bit about medicines; I can act – tragedy and such; if I get the chance, I am interested in hypnotism and phrenology, I can read character by looking at the skull; sometimes, for a change, I teach singing and geography; I give sermons – I do a lot of things – I have a finger in every pie, as long as it's not menial work. So what do you do?”
es: —By trade, I am a printing press operator; I work occasionally in over-the-counter medicines; theater actor: tragedy, you know; sometimes a bit of mesmerism and phrenology, when there's an opportunity; singing and geography teacher for a change; a lecture now and then... Well, lots of things; practically anything that comes up, as long as it's not work. What do you specialize in?

en: “I’ve done considerble in the doctoring way in my time. Layin’ on o’ hands is my best holt—for cancer and paralysis, and sich things; and I k’n tell a fortune pretty good when I’ve got somebody along to find out the facts for me. Preachin’s my line, too, and workin’ camp-meetin’s, and missionaryin’ around.”
vi: - In my life, I have been a doctor quite a few times. The main thing is to live by these two hands. Treating cancer, paralysis, and similar conditions. But when someone discovers the truth, it's hard to make a living. Otherwise, I go preaching, attending evangelical camps.
tr: “Once upon a time, I practiced medicine for a long time. Healing with my hands is what I do best – for cancer, paralysis, and similar things; also, if I have a man to gather the necessary information for me, I can read fortunes very well. I also understand preaching; I work in tent meetings and missionary work.”
es: —I have worked quite a bit on the aspect of medicine. What I do best is laying on hands for cancer, paralysis, and things like that, and I don't do badly at fortune-telling when I have someone to find out the details for me. I also work on sermons, open-air preaching, and missions.

en: Nobody never said anything for a while; then the young man hove a sigh and says:
vi: After a while, no one spoke anymore. Then the younger person sighed and said:
tr: No one said anything for a long time; then the young man sighed deeply.
es: For a while, everyone remained silent; then the young man sighed and said:

en: “Alas!”
vi: - Oh my God!
tr: “Ah, what a pity!”
es: —Ouch!

en: “What ’re you alassin’ about?” says the baldhead.
vi: The bald old man asked: - What the heck?
tr: “What are you lamenting?” asked the bald-headed one.
es: —What are you complaining about? —asked the bald man.

en: “To think I should have lived to be leading such a life, and be degraded down into such company.” And he begun to wipe the corner of his eye with a rag.
vi: - I think that I have to keep living this kind of life forever, and then gradually lose my dignity among my fellow human beings like this? After speaking, she raised the handkerchief to dab at the corners of her eyes.
tr: "That I have come to live such a life, that I have fallen so low as to live among such people." He began to wipe the corner of his eye with a cloth.
es: —To think that I could have had such an easy life and now find myself reduced to this company —and he began to dry his eye with a cloth. —Blessed be!

en: “Dern your skin, ain’t the company good enough for you?” says the baldhead, pretty pert and uppish.
vi: The old man asked again with a tone that seemed authoritative:
tr: The bald-headed one brazenly stood up: "Oh really, do we not look good enough for you?"
es: Don't you think this company is good? —asks the bald man, very dignified and angry.

en: “Yes, it is good enough for me; it’s as good as I deserve; for who fetched me so low when I was so high? I did myself. I don’t blame you, gentlemen—far from it; I don’t blame anybody. I deserve it all. Let the cold world do its worst; one thing I know—there’s a grave somewhere for me. The world may go on just as it’s always done, and take everything from me—loved ones, property, everything; but it can’t take that. Some day I’ll lie down in it and forget it all, and my poor broken heart will be at rest.” He went on a-wiping.
vi: - It's tough, poor thing, but are the people traveling with you nice? - Yes, they treat me quite well. I can tolerate it. Moreover, who dares to belittle me while I am like this. Only I can belittle myself. I do not avoid you people, I do not avoid anyone. I endure everything. No matter where this cold life leads to the most painful place, let it lead. But one thing I know for sure is that there will be a grave waiting for me somewhere. Let life go on as it has always gone on, and take everything from me - loved ones, property, everything. But how can it take away that grave. One day, I will close my eyes and forget everything, and my broken, suffering heart will rest. He said that and then wiped his tears again.
tr: “No way, you’re fine, you’re good; besides, this is what I deserve anyway, isn’t someone like me who fell from the top to here worthy of this? I brought this upon myself. I am not blaming you, gentlemen… Don’t even think such a thing; I am not blaming anyone. I deserved all of it. Let the merciless life do its worst; the only thing I know is… there is a grave somewhere for me too. No matter how this world turns, even if it takes everything from me – my loved ones, my possessions, everything – it cannot take this from me. One day I will enter that grave and forget everything, and at that moment my broken heart will find peace.” He started to cry.
es: —Yes, it is good enough; it is the most I deserve, for who brought me so low when I was born so high? Myself. I do not blame you, gentlemen, far from it; I blame no one, I deserve it all. Let the cold world perpetuate its revenge; one thing I know: somewhere a grave awaits me. The world can continue as it always has and take everything from me: loved ones, possessions, everything; but that it cannot take from me. Someday I will lie in it and forget everything, and my poor broken heart will be able to rest —and he continued to dry an eye.

en: “Drot your pore broken heart,” says the baldhead; “what are you heaving your pore broken heart at us f’r? We hain’t done nothing.”
vi: The bald old man said: - Why are you dragging your broken, suffering heart to us? What have we done to you?
tr: “Damn your poor broken heart,” said the bald-headed man; “why are you pinning that poor broken heart on us? What did we do to you?”
es: —Bless your poor broken heart —says the bald man—; what broken heart are you talking about? We haven't done anything.

en: “No, I know you haven’t. I ain’t blaming you, gentlemen. I brought myself down—yes, I did it myself. It’s right I should suffer—perfectly right—I don’t make any moan.”
vi: - I know you people won't do anything to me. I don't avoid you, it's just that I bring myself down, so I have to endure everything, I don't dare to complain at all.
tr: “I know you didn't do anything. I'm not blaming you, gentlemen. The reason for my downfall is me… I am responsible for all of it. It is right for me to suffer… This is the most correct… I'm not complaining.”
es: —No, I know that. I do not blame you, gentlemen. I have debased myself; yes, I alone. It is fair that I now suffer, perfectly fair; I cannot complain.

en: “Brought you down from whar? Whar was you brought down from?”
vi: - Where did you lower yourself? Where exactly?
tr: “Where did you fall from? What caused you to fall?”
es: —Lowered from what? What have you lowered yourself from?

en: “Ah, you would not believe me; the world never believes—let it pass—’tis no matter. The secret of my birth—”
vi: - Even if I say it, no one will believe me. But never mind, it doesn't matter. The secret of my life.
tr: “Ah, you wouldn't believe me; no one in the world would believe me... Never mind... It's not important. The secret of my birth...”
es: —Ah, you wouldn't believe me; the world never believes... but leave it; it doesn't matter. The secret of my birth...

en: “The secret of your birth! Do you mean to say—”
vi: - Your secret life? Are you trying to say that...
tr: “What was the secret at his birth?” “What do you mean?””
es: —The secret of your birth! Are you going to tell us...?

en: “Gentlemen,” says the young man, very solemn, “I will reveal it to you, for I feel I may have confidence in you. By rights I am a duke!”
vi: - Gentlemen - he said solemnly - I will reveal to you, because I see that I can trust you. I myself am a Duke.
tr: The young man said with great seriousness, "Gentlemen; I will reveal my secret to you, because I feel that I can trust you." "I am the son of a duke!"
es: —Gentlemen —says the young man very solemnly—, I will reveal it to you, for I believe I can trust you. In reality, I am a duke!

en: Jim’s eyes bugged out when he heard that; and I reckon mine did, too. Then the baldhead says: “No! you can’t mean it?”
vi: Hearing that, Jim's eyes widened, and it seemed mine did too. Then the bald old man said:
tr: When Jim heard this, his eyes popped out of their sockets; surely, my eyes must have popped out too. Upon this, the bald man started to speak:
es: Jim's eyes popped out when he heard it, and I think mine did too. Then the bald guy goes and says: —No! You can't mean it!

en: “Yes. My great-grandfather, eldest son of the Duke of Bridgewater, fled to this country about the end of the last century, to breathe the pure air of freedom; married here, and died, leaving a son, his own father dying about the same time. The second son of the late duke seized the titles and estates—the infant real duke was ignored. I am the lineal descendant of that infant—I am the rightful Duke of Bridgewater; and here am I, forlorn, torn from my high estate, hunted of men, despised by the cold world, ragged, worn, heart-broken, and degraded to the companionship of felons on a raft!”
vi: - Nonsense, how could that be. - Yes, my grandfather's father was the eldest son of the Duke of Bilgewater; he fled to this land around the end of the last century to breathe the fresh air of freedom; then he married there, and died, leaving behind a son. The Duke of Bilgewater also passed away around that time. The second son of the duke inherited the title along with all the property, but my grandfather's father, who was the rightful duke, was abandoned. Thus, I should have been the Duke of Bilgewater. Yet here I am now, in such a pitiful state. I am shunned, treated with cold contempt; my life is tattered, wandering, painful, and reduced to the lowest state, having to associate with the wretched on every raft.
tr: “No way! You can't be serious, right?” “Yes. My great-great-grandfather was the eldest son of the Duke of Bridgewater; he fled to this country at the end of the last century to breathe the pure air of freedom; he married here; when he died, leaving behind a son, his own father had also died. The deceased duke's second son seized the title and estates – the true baby duke was ignored. I am descended from that baby – the right to be the Duke of Bridgewater is mine; but here I am, in a wretched state, stripped of my estates and nobility, people are chasing after me; this cruel world hates me; my clothes are in tatters, I am worn out, my heart is broken, and I have fallen so low as to travel on a raft with outlaws!”
es: —Yes. My great-grandfather, the eldest son of the Duke of Aguasclaras, fled to this country at the end of the last century to breathe the pure air of freedom; he married here and died, leaving a son at the very moment his own father passed away. The second son of the late duke seized the titles and estates, and the true duke, newly born, was disinherited. I am the direct descendant of that child: I am the true Duke of Aguasclaras, and here I am, forgotten, stripped of my own possessions, persecuted by men, despised by the cold world, ragged, worn out, with a broken heart, and reduced to the company of criminals on a raft!

en: Jim pitied him ever so much, and so did I. We tried to comfort him, but he said it warn’t much use, he couldn’t be much comforted; said if we was a mind to acknowledge him, that would do him more good than most anything else; so we said we would, if he would tell us how. He said we ought to bow when we spoke to him, and say “Your Grace,” or “My Lord,” or “Your Lordship”—and he wouldn’t mind it if we called him plain “Bridgewater,” which, he said, was a title anyway, and not a name; and one of us ought to wait on him at dinner, and do any little thing for him he wanted done.
vi: Jim felt very sorry for him after hearing that. So did I. We intended to find a way to comfort him, but he said comforting was useless; no one could comfort him anymore. He said that if we wanted to acknowledge him as he was, it would be better than anything else. We said: fine, we would acknowledge him, but he had to tell us how. He said that whenever we talked to him, we had to bow and say "Your Grace," "Your Lordship," and so on... and if we called him by the name Bilgewater, it was okay too, saying that name was just a title, not a name; and he also said that one of us had to stand by when he ate and drank; and had to do all the little tasks he ordered.
tr: Jim felt very sorry for him, and so did I. We tried to comfort him, but he said it wouldn't work, that he was beyond consolation; he said that if we showed the courtesy of accepting his dukedom, we would be doing him a kindness beyond anything else; we said we would be happy to do so if he told us how. When speaking with him, we had to bow and address him as "Your Excellency," "Your Lordship," or "Honorable Duke" – although it was also acceptable to simply call him "Bridgewater" – because that was not his name, but his title; additionally, one of us had to serve him at meals and attend to his small requests.
es: Jim felt very sorry for him, and so did I. We tried to console him, but he said it was no use, that he couldn't be consoled much; he said that if we wanted to acknowledge his dignity, that would serve him more comfort than anything in the world, so we promised to do so if he told us how. He said we should bow when speaking to him and say "your grace," or "milord," or "your lordship," and that he didn't mind if we simply called him "Clearwaters," because, as he said, that was a title and not a name, and one of us would have to serve him at mealtimes and do all the little things he wanted.

en: Well, that was all easy, so we done it. All through dinner Jim stood around and waited on him, and says, “Will yo’ Grace have some o’ dis or some o’ dat?” and so on, and a body could see it was mighty pleasing to him.
vi: All those measurements weren't difficult, so we obediently followed along. Throughout the entire lunch, Jim stood around serving him and said, "Does the Duke need this, need that?" and so on...
tr: All of this was very easy, and we did it too. During the meal, Jim stood up and served him, asking, "Would His Excellency like a bit of this or that?"
es: Well, that turned out to be easy, so we did it. Jim spent the entire dinner standing, serving him and saying, "Would your grace like to try a bit of this or that?" and so on, and it was easy to see that he found it very pleasant.

en: But the old man got pretty silent by-and-by—didn’t have much to say, and didn’t look pretty comfortable over all that petting that was going on around that duke. He seemed to have something on his mind. So, along in the afternoon, he says:
vi: The Duke seemed very pleased. But the old man remained silent and said nothing. He seemed very annoyed with the demeanor of that duke. It seemed like he was thinking about something. By the end of the afternoon, he said:
tr: It was clear that the man was very pleased with this situation. But the old man had become silent; he seemed to be increasingly disturbed by our circling around the shop and serving him. I think he had something on his mind too. In the afternoon, he started talking to the duke at some point:
es: But the old man remained very silent; he didn't have much to say and didn't seem very pleased with all the attention the duke was getting. He seemed to be thinking about something. So in the afternoon, he goes and says:

en: “Looky here, Bilgewater,” he says, “I’m nation sorry for you, but you ain’t the only person that’s had troubles like that.”
vi: - Hey, Bilgewater, I really sympathize with you. But you're not the only one facing such difficulties.
tr: “Look at me, Bridgewater,” he said, “I am very sorry for you, but you are not the only one with such problems?”
es: —Look, Aguassucias —he goes and says—, I feel really bad for you, but you're not the only one who has had problems of that kind.

en: “No?”
vi: - Not so?
tr: "Am I not?""
es: —No?

en: “No you ain’t. You ain’t the only person that’s ben snaked down wrongfully out’n a high place.”
vi: - That's right. You are not the only one who has been blatantly brought down like that!
tr: "No; you are not. You are not the only person who has been unjustly brought down from a high position."
es: —No, you are not the only one. You are not the only one who has been thrown out of the heights in a bad way.

en: “Alas!”
vi: - Heavens!
tr: “What a disaster!”
es: —Ouch!

en: “No, you ain’t the only person that’s had a secret of his birth.” And, by jings, he begins to cry.
vi: - No, you are not the only one who keeps secrets about your life. Upon saying that, I began to cry uncontrollably.
tr: “You are not the only one with a secret about their birth.” This time, the old man started crying.
es: —No, you are not the only one who has a birth secret —and I swear she started to cry.

en: “Hold! What do you mean?”
vi: - Wait a minute, what are you trying to say?
tr: “Wait a minute! What do you mean?”
es: —Wait! What do you mean?

en: “Bilgewater, kin I trust you?” says the old man, still sort of sobbing.
vi: - Bilgewater, can I trust you? - He asked, his voice still trembling.
tr: "Bridgewater, can I trust you?" asked the old man, continuing to sob uncontrollably.
es: —Aguassucias, can I trust you? —asks the old man, still half-crying.

en: “To the bitter death!” He took the old man by the hand and squeezed it, and says, “That secret of your being: speak!”
vi: - I swear to live with it in my heart, and take it to my grave - That man held the old man's hand tightly, then continued - Tell me, what is the secret of your life?
tr: "You can take my life, but you can't take my secret!" Holding the old man's hand tightly, "Your secret is safe with me. Tell me!" he said.
es: —Even the cruelest of deaths! —he took the old man by the hand, squeezed it, and said—: That secret of yours: speak!

en: “Bilgewater, I am the late Dauphin!”
vi: - Bilgewater, I am the crown prince.
tr: “Bridgewater; I am the heir to the French throne who was thought to be dead!”
es: —Dirty waters, I am the missing dolphin!

en: You bet you, Jim and me stared this time. Then the duke says:
vi: This time, both Jim and I stared wide-eyed at the old man. The duke asked:
tr: Jim and I were left standing with our mouths agape this time. The Duke felt the need to repeat:
es: You can bet that Jim and I kept our eyes wide open that time. Then the duke says:

en: “You are what?”
vi: - What did you say?
tr: “What are you?”
es: —What are you?

en: “Yes, my friend, it is too true—your eyes is lookin’ at this very moment on the pore disappeared Dauphin, Looy the Seventeen, son of Looy the Sixteen and Marry Antonette.”
vi: - Yes, my friend, what I just said is true. At this moment, in your eyes is the poor prince, Louis the Seventeenth, and here are Louis the Sixteenth and Marie Antoinette.
tr: “Yes, my friend, this is true… these eyes are looking right now at the poor, lost heir; I am Louis XVII; the son of Louis XVI and Marie Antoinette.”
es: —Yes, my friend, it is true: you are looking at this moment at the poor missing dolphin, Louis the 17th, son of Louis the 16th, and Marie Antoinette.

en: “You! At your age! No! You mean you’re the late Charlemagne; you must be six or seven hundred years old, at the very least.”
vi: - Is that you? Are you really this old? If you were the last Charlemagne, you would be six hundred years old by now.
tr: "Is it you? At this age? Impossible! Are you saying you are the last Charlemagne? You should be at least six hundred – seven hundred years old though."
es: —You! At your age! No! You mean to say that you are the late Charlemagne; you must be at least six or seven hundred years old.

en: “Trouble has done it, Bilgewater, trouble has done it; trouble has brung these gray hairs and this premature balditude. Yes, gentlemen, you see before you, in blue jeans and misery, the wanderin’, exiled, trampled-on, and sufferin’ rightful King of France.”
vi: - Because hardships have turned me into such a wretched person, Bilgewater. Hardships have made my hair turn completely white and ask like this. Before your eyes, this person in filthy blue clothes, who has been wandering, tormented, trampled upon, and in pain, is the King of France.
tr: “Troubles have brought me to this state, Bridgewater; I have fallen into this condition because of my troubles; these gray hairs, this bald head are all due to distress and suffering. Yes, gentlemen; before you stands the legitimate King of France, wandering in misery, exiled, trampled underfoot, wearing blue jeans.”
es: —There have been so many problems, Aguassucias, so many problems that have turned my hair gray and brought this premature baldness. Yes, gentlemen, before you stands, dressed in cowboy clothes and in misery, the vagabond, the exiled, the persecuted, and the suffering legitimate king of France.

en: Well, he cried and took on so that me and Jim didn’t know hardly what to do, we was so sorry—and so glad and proud we’d got him with us, too. So we set in, like we done before with the duke, and tried to comfort him. But he said it warn’t no use, nothing but to be dead and done with it all could do him any good; though he said it often made him feel easier and better for a while if people treated him according to his rights, and got down on one knee to speak to him, and always called him “Your Majesty,” and waited on him first at meals, and didn’t set down in his presence till he asked them. So Jim and me set to majestying him, and doing this and that and t’other for him, and standing up till he told us we might set down. This done him heaps of good, and so he got cheerful and comfortable. But the duke kind of soured on him, and didn’t look a bit satisfied with the way things was going; still, the king acted real friendly towards him, and said the duke’s great-grandfather and all the other Dukes of Bilgewater was a good deal thought of by his father, and was allowed to come to the palace considerable; but the duke stayed huffy a good while, till by-and-by the king says:
vi: After speaking, the old man kept crying, making Jim and me not know what to do. We often felt sorry for him and proud too because he came here with us. So we went to comfort him, as we had comforted the duke before. But he said that comforting was useless, only death could relieve him of all his sorrows. But he also felt better when we treated him in certain ways, like kneeling on one knee when speaking to him, always addressing him as "Your Majesty," standing by his side when he ate and drank, and not sitting in his presence unless he permitted it. So Jim and I had to address him as "Your Majesty," do various things for him, and stand until he allowed us to sit. That made him very pleased, showing great joy and amusement. But the duke felt uncomfortable about this. Nevertheless, the King still showed great intimacy with the duke. He said that all the dukes of Bilgewater were remembered by his father and were always invited to the palace. But the duke seemed annoyed. A moment later, the King spoke again:
tr: He cried and whined so much that Jim and I didn't know what to do, we were very upset – but we were also very pleased and proud to be with him. So we tried to comfort him just as we had done with the duke before. But he said it wouldn't do any good, nothing would help him except dying and getting rid of everything; although he said he would feel a little better if people treated him as he deserved; they should kneel on one knee while talking to him; call him "Your Majesty," serve him first at meals, and not sit down until he gave permission. So Jim and I started calling him your majesty, doing this and that for him, and standing until he told us we could sit. What we did made him feel very good, he became a cheerful and relaxed man again. But this time the duke was frowning; he didn't seem at all pleased with the turn of events; still, the king was really friendly to him, saying that his father loved the duke's great-great-grandfather and the other Dukes of Bridgewater very much and often invited them to the palace; but when the duke couldn't shake off his resentment for a while, the king finally said:
es: Well, he burst into tears and got so upset that neither Jim nor I knew what to do, feeling both sorry for him and at the same time happy and proud that he was on the raft with us. So we set to work, just as we had done before with the duke, and tried to console him as well. But he said it was no use, that the only thing that could console him was to die once and for all and end everything; although he said that sometimes he felt more comfortable and better if people treated him according to his rights, knelt down to speak to him, always called him "your majesty" and served him first at meals and did not sit in his presence until he said so. So Jim and I started to "majesty" him, doing everything he asked of us and standing until he told us we could sit down. That made him feel really good and he became very cheerful and happy. But the duke seemed to get angry with him and didn't seem at all satisfied with how things were going; but the king was very friendly with him and said that the duke's great-grandfather and all the other dukes of Aguassucias had the highest regard for his father and could visit the palace many times, but the duke remained angry for quite a while, until finally the king goes and says:

en: “Like as not we got to be together a blamed long time on this h-yer raft, Bilgewater, and so what’s the use o’ your bein’ sour? It’ll only make things oncomfortable. It ain’t my fault I warn’t born a duke, it ain’t your fault you warn’t born a king—so what’s the use to worry? Make the best o’ things the way you find ’em, says I—that’s my motto. This ain’t no bad thing that we’ve struck here—plenty grub and an easy life—come, give us your hand, Duke, and le’s all be friends.”
vi: - We won't be on this wooden raft together for much longer, Bilgewater, so why are you sad? I was not born a duke, it's not my fault. You were not born a king, it's not your fault either. So why worry about it? Accepting and making the best of our circumstances is what we should do. Moreover, life here isn't too uncomfortable, food and drink are still plentiful. Come on, let's shake hands, duke, we are friends after all.
tr: “It looks like we will stay on this raft for quite a long time; Bridgewater; what's the use of making a face? You only make things more uncomfortable. It's not my fault that I wasn't born a Duke, and it's not your fault that you weren't born a king… They say, 'A sharp vinegar harms its own container.' Appreciate what you have, that's what I say… That is my motto. It's not a bad thing that we ended up here… There's plenty of food, we're in high spirits… Come on, give me your hand Duke, let's all be friends now.”
es: —The most likely thing is that we are going to spend a lot of time on this raft, Dirtywaters, so, what good is it to get angry? It only serves to annoy us. It's not my fault I wasn't born a duke and it's not your fault you weren't born a king, so why worry? What I say is that we have to make the most of things as they are: that's my motto. And it's not bad luck to have ended up here: good food and an easy life; come on, give me your hand, duke, and let's be friends.

en: The duke done it, and Jim and me was pretty glad to see it. It took away all the uncomfortableness and we felt mighty good over it, because it would a been a miserable business to have any unfriendliness on the raft; for what you want, above all things, on a raft, is for everybody to be satisfied, and feel right and kind towards the others.
vi: The Duke reached out his hand to shake. Jim and I were glad to see that. The heavy atmosphere suddenly dissipated, and we felt happy as well. On a raft, everyone must be cheerful and harmonious with each other for life to be bearable for a few moments.
tr: When the Duke did what he said, Jim and I were very happy. All our discomforts flew away, we felt very good, because there is nothing as terrible as resentment on a raft; the first thing you want on a raft is for everyone to be satisfied, to treat others correctly and well.
es: The duke gave it to her, and Jim and I were very glad to see that. So we stopped feeling annoyed and were very happy because it would have been a shame not to get along on the raft; because the first thing you need on a raft is for everyone to be happy, to feel good, and to get along with each other.

en: It didn’t take me long to make up my mind that these liars warn’t no kings nor dukes at all, but just low-down humbugs and frauds. But I never said nothing, never let on; kept it to myself; it’s the best way; then you don’t have no quarrels, and don’t get into no trouble. If they wanted us to call them kings and dukes, I hadn’t no objections, ’long as it would keep peace in the family; and it warn’t no use to tell Jim, so I didn’t tell him. If I never learnt nothing else out of pap, I learnt that the best way to get along with his kind of people is to let them have their own way.
vi: Before long, I realized that these two guys were not kings or dukes at all but just swindlers and thieves. But I didn't say a word or show any attitude. That was the best way to avoid troublesome arguments. If they wanted to be called kings or dukes, I would call them that as long as it kept the peace. I didn't tell Jim either because it wouldn't do any good. If I hadn't learned anything else from my father, I learned one thing here: just live with people like this and let them do whatever they want.
tr: It didn't take me long to realize that these two liars were not a king or a duke, but mere braggarts and frauds. But I definitely didn't open my mouth, I didn't reveal that I understood; that was the best, then you don't have to argue, and you don't get into trouble. If they wanted us to call them king and duke, I wouldn't object as long as we could maintain peace in the family; besides, it wouldn't have been useful to explain this to Jim, so I didn't. If I learned nothing else from my father, I learned that the only way to get along with people like him was not to mess with them.
es: It didn't take me long to realize that those liars were not kings or dukes at all, but the lowest of swindlers and frauds. But I never said anything or revealed it; I kept it to myself; it's the best way; that way there are no fights and you don't get into trouble. If they wanted us to call them kings and dukes, I had no objection, as long as there was peace in the family, and it was no use telling Jim, so I didn't. If I learned anything from my father, it's that the best way to get along with people like that is to let them go their own way.

en: CHAPTER XX.
vi: Chapter XX
tr: Chapter Twenty
es: Chapter 20

en: They asked us considerable many questions; wanted to know what we covered up the raft that way for, and laid by in the daytime instead of running—was Jim a runaway nigger? Says I:
vi: They asked me a lot of questions: Why did we cover the raft like that? Why did we rest during the day and travel at night? Is Jim the black man who is running away? I said:
tr: The duke and the king asked us a lot of questions; they wondered why we hid on Tuesday, why we hid during the day instead of escaping – or was Jim a runaway black man? “For God's sake,” I said, “do runaway negroes go south?”
es: THEY ASKED us a bunch of questions; they wanted to know why we were hiding the raft like that and resting during the day instead of moving forward: Was Jim a runaway slave? I answered: —For God's sake!

en: “Goodness sakes, would a runaway nigger run south?”
vi: - Oh my God, when has there ever been a black man running away to the South?
tr: “For God's sake,” I said, “do runaway negroes go south?”
es: Would a runaway slave flee to the South?

en: No, they allowed he wouldn’t. I had to account for things some way, so I says:
vi: They said that wasn't true. I immediately replied:
tr: No; they said it wouldn't go. But I still needed to explain what had happened somehow. I began to explain:
es: No, they admitted that they didn't. I had to explain things somehow, so I said:

en: “My folks was living in Pike County, in Missouri, where I was born, and they all died off but me and pa and my brother Ike. Pa, he ’lowed he’d break up and go down and live with Uncle Ben, who’s got a little one-horse place on the river, forty-four mile below Orleans. Pa was pretty poor, and had some debts; so when he’d squared up there warn’t nothing left but sixteen dollars and our nigger, Jim. That warn’t enough to take us fourteen hundred mile, deck passage nor no other way. Well, when the river rose pa had a streak of luck one day; he ketched this piece of a raft; so we reckoned we’d go down to Orleans on it. Pa’s luck didn’t hold out; a steamboat run over the forrard corner of the raft one night, and we all went overboard and dove under the wheel; Jim and me come up all right, but pa was drunk, and Ike was only four years old, so they never come up no more. Well, for the next day or two we had considerable trouble, because people was always coming out in skiffs and trying to take Jim away from me, saying they believed he was a runaway nigger. We don’t run daytimes no more now; nights they don’t bother us.”
vi: - My family is in Pike, Missouri. My whole family is dead, only my father, my younger brother Ike, and I are left. My father left home to stay with my uncle Ben. My uncle has a motorboat that ferries passengers across the river, down below, forty-four miles from Orleans. My father is very poor and in debt. So when my father left, he didn't leave anything behind except sixteen dollars and a black man named Jim. With that little money, we couldn't make the journey by steamboat or any other means. Then the flood came, and my father luckily got a raft, and we decided to go to Orleans. But unfortunately, one night a steamboat hit one side of the raft. We jumped into the river, diving deep to avoid the paddle wheel; Jim and I escaped unharmed. But my father, who was drunk at the time, and my four-year-old brother Ike did not resurface. A few days later, we faced many difficulties because there were people on boats in the middle of the river trying to catch Jim, claiming he was a runaway black man. So now we don't travel during the day anymore, but at night to avoid trouble.
tr: “My family lived in Pike County, Missouri; I was born there. They all passed away, leaving no one but my father and my brother Ike. My father said we would leave everything behind and go down the river to stay with Uncle Ben. Uncle Ben had a nice little piece of land on the river, forty-four miles below Orleans. My father was very poor and had accumulated debts; so when he gathered everything, he only had sixteen dollars and our black servant Jim left. Even if we slept on the deck, this money wouldn't be enough to take us fourteen hundred miles. Then, when the river rose, my father got lucky and caught this piece of raft; we thought we could go to Orleans by raft. But my father's luck didn't last; one night while on the way, a steamboat passed by the corner of the front of the raft, we all tumbled into the water and dived to avoid the paddlewheel. Jim and I managed to come back up, but my father was drunk, and Ike was only four years old, they never surfaced again. For the next couple of days, we were in constant trouble because people coming in boats tried to take Jim away from me, saying he was a runaway slave. So we no longer travel during the day; no one bothers us at night.”
es: —My family lived in Pike County, Missouri, where I was born, and they all died except for me, father, and my brother Ike. Father said he preferred to leave and go live with Uncle Ben, who has a little house by the river, forty-four miles down from Orleans. Father was very poor and we had some debts, so when he settled everything, there were only sixteen dollars left and our black man, Jim. That wasn't enough to travel fourteen hundred miles, neither on deck nor in any other way. Well, when the river rose, father had a stroke of luck one day; he found this raft, so we thought of going to Orleans on it. Father's luck didn't last long; a steamboat took off the front corner of the raft one night and we all fell into the water and dove under the wheel; Jim and I came out fine, but father was drunk and Ike was only four years old, so they never came out again. For a few days we had a lot of trouble, because people kept coming in boats and trying to take Jim, saying they thought he was a runaway black man. That's why we no longer sail during the day; at night they don't bother us.

en: The duke says:
vi: The Duke said:
tr: “Give me some time,” said the duke.
es: The duke goes and says:

en: “Leave me alone to cipher out a way so we can run in the daytime if we want to. I’ll think the thing over—I’ll invent a plan that’ll fix it. We’ll let it alone for to-day, because of course we don’t want to go by that town yonder in daylight—it mightn’t be healthy.”
vi: - Let me think if there's a way to travel during the day. I'll think about it first. I'll come up with a trick that might solve this. For today, let's not rush into it, because obviously, we shouldn't pass through that town during the day, in case something bad happens.
tr: “I will think of a way for us to be able to travel during the day when necessary. After thoroughly considering the matter... I will make a plan that will set everything right. Let's continue like this for today, because we certainly don't want to pass through that town ahead during the day; it might not be very safe.”
es: —Let me think of a way that we can sail during the day if we wish. I will think about it and come up with a plan to organize ourselves. Today we will continue like this because naturally we do not want to pass through that village over there in the daylight, it might not be healthy.

en: Towards night it begun to darken up and look like rain; the heat lightning was squirting around low down in the sky, and the leaves was beginning to shiver—it was going to be pretty ugly, it was easy to see that. So the duke and the king went to overhauling our wigwam, to see what the beds was like. My bed was a straw tick better than Jim’s, which was a corn-shuck tick; there’s always cobs around about in a shuck tick, and they poke into you and hurt; and when you roll over the dry shucks sound like you was rolling over in a pile of dead leaves; it makes such a rustling that you wake up. Well, the duke allowed he would take my bed; but the king allowed he wouldn’t. He says:
vi: At night, the sky began to darken and it looked like it was about to rain. Lightning flashed at the horizon. The Duke and the King came into our tent to see how the sleeping arrangements were. My bed was a straw mat, but it was much more comfortable than Jim's, which was a nest made of corn stalks. The corn stalks were stiff, and every time he turned, the dry leaves rustled, waking him up. The Duke demanded to sleep on my bed, but the King refused. He said:
tr: Towards the evening, the sky clouded over, it was going to rain; lightning was flashing on the horizon, the sound of which did not reach us, and the leaves had started to tremble – a very harsh weather was coming, it was not hard to understand this. The Duke and the King went to inspect our shelter to see how the beds were. The inside of my mattress was filled with straw and it was more comfortable than Jim's corn husk mattress; the husks would remain inside the mattress, poke your back, and hurt you; moreover, when you turned in bed, the dried husks would make a sound as if you were lying in a pile of dry leaves; they would creak so much that you would wake up. The Duke said he would take my bed, but the King did not allow it.
es: Towards the night it began to cloud over and it seemed like it was going to rain; the lightning flashed very low across the sky and the leaves were starting to tremble: it was going to be quite strong, it was easy to see. So the duke and the king started to prepare our wigwam to see how the beds were. Mine was made of straw, better than Jim's, who had a mattress made of corn leaves; in those corn mattresses there are always grains that get into your skin and hurt, and when you turn over, the dry corn leaves sound like you're crushing a bed of dead leaves and make so much noise that they wake you up. Well, the duke preferred to stay with my bed, but the king said no. He pointed out:

en: “I should a reckoned the difference in rank would a sejested to you that a corn-shuck bed warn’t just fitten for me to sleep on. Your Grace’ll take the shuck bed yourself.”
vi: - You should know that in terms of rank and position, I am no more suited to a bed made of corn stalks than you are. Therefore, you should know your place and understand that lying on that bed is the most appropriate...
tr: “I thought the difference in our positions would remind you that it is not appropriate for me to sleep in the bed with the tassels. Your Excellency should sleep in the bed with the tassels.”
es: —I would say that the difference in rank would suggest to you that a corn mattress is not the most suitable for me. Your grace will stay with the corn bed.

en: Jim and me was in a sweat again for a minute, being afraid there was going to be some more trouble amongst them; so we was pretty glad when the duke says:
vi: Jim and I were sweating with fear that the two of them would cause trouble again. But fortunately, the duke said:
tr: Jim and I had started to worry again, fearing that there would be trouble between them; so we were relieved by the duke's response:
es: Jim and I started to worry again for a moment, as we feared there might be more trouble between them, so we were very relieved when the duke went ahead and said:

en: “’Tis my fate to be always ground into the mire under the iron heel of oppression. Misfortune has broken my once haughty spirit; I yield, I submit; ’tis my fate. I am alone in the world—let me suffer; I can bear it.”
vi: - My fate is unlucky wherever I go. The suffering and pain that I have endured up to now have made me lose all my spirit. I surrender. That's just how my fate is. In this world, only I am lonely... Please let me suffer, I can endure it.
tr: “It is my fate to be muddied under the iron heel of the mighty. Misfortune has long taken away my proud spirit; I bow, I surrender; this is my fate. I am all alone in this world… I must endure my suffering; I can bear it.”
es: —It is my eternal destiny: to always see myself crushed under the iron heel of pressure. Misfortune has broken my once proud spirit; I yield, I submit; it is my destiny. I am alone in the world: suffering falls upon me and I can endure it.

en: We got away as soon as it was good and dark. The king told us to stand well out towards the middle of the river, and not show a light till we got a long ways below the town. We come in sight of the little bunch of lights by-and-by—that was the town, you know—and slid by, about a half a mile out, all right. When we was three-quarters of a mile below we hoisted up our signal lantern; and about ten o’clock it come on to rain and blow and thunder and lighten like everything; so the king told us to both stay on watch till the weather got better; then him and the duke crawled into the wigwam and turned in for the night. It was my watch below till twelve, but I wouldn’t a turned in anyway if I’d had a bed, because a body don’t see such a storm as that every day in the week, not by a long sight. My souls, how the wind did scream along! And every second or two there’d come a glare that lit up the white-caps for a half a mile around, and you’d see the islands looking dusty through the rain, and the trees thrashing around in the wind; then comes a h-whack!—bum! bum! bumble-umble-um-bum-bum-bum-bum—and the thunder would go rumbling and grumbling away, and quit—and then rip comes another flash and another sockdolager. The waves most washed me off the raft sometimes, but I hadn’t any clothes on, and didn’t mind. We didn’t have no trouble about snags; the lightning was glaring and flittering around so constant that we could see them plenty soon enough to throw her head this way or that and miss them.
vi: We set off when it was completely dark. The king ordered us to push the raft to the middle of the river and only light the lamps once we were far enough from the city. A while later, we saw clusters of flickering lights by the river. That was the town. The raft smoothly glided past about half a mile. After nearly a mile, we hung up the lamps. Around ten o'clock at night, it started pouring rain, the wind howled intermittently, and thunder rumbled. The king told the two of us to take turns keeping watch carefully until the weather cleared up completely. Meanwhile, he and the duke crawled into the tent to sleep. I had to keep watch until midnight. But even if I were in bed, I probably wouldn't be able to close my eyes. In fact, it hadn't rained and stormed like this all week. The wind howled intermittently, chillingly. Occasionally, a streak of lightning illuminated the white-tipped land mounds stretching about half a mile. But the island, seen through the rain, looked as if it were covered in a veil of dust. The trees seemed to be whirling in the wind. The sound of crackling and rumbling arose, then gradually spread out into the distance. Waves splashed strongly, soaking me completely on the raft. But since I wasn't wearing any clothes, I wasn't afraid of getting wet. Luckily, thanks to the flashes of lightning, we could see the submerged rocks from afar and avoided hitting them.
tr: As soon as it got dark enough, we set out immediately. The king told us to stay in the middle of the river and not to show any light until we had gone quite a bit downstream of the town. After a while, we saw a small cluster of lights – this cluster was the town – and we passed it without any trouble about half a mile offshore. When we had gone about three-quarters of a mile downstream, we put up the signal lantern; around ten o'clock, it started to rain, and lightning began to illuminate everything around; the king told us both to keep watch until the weather cleared up; then he and the duke went into the shelter to get ready to sleep. The watch on the downstream side was mine until twelve, but even if I had a bed to sleep in, I wouldn't have gone into the shelter; because you can't see such a storm every day, you don't even get the chance to watch it from a distance. My God, how the wind was howling! Almost every second, there was a flash of light illuminating the foamy waves around us within a half-mile distance; we could see blurry islands in the rain and trees flapping in the wind; then crack! – the thunder rumbled and roared away with crashes and booms, then it went silent – then another crack of lightning and again a thunder. The waves were so big they almost knocked me off the raft, but I didn't care since I had no clothes on. The bushes and such that the raft could get caught on were no trouble at all; there was so much lightning that we could see them well in advance and steer the raft around them.
es: We left as soon as it was dark enough. The king told us to head towards the center of the river and not to show any light until we had passed far enough from the town. Soon we came into view of the small cluster of lights that was the town and we slipped by about half a mile away, everything perfectly, everything perfectly. When we were three-quarters of a mile further down, we used our signal lantern, and around ten it started to rain, blow, thunder, and lightning like the devil; so the king told us two to keep watch until the weather improved; then he and the duke crawled into the wigwam to spend the night. I was on watch until twelve, but I wouldn't have gone to bed even if I had one, because you don't see a storm like that every day, not by a long shot. Good heavens, how the wind howled! And every one or two seconds there was a flash that lit up the waves for half a mile around and the islands looked dusty in the rain and the trees swayed in the wind; then there was a brrruuum!... boom! boom! boom, boom, boom, boom, boom, boom! and the thunder rolled away growling and buzzing until it disappeared, and then, wham!, there was another flash and another crash. Sometimes the waves almost knocked me off the raft, but since I wasn't wearing anything, I didn't mind. We had no trouble with the logs coming down; the lightning lit everything up so we could see the logs coming with more than enough time to steer this way or that and avoid them.

en: I had the middle watch, you know, but I was pretty sleepy by that time, so Jim he said he would stand the first half of it for me; he was always mighty good that way, Jim was. I crawled into the wigwam, but the king and the duke had their legs sprawled around so there warn’t no show for me; so I laid outside—I didn’t mind the rain, because it was warm, and the waves warn’t running so high now. About two they come up again, though, and Jim was going to call me; but he changed his mind, because he reckoned they warn’t high enough yet to do any harm; but he was mistaken about that, for pretty soon all of a sudden along comes a regular ripper and washed me overboard. It most killed Jim a-laughing. He was the easiest nigger to laugh that ever was, anyway.
vi: I stood guard halfway through but got too sleepy, Jim said he would guard for me. Jim is always very good to me. I crawled into the tent, but the king and the duke were sprawled all over, leaving no room for me. I had to sleep outside the tent, despite the howling wind and rain. Around two o'clock, the waves became more violent. Jim intended to call me but decided not to because he thought the waves weren't too dangerous yet. But he was wrong, right after that, a big wave surged over my head. Jim looked at me and laughed heartily. The waves kept crashing and splashing all over me. Jim laughed so hard he almost burst. He was a black man who laughed easily, something I rarely encountered.
tr: The second watch was mine, but I was getting really sleepy, so Jim said he could take the first half of my watch; Jim has always been such a kind-hearted person. I bent down and went inside the shelter, but I couldn't find a place for myself because the king and the duke were lying with their legs spread out; so I went back outside – I didn't mind the rain because the weather was warm and the waves weren't rising that much anymore. Around two in the night, the waves rose again, Jim was about to call out to me, but then he changed his mind because he thought the waves hadn't risen enough to cause any harm yet; however, he was wrong about that, because a little later a giant wave came and knocked me into the water. Jim almost died laughing. I've never seen a black man who laughs so easily at everything in my life.
es: It was my turn for the middle watch, you know, but by that time I was quite sleepy, so Jim said he would take the first half; Jim always behaved very well in that regard. I crawled into the wigwam on all fours, but the king and the duke had stretched out so much that there was no room left, so I stayed outside; I didn't mind the rain, because it was warm and now the waves weren't reaching as high. But around two o'clock they started rising again and Jim was going to call me, although he changed his mind because he figured they weren't high enough to do us any harm, but he was wrong because very soon one of those huge ones came and threw me into the water. Jim almost died laughing. Anyway, he was the black man who laughed the most of all those I have known.

en: I took the watch, and Jim he laid down and snored away; and by-and-by the storm let up for good and all; and the first cabin-light that showed, I rousted him out and we slid the raft into hiding quarters for the day.
vi: I went out to stand guard in place of Jim. He had just laid down and was already snoring. Gradually, the storm subsided. At the first light of dawn, I woke Jim up and then steered the raft into hiding.
tr: I took over the watch and Jim immediately lay down and started snoring; the storm was gradually dying down, and when I saw the first cabin light, I woke Jim up and we started looking for a place to hide the raft for the day.
es: I took the watch and Jim lay down and started snoring; after a while the storm subsided and went away, and as soon as we saw the first light of a cabin, I woke him up and we hid the raft in our hiding place for the day.

en: The king got out an old ratty deck of cards after breakfast, and him and the duke played seven-up a while, five cents a game. Then they got tired of it, and allowed they would “lay out a campaign,” as they called it. The duke went down into his carpet-bag, and fetched up a lot of little printed bills and read them out loud.
