They sent the yawl and we boarded; it was from Cincinnati, and when they found out that we only wanted to travel four or five miles, they got furious and cursed us and said they would not disembark us. But the king said very calmly:

en: “If gentlemen kin afford to pay a dollar a mile apiece to be took on and put off in a yawl, a steamboat kin afford to carry ’em, can’t it?”
vi: - If we pay one dollar per mile, will the ship agree to carry the load?
tr: “If gentlemen pay one dollar per mile to be picked up and dropped off by lifeboat, steamships can carry them; isn't that so?”
es: —If the gentlemen can afford a dollar per mile each to be taken up and down in a skiff, then a steamboat can afford to transport them, can't it?

en: So they softened down and said it was all right; and when we got to the village they yawled us ashore. About two dozen men flocked down when they see the yawl a-coming, and when the king says:
vi: Hearing that, they immediately agreed and were no longer angry. Upon reaching the place we indicated, the ship carried us to the shore. More than twenty people rushed out when they saw our boat approaching. The king asked:
tr: Upon this, they softened and said there was no longer a problem, and when we reached the town, they brought us ashore with a lifeboat. When they saw the lifeboat coming, about two dozen men came to the shore.
es: So they softened and said fine, and when we got to the town they took us to the riverbank in the skiff. When they saw it arrive, about two dozen men came down to see it, and when the king said:

en: “Kin any of you gentlemen tell me wher’ Mr. Peter Wilks lives?” they give a glance at one another, and nodded their heads, as much as to say, “What d’ I tell you?” Then one of them says, kind of soft and gentle:
vi: - Can you show me where Mr. Peter Wilks lives? The people looked at each other and shook their heads sadly. But one person replied in a very polite voice:
tr: When the king said to them, "Gentlemen, can you tell me where Mr. Peter Wilks lives?" they first looked at each other and nodded as if to say, "Didn't I tell you?" One of them answered politely and softly:
es: —Can any of you gentlemen tell me where Mr. Peter Wilks lives? —they looked at each other, nodding their heads, as if saying: "What did I tell you?" Then one of them says, in a very kind voice:

en: “I’m sorry sir, but the best we can do is to tell you where he did live yesterday evening.”
vi: - I'm very sorry, sir. But we can only tell you where he was staying last night.
tr: “I'm sorry, sir, but the best thing we can do for you is to tell you where he was staying last night.”
es: —I'm sorry, sir, but the most we can do is tell you where he lived until last night.

en: Sudden as winking the ornery old cretur went an to smash, and fell up against the man, and put his chin on his shoulder, and cried down his back, and says:
vi: Then suddenly, the king burst into tears, hugging the other person tightly, crying and saying:
tr: Our old rascal suddenly shook as if he had been struck, collapsed onto the man, rested his chin on his shoulder, and began crying towards his back:
es: In the blink of an eye, the old rascal began to tremble, let himself fall against the man, resting his chin on his shoulder and crying on his back, and said:

en: “Alas, alas, our poor brother—gone, and we never got to see him; oh, it’s too, too hard!”
vi: - Oh dear, our unfortunate brother has passed away, we will never be able to see his face again! Oh, the pain!
tr: “Ah, what a pity, what a pity, my poor brother... He passed away and we didn't get the chance to see him; oh, how terrible, how terrible!”
es: —Oh, oh, our poor brother... He is gone and we never got to see him! Oh, this is too much, too much!

en: Then he turns around, blubbering, and makes a lot of idiotic signs to the duke on his hands, and blamed if he didn’t drop a carpet-bag and bust out a-crying. If they warn’t the beatenest lot, them two frauds, that ever I struck.
vi: Then the old man turned around and signaled to the duke. So the duke threw the two bags on the ground and burst into tears. I have never seen anyone as cunning as these two before.
tr: Then, amidst sobs, he turned his back and made a bunch of silly gestures at the duke with his hands. The duke also dropped the bag he was holding and started to cry. If I have ever seen men as skilled at their job as these two swindlers, may I be damned.
es: And he turns around whining and makes a series of idiotic signals to the duke with his hands, and I'll be hanged if the duke didn't drop one of the suitcases and start crying. They truly were the most sinister pair of swindlers I have ever seen in my life.

en: Well, the men gathered around and sympathized with them, and said all sorts of kind things to them, and carried their carpet-bags up the hill for them, and let them lean on them and cry, and told the king all about his brother’s last moments, and the king he told it all over again on his hands to the duke, and both of them took on about that dead tanner like they’d lost the twelve disciples. Well, if ever I struck anything like it, I’m a nigger. It was enough to make a body ashamed of the human race.
vi: The crowd gathered around, showing pity, they tried their best to console, then helped carry the two bags up the hill, allowing the two people to lean on their shoulders and cry, and recount everything about the final moments of their brother to the king. As for the king, he used hand signals to communicate with the duke, and both acted as if losing the brother who worked as a tanner was akin to losing a religion. Honestly, I never thought people could be so deceitful.
tr: Anyway, the men gathered around them and said all sorts of things to console them. They carried their bags uphill; they let them cry on their shoulders and told the king everything about his brother's last moments. The king then conveyed all of this to the duke using hand gestures, and both of them lamented for the dead undertaker. Anyone who saw them would think they were mourning the twelve apostles. If I have seen anything like this in my life, let me be a black man. As I watched them, I was ashamed of my humanity.
es: Well, the men formed a group and offered their condolences, they said all kinds of things and carried their suitcases up the hill and let them lean on them and cry, and when they told the king all the details of his brother's last moments, he recounted everything with his hands to the duke and the two of them cried for that dead tanner as if they had lost the twelve disciples. Well, if I ever come across something like that again, then I am a black man. That was enough to feel ashamed of the human race.

en: CHAPTER XXV.
vi: Chapter XXV
tr: Chapter Twenty-Five
es: Chapter 25

en: The news was all over town in two minutes, and you could see the people tearing down on the run from every which way, some of them putting on their coats as they come. Pretty soon we was in the middle of a crowd, and the noise of the tramping was like a soldier march. The windows and dooryards was full; and every minute somebody would say, over a fence:
vi: In just two minutes, the whole town knew the news. They rushed in from all directions. Moments later, we were surrounded by a crowd of people, the noise rumbling like a parade. Everywhere, big doors and small doors were filled with people; every now and then, someone would ask:
tr: The news spread throughout the town in two minutes; I could see people running from all directions, some even trying to put on their jackets while running. Soon we were in the middle of the crowd, moving with as much noise as a regiment of soldiers. The windows and doorways were filled with people; I could see the same words being repeated over and over from over the fences:
es: The NEWS spread throughout the town in two minutes and people could be seen arriving running from all directions, some putting on their jackets. Soon we found ourselves in the middle of a crowd and the sound of footsteps was like that of a marching regiment. The windows and doors were full, and every minute someone would ask, over a fence:

en: “Is it them?”
vi: - Is that them?
tr: "Them?""
es: —Is it them?

en: And somebody trotting along with the gang would answer back and say:
vi: And a voice from the crowd immediately responded:
tr: One of those walking within the crowd was answering:
es: And someone who was trotting along with the group replied:

en: “You bet it is.”
vi: - That's right.
tr: “Of course, they are.”
es: —I bet so.

en: When we got to the house the street in front of it was packed, and the three girls was standing in the door. Mary Jane was red-headed, but that don’t make no difference, she was most awful beautiful, and her face and her eyes was all lit up like glory, she was so glad her uncles was come. The king he spread his arms, and Mary Jane she jumped for them, and the hare-lip jumped for the duke, and there they had it! Everybody most, leastways women, cried for joy to see them meet again at last and have such good times.
vi: We walked to Peter's house, everyone was crowded together, three girls were standing in front of the door. Mary Jane had red hair, but it did not affect her dazzling beauty. She was very happy, her face lit up, her eyes sparkled when she saw the uncles had returned. The king was spreading his arms wide, and Mary Jane jumped over; she ran to the duke with a split lip. Everyone, especially the women, cheered with joy seeing them reunite so warmly.
tr: When we arrived in front of the house, the street was so crowded you couldn't drop a needle, and three girls were waiting for us at the door. Mary Jane was the red-haired one, but it didn't matter, because she was the most strikingly beautiful; her face and eyes seemed to be illuminated by a divine light, and she appeared very pleased that her uncles had arrived. The King opened his arms and Mary Jane threw herself into them, the hare-lipped one threw herself into the Duke's arms, and they all reunited with great affection! Not only the women, but almost everyone cried with joy at their eventual reunion and happiness.
es: When we arrived at the house, the street was full of people and at the door were the three girls. Mary Jane was a redhead, but that doesn't matter: she was the prettiest, and her face and eyes were glowing with joy at seeing her uncles arrive. The king opened his arms and Mary Jane jumped into them, and the one with the cleft lip threw herself into the duke's, and what a scene it was! Almost everyone, at least the women, burst into tears of joy at seeing them reunited again at last, and everyone so happy.

en: Then the king he hunched the duke private—I see him do it—and then he looked around and see the coffin, over in the corner on two chairs; so then him and the duke, with a hand across each other’s shoulder, and t’other hand to their eyes, walked slow and solemn over there, everybody dropping back to give them room, and all the talk and noise stopping, people saying “Sh!” and all the men taking their hats off and drooping their heads, so you could a heard a pin fall. And when they got there they bent over and looked in the coffin, and took one sight, and then they bust out a-crying so you could a heard them to Orleans, most; and then they put their arms around each other’s necks, and hung their chins over each other’s shoulders; and then for three minutes, or maybe four, I never see two men leak the way they done. And, mind you, everybody was doing the same; and the place was that damp I never see anything like it. Then one of them got on one side of the coffin, and t’other on t’other side, and they kneeled down and rested their foreheads on the coffin, and let on to pray all to themselves. Well, when it come to that it worked the crowd like you never see anything like it, and everybody broke down and went to sobbing right out loud—the poor girls, too; and every woman, nearly, went up to the girls, without saying a word, and kissed them, solemn, on the forehead, and then put their hand on their head, and looked up towards the sky, with the tears running down, and then busted out and went off sobbing and swabbing, and give the next woman a show. I never see anything so disgusting.
vi: Then the king winked privately at the duke, then he looked around the house, looked at the coffin placed in the corner of the house, set on two chairs. He, along with the duke, one hand resting on each other's shoulders, the other hand covering their faces, walked slowly and solemnly to the place where the coffin was placed. Everyone stepped back to make room for the two to enter, all the whispering stopped, someone said "shh," then everyone took off their hats, bowed their heads to the coffin, glanced at it, and then both burst into loud sobs that could be heard all the way in Orleans. Then they wrapped their arms around each other's necks, leaned their heads on each other's shoulders, for three minutes or maybe four without separating. Notably, everyone else did the same, making the scene more tragic than ever seen before. Then each stood at one end of the coffin, knelt down, rested their foreheads on the coffin so that everyone around could pray for them. Everyone cried out loud, even those poor girls, then the ladies, no one said a word, solemnly stepped up to kiss their foreheads, then placed their hands on their heads, faces turned up to the sky, tears streaming down, then burst into sobs again, one after another. I have never seen such a despicable scene.
tr: Then the king discreetly nudged the duke with his elbow – but I saw it – then he looked around and saw the coffin placed between two chairs; upon this, the king and the duke put one arm around each other's shoulders and, wiping their eyes with the other arm, they slowly and solemnly walked towards the coffin. Everyone stepped back to make way for them, all conversations and noises ceased; people were saying "Shh!" to each other and all the men took off their hats and bowed their heads; you could hear a pin drop. Our guys reached the head of the coffin, bent over and looked inside, looked again, and then started crying so loudly that you could hear them from Orleans; they put their hands on each other's necks; rested their chins on each other's shoulders; for the next three, even four minutes, they shed more tears than I had ever seen before. Moreover, everyone else was also bawling their eyes out. It was the first time I had seen a place get so damp. Then one of them went to one side of the coffin, the other to the other side, knelt down and rested their foreheads on the coffin and began to pray silently. This had a strange effect on the crowd that I had never seen before, everyone's hearts were broken and they started crying loudly – the poor girls were crying too. Almost all the women headed towards where the girls were, without saying anything, they kissed them on the forehead with great seriousness; placed their hands on their heads and turned their tear-filled eyes upwards, then they too started sobbing and wiping their eyes; they left their place to the next woman. I had never seen anything so nauseating, honestly.
es: Then the king made a private signal to the duke (I saw it) and looked around to see the coffin, placed in a corner on two chairs; then he and the duke, each with one hand on the other's shoulder and the other on their eyes, approached slowly and solemnly, and everyone stepped back to make room for them and stopped talking and making noise while you could hear "shhh!" and all the men took off their hats and bowed their heads, so you could have heard a pin drop. And when they arrived, they leaned over and looked at the coffin, and at the first glance, they started crying so loudly that they could have been heard all the way to Orleans, or almost, and then they threw their arms around each other's necks, resting their chins on each other's shoulders, and for three minutes, or maybe four, I have never seen two men sob like those two. And, mind you, everyone else did the same, and the place started to ooze with moisture like I had never seen before. Then one of them stood on one side of the coffin and the other on the other side, and they knelt and rested their foreheads on the coffin and started to pretend to pray silently. Well, when that happened, people got more emotional than I have ever seen in my life, everyone broke into tears and continued crying out loud; the poor girls too, and almost all the women went to them, without saying a word, and kissed them very solemnly on the forehead, and then placed their hands on their heads looking up to the sky, all full of tears, and left sobbing and staggering to make way for others. I have never seen anything so disgusting.

en: Well, by-and-by the king he gets up and comes forward a little, and works himself up and slobbers out a speech, all full of tears and flapdoodle about its being a sore trial for him and his poor brother to lose the diseased, and to miss seeing diseased alive after the long journey of four thousand mile, but it’s a trial that’s sweetened and sanctified to us by this dear sympathy and these holy tears, and so he thanks them out of his heart and out of his brother’s heart, because out of their mouths they can’t, words being too weak and cold, and all that kind of rot and slush, till it was just sickening; and then he blubbers out a pious goody-goody Amen, and turns himself loose and goes to crying fit to bust.
vi: Later, the king stood up, tears streaming down his face, and began to speak. He said that it was an extremely painful thing for him and his younger brother to have lost a loved one after traveling four thousand miles to return here, only to find that the unfortunate person was no longer alive; then he said that this pain was somewhat alleviated and comforted by the affection of relatives and those sacred tears, and from the bottom of his heart, he thanked everyone, then he once again burst into a series of prayers and turned to cry silently.
tr: After a while, the king stood up, walked a bit forward, composed himself, and began to deliver a slobbering speech, babbling amidst his tears; he talked about how losing the deceased and not being able to see him alive after a long journey of four thousand miles was a painful trial for both himself and his poor brother; but because their sorrows were shared so sincerely and holy tears were shed, it was a sweet and blessed trial; therefore, he was deeply thankful on behalf of both himself and his brother, as words could not express their gratitude because words were too weak and cold; he went on and on with such absurdly emotional things until it made me feel nauseous; then he concluded with a pious but insincere Amen, suddenly relaxed, and started sobbing uncontrollably again.
es: Well, after a while the king gets up, steps forward a bit, gathers his strength, and starts delivering a trembling speech, all full of tears and nonsense, saying how hard it is for him and his poor brother to lose the deceased, and not having managed to see him alive after a long journey of four thousand miles, but it is a trial that is softened and sanctified by this great solidarity and by these sacred tears, so he thanks them from the bottom of his heart, his and his brother's, because they cannot with their mouths, because words are too weak and cold, and all that kind of nonsense and foolishness, until it becomes stomach-churning, and then he whimpers a pious amen, amen, Lord, and lets himself go and starts crying like a madman again.

en: And the minute the words were out of his mouth somebody over in the crowd struck up the doxolojer, and everybody joined in with all their might, and it just warmed you up and made you feel as good as church letting out. Music is a good thing; and after all that soul-butter and hogwash I never see it freshen up things so, and sound so honest and bully.
vi: As soon as the old man finished speaking, someone in the crowd started singing a hymn, and others joined in, making the atmosphere quite eerie. Music really does have an effect. After all the king's empty words, I felt the atmosphere become much cooler and even seemed more honest.
tr: As soon as these last words left his mouth, someone in the crowd began a hymn of gratitude and everyone joined in, shouting at the top of their lungs; this hymn warmed the heart and made one feel good, like when a church service ends. Music is a good thing; after all that spiritual flattery and nonsense, everything felt fresh, and the surroundings were filled with the grandeur of honesty.
es: And at the moment he let that out, someone in the group started singing the Gloria Patri, and everyone joined in with all their might, in such a way that it was very comforting and one felt like being in church. Music is such a good thing that after all those foolishness and lies, I have never seen anything that cleansed the atmosphere more and sounded more honest and more lively.

en: Then the king begins to work his jaw again, and says how him and his nieces would be glad if a few of the main principal friends of the family would take supper here with them this evening, and help set up with the ashes of the diseased; and says if his poor brother laying yonder could speak he knows who he would name, for they was names that was very dear to him, and mentioned often in his letters; and so he will name the same, to wit, as follows, vizz.:—Rev. Mr. Hobson, and Deacon Lot Hovey, and Mr. Ben Rucker, and Abner Shackleford, and Levi Bell, and Dr. Robinson, and their wives, and the widow Bartley.
vi: Then the king continued his blathering.
tr: Then the king's jaw started working again; the family's main friends would join them for dinner that evening and would not leave them alone with the ashes of the deceased; he and his nephews would be very pleased if they did so. Moreover, if his poor brother lying there could speak, he would tell who these friends were, as these names were very valuable to him and he often mentioned them in his letters; therefore, he would name these friends as best as he could remember: Reverend Hobson, assistant pastor Lot Hovey, Mr. Ben Rucker, Abner Shackleford, Levi Bell, Dr. Robinson and their wives, and the widow Mrs. Bartley.
es: Then the king started flapping his gums again, saying that he and his nieces would celebrate by having some of the family's closest friends dine with them that night and help keep vigil over the deceased. He said that if his poor brother lying there could speak, he knows who he would mention, because they were names very dear to him and often mentioned in his letters, so he will name them himself, that is, the following: Reverend Mr. Hobson and Deacon Lot Hovey, and Mr. Ben Rucker, and Abner Shackleford, and Levi Bell, and Dr. Robinson and their wives, and the widow Bartley.

en: Rev. Hobson and Dr. Robinson was down to the end of the town a-hunting together—that is, I mean the doctor was shipping a sick man to t’other world, and the preacher was pinting him right. Lawyer Bell was away up to Louisville on business. But the rest was on hand, and so they all come and shook hands with the king and thanked him and talked to him; and then they shook hands with the duke and didn’t say nothing, but just kept a-smiling and bobbing their heads like a passel of sapheads whilst he made all sorts of signs with his hands and said “Goo-goo—goo-goo-goo” all the time, like a baby that can’t talk.
vi: He said that he and those nieces of his would be very pleased if some of the family's close friends stayed for dinner. He even repeated the names of the close friends he had managed to memorize. They stepped forward to shake the king's hand, thanked him, talked to him; then shook the duke's hand without saying anything, just smiling and nodding.
tr: Reverend Hobson and Dr. Robinson had "gone hunting" on the other side of town; that is, the doctor was sending a sick man to the other world and the reverend was ensuring he didn't lose his way. Lawyer Bell had gone to Louisville for some business. But the rest were there; each one came up and shook the king's hand, expressed their thanks, exchanged a few words; then they shook hands with the duke and, without saying anything, just smiled while the duke made various gestures with his hands and said "Uuu-uuu – uuu-uuu-uuu" like a baby who couldn't speak, and they nodded their heads like fools.
es: The Reverend Hobson and Doctor Robinson were at the other end of the town, hunting together; that is to say, I mean that the doctor was sending a sick person to the other world and the preacher was teaching him the straightest path to get there. The lawyer Bell was in Louisville on business. But the others were all there, so they came to shake the king's hand and thanked him and talked with him, and then they shook the duke's hand and said nothing, but just stood there smiling and nodding like a bunch of idiots while he made all kinds of hand signs and said, "Goo-goo-goo-goo" all the time, like a baby who doesn't know how to talk.

en: So the king he blattered along, and managed to inquire about pretty much everybody and dog in town, by his name, and mentioned all sorts of little things that happened one time or another in the town, or to George’s family, or to Peter. And he always let on that Peter wrote him the things; but that was a lie: he got every blessed one of them out of that young flathead that we canoed up to the steamboat.
vi: Then after that, the king continued to boastfully inquire about everyone, every dog in the province, calling them by name and mentioning countless trivial matters that had happened at various times in the area, or talking about George's or Peter's family. He always mentioned that Peter wrote him letters about those things exactly as the foolish fellow who had just sat on the boat had inadvertently told him.
tr: Upon this, the king started rambling again and asked how almost every person and dog in the town was, mentioning many things that had happened in the town, to George's family, or to Peter's family; he also repeatedly stated that Peter had written all this to him, but this was a complete lie, because he had learned it all from the young fish we had taken by canoe to the steamboat.
es: So the king kept on chattering and managed to ask practically about all the people and even the dogs in the village; he knew everyone's names, and mentioned all sorts of things that had happened at one time or another in the village or to George's family or Peter's. And he always suggested that Peter had told him in his letters, but it was a lie; he had gotten everything out of that poor idiot we went canoeing with to the steamboat.

en: Then Mary Jane she fetched the letter her father left behind, and the king he read it out loud and cried over it. It give the dwelling-house and three thousand dollars, gold, to the girls; and it give the tanyard (which was doing a good business), along with some other houses and land (worth about seven thousand), and three thousand dollars in gold to Harvey and William, and told where the six thousand cash was hid down cellar. So these two frauds said they’d go and fetch it up, and have everything square and above-board; and told me to come with a candle. We shut the cellar door behind us, and when they found the bag they spilt it out on the floor, and it was a lovely sight, all them yaller-boys. My, the way the king’s eyes did shine! He slaps the duke on the shoulder and says:
vi: Then Miss Mary Jane went to get the letter her father had left behind. The king took that letter, read it aloud, and cried again. The letter stated that the house and three thousand gold dollars were left for the daughters; the tannery (worth seven thousand dollars) and three thousand gold dollars were left for Harvey and William. The letter said that all six thousand gold dollars were hidden in the cellar. So the two swindlers said they would go find that money to make things clear and definite. They told me to come along, bringing a candle with me. We stepped down and closed the cellar door. When they saw the bundle of money, they poured it all out onto the ground, looking incredibly bright and beautiful, all shimmering gold! The king's eyes lit up! He slapped the duke on the shoulder and said:
tr: Mary Jane brought the letter left by her father, and the king read it aloud and cried. According to the letter, the house they lived in and three thousand dollars in gold were left to the girls, the tannery (which was doing quite well), the other houses, lands (worth about seven thousand), and three thousand dollars in gold were left to Harvey and William; it also specified where in the cellar the six thousand dollars were hidden. Our two conmen said they would go and get the gold and make everything complete and clear, then they asked me to take a lantern and follow them. We closed the cellar door behind us; when they found the bag, they emptied its contents onto the floor, and those glittering gold coins made a magnificent sight. I was astonished to see how the king's eyes sparkled! He gave the duke a pat on the shoulder with his palm.
es: Then Mary Jane brought the letter that her father had left, and the king read it aloud and began to cry with her. He left the house and three thousand dollars in gold to the girls, and the tannery (which was a good business), along with other houses and lands (worth about seven thousand) and three thousand dollars in gold to Harvey and William, and he said where the six thousand dollars in coins were hidden in the basement. So the two swindlers said they were going to look for it to make everything clear and sent me to go with a candle. We closed the basement door as we entered, and when they found the bag, they opened it on the floor and it was a wonderful sight to see so much gold together: How the king's eyes sparkled! He gives the duke a pat on the shoulder and says:

en: “Oh, this ain’t bully nor noth’n! Oh, no, I reckon not! Why, Bilji, it beats the Nonesuch, don’t it?”
vi: - See? Isn't it wonderful? It's way better than your theatrical performances, right?
tr: "Now, if this isn't what I call hitting the jackpot, then what is!" "Wow! This beats our Curcuna by a mile, doesn't it, Bridgewater?"
es: —This is really worth it! Oh, yes, of course it is! Well, Biljy, it's better than the Peerless, isn't it?

en: The duke allowed it did. They pawed the yaller-boys, and sifted them through their fingers and let them jingle down on the floor; and the king says:
vi: The Duke nodded in acknowledgment. The two people fondled and felt the gold coin, squeezing it repeatedly in their palms, then let it fall to the ground. Then the king said:
tr: The duke agreed with him. They were grabbing the gold coins and then pouring them back onto the pile. “No need for more words,” said the king.
es: The duke acknowledged that he did. They caressed the coins and let them slip through their fingers and clink on the ground, and the king says:

en: “It ain’t no use talkin’; bein’ brothers to a rich dead man and representatives of furrin heirs that’s got left is the line for you and me, Bilge. Thish yer comes of trust’n to Providence. It’s the best way, in the long run. I’ve tried ’em all, and ther’ ain’t no better way.”
vi: - No need to think about it anymore. We are now making a brotherhood with a wealthy dead man. Do you believe in God now? I've managed a lot, there's no better way.
tr: “For both you and me, Bridgewater, the best way is to be the representatives of the heirs left behind by the brothers of a wealthy dead man. If you take refuge in the Creator, this is how your fortune turns. In the long run, this is also the best. Believe me, I have tried everything, this is truly the best.”
es: —There's no need to overthink it; what suits you and me, Aguassucias, is to be the siblings of a rich dead man and representatives of the only remaining foreign heirs. We owe this to Providence. In the long run, it's best to trust in it. I've tried everything, and there's no better solution.

en: Most everybody would a been satisfied with the pile, and took it on trust; but no, they must count it. So they counts it, and it comes out four hundred and fifteen dollars short. Says the king:
vi: Although very happy with the money, the two swindlers still counted it again and were annoyed to find four hundred and fifteen dollars missing. The king said:
tr: Anyone else would have been satisfied with the appearance of this pile and wouldn't have felt the need to count it; but no, they absolutely had to count it. They sat down and counted it one by one and saw that four hundred and fifteen dollars were missing. “That accursed man,” said the king.
es: Almost anyone would have been satisfied with that pile and would have trusted the count, but no, they had to count it. So they count it and it turns out that four hundred fifteen dollars are missing. And then the king says:

en: “Dern him, I wonder what he done with that four hundred and fifteen dollars?”
vi: - Damn it, what did he do with those four hundred and fifteen dollars?
tr: “What did he do with that four hundred and fifteen dollars, I wonder?”
es: —Damn it, what could he have done with those four hundred fifteen dollars?

en: They worried over that awhile, and ransacked all around for it. Then the duke says:
vi: Both of them searched around in the cellar for a while, then the duke said:
tr: For a while, they anxiously turned everything upside down looking for the remaining money. Finally, the duke thought of something else:
es: They stayed thinking about it for a while, looking for an explanation. Then the duke says:

en: “Well, he was a pretty sick man, and likely he made a mistake—I reckon that’s the way of it. The best way’s to let it go, and keep still about it. We can spare it.”
vi: - He must have been too sick and counted wrong. It's better to stay silent. We'll just share the loss there.
tr: “Adam is very sick, he probably made a calculation error... It can't be any other way. It's best if we stop searching and keep quiet. We can manage this much.”
es: —Well, he was quite sick and probably made a mistake... I guess that's what happened. The best thing is to leave it and say nothing. We don't need it.

en: “Oh, shucks, yes, we can spare it. I don’t k’yer noth’n ’bout that—it’s the count I’m thinkin’ about. We want to be awful square and open and above-board here, you know. We want to lug this h-yer money up stairs and count it before everybody—then ther’ ain’t noth’n suspicious. But when the dead man says ther’s six thous’n dollars, you know, we don’t want to—”
vi: - We can bear the loss of that shortage, but we must go up there, open the package, and count the money in front of everyone, so that no one has any doubts. But the deceased said there was a total of six thousand dollars, so we don't want this amount to be short.
tr: “Of course, we'll manage somehow. I'm not thinking about that... What really worries me is what we'll do when the money is being counted. We need to be completely thorough, open, and honest here. We have to take all this money upstairs and count it in front of everyone... Then no one will suspect anything. But when the dead man says there's six thousand dollars here and we count...”
es: —Ah, of course, yes, we don't need it. That doesn't matter to me. What I'm thinking about is the account. In this case, we have to act very clearly, you know. What we need is to take this money upstairs and count it in front of everyone so they can't suspect anything. But when the dead man says there are six thousand dollars, you know it's not convenient for us...

en: “Hold on,” says the duke. “Le’s make up the deffisit,” and he begun to haul out yaller-boys out of his pocket.
vi: The Duke said: - Alright, let me make up for that shortfall.
tr: “Wait a minute,” said the duke. “Let's make up the difference.” Then he began to take out more gold from his pocket.
es: —One moment —says the duke—. We can add what is missing —and he begins to take gold coins out of his pocket.

en: “It’s a most amaz’n’ good idea, duke—you have got a rattlin’ clever head on you,” says the king. “Blest if the old Nonesuch ain’t a heppin’ us out agin,” and he begun to haul out yaller-jackets and stack them up.
vi: The king said: - Your opinion is truly insightful. You are indeed an exceptionally intelligent person. It's really unfortunate that the act of pretending no longer helps us. Then the old man took off his shirt and emptied the rest of his pockets.
tr: “This is a brilliant idea, duke… You are truly a very clever man,” said the king. “Our Jester has come to our rescue again, do you see,” – he also started adding the gold coins from his pocket to the pile.
es: —That idea is most astute, Duke... You have a very good head on your shoulders —says the king—. Blessed be the Peerless One who helps us once again —and he starts pulling gold coins out of his pocket and piling them up.

en: It most busted them, but they made up the six thousand clean and clear.
vi: They were overjoyed, because the amount of money they spent was exactly six thousand dollars.
tr: They almost ran out of money, but they managed to come up with six thousand dollars.
es: They almost ran out of money, but they reached exactly six thousand dollars.

en: “Say,” says the duke, “I got another idea. Le’s go up stairs and count this money, and then take and give it to the girls.”
vi: The Duke said: - Hey, I thought of something else. Let's go upstairs and count this money, then give it all to the girls.
tr: “I have another idea,” said the duke. “Let's go upstairs and count the money, then give it all to the girls.”
es: —Hey —says the duke—, I have another idea. Let's go upstairs, count the money, and then give it to the girls.

en: “Good land, duke, lemme hug you! It’s the most dazzling idea ’at ever a man struck. You have cert’nly got the most astonishin’ head I ever see. Oh, this is the boss dodge, ther’ ain’t no mistake ’bout it. Let ’em fetch along their suspicions now if they want to—this’ll lay ’em out.”
vi: - Wonderful, Duke. Let me give you a hug and a kiss. What a brilliant idea. You are truly a master, beyond any criticism. Even if they still have doubts about us, this action will dispel them immediately.
tr: “You thought very well, duke, let me give you a hug! This is the brightest idea that could come to a man's mind. Truly, you have the most astonishing intelligence I have ever seen. I have never seen such a great scheme, it has definitely become perfect now. Let's see someone get up and suspect us, after this move, no mountain can stand in our way.”
es: —For God's sake, Duke, let me give you a hug! It's the most brilliant idea in the world. Of course, you have a very good head on your shoulders. Now let them suspect whatever they want... That way they'll be convinced.

en: When we got up-stairs everybody gethered around the table, and the king he counted it and stacked it up, three hundred dollars in a pile—twenty elegant little piles. Everybody looked hungry at it, and licked their chops. Then they raked it into the bag again, and I see the king begin to swell himself up for another speech. He says:
vi: We went up to the main house and saw everyone sitting around the table. The king took out a bundle of money, counted it, and separated it into piles of three hundred dollars each, making a total of twenty small piles, which looked very pleasing to the eye. Everyone licked their lips, appearing eager. After putting the money back into the bundle, the king stood up and gave another speech. He said:
tr: When we went upstairs, everyone gathered around the table, the king counted the money and stacked it in piles of three hundred dollars – he made twenty such piles. Everyone was looking at the money with greedy eyes and licking their lips. Then the money was put back into the bag, and I saw that the king was preparing to give another speech.
es: When we went up, everyone gathered around the table and the king counted it and piled it up, three hundred dollars per pile: twenty very elegant little piles. Everyone looked at them with envy, licking their lips. Then they put everything back in the bag and I saw that the king was starting to puff up to give another speech. He goes and says:

en: “Friends all, my poor brother that lays yonder has done generous by them that’s left behind in the vale of sorrers. He has done generous by these yer poor little lambs that he loved and sheltered, and that’s left fatherless and motherless. Yes, and we that knowed him knows that he would a done more generous by ’em if he hadn’t ben afeard o’ woundin’ his dear William and me. Now, wouldn’t he? Ther’ ain’t no question ’bout it in my mind. Well, then, what kind o’ brothers would it be that ’d stand in his way at sech a time? And what kind o’ uncles would it be that ’d rob—yes, rob—sech poor sweet lambs as these ’at he loved so at sech a time? If I know William—and I think I do—he—well, I’ll jest ask him.” He turns around and begins to make a lot of signs to the duke with his hands, and the duke he looks at him stupid and leather-headed a while; then all of a sudden he seems to catch his meaning, and jumps for the king, goo-gooing with all his might for joy, and hugs him about fifteen times before he lets up. Then the king says, “I knowed it; I reckon that’ll convince anybody the way he feels about it. Here, Mary Jane, Susan, Joanner, take the money—take it all. It’s the gift of him that lays yonder, cold but joyful.”
vi: - Dear all, my poor brother has shown great generosity towards the living. He has thought of the young children he loved and protected, who are now without parents. Yes, we also understand that our brother wanted to care for them even more, but perhaps he was also concerned about William and me, fearing that the bond of brotherhood might not be complete. But in my heart, I truly did not think of that. I could not bring myself to take away the money from the young nieces and nephews whom my brother cherished so much... Perhaps William will not oppose me either. Alright, I will ask their uncle. The old man turned around and signaled to the worker. The man looked at the old man with a dumbfounded, fearful expression for a moment, then suddenly seemed to understand what the old man meant, ran over to the king, uttered a few incoherent sounds of joy, and hugged the old man tightly for fifteen minutes before letting go. Then the king spoke again: - I know, he is also very willing to do as I do. Mary Jane, Susan, Joanna, you all take this money. This is a gift left by your father, though it may seem cold, it will be useful for you.
tr: “My friends, my poor brother lying here has made a generosity to those left behind in this mournful land. He has made a generosity to these poor little lambs he loved and protected, now left without a father and mother. We who know him, know very well that if he did not hesitate to hurt his dear brother William and me, he would be even more generous to them. Am I wrong? If you ask me, I have no doubt about it. So how can we call him brother if we hinder him at such a time? If we rob these poor tender lambs he loved more than his own life at such a time... yes, if we rob them... what kind of uncles would we be? If I know William... and I believe I do... he too... it’s best we ask him.” He turned towards the duke and made a bunch of signs with his hands again; the duke first looked at him like a complete fool, then suddenly seemed to understand, jumped in place with joy, made a uuu-uuu sound, and hugged the king at least fifteen times. Then the king turned to the crowd: “I knew it; surely everyone understands what he thinks about this. Here, Mary Jane, Susan, and Joanner, take the money... Take it all. This is a gift to you from the departed, whose body is now cold but whose soul is happy.”
es: —Friends all, my poor brother who lies there has been generous with those of us left behind in this valley of tears. He has been generous with these little lambs that he loved and protected and who now are left without father or mother. Yes, and those of us who knew him know that he would have been more generous with them had he not feared hurting his dear William and me. Isn't that right? I have no doubt. Well then, what kind of brothers would oppose his will at a time like this? And what kind of uncles would steal, yes, steal, from poor little lambs like these, whom he loved so much, at a time like this? If I know William, and I think I do... he... well, I'm going to ask him. And he turns around and starts making a bunch of signals to the duke with his hands, and the duke watches him with a stupid and expressionless look for a while, and then suddenly seems to understand what he's saying and jumps on the king, saying "goo-goo" with all his might out of joy and gives him about fifteen hugs before letting him go. Then, the king goes and says: —I already knew it; I reckon this will convince everyone of what he thinks. Come on, Mary Jane, Susan, Joanna, take the money... take it all. It is the gift of the one who lies there, cold but content.

en: Mary Jane she went for him, Susan and the hare-lip went for the duke, and then such another hugging and kissing I never see yet. And everybody crowded up with the tears in their eyes, and most shook the hands off of them frauds, saying all the time:
vi: Mary Jane walked over to the king, while Susan and the harelip girl went to the duke, hugging him tightly and kissing him. I had never seen such intense kissing before. Then everyone gathered around, tears streaming down their faces, and everyone shook hands with those two swindlers. Everyone said:
tr: Mary Jane ran towards him, and Susan and Hare-lip also ran towards the duke; there was more hugging and kissing than I had ever seen before. There were tears in the eyes of everyone filling the room, many of them shaking our frauds' hands, saying, "You are really very kind!...
es: Mary Jane threw herself at him and Susan and the one with the cleft lip at the duke, and they started giving them such kisses and hugs as I have never seen. And everyone crowded around with tears in their eyes, shaking hands with those swindlers, saying all the time:

en: “You dear good souls!—how lovely!—how could you!”
vi: - How precious! You all are such good people.
tr: So humane!... How could you do it!" and so on.
es: —Kind souls! How good you are! How could you!

en: Well, then, pretty soon all hands got to talking about the diseased again, and how good he was, and what a loss he was, and all that; and before long a big iron-jawed man worked himself in there from outside, and stood a-listening and looking, and not saying anything; and nobody saying anything to him either, because the king was talking and they was all busy listening. The king was saying—in the middle of something he’d started in on—
vi: Moments later, everyone resumed talking about the unfortunate person. They spoke of how kind he was, how much of a loss his death was... Suddenly, a man with a square jaw walked in from outside. That person just stood there listening and watching, not saying a word, and no one spoke to him either, because they were all engrossed in listening to the king speak. The king was in the middle of speaking, and he said this:
tr: Before long, everyone started talking about the deceased again, mentioning how good a person he was and what a great loss his death was; after a while, a burly, square-faced man pushed his way in and started looking at us and listening to us without saying anything; no one had said anything to him either, because the king was speaking and everyone was busy listening to him. The king was in the middle of his speech:
es: Well, soon everyone started talking about the deceased again and how good he was and what a great loss he represented and all that, and a little later a big man with a square jaw arrived who stood listening and watching without saying anything, and no one said anything to him either, because the king was speaking and everyone was busy listening. The king continued speaking, in the middle of something he had already started:

en: “—they bein’ partickler friends o’ the diseased. That’s why they’re invited here this evenin’; but tomorrow we want all to come—everybody; for he respected everybody, he liked everybody, and so it’s fitten that his funeral orgies sh’d be public.”
vi: - ... You are close friends of my brother, so tonight I invite you all to stay here. We hope that tomorrow everyone else will also come, because when he was alive, my brother loved everyone. We also want to hold a proper funeral for him so that the public can be informed.
tr: "... because they were close friends of the deceased. That is why they were invited to the house this evening; but tomorrow we want all of you to come... everyone; because he had respect for everyone, he loved everyone, so it is very appropriate for the funeral ceremony to be open to everyone."
es: —... friends, especially of the deceased. That is why you are invited here this afternoon, but the truth is we want everyone to come... everyone; for he respected everyone, loved everyone, and that is why it is fitting that his funeral orgies be public.

en: And so he went a-mooning on and on, liking to hear himself talk, and every little while he fetched in his funeral orgies again, till the duke he couldn’t stand it no more; so he writes on a little scrap of paper, “obsequies, you old fool,” and folds it up, and goes to goo-gooing and reaching it over people’s heads to him. The king he reads it and puts it in his pocket, and says:
vi: Then, the old man just kept rambling on as if he were talking only to himself. Every now and then, he would bring up the funeral arrangements again, to the point where the duke standing nearby could no longer bear it and wrote a few words on a small piece of paper. "It's called a funeral, not a burial," then folded the small piece of paper and passed it over everyone's heads to the king. The king took the piece of paper, read it, put it in his pocket, and then said:
tr: Then he continued to whine and complain, it must have sounded pleasant to his ears because he kept talking about the funeral debauchery over and over again; finally, the duke could no longer bear it; so he wrote on a piece of paper, "you will say ceremony, you big fool," folded the paper and, making a uuu-uuu sound, passed it to him over the heads of the crowd. The king read what was written, put the paper in his pocket, and continued his speech:
es: And he kept saying stupid things because he liked to hear himself talk. And every now and then he would bring up the funeral orgies again, until the duke couldn't take it anymore and wrote on a small piece of paper: "Funerals, you old idiot," folded it, made a "coo-coo" sound, and passed it over everyone's heads. The king read it, put it in his pocket, and said:

en: “Poor William, afflicted as he is, his heart’s aluz right. Asks me to invite everybody to come to the funeral—wants me to make ’em all welcome. But he needn’t a worried—it was jest what I was at.”
vi: - Poor William, his uncle is always so considerate, reminding me to invite everyone to the funeral and telling me to welcome everyone properly. But he can rest assured, I have thought the same way.
tr: “Poor William, he may be crippled; but his heart always shows him the right way. He wants me to invite everyone to the funeral… He tells me to show hospitality to all of them. But he doesn't need to worry… I was going to do that anyway.”
es: —Poor William, despite his affliction, his heart always gets it right. He asks me to invite everyone to come to the funeral... he wants me to welcome everyone. But he doesn't need to worry, that was exactly what I was doing.

en: Then he weaves along again, perfectly ca’m, and goes to dropping in his funeral orgies again every now and then, just like he done before. And when he done it the third time he says:
vi: Then the old man continued the story, occasionally mixing up the words "funeral" and "burial." When he said it for the third time, he explained:
tr: Then, without breaking his composure, he continued to speak, occasionally mentioning the funeral revelry as he had before. After saying it three more times, he said:
es: And then he continued with his speech, so calmly, and he goes on to talk about his funeral orgies over and over again, exactly the same as before. By the third time he says:

en: “I say orgies, not because it’s the common term, because it ain’t—obsequies bein’ the common term—but because orgies is the right term. Obsequies ain’t used in England no more now—it’s gone out. We say orgies now in England. Orgies is better, because it means the thing you’re after more exact. It’s a word that’s made up out’n the Greek orgo, outside, open, abroad; and the Hebrew jeesum, to plant, cover up; hence inter. So, you see, funeral orgies is an open er public funeral.”
vi: - I often say "cất đám" instead of "tang lễ" because although "tang lễ" is a common term, it is rarely used in England nowadays. That old man is really shameless, I have never seen anyone like that.
tr: “The reason I say 'sefahat' is not because it is widely used, as the commonly used word is 'merasim,' but the correct one is 'sefahat.' In England, no one says 'merasim' anymore... This word has been forgotten. In England, we now say 'funeral sefahat.' 'Sefahat' is more appropriate because it conveys the meaning more accurately. The word 'sefahat' comes from the Greek 'sefum,' meaning outside, open area, exterior, and the Hebrew 'abat,' meaning to plant, to cover. Therefore, public funerals are called 'funeral sefahat.'”
es: —I say orgies, not because it is the vulgar term, which it is not, the vulgar term is obsequies, but because orgies is the exact term. In England, we no longer say obsequies... That word has fallen into disuse. In England, we now say orgies. Orgies is better because it more accurately signifies what one wants to say. It is a compound word from the Greek orgo, outside, open, in the open air, and the Hebrew geesum, to plant, to cover; hence, to bury. So, as you can see, funeral orgies are a public, ahem, open funeral.

en: He was the worst I ever struck. Well, the iron-jawed man he laughed right in his face. Everybody was shocked. Everybody says, “Why, doctor!” and Abner Shackleford says:
vi: That old man is really shameless, I have never seen anyone like that. Then, that man laughed in the king's face. Everyone showed their displeasure. They spoke.
tr: Honestly, he messed up really badly. The square-faced man burst out laughing in the face of our king. Everyone was stunned with amazement. People asked, "Why did you laugh, doctor?" and Abner Shackleford added:
es: It was the most shameless thing I had ever seen. Well, the guy with the square jaw laughed in his face. Everyone was scandalized. Everyone said, "But, man, doctor!" and Abner Shackleford said:

en: “Why, Robinson, hain’t you heard the news? This is Harvey Wilks.”
vi: - Oh, look, Dr. Robinson, haven't you heard the news? This is Harvy Wilks.
tr: "Are you unaware of what's going on, Robinson? The person in front of you is Harvey Wilks."
es: —But, Robinson, haven't you heard the news? This is Harvey Wilks.

en: The king he smiled eager, and shoved out his flapper, and says:
vi: The king laughed heartily, extended his hand to shake, and asked:
tr: The king extended his hand to the man with a sincere smile:
es: The king grinned from ear to ear, extended his hoof, and said:

en: “Is it my poor brother’s dear good friend and physician? I—”
vi: - Is that the doctor, the good friend of my poor brother? I...
tr: “Or are you the doctor friend whom my poor brother loved so much? I…”
es: —Is it the dear friend and doctor of my poor brother? I...

en: “Keep your hands off of me!” says the doctor. “You talk like an Englishman, don’t you? It’s the worst imitation I ever heard. You Peter Wilks’s brother! You’re a fraud, that’s what you are!”
vi: - Don't touch me. - The man replied - You said you are an Englishman, didn't you? That is the worst imitation I have ever seen. Are you Peter Wilks' brother? No, you are just a big fraud.
tr: “Put your hand down!” said the doctor. “So you speak like the English... is that so? The worst imitation I've ever seen. So you are Peter Wilks' brother. No, I think you are a complete fraud!”
es: —Don't touch me! —replied the doctor—. You pretend to speak like an Englishman, don't you? It's the worst imitation I've heard in my life. You, the brother of Peter Wilks? You are a fraud, that's what you are!

en: Well, how they all took on! They crowded around the doctor and tried to quiet him down, and tried to explain to him and tell him how Harvey ’d showed in forty ways that he was Harvey, and knowed everybody by name, and the names of the very dogs, and begged and begged him not to hurt Harvey’s feelings and the poor girl’s feelings, and all that. But it warn’t no use; he stormed right along, and said any man that pretended to be an Englishman and couldn’t imitate the lingo no better than what he did was a fraud and a liar. The poor girls was hanging to the king and crying; and all of a sudden the doctor ups and turns on them. He says:
vi: Everyone was stunned, gathering around the doctor, intending to advise him not to be so harsh, and trying to explain that it was indeed Harvey because he knew everyone's names, even the names of the dogs. They kept pleading with the doctor not to do anything to harm Harvey and those poor girls. But it was useless, the doctor kept making a fuss, saying that anyone who claimed to be English but couldn't speak properly was just a fraud, a liar... The poor girls clung tightly to the king and cried. Suddenly, the doctor turned towards the girls and said:
tr: Suddenly, everyone's face fell! They surrounded the doctor, trying to silence him, to explain what had happened, and to tell how Harvey had proven himself to be Harvey in forty different ways. He knew everyone by name, he even knew the names of the dogs. They also begged him not to hurt Harvey's and the poor girls' feelings. But none of it worked; the man continued to speak angrily and said that someone who tried to speak like an Englishman but did such a poor imitation could be nothing but a fraud and a liar. The poor girls were crying, clinging to the king; the doctor suddenly broke away from the crowd and turned to them.
es: Well, what a commotion it caused! They gathered around the doctor and tried to calm him down by explaining everything and telling him that Harvey had proven in forty different ways that he was Harvey and knew everyone by name, even the names of the dogs, and they begged him over and over not to hurt Harvey's feelings or those of the poor girls and all that. But it was all in vain; he kept shouting and saying that if someone claimed to be English and couldn't mimic the way the English spoke better than that, it was because he was a fraud and a liar. The poor girls clung to the king and cried, and suddenly the doctor turned on them. He went and said:

en: “I was your father’s friend, and I’m your friend; and I warn you as a friend, and an honest one that wants to protect you and keep you out of harm and trouble, to turn your backs on that scoundrel and have nothing to do with him, the ignorant tramp, with his idiotic Greek and Hebrew, as he calls it. He is the thinnest kind of an impostor—has come here with a lot of empty names and facts which he picked up somewheres, and you take them for proofs, and are helped to fool yourselves by these foolish friends here, who ought to know better. Mary Jane Wilks, you know me for your friend, and for your unselfish friend, too. Now listen to me; turn this pitiful rascal out—I beg you to do it. Will you?”
vi: - I am a friend of your father, and I am also a friend of yours. Therefore, I want to protect you and keep you from being harmed by others. You must immediately throw that rogue out the door. He is just a common impostor who has come here with some knowledge he accidentally stole from somewhere. And there are even madmen here helping you believe it further. Mary Jane Wilks, you know that I have no interest in any profit in this matter. Listen to me, throw that scoundrel out. I beg you, will you agree?
tr: "I was your father's friend, and I am your friend too; as a friend who wants to protect you, who doesn't want you to get into trouble and get hurt, I am warning you to turn your back on this scoundrel, to cut all ties with this ignorant vagabond who is trying to convince you with his foolish nonsense in Greek and Hebrew." "One of the most despicable swindlers I've ever seen..." "He talks about a bunch of names and events, who knows where he learned them from; you take these as evidence and, with the help of my supposedly sensible but foolish friends here, you are making a fool of yourself." "Mary Jane Wilks, you know that I am your friend, moreover, a friend who never thinks of himself." "Now listen to me and throw this miserable rascal out..." "I beg you." "Will you do as I say?""
es: —I was a friend of your father and I am your friend, and I warn you as a friend, and an honest friend who wants to protect you and save you from troubles and sufferings, to turn your back on that scoundrel and have nothing to do with him, with that ignorant vagabond, with those idiocies of Greek and Hebrew, he says. He is the most obvious impostor: he has come here with a bunch of empty names and data that he has obtained somewhere, and you believe they are proofs. And those foolish friends who should be more intelligent help you deceive yourselves. Mary Jane Wilks, you know that I am your friend, and that I am not a selfish friend. Now listen to me; kick this unscrupulous scoundrel out... I beg you to do it. Are you willing?

en: Mary Jane straightened herself up, and my, but she was handsome! She says:
vi: Mary Jane stood up straight and said decisively:
tr: Mary Jane stood upright without hesitation, oh, how beautiful she was! “Here is my answer,” he said.
es: Mary Jane straightened up and, wow, how beautiful she was!, she responded: —This is my answer —she grabbed the money bag, put it in the king's hands, and said—:

en: “Here is my answer.” She hove up the bag of money and put it in the king’s hands, and says, “Take this six thousand dollars, and invest for me and my sisters any way you want to, and don’t give us no receipt for it.”
vi: - This is my answer. - I said, as she lifted the bundle of money and placed it into the king's hand - You take all these six thousand dollars, and you invest it for me and my two siblings, wherever and however you see fit, we don't need to sign any receipt at all.
tr: “Here is my answer,” he said. He took the money bag and handed it to the king. “Take this six thousand dollars and use it as you see fit for me and my siblings. No receipt or anything is needed for this.”
es: —This is my answer —she grabbed the money bag, put it in the king's hands, and said—: Take these six thousand dollars and invest them for me and my sisters as you wish, and we don't need you to give us any receipt.

en: Then she put her arm around the king on one side, and Susan and the hare-lip done the same on the other. Everybody clapped their hands and stomped on the floor like a perfect storm, whilst the king held up his head and smiled proud. The doctor says:
vi: Then she stepped aside, wrapped her arms around the king, while Susan and the girl with the cleft lip came to stand on the other side. Everyone applauded, stomping loudly on the floor. The king looked up and smiled proudly. The doctor said:
tr: Then one person took the king's arm, and Susan and Harelip took his other arm. As the king held his head high and smiled proudly, a storm of applause and cheers erupted. The doctor said, "Alright, the sin is off my shoulders."
es: Then she took the king by one arm, and Susan and the girl with the cleft lip did the same with the other. Everyone applauded and stomped on the ground, with a noise like a storm, while the king lifted his head with an arrogant smile. The doctor said:

en: “All right; I wash my hands of the matter. But I warn you all that a time ’s coming when you’re going to feel sick whenever you think of this day.” And away he went.
vi: - Fine. I won't be involved in this matter anymore. But I must say in advance that there will come a time when you will regret thinking about today. Then he stepped out.
tr: The doctor said, "Alright, the sin is off my shoulders." "But I'm warning you, one day you'll feel sick every time you think about today..." Then he left.
es: —Very well; I wash my hands of this. But I warn you that the time will come when you will feel bad every time you remember this day —and he left.

en: “All right, doctor,” says the king, kinder mocking him; “we’ll try and get ’em to send for you;” which made them all laugh, and they said it was a prime good hit.
vi: The king replied with a sarcastic tone: - Very well, doctor, we will try to come to see you. Everyone burst into laughter, and they said that it was the most profound sarcastic remark. Bookshelf Share
tr: “Alright doctor,” said the king, mimicking his speech mockingly, “then we will call you.” Upon hearing this, everyone burst into laughter and said he had given a very good comeback.
es: —Very well, doctor —said the king, as if mocking him—; then someone will go fetch you —at which everyone laughed a lot and said it was very clever.

en: CHAPTER XXVI.
vi: Chapter XXVI
tr: Chapter Twenty-Six
es: Chapter 26

en: Well, when they was all gone the king he asks Mary Jane how they was off for spare rooms, and she said she had one spare room, which would do for Uncle William, and she’d give her own room to Uncle Harvey, which was a little bigger, and she would turn into the room with her sisters and sleep on a cot; and up garret was a little cubby, with a pallet in it. The king said the cubby would do for his valley—meaning me.
vi: When everyone had left, the king asked Mary Jane if there was any room left to rest. She said there was a spare room for Uncle William, her own room would be for the old man because he was larger, and she would move to her sisters' room and sleep on a small bed. There was also a spot upstairs with a bed. The king said that spot would be for his servant - that is, me.
tr: After everyone had left, the king asked Mary Jane if they had any extra rooms. The girl said there was an extra room that would be enough for Uncle William, and she would give her own slightly larger room to Uncle Harvey; she herself would set up a bed in her sisters' room; and there was also a small space in the attic with a straw mattress. The king said the mattress would be enough for his servant – that is, for me.
es: WELL, when everyone had left, the king asked Mary Jane if there was a free room, and she told him that she had one that would do for Uncle William, and that she would give hers to Uncle Harvey, who was a bit taller, because she would go to her sisters' room to sleep on a Turkish bed, and that there was a small room with a mattress in the attic. The king said that the mattress would be enough for his valet, meaning me.

en: So Mary Jane took us up, and she showed them their rooms, which was plain but nice. She said she’d have her frocks and a lot of other traps took out of her room if they was in Uncle Harvey’s way, but he said they warn’t. The frocks was hung along the wall, and before them was a curtain made out of calico that hung down to the floor. There was an old hair trunk in one corner, and a guitar-box in another, and all sorts of little knickknacks and jimcracks around, like girls brisken up a room with. The king said it was all the more homely and more pleasanter for these fixings, and so don’t disturb them. The duke’s room was pretty small, but plenty good enough, and so was my cubby.
vi: Mary Jane showed them the guest room. The room looked quite ordinary, but it was tidy and clean. She said she would move her clothes and personal items out of the room if Uncle Hary wanted, but the king declined. Her clothes were hung on the wall, covered by a fabric curtain that reached down to the wooden floor. In one corner, there were two small boxes containing jewelry. In the other corner, there was a music box and other toys; it seemed the girls only sat and played together in this room. The king said to leave it as it was to maintain a homely atmosphere and keep it cheerful, without moving anything. The duke's room was smaller but also quite nice. As for my room, it was just okay.
tr: Mary Jane took us all upstairs and showed us our simple yet charming rooms. She said that Uncle Harvey could take the clothes and other knick-knacks from the room if they would get in his way, but he replied that he wouldn't be bothered at all. The clothes were hung on the wall, with a flannel curtain drawn from ceiling to floor in front of them. In one corner, there was a leather suitcase, and in another corner, a guitar case, and there were knick-knacks and ornaments that girls like scattered around the room. The King said that the room felt warmer and more pleasant with these accessories and that there was no need to change their places. The Duke's room was quite small, but it was also very nice, just like my little attic room.
es: So Mary Jane made us go up and showed us her rooms, which were simple but pleasant. She said she would have her dresses and other things removed from her room if they bothered Uncle Harvey, but he said no. The dresses were hung next to a wall, covered by a calico curtain that reached the floor. In one corner there was an old hair trunk, and in another, a guitar case; the rest was filled with decorations and those things that girls like to use to brighten up a room. The king said it was much more homely and pleasant with those decorations, so there was no need to change them. The duke's room was very small, but more than sufficient, just like my cubicle.

en: That night they had a big supper, and all them men and women was there, and I stood behind the king and the duke’s chairs and waited on them, and the niggers waited on the rest. Mary Jane she set at the head of the table, with Susan alongside of her, and said how bad the biscuits was, and how mean the preserves was, and how ornery and tough the fried chickens was—and all that kind of rot, the way women always do for to force out compliments; and the people all knowed everything was tiptop, and said so—said “How do you get biscuits to brown so nice?” and “Where, for the land’s sake, did you get these amaz’n pickles?” and all that kind of humbug talky-talk, just the way people always does at a supper, you know.
vi: That night, they had a grand feast. All the gentlemen and ladies were present. I stood behind the king and the duke to serve, while the black servants attended to the other guests. Mary Jane sat at the head of the table, with Susan beside her; she criticized all the dishes, saying the cake was poorly made, the meat was terrible, and the fried chicken was too tough. Women often have such a tone, just to subtly remind others to praise them. But the other diners found every dish delicious. They said: - How do you make the cakes smell so good? Where do you find such delicious vegetables? ... etc.
tr: That night a grand dinner was given, almost all the men and women came, I stood behind the chairs of the king and the duke and served, while the black people served the others. Mary Jane sat at the head of the table, Susan sat next to her and was talking about how bad the cookies were, how cheap the candies were, and also said that the roast chicken was very bland and tough – just like women always do, babbling nonsense to force compliments. She expected people to know and even say that everything was very nice. She wanted them to say, “How did you make these cookies so brown and crispy? For God's sake, did you make these wonderful pickles yourself?” and such charlatan chatter; you know, the kind people always do at such communal meals.
es: That night they held a great dinner where all the men and women were present; I stayed behind the chairs of the king and the duke to serve them, and the black servants took care of everyone else. Mary Jane sat at the head of the table, with Susan beside her, commenting on how bad the buns were and how poor the preserves were and how ordinary and tough the fried chickens were, and all that kind of nonsense, as women always do in search of compliments, but people knew everything was magnificent and told her: "How do you get the buns so toasty and so good?" and "Where did you get these wonderful pickles?" and all that nonsense people say just to say at dinners, you know.

en: And when it was all done me and the hare-lip had supper in the kitchen off of the leavings, whilst the others was helping the niggers clean up the things. The hare-lip she got to pumping me about England, and blest if I didn’t think the ice was getting mighty thin sometimes. She says:
vi: When everyone had finished eating, the girl with the cleft lip and I took the leftovers down to the kitchen to eat together. Meanwhile, the others helped the black man clean up the tables and chairs. The girl with the cleft lip asked me about England. It was truly embarrassing; if there had been a crack in the ground, I would have crawled right into it. She asked:
tr: After everyone had eaten and drunk, the harelip and I ate our meal in the kitchen with the leftovers, while the others helped the blacks wash the dishes. The harelip started pressing me about England, and a few times I felt really cornered. “Have you ever seen the king?”
es: And when it was all over, the girl with the cleft lip and I ate the leftovers in the kitchen, while the others helped the black people clean up. The girl with the cleft lip started asking me things about England, and hang me if it didn’t seem like things were getting difficult at times. She goes and says:

en: “Did you ever see the king?”
vi: - Have you ever seen the King of England?
tr: “Have you ever seen the king?”
es: —Have you ever seen the king?

en: “Who? William Fourth? Well, I bet I have—he goes to our church.” I knowed he was dead years ago, but I never let on. So when I says he goes to our church, she says:
vi: - Oh, William the Fourth? Of course, he still often attends services at our church. I know that William has been dead for a long time, but I just ignore it. Seeing me say that the king often goes to church at my place, she asked again:
tr: “Who? William the Fourth? Of course, I’ve seen him… He comes to our church.” I knew he had died years ago, but I didn't let on. Upon saying that the king came to our church, the girl asked:
es: —To whom? To William IV? Man, of course: he goes to our church. I knew he had died years ago, but I didn't comment. So when I said he went to our church, she asked:

en: “What—regular?”
vi: - What? Going to the ceremony already?
tr: “How… Regularly?”
es: —How... is it always going?

en: “Yes—regular. His pew’s right over opposite ourn—on t’other side the pulpit.”
vi: - Yes, let's go right away. His seat is right in front of where we are; on the side where the sermon is given.
tr: “Yes... Regularly. His compartment is directly across from ours... On the other side of the podium.”
es: —Yes, always. He has the pew in front of ours, on the other side of the pulpit.

en: “I thought he lived in London?”
vi: - I thought he was in London?
tr: “I thought the King lived in London, didn't he?”
es: —I thought you lived in London.

en: “Well, he does. Where would he live?”
vi: - Yes, he is in London, where else would he be?
tr: “Yes, sitting there. Where else would they sit?”
es: —Man, of course. Where else would I live?

en: “But I thought you lived in Sheffield?”
vi: - But I thought you were in Sheffield?
tr: “But I thought you lived in Sheffield. That's a different city.”
es: —But I thought you lived in Sheffield.

en: I see I was up a stump. I had to let on to get choked with a chicken bone, so as to get time to think how to get down again. Then I says:
vi: I became confused. I had to pretend that a chicken bone was stuck in my throat to have time to think. Then I said:
tr: I was momentarily stunned. I pretended as if a chicken bone was stuck in my throat and tried to figure out how to backtrack. Finally, I said:
es: I saw that he had me cornered. I had to pretend I was choking on a chicken bone to think about how to get out of that situation. Then I said:

en: “I mean he goes to our church regular when he’s in Sheffield. That’s only in the summer time, when he comes there to take the sea baths.”
vi: - I mean to say that he often attends services at our church whenever he comes to Sheffield. That's only during the summer, but when he goes to the beach, you know.
tr: "I meant to say that when he is in Sheffield, he comes to our church regularly. He only comes in the summers when he wants to go swimming."
es: —I mean that he always goes to our church when he is in Sheffield. That's only in the summer, when he goes to take sea baths.

en: “Why, how you talk—Sheffield ain’t on the sea.”
vi: - What are you talking about! Sheffield is not near the sea
tr: "No way, you fool..." "Sheffield doesn't have a coast.""
es: —But what are you saying... Sheffield is not by the sea.

en: “Well, who said it was?”
vi: - Who said it's near the sea?
tr: “Who said it?” "You said it.""
es: —Well, and who said yes?

en: “Why, you did.”
vi: - I just said it.
tr: “I didn't say such a thing.”
es: —Well, you.

en: “I didn’t nuther.”
vi: - When did I say that?
tr: “I didn't say such a thing.”
es: —That's not true.

en: “You did!”
vi: - You were the one who just said it.
tr: "Dedin!"" "I didn't say that."" "You said it!""
es: —Yes!

en: “I didn’t.”
vi: - No, I won't say.
tr: “I would never say such a thing in my life.”
es: —No.

en: “You did.”
vi: - He did say.
tr: “I would never say such a thing in my life.”
es: —Yes.

en: “I never said nothing of the kind.”
vi: - I never said that.
tr: “I would never say such a thing in my life.”
es: —I haven't said anything like that.

en: “Well, what did you say, then?”
vi: - So what did you just say?
tr: “So, what did you say?”
es: —Well, then, what did you say?

en: “Said he come to take the sea baths—that’s what I said.”
vi: - I said that he came to swim in the sea.
tr: “I told him that he came there to swim in the sea… I said it exactly like this.”
es: —I said I was going to take sea baths; that's what I said.

en: “Well, then, how’s he going to take the sea baths if it ain’t on the sea?”
vi: - Okay, how could he go swimming in the sea when Sheffield is not near the sea?
tr: “That's it! If it doesn't have a coast, how will it go into the sea?”
es: —Well, then, how are you going to take sea baths if you're not in the sea?

en: “Looky here,” I says; “did you ever see any Congress-water?”
vi: - Have you ever seen the water at Congress?
tr: “Now listen carefully, have you ever seen mineral water?”
es: —Look —I replied—, have you ever had mineral water?

en: “Yes.”
vi: - Then
tr: “Yes, I saw it.”
es: —Yes.

en: “Well, did you have to go to Congress to get it?”
vi: - So, do you have to go there to get water?
tr: “So, do you need to go to the mine to see mineral water?”
es: —Well, did you have to go to a mine to look for it?

en: “Why, no.”
vi: - What are you going to do?
tr: “No, don't.”
es: —Well, no.

en: “Well, neither does William Fourth have to go to the sea to get a sea bath.”
vi: - Then King William doesn't need to go all the way to the sea to bathe.
