tr: “William the Fourth doesn't need to go to the sea to take a dip in the sea.”
es: —Well, then, neither does William IV have to go to the sea to take a sea bath.

en: “How does he get it, then?”
vi: - So how do we do it?
tr: “Well, then where does he find the sea?”
es: —So, how does he give them to them?

en: “Gets it the way people down here gets Congress-water—in barrels. There in the palace at Sheffield they’ve got furnaces, and he wants his water hot. They can’t bile that amount of water away off there at the sea. They haven’t got no conveniences for it.”
vi: - Then do as everyone here does, go get Congress water, which means getting it into a barrel. In the palace in Sheffield, there is a stove, and he wants to bathe in hot seawater.
tr: “People find mineral water just as they find it... They bring it in barrels. There are large stoves in the palace in Sheffield, the king likes his water hot. They surely can't heat the water in the sea. They don't have enough materials for that.”
es: —He does the same as the people here to drink mineral water: in barrels. There in the Sheffield palace, they have some very hot ovens and he likes the water to be hot. You can't boil all the water in the sea. There aren't enough machines there.

en: “Oh, I see, now. You might a said that in the first place and saved time.”
vi: - So, I understand now. If only you had said it from the beginning, we wouldn't have wasted time.
tr: “Ah, now I understand. If you had said it at the beginning, we wouldn't have wasted so much time.”
es: —Ah, I understand now. You could have said that to begin with and we would have saved time.

en: When she said that I see I was out of the woods again, and so I was comfortable and glad. Next, she says:
vi: When she said that, I felt very relieved and pleased. After that, she asked again:
tr: When I said this, I realized that I had come out into the open again, I felt relieved and pleased. Then he asked again:
es: When he said that, I saw that I had gotten rid of the matter, so I felt more comfortable and happy. Then he asked:

en: “Do you go to church, too?”
vi: - So, do you go to church?
tr: “Do you also go to church?”
es: —Are you also going to church?

en: “Yes—regular.”
vi: - Yes, let's go right away
tr: “Yes… Regularly.”
es: —Yes, always.

en: “Where do you set?”
vi: - Where are you sitting!
tr: "Where do you live?""
es: —Where do you sit?

en: “Why, in our pew.”
vi: - Sit in the chair.
tr: “In our compartment, of course.”
es: —Man, in our bank.

en: “Whose pew?”
vi: - Whose chair is this?
tr: "Whose compartment is it?"
es: —Whose bank?

en: “Why, ourn—your Uncle Harvey’s.”
vi: - Mr. Harvey's chair.
tr: “In ours, you know… During Uncle Harvey's time.”
es: —Well, ours; your Uncle Harvey's.

en: “His’n? What does he want with a pew?”
vi: - Does he need a chair?
tr: “Is it his? What is he going to do with the compartment?”
es: —His? And why does he need a bank?

en: “Wants it to set in. What did you reckon he wanted with it?”
vi: - There must be a seat to sit on, right? What did you think it was for?
tr: “To sit down. What else did you think you would do?”
es: —To sit on it. What did you think I needed it for?

en: “Why, I thought he’d be in the pulpit.”
vi: - I thought you were going to stand up and give a lecture?
tr: “Well, I thought he would be at the podium.”
es: —Man, I thought he was in the pulpit.

en: Rot him, I forgot he was a preacher. I see I was up a stump again, so I played another chicken bone and got another think. Then I says:
vi: It's a complete disaster, I totally forgot that her uncle is a pastor. So I had to pretend to choke on a chicken bone again to think. Then I said:
tr: Damn, I had forgotten he was a priest. I was stuck again, so I pretended to choke on a chicken bone to find a way out. Then I said:
es: Damn it, I had forgotten he was a preacher. I saw that he had caught me again, so I choked up again to think about it, and then I said:

en: “Blame it, do you suppose there ain’t but one preacher to a church?”
vi: - So you think that there is only one person preaching in the church?
tr: “Oh Allah, do you think there is only one priest in the church?”
es: —Damn, do you think there's only one preacher in a church?

en: “Why, what do they want with more?”
vi: - What is there to do?
tr: “Yes, what more will they do?” “What!
es: —But, why do they need more? —How!

en: “What!—to preach before a king? I never did see such a girl as you. They don’t have no less than seventeen.”
vi: - To preach in front of the king. You're really strange. My church has up to seventeen pastors.
tr: To preach in front of the King? Honestly, I've never seen a girl like you in my life. There are at least seventeen priests.”
es: To preach when the king is coming! I've never seen a girl like that. They have no less than seventeen.

en: “Seventeen! My land! Why, I wouldn’t set out such a string as that, not if I never got to glory. It must take ’em a week.”
vi: - Seventeen pastors? If that's the case, it would take a whole week to finish the sermon?
tr: "Seventeen!" "Oh my God! No matter how much merit it brings, I can't sit and listen to a sermon in such a church." "Surely it would take a week for all of them to give their sermons."
es: —Seventeen! My God! Well, I wouldn't be able to stand listening to so many, even if I never went to paradise. It must take them a week.

en: “Shucks, they don’t all of ’em preach the same day—only one of ’em.”
vi: - Not all of those people lecture in one day, only one person does.
tr: “Oh come on, not all of them give sermons on the same day… Only one of them does.”
es: —Darn, they don't all preach on the same day: only one of them does.

en: “Well, then, what does the rest of ’em do?”
vi: - So, what are those people doing?
tr: “So what are the others doing?”
es: —Well, and what does the rest do?

en: “Oh, nothing much. Loll around, pass the plate—and one thing or another. But mainly they don’t do nothing.”
vi: - Then sit around the fire, go collect money, or do this and that. But mostly, they do nothing at all.
tr: “They don't do much. They wander around, carrying dishes and bowls... They do small tasks. But essentially, they just stand around idly.”
es: —Bah, not much. They walk around, pass the tray, and things like that. But in general, they don't do anything.

en: “Well, then, what are they for?”
vi: - What did they go there to do?
tr: “Then what are they doing in the church?”
es: —Well, then, what are they there for?

en: “Why, they’re for style. Don’t you know nothing?”
vi: - That is their duty. She doesn't know anything.
tr: “They are standing there as a matter of principle. Do you not know anything either?”
es: —Man, it's a matter of class. Don't you know anything?

en: “Well, I don’t want to know no such foolishness as that. How is servants treated in England? Do they treat ’em better ’n we treat our niggers?”
vi: - I don't need to know such nonsense anymore. I ask you this: in England, how are the servants treated? Is it better than how we treat the black people here?
tr: “I can do without knowing something as foolish as this. So, how do they treat servants in England? Do they treat them better than we treat our black people?”
es: —Well, I don't want to know silly things. How do they treat servants in England? Do they treat them better than we treat our black people?

en: “No! A servant ain’t nobody there. They treat them worse than dogs.”
vi: - No, there, they don't give a damn about the servants. They treat them worse than dogs.
tr: “No! No one there treats the servants as human beings. They see them as lower than dogs.”
es: —No! There, a servant is nothing. They treat them worse than dogs.

en: “Don’t they give ’em holidays, the way we do, Christmas and New Year’s week, and Fourth of July?”
vi: - Do they give holidays like they do here?
tr: “Don't they give them holidays like we do during Christmas, New Year week, and the Fourth of July?”
es: —Don't they get holidays like we do, for Christmas week, New Year's, and the 4th of July?

en: “Oh, just listen! A body could tell you hain’t ever been to England by that. Why, Hare-l—why, Joanna, they never see a holiday from year’s end to year’s end; never go to the circus, nor theater, nor nigger shows, nor nowheres.”
vi: For example, Christmas, New Year, or National Day? - It's true that you have never been to England, Miss... I mean, Miss Joanna. Over there from the beginning of the year to the end of the year, there's no circus, no theater, nothing at all.
tr: "No way!" "One can tell from here that you have never been to England." "Look now, Tavş..." "Joanna, they don't take any holidays from the beginning to the end of the year; they can never go to the circus, the theater, or to black shows, they can't go anywhere.""
es: —What things you say! Just with that, it's clear that you've never been to England. But, lip...; but, Joanna, they don't even have a single day off a year; they never go to the circus, or the theater, or shows for black people, or anywhere.

en: “Nor church?”
vi: - Not going to church anymore either?
tr: “To the church too?”
es: —Not even to church?

en: “Nor church.”
vi: - Yes, not going to church.
tr: “To the church too?”
es: —Not even to the church.

en: “But you always went to church.”
vi: - So why are you still allowed to go to church?
tr: “But you always said you went to church.”
es: —But you always go to church.

en: Well, I was gone up again. I forgot I was the old man’s servant. But next minute I whirled in on a kind of an explanation how a valley was different from a common servant and had to go to church whether he wanted to or not, and set with the family, on account of its being the law. But I didn’t do it pretty good, and when I got done I see she warn’t satisfied. She says:
vi: Once again, I was at a loss for words. I had forgotten that I was her uncle's servant. But then I hurriedly explained that I was a close servant and thus had the freedom to go to church or not, as the law permitted. However, my explanation wasn't very convincing, and she seemed displeased. She said.
tr: I had messed up again. I had forgotten that I was the old man's servant. But a moment later, I backtracked and explained that the servant was different from the usual servants; whether they wanted to or not, servants had to go to church, and according to the laws, they had to sit with the family. But this time, I hadn't managed it very well, because it was clear that he didn't quite believe me. “Really?” he asked, “You haven't told me a bunch of lies, have you?”
es: Well, he had caught me again. I had forgotten that I was the old man's servant. But the next moment, I came up with a sort of explanation that a valet was different from an ordinary servant and had to go to church whether he wanted to or not and sit with the family, because that was what the law said. But it didn't come out very well, and when I finished, I didn't see her convinced. She said:

en: “Honest injun, now, hain’t you been telling me a lot of lies?”
vi: - Hey, have you been deceiving me all this time?
tr: “Really?” he asked, “You haven't told me a bunch of lies, have you?”
es: —The truth, now, haven't you been telling me lies?

en: “Honest injun,” says I.
vi: I replied:
tr: "Really," I said.
es: —Really, no —I replied.

en: “None of it at all?”
vi: - I'm telling the truth.
tr: “Wasn't any of it a lie?”
es: —Not a single one?

en: “None of it at all. Not a lie in it,” says I.
vi: - Right? - Correct.
tr: “There were no lies. I didn't tell a single lie,” I said.
es: —Not a single one. I haven't told you a single lie.

en: “Lay your hand on this book and say it.”
vi: - Put your hand on this holy book and repeat after me.
tr: "Swear on this book and say it like that.""
es: —Put your hand on this book and repeat it.

en: I see it warn’t nothing but a dictionary, so I laid my hand on it and said it. So then she looked a little better satisfied, and says:
vi: To me, whether it's a scripture or any other book, it makes no difference, so I put my hand on it and repeated. She seemed a bit more satisfied. She said:
tr: I saw that the book was a simple dictionary, so I placed my hand on it and repeated my words. This time, he seemed a bit more convinced; he said:
es: I saw that it was nothing more than a dictionary, so I put my hand on it and repeated it. Then she seemed a bit more convinced and said:

en: “Well, then, I’ll believe some of it; but I hope to gracious if I’ll believe the rest.”
vi: - Alright, I believe some of it but not all.
tr: “Alright, I believe some of it; but it's hard to believe the rest.”
es: —Well, then I will believe some of what you have said, but the truth is that I am not going to believe the rest.

en: “What is it you won’t believe, Joe?” says Mary Jane, stepping in with Susan behind her. “It ain’t right nor kind for you to talk so to him, and him a stranger and so far from his people. How would you like to be treated so?”
vi: Mary Jane walked in from the door with Susan and said: - Joanna, what don't you believe? He's someone who came from afar, it's not good for you to say that. What if people treated you the same way?
tr: “What do you find hard to believe, Joe?” said Mary Jane, who appeared behind him with Susan by her side. “It's not right to talk to him like that, it's not polite either, because he is a stranger and far away from his own people. How can you treat him like this?”
es: —What is it that you won't believe, Jo? —asked Mary Jane, who entered with Susan behind her—. It's neither right nor kind to speak to a stranger who is so far from home like that. How would you feel if you were treated that way?

en: “That’s always your way, Maim—always sailing in to help somebody before they’re hurt. I hain’t done nothing to him. He’s told some stretchers, I reckon, and I said I wouldn’t swallow it all; and that’s every bit and grain I did say. I reckon he can stand a little thing like that, can’t he?”
vi: - You always defend others unconditionally. I didn't do anything to him. He made up some fabricated stories, and I said I didn't believe them, that's all. He probably couldn't stand those things either, right?
tr: “You always do this, Mary… You rush to help people before they even get hurt. I didn't tell him anything. He said some unreasonable things, and I told him I didn't swallow it all; I didn't say anything else. He can probably handle something this small, can't he?”
es: —That's what you always say, Maim: you always go to help someone before anything happens to them. I haven't done anything to him. I guess he told some exaggerations and I said I wasn't going to swallow all of them, that's all I did. I suppose he can handle it, right?

en: “I don’t care whether ’twas little or whether ’twas big; he’s here in our house and a stranger, and it wasn’t good of you to say it. If you was in his place it would make you feel ashamed; and so you oughtn’t to say a thing to another person that will make them feel ashamed.”
vi: - Whether it's a small matter or a big one, he's a guest in our house, you shouldn't say that. If you were in his position, you would feel embarrassed. You shouldn't say things that make others feel embarrassed.
tr: “I don't care whether it is small or large, here it is our guest and a stranger, it is not right for you to say these things. If you were in its place, you would be ashamed when the same things were said; therefore, you should not say things that would cause someone else to be ashamed.”
es: —I don't care if you told him a lot or a little; he is in our house and he is a stranger, and it is not right for you to say those things. If you were in his place, you would be ashamed, so you shouldn't say things to others that would make them feel ashamed.

en: “Why, Mam, he said—”
vi: - But, he said that...
tr: “But, Mary, said that...”
es: —But, Maim, he said...

en: “It don’t make no difference what he said—that ain’t the thing. The thing is for you to treat him kind, and not be saying things to make him remember he ain’t in his own country and amongst his own folks.”
vi: - She doesn't care about what he says. The important thing is that you must treat him well, and make him feel like he is living abroad, among strangers.
tr: “It doesn't matter what you said... That's not the issue. The issue is treating him well and avoiding things that would remind him he's not in his own country, not among his own people.”
es: —It doesn't matter what he said; that's not it. What matters is that you treat him with kindness, and don't go around saying things that remind him he's not in his own country and among his own people.

en: I says to myself, this is a girl that I’m letting that old reptile rob her of her money!
vi: I thought to myself: - A girl like that, and we let that despicable old man take all her money!
tr: This is the kind of girl I let our old reptile strip, I said to myself!
es: I said to myself: "And this is the girl I'm going to let that old reptile steal all her money from!"

en: Then Susan she waltzed in; and if you’ll believe me, she did give Hare-lip hark from the tomb!
vi: Then Miss Susan scolded her again, making her lip split.
tr: Then Susan interrupted and, believe me, hare-lip got the worst scolding I've ever heard in my life from her!
es: Then Susan got involved, and you can believe me, she gave harelip a piece of her mind.

en: Says I to myself, and this is another one that I’m letting him rob her of her money!
vi: I thought to myself: - This is the second girl that I am letting that old man take all the money from.
tr: Another one I let ours peel, I said to myself!
es: And I said to myself: "And this is another one I'm going to let get her money stolen!"

en: Then Mary Jane she took another inning, and went in sweet and lovely again—which was her way; but when she got done there warn’t hardly anything left o’ poor Hare-lip. So she hollered.
vi: Then Mary Jane spoke again, though her voice remained gentle and affectionate, which was her way of speaking. After speaking, the poor cleft-lipped girl burst into tears.
tr: Then Mary Jane took over the watch and this time adopted a sweet and loving demeanor – that was her style – but when she finished speaking, poor Hare-lip had only one option left. In the end, he gave up.
es: Then Mary Jane moved on to other things and became all charming again, which was her true style. But when she finished, the poor cleft-lip girl was practically devastated. So she started to scream.

en: “All right, then,” says the other girls; “you just ask his pardon.”
vi: The two older sisters said: - Now, you have to apologize to him.
tr: “Alright then,” said the other girls; “now go ahead and apologize to her.” The poor girl apologized to me.
es: —Very well, then —said the other girls—you just have to apologize to him.

en: She done it, too; and she done it beautiful. She done it so beautiful it was good to hear; and I wished I could tell her a thousand lies, so she could do it again.
vi: She apologized, and her apology was very adorable. I was moved when I heard it and wished I could tell a thousand lies just to hear her apologize again.
tr: And she apologized very beautifully. She apologized so beautifully that it was the sweetest thing I had ever heard; I wanted to tell her a thousand more lies so she could apologize to me again.
es: And that's what she did, and she did it very well, so well that it was a pleasure to listen to her, and I wish I could tell her a thousand lies again so she would repeat it once more.

en: I says to myself, this is another one that I’m letting him rob her of her money. And when she got through they all jest laid theirselves out to make me feel at home and know I was amongst friends. I felt so ornery and low down and mean that I says to myself, my mind’s made up; I’ll hive that money for them or bust.
vi: I silently thought to myself: - This is the third girl that I am letting that old man take all the money from. Then, they went outside so I could be at ease and feel like I was living among close friends. I felt so wicked and despicable, and thought I must find a way to hide that money for them.
tr: This is one of the girls whose money I allowed to be stolen, I said to myself! After Rabbit-lip finished speaking, they did everything to make me feel at home, to make me know I was among friends. I felt so despicable, treacherous, and bad that I made a firm promise to myself; I would either return the money to them or die.
es: And I said to myself: "This is another one I'm letting steal my money." And when it was over, they all started making me feel at home and letting me know I was among friends. I felt so low and vile that I said to myself: "It's decided; either I get them that money or I burst."

en: So then I lit out—for bed, I said, meaning some time or another. When I got by myself I went to thinking the thing over. I says to myself, shall I go to that doctor, private, and blow on these frauds? No—that won’t do. He might tell who told him; then the king and the duke would make it warm for me. Shall I go, private, and tell Mary Jane? No—I dasn’t do it. Her face would give them a hint, sure; they’ve got the money, and they’d slide right out and get away with it. If she was to fetch in help I’d get mixed up in the business before it was done with, I judge. No; there ain’t no good way but one. I got to steal that money, somehow; and I got to steal it some way that they won’t suspicion that I done it. They’ve got a good thing here, and they ain’t a-going to leave till they’ve played this family and this town for all they’re worth, so I’ll find a chance time enough. I’ll steal it and hide it; and by-and-by, when I’m away down the river, I’ll write a letter and tell Mary Jane where it’s hid. But I better hive it tonight if I can, because the doctor maybe hasn’t let up as much as he lets on he has; he might scare them out of here yet.
vi: I walked outside, thinking aimlessly, then went to sleep. Waking up, lying alone, I thought about that matter again. I asked myself if I should go to that doctor’s house to expose this deceit? That’s impossible. He would reveal who the accuser is, and the king and the duke might beat me to death. Or should I go and talk privately to Miss Mary Jane? That wouldn’t work either. What if she becomes suspicious and they find out, they would take the money and run away. There’s only one best way: I will steal that money, and steal it in such a way that they won’t suspect me. They are making a good profit, as long as they haven’t taken everything, they won’t leave. So I still have enough time to plan this. I will steal the money bag and hide it. Then I will leave, and write Miss Mary Jane a letter, telling her where I hid the money. If I can hide it tonight, I should do it immediately; because that doctor hasn’t given up and will continue to investigate, and they might get scared and run away, who knows.
tr: Then I said I was going to bed and left the kitchen, but I wasn't really going to bed, to be honest. When I was alone, I thought everything over thoroughly. I wondered to myself if I should secretly go to that doctor and report our fraudsters. No – that wouldn't work. He could say where he learned it from, and then the king and the duke would make my life miserable. Should I secretly go and tell Mary Jane? No – I couldn't do that either. They would understand everything the moment they looked at the girl's face; they would take the money and run away immediately. Even if the poor girl asked someone for help, I would get involved in one way or another. No, there was only one way that could work. I had to steal the money, and I had to do it in such a way that they would never suspect me. They had found a good opportunity here and had no intention of leaving without robbing both this family and the town, so I had enough time to wait for a chance. I would steal the money, hide it somewhere; then after going a bit down the river, I would write a letter to Mary Jane telling her where the money was hidden. But maybe the best thing was to get the money tonight if I could; because the doctor might not stay as calm as he seemed and could scare our guys into running away.
es: So I took off; to sleep, I said, without specifying the moment. When I was left alone, I started thinking things over. I asked myself: "Am I going to see that doctor, in secret, and betray these scoundrels? No, that wouldn't turn out well. He could say who told him and then the king and the duke would take care of me. Should I go and tell Mary Jane in secret? No... I don't dare. She would surely reveal it with some gesture; they already have the money and would take off with it. If I went looking for help, I would surely find myself caught up in the matter. No, there's only one way. I have to steal that money however I can and in a way that they don't suspect me. They've found a good vein here and they're not going to leave until they've squeezed everything they can out of this family and this town, so I have enough time to find a solution. I'm going to steal it and hide it and then, when I'm downriver, I'll write a letter and tell Mary Jane where it's hidden. But I'd better get it out tonight if I can, because maybe the doctor hasn't given up as he said and he might still scare them and drive them away."

en: So, thinks I, I’ll go and search them rooms. Upstairs the hall was dark, but I found the duke’s room, and started to paw around it with my hands; but I recollected it wouldn’t be much like the king to let anybody else take care of that money but his own self; so then I went to his room and begun to paw around there. But I see I couldn’t do nothing without a candle, and I dasn’t light one, of course. So I judged I’d got to do the other thing—lay for them and eavesdrop. About that time I hears their footsteps coming, and was going to skip under the bed; I reached for it, but it wasn’t where I thought it would be; but I touched the curtain that hid Mary Jane’s frocks, so I jumped in behind that and snuggled in amongst the gowns, and stood there perfectly still.
vi: Thinking so, I groped my way to their room. The hallway upstairs was pitch dark, but I still found the duke's room. I reached out and felt around, but then I suddenly remembered that it seemed the king didn't let anyone but the old man keep that money. I groped my way to the old man's room and felt around. It was too dark, there wasn't a single candle, and even if there was, I wouldn't dare light it. I had to lie here and listen to see what would happen. At that moment, I heard their footsteps approaching, so I crawled under the bed, but thinking that spot wasn't safe, I felt worried and then touched Mary Jane's clothes curtain, so I slipped right into the curtain and hid among the clothes, standing there very quietly.
tr: Then I thought, the best thing to do is to go and search their rooms. The corridor upstairs was dark, but I found the duke's room and started feeling around; but then it dawned on me that the king wouldn't entrust that much money to someone else; so I went to his room and started searching there. However, after a while, I realized I couldn't see anything without light, and besides, lighting a candle here wasn't a smart idea. The best thing was to resort to the other way, wait for them, and listen to their conversations. At that moment, I heard footsteps coming from downstairs and made a move to get under the bed; I was just about to get in, but the bed wasn't where I expected it to be, instead, I grabbed the curtain covering Mary Jane's clothes, immediately jumped behind the curtain, and took refuge among the nightgowns, then didn't move at all.
es: “So —I thought— I’m going to search their rooms.” Although the hallway upstairs was dark, I found the duke’s room and started rummaging with my hands, but I remembered that just as the king was, he wouldn’t let anyone but himself handle the money, so I went to his room and started rummaging. But I saw that I couldn’t do anything without a candle and, naturally, I didn’t dare to light one. So I thought of doing the other thing: staying put and listening to what they said. Almost at that moment I heard them coming up and decided to hide under the bed; I went towards it, but it wasn’t where I thought, I touched the curtain behind which Mary Jane’s dresses were, so I jumped behind it, snuggled among the dresses, and stayed there very quietly.

en: They come in and shut the door; and the first thing the duke done was to get down and look under the bed. Then I was glad I hadn’t found the bed when I wanted it. And yet, you know, it’s kind of natural to hide under the bed when you are up to anything private. They sets down then, and the king says:
vi: We entered the room and then closed the door. The first thing the duke did was bend down to look under the bed. Fortunately, I was not hiding under the bed. Whenever people intend to investigate someone's private matters, they often hide under the bed. They sat down, and the king said:
tr: They entered and closed the door; the first thing the shopkeeper did was to bend down and look under the bed. At that moment, I was glad I hadn't found the bed. Still, if you're doing something special, hiding under the bed is very natural. After that, they sat down and the king began to speak:
es: They entered, closed the door, and the first thing the duke did was to bend down to look under the bed. Then I was glad I hadn't found it when I was looking for it. And that, you know, it seems natural to hide under the bed when you don't want to be found. Then they sat down and the king says:

en: “Well, what is it? And cut it middlin’ short, because it’s better for us to be down there a-whoopin’ up the mournin’ than up here givin’ ’em a chance to talk us over.”
vi: - Say what you need to quickly. We still have to go down there and take care of the funeral, sitting here any longer just gives them more reason to gossip.
tr: "Yes, what is it? It would be better if you cut it short, because right now it's more appropriate for us to join the mourning downstairs rather than giving them a chance to stand upstairs and talk about us."
es: —Well, what's going on? And don't go on too long, because it's better if we get up really early in the morning so they don't have a chance to talk about us.

en: “Well, this is it, Capet. I ain’t easy; I ain’t comfortable. That doctor lays on my mind. I wanted to know your plans. I’ve got a notion, and I think it’s a sound one.”
vi: We still have to go down there and take care of the funeral, sitting here any longer just gives them more reason to gossip. - I'm very worried. That doctor will cause trouble for us, just wait and see. I've just thought of a plan, I wonder what you think about it.
tr: "That's enough; Capet. I'm not at ease, I don't feel peaceful at all. My mind is stuck on the doctor. I want to know what you are planning. I have some ideas, and it would be great if we act according to them."
es: —Well, it's about the following, Capeto. It's not easy; I don't feel at ease. I can't forget about that doctor. I wanted to know what plans you had. I have an idea and I think it's good.

en: “What is it, duke?”
vi: - What plan?
tr: “What is it, Duke?”
es: —What is it, Duke?

en: “That we better glide out of this before three in the morning, and clip it down the river with what we’ve got. Specially, seeing we got it so easy—given back to us, flung at our heads, as you may say, when of course we allowed to have to steal it back. I’m for knocking off and lighting out.”
vi: - Let's sneak out of here before three in the morning, taking all our belongings to the raft and heading downstream. Getting that amount of money is more than enough. I'll sneak out first to arrange things.
tr: “The best thing is to leave here before three in the morning without being seen and continue down the river with what we have. Look how easily we handled it – everything was given back to us, almost thrown at our heads; so it means we are allowed to take and go. If you ask me, let's leave and never come back.”
es: —We better get out of here before three in the morning and head down to the river with what we already have. Especially since we got it so easily that it was practically given to us, you could say it was forced upon us, when we thought we would have to steal it again. I think it's best if we leave as soon as possible.

en: That made me feel pretty bad. About an hour or two ago it would a been a little different, but now it made me feel bad and disappointed, The king rips out and says:
vi: Hearing him say that, I felt too much and became disappointed. The king interrupted and asked:
tr: When I heard this, I felt very bad. A couple of hours earlier, it would have been a bit different, but now I felt both bad and frustrated. The king replied angrily:
es: That made me feel quite bad. An hour or two earlier it would have been something different, but now it made me feel bad and disenchanted. The king lets out a shout and says:

en: “What! And not sell out the rest o’ the property? March off like a passel of fools and leave eight or nine thous’n’ dollars’ worth o’ property layin’ around jest sufferin’ to be scooped in?—and all good, salable stuff, too.”
vi: - And what about the unsold assets, eight or nine thousand dollars, not a small amount. And they're all good, all things that can fetch a good price.
tr: “What did you say? So, we shouldn't sell the rest of the property? Should we just leave like two fools and let property worth eight to nine thousand dollars, which is waiting for us to enjoy the cream, stay behind? Besides, there are still a lot of valuable things to sell.”
es: —What! And not sell the rest of the inheritance? Leave like a couple of idiots and leave eight or nine thousand dollars in land waiting for someone to take it?; when everything can be sold in a moment!

en: The duke he grumbled; said the bag of gold was enough, and he didn’t want to go no deeper—didn’t want to rob a lot of orphans of everything they had.
vi: The duke grumbled, saying that the bag of money was already enough, there was no need to be too greedy - and they shouldn't take everything from the orphaned girls either.
tr: The Duke continued to grumble; he said that his bag of gold was sufficient and that he did not want to go any further – he did not want to steal everything from the orphaned children.
es: The duke started to grumble, said that the bag of gold was enough and that he didn't want to get into more trouble; that he didn't want to rob some orphans of everything they had.

en: “Why, how you talk!” says the king. “We sha’n’t rob ’em of nothing at all but jest this money. The people that buys the property is the suff’rers; because as soon ’s it’s found out ’at we didn’t own it—which won’t be long after we’ve slid—the sale won’t be valid, and it’ll all go back to the estate. These yer orphans ’ll git their house back agin, and that’s enough for them; they’re young and spry, and k’n easy earn a livin’. They ain’t a-goin to suffer. Why, jest think—there’s thous’n’s and thous’n’s that ain’t nigh so well off. Bless you, they ain’t got noth’n’ to complain of.”
vi: The king said: - This guy speaks strangely. We didn't steal anything else besides this money. The person who buys the property is the one who gets deceived, because when they find out this property doesn't belong to them, it will become state property. Then the house will return to those orphaned girls. That's enough. They are still young, still cry, and can easily make a living. Just think, thousands, thousands of dong are about to fall into our hands. They have nothing to complain about.
tr: “What nonsense are you talking about!” said the king. “We are not completely robbing them, we are just taking this money. The real trouble will fall upon those who bought the property – the event will be heard shortly after we leave – the sales will be invalidated and all the property will return to them. Those orphans of yours will get their homes back and that will be enough for them; they are all still in the prime of their lives, they can easily earn their livelihoods. They will not bear the brunt of this matter. Just think… there are thousands of people who are not as well off as they are. They will not be in a situation to complain at all.”
es: —What things you say! —replied the king—. We are only going to steal this money from them. Those who buy these properties will lose out, because as soon as it is discovered that they were not ours, which will be shortly after we have left, the sale will not be valid and everything will return to the estate. These orphans will get their house back again, and that is enough for them; they are young and strong, and they can easily earn a living. They are not going to lose anything. But, man, think about it; there are thousands and thousands of people who don't have even half. I assure you that they have no reason to complain.

en: Well, the king he talked him blind; so at last he give in, and said all right, but said he believed it was blamed foolishness to stay, and that doctor hanging over them. But the king says:
vi: The king's reasoning even swayed the duke. But he was still worried about staying because he feared that doctor might cause trouble. But the king said:
tr: The king kept advancing towards him, and the duke finally gave in. But the doctor did not forget to say that staying around was a great foolishness. The king immediately replied:
es: The king gave him so many arguments that he eventually gave in and said fine, but he thought it was stupid to stay there, with that doctor suspecting them. But the king says:

en: “Cuss the doctor! What do we k’yer for him? Hain’t we got all the fools in town on our side? And ain’t that a big enough majority in any town?”
vi: - Ignore that doctor! Why worry so much? Plenty of fools in this town are on our side. We've got the majority already.
tr: “To hell with the doctor! Why should we care about him? Aren't all the fools in the town already on our side? Don't they make up the majority of the town?”
es: —To hell with the doctor! What do we care about him? Don't we have all the fools in the town on our side? And isn't that a sufficient majority in any town?

en: So they got ready to go down stairs again. The duke says:
vi: After speaking, the two prepared to go downstairs. The Duke said:
tr: They prepared to descend again. "I don't think we put the money in a good place," said the duke.
es: So they prepared to go back down. The duke says:

en: “I don’t think we put that money in a good place.”
vi: - I think keeping money like that is not secure.
tr: "I don't think we put the money in a good place," said the duke.
es: —I don't think we left the money in a good place.

en: That cheered me up. I’d begun to think I warn’t going to get a hint of no kind to help me. The king says:
vi: Hearing that, I was overjoyed. So I no longer had to struggle with the search. The king asked
tr: I was glad to hear this. I had started to think that they wouldn't give me any useful clues. “Why?” asked the king.”
es: That encouraged me. I had started to think that they wouldn't give me a single clue that would help me. The king says:

en: “Why?”
vi: - Why?
tr: “Why?” asked the king.”
es: —Why?

en: “Because Mary Jane ’ll be in mourning from this out; and first you know the nigger that does up the rooms will get an order to box these duds up and put ’em away; and do you reckon a nigger can run across money and not borrow some of it?”
vi: - Because Mary Jane will have to go into this room to get the mourning clothes, the black servants cleaning the room and arranging the furniture neatly might see the bundle of money and borrow some, right?
tr: “Because Mary Jane will be dressed in mourning clothes from now on, the black servant who looks after the rooms will be told to gather these clothes and put them in a chest and store it away; don't you think a black servant would pocket some money if they found it?”
es: —Because from now on Mary Jane will be in mourning and the first thing she will do is tell the black man to clean the rooms, to put those clothes in a box and take them away; and, do you think that a black man is going to find the money and not borrow something?

en: “Your head’s level agin, duke,” says the king; and he comes a-fumbling under the curtain two or three foot from where I was. I stuck tight to the wall and kept mighty still, though quivery; and I wondered what them fellows would say to me if they catched me; and I tried to think what I’d better do if they did catch me. But the king he got the bag before I could think more than about a half a thought, and he never suspicioned I was around. They took and shoved the bag through a rip in the straw tick that was under the feather-bed, and crammed it in a foot or two amongst the straw and said it was all right now, because a nigger only makes up the feather-bed, and don’t turn over the straw tick only about twice a year, and so it warn’t in no danger of getting stole now.
vi: The king said: - You are very wise. Then the old man went into the place with the clothes curtain, just about a meter away from me. I pressed myself tightly against the wall, standing very still, even though I had already started to tremble. I was thinking about what I would say if they caught me here when the king took out a money pouch and stuffed it under the mattress, pushing it in about a meter deep.
tr: “Your mind is sharp as ever, duke,” said the king. He started probing under the curtain a meter away from where I was. I pressed myself against the wall and didn't even breathe, but I was trembling with fear; at first, I thought about what these men would say if they caught me, and then I tried to think about what I would say if they did. But before I could gather my thoughts, the king found the bag and didn't notice that I was nearby at all. They pushed the bag through a tear in the straw mattress under the feather bed; they pushed it in about half a meter and said there was no longer a problem because the blacks only made the feather bed and turned the straw mattress only twice a year, so there was no longer any danger of the bag being stolen.
es: —You have your head screwed on right again, Duke —says the king. He started looking under the curtain two or three feet from where I was. I pressed myself against the wall without making any noise, although I was trembling, and I wondered what those guys would say if they caught me, trying to think about what I would have to do then. But the king found the bag before I could come up with even half an idea, and it was never suspected that I was around there. They grabbed the bag and put it through a tear in the straw mattress, under the feather mattress, and left it tucked about a foot or two between the straw and said it was fine because the blacks only make the feather mattress and only turn the straw mattress once or twice a year, so now there was no danger of it being stolen.

en: But I knowed better. I had it out of there before they was half-way down stairs. I groped along up to my cubby, and hid it there till I could get a chance to do better. I judged I better hide it outside of the house somewheres, because if they missed it they would give the house a good ransacking: I knowed that very well. Then I turned in, with my clothes all on; but I couldn’t a gone to sleep if I’d a wanted to, I was in such a sweat to get through with the business. By-and-by I heard the king and the duke come up; so I rolled off my pallet and laid with my chin at the top of my ladder, and waited to see if anything was going to happen. But nothing did.
vi: They said that place was safe because the black man who tidied the bed would only work on the surface. I waited until they were halfway down the stairs, then took out the money pouch, ran upstairs to where I slept, and hid it in a spot until a more convenient time. I thought it might be better to hide it somewhere outside this house. Because if they noticed it was missing, they would thoroughly search the house first. Then I went back into the house, my clothes neat and tidy. I wanted to sleep but couldn't because I was worried about this matter. A little later, the king and the duke came back up; I lay on the mattress, poking my head out near the stair railing, waiting to see if anything would happen. But nothing happened.
tr: But I knew the location of the bag. Before they reached halfway down the stairs, I took the bag from there. Without being seen by anyone, I went up to the attic and hid the bag there until I found a better place. The best thing was to hide the bag somewhere outside the house, because if my family realized it was missing, they could turn the house upside down. I had no doubt about that. Then I lay down on the bed without taking off my clothes, but no matter how much I wanted to, I couldn't sleep; I wouldn't be able to calm down and sleep until I finished this task. After a while, I heard the king and the duke coming up; I got out of bed, leaned my chin on the top of the stairs, and started waiting to see if anything would happen. Nothing happened.
es: But they didn't count on me. I took it out before they had reached the bottom of the stairs. I groped my way to my cubicle and hid it there until I could think of something better. I thought it would be better to hide it somewhere outside the house, because if they missed it, they would search the house thoroughly; I was convinced of that. Then I went to bed with all my clothes on, but I couldn't fall asleep even if I wanted to, because I was so eager to finish with the whole matter. After a while, I heard the king and the duke coming up, so I got off the cot and rested my chin on the last step of the stairs to see if anything would happen. But nothing happened.

en: So I held on till all the late sounds had quit and the early ones hadn’t begun yet; and then I slipped down the ladder.
vi: So I waited until it was quiet, then he gently grasped the stair railing and went downstairs.
tr: Upon this, I waited until the sounds of those preparing to sleep ceased, and before the sound of shields could be heard, I quietly descended the stairs to finish my task.
es: That's how I stayed until the last noises stopped being heard and the first ones hadn't started yet, and then I went down the stairs in silence.

en: CHAPTER XXVII.
vi: Chapter XXVII
tr: Chapter Twenty-Seven
es: Chapter 27

en: I crept to their doors and listened; they was snoring. So I tiptoed along, and got down stairs all right. There warn’t a sound anywheres. I peeped through a crack of the dining-room door, and see the men that was watching the corpse all sound asleep on their chairs. The door was open into the parlor, where the corpse was laying, and there was a candle in both rooms. I passed along, and the parlor door was open; but I see there warn’t nobody in there but the remainders of Peter; so I shoved on by; but the front door was locked, and the key wasn’t there. Just then I heard somebody coming down the stairs, back behind me. I run in the parlor and took a swift look around, and the only place I see to hide the bag was in the coffin. The lid was shoved along about a foot, showing the dead man’s face down in there, with a wet cloth over it, and his shroud on. I tucked the money-bag in under the lid, just down beyond where his hands was crossed, which made me creep, they was so cold, and then I run back across the room and in behind the door.
vi: I leaned my ear close to the door of the conman's room; they were snoring loudly. I tiptoed down the stairs. There wasn't a sound around. I peeked through the crack of the dining room door and saw that the people watching over the coffin were fast asleep. The dining room door led to the living room. The coffin was there. Each room had a candle lit. I walked through; the living room door was still open, but there was no one there, only Peter's corpse. So, I slipped outside quietly, but the front door was locked. Just then, I heard footsteps coming down the stairs, right behind me. I ran into the living room, glanced around quickly, and saw that besides the coffin, there was nowhere to hide. The coffin lid was left open a few inches, revealing the face of the dead person covered with a wet cloth, along with the burial cloth. I hurriedly slipped the money bundle under the coffin lid, right under the crossed hands of the dead person. When I touched it, I felt a chill run through my body. Then I dashed through the dining room and hid behind the door.
tr: Tiptoeing, I came to their door and started listening; both were snoring. So, I went downstairs again without making a sound. Not a sound was heard. When I looked inside through a crack in the dining room door, I saw that the men waiting for the funeral had fallen asleep on the couches. The dining room opened into the parlor where the body lay, and there was a lit candle in each room. When I entered, I saw that the parlor door was open; but there was no one in the parlor except Peter's corpse; so I continued on my way, but the front door was locked and the key was nowhere to be seen. Just then, I heard someone coming down the stairs and approaching from behind. I immediately ran to the parlor and looked around hastily; the only place I could hide the bag was the coffin. The coffin lid was open about thirty centimeters and the dead man's face was exposed, or rather, only a wet cloth covered his face. I pushed the money bag inside the lid, just below where his hands were clasped on his chest. When I touched his ice-cold hands, my hair stood on end. Then I immediately ran to the other end and hid behind the door.
es: I WENT IN SILENCE to their doors to listen; they were snoring. So I tiptoed on and went down the stairs. There wasn't a sound anywhere. I looked through a crack in the dining room door and saw the men watching over the corpse, all asleep in their chairs. The door led to the room where the body was, and there was a candle in each room. I went on to the door of the room, which was open, but I saw that there was no one there except Peter's remains, so I continued: the main door was closed, and the key was nowhere to be seen. Just then I heard someone coming down the stairs behind me. I ran to the room, looked quickly around, and the only place I saw to hide the bag was in the coffin. The lid was ajar by about a foot, exposing the dead man's face with a damp cloth over it and the shroud. I slipped the money bag under the lid, just beyond where his crossed hands were, which gave me the creeps; they were icy cold, and then I ran back across the room and hid behind the door.

en: The person coming was Mary Jane. She went to the coffin, very soft, and kneeled down and looked in; then she put up her handkerchief, and I see she begun to cry, though I couldn’t hear her, and her back was to me. I slid out, and as I passed the dining-room I thought I’d make sure them watchers hadn’t seen me; so I looked through the crack, and everything was all right. They hadn’t stirred.
vi: The person who just walked in is Miss Mary Jane. She went to the coffin, knelt down to look inside, took out a handkerchief, and sobbed quietly, her back turned to me. I stepped outside, passing through the dining room, to make sure that the people keeping watch didn't see me, so I stopped and peered through the crack in the door. They didn't move at all, which was reassuring.
tr: The person who came was Mary Jane. She quietly went to the side of the coffin, bent down and looked inside; then she took out her handkerchief and I saw that she started crying, but she made no sound and her back was turned to me. I immediately left there quietly and after passing through the dining room and closing the door behind me, I looked through the crack in the door to make sure the guards hadn't seen me. Everything seemed to be fine. They hadn't moved at all.
es: The one who entered was Mary Jane. She went to the coffin, walking slowly, knelt down and looked inside; then she took out her handkerchief and I saw that she started to cry, although I couldn't hear her and she had her back to me. I came out of my hiding place and as I passed by the dining room I thought of making sure that those at the wake hadn't seen me, so I looked through a crack and everything was in order. They hadn't even moved.

en: I slipped up to bed, feeling ruther blue, on accounts of the thing playing out that way after I had took so much trouble and run so much resk about it. Says I, if it could stay where it is, all right; because when we get down the river a hundred mile or two I could write back to Mary Jane, and she could dig him up again and get it; but that ain’t the thing that’s going to happen; the thing that’s going to happen is, the money ’ll be found when they come to screw on the lid. Then the king ’ll get it again, and it ’ll be a long day before he gives anybody another chance to smouch it from him. Of course I wanted to slide down and get it out of there, but I dasn’t try it. Every minute it was getting earlier now, and pretty soon some of them watchers would begin to stir, and I might get catched—catched with six thousand dollars in my hands that nobody hadn’t hired me to take care of. I don’t wish to be mixed up in no such business as that, I says to myself.
vi: I went back to bed, still scared because of what I had just done, arduous and dangerous. I planned that when we traveled about a hundred miles downstream, I could write a letter to inform Miss Mary Jane, and she could dig up the grave to retrieve the money. But what if things didn't go as planned, and when they closed the coffin, they discovered the money hidden inside? In that case, the king would get it again, and I wouldn't have a chance to retrieve it. At this moment, I wanted to crawl down and get the money bag out. But I didn't dare to leave anymore. The sky was gradually getting brighter. The people keeping watch had started to wake up. If I went down again, I could very likely get caught with six thousand dollars in hand. It's best not to get involved in that matter anymore.
tr: I quietly went up to the attic and lay down on my bed feeling downcast; despite getting myself into so much trouble and taking so many risks, it hadn't turned out well. As long as the bag stayed where it was, there was no problem; because after the river flowed down about a hundred miles, I could write a letter to Mary Jane and have her dig up the grave to get the money; but that's not how it would go, they would find the money when they closed the lid. Then the king would get hold of the money again and wouldn't let anyone near it. Of course, I very much wanted to go down and get the bag from there, but I just couldn't muster the courage. Morning was approaching and some of the guards might wake up, and I would get caught – and I would get caught with six thousand dollars that no one had allowed me to take. I thought to myself, I would never want to be in such a situation.
es: I went to bed, quite sad, because of how things were turning out after I had worried so much and taken so many risks. I said to myself: "If it could stay where it is, very well; because when we get to the river, a hundred or two hundred miles away, I could write to Mary Jane and she could dig it up and take it out, but that's not what's going to happen; what's going to happen is that they'll find the money when they go to close the lid. Then the king will get it again and won't give anyone else a chance to steal it." Naturally, I wanted to go down and take it out of there, but I didn't dare try. Every minute dawn was approaching and very soon some of the people from the wake would start moving and maybe catch me with six thousand dollars in my hands when no one had entrusted me with the money. "Damn the need for me to get involved in something like this," I said to myself.

en: When I got down stairs in the morning the parlor was shut up, and the watchers was gone. There warn’t nobody around but the family and the widow Bartley and our tribe. I watched their faces to see if anything had been happening, but I couldn’t tell.
vi: In the morning, I went downstairs to find the living room door closed, and the guards had all left. Only the household members, the widow Barley, and us remained. I carefully examined their faces to see if there were any changes, but I saw nothing different.
tr: When I went downstairs in the morning, the living room was closed and the guards were gone. Apart from the family members, the widow Mrs. Bartley, and our own people, there was no one else around. I examined their faces to see if anything had happened, but I couldn't understand anything.
es: When I came down in the morning, the living room was closed and the people from the wake had left. There was no one left but the family, the widow Bartley, and our tribe. I looked at their faces to see if anything had happened, but I couldn't see anything.

en: Towards the middle of the day the undertaker come with his man, and they set the coffin in the middle of the room on a couple of chairs, and then set all our chairs in rows, and borrowed more from the neighbors till the hall and the parlor and the dining-room was full. I see the coffin lid was the way it was before, but I dasn’t go to look in under it, with folks around.
vi: By noon, the funeral director arrived with another person. They carried the coffin to the middle of the house, placed it on two chairs, then arranged all the other chairs in rows, even borrowing more chairs from neighboring houses to fill both the dining room and the living room. I looked at the coffin lid and saw it was still the same, but because there were many people around, I didn't dare to step closer to look inside. Later, many people gradually arrived.
tr: Towards midday, the supplier came with a man and they brought the coffin into the middle of the room and placed it on top of two chairs; then they lined up all the chairs side by side, borrowed some chairs from the neighbors, and filled both the entrance, the living room, and the dining room. I saw that the lid of the coffin was still in the same position as before, but with so many people around, I didn't dare to look inside.
es: By midday, the gravedigger arrived with his assistant and placed the coffin in the middle of the living room, supported by a couple of chairs; then they arranged all our chairs in rows and borrowed more from the neighbors until the foyer, the dining room, and the living room were full. I saw that the coffin lid was the same as before, but I didn't dare to look at what was underneath it, with so many people in front.

en: Then the people begun to flock in, and the beats and the girls took seats in the front row at the head of the coffin, and for a half an hour the people filed around slow, in single rank, and looked down at the dead man’s face a minute, and some dropped in a tear, and it was all very still and solemn, only the girls and the beats holding handkerchiefs to their eyes and keeping their heads bent, and sobbing a little. There warn’t no other sound but the scraping of the feet on the floor and blowing noses—because people always blows them more at a funeral than they do at other places except church.
vi: The two swindlers and the girls sat in the front row of seats right by the coffin. For half an hour, the procession of people slowly walked around the coffin, eyes fixed on the deceased for a minute with a solemn, respectful expression. The girls and the two swindlers dabbed their faces with handkerchiefs and then bowed down, sobbing. Only the sound of shuffling feet on the floor and the sniffles could be heard, because people tend to sniffle more at a funeral than in other places, sometimes even more than in church.
tr: After a while, other people started to arrive; women and girls sat in the row by the coffin. For half an hour, people slowly passed by in a line, each taking a minute to look at the dead man's face. Some shed a few tears. Everything was extremely quiet and serious; only the girls and women were wiping their eyes with handkerchiefs and standing with their heads bowed. Occasionally, they would sob. Nothing could be heard except for the sound of feet dragging on the ground and the sniffles – because people tend to sniffle more at funerals compared to other places outside the church.
es: Then people and authorities began to arrive, and the girls took seats in the front row, next to the head of the coffin, and for half an hour people filed past, each taking a moment to look at the face of the deceased, and some shed a tear, all very quietly and solemnly, and the girls and the authorities were the only ones who brought handkerchiefs to their eyes, kept their heads down, and whimpered a little. No other noise was heard, except for the shuffling of feet on the floor and the sound of noses blowing, because people always blow their noses more at a funeral than anywhere else, except in church.

en: When the place was packed full the undertaker he slid around in his black gloves with his softy soothering ways, putting on the last touches, and getting people and things all ship-shape and comfortable, and making no more sound than a cat. He never spoke; he moved people around, he squeezed in late ones, he opened up passageways, and done it with nods, and signs with his hands. Then he took his place over against the wall. He was the softest, glidingest, stealthiest man I ever see; and there warn’t no more smile to him than there is to a ham.
vi: When everyone had arrived, the funeral director stepped out, wearing black gloves, with a very calm demeanor. He made final preparations, arranging for everyone to be seated somewhere. He didn't say anything; directing one person here, urging another there, clearing pathways from one place to another, all done with nods and hand signals. Then he stood close to the wall. He was truly a gentle, graceful person like no other. It seemed he never smiled.
tr: When all the chairs were filled, the quartermaster, with his black gloves and soft, soothing demeanor, made a round to make final adjustments, arranging people and objects neatly and comfortably, all the while behaving as quietly as a cat. He did not speak at all; he moved people around, squeezed in the latecomers, opened passageways, and did it all with nods and hand signals. Then he took his place in front of the wall. He was the lightest, most stealthily advancing, and inconspicuously moving man I had ever seen up to that day; moreover, there was not the slightest hint of a smile on his face.
es: When the house was full, the undertaker walked around everywhere with his black gloves and his soft and soothing manners, adding the final touches, putting everything in order, and making people feel comfortable, without making any noise, like a cat. He didn't say a word; he moved people around, found places for the last arrivals, opened pathways, all with gestures of his head and hands. Then he took his place leaning against the wall. He was the softest, slipperiest, and most unctuous man I have ever seen in my life; and he never smiled, he was like a piece of meat.

en: They had borrowed a melodeum—a sick one; and when everything was ready a young woman set down and worked it, and it was pretty skreeky and colicky, and everybody joined in and sung, and Peter was the only one that had a good thing, according to my notion. Then the Reverend Hobson opened up, slow and solemn, and begun to talk; and straight off the most outrageous row busted out in the cellar a body ever heard; it was only one dog, but he made a most powerful racket, and he kept it up right along; the parson he had to stand there, over the coffin, and wait—you couldn’t hear yourself think. It was right down awkward, and nobody didn’t seem to know what to do. But pretty soon they see that long-legged undertaker make a sign to the preacher as much as to say, “Don’t you worry—just depend on me.” Then he stooped down and begun to glide along the wall, just his shoulders showing over the people’s heads. So he glided along, and the powwow and racket getting more and more outrageous all the time; and at last, when he had gone around two sides of the room, he disappears down cellar. Then in about two seconds we heard a whack, and the dog he finished up with a most amazing howl or two, and then everything was dead still, and the parson begun his solemn talk where he left off. In a minute or two here comes this undertaker’s back and shoulders gliding along the wall again; and so he glided and glided around three sides of the room, and then rose up, and shaded his mouth with his hands, and stretched his neck out towards the preacher, over the people’s heads, and says, in a kind of a coarse whisper, “He had a rat!” Then he drooped down and glided along the wall again to his place. You could see it was a great satisfaction to the people, because naturally they wanted to know. A little thing like that don’t cost nothing, and it’s just the little things that makes a man to be looked up to and liked. There warn’t no more popular man in town than what that undertaker was.
vi: They had already borrowed an old accordion. When everyone was ready, a young woman sat down and began to play music, which sounded so mournful it could break your heart. Everyone sang along to the tune. Then Father Hobson solemnly, slowly began to speak. Just as the priest was about to start speaking, a terrible noise suddenly echoed from downstairs. It was the barking of a dog. The priest had to stand by the coffin waiting until the dog stopped barking, otherwise no one would hear what he was saying. But the undertaker raised his hand to signal to the priest as if to say, "Don't worry, I've got this." He bent down and walked along the wall, yet his shoulders still stood out above everyone else. The dog's barking grew louder and louder. He passed through two rooms and then turned downstairs. Two seconds later, I heard a loud bang, the dog howled a few more times, and then it fell silent. Only then did the priest solemnly begin the sermon. A few minutes later, the undertaker walked back along the wall, his head and shoulders bobbing past several walls in the room, then he stood up straight, covered his mouth with his hand, stretched his neck over everyone's heads towards the priest, and whispered in a slightly sharp tone: "It caught a rat," then bent down and walked back to his original spot. Everyone seemed very pleased, as they had been curious to know what was happening. Such a small matter wasn't worth knowing, but everyone paid great attention to it. In this town, the undertaker was the most well-known person.
tr: A borrowed organ had been brought in – it was a bit out of tune; once everything was ready, a young woman sat down and started playing the organ; it was making quite a bit of creaking and groaning, everyone was joining in the music and singing the hymn. Probably the only person who was comfortable at that moment was Peter. Then Reverend Hobson stood up and began to speak slowly and solemnly; just then, a tremendous barking was heard from the basement; it was a single dog, but it was making a terrible noise, and it just wouldn't stop; the reverend had to stand there by the coffin and wait...One couldn't even hear their own thoughts. It was truly a very inappropriate situation, and no one seemed to know what to do. Soon they saw the long-legged undertaker make a sign to the reverend, meaning "Don't worry, I'll handle it right away. " Then the undertaker began to slide along the wall, only his shoulders visible over the heads of the people. As he slid along, the noise and commotion increased, becoming more nerve-wracking; finally, he crossed from one end of the room to the other and disappeared at the basement door. A few seconds later, we heard a "thud!" sound, the dog howled in surprise once or twice, then the noise completely stopped, and the reverend continued his eulogy from where he had left off. A minute or two later, the undertaker's back and shoulders began to slide along the wall again; he slid around three sides of the room, rose a bit, covered his mouth with his hand, stretched his neck towards the reverend over the heads of the people, and whispered loudly: "Caught a rat!" He then lowered himself and slid back to his place along the wall. People seemed very relieved, naturally wanting to know what had happened. Such a small kindness costs nothing, and it is precisely these little things that make a person valued and loved. There was probably no one in town as beloved as this undertaker.
es: They had borrowed a harmonium that was in pretty bad shape; when everything was ready, a young woman sat at it and started to play, but it only produced squeaks and wheezes, and everyone started to sing. Peter was the only one who seemed to enjoy himself, as it appeared to me. Then it was Reverend Hobson's turn, who began to speak slowly and solemnly, and immediately the most horrible noise imaginable was heard from the basement: it was just a dog, but it was making a fearful racket and wouldn't stop; the priest had to stand there beside the coffin and wait: nothing else could be heard. It was truly terrible, and it seemed that no one knew what to do. But then they saw that the tall undertaker was signaling to the priest as if to say, "Don't worry; I'm here." Then he bent down and started to slide along the wall; only his shoulders could be seen above the heads of the people. So he kept sliding, with that racket growing more and more horrible, and finally, after he had gone around two sides of the room, he disappeared into the basement. Then, after about two seconds, we heard a thud and the dog ended with one or two of the strangest barks, and then everyone fell silent and the priest resumed his solemn talk from where he had left off. After a minute or two, the back and shoulders of the undertaker reappeared, sliding along the wall again, and he continued sliding around three sides of the room; then he stood up, cupped his hands around his mouth, and, stretching his neck towards the priest, said in a sort of hoarse whisper, over the heads of the people: "It had a rat!" Then he slid back along the wall to return to his place. It was clear that this was very satisfactory to the people, because naturally they wanted to know what it was about. These little things cost nothing and are what earn a man admiration and respect. There was no one more popular in the whole town than that undertaker.

en: Well, the funeral sermon was very good, but pison long and tiresome; and then the king he shoved in and got off some of his usual rubbage, and at last the job was through, and the undertaker begun to sneak up on the coffin with his screw-driver. I was in a sweat then, and watched him pretty keen. But he never meddled at all; just slid the lid along as soft as mush, and screwed it down tight and fast. So there I was! I didn’t know whether the money was in there or not. So, says I, s’pose somebody has hogged that bag on the sly?—now how do I know whether to write to Mary Jane or not? S’pose she dug him up and didn’t find nothing, what would she think of me? Blame it, I says, I might get hunted up and jailed; I’d better lay low and keep dark, and not write at all; the thing’s awful mixed now; trying to better it, I’ve worsened it a hundred times, and I wish to goodness I’d just let it alone, dad fetch the whole business!
vi: The pastor's sermon was good but too long. Then, after that, the king came out and babbled for a while. When everything was done, the funeral director approached the coffin with a wrench to tighten the screws. At that moment, I was very nervous, my eyes fixed on the funeral director. But he just slowly and gently lowered the lid, then tightened the screws very firmly. That's it! I wondered what if someone deceitful had already taken the money bundle out? Should I write a letter to Mary Jane? What if I write it and she digs up the grave and finds nothing, what would she think of me? I might even end up in jail. It's better not to write anything at all. Everything in my head was now all mixed up. The more I thought about it, the more complicated it seemed, so I decided to just let it be.
tr: The funeral ceremony went very well, but it was still long and boring. Finally, the king also approached the coffin and offered a bunch of his usual nonsense, and when he was done, the undertaker approached the coffin with his screwdriver. That's when I got anxious and started watching him closely. But he didn't dawdle at all; he just closed the lid very slowly and tightened the screws well. Look at this situation! I didn't know if the money was in the coffin. What if someone took the bag without anyone noticing, I thought...How would I know whether or not to write to Mary Jane now? Let's say she dug up the grave and found nothing...What would she think about me? Damn, I could get caught and thrown in jail; the best thing was to keep quiet and not draw too much attention, not to write any letters; things had gotten really messed up; I had made things worse while trying to fix them, I wished I had never gotten involved, I was truly a thousand times regretful!
es: Well, the funeral sermon turned out very well, but horribly long and tiring; then the king got up and spouted some of his usual nonsense, and finally the affair ended and the undertaker approached the coffin with his screwdriver. I started sweating and watched him very closely. But he didn't see anything, he just slid the lid, smooth as if it were greased, and screwed it down tight. That's how we were! I didn't know if the money was in there or not. Then I said to myself: "What if someone has secretly taken the bag? How do I know whether to write to Mary Jane or not? And if he digs it up and finds nothing, what will he think of me? Darn it," I said to myself, "they might as well look for me and lock me up: I'd better keep my mouth shut and not write anything; now everything is a mess and by trying to improve it I've made it a hundred times worse than before; I wish I had left everything alone. Damn the whole affair!

en: They buried him, and we come back home, and I went to watching faces again—I couldn’t help it, and I couldn’t rest easy. But nothing come of it; the faces didn’t tell me nothing.
vi: After the burial was finished, we returned home. I once again paid attention to the faces to see what I could find, but I found nothing in those expressions; I couldn't understand.
tr: They buried the funeral; when we returned home, I started examining the faces again – I couldn't help it, I just couldn't relax. But again, I couldn't make anything out – the faces were telling me nothing.
es: They buried him, we returned home, and I went back to looking at everyone's faces; I couldn't help it nor could I stay calm. But nothing happened; the faces told me nothing.

en: The king he visited around in the evening, and sweetened everybody up, and made himself ever so friendly; and he give out the idea that his congregation over in England would be in a sweat about him, so he must hurry and settle up the estate right away and leave for home. He was very sorry he was so pushed, and so was everybody; they wished he could stay longer, but they said they could see it couldn’t be done. And he said of course him and William would take the girls home with them; and that pleased everybody too, because then the girls would be well fixed and amongst their own relations; and it pleased the girls, too—tickled them so they clean forgot they ever had a trouble in the world; and told him to sell out as quick as he wanted to, they would be ready. Them poor things was that glad and happy it made my heart ache to see them getting fooled and lied to so, but I didn’t see no safe way for me to chip in and change the general tune.
vi: In the evening, the king visited familiar people, pretending to be friendly. The old man said that his parishioners in England were eagerly waiting for him, so he had to quickly arrange and settle everything to return. The old man said he regretted having to rush like that. Everyone said the same, they wished he could stay longer. The old man also said that he and William would take those nieces back to their country. Hearing that, everyone was happy for the girls who would have relatives to rely on. The girls were also delighted to hear him say that. The girls urged him to sell the house and land quickly. The more joyful they were, the more heartbroken I felt seeing them being deceived. But I had no way to change the situation.
tr: When evening came, the king walked around, spoke sweet words to everyone, and acted friendly; meanwhile, he hinted in various ways that his congregation in England was eagerly waiting for him, so he had to hurry, sell off the properties, and return home. He was sad because he had so little time, and the townspeople were very upset too; they were hoping he would stay longer, but they could understand why that wasn't possible. Of course, he and William would take the girls home with them; this made everyone happy because the girls would be taken care of, they would be with their relatives; the girls were also happy about this – they were very delighted because they could start a new chapter in their lives and forget their previous troubles; they told him to sell the properties as quickly as possible, they would be ready. The poor things were so joyful and happy that it broke my heart to see them being deceived and lulled with lies, but I couldn't think of a safe way to intervene and change everything.
es: The king was seeing a lot of people that afternoon, reassuring everyone, very friendly, and he made them understand that in England his parishioners would be worried about him, so he had to hurry and immediately resolve the inheritance issue before leaving. He regretted very much having to rush, and the same was true for the others; they wanted him to stay longer, but they said they understood that it was impossible. And he said that naturally William and he would take the girls home with them, which also pleased everyone a lot, because then the girls would be well protected and among their own relatives, and it also pleased the girls; they liked it so much that they practically forgot they had any problems in the world and told him to sell everything whenever he wanted, that they were ready. The poor girls were so happy and content that it broke my heart to see how they were being deceived and lied to so much, but I couldn't see a safe way to intervene and change the general state of things.

en: Well, blamed if the king didn’t bill the house and the niggers and all the property for auction straight off—sale two days after the funeral; but anybody could buy private beforehand if they wanted to.
vi: After that, the king announced the sale of the house, property, and the black workers who worked there two days after the burial, but before that, anyone who wanted to buy anything separately could do so.
tr: The king immediately opened an auction for the house, the slaves, and all the property – it would be held two days after the funeral, but those interested could come and make offers beforehand.
es: Well, damned if the king didn't immediately put the house and the slaves and all the lands up for auction immediately, two days after the funeral; but anyone who wanted to could buy privately before if they wanted.

en: So the next day after the funeral, along about noon-time, the girls’ joy got the first jolt.
