A couple of nigger traders come along, and the king sold them the niggers reasonable, for three-day drafts as they called it, and away they went, the two sons up the river to Memphis, and their mother down the river to Orleans. I thought them poor girls and them niggers would break their hearts for grief; they cried around each other, and took on so it most made me down sick to see it. The girls said they hadn’t ever dreamed of seeing the family separated or sold away from the town. I can’t ever get it out of my memory, the sight of them poor miserable girls and niggers hanging around each other’s necks and crying; and I reckon I couldn’t a stood it all, but would a had to bust out and tell on our gang if I hadn’t knowed the sale warn’t no account and the niggers would be back home in a week or two.
vi: The next day, after the funeral was over, the girls' joys encountered their first obstacle. A few slave traders came by, and the king sold all the black people working in the house at a reasonable price and took a promissory note. Thus, the black people left one by one. The two sons went up to Memphis, while the mother went down to Orleans. The mistresses and they hugged each other, crying with infinite sorrow. The girls said they never expected to see the family separated and to have to sell them off like this. They hugged each other and cried continuously, making me want to immediately expose the scoundrels so that the black people could stay with their mistresses.
tr: The first blow to the girls' joy came the very next day after the funeral, around noon; a few slave traders arrived, and the king sold the blacks at a reasonable price with a three-day note; two of the boys were sent upriver to Memphis, while their mother was sent downriver to Orleans. I thought the hearts of the poor girls and their blacks would break from grief; they cried and were so distressed while saying goodbye that I couldn't bear to watch anymore. The girls said they never even considered the possibility that the family would be separated or sold out of town. I can't seem to forget that scene, the image of the poor, miserable girls and the blacks hugging each other and crying won't leave my mind; if I didn't know that the sale was unjust and that the blacks would return in a week or two, I probably wouldn't have been able to stand it and would have blown the whistle on our gang.
es: So the day after the funeral, around noon, the girls got their first surprise. A pair of slave traders appeared, and the king sold the black people to them at a reasonable price, with three-day promissory notes, according to what they said, and they took them away: the two sons upriver to Memphis, and their mother downriver to Orleans. I thought those poor girls and the black people were going to have their hearts broken with grief; they cried together and were so sad that it almost made me sick to see it. The girls said they had never dreamed of seeing that family separated or sold far from town. I will never be able to erase from my memory the vision of those poor girls and the black people so sad, hugging and crying; I think I wouldn't have been able to bear it and would have burst and betrayed our gang if I hadn't known that the sale was invalid and that the black people would be back home within a week or two.

en: The thing made a big stir in the town, too, and a good many come out flatfooted and said it was scandalous to separate the mother and the children that way. It injured the frauds some; but the old fool he bulled right along, spite of all the duke could say or do, and I tell you the duke was powerful uneasy.
vi: The sale made everyone in the town resentful, considering it cruel. The honor of the two old swindlers was slightly diminished. But that crazy old man insisted on doing things his way, despite the duke's objections.
tr: This event also caused discomfort in the town, with many people openly stating that separating the mother from her children in such a manner was a complete disgrace. Our swindlers seemed to be in a bit of hot water, but despite everything the duke said or did, the old fool stubbornly stuck to his guns; it was not hard to see that the duke was very disturbed by this situation.
es: That also attracted a lot of attention in the village, and many came running to say that it was a scandal to separate the mother and children like that. The impostors took it badly, but the old man insisted on moving forward, despite what the duke might say or do, and I assure you that the duke felt very uncomfortable.

en: Next day was auction day. About broad day in the morning the king and the duke come up in the garret and woke me up, and I see by their look that there was trouble. The king says:
vi: The next day was the auction day. At dawn, the king and the duke went upstairs to wake me up. Seeing their faces, I immediately guessed that something was up. The king asked:
tr: The auction was to be held the next day. After the sun had risen in the morning, the king and the duke came to the attic and woke me up; judging by the look on their faces, there was a problem. "Did you enter my room the night before last?" asked the king.
es: The next day was the day of the auction. Well into the morning, the king and the duke went up to the attic to wake me up, and from their expressions, I could see there was trouble. The king goes and says:

en: “Was you in my room night before last?”
vi: - The night before, did you come into my room?
tr: "Did you enter my room the night before last?" asked the king.
es: —Were you in my room the night before last?

en: “No, your majesty”—which was the way I always called him when nobody but our gang warn’t around.
vi: - No, Your Majesty, - When it's just us, I usually address him like that.
tr: "No, your majesty," I said – I always addressed him this way when there was no one around except our gang.
es: —No, your majesty —which is how I always addressed him when there were only people from our group present.

en: “Was you in there yisterday er last night?”
vi: - So, did you come in last night?
tr: “So, did you log in last night?”
es: —Were you there yesterday or last night?

en: “No, your majesty.”
vi: - Your Majesty, do you have a letter?
tr: “No; your majesty.” “Do you swear?
es: —No, your majesty.

en: “Honor bright, now—no lies.”
vi: - Swear on your honor, you must not lie.
tr: Don't you dare lie to me.”
es: —Your word of honor; without lying.

en: “Honor bright, your majesty, I’m telling you the truth. I hain’t been a-near your room since Miss Mary Jane took you and the duke and showed it to you.”
vi: - I swear on my honor that I'm telling the truth. Since Miss Mary Jane took the king and the duke upstairs, I haven't gone near there at all.
tr: "I swear, your majesty. I am telling you the truth. Since Miss Mary Jane took you and the duke to show you your room, I have not approached your room in any way."
es: —My word of honor, your majesty. I am telling you the truth. I have not been near your room since Miss Mary Jane took you there with the duke to show it to you.

en: The duke says:
vi: The Duke asked:
tr: “Well, did you see anyone coming in or going out?” asked the duke.
es: The duke goes and says:

en: “Have you seen anybody else go in there?”
vi: - Did you see anyone come there?
tr: “Well, did you see anyone coming in or going out?” asked the duke.
es: —Have you seen anyone else enter it?

en: “No, your grace, not as I remember, I believe.”
vi: - Sir, I don't remember very clearly
tr: “No, Your Excellency, I don't remember seeing anyone.”
es: —No, your grace, not that I remember, I think.

en: “Stop and think.”
vi: - Try to remember.
tr: "Pause and think a little."
es: —Think about it calmly.

en: I studied awhile and see my chance; then I says:
vi: I remained silent to think if there was any way to speak, then replied.
tr: I pretended to think for a while, and during this time, realizing that my luck had changed, I responded:
es: I was thinking about it for a moment and seeing my opportunity, I said:

en: “Well, I see the niggers go in there several times.”
vi: - Yes, I saw some black people go in there.
tr: “I saw black people go in there a few times.”
es: —Well, I've seen the black people go in there several times.

en: Both of them gave a little jump, and looked like they hadn’t ever expected it, and then like they had. Then the duke says:
vi: Both of them were startled, then the duke asked again:
tr: They both jumped into the air with unease without realizing it. Then they adopted an attitude as if they had already been expecting this answer from me. "Did you see me come and go from all of them?" asked the duke.
es: The two of them gave a little jump, as if they had never expected it, and then as if it seemed like they had. Then the duke goes and says:

en: “What, all of them?”
vi: - All of them are black people?
tr: “No…
es: —How, all of them?

en: “No—leastways, not all at once—that is, I don’t think I ever see them all come out at once but just one time.”
vi: - No, not all at once, I only saw it once.
tr: At least I didn't see them all at once. I mean, I don't ever remember them all coming out at the same time, except for one time.”
es: —No, I mean, at least not all at once; I think I never saw them leave together, except for once.

en: “Hello! When was that?”
vi: - When?
tr: “So, when was that?””
es: —Wow! When was that?

en: “It was the day we had the funeral. In the morning. It warn’t early, because I overslept. I was just starting down the ladder, and I see them.”
vi: - On the day of the funeral, but not early in the morning, I also woke up late. As I was stepping down the stairs, I saw them.
tr: “The day of the funeral. In the morning. It wasn't very early, because I had overslept. Just as I was going down the stairs, I saw them.”
es: The day of the funeral, in the morning. It wasn't early because I slept in late. I was starting to go down the stairs when I saw them.

en: “Well, go on, go on! What did they do? How’d they act?”
vi: - Go ahead! What else did they do? How did they do it?
tr: "Keep telling, go on... What did they do?"
es: —Well, go on, go on! What did they do? What happened next?

en: “They didn’t do nothing. And they didn’t act anyway much, as fur as I see. They tiptoed away; so I seen, easy enough, that they’d shoved in there to do up your majesty’s room, or something, s’posing you was up; and found you warn’t up, and so they was hoping to slide out of the way of trouble without waking you up, if they hadn’t already waked you up.”
vi: - They were just gentle. I think they went in there to clean the king's room. Perhaps the king had already woken up, but they saw him still lying down, so they quietly left to avoid disturbing him.
tr: “They didn't do anything. As far as I could see, they didn't act strangely either. They tiptoed away; I thought they went inside to tidy up the room, thinking that your majesty had already gotten up, but when they saw that you hadn't, they tried to leave quietly so as not to wake you and get into trouble, of course, if they hadn't already woken you.”
es: —They did nothing. And nothing special happened either, that I could see. They tiptoed away; so I saw very well that they had gone to prepare your majesty's room, or something like that, if you had already gotten up, and upon seeing that you hadn't gotten up, they hoped to disappear and avoid getting into trouble instead of waking you up, if they hadn't already woken you up.

en: “Great guns, this is a go!” says the king; and both of them looked pretty sick and tolerable silly. They stood there a-thinking and scratching their heads a minute, and the duke he bust into a kind of a little raspy chuckle, and says:
vi: Both looked at each other sadly, dejectedly. The king said: - This way, everything is ruined. The Duke pondered for a moment, then let out a sneer and said:
tr: “My God, we are doomed!” said the king; both of them looked as if they had been struck by a jinn. They stood there scratching their heads for about a minute, then the duke let out a nervous laugh.
es: —Devil, this one is really good! —says the king, and the two of them were left with a desperate and rather silly expression. They stayed there thinking and scratching their heads, and the duke let out a sort of rasping chuckle and said:

en: “It does beat all how neat the niggers played their hand. They let on to be sorry they was going out of this region! And I believed they was sorry, and so did you, and so did everybody. Don’t ever tell me any more that a nigger ain’t got any histrionic talent. Why, the way they played that thing it would fool anybody. In my opinion, there’s a fortune in ’em. If I had capital and a theater, I wouldn’t want a better lay-out than that—and here we’ve gone and sold ’em for a song. Yes, and ain’t privileged to sing the song yet. Say, where is that song—that draft?”
vi: - The black folks played a high-level trick. They pretended to be very miserable before they left this place. I, you, and everyone else thought so. Don't think that the black folks don't have any talent. If I had the capital and a theater, I would immediately hire them as actors. So now we have sold them in exchange for a song. And yet we haven't even sung that song. By the way, where is that song, that contract? Where?
tr: “They say 'a hand is superior to another,' and the blacks did what they had to do. They looked so sad because they were going to leave these places! I truly believed that they were sad. You believed it too, everyone did. No one should tell me anymore that blacks don't have acting talent. They acted so well that they could have fooled everyone. In my opinion, those blacks are worth a treasure. If I had some capital and a theater, they alone would be enough as actors… And we went and sold them for a pittance. Yes, and on top of that, we don't even have cash, just a promissory note. What did you do with the note?”
es: —It's fabulous how those blacks have played their hand. They acted as if they were so sad to leave this region! And I believed they really were, just like you and everyone else. Don't ever tell me again that blacks don't have acting talent. They gave a performance that would fool anyone. To me, they are worth a fortune. If I had capital and a theater, I wouldn't want better actors... And we sold them for a bargain. Yes, and we can't even touch that bargain yet. Hey, where is that bargain... that note?

en: “In the bank for to be collected. Where would it be?”
vi: - You have to go to the bank to get it!
tr: “I gave it to the bank, of course, we'll get it when the return comes. Where else would it be?”
es: —At the bank waiting to get paid. Where else would I be?

en: “Well, that’s all right then, thank goodness.”
vi: - Well, that's still quite fortunate.
tr: “Alright, good then, thank God.”
es: —Well, then it doesn't matter, thank God.

en: Says I, kind of timid-like:
vi: I timidly asked:
tr: I interjected a bit timidly:
es: I asked, somewhat shyly:

en: “Is something gone wrong?”
vi: - What's going on?
tr: "Is there a problem?""
es: —Has something happened?

en: The king whirls on me and rips out:
vi: The king looked at me annoyed and said:
tr: The king turned to me angrily and shouted:
es: The king turned to me and exclaimed:

en: “None o’ your business! You keep your head shet, and mind y’r own affairs—if you got any. Long as you’re in this town don’t you forgit that—you hear?” Then he says to the duke, “We got to jest swaller it and say noth’n’: mum’s the word for us.”
vi: - None of your business! Don't stick your nose into other people's affairs. As long as you're in this town, you better keep your mouth shut, got it? Then the old man turned around and said to the duke: - Let's not have anything, just stay silent.
tr: “This is none of your business! Keep your mouth shut and mind your own business… If you have any, that is. Never forget this as long as you are in this town, do you hear me?” Then he turned to the duke again: “There is no other way but to drink a glass of cold water and keep quiet.”
es: —It's none of your business! You shut your mouth and mind your own business... If you have any. And while you're in this town, don't forget it, understand? —and then he says to the duke—: we have to endure and say nothing; we have to keep quiet.

en: As they was starting down the ladder the duke he chuckles again, and says:
vi: They walked down the stairs, the duke still whispering:
tr: As they were descending the stairs, the duke let out another laugh:
es: When they started to go down the stairs, the duke laughed again and said:

en: “Quick sales and small profits! It’s a good business—yes.”
vi: - Sell quickly, even if the profit is small.
tr: “Quick sales; small profits! What a trade...”
es: —Quick sales and small profits! It's a good business.

en: v
vi: Quickly have the money in hand.
tr: What a trade...”
es: Yes.

en: The king snarls around on him and says:
vi: The king grinned, looking at the duke and said:
tr: The king replied angrily:
es: The king let out a snort and said to him:

en: “I was trying to do for the best in sellin’ ’em out so quick. If the profits has turned out to be none, lackin’ considable, and none to carry, is it my fault any more’n it’s yourn?”
vi: - I'm planning to try to sell everything quickly for the maximum profit. If it doesn't make much, or doesn't make anything at all, then is that my fault or yours?
tr: “I was doing my best to get rid of them quickly. If we never made a profit, if we have nothing left, isn't it as much your fault as it is mine?”
es: —When I sold them so quickly, I was trying to do what was best for us. If it turns out there are no profits, that we gain nothing and get nothing, am I more to blame than you?

en: “Well, they’d be in this house yet and we wouldn’t if I could a got my advice listened to.”
vi: - If you had listened to me, the blacks would still be in the house and we would have already escaped with the big bag of money.
tr: “If you had listened to my advice, they would still be in this house, but we would not be.””
es: —Well, if they had listened to me, they would still be in this house and we wouldn't.

en: The king sassed back as much as was safe for him, and then swapped around and lit into me again. He give me down the banks for not coming and telling him I see the niggers come out of his room acting that way—said any fool would a knowed something was up. And then waltzed in and cussed himself awhile, and said it all come of him not laying late and taking his natural rest that morning, and he’d be blamed if he’d ever do it again. So they went off a-jawing; and I felt dreadful glad I’d worked it all off on to the niggers, and yet hadn’t done the niggers no harm by it.
vi: The king, afraid of the secret getting out, ran over to me to threaten me not to tell anyone about seeing the black man coming out of the old man's room, because if I did, everyone would immediately know something was up. Then the old man staggered back to his room, cursing himself for a while and saying that it was all his fault for not staying in his room longer like every morning, and swore that from then on he wouldn't be so foolish. Then they went on to discuss something else with each other. As for me, I was secretly glad that I had exonerated the black men without causing them any harm.
tr: The king replied to him, trying not to let anyone else hear, and then brought the conversation back to me. Even though I saw the blacks quietly leaving the room, he cursed and swore at me for not telling him – he said even the most brainless person could understand that something was going on. Then he turned back and cursed himself a bit; he said all this happened because he stayed up late and didn't get enough rest that morning, and he swore he would never do such a thing again. They walked away chatting like that, and I was extremely happy because I blamed the blacks, but they wouldn't suffer any harm from it.
es: The king responded to him as best he could and then turned around and went back to dealing with me. He gave me a scolding for not telling him that I had seen the blacks leaving his room in that manner, which even an idiot would have understood meant something was up. And then he changed again and cursed himself above all for a while, saying that everything had happened because he hadn't stayed in bed until late and rested as much as he needed that morning, and that damned if he would ever do it again in his life. So they went off chatting and I felt very happy to have put all the blame on the blacks without having done them any harm.

en: CHAPTER XXVIII.
vi: Chapter XXXVIII
tr: Twenty-Eighth Chapter
es: Chapter 28

en: By-and-by it was getting-up time. So I come down the ladder and started for down-stairs; but as I come to the girls’ room the door was open, and I see Mary Jane setting by her old hair trunk, which was open and she’d been packing things in it—getting ready to go to England. But she had stopped now with a folded gown in her lap, and had her face in her hands, crying. I felt awful bad to see it; of course anybody would. I went in there and says:
vi: Jim said that engraving letters was the hardest of all. But Tom insisted that Jim must write. The prisoner had to leave his handwriting on the wall for posterity, along with his emblem. Jim said:
tr: It was almost time to get up. I came down from the attic stairs and headed towards the stairs to the lower floor, but as I passed by the girls' room, I noticed that the door was open. Mary Jane was sitting inside next to an old trunk, the trunk was open and partially filled – she was preparing to go to England. But now she was sitting with a folded nightgown in her lap, crying with her face in her hands. Seeing her like that made me feel terrible, anyone's heart would break. I went inside and said to her:
es: Little by little, the time for everyone to get up was approaching. So I descended the stairs to the lower floor, but upon reaching the girls' room, the door was open and I saw Mary Jane sitting next to her old horsehair trunk, which was open and into which she had been putting things, preparing to go to England. But now she had stopped with a folded dress in her lap and had her face in her hands while she cried. I felt very bad seeing that; naturally, just as anyone would have felt. I went in and said:

en: “Miss Mary Jane, you can’t a-bear to see people in trouble, and I can’t—most always. Tell me about it.”
vi: Jim said:
tr: "Ms. Mary Jane, you can't stand seeing people suffer, I can't stand it either... Not at all. Tell me about it."
es: —Miss Mary Jane, you can't stand to see people suffer, and neither can I: almost never. Tell me everything.

en: So she done it. And it was the niggers—I just expected it. She said the beautiful trip to England was most about spoiled for her; she didn’t know how she was ever going to be happy there, knowing the mother and the children warn’t ever going to see each other no more—and then busted out bitterer than ever, and flung up her hands, and says:
vi: Jim said:
tr: He narrated. He was thinking about the black people – exactly what I had guessed. The trip he was going to make to England had almost turned into a nightmare for him; knowing that the mother and her children might never see each other again, could he be happy there even for a single day? Then, with an even more sorrowful gesture, he raised his hands upwards:
es: So she told me, and it was about the slaves, just as I expected. She said that wonderful trip to England no longer excited her; she didn't know how she could be happy there, knowing that the mother and children would never see each other again, and then she started crying harder than ever, opened her hands, and said:

en: “Oh, dear, dear, to think they ain’t ever going to see each other any more!”
vi: Jim said:
tr: "My God, my God, even thinking that they will never see each other again!.." “But they will see…
es: —Oh, my God, my God, to think that they will never see each other again!

en: “But they will—and inside of two weeks—and I know it!” says I.
vi: Jim said:
tr: Within two weeks… I am sure of it!”
es: —But they will see each other, and within two weeks, and I know it! —I replied.

en: Laws, it was out before I could think! And before I could budge she throws her arms around my neck and told me to say it again, say it again, say it again!
vi: Jim said:
tr: Without even realizing it, the words slipped out of my mouth!.. Before I could say anything, she hugged my neck and started saying, say it again, say it again, say it again!
es: My God, it had slipped out without thinking! And before I could even move, she had thrown her arms around my neck, asking me to repeat it, again, to repeat it again, to repeat it again!

en: I see I had spoke too sudden and said too much, and was in a close place. I asked her to let me think a minute; and she set there, very impatient and excited and handsome, but looking kind of happy and eased-up, like a person that’s had a tooth pulled out. So I went to studying it out. I says to myself, I reckon a body that ups and tells the truth when he is in a tight place is taking considerable many resks, though I ain’t had no experience, and can’t say for certain; but it looks so to me, anyway; and yet here’s a case where I’m blest if it don’t look to me like the truth is better and actuly safer than a lie. I must lay it by in my mind, and think it over some time or other, it’s so kind of strange and unregular. I never see nothing like it. Well, I says to myself at last, I’m a-going to chance it; I’ll up and tell the truth this time, though it does seem most like setting down on a kag of powder and touching it off just to see where you’ll go to. Then I says:
vi: Jim said: - Uncle Tom, I don't have any personal badge at all, I only have this shirt you gave me and I have to write my diary on it. - You don't understand anything, Jim, the badge is different, it's not like that. I said:
tr: At a moment when I least expected it, he spoke, said too many things, and I was cornered. I asked for a minute to think; there, with impatience and excitement, in all her beauty, but in a happy and relieved state, she sat like someone whose aching tooth had been pulled. I also started to ponder in my own way. In a moment when he was cornered, a person who stood up and told the truth would probably have taken great risks; though I had no experience in this matter, so I wasn't absolutely sure, but that's what I thought. Still, it was clear that I was in a situation where telling the truth was better, even safer, than lying. I should write this down in a corner of my mind and think it over thoroughly at a convenient time, it seemed very strange and against the rules. Such a thing had never happened to me before. In the end, well, I said to myself, I will face everything, it will be like sitting on a powder keg and striking a match to see where I will fly, but this time I will take the risk and tell the truth.
es: I realized that I had spoken too much and too soon and that I had gotten myself into a trap. I asked her to let me think about it for a minute; she remained seated, very impatient and nervous, so beautiful, but with a happy and calm air, like a person who has just had a tooth pulled. Then I began to study it. I said to myself: "I figure that someone who goes and tells the truth when they are in a trap is taking a considerable risk, although I have no experience and cannot say for sure, but in any case, it seems to me that this is one of those occasions where the truth appears to be better and indeed safer than the lie. I have to remember this and think it over again when I have time, because it is most strange and irregular. In my life, I have never seen anything like it. Well," I finally said to myself, "I'm going to take the risk; this time I'm going to tell the truth even though it's like sitting on a barrel of gunpowder and lighting it to see what happens next." Then I went and said:

en: “Miss Mary Jane, is there any place out of town a little ways where you could go and stay three or four days?”
vi: - Jim is right.
tr: “Miss Mary Jane,” I said, “is there a place not too far outside of town where you could stay for two or three days?”
es: —Miss Mary Jane. Is there any place out of town, not too far, where you could spend three or four days?

en: “Yes; Mr. Lothrop’s. Why?”
vi: - Jim is right. He doesn't have any badges.
tr: "Yes... Mr. Lothrop's house. Why?"
es: —Yes; at Mr. Lothrop's house. Why?

en: “Never mind why yet. If I’ll tell you how I know the niggers will see each other again inside of two weeks—here in this house—and prove how I know it—will you go to Mr. Lothrop’s and stay four days?”
vi: Tom replied: - I know, but Jim needs to have a badge before leaving this place.
tr: "Never mind the reason for now. If I tell you that the Negroes will see each other again, and within two weeks in this very house, and if I prove how I know it... can you go and stay at the Lothrops' for about four days?"
es: —The reason still doesn't matter. If I tell you how I know that the black people will meet again, here in this house, in two weeks, and I prove how I know it, will you go to Mr. Lothrop's house to stay for four days?

en: “Four days!” she says; “I’ll stay a year!”
vi: So Tom sat down, racking his brain to come up with a badge for Jim.
tr: “Four days!” he said. “I would stay even for a year!”
es: —Four days! —he replied—. I would stay for a year!

en: “All right,” I says, “I don’t want nothing more out of you than just your word—I druther have it than another man’s kiss-the-Bible.” She smiled and reddened up very sweet, and I says, “If you don’t mind it, I’ll shut the door—and bolt it.”
vi: After a while, he said he had thought of many but didn't know which one to choose. Finally, he picked a design and said:
tr: “Alright then,” I said, “I just want you to promise me one thing…” “If it were someone else, I would ask them to kiss the Holy Book.” She smiled, and a very pleasant blush appeared on her cheeks. “If you don't mind, I won't even close the door… in fact, I need to bolt it,” I said.
es: —Very well —I added—, the only thing I ask for is your word: it means more to me than someone else's oath on the Bible. —She smiled and blushed a little, very lovely, and I continued—: If you don't mind, I'm going to close the door, and with the lock.

en: Then I come back and set down again, and says:
vi: Finally, he picked a design and said:
tr: After locking the door, I came back, sat down again, and started to tell:
es: Then I sat down again and said:

en: “Don’t you holler. Just set still and take it like a man. I got to tell the truth, and you want to brace up, Miss Mary, because it’s a bad kind, and going to be hard to take, but there ain’t no help for it. These uncles of yourn ain’t no uncles at all; they’re a couple of frauds—regular dead-beats. There, now we’re over the worst of it, you can stand the rest middling easy.”
vi: Finally, he picked a design and said: - On that coat of arms, a circle is drawn around it, in front is a yellow cross, with a dog lying down, showing subservience, under the dog's feet is a chain, then there is a place to record achievements in green, with serrated edges, a green letter V at the top of the coat of arms, three slanted lines on a blue background with many dots.
tr: “Do not scream. Sit quietly in your place and try to react like a man. I will tell you the truth and you will brace yourself, Miss Mary, because I am going to tell you something bad, something hard to bear, but I have no other choice. These uncles of yours are definitely not your real uncles… just a pair of impostors… common thieves that you know. Yes, we have passed the hardest part… you can endure the rest more easily.”
es: —Don't shout. Stay seated there and take it like a man. I have to tell the truth and you have to prepare yourself well, Miss Mary, because it's a bad thing and it's going to be difficult for you, but there's no way to avoid it. Those uncles of yours are not uncles at all; they are a pair of frauds, lifelong impostors. Well, we've gotten through the worst, and you will be able to handle the rest more easily.

en: It jolted her up like everything, of course; but I was over the shoal water now, so I went right along, her eyes a-blazing higher and higher all the time, and told her every blame thing, from where we first struck that young fool going up to the steamboat, clear through to where she flung herself on to the king’s breast at the front door and he kissed her sixteen or seventeen times—and then up she jumps, with her face afire like sunset, and says:
vi: - On that coat of arms, a circle is drawn around it, in front is a yellow cross, with a dog lying down, showing subservience, under the dog's feet is a chain, then there is a place to record achievements in green, with serrated edges, a green letter V at the top of the coat of arms, three slanted lines on a blue background with many dots.
tr: Of course, he was shaken when he heard this; but I had already moved to shallow waters, so I told everything without a pause, as sparks increasingly flashed in his eyes; I started from where we first encountered the young fool going up the river to board the steamboat, and as I was recounting how she threw herself into the king's arms in front of the house and kissed him sixteen or seventeen times, the girl suddenly jumped up, she was bright red.
es: Naturally, that left her absolutely stunned, but now I had already said the hardest part, so I continued while her eyes lit up more and more and I told her absolutely everything, from the first time we met the foolish boy who was going to the steamboat to when she had thrown herself into the king's arms at the main gate and he had kissed her sixteen or seventeen times, and then she jumped, her face blazing like a sunset, and said:

en: “The brute! Come, don’t waste a minute—not a second—we’ll have them tarred and feathered, and flung in the river!”
vi: A symbol of a black man running away carrying a bundle of luggage, and another symbol of two guys following to help, that is, you and me. So it resolved the matter of the badge, now it just had to finish the remaining part, which was to draft a farewell letter, saying that Jim must have such a letter, as it was mentioned in the book.
tr: "Monster! Come, we can't lose even a minute, not even a second..." "Let them cover them in tar and feathers, then throw them into the river!""
es: —Wicked! Come on, don't waste a minute, not even a second, let's have them tarred, feathered, and thrown into the river!

en: Says I:
vi: It wrote it down on a piece of paper, then read it aloud:
tr: “Absolutely true,” I said.
es: I answered:

en: “Cert’nly. But do you mean before you go to Mr. Lothrop’s, or—”
vi: 1) Here, a captive heart is breaking. 2) Here, a pitiable prisoner, abandoned by life and friends, must live withering and decaying.
tr: “Absolutely true,” I said. “But before you go to the Lothrops, or...”
es: —Of course. But do you mean before going to Mr. Lothrop's house or...?

en: “Oh,” she says, “what am I thinking about!” she says, and set right down again. “Don’t mind what I said—please don’t—you won’t, now, will you?” Laying her silky hand on mine in that kind of a way that I said I would die first. “I never thought, I was so stirred up,” she says; “now go on, and I won’t do so any more. You tell me what to do, and whatever you say I’ll do it.”
vi: 2) Here, a pitiable prisoner, abandoned by life and friends, must live withering and decaying. 3) Here, a lonely heart is broken, a spirit has grown weary after thirty-seven years of solitary confinement. 4) Here, the child of Louis the Fourteenth died homeless, without close friends, after thirty-seven years of imprisonment. When reading those sentences, Tom's voice trembled with emotion. After finishing reading, he didn't know which sentence to choose for Jim to write on the wall because they all seemed good; in the end, he decided to let Jim write all of them.
tr: “Ah, what nonsense am I talking!” she said and sat down again. “Please pretend you didn't hear anything I said, I didn't say anything, okay?” She placed her hand, as soft as silk, on mine in such a way that I could have given my life rather than resist her. “I completely lost my mind, I got very angry,” she said; “now continue, I won't do it again. Tell me what we should do, I will do whatever you say.”
es: —Ah —she replied—, what am I thinking! —and she sat down again—. Don't pay attention to what I said, I beg you. You won't, will you? She gently placed her little hand in mine in such a way that I responded that I would rather die first. —I haven't stopped to think about it because I was so angry —she added—; now go on and I promise I won't act like that again. Tell me what I have to do and I will do everything you say.

en: “Well,” I says, “it’s a rough gang, them two frauds, and I’m fixed so I got to travel with them a while longer, whether I want to or not—I druther not tell you why; and if you was to blow on them this town would get me out of their claws, and I’d be all right; but there’d be another person that you don’t know about who’d be in big trouble. Well, we got to save him, hain’t we? Of course. Well, then, we won’t blow on them.”
vi: After finishing reading, he didn't know which sentence to choose for Jim to write on the wall because they all seemed good; in the end, he decided to let Jim write all of them.
tr: “I can outsmart these two swindlers, and I've been forced to travel with them for a while now... It's better if I don't tell you the reason... If you report them immediately, the townspeople will rescue me from their clutches, and I will be safe, but there's someone else you don't know about, and they will get into big trouble. We need to protect them, don't we? Of course, I'm right. Anyway, let's not report them right away.”
es: —Well —I said—, these two swindlers are tough guys and I have no choice but to keep traveling with them a bit longer, whether I like it or not; I prefer not to tell you why; and if you reported them, this town would free me from their clutches and I would be perfectly fine; but there would be another person you don't know about who would have terrible problems. Well, we have to save that person, right? Of course. Well, then we can't report them.

en: Saying them words put a good idea in my head. I see how maybe I could get me and Jim rid of the frauds; get them jailed here, and then leave. But I didn’t want to run the raft in the daytime without anybody aboard to answer questions but me; so I didn’t want the plan to begin working till pretty late to-night. I says:
vi: Jim said it would take him a year to finish writing all those words, so Tom would write them outside, and Jim would just trace them on the wall. Then he said:
tr: While saying these words, a good idea came to my mind. Maybe Jim and I could get rid of these frauds; they would end up in jail here, and we would just leave. But I didn't want to travel on the raft during the day without anyone else to answer questions; so I had to adjust my plan for quite late hours. "Ms. Mary Jane, now let me tell you what we are going to do," I said.
es: When I said that, a good idea occurred to me. I saw how I could get Jim and myself free from the frauds; make them stay in the local jail and then leave. But I didn't want to navigate the raft during the day with no one but me on board to answer questions, so I didn't want the plan to start working until well into the night. I continued saying:

en: “Miss Mary Jane, I’ll tell you what we’ll do, and you won’t have to stay at Mr. Lothrop’s so long, nuther. How fur is it?”
vi: - Writing on wood won't work, because there are no wooden walls in the tower prison. We have to carve the letters into the stone instead.
tr: "You won't need to stay at Mr. Lothrop's house for too long. How far is it?"
es: —Miss Mary Jane, I'm going to tell you what we're going to do and you won't have to stay so long at Mr. Lothrop's house either. How far is it?

en: “A little short of four miles—right out in the country, back here.”
vi: Jim said that carving on stone is even harder than on wood, so it would take him a long time to finish and escape.
tr: “A little closer than four miles... Just outside the town.”
es: —A little less than four miles, right there in the field.

en: “Well, that’ll answer. Now you go along out there, and lay low till nine or half-past to-night, and then get them to fetch you home again—tell them you’ve thought of something. If you get here before eleven put a candle in this window, and if I don’t turn up wait till eleven, and then if I don’t turn up it means I’m gone, and out of the way, and safe. Then you come out and spread the news around, and get these beats jailed.”
vi: Jim said that carving on stone is even harder than on wood, so it would take him a long time to finish and escape.
tr: “Well, this will do the job. Now you will go there and stay out of sight until nine or nine-thirty this evening, then tell them to take you home because you forgot something. If you come back before eleven in the evening, light a candle in front of this window; if I am not around, wait until eleven, and if I still do not appear, it means I have left and am safe. Then you can come out and spread the news to everyone, and those scoundrels can be put in jail.”
es: —Well, all right. Now go over there and stay without saying anything until nine or nine-thirty at night and then have them bring you back home: tell them you forgot something. If you arrive before eleven, put a candle in this window and wait until eleven; if I don't show up after that, it means I've left and you're safe. Then go out, spread the news, and have those wretches thrown in jail.

en: “Good,” she says, “I’ll do it.”
vi: Jim said that carving on stone is even harder than on wood, so it would take him a long time to finish and escape.
tr: “Okay,” he said, “I will do exactly that.”
es: —Very well —he responded—, I will do that.

en: “And if it just happens so that I don’t get away, but get took up along with them, you must up and say I told you the whole thing beforehand, and you must stand by me all you can.”
vi: Jim said that carving on stone is even harder than on wood, so it would take him a long time to finish and escape.
tr: "But if I cannot escape and get caught with them, you must say that I told you everything in advance and defend me with all your strength.""
es: —And if by any chance I don't manage to escape, but they catch me with them, you have to say that I had told you everything beforehand and defend me as much as you can.

en: “Stand by you! indeed I will. They sha’n’t touch a hair of your head!” she says, and I see her nostrils spread and her eyes snap when she said it, too.
vi: Jim said that carving on stone is even harder than on wood, so it would take him a long time to finish and escape. But Tom said he would let me help. Then he looked to see how far Jim and I had written.
tr: “Of course, I will defend you. They can't even touch a single strand of your hair!” he said. As he said these things, I saw his nostrils flare and his eyes shine.
es: —Defend you! Of course. They won't lay a finger on you! —he said, and I saw his nostrils flare and his eyes gleam as he said it.

en: “If I get away I sha’n’t be here,” I says, “to prove these rapscallions ain’t your uncles, and I couldn’t do it if I was here. I could swear they was beats and bummers, that’s all, though that’s worth something. Well, there’s others can do that better than what I can, and they’re people that ain’t going to be doubted as quick as I’d be. I’ll tell you how to find them. Gimme a pencil and a piece of paper. There—‘Royal Nonesuch, Bricksville.’ Put it away, and don’t lose it. When the court wants to find out something about these two, let them send up to Bricksville and say they’ve got the men that played the Royal Nonesuch, and ask for some witnesses—why, you’ll have that entire town down here before you can hardly wink, Miss Mary. And they’ll come a-biling, too.”
vi: Then he looked to see how far Jim and I had written. Doing this was really a very difficult and slow task; my hands, already sore, hurt even more, and the work seemed to make no progress at all. Tom said: - I have an idea. We need to find a stone to make a badge and write on it. There is a very large grinding stone in the workshop, we will bring it up here and write things on it, and we can also use it to sharpen pens and saws.
tr: "If I leave, I won't be here to prove that those swindlers are not your uncles, and even if I were here, I couldn't prove it. All I could do is swear that they are swindlers and frauds; though that is something. Anyway, there are those who can prove it better than I can, and no one will doubt them. Let me tell you how to find them. Give me a pen and paper. Here... 'Royal Nonesuch, Bricksville.' Put this paper somewhere safe, don't lose it. If the court wants evidence about these two, let them send someone to Bricksville and tell them to catch the men staging the Royal Nonesuch and ask for witnesses... The whole town will come to testify in the blink of an eye, Miss Mary. And they will be quite angry too."
es: —If I escape, I won't be here —I pointed out— to prove that those scoundrels are not your uncles, and if I were here, I couldn't prove it. I could swear they were cheats and vagabonds, and nothing more, although that is something. Well, there are others who can do it better than I, and they are people who won't be doubted as easily as me. I'm going to tell you how to find them. Give me a pencil and a piece of paper. That's it: "The Royal Nonesuch, Bricksville." Keep it and don't lose it. When the judge wants to know something about those two, have someone go to Bricksville and say they have the men who performed in "The Royal Nonesuch," and as for witnesses, you'll get the whole town to come in the blink of an eye, Miss Mary. And ready for anything, too.

en: I judged we had got everything fixed about right now. So I says:
vi: It was a bizarre idea, but we thought we could do it.
tr: I have decided that we have now settled everything. So I continued:
es: I figured that we already had everything on track and said:

en: “Just let the auction go right along, and don’t worry. Nobody don’t have to pay for the things they buy till a whole day after the auction on accounts of the short notice, and they ain’t going out of this till they get that money; and the way we’ve fixed it the sale ain’t going to count, and they ain’t going to get no money. It’s just like the way it was with the niggers—it warn’t no sale, and the niggers will be back before long. Why, they can’t collect the money for the niggers yet—they’re in the worst kind of a fix, Miss Mary.”
vi: It was not yet midnight, we went outside and headed down to the workshop, leaving only Jim to do his work.
tr: “Let the auction proceed, there's nothing to worry about. On the day of the auction, no one has to pay for what they have bought until the end of the day, they just give a promissory note and our swindlers can't go anywhere until they get the money… When we expose their fraud, the promissory notes will become useless and they won't get a single penny. It will be just like with the negroes… Since the sale is not valid, the negroes will return soon. They won't be able to get the negroes' money either… Honestly, I don't think they can get away with this, Mrs. Mary.”
es: —Leave them with their auction and don't worry. Nobody will have to pay for what they buy until a day after the auction, since it was announced so hastily, and they won't leave until they get that money; the way we've arranged it, the sale won't count and they won't get any money. It's just like what happened with the black people: the sale isn't valid and the black people will come back very soon. Notice that they still can't collect the money from the black people... They're in a very bad situation, Miss Mary.

en: “Well,” she says, “I’ll run down to breakfast now, and then I’ll start straight for Mr. Lothrop’s.”
vi: It was not yet midnight, we went outside and headed down to the workshop, leaving only Jim to do his work.
tr: “Alright then,” she said, “I’ll go down and prepare breakfast now, then I’ll head straight to Mr. Lothrop’s.”
es: —Well —she replied—, I'm going to go down for breakfast and then I'll go straight to Mr. Lothrop's house.

en: “’Deed, that ain’t the ticket, Miss Mary Jane,” I says, “by no manner of means; go before breakfast.”
vi: It was not yet midnight, we went outside and headed down to the workshop, leaving only Jim to do his work.
tr: “This is absolutely not possible, Miss Mary Jane,” I said, “you will ruin the whole thing; go before breakfast.”
es: —That can't be, Miss Mary Jane —I indicated—, not at all; go before breakfast.

en: “Why?”
vi: It was not yet midnight, we went outside and headed down to the workshop, leaving only Jim to do his work.
tr: “Why?”
es: —Why?

en: “What did you reckon I wanted you to go at all for, Miss Mary?”
vi: It was not yet midnight, we went outside and headed down to the workshop, leaving only Jim to do his work.
tr: “Why do you think I wanted you to leave from the very beginning, Miss Mary?”
es: —Why do you think I wanted you to do all this, Miss Mary Jane?

en: “Well, I never thought—and come to think, I don’t know. What was it?”
vi: It was not yet midnight, we went outside and headed down to the workshop, leaving only Jim to do his work. We carried the stone outside and rolled it home, but it was so heavy that several times it almost crushed our feet.
tr: "Actually, I had never thought about it... That's right, I don't know. Why do you want me to leave?"
es: —Well, it hadn't occurred to me... And now that I think about it, I don't know. Why?

en: “Why, it’s because you ain’t one of these leather-face people. I don’t want no better book than what your face is. A body can set down and read it off like coarse print. Do you reckon you can go and face your uncles when they come to kiss you good-morning, and never—”
vi: Tom said that someone would definitely get their foot crushed by the stone before we could carry it all the way back.
tr: “Because you are not a brazen type like others. One can read your face like a book. I'm very serious, even deciphering letters and reading a book is harder. Can you go downstairs and face your uncles, when they kiss you and say good morning...”
es: —Well, because you are not a shameless person. I like your face just the way it is. One can sit down to read it as if it were written in capital letters. Do you think you can go see your uncles when they come to say good morning with a kiss and not... ?

en: “There, there, don’t! Yes, I’ll go before breakfast—I’ll be glad to. And leave my sisters with them?”
vi: Halfway there, we were exhausted, staggering, and drenched in sweat. We had to call Jim, Jim got up and unhooked the chain from the bedpost, crawled out through the hole to where the stone was, and Jim and I lifted the stone, walking as if it was nothing, while Tom commanded.
tr: “Oh no, oh no, I can't do it! Right, I should go before breakfast... I'll gladly go right away. But am I going to leave my sisters with them?”
es: —Let's go, let's go, don't continue! Yes, I will leave before breakfast and very happy. And do I leave my sisters with them?

en: “Yes; never mind about them. They’ve got to stand it yet a while. They might suspicion something if all of you was to go. I don’t want you to see them, nor your sisters, nor nobody in this town; if a neighbor was to ask how is your uncles this morning your face would tell something. No, you go right along, Miss Mary Jane, and I’ll fix it with all of them. I’ll tell Miss Susan to give your love to your uncles and say you’ve went away for a few hours for to get a little rest and change, or to see a friend, and you’ll be back to-night or early in the morning.”
vi: He could command any other child. He could do all sorts of things. The hole we dug was quite large, but the rock still couldn't fit through, so Jim took the pickaxe and dug it wider. Tom took a nail and marked the rock, telling Jim to chisel along the marks. He told Jim to keep working until the candle went out, then hide the rock under the bed and sleep on top of it.
tr: “Yes, don't worry about them. They can manage for a short while longer. If all of you go at once, the men might get suspicious. You must not see them, nor your sisters or anyone else in town; if one of your neighbors asks you how your uncles are this morning, I'm afraid the answer will be written on your face. No; go straight without stopping anywhere, Miss Mary Jane, I'll handle the rest. I'll tell Miss Susan that you sent your love to your uncles and that you went out for a few hours to rest, for a change of scenery, or to see a friend, and that you'll be back this evening or early tomorrow morning.”
es: —Yes, don't worry about them. They have to keep enduring for a while. They might suspect something if all of you disappeared. I don't want you to see them, nor your sisters nor anyone from the town; if a neighbor asks you how your uncles are this morning, you might reveal something with a gesture. No, leave immediately, Miss Mary Jane, and I'll handle everything with them. I'll tell Miss Susan to greet your uncles warmly and to say that you have gone away for a few hours to rest a bit and change, or to visit a friend, and that you will be back tonight or early in the morning.

en: “Gone to see a friend is all right, but I won’t have my love given to them.”
vi: He told Jim to keep working until the candle went out, then hide the rock under the bed and sleep on top of it.
tr: “There's no problem in saying that I went to see a friend, but I'm not going to send them my regards or anything.”
es: —It's fine that I went to see some friends, but I don't want you to greet them on my behalf.

en: “Well, then, it sha’n’t be.” It was well enough to tell her so—no harm in it. It was only a little thing to do, and no trouble; and it’s the little things that smooths people’s roads the most, down here below; it would make Mary Jane comfortable, and it wouldn’t cost nothing. Then I says: “There’s one more thing—that bag of money.”
vi: He told Jim to keep working until the candle went out, then hide the rock under the bed and sleep on top of it. We helped Jim reattach the chain to the bed leg, then we also got ready to sleep. But suddenly, Tom said:
tr: “Alright, since you don't want it.” Answering her this way was the best – what harm was there. It was a small thing and it didn't harm anyone; it's such small things that allow people to proceed safely on their paths; Miss Jane would be comfortable and there would be no cost. “There's just one more thing,” I said, “that money bag.”
es: —Well, then don't tell them anything. He could tell her that, because it didn't hurt anyone, it was something unimportant and caused no problems, and it's the unimportant things that make life easier for people down here; Mary Jane would be at ease, and it cost nothing. Then I added: —There's one more thing: the bag with the money.

en: “Well, they’ve got that; and it makes me feel pretty silly to think how they got it.”
vi: - Is there any spider in here, Jim?
tr: "Yes, they took that too; when I think about how they took it, I feel like a fool."
es: —Well, they already have that, and I feel very foolish thinking about how they got it.

en: “No, you’re out, there. They hain’t got it.”
vi: - No, there isn't, my friend. - Okay, let me go get some for you.
tr: “Don't feel that way at all. The bag is not with them.”
es: —No, you are mistaken there. They don't have it.

en: “Why, who’s got it?”
vi: - Oh, I'm very scared.
tr: “Why, with whom?”
es: —Well, who has it?

en: “I wish I knowed, but I don’t. I had it, because I stole it from them; and I stole it to give to you; and I know where I hid it, but I’m afraid it ain’t there no more. I’m awful sorry, Miss Mary Jane, I’m just as sorry as I can be; but I done the best I could; I did honest. I come nigh getting caught, and I had to shove it into the first place I come to, and run—and it warn’t a good place.”
vi: - Oh, I'm very scared. I'd rather have snakes than spiders. Tom thought for a few minutes and then said:
tr: "I wish I knew, but I don't. I had it, because I stole the bag from them: I was thinking of giving it to you, I know where I hid it, but I'm afraid it's not there anymore. I'm very sorry, Miss Mary Jane, I don't know how to express my sorrow; but I did my best; I'm really telling the truth. I was almost caught, so I put it in the first place I came across, and then I ran away – but the place I hid it wasn't a good place at all."
es: —I wish I knew, but I don't. I had it, because I stole it, and I stole it to give it to you, and I know where I hid it but I'm afraid it's no longer there. I'm terribly sorry, Miss Mary Jane, I can't feel worse; but I did everything I could; I really did. They almost caught me and I had to put it in the first place I found and run away, but it wasn't a good place.

en: “Oh, stop blaming yourself—it’s too bad to do it, and I won’t allow it—you couldn’t help it; it wasn’t your fault. Where did you hide it?”
vi: - That's a good idea. So where did you put it?
tr: “Stop blaming yourself already... It's very bad for you to do this and I can't allow such a thing... You had no other choice, it was not in your control. So, where did you hide it?”
es: —Well, stop blaming yourself; it makes you feel bad and I won't allow it; you couldn't avoid it; it wasn't your fault. Where did you hide it?

en: I didn’t want to set her to thinking about her troubles again; and I couldn’t seem to get my mouth to tell her what would make her see that corpse laying in the coffin with that bag of money on his stomach. So for a minute I didn’t say nothing; then I says:
vi: - Leave what, Tom? - A snake, what else?
tr: I didn't want to reopen her wounds, moreover, I couldn't bring myself to say the words that would make her see her father's funeral with a money bag on his belly. For about a minute, the words got stuck in my throat. Finally, I said:
es: I didn't want him to start thinking about his problems again, and I couldn't get my mouth to say something that would make him see that corpse with the bag of money in its stomach again. So for a moment, I didn't say anything, and then I responded:

en: “I’d ruther not tell you where I put it, Miss Mary Jane, if you don’t mind letting me off; but I’ll write it for you on a piece of paper, and you can read it along the road to Mr. Lothrop’s, if you want to. Do you reckon that’ll do?”
vi: - Oh my God, if a snake crawls in here, I will immediately have to squeeze through that hole in the wall to escape. - Oh, Jim, don't be so scared.
tr: "It would be better if I didn't say where I put it, Miss Mary Jane, that is, if you can allow it; but if you want, I can write it down on a piece of paper, and you can read it when you go to the Lothrops'. Is there any problem with doing it this way?"
es: —I prefer not to tell you where I put it, Miss Mary Jane, if you don't mind forgiving me; but I will write it on a piece of paper and you can read it on the way to Mr. Lothrop's house, if you want. Does that seem alright to you?

en: “Oh, yes.”
vi: Can you conquer it?
tr: “Of course not.”
es: —Ah, yes.

en: So I wrote: “I put it in the coffin. It was in there when you was crying there, away in the night. I was behind the door, and I was mighty sorry for you, Miss Mary Jane.”
vi: - Conquer? - Yes, it's easy. Any animal that you love will be grateful and will never harm you.
tr: Upon this, I took a piece of paper and wrote: "I put the bag inside the coffin. While you were crying alone at the coffin at night, I was there too. I was hiding behind the door and felt very sorry for you, Miss Mary Jane."
es: So I wrote: "I put her in the coffin. She was there when you spent the night crying. I was behind the door and felt very sad for you, Miss Mary Jane."

en: It made my eyes water a little to remember her crying there all by herself in the night, and them devils laying there right under her own roof, shaming her and robbing her; and when I folded it up and give it to her I see the water come into her eyes, too; and she shook me by the hand, hard, and says:
vi: Any animal that you love will be grateful and will never harm you.
tr: When I thought about her crying alone at night, while the other devils were doing shameful things under her roof and intending to strip her of everything, my eyes welled up with tears again; then, when I folded the paper and gave it to her, I saw that her eyes were also filled with tears. Gripping my hand with all her strength, she said:
es: A few tears welled up in my eyes as I remembered how she had been left crying there alone all night while those devils slept under her own roof, deceiving and robbing her, and when I folded the note and gave it to her, I saw that tears had welled up in her eyes too, and she grabbed my hand very tightly and said to me:

en: “Good-bye. I’m going to do everything just as you’ve told me; and if I don’t ever see you again, I sha’n’t ever forget you and I’ll think of you a many and a many a time, and I’ll pray for you, too!”—and she was gone.
vi: Just give it a try. Then it might let you wrap it around your neck and even nuzzle its head into your mouth.
tr: "Goodbye. I will do everything exactly as you told me; even if I never see you again, know that I will never forget you, I will think of you many times and pray for you!"
es: —Goodbye. I will do everything exactly as you have told me, and if I never see you again, I will never forget you and I will think of you many, many times, and I will always pray for you! —and she left.

en: Pray for me! I reckoned if she knowed me she’d take a job that was more nearer her size. But I bet she done it, just the same—she was just that kind. She had the grit to pray for Judus if she took the notion—there warn’t no back-down to her, I judge. You may say what you want to, but in my opinion she had more sand in her than any girl I ever see; in my opinion she was just full of sand. It sounds like flattery, but it ain’t no flattery. And when it comes to beauty—and goodness, too—she lays over them all. I hain’t ever seen her since that time that I see her go out of that door; no, I hain’t ever seen her since, but I reckon I’ve thought of her a many and a many a million times, and of her saying she would pray for me; and if ever I’d a thought it would do any good for me to pray for her, blamed if I wouldn’t a done it or bust.
vi: - I beg you, I don't dare to listen! Will it let me put its head in my mouth? Never. Moreover, I don't want it to sleep with me. - Jim, don't be so foolish. A prisoner must have an animal to keep him company. Until now, no one has ever kept a snake, so if you are the first to do it, it will be even more glorious.
tr: Saying this, she left. She said she would pray for me! If she knew me, she would probably find a more appropriate occupation for herself. But she still did it – she was that kind of person. If needed, she was brave enough to pray for the treacherous apostle Judas – she was never the type of girl to back down in the face of difficulties. No matter what anyone says, in my opinion, she was the bravest girl I have ever seen; in fact, I think you couldn't find someone as courageous as her even if you searched for forty years. It might seem like I'm flattering her, but that's not the case at all. As for beauty – and also goodness – no one could hold a candle to her. Since she walked out that door, I haven't seen her; we definitely haven't met again, but I must have thought about her a million times and imagined her saying she would pray for me; if I knew that praying for her would do any good, I would certainly pray with all my heart.
es: Pray for me! I thought that if she knew me, she would have set herself a task more worthy of her. But I bet she did it anyway: she was like that. She had the strength to pray for Judas if it occurred to her, and she never backed down. People can say what they want, but to me, she was the bravest girl I had ever known; to me, she was full of courage. It seems like a compliment, but it isn't. And as for beauty —and also kindness—, she had more than anyone in the world. I haven't seen her since that time she walked out the door; no, I haven't seen her since then, but I think I've thought about her many, many millions of times and how she said she was going to pray for me, and if it ever occurred to me that it would be worth anything for me to pray for her, I would either pray or burst.

en: Well, Mary Jane she lit out the back way, I reckon; because nobody see her go. When I struck Susan and the hare-lip, I says:
vi: - Tom, I don't want that glory. The snake will bite me. No, I don't want to do that.
tr: Mary Jane thus went out, probably using the back door, because no one noticed she had left. When I ran into Susan and Harelip, I said:
es: Well, I guess Mary Jane went out the back door, because no one saw her leave. When I met Susan and the girl with the cleft lip, I told them:

en: “What’s the name of them people over on t’other side of the river that you all goes to see sometimes?”
vi: - Damn it, can't you just try?
tr: “What was the name of the family that lived across the river and that you sometimes visited together?”
es: —What is the name of that family on the other side of the river that you sometimes go to see?

en: They says:
vi: I just want you to try.
tr: “There are a few families,” they said.
es: They answered:

en: “There’s several; but it’s the Proctors, mainly.”
vi: If you don't like it, you don't have to keep it forever!
tr: “But we mostly go to the Proctors.”
es: —There are several; but above all, the Proctor family.

en: “That’s the name,” I says; “I most forgot it. Well, Miss Mary Jane she told me to tell you she’s gone over there in a dreadful hurry—one of them’s sick.”
vi: - But while I was trying, it bit me already. Tom, I don't want to do those things. If Huck brings a snake in here, I'll leave immediately, for sure.
tr: “That was all of them,” I said. “I almost forgot. Miss Mary Jane asked me to tell you that she needs to go there urgently... One of them has fallen ill.”
es: —That is the name —I said—; I almost forgot. Well, Miss Mary Jane asked me to tell you that she had to leave in a hurry: someone is sick.

en: “Which one?”
vi: - Well, never mind then.
tr: “Which one?”
es: —Which one?

en: “I don’t know; leastways, I kinder forget; but I thinks it’s—”
vi: We'll find you a few non-venomous snakes instead.
tr: “I don't know; or rather, I forgot, but most likely…””
es: —I don't know: or if I do know, I've forgotten; but I think it is...

en: “Sakes alive, I hope it ain’t Hanner?”
vi: - I can't stand it either, Tom.
tr: “Oh my God, I hope it's not Hanner!”
es: —My God. I hope it's not Hanna!

en: “I’m sorry to say it,” I says, “but Hanner’s the very one.”
vi: I'm telling you the truth, I've never felt so worried and miserable like this.
tr: “I'm sorry for saying this, but I remember the name as Hanner.”
es: —I'm sorry to say it —I added—, but it's precisely her.

en: “My goodness, and she so well only last week! Is she took bad?”
vi: I'm telling you the truth, I've never felt so worried and miserable like this. - So, are there any mice here?
tr: “Oh no, it had just recovered last week! Is its condition very bad?”
es: —My God, she was doing so well last week! Is she very sick?

en: “It ain’t no name for it. They set up with her all night, Miss Mary Jane said, and they don’t think she’ll last many hours.”
vi: - No, I didn't see any. - Well, we will find you some mice...
tr: "And how. They have been watching over him all night; according to Miss Mary Jane, he might only last a few more hours."
es: —I have no idea. They stayed sitting with her all night, said Miss Mary Jane, and they don't think she will last many hours.

en: “Only think of that, now! What’s the matter with her?”
vi: - I don't need mice, Tom. They are the most annoying creatures, always bothering people, climbing on them, biting their feet, and preventing them from sleeping.
tr: “Oh, such is fate! What kind of illness does he have?”
es: —Who would have thought! What's wrong with him?

en: I couldn’t think of anything reasonable, right off that way, so I says:
vi: I'd rather you put in regular snakes than bring mice in here.
tr: I couldn't find anything reasonable at the moment and blurted out the first thing that came to mind:
es: Nothing reasonable occurred to me to say immediately, so I replied:

en: “Mumps.”
vi: I have no use for mice.
tr: “He has mumps.”
es: —He has mumps.

en: “Mumps your granny! They don’t set up with people that’s got the mumps.”
vi: - But you must have a mouse. Don't worry, they all do it that way.
tr: "Your grandmother is mumps!" "Do they ever stand by the head of someone with mumps all night?""
es: —Mumps, your grandmother! People don't stay to keep company with those who have mumps.

en: “They don’t, don’t they? You better bet they do with these mumps. These mumps is different. It’s a new kind, Miss Mary Jane said.”
vi: Don't worry, they all do it that way. Prisoners never have mice, they train them with many tricks, and then those mice become as familiar as flies.
tr: “They don't stand; why would they stand? But you see, it's necessary to stand by someone who has mumps like this. It's a different kind of mumps. It's a new type, said Mrs. Mary Jane.”
es: —So, no, eh? Well, I bet it's yes when it's mumps like yours. These mumps are different. They're a new kind, Miss Mary Jane told me.

en: “How’s it a new kind?”
vi: Prisoners never have mice, they train them with many tricks, and then those mice become as familiar as flies.
tr: “How is it a new species?”
es: —What new type?

en: “Because it’s mixed up with other things.”
vi: And you also have to play music for them.
tr: “It was a mumps mixed with other things.”
es: —Mixed with other things.

en: “What other things?”
vi: Do you have anything to play music?
tr: “What other things?”
es: —What other things?

en: “Well, measles, and whooping-cough, and erysiplas, and consumption, and yaller janders, and brain-fever, and I don’t know what all.”
vi: - I only have a broken comb and a piece of paper to make a plucked instrument.
tr: “Measles, whooping cough, erysipelas, tuberculosis, jaundice, brain fever, and a whole lot more.”
es: —Well, measles, whooping cough, erysipelas, and consumption, and jaundice and brain fever and I don't know what else.

en: “My land! And they call it the mumps?”
vi: But I'm sure they don't like plucked instruments. - Yes, they do.
tr: “No way! Do they call all of this mumps?”
es: —My God! And they call that mumps?

en: “That’s what Miss Mary Jane said.”
vi: They don't discriminate against any kind of music.
tr: “Miss Mary Jane said so.”
es: —That's what Miss Mary Jane said.

en: “Well, what in the nation do they call it the mumps for?”
vi: They don't discriminate against any kind of music.
tr: “Alright, but what sense does it make to call this mumps?”
es: —Well, and, why the devil do they call it mumps?

en: “Why, because it is the mumps. That’s what it starts with.”
vi: Plucking the instrument is already good enough for the mice.
tr: “Because it's the mumps. Everything started with the mumps.”
es: —Well, because it's the mumps. Start there.

en: “Well, ther’ ain’t no sense in it. A body might stump his toe, and take pison, and fall down the well, and break his neck, and bust his brains out, and somebody come along and ask what killed him, and some numskull up and say, ‘Why, he stumped his toe.’ Would ther’ be any sense in that? No. And ther’ ain’t no sense in this, nuther. Is it ketching?”
vi: Plucking the instrument is already good enough for the mice. All animals like music, and in prison, they like it even more, especially sad music. The mice love it.
tr: “What you said doesn't make any sense to me. Let's say someone first hit their foot somewhere, then got poisoned, fell into a well, broke their neck, and their brain came out, when someone asks how they died, which thick-headed person would say, 'They hit their foot,'? Does that make sense to you? No. It's utter nonsense. The story you told is just like that. I wonder if it's contagious?”
es: —Well, it doesn't make sense. Someone could prick their foot, get infected, fall into a well and break their neck, and their brains could spill out, and then some idiot would come along and say they died because they cut their foot. Would that make sense? No, and this doesn't make sense either. Is it contagious?

en: “Is it ketching? Why, how you talk. Is a harrow catching—in the dark? If you don’t hitch on to one tooth, you’re bound to on another, ain’t you? And you can’t get away with that tooth without fetching the whole harrow along, can you? Well, these kind of mumps is a kind of a harrow, as you may say—and it ain’t no slouch of a harrow, nuther, you come to get it hitched on good.”
vi: The mice love it. They will come out to see what strange thing you have. At night, before going to sleep and early in the morning when you wake up, you have to sit on the bed for a while and play that plucking instrument. If you play for about two minutes, you will see all kinds of mice, snakes, spiders, etc., feeling sad for you and gathering around you.
tr: “Is it not contagious? You're the one talking nonsense! It's like stepping on a rake in the dark. If you don't step on one prong, you'll step on another. Moreover, if you try to lift your foot off the prong you stepped on, the whole rake comes with it. The mumps I'm talking about is like such a rake.
es: —Is it contagious? What things you say. Can one get hooked by a rake in the dark? If it doesn't hit one tooth, it hits the other, right? And you can't remove the tooth without dragging the whole rake, right? Well, this type of mumps is like a kind of rake, so to speak, and not a toy rake, but when you get stuck with it, you really get hooked.

en: “Well, it’s awful, I think,” says the hare-lip. “I’ll go to Uncle Harvey and—”
vi: -Yes, I think so too.
tr: It spreads that badly. And don't think it's like a broken, old rake; once it spreads, it spreads thoroughly.” “It's really terrible,” said Harelip. “I should go to Uncle Harvey right away...”
es: —Well, I think it's horrible —said the one with the cleft lip—; I'm going to see Uncle Harvey and...

en: “Oh, yes,” I says, “I would. Of course I would. I wouldn’t lose no time.”
vi: -Yes, I think so too. But right now I don't understand anything, I will try to follow if I have to do it.
tr: "Go ahead," I said, "if it were me, I would go immediately. It is absolutely necessary to go to him. If it were me, I wouldn't waste any time."
es: —Ah, yes —I said—. That's what I would do. Of course. I wouldn't waste a moment.

en: “Well, why wouldn’t you?”
vi: I will make those animals satisfied and there will be no trouble in the house.
tr: “Why wouldn't you lose?”
es: —Well, why not?

en: “Just look at it a minute, and maybe you can see. Hain’t your uncles obleegd to get along home to England as fast as they can? And do you reckon they’d be mean enough to go off and leave you to go all that journey by yourselves? You know they’ll wait for you. So fur, so good. Your uncle Harvey’s a preacher, ain’t he? Very well, then; is a preacher going to deceive a steamboat clerk? is he going to deceive a ship clerk?—so as to get them to let Miss Mary Jane go aboard? Now you know he ain’t. What will he do, then? Why, he’ll say, ‘It’s a great pity, but my church matters has got to get along the best way they can; for my niece has been exposed to the dreadful pluribus-unum mumps, and so it’s my bounden duty to set down here and wait the three months it takes to show on her if she’s got it.’ But never mind, if you think it’s best to tell your uncle Harvey—”
vi: Tom thought for a moment longer to see if there was anything else, then he said: - There's one more thing I forgot. Can you leave the flowers here? - I don't know, but maybe. But it's very dark in here, and I don't need flowers, it just adds more trouble. - You should give it a try. The other prisoners also grow flowers. - it seems that you can grow cattail flowers here, but it's not worth the effort to plant them. - Don't think that way.
tr: “If you stop and think for a minute, you can figure it out yourself. Your uncles have to return to England as quickly as possible, don't they? Surely, they are not thinking of going ahead and making you travel the whole journey alone. You know they will wait for you. There's no problem up to this point. Your Uncle Harvey is a priest, isn't he? So, would a priest deceive the ship's officer just to get his nephew on board against the rules, especially when there's such an infectious disease in question? You know he can't do that. So what will he do? ‘What a pity, but the problems of my church have to be solved on their own, because my nephew has been exposed to a terrible mumps germ made up of many microbes, and my duty is to stay here and wait for three months to see if he gets infected,’ he will say. But if you still think it's best to tell Uncle Harvey everything, forget it, it's not important.” “No way!
es: —You just need to think about it for a minute and maybe you'll understand. Aren't your uncles obligated to return to England as soon as they can? And do you think they are going to be so mean as to leave and let you make that whole trip alone? You know they will wait for you. Very well. Your uncle Harvey is a preacher, isn't he? Very well, then. Is a preacher going to deceive a ship line employee? Is he going to deceive the ship's purser? To get them to let Miss Mary Jane board? You know perfectly well that he won't. So what is he going to do? Well, he'll say: "It's a shame, but my church matters will have to manage as they can, because my niece has been exposed to those horrible pluribusunum mumps, so I have the obligation to stay here waiting the three months needed to see if she has been infected." But it doesn't matter, if you think it's better to tell your uncle Harvey...

en: “Shucks, and stay fooling around here when we could all be having good times in England whilst we was waiting to find out whether Mary Jane’s got it or not? Why, you talk like a muggins.”
vi: We will find you a sapling, and you will plant it in that corner of the house over there. Don't call it a cat's tail flower, you must call it Pitchiola.
tr: While we could be traveling and having a good time in England, are we going to hang around here waiting to see if Mary Jane gets sick or not? Now you talked like a complete fool.”
es: —That, and staying here doing nothing when we could be having fun in England while we waited to see if Mary Jane got it or not. What nonsense you speak.

en: “Well, anyway, maybe you’d better tell some of the neighbors.”
vi: And you must water it with your tears.
tr: “Still, it might be good to tell one of the neighbors.””
es: —Well, in any case, maybe you should tell one of the neighbors.

en: “Listen at that, now. You do beat all for natural stupidness. Can’t you see that they’d go and tell? Ther’ ain’t no way but just to not tell anybody at all.”
vi: - What's wrong? I have plenty of rainwater here. - You cannot water it with rain; you must water it with tears. Everyone does it that way.
tr: “Can't you hear what I'm saying? I mean, there's no one more foolish than you by birth. Does it never occur to you that they might go and talk to my uncle? There's no other choice but to not tell anyone anything.”
