es: —Look now at what he says. You are the most stupid thing I have ever seen. Don't you understand that they would tell everything? The only thing to do is not to tell anyone.

en: “Well, maybe you’re right—yes, I judge you are right.”
vi: - Uncle Tom, then that flower will surely die, because I rarely cry.
tr: "Hmm, maybe you're right... Yes, you're definitely right."
es: —Well, maybe you're right... Yes, I think you're right.

en: “But I reckon we ought to tell Uncle Harvey she’s gone out a while, anyway, so he won’t be uneasy about her?”
vi: - Uncle Tom, then that flower will surely die, because I rarely cry.
tr: "But still, let's tell Uncle Harvey that she went to his place for a while so he doesn't worry later, right?"
es: —But I think we should still tell Uncle Harvey that she has gone away for a while so he doesn't worry about her.

en: “Yes, Miss Mary Jane she wanted you to do that. She says, ‘Tell them to give Uncle Harvey and William my love and a kiss, and say I’ve run over the river to see Mr.’—Mr.—what is the name of that rich family your uncle Peter used to think so much of?—I mean the one that—”
vi: Tom was at a loss for words. But after thinking for a while, he told Jim to rub an onion on his eyes to make tears. He promised to pick an onion and secretly put it in Jim's coffee pot in the morning.
tr: “Yes, Miss Mary Jane wanted you to do that anyway. ‘Tell them to send my love to Uncle Harvey and Uncle William, kiss them for me, and go across to the other side to see the things… the things… what was the name of that rich family your Uncle Peter always talked about?.. You know, the one…”
es: —Yes, Miss Mary Jane wanted you to tell them. She told me: "Tell them to greet Uncle Harvey and Uncle William for me and give them a kiss and tell them that I have gone to the other side of the river to see Mr... Mr... " What is the name of that rich family that your Uncle Peter esteemed so much?... I mean the one that...

en: “Why, you must mean the Apthorps, ain’t it?”
vi: Jim said that would make the coffee smell like onions, and then Jim complained about Tom's plans, such as planting cattail flowers, playing music for the mice, petting snakes and spiders, and also having to sharpen pencils, carve letters into stone, and write a diary, etc.
tr: “I guess you mean the Apthorps, right?”
es: —Man, you must be referring to the Apthorp, right?

en: “Of course; bother them kind of names, a body can’t ever seem to remember them, half the time, somehow. Yes, she said, say she has run over for to ask the Apthorps to be sure and come to the auction and buy this house, because she allowed her uncle Peter would ruther they had it than anybody else; and she’s going to stick to them till they say they’ll come, and then, if she ain’t too tired, she’s coming home; and if she is, she’ll be home in the morning anyway. She said, don’t say nothing about the Proctors, but only about the Apthorps—which’ll be perfectly true, because she is going there to speak about their buying the house; I know it, because she told me so herself.”
vi: Jim said that would make the coffee smell like onions, and then Jim complained about Tom's plans, such as planting cattail flowers, playing music for the mice, petting snakes and spiders, and also having to sharpen pencils, carve letters into stone, and write a diary, etc.
tr: “Of course, ah these names never stick in my mind, they are all so complicated. Yes, he said that you should say you went to call the Apthorps to the auction to buy this house, because Uncle Peter doesn't want anyone else to buy the house; your sister will stay there until she convinces them to come to the auction, and then she will come home if she is not too tired; if she is tired, she will come in the morning. He asked you not to say anything about the Proctors, just to talk about the Apthorps – you will be telling the truth anyway, because he really is going to visit them to discuss the matter of buying the house; that's exactly what he told me.”
es: —Naturally, damn names, I don't know why but half the time I forget them. Yes, she asked me to tell you that she has gone to see the Apthorps to make sure they come to the auction and buy this house, because she knows that her uncle Peter would prefer them to have it more than anyone else, and that she will stay with them until they say they are coming, and then, if she is not too tired, she will come back home, and if she is tired she will come back in the morning anyway. She asked me not to say anything about the Proctors, and to talk only about the Apthorps, which is perfectly true, because she is going there to talk about buying the house; I know because she told me herself.

en: “All right,” they said, and cleared out to lay for their uncles, and give them the love and the kisses, and tell them the message.
vi: Jim said that would make the coffee smell like onions, and then Jim complained about Tom's plans, such as planting cattail flowers, playing music for the mice, petting snakes and spiders, and also having to sharpen pencils, carve letters into stone, and write a diary, etc.
tr: "Alright then," they said and immediately ran to their uncle, conveyed their love and kisses, and delivered their sister's message.
es: —Very well —they said, and they went off to find their uncles and give them greetings and kisses and deliver the message.

en: Everything was all right now. The girls wouldn’t say nothing because they wanted to go to England; and the king and the duke would ruther Mary Jane was off working for the auction than around in reach of Doctor Robinson. I felt very good; I judged I had done it pretty neat—I reckoned Tom Sawyer couldn’t a done it no neater himself. Of course he would a throwed more style into it, but I can’t do that very handy, not being brung up to it.
vi: It was really troublesome and annoying. He talked for a while, making Tom discouraged. Tom said that he had thought of all those things just to make Jim famous, but Jim's complaints made it all seem in vain.
tr: Everything was now complete. The girls wouldn't say anything because they wanted to go to England; the king and the duke would also prefer Mary Jane to go away and work for the auction instead of hanging around Dr. Robinson. I was feeling very good; I thought I did this job well... Probably even Tom Sawyer couldn't have done better. Though he would certainly do it by the book, but since I haven't done such things in my life, I'm not as skillful as he is.
es: Now everything was in order. The girls wouldn't say anything because they wanted to go to England, and the king and the duke would prefer that Mary Jane had gone to work so that the auction would go well and she wouldn't be within Dr. Robinson's reach. I felt great, and I figured I had done very well... I figured not even Tom Sawyer himself could have done it better. Of course, he would have done it with more style, but that's not easy for me, because I haven't been educated that way.

en: Well, they held the auction in the public square, along towards the end of the afternoon, and it strung along, and strung along, and the old man he was on hand and looking his level pisonest, up there longside of the auctioneer, and chipping in a little Scripture now and then, or a little goody-goody saying of some kind, and the duke he was around goo-gooing for sympathy all he knowed how, and just spreading himself generly.
vi: Tom said that he had thought of all those things just to make Jim famous, but Jim's complaints made it all seem in vain.
tr: Anyway, they held the auction in the town square, towards the evening; they dragged it out as long as they could, the old man stood right next to the auctioneer and was striking his most pious poses, occasionally reading a few sentences from the Bible and making fancy speeches; while the duke was wandering around making pitiful sounds like uuu-uuu to gain sympathy.
es: Well, they organized the auction in the public square, around mid-afternoon, and it went on and on; and there was the old man, with his sanctimonious airs, right next to the auctioneer, occasionally quoting something from the Scriptures or some pious saying, and the duke was going back and forth making "goo-goo" sounds so that everyone would feel sorry for him, and smiling at everyone.

en: But by-and-by the thing dragged through, and everything was sold—everything but a little old trifling lot in the graveyard. So they’d got to work that off—I never see such a girafft as the king was for wanting to swallow everything. Well, whilst they was at it a steamboat landed, and in about two minutes up comes a crowd a-whooping and yelling and laughing and carrying on, and singing out:
vi: Tom said that he had thought of all those things just to make Jim famous, but Jim's complaints made it all seem in vain. Hearing that, Jim felt remorseful and promised not to behave like that anymore.
tr: But slowly but surely, the auction progressed and eventually everything was sold. Only a small bag of details remained in the cemetery. They would find it themselves now... I had never seen anyone try to extract oil from a fly as much as our king. While they were busy with this, a steamboat docked at the pier, and two minutes later, the crowd came towards us, shouting, laughing, and making a racket:
es: But little by little, things started to run out and everything was sold, except for a few that remained in the cemetery. Then they set about trying to sell those; in my life, I have never seen even a giraffe like the king, so willing to swallow everything. And when they were at it, a steamboat docked and about two minutes later a group arrived, shouting and screaming, laughing and making a racket and yelling:

en: “Here’s your opposition line! here’s your two sets o’ heirs to old Peter Wilks—and you pays your money and you takes your choice!”
vi: Hearing that, Jim felt remorseful and promised not to behave like that anymore. After that, Tom and I went back to our room to sleep.
tr: "Here are your rivals! Two more heirs have come for our Peter Wilks... Whoever pays can choose whichever they want!"
es: —Here comes the opposition! Now we have two groups of Peter Wilks' heirs: Step right up, pay, and see!

en: CHAPTER XXIX.
vi: Chapter XXIX
tr: Twenty-Ninth Chapter
es: Chapter 29

en: They was fetching a very nice-looking old gentleman along, and a nice-looking younger one, with his right arm in a sling. And, my souls, how the people yelled and laughed, and kept it up. But I didn’t see no joke about it, and I judged it would strain the duke and the king some to see any. I reckoned they’d turn pale. But no, nary a pale did they turn. The duke he never let on he suspicioned what was up, but just went a goo-gooing around, happy and satisfied, like a jug that’s googling out buttermilk; and as for the king, he just gazed and gazed down sorrowful on them new-comers like it give him the stomach-ache in his very heart to think there could be such frauds and rascals in the world. Oh, he done it admirable. Lots of the principal people gethered around the king, to let him see they was on his side. That old gentleman that had just come looked all puzzled to death. Pretty soon he begun to speak, and I see straight off he pronounced like an Englishman—not the king’s way, though the king’s was pretty good for an imitation. I can’t give the old gent’s words, nor I can’t imitate him; but he turned around to the crowd, and says, about like this:
vi: They approached an old man who looked very polite along with a younger man, who also looked quite mature, with a bandage on his right arm. It seemed like this matter was not a joke. Perhaps the king and the duke were also feeling uneasy. I'm sure they would be scared pale. But no, they didn't show any signs of it. The duke still calmly wandered around there, looking satisfied. And the king looked up and down, appearing hesitant and worried; it seemed that it pained him to think that there could be such deceitful swindlers in the world. Many people stood around the king to support him. A moment later, the dignified old man began to speak. I immediately noticed that he spoke exactly like a real Englishman, unlike the king's manner of speaking. He spoke roughly like this:
tr: They were bringing along a very elegant elderly gentleman, and also a younger man, equally elegant, with his right arm in a sling. My God, how people were shouting; laughing and making a racket. But I didn't find the situation funny at all, and I thought the duke and the king would be scared when they saw them. I thought both of them would turn pale as a sheet. But no, they didn't turn pale at all. The duke didn't let on that he understood what was happening, he continued to wander around happily and making a "uuu-uuu" sound like a milk churn spraying cream everywhere; the king, on the other hand, looked at the scene with a pained and sorrowful expression, as if deeply wounded by the existence of such frauds and scoundrels in the world. Ah, it was truly an admirable performance. Most of the people in the town gathered around the king, trying to show their support for him. The elderly gentleman came in, utterly dumbfounded. Soon enough, he started to speak, and indeed, he spoke just like an Englishman, very different from the king's speech, although the king's speech was quite good for an imitation. I can't describe how the old man spoke, nor can I imitate it; but turning to the crowd, he said something along these lines:
es: THEY BROUGHT AN elderly gentleman of very good appearance and another younger one, also of good appearance, with his right arm in a sling. My God, how those people shouted and laughed, without stopping for a moment! But I didn't see the humor in it and supposed that the duke and the king would also find it hard to see. I had the feeling they were going to turn pale. But no, they did not turn pale. The duke did not let on that he suspected what was happening, but continued making "goo-goo" sounds to the people, happy and content, like a pitcher pouring out milk, and as for the king, he just looked sadly at the newcomers, as if his stomach hurt just thinking that there could be people in the world with so little shame. Ah, he did it admirably. Many of the town's characters went to the king to show him they were on his side. The old gentleman who had just arrived seemed dead with embarrassment. He immediately began to speak and I saw right away that they had an accent just like an Englishman's, not like the king's, although the king did very well with imitations. I can't write exactly what the old man said, nor can I imitate it, but he turned to the people and said something like this:

en: “This is a surprise to me which I wasn’t looking for; and I’ll acknowledge, candid and frank, I ain’t very well fixed to meet it and answer it; for my brother and me has had misfortunes; he’s broke his arm, and our baggage got put off at a town above here last night in the night by a mistake. I am Peter Wilks’ brother Harvey, and this is his brother William, which can’t hear nor speak—and can’t even make signs to amount to much, now’t he’s only got one hand to work them with. We are who we say we are; and in a day or two, when I get the baggage, I can prove it. But up till then I won’t say nothing more, but go to the hotel and wait.”
vi: - This is truly a strange thing that I could not have anticipated. My brother and I had an unfortunate incident; my brother broke his arm, and our luggage was mistakenly sent to another town. I am Harvey, the brother of Peter Wilks; and this is my brother William. William cannot hear or speak, and he can't make many signs because he has broken an arm. In a few days, when we retrieve our luggage, we will have enough evidence. But until then, I don't want to say anything more, we will go to the hotel and wait there. Then the two people walked away.
tr: “I encountered a very surprising situation here that I did not expect at all; I must honestly say that I am not very prepared to face and fight such a thing; because my brother and I had some misfortunes, he broke his arm, and our belongings were mistakenly taken to a town up here last night. I am Harvey, the older brother of Peter Wilks, and this is his brother William, who is deaf and mute – moreover, since his arm is in a sling now, he cannot even use sign language. We are the people we claim to be, and I will prove it when my belongings arrive in a day or two. But until then, I will not say anything else and will go to the hotel to wait.”
es: —This is a surprise I did not expect, and I sincerely admit that I am not very well prepared to react to it and respond, as my brother and I have suffered some misfortunes; he has broken his arm and last night our luggage was left in a town further up by mistake. I am Harvey, Peter Wilks' brother, and this is his brother William, who is deaf-mute, and now he can't even communicate much through signs, given that he only has one free hand. We are who we say we are, and within a day or two, when the luggage arrives, I will be able to prove it. But until then I will not say more, and I am going to the hotel to wait.

en: So him and the new dummy started off; and the king he laughs, and blethers out:
vi: The king laughed and muttered for a while:
tr: Thus, he walked away with the new deaf-mute by his side, and the king called out after him with a laugh:
es: So he and the new mute set off, and the king burst out laughing and said: —So, you've broken your arm, huh, just in time, right?

en: “Broke his arm—very likely, ain’t it?—and very convenient, too, for a fraud that’s got to make signs, and ain’t learnt how. Lost their baggage! That’s mighty good!—and mighty ingenious—under the circumstances!”
vi: - A broken arm, yes, that's possible, isn't it, gentlemen? And it's convenient for a trickster who needs to make a signal. Losing luggage, now that's an intelligent ruse!
tr: “He broke his arm... no doubt about it! He broke it at just the right time, truly, at a very convenient time for those tricksters who need to use sign language but haven't learned how to use it. They lost their belongings! This is even more marvelous!.. Moreover, very clever... Considering the circumstances!”
es: And very convenient for a liar who has to speak in signs and hasn't learned them. They've lost their luggage! That's a good one! And it turns out to be very clever, in these circumstances.

en: So he laughed again; and so did everybody else, except three or four, or maybe half a dozen. One of these was that doctor; another one was a sharp-looking gentleman, with a carpet-bag of the old-fashioned kind made out of carpet-stuff, that had just come off of the steamboat and was talking to him in a low voice, and glancing towards the king now and then and nodding their heads—it was Levi Bell, the lawyer that was gone up to Louisville; and another one was a big rough husky that come along and listened to all the old gentleman said, and was listening to the king now. And when the king got done this husky up and says:
vi: Then the old man laughed loudly, and everyone else laughed along, except for three or four people who did not agree. One of those people was the doctor. The second person was a very polite man, carrying a suitcase, who had just disembarked from the ship earlier and was speaking quietly with the doctor, occasionally looking up at the king and nodding their heads. That was lawyer Levi Ben, who had just returned from Louisville. The third person was large and muscular, who had just arrived and was listening to the old man earlier and now listening to the king. After the king finished speaking, that person looked up and asked:
tr: He laughed again; the others joined him, but three or four people, maybe six or so, did not laugh. One of them was a doctor; the other was a stern-looking man carrying an old-fashioned cloth bag made of kilim. He had just gotten off the ferry and was whispering with the doctor; occasionally they would look at the king and nod their heads – this man was Levi Bell, the lawyer who had gone to Louisville; there was also a burly man who came and listened to everything the old gentleman said, and now he was listening to what the king was saying. When the king finished his words, the burly man called out to him loudly:
es: So he laughed again, just like everyone else, except three or four, or maybe half a dozen. One of them was the doctor, another a gentleman with a shrewd appearance, carrying one of those old-fashioned carpet bags, who had just disembarked from the steamboat and was speaking quietly with the doctor, while they occasionally glanced at the king and nodded: it was Levi Bell, the lawyer who had gone to Louisville, and another was a tall, sturdy fellow who had approached to hear what the old man was saying and was now listening to the king. And when the king finished, the sturdy fellow goes and says:

en: “Say, looky here; if you are Harvey Wilks, when’d you come to this town?”
vi: - If you are Harvey Wilks, then when did you arrive in this town?
tr: "Hey, look at me, if you are Harvey Wilks, when did you arrive in town?"
es: —Listen, one thing: if you are Harvey Wilks, when did you arrive in town?

en: “The day before the funeral, friend,” says the king.
vi: - The day before the funeral, sir.
tr: “I arrived the day before the funeral, my friend,” said the king.
es: —The day before the funeral, my friend —says the king.

en: “But what time o’ day?”
vi: - But at what time?
tr: “So, what time did you arrive?”
es: —But, at what time?

en: “In the evenin’—’bout an hour er two before sundown.”
vi: - In the afternoon, about one or two hours before sunset.
tr: “I came in the evening... About an hour or two before sunset.”
es: —In the afternoon, an hour or two before dusk.

en: “How’d you come?”
vi: - How did you get here?
tr: “How did you come?”
es: —How did he arrive?

en: “I come down on the Susan Powell from Cincinnati.”
vi: - I took the Susan Powell train from Cincinnati to here.
tr: “I came with Susan Powell from Cincinnati.”
es: —I came on the Susan Powell from Cincinnati.

en: “Well, then, how’d you come to be up at the Pint in the mornin’—in a canoe?”
vi: - So how did you manage to get to the dock in the morning, did you take a boat?
tr: “Well then, what were you doing up at Pint in the morning... Why were you in a canoe?”
es: —So, how is it that you were at La Punta that morning, in a canoe?

en: “I warn’t up at the Pint in the mornin’.”
vi: - I do not go to the dock in the morning.
tr: “I wasn't in Pint in the morning.”
es: —That morning I wasn't at the Punta.

en: “It’s a lie.”
vi: - Nonsense.
tr: "You are lying."
es: —He lies.

en: Several of them jumped for him and begged him not to talk that way to an old man and a preacher.
vi: Many people came forward and demanded that the other person not speak in such a manner to a pastor. - Pastor?
tr: A few people immediately went to him and begged him not to speak like that to an old man and a priest.
es: A few of them jumped on him and told him not to talk like that to an old man who was also a preacher.

en: “Preacher be hanged, he’s a fraud and a liar. He was up at the Pint that mornin’. I live up there, don’t I? Well, I was up there, and he was up there. I see him there. He come in a canoe, along with Tim Collins and a boy.”
vi: Hang him up, he's a fraud. He arrived at the dock that morning. I was there myself and saw him. He went by boat, along with Tim Collins and another boy.
tr: “To hell with the priest, he's nothing but a fraud and a liar. He was at Pint in the morning. Don't you know I sit there? He was there while I was in front of the house. I'm sure I saw him. He was in a canoe, with Tim Collins and a boy beside him.”
es: —As a preacher, nothing; he's a liar and a fraud. That morning he was at the Point. I live there, don't I? Well, I was there and he was there, and I saw him. He arrived in a canoe, with Tim Collins and a boy.

en: The doctor he up and says:
vi: The doctor asked:
tr: The doctor intervened and asked, "Would you recognize that boy if you saw him again, Hines?"
es: The doctor goes and says:

en: “Would you know the boy again if you was to see him, Hines?”
vi: - If you see that boy again, would you recognize him, Hines?
tr: The doctor intervened and asked, "Would you recognize that boy if you saw him again, Hines?"
es: —Would you recognize the boy if you saw him again, Hines?

en: “I reckon I would, but I don’t know. Why, yonder he is, now. I know him perfectly easy.”
vi: - Recognize it? Ah, there it is. That person pointed directly at me.
tr: “I probably know him, but I'm not sure. But wait, there he is. I recognized him immediately.”
es: —I suppose so, but I don't know. Well, there it is. I recognize it perfectly.

en: It was me he pointed at. The doctor says:
vi: That person pointed directly at me. The doctor said:
tr: He had pointed at me. The doctor turned to the others:
es: And he pointed at me. The doctor says:

en: “Neighbors, I don’t know whether the new couple is frauds or not; but if these two ain’t frauds, I am an idiot, that’s all. I think it’s our duty to see that they don’t get away from here till we’ve looked into this thing. Come along, Hines; come along, the rest of you. We’ll take these fellows to the tavern and affront them with t’other couple, and I reckon we’ll find out something before we get through.”
vi: - Ladies and gentlemen, I am not yet sure if the two people who just arrived are frauds or not, but if these two guys here are not swindlers, then I am just a fool. I think it is our duty to keep them from leaving this place until we understand the situation. Everyone, follow me to the hotel and confront the two newcomers; I am sure we can find something. Everyone appeared angry except for those who sided with the king.
tr: “I don't know if the newcomers are frauds, my friends; but if these two are not frauds, then I must be a fool. I think our primary duty is to prevent them from escaping until this matter is resolved. Come on, Hines; the rest of you, follow. Let's take these men to the inn and confront them with the other two, maybe then we can learn something.”
es: —Neighbors, I don't know if these new ones are two liars or not, but if they're not, then I'm an idiot, that's what I say. I think we need to stop them from leaving here until we've cleared everything up. Come on, Hines; all of you, come along. Let's take these guys to the tavern to confront them with the other two and surely before we're done we'll have figured something out.

en: It was nuts for the crowd, though maybe not for the king’s friends; so we all started. It was about sundown. The doctor he led me along by the hand, and was plenty kind enough, but he never let go my hand.
vi: So, we all had to go. At that time, the sun was about to set. The doctor took my hand and led me, gently, but he didn't let go of me for a moment.
tr: The crowd was filled with excitement, although the king's friends were probably not very pleased; still, we all set off together. The sun was about to set. The doctor held my hand and led me along the way, he was behaving very well but he definitely did not let go of my hand.
es: The people loved it, although perhaps not the king's friends; so we set off. It was towards the evening. The doctor took me by the hand and was very kind, but he never let go.

en: We all got in a big room in the hotel, and lit up some candles, and fetched in the new couple. First, the doctor says:
vi: Everyone entered a large room in the hotel, then summoned the two people from earlier. The doctor spoke first:
tr: We all gathered in the hotel's large hall, the lamps were lit, and the new couple was brought in. First, the doctor spoke:
es: We all entered a large room in the hotel, lit some candles, and brought in the two newcomers. First, the doctor says:

en: “I don’t wish to be too hard on these two men, but I think they’re frauds, and they may have complices that we don’t know nothing about. If they have, won’t the complices get away with that bag of gold Peter Wilks left? It ain’t unlikely. If these men ain’t frauds, they won’t object to sending for that money and letting us keep it till they prove they’re all right—ain’t that so?”
vi: - I don't want to do anything excessive to these two people, but because I think they are swindlers, and they might have schemes that we don't know about. Would they dare to slip away and leave Peter Wilks' bundle of money behind? Probably not. If these guys aren't swindlers, they would probably take out that bundle of money for us to keep until they can prove they are honest, wouldn't everyone agree?
tr: “I don't want to wrong these two men, but if you ask me, they are swindlers, and they might have accomplices we don't know about. If they have accomplices, they would have already taken the bag with Peter Wilks' gold and fled? We cannot allow this. If these two are not frauds, they will not object to bringing the money and letting us keep it until they prove they are telling the truth… Am I wrong?”
es: —I don't want to be too harsh on these two men, but I believe they are swindlers and might have accomplices we know nothing about. In that case, won't the accomplices escape with the sack of gold that Peter Wilks left? It wouldn't be surprising. If these men are not swindlers, they won't object to us going to fetch the money and keeping it until they prove they aren't; don't you think?

en: Everybody agreed to that. So I judged they had our gang in a pretty tight place right at the outstart. But the king he only looked sorrowful, and says:
vi: Everyone answered in agreement. I think they had cornered us right from the start. But the king only showed a hint of sadness. He said:
tr: Everyone agreed to this. I had already decided that our gang was cornered. They had lost from the start. But the king replied with sorrow:
es: Everyone agreed. So I thought that from the very beginning they had put our band in serious trouble. But the king only put on a sad face and said:

en: “Gentlemen, I wish the money was there, for I ain’t got no disposition to throw anything in the way of a fair, open, out-and-out investigation o’ this misable business; but, alas, the money ain’t there; you k’n send and see, if you want to.”
vi: - Dear sirs, I also hope that the money pouch is still there, because I do not want to hinder the discovery of the whole story. But the money pouch is no longer there. If you don't believe me, you can send someone to search.
tr: “Gentlemen; I wish the money were at home, because I have no intention of obstructing the fair, transparent, and detailed investigation of this dirty business; but unfortunately, the money is not there; you can send someone to check if you want.”
es: —Gentlemen, I wish the money were there, for I am not one to put obstacles in the way of a fair, open, and thorough investigation of this sad matter; but, unfortunately, the money is not there; you can send to look for it, if you wish.

en: “Where is it, then?”
vi: - Where did you put the money?
tr: “So where is the money?”
es: —Where is it, then?

en: “Well, when my niece give it to me to keep for her I took and hid it inside o’ the straw tick o’ my bed, not wishin’ to bank it for the few days we’d be here, and considerin’ the bed a safe place, we not bein’ used to niggers, and suppos’n’ ’em honest, like servants in England. The niggers stole it the very next mornin’ after I had went down stairs; and when I sold ’em I hadn’t missed the money yit, so they got clean away with it. My servant here k’n tell you ’bout it, gentlemen.”
vi: - When my granddaughter gave it to me, I hid it under the mattress of my bed, because I was staying here for a few days and didn't want to deposit that money into the bank. I thought black people were as honest as my servants, but who would have thought they would take all that money before leaving this place. My servant here can explain this clearly for you to understand.
tr: “My nephew had given me the money to keep, thinking we would stay here for at most a few days, I didn't see the need to deposit it all in the bank and placed it inside the straw mattress under my bed; I thought the bed was a safe place, we are not very accustomed to negroes, we thought they were like the honest servants in England. The next morning, as soon as I came down the stairs, the negroes had stolen the money; I didn't know the money was gone when I sold them, so we couldn't catch them. My servant can confirm what I have said.”
es: —Well, when my niece gave it to me to keep it for her, I hid it in the mattress of my bed, because I didn't want to take it to the bank just for a few days and I thought the bed would be a safe place, since we are not used to black people and I assumed they were honest, just like English servants. The black people stole it the next morning, when I went downstairs, and when I sold them I still hadn't realized it was missing, so they left with it. Here my servant can confirm it, gentlemen.

en: The doctor and several said “Shucks!” and I see nobody didn’t altogether believe him. One man asked me if I see the niggers steal it. I said no, but I see them sneaking out of the room and hustling away, and I never thought nothing, only I reckoned they was afraid they had waked up my master and was trying to get away before he made trouble with them. That was all they asked me. Then the doctor whirls on me and says:
vi: The doctor, along with many others, also said: - Stop it! Nobody believes what that old man says. Someone asked me if I saw the black people stealing money. I said that I only saw them hurrying out of the room. I thought they were afraid of waking up my boss, so they had to step outside. But the doctor angrily asked me:
tr: The doctor and a few others said, "Nonsense!" and I saw that no one fully believed the king. One of the men turned to me and asked if the money had been stolen by the black people. I said I hadn't seen it, but I had seen them quietly leaving the room and nothing had occurred to me; I thought they were afraid of waking the gentleman and were trying to get away without getting into trouble. They only asked me this. Then the doctor suddenly turned to me and asked:
es: The doctor and several others said "wow!", and I saw that no one completely believed it. A man asked me if I had seen the black men steal it. I said no, but that I had seen them sneak out of the room and leave and that I had never thought anything bad, because I believed they had been scared of waking my master and were trying to leave before he reprimanded them. They didn't ask me anything else. Then the doctor turned to me and asked:

en: “Are you English, too?”
vi: - Are you English?
tr: “Are you English too?”
es: —Are you English too?

en: I says yes; and him and some others laughed, and said, “Stuff!”
vi: I said yes, then he and everyone laughed and said: - Another con artist!
tr: Yes, I said; the doctor and a few others laughed out loud, saying, "Nonsense!"
es: I said yes and he and others burst out laughing and said: "Nonsense!"

en: Well, then they sailed in on the general investigation, and there we had it, up and down, hour in, hour out, and nobody never said a word about supper, nor ever seemed to think about it—and so they kept it up, and kept it up; and it was the worst mixed-up thing you ever see. They made the king tell his yarn, and they made the old gentleman tell his’n; and anybody but a lot of prejudiced chuckleheads would a seen that the old gentleman was spinning truth and t’other one lies. And by-and-by they had me up to tell what I knowed. The king he give me a left-handed look out of the corner of his eye, and so I knowed enough to talk on the right side. I begun to tell about Sheffield, and how we lived there, and all about the English Wilkses, and so on; but I didn’t get pretty fur till the doctor begun to laugh; and Levi Bell, the lawyer, says:
vi: We were being talked up and down for several hours without anyone mentioning anything about eating or drinking. They made the king recount the whole story of the old man, and then they asked that distinguished old man to also recount his whole story. But no one dared to assert whether the old man was telling the truth or the king was lying. After a while, they told me to step forward and recount everything I knew. The king glanced at me, so I knew how to speak appropriately. I began to talk about the city of Sheffield, how we lived there, and everything about the Wilks family in England.
tr: Then they returned to the general inquiry; one spoke, then the other, hours passed, and no one mentioned eating, it seemed as if food hadn't even crossed their minds – they argued and argued; it was the most complicated situation you could ever see. They made the king tell his own story, they made the old gentleman tell his own story; everyone except the biased fools realized that the old gentleman was telling the truth and the king was lying. At one point, they asked me to tell everything I knew. The king glanced sideways, obviously expecting me to take his side. I started talking about Sheffield and how we lived there; I also mentioned the English Wilkses; but I couldn't say much, because the Doctor started laughing and the lawyer Levi Bell said:
es: Well, then they continued with the general investigation, which went on with its ups and downs, hour after hour, and no one said a word about dinner, it seemed like they didn't even remember it, so they kept going and going and it turned out to be very complicated. They made the king tell his version, and then the old man tell his, and anyone who wasn't a mule full of prejudices would have seen that the old gentleman was telling the truth and the other was lying. And then they forced me to tell what I knew. The king looked at me out of the corner of his eye and I realized what it was convenient for me to say. I started talking about Sheffield and how we lived there and all the Wilks there were in England, and all that; but I hadn't said much when the doctor started laughing and then Levi Bell, the lawyer, goes and says:

en: “Set down, my boy; I wouldn’t strain myself if I was you. I reckon you ain’t used to lying, it don’t seem to come handy; what you want is practice. You do it pretty awkward.”
vi: But before I could finish, that doctor burst out laughing, and then Levi Ben, the lawyer, also spoke: - Well, the machine isn't used to lying, so it often stumbles over its words. I didn't pay attention to the compliment; I was just very happy to have escaped.
tr: “Sit here, child. If I were you, I wouldn't stress myself so much. You're probably not used to lying, you can't make things up on the spot, you need some practice. You're a very bad liar.”
es: —Sit down, boy; if I were you, I wouldn't tire myself out. I figure you're not used to lying and it's not easy for you; you lack practice. You're doing it quite poorly.

en: I didn’t care nothing for the compliment, but I was glad to be let off, anyway.
vi: I didn't pay attention to the compliment; I was just very happy to have escaped.
tr: I was in no condition to care about the man's praise; I was very pleased to be left alone.
es: I didn't like that compliment very much, but in any case, I was glad they left me alone.

en: The doctor he started to say something, and turns and says:
vi: Now, the doctor turned to the side and said:
tr: The doctor started to explain something, but then turned and said:
es: The doctor started to say something and then turns around and says:

en: “If you’d been in town at first, Levi Bell—” The king broke in and reached out his hand, and says:
vi: - If only you had been in this town from the very beginning, wouldn't that be better, Mr. Levi Ben? The king raised his hand and interjected:
tr: "I wish you had been here when they came to town, Levi Bell..."" The king immediately intervened and extended his hand.
es: —If you had been in the town from the beginning, Levi Bell... The king interrupted, reached out his hand, and said:

en: “Why, is this my poor dead brother’s old friend that he’s wrote so often about?”
vi: - So this is the friend that my brother often mentioned in his letters?
tr: “Aren't you the old friend my poor deceased brother often wrote letters about?”
es: —But, is this the old friend of my poor brother, may he rest in peace, whom he told me so much about in his letters?

en: The lawyer and him shook hands, and the lawyer smiled and looked pleased, and they talked right along awhile, and then got to one side and talked low; and at last the lawyer speaks up and says:
vi: The lawyer shook hands with the old man, smiling with satisfaction, then the two exchanged a few words, and stepped aside to speak quietly.
tr: They shook hands with the lawyer, the lawyer smiled, he seemed pleased. After talking for a while, they stepped aside and whispered a bit. Finally, the lawyer said loudly:
es: The lawyer and he shook hands and the lawyer smiled with a satisfied air and they chatted for a while and then they moved to the side and spoke in low voices, and finally the lawyer speaks out loud and says:

en: “That’ll fix it. I’ll take the order and send it, along with your brother’s, and then they’ll know it’s all right.”
vi: A moment later, the lawyer spoke up: - Alright, I will take the documents from both sides to understand the truth of the matter.
tr: “Then it will be resolved. If you and your brother provide written instructions, there will be no problem.”
es: —That's how things will be sorted out. We place the order and send it, along with your brother's, and that way you'll see that everything is in order.

en: So they got some paper and a pen, and the king he set down and twisted his head to one side, and chawed his tongue, and scrawled off something; and then they give the pen to the duke—and then for the first time the duke looked sick. But he took the pen and wrote. So then the lawyer turns to the new old gentleman and says:
vi: So they took out paper and pen. The king sat down, tilted his head to one side, and scribbled something on it. Then they handed the pen to the duke, who seemed fearful. But he still took the pen and wrote. Then the lawyer turned to the old man and said:
tr: Thus, they found a piece of paper and a pen; the king sat down, tilted his head to one side, stuck his tongue out halfway, and scribbled something; then he handed the pen to the duke – the duke looked genuinely on edge for the first time. But still, he took the pen and wrote. The lawyer then turned to the new elderly gentleman:
es: So they brought a paper and a pen, and the king sat down, tilted his head to one side, bit his tongue, and scribbled something; then they handed the pen to the duke, and for the first time, he looked troubled. But he took the pen and wrote. Then the lawyer turns to the newly arrived old man and says to him:

en: “You and your brother please write a line or two and sign your names.”
vi: - You and your brother, please write a few lines here and sign your names below.
tr: “Please, you and your brother each write a few lines and sign them.””
es: —You and your brother, please write a line or two and sign with your name.

en: The old gentleman wrote, but nobody couldn’t read it. The lawyer looked powerful astonished, and says:
vi: The old man wrote, but no one could read a single word. The lawyer took an old bundle of letters from his pocket, examined them carefully, then looked at the old man's handwriting, and then at the handwriting of the king and the duke, showing great surprise, he said:
tr: The elderly gentleman wrote, but no one could read what he had written. The lawyer was very surprised by this.
es: The elderly gentleman wrote, but no one managed to read what it said. The lawyer seemed extremely astonished and said:

en: “Well, it beats me”—and snaked a lot of old letters out of his pocket, and examined them, and then examined the old man’s writing, and then them again; and then says: “These old letters is from Harvey Wilks; and here’s these two handwritings, and anybody can see they didn’t write them” (the king and the duke looked sold and foolish, I tell you, to see how the lawyer had took them in), “and here’s this old gentleman’s hand writing, and anybody can tell, easy enough, he didn’t write them—fact is, the scratches he makes ain’t properly writing at all. Now, here’s some letters from—”
vi: - Strange, these old letters are from Harvey Wilks and here are two handwriting samples. Anyone can see that those people did not write like this. As for this old man's handwriting, anyone can easily see that it's not his writing...
tr: “Well, that’s correct,” he said – taking out a bunch of old letters from his pocket and examining them, then examining the handwriting of the old men: “These are letters from Harvey Wilks; and these are the handwriting of these two, it’s immediately obvious that they didn’t write the letters” (the king and the duke had realized how the lawyer had outsmarted them and were left gaping like fools), “this handwriting you see here is also from this old gentleman, it’s immediately obvious that he didn’t write the letters either… In fact, the scribbles don’t even resemble proper writing. Here are these letters too…”
es: —Well, I don't understand it —and he took a bunch of old letters out of his pocket and examined them; then he examined what the old man had written and then the letters again, and he goes and says—: These old letters are from Harvey Wilks, and here we see these two letters; you can all see that neither of the two wrote the letters (the king and the duke put on the faces of deceived fools, I assure you, seeing how the lawyer had made them take the bait), and this is the handwriting of that gentleman, and you can all easily see that he didn't write them either; in fact, the scribbles he makes can't even be called writing. Here we have some letters from...

en: The new old gentleman says:
vi: The old man interrupted:
tr: The new elderly gentleman interjected:
es: The new old man goes and says:

en: “If you please, let me explain. Nobody can read my hand but my brother there—so he copies for me. It’s his hand you’ve got there, not mine.”
vi: - I would like to offer an explanation. No one can read my handwriting, except for my younger brother. Therefore, my brother always transcribes the letters I write. The letters you are holding are all in my brother's handwriting, not mine.
tr: "If you allow me, I will explain. No one but my brother can read my handwriting... That's why he transcribes my letters. The handwriting you see in your letters is not mine but his."
es: —Please, allow me to explain it. No one can understand my handwriting, but here my brother copies the letters for me. What you are showing is his handwriting, not mine.

en: “Well!” says the lawyer, “this is a state of things. I’ve got some of William’s letters, too; so if you’ll get him to write a line or so we can com—”
vi: - In that case, - the lawyer said - I also have some letters from William here. So if you let him write a few lines, we can... .
tr: “Alright!” said the lawyer, “It sounds like a reasonable claim. I also have some of William's letters with me; if you can get him to write a few lines, we can get a definite result...”
es: —Good! —says the lawyer—. That's how things stand. I also have some of William's letters here, so if you could tell him to write a line or two, then we can compa...

en: “He can’t write with his left hand,” says the old gentleman. “If he could use his right hand, you would see that he wrote his own letters and mine too. Look at both, please—they’re by the same hand.”
vi: - My brother cannot write with his left hand. If my brother's right hand had not been broken, you would clearly see that both letters were written by the same person.
tr: “He cannot write with his left hand,” the elderly gentleman interrupted. “If he could use his right hand, you would see that he wrote both his own letters and mine. Please compare the handwriting in the letters... You will see that they are the same.”
es: —He cannot write with his left hand —says the elderly gentleman—. If he could use his right hand, you would see that he wrote his own letters and also mine. Please compare them yourself and you will see that they are written in the same handwriting.

en: The lawyer done it, and says:
vi: The lawyer looked at it and said:
tr: The lawyer compared the letters and said: “Indeed, the same person wrote it...
es: The lawyer compared them, and says:

en: “I believe it’s so—and if it ain’t so, there’s a heap stronger resemblance than I’d noticed before, anyway. Well, well, well! I thought we was right on the track of a solution, but it’s gone to grass, partly. But anyway, one thing is proved—these two ain’t either of ’em Wilkses”—and he wagged his head towards the king and the duke.
vi: - I think it's probably true, I see the two handwritings are very similar. Alright! I think we are about to reach a resolution, but some parts are still unclear. Anyway, there is one thing that can prove these two are not the Wilks brothers.
tr: Even if it's not the same person, there is an incredible similarity that I never noticed before. Yes, the matter has become a bit complicated! Actually, I thought I was making progress towards a solution, but it seems we've hit a wall again. Still, one thing is certain - these two are definitely not the Wilkses”– he indicated the king and the duke with his head.
es: —I think so, and if not, in any case, there is a much greater resemblance than I had noticed until now. Well, well, well! I thought we were on the track of a solution, but now it has disappeared, at least in part. But, in any case, there is one thing that is proven: neither of those two is a Wilks —with a nod towards the king and the duke.

en: Well, what do you think? That muleheaded old fool wouldn’t give in then! Indeed he wouldn’t. Said it warn’t no fair test. Said his brother William was the cussedest joker in the world, and hadn’t tried to write—he see William was going to play one of his jokes the minute he put the pen to paper. And so he warmed up and went warbling and warbling right along till he was actuly beginning to believe what he was saying himself; but pretty soon the new gentleman broke in, and says:
vi: As he spoke, he turned towards the king and the duke. At this point, the old man still wouldn't admit defeat. He said that William was a stubborn and playful person, that when he put pen to paper it was just one of his pranks. Then the old man rambled on for a while until he thought he was actually talking about himself.
tr: Yes, in this situation, what do you think our mule-brained old fool did? He still wouldn't give up, you say, right? Indeed, he didn't give up. He said this was an unfair test. He said his brother William was the most incorrigible jester in the world, he hadn't even tried to write properly... In fact, he had sensed that the moment a pen and paper were placed in front of William, he would make one of his jokes again. He gradually opened up and continued to babble, eventually even starting to believe what he was saying himself – but soon the new old gentleman interrupted:
es: Well, what can I tell you? The stubborn old fool wasn't willing to confess even then. Really, he wasn't. He said that the test wasn't fair. He said that his brother William spent his time joking around and hadn't tried to write, and that he was sure William was going to play one of his jokes as soon as he picked up the paper. And he kept getting more heated and talking so much that he started to believe what he was saying himself; but soon the new gentleman interrupted him, and said:

en: “I’ve thought of something. Is there anybody here that helped to lay out my br—helped to lay out the late Peter Wilks for burying?”
vi: But the other old man interrupted: - I have an idea, is there anyone here who helped with the shrouding of Mr. Peter Wilks before his burial?
tr: “I just thought of something. His brother… I mean, was there anyone among you who helped with the burial of the late Peter Wilks?”
es: —I just thought of something. Is there anyone here who helped dress my her... who helped dress the late Mr. Peter Wilks for the burial?

en: “Yes,” says somebody, “me and Ab Turner done it. We’re both here.”
vi: There was a voice speaking: - What! Ab Turner and I did that. Both of us went there.
tr: Someone said, "Yes, Ab Turner and I did it." "We are both here."
es: —Yes —someone said—, Ab Turner and I. Here we both are.

en: Then the old man turns towards the king, and says:
vi: Then the old man turned to ask the king:
tr: Upon this, the old man turned to the king and asked:
es: Then the old man turns to the king and says:

en: “Perhaps this gentleman can tell me what was tattooed on his breast?”
vi: - Could you tell me what tattoo Peter has on his chest?
tr: "Maybe this gentleman can tell us what tattoo the deceased had on his chest, what do you think?"
es: —Could this gentleman tell me what he had tattooed on his chest?

en: Blamed if the king didn’t have to brace up mighty quick, or he’d a squshed down like a bluff bank that the river has cut under, it took him so sudden; and, mind you, it was a thing that was calculated to make most anybody sqush to get fetched such a solid one as that without any notice, because how was he going to know what was tattooed on the man? He whitened a little; he couldn’t help it; and it was mighty still in there, and everybody bending a little forwards and gazing at him. Says I to myself, Now he’ll throw up the sponge—there ain’t no more use. Well, did he? A body can’t hardly believe it, but he didn’t. I reckon he thought he’d keep the thing up till he tired them people out, so they’d thin out, and him and the duke could break loose and get away. Anyway, he set there, and pretty soon he begun to smile, and says:
vi: - Could you tell me what tattoo Peter has on his chest? This time, it's really dangerous. If he doesn't answer quickly, there will be no way to escape. How could he know what tattoo was on the chest of the deceased? He turned pale for a moment, and everyone seemed to lean forward a bit, staring intently at him. He still wouldn't give in, determined to go all the way to prevent everyone from catching him off guard and escaping. He still sat there confidently, and after a while, he smiled and answered:
tr: I saw the king stagger slightly, he immediately recovered, otherwise, he would have collapsed like a piece of shore undermined by the river. He had taken the blow suddenly, and it was such a blow that whoever it struck suddenly would be flattened. How could he have known what tattoo the man had on his chest? He turned a bit pale; he couldn't help it; there wasn't a sound, and everyone was leaning forward a bit, looking at him. This time he will throw in the towel, I said to myself – he had nothing left to do. Did he surrender then? It's hard to believe, but he still didn't surrender. He was probably planning to drag the matter out until people got tired, so the crowd would thin out and he could escape with the duke. Yet he continued to sit there and finally responded with a smile:
es: Hang me if the king didn't have to react at full speed, or he would have shattered like a clod of earth falling into the river, it was so sudden; and I assure you it was something that would have shattered anyone if they had been hit like that without any warning; because, how was he to know what that man had tattooed? He paled a little; he couldn't help it; and you could have heard a fly buzz, because everyone leaned forward a bit to see what he would say. I said to myself: "Now he's going to have to throw in the towel; he has nothing left to do." Nothing to do? Ha! It's almost impossible to believe, but there he stayed. I figure his idea was to keep going with it until he tired people out so they would start leaving, and then he and the duke could flee and escape. In any case, there he stayed, and after a moment he started to smile and said:

en: “Mf! It’s a very tough question, ain’t it! Yes, sir, I k’n tell you what’s tattooed on his breast. It’s jest a small, thin, blue arrow—that’s what it is; and if you don’t look clost, you can’t see it. Now what do you say—hey?”
vi: He still sat there confidently, and after a while, he smiled and answered: - That is indeed a difficult question to answer. Yes, sir, I can tell you what tattoo was on the chest of the deceased. It was just a very small, blue arrow, which could not be seen unless looked at very closely. So, what do you think?
tr: "This is truly a difficult question, isn't it! Let me tell you what tattoo the deceased had on his chest, sir. Just a small, thin blue arrow – that's all the tattoo is; but you can't see it unless you look closely. So what do you think is on his chest... huh?"
es: —Hmm! What a difficult question! Yes, sir, I can tell you what he had tattooed on his chest. It was a small, very fine, blue arrow... That was it; and if you don't look very closely, you can't see it. And now, what do you say?

en: Well, I never see anything like that old blister for clean out-and-out cheek.
vi: I've never seen anyone as brazen as him.
tr: I had truly never seen anyone as brazen and leather-faced as this old trickster.
es: The truth is that in my life I have never seen anyone as shameless as that unscrupulous person.

en: The new old gentleman turns brisk towards Ab Turner and his pard, and his eye lights up like he judged he’d got the king this time, and says:
vi: The old man immediately turned towards Ab Turner and Ab Turner's friend, his eyes lighting up because he thought to himself that this time he had caught the king. The old man asked:
tr: The new elderly gentleman immediately turned to Ab Turner and his friend. This time, it was clear from the sparkle in his eyes that he thought he had caught the king.
es: The old man, with a fiery gaze, immediately turns towards Ab Turner and his companion, as if thinking that this time he has indeed caught the king, and then says:

en: “There—you’ve heard what he said! Was there any such mark on Peter Wilks’ breast?”
vi: - There, you all heard what that man just said! So, does Peter Wilks have such a tattoo on his chest?
tr: “So, you heard what he said!” he said. “Was there such a mark on Peter Wilks' chest?”
es: —Well, you have heard what he said! Was there such a tattoo on Peter Wilks' chest?

en: Both of them spoke up and says:
vi: Both of them answered together:
tr: Both men answered at once:
es: Both of them replied:

en: “We didn’t see no such mark.”
vi: - We did not see any such signs
tr: "We did not see such a sign."
es: —We didn't see anything like it.

en: “Good!” says the old gentleman. “Now, what you did see on his breast was a small dim P, and a B (which is an initial he dropped when he was young), and a W, with dashes between them, so: P—B—W”—and he marked them that way on a piece of paper. “Come, ain’t that what you saw?”
vi: - Very good, - The old man continued - On Peter's chest, do you see a few small letters P and B with the letter W, with dashes between the three letters, like this P - B - W? The two men said again:
tr: “Alright!” said the elderly gentleman. “On the tattoo you saw on his chest, there was a small dark-colored P and a B (these were the initials he used when he was young) and a W, with dashes in between: P – B – W” – then he made a copy of the tattoo on a piece of paper. “Look… Wasn't the tattoo you saw like this?”
es: —Good! —says the elderly gentleman—. What they did see tattooed on his chest was a small, partially erased capital P and a capital B (which is an initial he stopped using when he was young) and a capital W, with dashes between them arranged like this: P—B—W. And he wrote it on a sheet of paper. Come on, wasn't that what they saw?

en: Both of them spoke up again, and says:
vi: The two men said again:
tr: The men both answered again:
es: The other two started talking again and said:

en: “No, we didn’t. We never seen any marks at all.”
vi: - No, we didn't see anything. There were no signs at all.
tr: “No, it wasn't. We never saw these signs.”
es: —No, we didn't see it. We didn't see any tattoo at all.

en: Well, everybody was in a state of mind now, and they sings out:
vi: At that moment, everyone was confused, then they screamed:
tr: This time, everyone was confused; they started shouting:
es: Well, now everyone was in a terrible mood and they started shouting:

en: “The whole bilin’ of ’m ’s frauds! Le’s duck ’em! le’s drown ’em! le’s ride ’em on a rail!” and everybody was whooping at once, and there was a rattling powwow. But the lawyer he jumps on the table and yells, and says:
vi: - They're all just a bunch of swindlers! Throw them all into the river! But the lawyer jumped onto the table and shouted loudly:
tr: “They are all swindlers! Let's give them a good soaking! Throw them into the river and drown them, tie them to a post!” There was quite a commotion as everyone was shouting and yelling in unison. But the lawyer climbed onto the table and shouted:
es: —They are all swindlers! To the pond with them! Let's drown them! Let's run them out on a rail! —Everyone was shouting at once, with an overwhelming uproar. But the lawyer jumps onto the table and shouts:

en: “Gentlemen—gentlemen! Hear me just a word—just a single word—if you PLEASE! There’s one way yet—let’s go and dig up the corpse and look.”
vi: - Everyone, please listen to me, just one sentence, only one sentence. There is only one way left, let's go dig up the corpse and see.
tr: “Gentlemen… gentlemen! Listen to me for a moment, I will say just one thing – if you want! There is another way… Let's go and exhume the body and see.”
es: —Gentlemen... Gentlemen! Allow me a word: just one word... PLEASE! We can still see it: let's exhume the corpse to see the tattoo.

en: That took them.
vi: Everyone agreed, wanting to leave immediately, but the lawyer and the doctor spoke loudly:
tr: This is what they liked.
es: That convinced them.

en: “Hooray!” they all shouted, and was starting right off; but the lawyer and the doctor sung out:
vi: Everyone agreed, wanting to leave immediately, but the lawyer and the doctor spoke loudly:
tr: People started to leave the hall shouting "Hurrah!"; but the lawyer and the doctor stopped them:
es: —Hurray! —everyone shouted, and they set off, but the lawyer and the doctor exclaimed:

en: “Hold on, hold on! Collar all these four men and the boy, and fetch them along, too!”
vi: - Wait a minute! Grab all four people and this guy carrying the baby and take them away.
tr: “Wait a moment! First, hold these four and the boy tightly, we're taking them too!”
es: —Calm down, calm down! Grab hold of these four men and the boy so they can come too.

en: “We’ll do it!” they all shouted; “and if we don’t find them marks we’ll lynch the whole gang!”
vi: Everyone shouted: - Alright, and if we don't see those tattoos, we'll hang the whole bunch of you.
tr: “Yes, let's catch him!” shouted the crowd, “If we see that he has no tattoos, we will lynch them all at once!”
es: —That's it! —they all shouted—, and if we don't find the tattoo, we're going to lynch the whole gang.

en: I was scared, now, I tell you. But there warn’t no getting away, you know. They gripped us all, and marched us right along, straight for the graveyard, which was a mile and a half down the river, and the whole town at our heels, for we made noise enough, and it was only nine in the evening.
vi: I was so scared, I couldn't escape anymore. They grabbed us tightly and led us straight to the cemetery about a mile down by the river. The whole town followed behind, making a lot of noise. It was only nine o'clock in the evening then.
tr: That's when I really started to get scared. But there was no way to get out of this situation. They held us tightly and took us to the cemetery a mile and a half down the river. The whole town was following us, because the commotion we caused had caught everyone's attention, and it was only nine in the evening.
es: I assure you that now I was scared. But there was no way to escape. They grabbed all of us and made us go with them directly to the cemetery, which was a mile and a half downstream, and the whole town followed us because we were making a lot of noise and it was only nine at night.

en: As we went by our house I wished I hadn’t sent Mary Jane out of town; because now if I could tip her the wink she’d light out and save me, and blow on our dead-beats.
vi: When passing by the house, I thought if only I hadn't told Miss Mary Jane to go to the suburbs, she would have come to rescue me and expose those scoundrels by now.
tr: As I was passing by our house, I regretted sending Mary Jane out of town; because if I gave her a signal, she could immediately come out and save me and also expose the fraudsters.
es: As I passed by our house, I regretted having sent Mary Jane out of town, because if I could signal her now, she would come to save me and could expose our swindlers.

en: Well, we swarmed along down the river road, just carrying on like wildcats; and to make it more scary the sky was darking up, and the lightning beginning to wink and flitter, and the wind to shiver amongst the leaves. This was the most awful trouble and most dangersome I ever was in; and I was kinder stunned; everything was going so different from what I had allowed for; stead of being fixed so I could take my own time if I wanted to, and see all the fun, and have Mary Jane at my back to save me and set me free when the close-fit come, here was nothing in the world betwixt me and sudden death but just them tattoo-marks. If they didn’t find them—
vi: The whole group followed the riverbank like wild cats. The sky darkened, the wind rustled the leaves, making me extremely frightened. What if they don't find the tattoo?
tr: We were moving along the road by the river in a disorderly mob, like wild animals. As if this situation wasn't frightening enough, the sky had darkened, lightning was striking here and there, and the whistle of the wind passing through the leaves was growing stronger. I was in the most terrifying and dangerous situation I had ever experienced; I was all tangled up; things had taken a very different turn from what I had calculated. Supposedly, I was going to wander around the town as I pleased and even watch the events from the outside. After all, Mary Jane was behind me, and if I got trapped, she would rescue me. But now, there was nothing between me and sudden death except for the signs on a tattoo. If they found the tattoo, that is…
es: Well, we arrived en masse at the river road, making more noise than a bunch of wild cats, and to make it scarier, the sky was darkening and some trembling lightning bolts were starting to appear, and the wind was making the leaves shake. It was the most terrible and dangerous situation I had ever been in my life, and I felt dazed; everything was going very differently from what I had thought; instead of happening in a way that I could take my time and enjoy what was happening, with Mary Jane backing me up to save me and give me back my freedom when things got ugly, now there was nothing in the world standing between sudden death and me, except those tattoos. If they didn't find them...

en: I couldn’t bear to think about it; and yet, somehow, I couldn’t think about nothing else. It got darker and darker, and it was a beautiful time to give the crowd the slip; but that big husky had me by the wrist—Hines—and a body might as well try to give Goliar the slip. He dragged me right along, he was so excited, and I had to run to keep up.
vi: Thinking about the imminent death, I couldn't bear it. The sky was getting darker, making it very convenient to escape, but Hines held my wrist tightly. He was angry, dragging me along roughly, I had to walk faster to avoid being pulled by him.
tr: I couldn't bear to think about the matter; but still, I couldn't think of anything else. The sky grew darker and darker. If I had the chance, I would have bolted and run away, but that giant – Hines – had grabbed me by the wrist. It would probably be easier to try to escape from a giant's hand. He was practically dragging me, he was very excited; I had to run to keep up with him.
es: I couldn't bear to think about it and, yet, I don't know why I couldn't think about anything else. It was getting darker and darker and it was a great moment to escape from those people, but the strongman (Hines) had me by the wrist and it was like trying to escape from Goliath. He was practically dragging me along, he was so nervous, and to avoid falling I had to run after him.

en: When they got there they swarmed into the graveyard and washed over it like an overflow. And when they got to the grave they found they had about a hundred times as many shovels as they wanted, but nobody hadn’t thought to fetch a lantern. But they sailed into digging anyway by the flicker of the lightning, and sent a man to the nearest house, a half a mile off, to borrow one.
vi: The crowd of people swarmed to the cemetery like ants, carrying hundreds of shovels, but no one thought to bring a light. However, they kept digging by the distant glimmering lights, while one person ran to the nearest house about half a mile from the cemetery to borrow a lamp. They kept digging.
tr: When the crowd arrived at the cemetery, they poured inside and spread among the graves like a flood. Upon reaching the grave, they realized that they had brought a hundred times more shovels than needed, but no one had brought a lantern. Nevertheless, they began digging by the light of the lightning and sent someone to borrow a lantern from the nearest house half a mile away.
es: When they arrived, they entered the cemetery and filled it with a surge. And upon reaching the grave, they saw that they had a hundred times more shovels than they needed, but no one had thought to bring a lantern. But anyway, they started digging by the light of the lightning and sent someone to the nearest house, which was half a mile away, to fetch a light.

en: So they dug and dug like everything; and it got awful dark, and the rain started, and the wind swished and swushed along, and the lightning come brisker and brisker, and the thunder boomed; but them people never took no notice of it, they was so full of this business; and one minute you could see everything and every face in that big crowd, and the shovelfuls of dirt sailing up out of the grave, and the next second the dark wiped it all out, and you couldn’t see nothing at all.
vi: The sky was pitch black, the wind howled, lightning flashed continuously, and thunder roared; but they paid no attention to any of it. They were engrossed in digging, sometimes the lightning lasted for a very bright minute, allowing everything and everyone in the crowd to be seen, even the shovels full of earth being thrown up from the grave. Then after a while, the sky turned pitch black again, and nothing could be seen.
tr: While they were digging with great effort, the sky grew darker, the rain poured down, the wind started to howl, the lightning drew closer and the thunder increased; but they were not even aware of it, all of them were focused on this task; for a moment, you could see everything and every face in that large crowd, the shovelfuls of mud being thrown out of the grave, and the next moment the darkness erased everything and you could see nothing.
es: So they dug and kept digging like prisoners, and the night turned black as pitch and it started to rain and the wind whistled and roared and the lightning became clearer and clearer while the thunder drummed; but those people didn't pay any attention, so enthusiastic were they about the matter; and as soon as everything and everyone's faces in that crowd could be seen with the shovelfuls of earth coming out of the grave, the darkness erased everything the next second and nothing at all could be seen.

en: At last they got out the coffin and begun to unscrew the lid, and then such another crowding and shouldering and shoving as there was, to scrouge in and get a sight, you never see; and in the dark, that way, it was awful. Hines he hurt my wrist dreadful pulling and tugging so, and I reckon he clean forgot I was in the world, he was so excited and panting.
vi: Finally, they managed to lift the coffin and pry out the nails sealing the lid. Everyone tried to jostle each other to get a look inside. It was horrifying; Hines kept gripping my wrist and pulling me along. I thought he would forget about me there, as he was also intently watching.
tr: Finally, they reached the coffin and began to remove the lid. In the crowd, there was a new wave of squeezing, elbowing, and pushing; everyone wanted to get closer and see the coffin; we were in a terrible state in that darkness. Hines was pulling my wrist so hard that it hurt a lot; he was probably so excited and curious that he had forgotten I even existed.
es: They finally took out the coffin and began to unscrew the lid, and the crowd jostled and shoved so much to get a spot and see what was happening like I had never seen in my life, and that, in the middle of the darkness, was terrifying. Hines hurt my wrist a lot by pulling on it, and I reckon he had forgotten about my existence, as nervous and panting as he was.

en: All of a sudden the lightning let go a perfect sluice of white glare, and somebody sings out:
vi: Suddenly, a flash of lightning lit up the entire area, and there was a shout.
tr: Suddenly, a lightning bolt flashed, and everything was illuminated in bright white. Someone shouted:
es: Suddenly, the lightning illuminated everything with a white light and someone shouted:

en: “By the living jingo, here’s the bag of gold on his breast!”
vi: - Oh Lord, the money pouch is lying on the chest of this dead person!
tr: “Oh my God, look over there, the bag of gold was right here on his chest!”
es: —By the living God, there is the bag of gold, on the chest!

en: Hines let out a whoop, like everybody else, and dropped my wrist and give a big surge to bust his way in and get a look, and the way I lit out and shinned for the road in the dark there ain’t nobody can tell.
vi: Hines screamed like everyone else, suddenly grabbed my wrist and pushed quickly, squeezing into the crowd to see; I took the opportunity to slip out, ran to the street without anyone noticing.
tr: A cry of astonishment rose from Hines just like everyone else. He let go of my wrist and started pushing through the crowd to get a look; no one saw that I had immediately disappeared and was running towards the road in the dark.
es: Hines let out a howl, just like everyone else, and released my wrist while giving a shove to make his way to look, and I assure you that no one has ever been seen to shoot off like I did in search of the path in the darkness.

en: I had the road all to myself, and I fairly flew—leastways, I had it all to myself except the solid dark, and the now-and-then glares, and the buzzing of the rain, and the thrashing of the wind, and the splitting of the thunder; and sure as you are born I did clip it along!
vi: I ran like the wind on the road. At least, I felt like it was just me and the darkness, with occasional flashes of lightning, the sound of pouring rain, the howling wind, and the rumbling thunder.
tr: There was no one else on the road but me, I was practically flying – at least on the road, there was nothing but the pitch darkness, the occasional lightning illuminating everything, the patter of the rain, the howl of the wind, and the thunder; I was wildly running along the road!
es: I had the road all to myself and I practically flew; at least I had it all to myself, except for those dense darknesses and the occasional lightning and the pounding rain and the gusts of wind and the cannonade of thunder, and you can believe me when I say that I ran with all my soul!

en: When I struck the town I see there warn’t nobody out in the storm, so I never hunted for no back streets, but humped it straight through the main one; and when I begun to get towards our house I aimed my eye and set it. No light there; the house all dark—which made me feel sorry and disappointed, I didn’t know why. But at last, just as I was sailing by, flash comes the light in Mary Jane’s window! and my heart swelled up sudden, like to bust; and the same second the house and all was behind me in the dark, and wasn’t ever going to be before me no more in this world. She was the best girl I ever see, and had the most sand.
vi: Upon arriving at the town, I didn't see a single soul, so I confidently walked down the middle of the main street. As I got closer to home, I kept an eye out to see if I noticed anything. There were no lights at all, the house was pitch dark, and I felt disheartened and disappointed, not understanding why. But then, just as I passed the house, I saw a flash of light at Mary Jane's room door. My heart felt like it was going to burst. Right after that moment, the house returned to complete darkness behind me, and I saw nothing more. I thought she was truly the most resilient girl I had ever met.
tr: When I arrived in the town, I saw that no one was left on the streets because of the storm, so I didn't wander through the back streets at all; I went straight down the main street, and as I approached our house, I squinted my eyes and looked carefully. I couldn't see any light; the house was shrouded in darkness – seeing this, I felt overwhelmed with disappointment, though I didn't know why. But just as I was about to lose sight of the house, a light turned on in Mary Jane's window! Suddenly, my heart started pounding with excitement; at the same time, the house and everything else remained behind me in the darkness, and I would never see that house again in my life. Mary Jane was the best and most honest girl I had ever seen until that day.
es: When I arrived at the village, I saw that there was no one around because of the storm, so I didn't look for hidden alleys; instead, I kept running down the main street, and when I started to reach where our house was, I squinted my eyes and saw it. Not a single light; the house was completely dark, which made me feel sad and disenchanted, I don't know why. But finally, just as I was passing by, the light in Mary Jane's window suddenly turned on! And my heart started pounding as if it were going to burst, and a second later the house and everything else had been left behind in the darkness, and I would never see it again in this world. She was the best girl I have ever seen in my life, and the bravest.

en: The minute I was far enough above the town to see I could make the tow-head, I begun to look sharp for a boat to borrow, and the first time the lightning showed me one that wasn’t chained I snatched it and shoved. It was a canoe, and warn’t fastened with nothing but a rope. The tow-head was a rattling big distance off, away out there in the middle of the river, but I didn’t lose no time; and when I struck the raft at last I was so fagged I would a just laid down to blow and gasp if I could afforded it. But I didn’t. As I sprung aboard I sung out:
vi: When I had gone quite far out of town, I carefully looked to see if there was a small boat I could borrow temporarily. Just then, lightning flashed, and I saw a boat not chained but only tied with a rope. I immediately jumped down and hurriedly rowed away. Reaching the raft, I was already exhausted, just wanting to lie down and catch my breath for a moment. But as soon as I climbed up, I called out:
