tr: After advancing far enough above the town to see our little island, I started scanning the shore to find a boat to borrow; at the first flash of lightning, I saw an unchained boat; I immediately grabbed it and placed the oar. It was a canoe and was only tied with a rope. The little island was quite far, somewhere in the middle of the river, but I didn't waste any time; when I finally reached the raft, I was so exhausted that if I had time, I would have immediately lain down to catch my breath for a while. But I didn't have time. As soon as I jumped onto the raft, I called out:
es: As soon as I was far enough from the town to see that I could reach the sandbar, I started to carefully look for a boat to borrow, and the first one I saw in the light of a lightning bolt that wasn't chained, I got into it and pushed off. It was a canoe and it was only tied with a rope. The sandbar was quite far, out there in the middle of the river, but I didn't waste any time, and when I finally reached the raft I was so exhausted that if I could have, I would have stayed there lying down to catch my breath. But I couldn't. As I jumped on board, I shouted:

en: “Out with you, Jim, and set her loose! Glory be to goodness, we’re shut of them!”
vi: - Jim, come here, let's set the raft off right away! We're so lucky, we've escaped from them.
tr: "We're leaving immediately, Jim, untie the ropes!" "May God help us, I think we've escaped from them!""
es: —Get out, Jim, and cast off the lines! Thank God, we've gotten rid of them!

en: Jim lit out, and was a-coming for me with both arms spread, he was so full of joy; but when I glimpsed him in the lightning my heart shot up in my mouth and I went overboard backwards; for I forgot he was old King Lear and a drownded A-rab all in one, and it most scared the livers and lights out of me. But Jim fished me out, and was going to hug me and bless me, and so on, he was so glad I was back and we was shut of the king and the duke, but I says:
vi: Jim came out, spreading his arms wide to hug me. He was extremely happy, but when there was a flash of light, I suddenly fell silent, looked at him, and stepped back. I had forgotten that he was pretending to be the dead Arab. But Jim didn't care, he just hugged me tightly, happy for me. He was overjoyed to see that I had returned and escaped from the two swindlers. But I said:
tr: Jim suddenly appeared and approached me with open arms joyfully; but when I saw him in the lightning's flash, my heart leapt into my mouth and I stepped back and fell off the raft; because I had forgotten that he was in the guise of both the old King Lear and the drowned Arab, I was almost scared out of my wits. Luckily, Jim pulled me out of the water, he wanted to hug me and pray, he was so happy that I had returned and escaped from the king and the duke, but I stopped him:
es: Jim came running and was approaching me with open arms of joy, but when I saw him in the light of a lightning bolt, my heart jumped into my mouth and I fell into the water on my back, for I had forgotten that he was King Lear and a drowned Arab, all at the same time, and it gave me a mortal fright. But Jim pulled me out of the water and was about to hug me and bless me, and all that out of joy at seeing that I had returned and that we had gotten rid of the king and the duke, but I went and said:

en: “Not now; have it for breakfast, have it for breakfast! Cut loose and let her slide!”
vi: - Let's talk later! Untie the raft and let's go!
tr: “Jim, save all of this for the morning, save everything for the morning! Untie the rope so we can get out of here!”
es: —Not now, let's leave it for breakfast, for breakfast! Cut the moorings and let the raft slide!

en: So in two seconds away we went a-sliding down the river, and it did seem so good to be free again and all by ourselves on the big river, and nobody to bother us. I had to skip around a bit, and jump up and crack my heels a few times—I couldn’t help it; but about the third crack I noticed a sound that I knowed mighty well, and held my breath and listened and waited; and sure enough, when the next flash busted out over the water, here they come!—and just a-laying to their oars and making their skiff hum! It was the king and the duke.
vi: So, just two seconds later, we were drifting down the river, feeling happy to be free again, alone on the big river, without anyone disturbing us anymore! I had to jump up a few times and click my heels for a bit because I couldn't see. But when I clicked my heels for the third time, I heard a familiar sound. I held my breath, listened, and waited to see. Just as a flash of lightning lit up the water, I saw them sitting with oars in hand, pushing the boat forward. It was the king with the duke.
tr: Two seconds later, we had started drifting down the river; how wonderful it was to be free again, to be on our own in the vast river, and for no one to disturb us. I was so excited that I couldn't stay still; I started spinning on the raft, jumping and clicking my heels together in the air, but when I clicked my heels together for the third time, I heard a very familiar sound – I immediately held my breath and started listening – it was very clear, the next flash of lightning illuminated the surface of the water, here they were coming! – they were rowing with all their might, practically making the boat fly! The king and the duke were right behind us.
es: So in two seconds we were going down the river and the truth was that it felt good to be free again and alone on the great river without anyone bothering us. I started jumping and running around and clicking my heels in the air a few times, because I couldn't help it; but by the third time I heard a noise I knew very well, and I held my breath and listened to see what was happening, and sure enough, when the next flash of lightning burst over the water, there they were!, rowing so hard that their boat was speeding like a bullet! They were the king and the duke.

en: So I wilted right down on to the planks then, and give up; and it was all I could do to keep from crying.
vi: I collapsed onto the raft. I did so just to keep myself from bursting into tears.
tr: At that moment, my knees gave way, I collapsed onto the planks and surrendered. I made a great effort not to sob uncontrollably.
es: So I collapsed in a heap among the trunks and gave up on everything; I had to hold back a lot to keep from bursting into tears.

en: CHAPTER XXX.
vi: Chapter XXX
tr: Thirtieth Chapter
es: Chapter 30

en: When they got aboard the king went for me, and shook me by the collar, and says:
vi: As soon as he got onto the raft, the king immediately came to me, grabbed my collar, and asked:
tr: When they left the room, the king immediately grabbed my throat and started shaking me:
es: WHEN THEY GOT on board, the king threw himself at me, grabbed me by the collar of my shirt, and said:

en: “Tryin’ to give us the slip, was ye, you pup! Tired of our company, hey?”
vi: - Are you planning to abandon us, child? Are you tired of us already?
tr: “So you were trying to get rid of us, you son of a dog! Were you getting tired of us, huh?”
es: —So, trying to escape, little boy! You had gotten tired of us, hadn't you?

en: I says:
vi: I replied:
tr: "No; your majesty," I said.
es: And I replied:

en: “No, your majesty, we warn’t—please don’t, your majesty!”
vi: - Yes, sir, no. I beg you, sir
tr: "We are not bored with you... Please don't do it, your majesty!"
es: —No, Your Majesty, it is not like that... Please, stop, Your Majesty!

en: “Quick, then, and tell us what was your idea, or I’ll shake the insides out o’ you!”
vi: - So, what are you planning to do? Speak quickly, or I'll skin you right now.
tr: “Then what was on your mind, quickly tell me, or I'll rip your liver out!”
es: —Then, quickly tell us what you were planning to do, or I'll rip your guts out piece by piece!

en: “Honest, I’ll tell you everything just as it happened, your majesty. The man that had a-holt of me was very good to me, and kept saying he had a boy about as big as me that died last year, and he was sorry to see a boy in such a dangerous fix; and when they was all took by surprise by finding the gold, and made a rush for the coffin, he lets go of me and whispers, ‘Heel it now, or they’ll hang ye, sure!’ and I lit out. It didn’t seem no good for me to stay—I couldn’t do nothing, and I didn’t want to be hung if I could get away. So I never stopped running till I found the canoe; and when I got here I told Jim to hurry, or they’d catch me and hang me yet, and said I was afeard you and the duke wasn’t alive now, and I was awful sorry, and so was Jim, and was awful glad when we see you coming; you may ask Jim if I didn’t.”
vi: - I will tell you everything that happened. The man who held my hand, he was very kind, saying that he also had a child as old as me who died last year, so when he saw me in danger, he felt compassion. When everyone was clamoring because they saw the money bundle in the coffin, he let go of my hand and whispered: "Run, or they'll hang you." So I ran. I couldn't do anything else. I just kept running until I found the boat, then went to the raft and told Jim to get away quickly or they'd catch me and hang me. I kept worrying about you and the duke, and so did Jim. Ask Jim if it's true.
tr: “Alright, alright, I will tell you everything as it is, honestly, your majesty. The man who held me treated me very well, he kept saying that he had a son around my age but he died last year, he was very upset to see a child in such a dangerous situation; when the gold was found and everyone rushed towards the coffin, he let me go and whispered: “Run away now, or they will definitely hang you!” So I ran away. There was no point in staying there – I couldn’t do anything and I didn’t want to stay and get hanged when I could escape. So I ran until I found a canoe; when I got here, I told Jim to hurry, otherwise they would catch and hang me, I told him that you and the duke were no longer alive, I was very upset, Jim was upset too, when we saw you coming, we were so happy that we didn’t know what to do, if you don’t believe me, ask Jim.”
es: —Honestly, I am going to tell you exactly what happened, Your Majesty. The man who was holding me was very kind to me and kept saying that he had a son my age who had died last year and that it was very sad for him to see a boy in such a dangerous situation, and when they were surprised to find the gold and rushed towards the coffin, he let me go and said: "Run away, or they will surely hang you," and I took off. It didn't seem to make any sense to stay... I couldn't do anything and I didn't want to be hanged if I could avoid it. So I didn't stop running until I found the canoe, and when I got here I told Jim to hurry or they might still come to catch and hang me, and I said that I feared the duke and you might no longer be alive and I got very sad, just like Jim; that's why I was so happy to see you arrive; ask Jim if it's not true.

en: Jim said it was so; and the king told him to shut up, and said, “Oh, yes, it’s mighty likely!” and shook me up again, and said he reckoned he’d drownd me. But the duke says:
vi: Jim also said the same thing. The king shouted at Jim and then grabbed my neck, threatening to drown me in the river. But the duke intervened.
tr: Jim confirmed me too, but the king told him to shut up and turned back to me: "Of course, I believed it too!" Then he started shaking me again and said the best thing would be to strangle me. But the duke intervened:
es: Jim said that it was so, and the king told him to shut his mouth and added: "Ah, yes, sure!", and he shook me again and said that he was thinking of drowning me. But the duke goes and says:

en: “Leggo the boy, you old idiot! Would you a done any different? Did you inquire around for him when you got loose? I don’t remember it.”
vi: - Let the boy go! I ask you, when you escaped, did you think about him? Probably not.
tr: "Leave the child, you old fool! Would you have acted any differently? Did you check where he was when he was free? I don't remember at all."
es: —Let go of the boy, you old fool! Would you have done anything different? Did you ask about him when you left? I don't remember that.

en: So the king let go of me, and begun to cuss that town and everybody in it. But the duke says:
vi: The king released me, then cursed the town and everyone in it. But the duke said:
tr: The king left me and started cursing the town and everyone in it. But the duke opposed again:
es: So the king let me go and started cursing that town and all its inhabitants. But the duke goes and says: —You'd better curse yourself because you deserve it the most.

en: “You better a blame sight give yourself a good cussing, for you’re the one that’s entitled to it most. You hain’t done a thing from the start that had any sense in it, except coming out so cool and cheeky with that imaginary blue-arrow mark. That was bright—it was right down bully; and it was the thing that saved us. For if it hadn’t been for that, they’d a jailed us till them Englishmen’s baggage come—and then—the penitentiary, you bet! But that trick took ’em to the graveyard, and the gold done us a still bigger kindness; for if the excited fools hadn’t let go all holts and made that rush to get a look, we’d a slept in our cravats to-night—cravats warranted to wear, too—longer than we’d need ’em.”
vi: - You should curse yourself instead, because you are the one most deserving of curses. From beginning to end, you haven't accomplished anything worthwhile, except for calmly thinking of the green arrow on the chest of the dead person. If not, they would have detained us, waiting for the Englishmen's luggage to arrive, and then we would be in jail! After that, the bundle of money saved us once again. If those madmen hadn't stormed off, tonight you and I would be tying our ties and sleeping forever.
tr: “You should actually curse yourself, because you are the one who deserves the curse the most. From the beginning, you did nothing that made any sense; your only useful move was fabricating that imaginary blue arrow sign with cold-bloodedness and brazenness. It was a brilliant idea – truly wonderful; it was what saved us. Otherwise, they would have locked us up somewhere until the Englishman's belongings arrived, and then we would have ended up in jail! We would have stayed there for life, God knows. But thanks to that trick, they went all the way to the cemetery, and the bag of gold did us an even greater favor; because if those fools hadn't left us in their excitement and rushed towards the grave, we would be sleeping with our neckties on tonight – the mandatory ones – and we would have worn them for much longer than we needed to.”
es: But the duke goes and says: —You'd better curse yourself because you deserve it the most. From the beginning, you haven't done a single sensible thing, except when you calmly made up that story about the blue arrow tattoo. That was really good; it was phenomenal. And it was what saved us. Because if it hadn't been for that, they would have put us in jail until the Englishmen's luggage arrived, and then, I bet from there to the penitentiary! But that trick made them go to the cemetery and the gold thing worked out even better for us, because if they hadn't gotten so nervous and let us go when they rushed to see what was there, tonight we would have slept with ties on, and ties that last forever, which is more than we wanted.

en: They was still a minute—thinking; then the king says, kind of absent-minded like:
vi: They were silent for a moment, then the king said absentmindedly:
tr: They paused for a moment and thought, then the king said absentmindedly:
es: They remained silent for a moment, thinking; then the king goes and says, as if remembering something:

en: “Mf! And we reckoned the niggers stole it!”
vi: - And yet, I mistakenly thought that the black people were stealing.
tr: “We thought the gold was stolen by the blacks!”
es: —Wow! And we thought it had been stolen by the black people!

en: That made me squirm!
vi: I was startled.
tr: I shuddered when I heard this!
es: I got extremely nervous!

en: “Yes,” says the duke, kinder slow and deliberate and sarcastic, “We did.”
vi: The Duke said bitterly: - Yes, I thought so too.
tr: “Yes, indeed,” said the duke, slowly, with a meaningful and mocking tone. “That's what we thought.”
es: —Yes —says the duke, slowly and sarcastically—, that's what we thought.

en: After about a half a minute the king drawls out:
vi: About half a minute later, the king spoke again:
tr: After thinking for about half a minute, the king spoke again:
es: After half a minute, the king blurts out:

en: “Leastways, I did.”
vi: - at least, that's what I think.
tr: “At least… that's what I thought.”
es: —At least, that's what I thought.

en: The duke says, the same way:
vi: The Duke spoke, in the same tone as the king:
tr: The Duke replied in the same manner:
es: The duke says, in the same tone:

en: “On the contrary, I did.”
vi: - I thought so too.
tr: “On the contrary… I thought so.”
es: —On the contrary, I was thinking it.

en: The king kind of ruffles up, and says:
vi: The king seemed to snap:
tr: The king suddenly straightened up:
es: The king gets irritated and says:

en: “Looky here, Bilgewater, what’r you referrin’ to?”
vi: - Hey, Bilgewater, what do you think that means?
tr: “Look at me, Bridgewater, what do you mean?”
es: —Look, Aguassucias, what do you mean?

en: The duke says, pretty brisk:
vi: The Duke replied irritably:
tr: The Duke immediately retorted:
es: And the duke replies, very firmly:

en: “When it comes to that, maybe you’ll let me ask, what was you referring to?”
vi: - So what are you trying to say?
tr: "Actually, I should be the one asking this, what did you mean?"
es: —If we get into that, perhaps you'll allow me to ask what you were referring to.

en: “Shucks!” says the king, very sarcastic; “but I don’t know—maybe you was asleep, and didn’t know what you was about.”
vi: The king sarcastically said: - Perhaps at that moment you were still drowsy and didn't know what you were supposed to be doing.
tr: "For God's sake!" said the king mockingly; "I have no idea... Maybe you are a sleepwalker and were not aware of what you were doing."
es: —Gosh! —says the king, very sarcastically—, well I don't know: maybe you were asleep and didn't know what you were doing.

en: The duke bristles up now, and says:
vi: The Duke jumped up:
tr: The Duke suddenly fumed:
es: Then the duke got really angry and replied:

en: “Oh, let up on this cussed nonsense; do you take me for a blame’ fool? Don’t you reckon I know who hid that money in that coffin?”
vi: - Oh, do you think I'm crazy? Do you think I don't know who hid the money in that coffin?
tr: “Keep your damn nonsense to yourself; do you think I'm a fool? Do you think I don't know who hid the money in the coffin?”
es: —Well, enough of this nonsense. Do you take me for a fool? Do you think I don't know who hid the money in the coffin?

en: “Yes, sir! I know you do know, because you done it yourself!”
vi: - Of course you know because you hid it there yourself - Nonsense!
tr: “Yes, sir! I am aware that you know, because you are the one hiding the money!”
es: —Yes, sir! I know you know it because you did it yourself! —Lies!

en: “It’s a lie!”—and the duke went for him. The king sings out:
vi: The Duke charged forward. The King cried out:
tr: “A blatant lie!” The Duke suddenly lunged at him. The King began to shout:
es: —and the duke lunges at him. The king shouts:

en: “Take y’r hands off!—leggo my throat!—I take it all back!”
vi: - Let go of me! Don't choke me like that. I can't speak anymore.
tr: "Get your hands off me!.. Stop choking me!.. I take back everything I said!"
es: —Take those hands off! Let go of my neck! I take it all back!

en: The duke says:
vi: The Duke said:
tr: “First, admit your crime,” said the duke.
es: The duke goes and says:

en: “Well, you just own up, first, that you did hide that money there, intending to give me the slip one of these days, and come back and dig it up, and have it all to yourself.”
vi: - It was you who kept the money, then you yourself buried it there, planning to dig it up alone when the opportunity arose.
tr: “Say that you hid the money there, planned to leave me after a few days, return, and dig up the money.”
es: —Well, first you have to confess that you hid that money, and that you were planning to leave me one of these days and come back to dig it up and keep it all for yourself.

en: “Wait jest a minute, duke—answer me this one question, honest and fair; if you didn’t put the money there, say it, and I’ll b’lieve you, and take back everything I said.”
vi: - Wait, Duke, please answer me this question honestly. If you hid the money there, just say so, I will believe you and forget everything that happened until now.
tr: “Wait a moment, Duke… Just answer one question honestly; if you didn't put the money there, tell me, and I will believe you and take back everything I said.”
es: —Man, one minute, duke: answer this question, with all sincerity: if you didn't put the money there, say so and I will believe you and take back everything I've said.

en: “You old scoundrel, I didn’t, and you know I didn’t. There, now!”
vi: - Old man, I'm not hiding, there's no way I would do that.
tr: “You old swindler, of course I didn't put it, and you know it very well. Got it?”
es: —You old scoundrel, it wasn't me and you know it. Let that be clear!

en: “Well, then, I b’lieve you. But answer me only jest this one more—now don’t git mad; didn’t you have it in your mind to hook the money and hide it?”
vi: - Alright, I believe you. But answer me one more question, deep down, did you ever think about taking the money and the papers away?
tr: “Okay, I believe you too. But answer one more question for me… but answer without getting angry; did it never cross your mind to take the money and hide it?”
es: —Well, then I believe you. But answer me just one more thing, and don't get angry. Didn't it occur to you to take the money and hide it?

en: The duke never said nothing for a little bit; then he says:
vi: The duke said nothing, and only after a while did he respond:
tr: The Duke couldn't respond for a while; then he said:
es: The duke remained silent for a moment and replied:

en: “Well, I don’t care if I did, I didn’t do it, anyway. But you not only had it in mind to do it, but you done it.”
vi: - If you think that way, it's okay. As for you, not only do you think that way, but you also act that way.
tr: “Even if I thought about it, it doesn't matter, I didn't do it in the end. But you didn't just think about it, you did it too.”
es: —Well, it doesn't matter whether I thought of it or not, because in any case, I didn't do it. But you not only thought of it, but you did it.

en: “I wisht I never die if I done it, duke, and that’s honest. I won’t say I warn’t goin’ to do it, because I was; but you—I mean somebody—got in ahead o’ me.”
vi: - I swear, if I do that, I will die immediately. I did think about it, but you or someone else already did it before me.
tr: “If I did it, may I never breathe again, duke, I am telling the truth. I am not saying I didn't think about doing it, because I did; but you…I mean someone else… Acted before me.”
es: —May I die if it was me, duke, and I tell you the truth. I'm not saying I wouldn't have done it, because that would be a lie, but you —or whoever it was— beat me to it.

en: “It’s a lie! You done it, and you got to say you done it, or—”
vi: I did think about it, but you or someone else already did it before me. - Hmph, it was you who stole, you must confess.
tr: “You're lying again! You did it and you will admit it, or else…”
es: —Liar! It was you and you have to say it or...

en: The king began to gurgle, and then he gasps out:
vi: The king stammered and then sighed:
tr: The king had started to make wheezing sounds, finally he spoke breathlessly:
es: The king began to gurgle and then gasped:

en: “’Nough!—I own up!”
vi: - Yes, then I'll take it.
tr: “Alright!.. I did it!”
es: —Enough! I confess!

en: I was very glad to hear him say that; it made me feel much more easier than what I was feeling before. So the duke took his hands off and says:
vi: I was overjoyed when I heard the king say that. The duke let go of the old man and said:
tr: Hearing him say this had made me very happy; I felt much lighter compared to before. Thus, the duke withdrew his hands and said:
es: I was very happy when he said it; it made me feel much calmer than before. So the duke took his hands off him and says:

en: “If you ever deny it again I’ll drown you. It’s well for you to set there and blubber like a baby—it’s fitten for you, after the way you’ve acted. I never see such an old ostrich for wanting to gobble everything—and I a-trusting you all the time, like you was my own father. You ought to been ashamed of yourself to stand by and hear it saddled on to a lot of poor niggers, and you never say a word for ’em. It makes me feel ridiculous to think I was soft enough to believe that rubbage. Cuss you, I can see now why you was so anxious to make up the deffisit—you wanted to get what money I’d got out of the Nonesuch and one thing or another, and scoop it all!”
vi: - If you keep denying it, I'll drown you. Now, you're still sitting there crying like a child! I've never met an old man as greedy as you. Yet, I always trusted you like my own father. You should be ashamed when you see innocent black people being blamed. Honestly, I was foolish to believe in those tricks. Now I understand that you made up the story about missing money so that I would give up the money I earned from the play, and you could take it all.
tr: “If you deny your crime again, I will drown you in the water. You deserve to sit here and cry like a baby... After what you've done, this is too little for you. I've never seen an old ostrich like you who is out to devour everything – yet I always trusted you, I considered you like my own father. If I were in your place, I would wish the ground would swallow me up. You are so cruel that you wouldn't object to blaming your crime on poor black people. The foolishness is on me for being naive enough to believe your nonsense. Damn you, now I understand why you were so eager to cover it up... You had your eyes on the money I earned from Curcuna and other jobs, you were after taking it all!”
es: —If you deny it again, I'll drown you. It's very well that you stay there sitting and crying like a child. It's what you deserve after what you've done. In my life, I've never seen even an ostrich swallow everything, and I trusted you all the time, as if you were my own father. You should be ashamed of yourself for staying there and hearing how they blamed a bunch of poor black people, without saying a word for them. I feel ridiculous remembering that I was such an idiot to believe that stupidity. Damn you, now I understand why you were so willing to fix the deficit: you wanted to keep the money that I had taken from the "unparalleled" and with one thing and another, keep everything.

en: The king says, timid, and still a-snuffling:
vi: The king sniffled and replied:
tr: The king, still sniffling, began to speak hesitantly: "But it was you who suggested making up the deficiency, duke, not me."
es: The king goes and says, all timid and still with a breathless voice:

en: “Why, duke, it was you that said make up the deffisit; it warn’t me.”
vi: - It was you who came up with that idea of covering the cost, not me.
tr: The king, still sniffling, began to speak hesitantly: "But it was you who suggested making up the deficiency, duke, not me."
es: —But, Duke, it was you who mentioned compensating for the deficit, not me.

en: “Dry up! I don’t want to hear no more out of you!” says the duke. “And now you see what you got by it. They’ve got all their own money back, and all of ourn but a shekel or two besides. G’long to bed, and don’t you deffersit me no more deffersits, long ’s you live!”
vi: - Shut up. I don't want to hear you talk anymore! Now you see the result. They have gotten back all their money and even more from us. Now go to sleep. As long as you are alive, don't do anything that harms my money anymore!
tr: “Shut up! I don't want to hear you talk anymore!” said the duke. “Do you see what you've achieved now? Not only did they take back all their money, but they also seized our meager possessions. Go to bed now...
es: —Shut up! I don't want to hear a single word from you! —says the duke—. And now look at what you've done. They've recovered all the money, and on top of that, ours too, except for a few pennies. Go to sleep and don't ever talk to me about deficit or no deficit in your entire life!

en: So the king sneaked into the wigwam and took to his bottle for comfort, and before long the duke tackled his bottle; and so in about a half an hour they was as thick as thieves again, and the tighter they got, the lovinger they got, and went off a-snoring in each other’s arms. They both got powerful mellow, but I noticed the king didn’t get mellow enough to forget to remember to not deny about hiding the money-bag again. That made me feel easy and satisfied. Of course when they got to snoring we had a long gabble, and I told Jim everything.
vi: So the king crawled into the tent, grabbed a bottle of wine, and took a swig. Then the duke also grabbed another bottle. About half an hour later, the two scoundrels were friendly with each other again as usual, hugging each other to sleep, snoring loudly. Both of them calmed down, but I noticed that the king wasn't quite at ease yet about not being able to deny hiding the bundle of money. That made me very pleased. We waited until they were snoring loudly, then we sat down and talked to each other, and I recounted the entire story to Jim.
tr: And don't ever talk to me about making up for anything ever again in your life!” The king quietly took the bottle of liquor and went into the shelter; soon after, the duke also started drinking from his own bottle; about half an hour later, they were on good terms again, even their bonds had strengthened and become more affectionate; they fell asleep in each other's arms and started snoring. Both of them seemed to be in high spirits, but the king didn't get drunk enough to deny hiding the money bag again. This made me feel more at ease and happy. When they started snoring, Jim and I, of course, talked for a long time, and I told him everything.
es: So the king went back to the wigwam and sought company in his bottle, and shortly after the duke started on his, and after about half an hour they were friends again, and the more friendly they got, the more affectionate they became, until they ended up snoring, embraced with each other. The two became very talkative, but I saw that the king wasn't so far gone as to forget that he shouldn't repeat that he wasn't the one who had hidden the bag with the money. That made me feel calm and satisfied. Naturally, when they started snoring, we talked for a long time and I told Jim everything.

en: CHAPTER XXXI.
vi: Chapter XXXI
tr: Chapter Thirty-One
es: Chapter 31

en: We dasn’t stop again at any town for days and days; kept right along down the river. We was down south in the warm weather now, and a mighty long ways from home. We begun to come to trees with Spanish moss on them, hanging down from the limbs like long, gray beards. It was the first I ever see it growing, and it made the woods look solemn and dismal. So now the frauds reckoned they was out of danger, and they begun to work the villages again.
vi: For many days after that, we didn't dare stop in any town, but kept going straight ahead. We headed south, where the climate was warm and it was also quite far from home. The trees were dense, with vines hanging from large branches, looking like long gray nets. It was the first time I saw those trees, and it seemed to make the forest even more solemn and sorrowful. By this point, the two swindlers thought the danger was over, so they went into the villages to scavenge again.
tr: We did not stop in the towns for days again, we went down the river without stopping. We had now moved well south, the weather had warmed up, and we were far from home. We had started to see trees covered with Spanish moss, the moss hanging from the branches like long gray beards. I was seeing this moss for the first time, it had given the forest a very solemn and gloomy atmosphere. Our swindlers, thinking they were now far enough from danger, started doing business in the towns again.
es: FOR DAYS AND DAYS we did not dare to stop in any other town, but continued down the river. We had already reached the South, where it was hot and we were very far from home. We began to find trees full of black moss, which hung from the branches like large gray beards. It was the first time I had seen them, and it gave the forest a solemn and sad appearance. The scoundrels figured they were out of danger and started working in the towns again.

en: First they done a lecture on temperance; but they didn’t make enough for them both to get drunk on. Then in another village they started a dancing-school; but they didn’t know no more how to dance than a kangaroo does; so the first prance they made the general public jumped in and pranced them out of town. Another time they tried to go at yellocution; but they didn’t yellocute long till the audience got up and give them a solid good cussing, and made them skip out. They tackled missionarying, and mesmerizing, and doctoring, and telling fortunes, and a little of everything; but they couldn’t seem to have no luck. So at last they got just about dead broke, and laid around the raft as she floated along, thinking and thinking, and never saying nothing, by the half a day at a time, and dreadful blue and desperate.
vi: At first, they talked about alcohol addiction, but they couldn't even make enough money to buy alcohol for themselves to drink. When they reached another village, they opened a dance class, but they only danced like kangaroos, so the public just joined in and chased them away immediately. Another time, they tried to give a speech, but after just a few sentences, the audience stood up and cursed them out, then kicked them out. They also tried preaching, hypnosis, healing, and fortune-telling, each a little bit, but it seemed like all these attempts were unlucky. In the end, they were so bored that they lay on the raft for half a day without saying a word, looking very sad and disappointed.
tr: First, they organized a meeting against alcohol, but they didn't even get enough money to get drunk. They established a dance school in another town; but they knew less about dancing than kangaroos; so the moment they started jumping around awkwardly, the townspeople intervened and chased them out of town. Then they started a public speaking course, but since they couldn't speak very well, the audience cursed and chased them away. They tried missionary work, spiritualism, medicine, and fortune-telling; they did everything a little bit, but it seemed their luck had run out. Finally, they were left penniless, lying on a raft slowly drifting down the river, spending half the day thinking without speaking, looking terribly unhappy and hopeless.
es: First, they gave a lecture on temperance; but they didn't make enough to get the two of them drunk. Then, in another town, they opened a dance school, but they danced worse than a kangaroo, so at the first pirouette the audience turned on them and expelled them from the town. Another time they tried to give elocution lessons, but they didn't "elocute" much, because the audience got up and started cursing them and made them leave. They tried being missionaries, hypnotists, doctors, fortune-tellers, and a bit of everything, but it seemed they had no luck. So, finally, they were practically out of money and did nothing but lie on the raft as it floated downstream, thinking and thinking, without saying a word all day, very sad and desperate.

en: And at last they took a change and begun to lay their heads together in the wigwam and talk low and confidential two or three hours at a time. Jim and me got uneasy. We didn’t like the look of it. We judged they was studying up some kind of worse deviltry than ever. We turned it over and over, and at last we made up our minds they was going to break into somebody’s house or store, or was going into the counterfeit-money business, or something. So then we was pretty scared, and made up an agreement that we wouldn’t have nothing in the world to do with such actions, and if we ever got the least show we would give them the cold shake and clear out and leave them behind. Well, early one morning we hid the raft in a good, safe place about two mile below a little bit of a shabby village named Pikesville, and the king he went ashore and told us all to stay hid whilst he went up to town and smelt around to see if anybody had got any wind of the Royal Nonesuch there yet. (“House to rob, you mean,” says I to myself; “and when you get through robbing it you’ll come back here and wonder what has become of me and Jim and the raft—and you’ll have to take it out in wondering.”) And he said if he warn’t back by midday the duke and me would know it was all right, and we was to come along.
vi: In the end, they huddled together and discussed something for two or three hours, looking very secretive. Jim and I were worried, surely they were plotting something nefarious again. After thinking for a while, we guessed that they were planning to break into a house or a shop, or perhaps they were about to counterfeit money. So we got really scared and agreed that we would definitely not get involved in their actions, and if possible, we would run away immediately. One early morning, we hid the raft in a safe place, two miles away from a shabby village named Pikesville. The Duke went ashore, instructing us to hide and wait for him to go to town to see if there was any gossip about the Royal Nonesuch performance. He said that if he didn't return by noon, the Duke and I would follow him.
tr: After a while, things started to change; every day, they would huddle together in the shelter for two or three hours, whispering secretly. Jim and I were on edge. Their intentions didn't seem very good. We thought they were making a more diabolical plan than ever. After talking amongst ourselves many times, we decided that they were either going to rob someone's house or shop, or maybe even print counterfeit money. We were both scared of this, and we swore that we would never get involved in such crimes, even if it killed us; at the first opportunity, we would get rid of them and immediately escape, leaving them behind. In the morning, we hid our raft in a safe place about two miles down from a rundown town called Pikesville; the king went ashore and told us to hide until he scouted the town to see if there was any news of the Royal Nonesuch here. ("That means until you find a house to rob," I muttered; "then you'll come back here after robbing the house, and when you don't see anyone, you'll wonder what happened to me, Jim, and the raft... wonder all you want.") The king also said that if he didn't return by noon, the duke and I should understand that everything was fine and go into town.
es: Finally, they started to change and began talking in the wigwam in a low and confidential tone for two or three hours straight. Jim and I got nervous. We didn't like it. We thought they were planning something worse than before. We talked about it many times and finally decided that they were going to rob someone's house or store, or that they were planning to counterfeit money, or something similar. Then we got really scared and decided that we wouldn't have anything to do with it, and that if the slightest opportunity arose, we would sneak away and abandon them. Well, one early morning we hid the raft in a good, safe spot, about two miles below a village called Pikesville, and the king went ashore and told us all to stay hidden while he went to town to see if anyone had found out about "The Royal Nonesuch" ("a house to rob, that's what you mean," I said to myself, "and when you're done robbing it, you're going to come back and wonder what happened to me and Jim and the raft, and you can wait for us sitting down"). And he said that if he didn't come back by noon, the duke and I would know that everything was fine and we should meet up with him.

en: So we stayed where we was. The duke he fretted and sweated around, and was in a mighty sour way. He scolded us for everything, and we couldn’t seem to do nothing right; he found fault with every little thing. Something was a-brewing, sure. I was good and glad when midday come and no king; we could have a change, anyway—and maybe a chance for the change on top of it. So me and the duke went up to the village, and hunted around there for the king, and by-and-by we found him in the back room of a little low doggery, very tight, and a lot of loafers bullyragging him for sport, and he a-cussing and a-threatening with all his might, and so tight he couldn’t walk, and couldn’t do nothing to them. The duke he begun to abuse him for an old fool, and the king begun to sass back, and the minute they was fairly at it I lit out and shook the reefs out of my hind legs, and spun down the river road like a deer, for I see our chance; and I made up my mind that it would be a long day before they ever see me and Jim again. I got down there all out of breath but loaded up with joy, and sung out:
vi: The duke seemed restless and irritable. He scolded us over the smallest things. Surely something is about to happen. I was very glad that by noon the king had not returned. So, the duke and I went ashore and into the village to find the king. A while later, we saw him behind a fishing boat, being pushed into a cramped house, and being taunted by a gang of ruffians... He was cursing loudly and threatening those people. When the duke arrived and saw this, he said that it was just a crazy old man. The king scolded the duke back. Taking advantage of their fierce argument, I slipped away, running like the wind down the riverside road. I ran to the hidden raft, out of breath, but feeling very happy inside. I called out:
tr: Thus, we continued to wait where we were. The duke was wandering around restlessly and kept making faces. He was scolding us for everything, as if he thought we couldn't do anything right; he found fault in even the smallest things. We had no doubt that something was going on. By noon, when the king didn't come, I was very happy; at least there would be a change – maybe we could find an opportunity to make the real change we had in mind. So, we went to town with the duke and started looking for the king. After a while, we found him in the back room of a filthy tavern, dead drunk and in trouble with a few idle men; he was cursing at the top of his lungs and threatening them, but he was so drunk that he couldn't even get up and do anything to them. The duke also taunted him, calling him an old fool, and the king retorted; suddenly, they started fighting! I immediately ran outside and started running as fast as I could, skipping along the river path like a deer – because we had found the chance we were looking for, and I was determined to do what was necessary so they would never see me and Jim again. I reached the raft's location, out of breath but filled with joy, and called out:
es: So we stayed where we were. The duke was nervous, sweaty, and in a terrible mood. He scolded us for everything and nothing we did seemed right to him; he found everything wrong. Of course, they were preparing something. I was very glad when noon came and the king hadn't returned; now things were going to change, and maybe an opportunity would present itself. So the duke and I went to town and started looking for the king; after a while, we found him in the back room of a seedy tavern, half-drunk, with a bunch of drunks who were provoking him for fun while he cursed and threatened them with all his might, so drunk that he couldn't walk or do anything to them. The duke was mocking him for being an old fool and the king responded, so as soon as I saw things heating up, I took off at full speed and ran down the river road like a deer, because I had seen our opportunity and decided that they could wait forever before seeing Jim and me again. I arrived breathless but very happy and shouted:

en: “Set her loose, Jim! we’re all right now!”
vi: - Jim, let's release the raft, we're free now.
tr: “Untie it, Jim, we can go now!”
es: —Cast off the moorings, Jim; everything is set!

en: But there warn’t no answer, and nobody come out of the wigwam. Jim was gone! I set up a shout—and then another—and then another one; and run this way and that in the woods, whooping and screeching; but it warn’t no use—old Jim was gone. Then I set down and cried; I couldn’t help it. But I couldn’t set still long. Pretty soon I went out on the road, trying to think what I better do, and I run across a boy walking, and asked him if he’d seen a strange nigger dressed so and so, and he says:
vi: But there was no answer, and no one came out of the tent. Jim was gone! I called out loudly once, then again - and again; ran in all directions into the forest, howling, shouting, but it was useless - Jim was lost. I sat down and sobbed uncontrollably. After a while, I returned to the main road, thinking about what to do next. Suddenly, I saw a boy coming from somewhere, and I asked if he had seen a black man dressed like that. He replied:
tr: But there was no answer, and no one came out of the shelter. Jim was not there! I called out in case he could hear… I called again, and then again; I ran frantically back and forth in the forest, but it was no use – our Jim had disappeared. I sat down and started to cry, I couldn't help it. But I couldn't sit for long. After a while, I set off thinking about what I could do, and on the way, I came across a boy and asked him if he had seen a strange-looking black man dressed like this and that.
es: But no one answered me nor came out of the wigwam. Jim had disappeared! I shouted once, then again and again, and started running through the forest up and down, shouting and yelling, but it was all for nothing: Jim had disappeared. Then I sat down and started to cry; I couldn't help it. But I couldn't stay sitting for long. After a while, I went back to the path trying to think about what I should do, and I met a boy who was walking by and asked him if he had seen a strange black man dressed in such and such a way, and he goes and says:

en: “Yes.”
vi: - Yes
tr: “I found it,” he said.
es: —Yes.

en: “Whereabouts?” says I.
vi: - So where is he? I asked:
tr: "Where?" I asked.
es: —Where? —I asked.

en: “Down to Silas Phelps’ place, two mile below here. He’s a runaway nigger, and they’ve got him. Was you looking for him?”
vi: - At Mr. Silas Phelps' house, two miles from here. He is a runaway black man; they caught him. Are you looking for him?
tr: “Two miles down, at Silas Phelps' place. There was a runaway negro, they caught him. Were you looking for that negro too?”
es: —By Silas Phelps' house, two miles down. He's a runaway slave and they've caught him. Were you looking for him?

en: “You bet I ain’t! I run across him in the woods about an hour or two ago, and he said if I hollered he’d cut my livers out—and told me to lay down and stay where I was; and I done it. Been there ever since; afeard to come out.”
vi: - No, I didn't find it. I met it in the forest two hours ago. It said if I made a sound, it would cut open my stomach, take out my liver, and make me lie down and stay still there. I had to lie down. Since then, I've been in the forest, too scared to come out. The boy said:
tr: “What do you mean, search for him, brother! A couple of hours ago, I ran into him in the forest, and he said if I made a sound, he would rip my lungs out. ‘Sit down where you are and don't move an inch,’ he said; so I did. I've been waiting since then, too scared to come out.”
es: —Absolutely! I found him in the forest one or two hours ago and he told me that if I screamed, he would rip out my guts and that I should stay still, where I was, which is what I did. I've been there since then because I was scared to leave.

en: “Well,” he says, “you needn’t be afeard no more, becuz they’ve got him. He run off f’m down South, som’ers.”
vi: - Well, now you don't have to be afraid anymore, they have already caught it. It seems like it ran towards the South.
tr: “You don't need to be afraid anymore, because it can't do anything to you,” he said. “It escaped from somewhere in the South.”
es: —Well —he goes and says—, you don't have to be afraid anymore because they've caught him. He escaped from I don't know where in the South.

en: “It’s a good job they got him.”
vi: - It's fortunate that it has been caught.
tr: “They've done a good job catching him, indeed.”
es: —It's a good thing they caught him.

en: “Well, I reckon! There’s two hunderd dollars reward on him. It’s like picking up money out’n the road.”
vi: - Getting a two hundred dollar reward, that's pretty sweet.
tr: "I think so too!" "A two hundred dollar bounty has been placed on his head." "It's like finding money on the street."
es: —Man, absolutely! They were offering a reward of two hundred dollars for him. It's like finding money on the ground.

en: “Yes, it is—and I could a had it if I’d been big enough; I see him first. Who nailed him?”
vi: - Oh right, if I were a bit older, it wouldn't have escaped me because I was the one who met it first. So who caught it?
tr: “Very true... I wish I were bigger, then I would have gotten the money; I saw it first. So who caught it?”
es: —Yes, it's true, and it could have been mine if I had been older. I saw it first. Who caught it?

en: “It was an old fellow—a stranger—and he sold out his chance in him for forty dollars, becuz he’s got to go up the river and can’t wait. Think o’ that, now! You bet I’d wait, if it was seven year.”
vi: - An old man, then he sold it to another person for forty dollars because he had to leave immediately with his friend, so he couldn't wait. Isn't that strange? As for me, I would wait, even for seven years.
tr: “An old man… a stranger… sold the reward money for forty dollars because he had to go upriver and couldn't wait. Look at that! If it were me, I would have waited even seven years.”
es: —A strange guy, a stranger, who sold his right to him for forty dollars because he has to go upriver and can't wait. Imagine that! Well, I would wait even if it were seven years.

en: “That’s me, every time,” says I. “But maybe his chance ain’t worth no more than that, if he’ll sell it so cheap. Maybe there’s something ain’t straight about it.”
vi: - Me too. But maybe he has some unclear issues, so he sold it cheaply like that. - Oh, what's unclear about this matter?
tr: “I would have expected that too,” I said. “But maybe it doesn't fetch more money if he sold it so cheaply. Maybe there's something fishy going on.”
es: —I say the same thing —I replied—. But maybe it's because their rights aren't worth much if they sell them for so little. Maybe there's something illegal there.

en: “But it is, though—straight as a string. I see the handbill myself. It tells all about him, to a dot—paints him like a picture, and tells the plantation he’s frum, below Newrleans. No-sirree-bob, they ain’t no trouble ’bout that speculation, you bet you. Say, gimme a chaw tobacker, won’t ye?”
vi: I saw the wanted poster with my own eyes, it even had its picture, saying it escaped from some plantation, seems like it was down in New Orleans. Hey, do you have a cigarette? Can I have one?
tr: “But everything is by the book. I saw the advertisement with my own eyes. It describes the black man in the smallest detail, almost drawing his picture. Moreover, it also mentioned which plantation below New Orleans he belonged to. No; brother, I definitely don't think there's anything fishy going on. If you have any, give me some chewing tobacco.”
es: —Well, I'm telling you no, it's completely legitimate. I myself have seen the reward notice. It gives all the details about him, down to the last one, as if it were in a painting, and it says which plantation he comes from, beyond New Orleans. No, sir, you can bet there's nothing strange about it. Hey, give me some chewing tobacco, do you have any?

en: I didn’t have none, so he left. I went to the raft, and set down in the wigwam to think. But I couldn’t come to nothing. I thought till I wore my head sore, but I couldn’t see no way out of the trouble. After all this long journey, and after all we’d done for them scoundrels, here it was all come to nothing, everything all busted up and ruined, because they could have the heart to serve Jim such a trick as that, and make him a slave again all his life, and amongst strangers, too, for forty dirty dollars.
vi: I said there wasn't any. So he left. I went back to the raft, sat in the tent, and pondered. I thought so hard that my head hurt, but I still couldn't find a way to get out of this troublesome boat. After a long and arduous journey, after so many hardships with those swindlers, now it seemed like we were getting nowhere.
tr: I had no tobacco, the boy left. So I turned to the shack, went inside the shelter, and started thinking. Nothing came to my mind. I thought until my head was about to burst, but I couldn't find a way out of this trouble. This long journey, all the things we did for those two swindlers, had been in vain, everything was ruined; because they were treacherous enough to play such a trick on Jim; to make him a lifelong slave among strangers for just forty dollars.
es: I had nothing left, so he left. I went to the raft and sat in the wigwam to think. But nothing came to mind. I thought until my head hurt, but I couldn't see a way out of that problem. After all the journey and what we had done for those heartless people, everything had ended, everything had fallen apart and been destroyed, because they had the bad blood to play such a trick on Jim and turn him back into a slave for his entire life, and on top of that among strangers, for forty filthy dollars.

en: Once I said to myself it would be a thousand times better for Jim to be a slave at home where his family was, as long as he’d got to be a slave, and so I’d better write a letter to Tom Sawyer and tell him to tell Miss Watson where he was. But I soon give up that notion for two things: she’d be mad and disgusted at his rascality and ungratefulness for leaving her, and so she’d sell him straight down the river again; and if she didn’t, everybody naturally despises an ungrateful nigger, and they’d make Jim feel it all the time, and so he’d feel ornery and disgraced. And then think of me! It would get all around that Huck Finn helped a nigger to get his freedom; and if I was ever to see anybody from that town again I’d be ready to get down and lick his boots for shame. That’s just the way: a person does a low-down thing, and then he don’t want to take no consequences of it. Thinks as long as he can hide it, it ain’t no disgrace. That was my fix exactly. The more I studied about this, the more my conscience went to grinding me, and the more wicked and low-down and ornery I got to feeling. And at last, when it hit me all of a sudden that here was the plain hand of Providence slapping me in the face and letting me know my wickedness was being watched all the time from up there in heaven, whilst I was stealing a poor old woman’s nigger that hadn’t ever done me no harm, and now was showing me there’s One that’s always on the lookout, and ain’t a-going to allow no such miserable doings to go only just so fur and no further, I most dropped in my tracks I was so scared. Well, I tried the best I could to kinder soften it up somehow for myself by saying I was brung up wicked, and so I warn’t so much to blame; but something inside of me kept saying, “There was the Sunday-school, you could a gone to it; and if you’d a done it they’d a learnt you there that people that acts as I’d been acting about that nigger goes to everlasting fire.”
vi: They were willing to play such a trick on Jim for just forty dollars and make him a slave again; being a slave near his home would be a thousand times better than in a strange place. So, I decided to write a letter to Tom Sawyer to tell him to inform Miss Watson where Jim was. But after thinking it over carefully, I abandoned that idea immediately. For two reasons: she would surely be disgusted with the ungrateful black man who left her, and she would sell him right away. And if she didn't do that, then Jim would always feel miserable and despicable. What to do now? Then there was the rumor that Huck Finn had helped a black man escape. If I met anyone in town, would I have to kneel down and shamefully lick their shoes? That's life: whoever does something wicked doesn't want to face the consequences of it. The more I thought about it, the more my conscience gnawed at me, and the more I felt despicable and lowly. Finally, I felt as if the hand of God had just slapped me in the face, telling me that God was still watching all my sinful deeds. I had stolen a black slave from a poor woman who had never done anything to harm me. I felt my guilt and was terribly afraid. I tried to console myself by thinking that I was born wicked, so it wasn't entirely my fault. But inside me, something still said: There's that seminary, you have to go there to learn, and if you do, they will teach you that those who do what you did to that black man will be burned to death.
tr: When I thought that if Jim was going to remain a slave where his family found him, it would be a thousand times better for him to be a slave in his own home, I decided it was best to write a letter to Tom Sawyer and ask him to tell Miss Watson where Jim was. But a little later, I changed my mind, for two reasons: Miss Watson would be very angry and hate him for the lowliness and treachery of abandoning her, so she would sell him down the river again; even if she didn't sell him, everyone naturally hates a treacherous black man and they would constantly make Jim feel this, so he would feel base and dishonored. And what about me? Everyone would hear that Huck Finn helped a black man gain freedom; I would have to bow my head and lick their boots in shame whenever I saw anyone from that town. That's how it always is: Someone does something despicable, and then doesn't want to face the consequences. As long as he can hide his fault, he assumes he hasn't done anything shameful. I had fallen into exactly such a predicament. The more I thought about what I had done, the more my conscience troubled me, and I felt increasingly base and despicable. Finally, I decided it was clear that God's blow had suddenly struck my face; it reminded me that my sins had been seen from above from the beginning, that God had witnessed me stealing the black man of a poor old woman who had never harmed me, and that He would not allow such vile sins to continue; I was so scared that I nearly lost my mind. Yet I did my best to find excuses for the mischief I had done; I said that I had been raised as a sinner, so it wasn't my fault; but still, a voice inside me said: "There was the church's Sunday school, you could have gone there; if you had gone, they would have taught you the right thing, they would have told you that those who treat blacks the way you do will burn in hell forever."
es: Once I told myself that it would be a thousand times better for Jim to be a slave at home, where his family was, if he had to be a slave, so it would be better to write a letter to Tom Sawyer to tell Miss Watson where he was. But I immediately gave up the idea for two reasons: she would be indignant and angry at his bad faith and ingratitude for escaping from her, so she would sell him down the river again, and if not, everyone naturally despises an ungrateful black man and would remind Jim of it all the time, so that he would feel miserable and dishonored. And, what would they think of me! Everyone would find out that Huck Finn had helped a black man gain his freedom, and if I ever saw anyone from town again, it would have to be to bow down and lick their boots out of shame. That's how things are: someone does something wrong and then doesn't want to face the consequences. They think that as long as they can hide, they won't have to feel ashamed. And that was my situation. The more I thought about it, the more my conscience gnawed at me, and the more wicked, low, and miserable I felt. And finally, when I suddenly realized that it was the hand of Providence slapping me in the face and telling me that my wickedness was always known up in heaven, because I had stolen a black man from a poor old woman who had never done anything wrong to me, and now it was showing me that there is always Someone who sees everything and does not allow such wickedness beyond a certain point, I almost fell to the ground from the fear it gave me. Well, I did everything I could to make things easier for myself by telling myself that I had been raised poorly, so it wasn't all my fault, but inside me, there was something that kept repeating: "There was Sunday school and you could have gone; and if you had gone, they would have taught you that people who do the things you have done for that black man are destined for eternal fire."

en: It made me shiver. And I about made up my mind to pray, and see if I couldn’t try to quit being the kind of a boy I was and be better. So I kneeled down. But the words wouldn’t come. Why wouldn’t they? It warn’t no use to try and hide it from Him. Nor from me, neither. I knowed very well why they wouldn’t come. It was because my heart warn’t right; it was because I warn’t square; it was because I was playing double. I was letting on to give up sin, but away inside of me I was holding on to the biggest one of all. I was trying to make my mouth say I would do the right thing and the clean thing, and go and write to that nigger’s owner and tell where he was; but deep down in me I knowed it was a lie, and He knowed it. You can’t pray a lie—I found that out.
vi: I shuddered in fear, and I thought I must pray to become an honest person. I knelt down. But I couldn't think of any words. Why is that? Perhaps it's because one cannot lie to God or oneself. I knew why I couldn't find the words for a prayer, simply because I wasn't being straightforward or sincere. I intended to abandon my sins, but my conscience was still burdened with them... God knows everything, so don't pray for deceitful things. I understood that.
tr: I shivered from head to toe. I decided to pray, maybe I could stop being a sinful child and try to be better. I knelt down. But the words just wouldn't come to my mind. Why wouldn't they come? It was impossible to hide from God what a servant knew. I couldn't hide it from myself either. I knew very well why the words wouldn't come to my mind. Because I wasn't praying from the heart, because I wasn't being honest, because I was being hypocritical. I wanted to say that I would stop sinning, but something inside me insisted on one of the greatest sins. I was trying to open my mouth to say that I would do the right thing, clean up the mess I had made, and write to the owner of the black man to inform him of his whereabouts; but deep down I knew it was a lie – God knew it too. You can't pray falsely – this is what I learned.
es: That made me tremble. And I decided to start praying and see if I could stop being a bad boy and become better. So I knelt down. But the words wouldn't come out. Why not? It was no use trying to hide it from Him. Nor from myself either. I knew very well why they wouldn't come out of me. It was because my soul was not clean; it was because I had not repented; it was because I was playing both sides. I acted as if I were going to renounce sin, but inside I was still determined on the worst of all. I tried to force my mouth to say that I was going to do what was right and correct and write to the owner of that black man to tell her where he was; but deep down I knew it was a lie, and so did He. You can't pray lies, as I understood then.

en: So I was full of trouble, full as I could be; and didn’t know what to do. At last I had an idea; and I says, I’ll go and write the letter—and then see if I can pray. Why, it was astonishing, the way I felt as light as a feather right straight off, and my troubles all gone. So I got a piece of paper and a pencil, all glad and excited, and set down and wrote:
vi: I was extremely worried. A moment later, I came up with an idea and told myself: I will write a letter to see, and then pray to see if it works. Strangely, as soon as I thought of that, I felt as light as a feather. All my worries disappeared completely. I grabbed a pencil and a piece of paper, eagerly sat down to write.
tr: I was in such great distress that I was at a loss for what to do. Finally, an idea came to my mind; I thought to myself, let me go and write this letter, and then try to pray. Strangely enough, I suddenly felt as light as a feather, all my troubles had almost vanished. I took paper and pen and started writing with joy and excitement:
es: So I was full of problems, all the problems in the world, and I didn't know what to do. Finally, I had an idea and said to myself: "I will write the letter and then try to pray." And, well, I was amazed at how I immediately felt as light as a feather again, and without any more problems. So I grabbed a sheet of paper and a pencil, feeling very happy and encouraged, and I sat down to write:

en: Miss Watson, your runaway nigger Jim is down here two mile below Pikesville, and Mr. Phelps has got him and he will give him up for the reward if you send.
vi: “Miss Watson, your black man Jim ran away down here, two miles from Pikesville. Mr. Phelps caught him and will return him to you for a reward if you send the money down.”
tr: Miss Watson, your runaway negro Jim is two miles below Pikesville, in the hands of Mr. Phelps, and if you send the reward, he will send your negro to you.
es: "Miss Watson, your runaway negro Jim is here two miles down from Pikesville and Mr. Phelps has him. He will return him for the reward if you send for him."

en: HUCK FINN.
vi: Huck Finn
tr: HUCK FINN
es: "HUCK FINN"

en: I felt good and all washed clean of sin for the first time I had ever felt so in my life, and I knowed I could pray now. But I didn’t do it straight off, but laid the paper down and set there thinking—thinking how good it was all this happened so, and how near I come to being lost and going to hell. And went on thinking. And got to thinking over our trip down the river; and I see Jim before me all the time: in the day and in the night-time, sometimes moonlight, sometimes storms, and we a-floating along, talking and singing and laughing. But somehow I couldn’t seem to strike no places to harden me against him, but only the other kind. I’d see him standing my watch on top of his’n, ’stead of calling me, so I could go on sleeping; and see him how glad he was when I come back out of the fog; and when I come to him again in the swamp, up there where the feud was; and such-like times; and would always call me honey, and pet me and do everything he could think of for me, and how good he always was; and at last I struck the time I saved him by telling the men we had small-pox aboard, and he was so grateful, and said I was the best friend old Jim ever had in the world, and the only one he’s got now; and then I happened to look around and see that paper.
vi: I felt relieved as if I had just shed all my sins. And I thought now I could pray. But I didn't pray immediately; instead, I put the piece of paper down and sat thinking. Everything had gone well just when I was most desperate. I thought again about the journey with Jim along this river. Jim was always by my side, day and night, under the moon as well as in the storm. We talked, laughed, and sang on the raft drifting along the water. I couldn't find a single thing that made me hate Jim; on the contrary. Jim stood guard for me, and instead of waking me up, he let me sleep; Jim was happy and joyful when he saw me return safely; and Jim always called me by a dear name, indulged me, and would do anything for me. Then I remembered when I saved Jim and told the others that there was someone with smallpox on the raft, and Jim told me I was his best friend in the world. Thinking that, I looked down at the piece of paper I had just written.
tr: I now felt as if I had done a good deed and, for the first time in my life, cleansed of sin; now I could pray. But I didn't start praying right away; I put down the paper and began to think – how good it was that things had ended this way, how close I had come to going down the wrong path and ending up in hell, I had narrowly escaped at the last moment. The more I thought, the more I thought. Then I started thinking about our journey down the river; the nights, the days, sometimes in the moonlight, sometimes in the storm, the moments I spent with Jim came to mind; we had traveled down the river for so long, talked, sung songs, laughed, and had fun. But for some reason, I had no memory that would harden my heart against him; on the contrary, I remembered things that softened it. I remembered how he took my watch after his own, how he couldn't bring himself to wake me up, how happy he was when I returned from the fog, how delighted he was when we met in the swamp where there was a blood feud; many similar things came to mind; he always called me the apple of his eye, patted my head, did everything he could think of for my comfort, always treated me well; lastly, I remembered the night I saved him by telling the men there were flowers on the raft, how grateful he was, how he said I was the best friend he had in this world, even his only friend now; as I thought about these things, I looked around and saw the paper.
es: I felt good and clean of sin for the first time in my life and understood that now I could pray. But I didn't do it immediately; instead, I put the piece of paper aside and stayed there thinking: thinking how good it was that everything had happened this way and how close I had been to losing myself and going to hell. And I kept thinking. And I started thinking about our journey down the river and saw Jim in front of me all the time: day and night, sometimes in the moonlight, other times in the middle of storms, and when we floated down, chatting and singing and laughing. But I don't know why it seemed that I couldn't find anything to harden me against him, but quite the opposite. I saw him take my watch in addition to his own, instead of waking me up, so that I could sleep more, and I saw how happy he was when I returned in the middle of the fog, and when we met again in the swamp, far away where the blood feud was, and all those moments, and how he always called me his boy and caressed me and did everything he could for me, and how good he had always been, until I reached the moment when I had saved him when I told the men that we had smallpox on board and how grateful he was and that he had said that I was the best friend he had in the world, old Jim, and the only one he has now, and then, when I looked around randomly, I saw the piece of paper.

en: It was a close place. I took it up, and held it in my hand. I was a-trembling, because I’d got to decide, forever, betwixt two things, and I knowed it. I studied a minute, sort of holding my breath, and then says to myself:
vi: What a dilemma. I picked up the piece of paper, fiddling with it in my hand. My body trembled because this was the moment I had to decide to follow one of two choices. I thought for a minute, held my breath, then told myself:
tr: It was right in front of me. I took the paper and held it in my hand. I was trembling because I knew I had to make a definite choice between two paths. I looked at the paper a bit more, held my breath, and finally said to myself:
es: It was hard for me to make up my mind. I grabbed the paper and held it in my hand. I was trembling, because I had to decide forever between two things, and I knew it. I looked at it for a minute, as if holding my breath, and then I said to myself:

en: “All right, then, I’ll go to hell”—and tore it up.
vi: - Alright, I'm ready to go to hell.
tr: “Whatever, if I go to hell, I go to hell.” I tore up the paper and threw it away.
es: "Well, fine, I'll go to hell!" and I broke it.

en: It was awful thoughts and awful words, but they was said. And I let them stay said; and never thought no more about reforming. I shoved the whole thing out of my head, and said I would take up wickedness again, which was in my line, being brung up to it, and the other warn’t. And for a starter I would go to work and steal Jim out of slavery again; and if I could think up anything worse, I would do that, too; because as long as I was in, and in for good, I might as well go the whole hog.
vi: So I tore the piece of paper to shreds. I chased away everything in my mind, and said that I would follow the wicked path because I was born that way, and could not be otherwise. I had to take action to rescue Jim from a life of slavery. If I could think of anything more wicked, I would do it too.
tr: These were terrible thoughts and terrible words, but they had already come out of my mouth. I didn't feel like taking them back, and from that day on, I didn't even think about changing my mind. From that moment on, I pushed them all out of my mind; I would continue to sin, because this was my path, I was raised for this, I couldn't follow another path. Now, what I needed to do was find a way to free Jim from slavery again; if I had to do something worse for this, I would do it, because I was already neck-deep in this and I wouldn't be able to sleep peacefully until I finished it completely.
es: They were terrible ideas and words, but it was already done. That's how I left it, and I didn't think about reforming anymore. I got it all out of my head and said I would go back to being bad, which was my thing, because that's how I was raised, and the other way didn't suit me. To start with, I was going to do whatever it took to get Jim out of slavery, and if I thought of something worse, I would do that too, because once you're in it, it doesn't matter if it's eight or eighty.

en: Then I set to thinking over how to get at it, and turned over some considerable many ways in my mind; and at last fixed up a plan that suited me. So then I took the bearings of a woody island that was down the river a piece, and as soon as it was fairly dark I crept out with my raft and went for it, and hid it there, and then turned in. I slept the night through, and got up before it was light, and had my breakfast, and put on my store clothes, and tied up some others and one thing or another in a bundle, and took the canoe and cleared for shore. I landed below where I judged was Phelps’s place, and hid my bundle in the woods, and then filled up the canoe with water, and loaded rocks into her and sunk her where I could find her again when I wanted her, about a quarter of a mile below a little steam sawmill that was on the bank.
vi: I thought about the action plan. After much deliberation, I decided to choose the plan that I found most suitable. I pushed the raft towards an island with many trees down the river, waited until it got dark, then hid the child in a place and returned to the tent. I slept there all night, waking up before dawn. I had a light meal, put on my clothes, and stepped into the boat to row to the shore. I docked the boat at a spot I guessed was the Phelps' house, hid the bundle of clothes at the edge of the forest, then let water flood the boat, put stones in it to sink it so that I could find it later if needed.
tr: I started making plans to rescue Jim and mulled over a lot of ideas in my mind; finally, I settled on one plan. I set my sights on a densely wooded island down the river, and as soon as it got dark, I emerged from my hiding place with my raft and headed for the island. I hid the raft on the island and lay down to sleep. I slept soundly through the night, woke up before dawn, had breakfast, put on the new clothes I had bought from the store, bundled up the others, got into the canoe, and went ashore. I made sure to land somewhere near Phelps' farm, hid my bundle in the woods, filled the canoe with water, put a few stones in it, and sank it at a spot where I could find it later, about a quarter mile down from a sawmill on a small creek that flowed into the river.
es: Then I started thinking about how to get it and turned it over and over in my mind until I found a plan that suited me. So I saw the position of a wooded island that was a little downstream, and as soon as it started to get a bit dark, I went out secretly with my raft and hid it there, and then I went to bed. I slept all night and got up before dawn, had breakfast, put on the clothes from the store and the rest in a bundle, and took the canoe to go ashore. I arrived where I thought the Phelps' house should be and hid the bundle in the woods; then I filled the canoe with water and stones and sank it where I could find it again whenever I wanted, about a quarter of a mile down from a small steam mill on the shore.

en: Then I struck up the road, and when I passed the mill I see a sign on it, “Phelps’s Sawmill,” and when I come to the farm-houses, two or three hundred yards further along, I kept my eyes peeled, but didn’t see nobody around, though it was good daylight now. But I didn’t mind, because I didn’t want to see nobody just yet—I only wanted to get the lay of the land. According to my plan, I was going to turn up there from the village, not from below. So I just took a look, and shoved along, straight for town. Well, the very first man I see when I got there was the duke. He was sticking up a bill for the Royal Nonesuch—three-night performance—like that other time. They had the cheek, them frauds! I was right on him before I could shirk. He looked astonished, and says:
vi: Then I walked up the road. Passing by the workshop, I saw a sign that read: Phelps' Workshop. I walked to a few houses a few hundred yards away, peering inside but not seeing anyone, even though it was already quite bright. But it didn't matter because I didn't want to meet anyone yet, I just wanted to scout out the place. According to the plan, I pretended to be someone coming from the town, not from downstream. The first person I met turned out to be the duke. He was posting an advertisement for the play "The Royal Nonesuch." They still knew no fear. I hadn't managed to avoid him before he saw me. He looked surprised and called out:
tr: I set out, and as I passed by the sawmill, I saw a sign that read "Phelps' Sawmill." When I reached the area of the farmhouses about two or three hundred meters away, I kept my eyes wide open and scouted the surroundings, but despite it being almost daylight, there was no one around. There wasn't supposed to be anyone anyway, because I didn't want to see anyone yet – I was just trying to get familiar with the area. According to my plan, they would see me coming from the direction of the town, not from below. So I just took a look around and headed straight towards the town.
