When I arrived in town, the first person I saw was the duke. He was putting up posters for the Royal Nonesuch – a three-night show – just like last time. How brazen these conmen were! Since we ran into each other suddenly, I couldn't escape from there. He looked at me in astonishment:
es: Then I set off, and when I passed by the mill I saw a sign that said "Phelps' Sawmill," and when I reached the houses, two or three hundred yards further on, I was very attentive, but no one was in sight, even though it was already fully daylight. But I didn't mind because I still didn't want to meet anyone: I just wanted to see what everything was like. According to my plan, I was going to appear there, coming from the town, and not from the river. So I took a look around and headed straight to the town. Well, the first person I saw when I arrived was the duke. He was putting up a poster for "The Royal Nonesuch" (three performances), just like the last time. What nerve those two scoundrels had! I stood beside him before he could even move. He seemed astonished and said:

en: “Hel-lo! Where’d you come from?” Then he says, kind of glad and eager, “Where’s the raft?—got her in a good place?”
vi: - So you're here? Where did you put the raft? Did you hide it in a safe place?
tr: "Oh my goodness!" "Where did you come from?" Then, with joy and eagerness, "Where is Sal?
es: —Hello! Where did you come from? —and then he adds, as if he were very happy—: Where is the raft? Did you put it in a good place?

en: I says:
vi: I replied:
tr: Did you find a good place?" he asked.
es: And I replied:

en: “Why, that’s just what I was going to ask your grace.”
vi: - I was also about to ask the duke that question.
tr: "I was just about to ask you the same thing, your excellency.""
es: —Man, that was what I was going to ask your grace.

en: Then he didn’t look so joyful, and says:
vi: He seemed unhappy and said:
tr: Suddenly, his mood soured.
es: Then he didn't seem so happy and asked:

en: “What was your idea for asking me?” he says.
vi: - What do you mean by asking me that question? I said:
tr: “What do you mean you were going to ask me?”
es: —Why were you going to ask me?

en: “Well,” I says, “when I see the king in that doggery yesterday I says to myself, we can’t get him home for hours, till he’s soberer; so I went a-loafing around town to put in the time and wait. A man up and offered me ten cents to help him pull a skiff over the river and back to fetch a sheep, and so I went along; but when we was dragging him to the boat, and the man left me a-holt of the rope and went behind him to shove him along, he was too strong for me and jerked loose and run, and we after him. We didn’t have no dog, and so we had to chase him all over the country till we tired him out. We never got him till dark; then we fetched him over, and I started down for the raft. When I got there and see it was gone, I says to myself, ‘they’ve got into trouble and had to leave; and they’ve took my nigger, which is the only nigger I’ve got in the world, and now I’m in a strange country, and ain’t got no property no more, nor nothing, and no way to make my living;’ so I set down and cried. I slept in the woods all night. But what did become of the raft, then?—and Jim—poor Jim!”
vi: - Yesterday, when I saw the king in that house, I thought it would be a long time before he sobered up, so I wandered down the street to kill time. At that moment, someone came and gave me a dime, asking me to take the boat across the river and then go catch a stray sheep. So I followed him. But when we brought the sheep to the boat. The sheep was so strong that it broke free and ran away, and we had to chase it. We ran through every nook and cranny until evening without finding it, so I headed back to the raft. When I got back, the raft was gone too. I told myself that something bad must have happened to the others, so they left and took my black friend with them. So I sat down and cried. I had to sleep in the forest all night. Poor Jim!
tr: “When I saw the king in the tavern yesterday, I thought we wouldn't be able to take him anywhere for a few more hours until he sobered up; so I started wandering around the town to pass the time. A man offered me ten cents to take a sheep across the river with a boat and come back, and I accepted; but while pulling the sheep onto the boat, the man left the rope with me for a moment to push the sheep from behind, but the sheep was stronger than me and suddenly broke free and ran away, so we chased after it. Since we didn't have a dog, we had to chase it over hills and valleys until it got tired. We couldn't catch it until it got dark, but finally we caught it and took it across, and I headed towards the raft. When I came to the place where we had hidden the raft and couldn't find it, I thought, ‘It seems they got into trouble and had to leave; they took my nigger too, the only nigger I had in this world, and now I'm left in a foreign land without any possessions, penniless, and there's nothing I can do to earn a living,’ I said to myself; I sat down and started to cry. I slept in the forest that night. So what happened to the raft then? And Jim, poor Jim!”
es: —Well —I go and say—, when I saw the king yesterday in that tavern, I told myself that it would take us hours to get him home until he had sobered up, so I started wandering around the town to kill time and wait. A man came and offered me ten cents if I helped him take a boat to the other side of the river and come back with a sheep, so I went with him; but when we were taking it to the boat and the man gave me the rope and went behind the boat to push, the sheep turned out to be too much for me alone and it broke free and ran off, and we ran after it. We didn't have a dog, so we had to chase it all over the field until it got tired. We didn't catch it until dusk; then we took it to the other side and I headed towards the raft. When I arrived and saw that it had disappeared, I said to myself: "They've gotten into trouble and had to leave, and they've taken my black man, who is the only black man I have in the world, and now I'm in a strange country and I have nothing of my own, I have nothing left at all nor any way to make a living," so I sat down to cry. I fell asleep in the forest all night. But then, what happened to the raft?... And Jim. Poor Jim!

en: “Blamed if I know—that is, what’s become of the raft. That old fool had made a trade and got forty dollars, and when we found him in the doggery the loafers had matched half-dollars with him and got every cent but what he’d spent for whisky; and when I got him home late last night and found the raft gone, we said, ‘That little rascal has stole our raft and shook us, and run off down the river.’”
vi: - He has forty dollars. When we caught him at that dilapidated house, it was exactly when he was gambling and lost everything, only having a little change left to buy alcohol. When I brought him back, the raft was already gone. We thought you had stolen the raft and fled.
tr: “If I know what happened to the raft, I am a scoundrel. That old fool had sold something and gotten forty dollars; when we found him in the tavern, ruffians had swarmed around him and taken every last cent from him through trickery, except for the money he had spent on whiskey. Late in the evening, when we took him back and noticed the raft was gone, we said, ‘That little rascal stole our raft and took our belongings down the river.’”
es: —Hang me if I know; I'm referring to what happened with the raft. The old fool made a deal and got forty dollars, and when we found him in the tavern, some clumsy guys had started playing half-dollars with him and had taken every last cent except what he had spent on whiskey, and when I went to take him home late at night and we saw that the raft had disappeared, we said to ourselves: "That little rascal has stolen the raft and escaped down the river."

en: “I wouldn’t shake my nigger, would I?—the only nigger I had in the world, and the only property.”
vi: - But what about my black man? He is my only relative.
tr: “But I'm not going to leave my black man behind, am I? In this world, I have only one black man; I have no other possessions.”
es: —I wasn't going to escape without my black man, was I? The only black man I had in the world, my only possession.

en: “We never thought of that. Fact is, I reckon we’d come to consider him our nigger; yes, we did consider him so—goodness knows we had trouble enough for him. So when we see the raft was gone and we flat broke, there warn’t anything for it but to try the Royal Nonesuch another shake. And I’ve pegged along ever since, dry as a powder-horn. Where’s that ten cents? Give it here.”
vi: - We don't think so. In fact, we already consider it our property. So when we saw the raft was gone, we returned empty-handed and had to put on this act. I haven't had anything to eat yet. Give me that penny.
tr: “This had never crossed our minds. To be honest, we had started to see him as our own black person; yes, we were now looking at him as our black person... God knows he didn't suffer any less because of us. When Sal left, we were left penniless and had no choice but to try Curcuna at the Palace again. Since then, even the last pennies in my pocket are gone, I'm dried up. Is that ten cents still there? Give it to me.”
es: —That hadn't occurred to us. The truth is, I reckon we had come to consider him as our black man; yes, that's it; God knows we had been quite bothered about him. So when we saw that the raft had disappeared and we were left without a cent, there was no choice but to try "The Unmatched Royalty" again. And here I am since then, drier than a desert. Where are those ten cents? Give them to me.

en: I had considerable money, so I give him ten cents, but begged him to spend it for something to eat, and give me some, because it was all the money I had, and I hadn’t had nothing to eat since yesterday. He never said nothing. The next minute he whirls on me and says:
vi: I still had a lot of money, so I gave him a dime and told him to buy something for us to eat together, because that was all the money I had and I hadn't eaten anything since yesterday. He didn't say anything. A minute later, he asked me:
tr: I had enough money, so I gave him ten cents, but I begged him to use it to buy something to eat, and he had to share the food with me because I had no other money and hadn't eaten anything since yesterday. He didn't say a word. But a moment later, he turned to me in a hurry and said:
es: I had quite a bit of money, so I gave him ten cents, but I begged him to spend it on something to eat and to give me something, because I had no more money and hadn't eaten since yesterday. He didn't say a word. The next moment he threw himself at me saying:

en: “Do you reckon that nigger would blow on us? We’d skin him if he done that!”
vi: - Do you think that black guy will rat us out? If he does, we'll skin him alive.
tr: “Do you think that black man will report us? If he does, we'll skin him alive!”
es: —Do you think that black guy is going to snitch on us? If he snitches, we'll skin him alive!

en: “How can he blow? Hain’t he run off?”
vi: - How dare it accuse you? It has already run away, hasn't it?
tr: “Where is he reporting? Didn't he run away?”
es: —How is he going to snitch? Hasn't he escaped?

en: “No! That old fool sold him, and never divided with me, and the money’s gone.”
vi: - That old man sold it, but he didn't give me a single penny. That money is all gone now.
tr: “No! Our old fool sold it and didn't share the money with me, and now he is also penniless.”
es: —No! The old fool sold it and didn't share it with me, and now there's nothing left. —He sold him?

en: “Sold him?” I says, and begun to cry; “why, he was my nigger, and that was my money. Where is he?—I want my nigger.”
vi: I burst into tears: - Sell him? He is my black man. He is my money. Give me back my black man.
tr: “Did he sell him?” I started crying; “but he was my black man and the money was my money. Where is he now? I want my black man back.”
es: —I said, and I began to cry—; but he was my black man, so he was my money. Where is he? I want my black man.

en: “Well, you can’t get your nigger, that’s all—so dry up your blubbering. Looky here—do you think you’d venture to blow on us? Blamed if I think I’d trust you. Why, if you was to blow on us—”
vi: - You won't get it back, so stop crying. Listen here, are you planning to accuse us? I can't trust you. I saw a fierce look in his eyes.
tr: “You can't get your money back, so stop whining. Look at me… do you think he can risk reporting us? I don't trust you much either. If you also try to report us…”
es: —Well, your black man is not going to come and that's it, so stop whining. Come on: do you think you would dare to snitch on us? Hang me if I trust you. Damn, if you were going to snitch on us...

en: He stopped, but I never see the duke look so ugly out of his eyes before. I went on a-whimpering, and says:
vi: I saw a fierce look in his eyes. I kept crying and said:
tr: He was silent, but I had never seen the shopkeeper look this angry. I continued to complain:
es: He fell silent, but he had never seen the duke cast such a terrible look. I kept crying and said:

en: “I don’t want to blow on nobody; and I ain’t got no time to blow, nohow. I got to turn out and find my nigger.”
vi: - I don't want to accuse anyone. I have to go find my black man.
tr: “I don't want to report anyone, I don't have time for that anyway. I just want to go and find my black man.”
es: —I don't want to snitch on anyone, and besides, I don't have time to do it; I have to find my black man.

en: He looked kinder bothered, and stood there with his bills fluttering on his arm, thinking, and wrinkling up his forehead. At last he says:
vi: He stood there, still holding the advertisement in his hand, frowning in thought. He said:
tr: He hesitated for a moment, rubbing his forehead while the flyers under his arm fluttered in the wind, and paused to think. Finally, he spoke:
es: He seemed annoyed and stayed with the programs fluttering above his arm, thinking and furrowing his brow. Finally, he said:

en: “I’ll tell you something. We got to be here three days. If you’ll promise you won’t blow, and won’t let the nigger blow, I’ll tell you where to find him.”
vi: He said: - We stayed there for three more days. If you promise me that you won't report me, and won't let the black guy report me, then I'll tell you where to find him.
tr: “Listen carefully. We will stay here for three days. If you promise not to report us, and that the black man won't report us either, I will tell you where to find him.”
es: —I'm going to tell you something. We have to stay here for three days. If you promise not to snitch and not to let the black guy snitch, I'll tell you where it is.

en: So I promised, and he says:
vi: I promise. He said again:
tr: I promised her.
es: So I promised him, and he continued:

en: “A farmer by the name of Silas Ph—” and then he stopped. You see, he started to tell me the truth; but when he stopped that way, and begun to study and think again, I reckoned he was changing his mind. And so he was. He wouldn’t trust me; he wanted to make sure of having me out of the way the whole three days. So pretty soon he says:
vi: - There was a ranch owner named Silas Ph... He suddenly stopped. He probably intended to tell the truth, but then changed his mind. He still didn't trust me and wanted me to leave this place within three days. He continued:
tr: “The name of the farmer who took him is Silas Ph…” then he fell silent. He was actually going to tell me the truth, but then he stopped and reconsidered, and as far as I could understand, he changed his mind. Apparently, he had concluded that he couldn't trust me and thought it best for me to stay out of the way for three days. A little later, he said:
es: —A farmer named Silas Ph... And then he fell silent. That is, he had started to tell me the truth, but when he fell silent and began to think and reflect, I figured he was changing his mind. And that was it. He didn't trust me; he wanted to make sure I wouldn't cause him problems for the entire three days. So after a moment, he goes and says:

en: “The man that bought him is named Abram Foster—Abram G. Foster—and he lives forty mile back here in the country, on the road to Lafayette.”
vi: - The person who bought Jim is Abram Foster, forty miles away from here, in the countryside, on the way to Lafayette
tr: “The name of the man who took it is Abram Foster… Abram G. Foster… He lives forty miles from here, inland on the Lafayette road.”
es: —The man who bought it is named Abram Foster, Abram G. Foster, and he lives forty miles across the country, on the road to Lafayette.

en: “All right,” I says, “I can walk it in three days. And I’ll start this very afternoon.”
vi: I said: - Alright, I will go there this afternoon, it will take just three days to arrive.
tr: “Okay, I can walk there in three days,” I said. “It would be good to start right this afternoon.”
es: —Very well —I said—. I can cover that in three days. And I am leaving this very afternoon.

en: “No you wont, you’ll start now; and don’t you lose any time about it, neither, nor do any gabbling by the way. Just keep a tight tongue in your head and move right along, and then you won’t get into trouble with us, d’ye hear?”
vi: - No, you should go right now. On the way, don't linger or chat with anyone, otherwise you'll get into trouble. I also only hope for that, I already have a plan in my head.
tr: “No, you must start immediately,” he said. “Do not waste any time, do not dawdle on the road. Keep your mouth shut along the way and walk without stopping, then you won't have any problems with us, do you hear me?”
es: —No, not a chance, you leave right now, and don't waste time or start chatting around. Keep your mouth shut and get moving; that way you won't have any problems with us, do you hear me?

en: That was the order I wanted, and that was the one I played for. I wanted to be left free to work my plans.
vi: He said: - Just go right away.
tr: I was already waiting for this order and trying to hear it. I wanted to be left alone to implement my own plan.
es: That was the order I wanted to receive and the one I was waiting for. I wanted freedom to carry out my plans.

en: “So clear out,” he says; “and you can tell Mr. Foster whatever you want to. Maybe you can get him to believe that Jim is your nigger—some idiots don’t require documents—leastways I’ve heard there’s such down South here. And when you tell him the handbill and the reward’s bogus, maybe he’ll believe you when you explain to him what the idea was for getting ’em out. Go ’long now, and tell him anything you want to; but mind you don’t work your jaw any between here and there.”
vi: When you meet Mr. Abram Foster, you can say whatever you want. Maybe you can convince him that Jim is your black servant, and he probably won't ask for any papers. Just go, say whatever you want when you meet him, but remember not to say a word from here to there.
tr: “Get lost,” he said; “You can tell Mr. Foster whatever you want. Maybe you can convince him that Jim is your slave... Some fools don't ask for documents... At least I've heard that there are some who don't ask for documents this far South. If you tell him that the advertisement and the reward are fake, that you made it all up to keep others away from your slave, he might believe you. Now go and tell him whatever you want; but make sure it's your feet doing the work, not your mouth, between here and there.”
es: —So get lost —he says—, and you can tell Mr. Foster whatever you want. Maybe you'll get him to believe that Jim is your black man, because there are idiots who don't demand documents, or at least that's what I've been told happens here in the South. And when you tell him that the flyer and the reward are fake, maybe he'll believe you when you explain why they were distributed. Now get lost and tell him whatever you want, but be careful not to wag your tongue anywhere until you get there.

en: So I left, and struck for the back country. I didn’t look around, but I kinder felt like he was watching me. But I knowed I could tire him out at that. I went straight out in the country as much as a mile before I stopped; then I doubled back through the woods towards Phelps’. I reckoned I better start in on my plan straight off without fooling around, because I wanted to stop Jim’s mouth till these fellows could get away. I didn’t want no trouble with their kind. I’d seen all I wanted to of them, and wanted to get entirely shut of them.
vi: I walked towards the outskirts. Although I didn't turn my head back, I still felt that he was watching me. I walked straight out to the outskirts about a mile away, then stopped, turned into the forest, and headed back to Mr. Phelps' house. I planned to carry out my plan immediately so that Jim wouldn't have time to report them, adding more trouble. Just hoping to escape from them would be a relief.
tr: So I left there and set off inward. I wasn't looking around, but I could feel him watching me. Of course, I knew I would tire him out soon enough. I walked about a mile through the fields, then turned back and headed towards the Phelps farm through the forest. I had to start executing my plan immediately without lingering around, because I wanted to keep Jim's mouth shut until these scoundrels left. I didn't want to get into trouble with people like them. I'd already had enough trouble with them, there was no need to face them again.
es: So I started walking towards the field. I didn't look back, but I had the feeling that I was being watched. But I knew I could make them tired of watching me. I kept walking towards the field for at least a mile before stopping; then I retraced my steps through the forest towards Phelps' house. I figured it was best to start with my plan without wasting any time because I wanted to prevent Jim from saying anything until those guys left. I didn't want trouble with people like that. I was already fed up with them and wanted to lose sight of them forever.

en: CHAPTER XXXII.
vi: Chapter XXXII
tr: Chapter Thirty-Two
es: Chapter 32

en: When I got there it was all still and Sunday-like, and hot and sunshiny; the hands was gone to the fields; and there was them kind of faint dronings of bugs and flies in the air that makes it seem so lonesome and like everybody’s dead and gone; and if a breeze fans along and quivers the leaves it makes you feel mournful, because you feel like it’s spirits whispering—spirits that’s been dead ever so many years—and you always think they’re talking about you. As a general thing it makes a body wish he was dead, too, and done with it all.
vi: When I arrived there, I saw that everything was as quiet as a Sunday. The sun was scorching hot. Everyone had gone to the fields to work. Only the buzzing of the flies made the atmosphere even more melancholic. I felt as if everyone had died. Every gust of wind that blew through made the leaves rustle, making the scene even sadder. Overall, looking at this scene, one just wanted to die to forget everything.
tr: When I arrived there, the surroundings were as calm as a Sunday, and it was also hot and sunny; the laborers had gone to the fields; there was a faint buzzing of insects and flies in the air, I felt very lonely and deserted, as if everyone except me had died and gone away. It was such a weather that if a breeze rustled the leaves, you would feel sorrowful, because it would seem as if spirits –even those that had been dead for many years– were whispering, and you would always think they were talking about you. In fact, generally in the face of such a thing, one comes to wish that they too had died and severed their connection with this world.
es: WHEN I ARRIVED everything was calm, as if it were Sunday, it was hot and the sun was shining; the slaves had gone to the fields and all you could hear was that buzzing of insects and flies in the air that makes you feel as lonely as if the whole world had died and disappeared, and if a breeze blows and makes the leaves tremble, you feel sad because it's as if they were spirits saying something, spirits that have been dead for many years, and you always think they are talking about you. In general, it makes you want to be dead, and to have finished with everything.

en: Phelps’ was one of these little one-horse cotton plantations, and they all look alike. A rail fence round a two-acre yard; a stile made out of logs sawed off and up-ended in steps, like barrels of a different length, to climb over the fence with, and for the women to stand on when they are going to jump on to a horse; some sickly grass-patches in the big yard, but mostly it was bare and smooth, like an old hat with the nap rubbed off; big double log-house for the white folks—hewed logs, with the chinks stopped up with mud or mortar, and these mud-stripes been whitewashed some time or another; round-log kitchen, with a big broad, open but roofed passage joining it to the house; log smoke-house back of the kitchen; three little log nigger-cabins in a row t’other side the smoke-house; one little hut all by itself away down against the back fence, and some outbuildings down a piece the other side; ash-hopper and big kettle to bile soap in by the little hut; bench by the kitchen door, with bucket of water and a gourd; hound asleep there in the sun; more hounds asleep round about; about three shade trees away off in a corner; some currant bushes and gooseberry bushes in one place by the fence; outside of the fence a garden and a watermelon patch; then the cotton fields begins, and after the fields the woods.
vi: The Phelps' camp was a small cotton plantation with an iron fence running around it. A gate made of pieces of sawed-off wood. In the yard, there were a few patches of grass, bare and withered. A two-room wooden house for white people, made of small planks, patched together with mortar that had been whitewashed many times. A kitchen, with a wide roof extending to the main house. A woodshed behind the kitchen. Three rooms for black people right beside it. Next to the fence, at the back, there was a small shed for dumping ashes. On the kitchen door, a few water barrels were scattered around. Dogs lay basking in the sun. In the corner of the garden, there were a few sparse trees. Outside the fence, there was another garden with a melon trellis. Beyond that was the cotton field, and beyond the cotton field was the forest.
tr: The Phelps' farm was one of the small cotton plantations, all of which are similar to each other. The two-acre yard was surrounded by a fence; logs cut into slices and arranged in steps of varying heights like barrels served both to climb the fence and to help women mount horses; in the wide yard, there were patches of yellowed grass here and there, but most of the yard was bare and flat, looking like an old hat with its nap worn off; a large two-story wooden house was built for the whites – the gaps in the walls made of logs smoothed with an ax were filled with mud or adobe, and these strips of mortar had been whitewashed at some point. The kitchen, with its round log walls, was connected to the house by a wide, open but roofed passage. Behind the kitchen, there was another wooden shack used for smoking, and beyond that, there were three negro cabins. A small cabin stood alone leaning against the back fences, with an ash silo and a large cauldron for soap making right next to it. On a table next to the kitchen door, there was a bucket of water and a gourd dipper. A hunting dog had curled up and fallen asleep right there in the sun; there were other dogs sleeping around as well. Three large trees in the corner shaded the yard. A grapevine covered part of the fence, outside the fence there was a vegetable garden and a watermelon field, and beyond that, the cotton fields began, and after the fields, there was a forest.
es: The Phelps' house was one of those very small cotton plantations, which are all alike. A log fence around a two-acre yard; an entrance made of sawn logs placed on the ground, like steps of different heights to climb over the fence and for women to mount horses; some tufts of grass in the yard, but generally everything very arid and smooth, like an old worn-out hat; a large double-log house for the whites: logs finished with the holes filled with adobe or mortar and with those separations that are whitewashed from time to time; a round-log kitchen with a wide, open but roofed passage leading to the house, a log cabin for smoking meat behind the kitchen, three small log cabins for the blacks, placed in a row on the other side of the smokehouse, another isolated cabin against the back fence and some sheds on the other side; a lime deposit and a large cauldron in which to boil soap next to the shed; a bench next to the kitchen door, a bucket of water and a gourd; a dog sleeping in the sun; more dogs sleeping on either side, bushes and mulberry trees in a spot next to the fence; on the other side of the fence, an orchard and a watermelon patch, and then the cotton fields and beyond that the woods.

en: I went around and clumb over the back stile by the ash-hopper, and started for the kitchen. When I got a little ways I heard the dim hum of a spinning-wheel wailing along up and sinking along down again; and then I knowed for certain I wished I was dead—for that is the lonesomest sound in the whole world.
vi: I walked around for a while and then climbed onto the roof to enter the kitchen area. After taking a few steps, I heard the hissing sound of a wheel echoing for a moment, then gradually fading away. At that moment, I felt like dying because that sound was so pitiful.
tr: I wandered around and entered the courtyard by climbing the steps near the ash silo, then headed towards the kitchen. As I moved a little further, I heard the whirring of a pulley rising and falling; that's when I thought, God take my life and save me – there is no sound that makes a person feel so lonely.
es: I turned around and climbed over the back gate next to where the quicklime was, and went to the kitchen. After a few steps, I heard the dull hum of a spinning wheel and then I realized that I would be better off dead, because it is the loneliest sound in the whole world.

en: I went right along, not fixing up any particular plan, but just trusting to Providence to put the right words in my mouth when the time come; for I’d noticed that Providence always did put the right words in my mouth if I left it alone.
vi: I kept walking straight in, my mind blank, leaving everything to God.
tr: I continued on my way without a specific plan, trusting that God would give me the right words when the time came; because I had realized that if I let myself relax, God always made me say the right words.
es: I went on, without making any concrete plan, trusting only that Providence would put the right words in my mouth when the time came, for I had noticed that Providence always put the exact words in my mouth if I left it alone.

en: When I got half-way, first one hound and then another got up and went for me, and of course I stopped and faced them, and kept still. And such another powwow as they made! In a quarter of a minute I was a kind of a hub of a wheel, as you may say—spokes made out of dogs—circle of fifteen of them packed together around me, with their necks and noses stretched up towards me, a-barking and howling; and more a-coming; you could see them sailing over fences and around corners from everywheres.
vi: Halfway there, a dog, then another, jumped at me. Of course, I stood still, looking at it. For nearly half a minute, I felt like I was spinning in the middle of a wheel trying to deal with the dogs. About fifteen of them surrounded me, pointing their snouts straight at me, barking loudly. Several other dogs crawled through the fence and from the corners of the garden came to completely encircle me.
tr: When I was halfway down the road, first one dog, then another dog got up and came towards me, so I immediately stopped and started waiting without moving, of course. The barking of the dogs raised a commotion! After about fifteen seconds, I had become like the hub of a wheel, with the spokes of the wheel made up of dogs; around fifteen dogs had gathered around me, stretching their necks and noses towards me, barking or howling; other dogs were also coming; I could see them jumping over fences, darting out from every conceivable corner.
es: When I was halfway there, first one dog and then another got up, so naturally I stood in front of them, completely still. And what a commotion they made! After a quarter of a minute, you could say that I was like the hub of a wheel and the spokes were the dogs, a circle of fifteen of them revolving around me, with their necks and noses pointed at me, barking and howling, and more kept coming; you could see them jumping over fences and coming out of corners from everywhere.

en: A nigger woman come tearing out of the kitchen with a rolling-pin in her hand, singing out, “Begone you Tige! you Spot! begone sah!” and she fetched first one and then another of them a clip and sent them howling, and then the rest followed; and the next second half of them come back, wagging their tails around me, and making friends with me. There ain’t no harm in a hound, nohow.
vi: A black woman ran out from the kitchen, holding a rolling pin in her hand, chasing the dogs! She struck each one of them, and they yelped and ran away. But just a second later, they came back, wagging their tails around me, looking very friendly.
tr: A black woman rushed out of the kitchen with a rolling pin in her hand. "Shoo! Come on, back off! Come on, Çomar! Hop, shoo!" she shouted, hitting first one and then the other with the rolling pin; the dogs howled and retreated, and the rest quickly scattered; a moment later, half of them came back, wagging their tails and started circling around me, trying to befriend me. After all, dogs don't harm humans.
es: From the kitchen ran out a black woman with a rolling pin in her hand, shouting: "Out! You, Tige! You, Spot! Out, I say!" And she gave a hit first to one and then to the other, who went away howling, and then followed the rest, and after a second half of them came back, wagging their tails and becoming friends with me. The truth is that dogs are not bad creatures.

en: And behind the woman comes a little nigger girl and two little nigger boys without anything on but tow-linen shirts, and they hung on to their mother’s gown, and peeped out from behind her at me, bashful, the way they always do. And here comes the white woman running from the house, about forty-five or fifty year old, bareheaded, and her spinning-stick in her hand; and behind her comes her little white children, acting the same way the little niggers was doing. She was smiling all over so she could hardly stand—and says:
vi: Following the black woman was a black girl and two black boys, wearing only thick fabric shirts, clinging to their mother's clothes and hiding behind her, looking at me fearfully, as all black children usually do. Then I saw a white woman step out from the house, about forty-five to fifty years old, bareheaded, holding a knitting needle in her hand, followed by several white children, also hiding behind their mother and looking at me. She smiled with a very delighted expression and said:
tr: A small black girl and two black boys came out after the black woman; the children wore nothing but linen shirts and were all clinging to the hem of their mother's dress, casting shy and furtive glances at me from behind her; children are always like that anyway. A white woman, around forty-five or fifty years old, came out of the house with her head uncovered; she still had a distaff in her hand; white children followed her, behaving just like the black children. The woman's mouth was stretched to her ears, she looked as if she might collapse from smiling:
es: And behind the woman appeared a black girl and two black boys who were wearing nothing but linen shirts and were clinging to their mother's dress, looking at me very shyly from behind her skirts, as they all do. Then the white woman, who must have been forty-five or fifty years old, ran out of the house, without a hat and with the spindle of the spinning wheel in her hand, and behind her, her white children, who were just as shy as the black ones. She was grinning from ear to ear, and she goes and says:

en: “It’s you, at last!—ain’t it?”
vi: - Is that you? I didn't have time to think and immediately replied:
tr: “You finally came!.. It's you, isn't it?”
es: —It's you at last! Right?

en: I out with a “Yes’m” before I thought.
vi: - Yes, ma'am
tr: Before I had time to think, the words "Yes, ma'am," had already slipped out of my mouth.
es: I blurted out a "yes, ma'am" before thinking about it.

en: She grabbed me and hugged me tight; and then gripped me by both hands and shook and shook; and the tears come in her eyes, and run down over; and she couldn’t seem to hug and shake enough, and kept saying, “You don’t look as much like your mother as I reckoned you would; but law sakes, I don’t care for that, I’m so glad to see you! Dear, dear, it does seem like I could eat you up! Children, it’s your cousin Tom!—tell him howdy.”
vi: She hugged me tightly, tears streaming down. Hugging and shaking weren't enough, she kept talking nonstop: - You don't resemble your mother as much as I thought. But thank God, I'm so happy to see you! I just want to give you a big hug! Kids, this is your cousin Tom! Say hello to him!
tr: As soon as the woman caught me, she took me into her arms; then she started shaking both of my hands; tears were streaming down her cheeks; it seemed like she couldn't get enough of hugging and shaking my hand. "You don't look as much like your mother as I thought, but it doesn't matter at all, I'm so glad to see you!" she said. "Oh my dear, I could just eat those cheeks of yours! Kids, your cousin Tom is here!.. Say welcome to him."
es: He hugged me and then took both of my hands and squeezed them many times, not stopping from saying: "You don't look as much like your mother as I thought, but the truth is I don't care at all. I'm so glad to see you! My God, my God, I could just eat you up! Kids, this is your cousin Tom! Come on, say hello to him.

en: But they ducked their heads, and put their fingers in their mouths, and hid behind her. So she run on:
vi: But they still put their fingers in their mouths and hid behind their mother. She continued:
tr: But the little ones hid even further behind their mother, watching me with their fingers in their mouths. The woman called out inside:
es: But they lowered their heads, put their fingers in their mouths, and hid behind their mother's skirts. Then she continued saying:

en: “Lize, hurry up and get him a hot breakfast right away—or did you get your breakfast on the boat?”
vi: - Lize, bring the hot food up for you. Or have you already had breakfast on the train?
tr: “Lize, quickly prepare a hot breakfast for him… Or did you have breakfast on the ferry?”
es: —Lize, quickly, prepare him a hot breakfast right now. Or did you already have breakfast on the boat?

en: I said I had got it on the boat. So then she started for the house, leading me by the hand, and the children tagging after. When we got there she set me down in a split-bottomed chair, and set herself down on a little low stool in front of me, holding both of my hands, and says:
vi: I said I had eaten on the train. She led me into the house, the children running behind. Once inside, my grandmother sat me down on a reclining chair, then she sat down on a small stool, took my hands, and asked:
tr: I said that I had breakfast on the ferry. Upon this, he grabbed my hand and dragged me towards the house, with the children following us. When we arrived at the house, he sat me down on a wicker chair, and he settled on a small stool directly opposite me. Taking my hands in his palms, he began to speak again:
es: I said that I had breakfast on the boat. Then she went towards the house holding my hand, and the children came behind. When we arrived, she made me sit in a wicker chair and she sat on a low stool in front of me, holding both of my hands, and she goes and says:

en: “Now I can have a good look at you; and, laws-a-me, I’ve been hungry for it a many and a many a time, all these long years, and it’s come at last! We been expecting you a couple of days and more. What kep’ you?—boat get aground?”
vi: - Now, let me take a good look at my nephew's face. It's been worth all these years of waiting for you. Why are you so late, did the train run aground?
tr: “Now let me take a good look at you; My God, I have wanted to see you for so many years, and finally, we have met! We were expecting you a few days ago. Why were you so late?.. Did the steamer run aground?”
es: —Now I can look at you properly and, God bless me, I have been longing to see you all these years, and finally you have arrived! We have been waiting for you for two days or more. Why did it take you so long? Did the ship run aground?

en: “Yes’m—she—”
vi: - Madam, yes, the train is...
tr: “Yes, ma'am...”
es: —Yes, ma'am... it's just that...

en: “Don’t say yes’m—say Aunt Sally. Where’d she get aground?”
vi: - Don't call me grandma, call me Aunt Saly. So where did the ship run aground?
tr: "Don't call me ma'am, call me Aunt Sally." "Where did it run aground?"
es: —Don't call me yes ma'am; call me Aunt Sally. Where did it run aground?

en: I didn’t rightly know what to say, because I didn’t know whether the boat would be coming up the river or down. But I go a good deal on instinct; and my instinct said she would be coming up—from down towards Orleans. That didn’t help me much, though; for I didn’t know the names of bars down that way. I see I’d got to invent a bar, or forget the name of the one we got aground on—or—Now I struck an idea, and fetched it out:
vi: I don't know how to say it right away, because I don't know if the boat is coming down from above or going up from below. But I guess it's the boat coming up from Orleans. But even so, I'm still not at ease because I don't know the names of the docks down there. I think I need to make up a name or pretend to forget the place where it got stuck, or...
tr: Suddenly, I didn't know what to say because I didn't know whether the steamboat was coming from upstream or downstream. But the best thing was to trust my instincts; according to my instincts, the steamboat was coming from downstream, from the direction of Orleans. But this information was of no use to me because I didn't know where the steamboat could run aground on its way here. So, I would either have to make up a name of a sandbar or say that I forgot where we ran aground... Then another idea suddenly came to my mind:
es: I didn't know exactly what to say, because I didn't know if the boat would come upstream or downstream. But I do many things by instinct, and my instinct said it would come upstream from Orleans more or less. But that didn't help me much either, because I didn't know the names of the bars in that part. I saw that I would have to invent a bar or forget the name of the one we had run aground on or... Then an idea occurred to me and I blurted it out.

en: “It warn’t the grounding—that didn’t keep us back but a little. We blowed out a cylinder-head.”
vi: Suddenly, an idea came to me, and I said: - It's not that the ship got stuck, it's that the boiler exploded.
tr: “The reason for our delay was not that we ran aground. One of the cylinder heads exploded.”
es: —It wasn't the grounding... That didn't delay us much. It was that a cylinder head blew out.

en: “Good gracious! anybody hurt?”
vi: - Lord, is there anything wrong?
tr: "Oh my God! Did anything happen to anyone?""
es: —My God! Is anyone injured?

en: “No’m. Killed a nigger.”
vi: - No, sir, only one black man was killed.
tr: “No, ma'am. Only a black man died.”
es: —No, ma'am. He killed a black man.

en: “Well, it’s lucky; because sometimes people do get hurt. Two years ago last Christmas your uncle Silas was coming up from Newrleans on the old Lally Rook, and she blowed out a cylinder-head and crippled a man. And I think he died afterwards. He was a Baptist. Your uncle Silas knowed a family in Baton Rouge that knowed his people very well. Yes, I remember now, he did die. Mortification set in, and they had to amputate him. But it didn’t save him. Yes, it was mortification—that was it. He turned blue all over, and died in the hope of a glorious resurrection. They say he was a sight to look at. Your uncle’s been up to the town every day to fetch you. And he’s gone again, not more’n an hour ago; he’ll be back any minute now. You must a met him on the road, didn’t you?—oldish man, with a—”
vi: - Lucky. The last few times, there were still people getting injured. Two years ago, your Uncle Silas came up from New Orleans, and the Lally Rock steamboat also had a boiler explosion that injured someone. It seems that person died later. Uncle Silas knew a family in Baton Rouge who knew him well. Oh, I remember now, he did die. Uncle Silas always mentions you whenever he comes here. He just left less than an hour ago and will be back soon. You must have met him on the way, right? He's old, so he's a bit confused...
tr: “Anyway, you were lucky; because sometimes people get hurt too. Two years ago, around Christmas time, Uncle Silas was coming from New Orleans with the old Lally Rook when the steamboat's cylinder cover exploded and a man was crippled. I think he died later. The man was a Baptist. Uncle Silas knew a family from Baton Rouge who knew that family well. Yes, now I remember, the man had died. He got gangrene, and they had to amputate one of his limbs. But he still couldn't be saved. Of course, he had gangrene… now I remember. The man turned purple and died with the hope of resurrection by God's grace on Judgment Day. They say he had a very strange appearance. Uncle went to town every day to bring you. He went to town again about an hour ago; he will be here soon. You must have met him on the way… An elderly man…”
es: —Well, thank goodness; because sometimes those things kill someone. Last Christmas it was two years since your uncle Silas came from New Orleans on the old Lally Rook and blew a cylinder head and left a man paralyzed. And I think he died afterward. He was a Baptist. Your uncle Silas knew a family from Baton Rouge that knew his very well. Yes, now I remember he did indeed die. He got gangrene and they had to amputate. But even that didn't save him. Yes, it was gangrene, that's what it was. He turned all blue and died with the hope of a glorious resurrection. They say it was scary to see him. Your uncle has gone to town every day to look for you, and he just went out again only an hour ago; he must be about to return. You must have met him on the road, right? Older now, with a...

en: “No, I didn’t see nobody, Aunt Sally. The boat landed just at daylight, and I left my baggage on the wharf-boat and went looking around the town and out a piece in the country, to put in the time and not get here too soon; and so I come down the back way.”
vi: - I didn't meet anyone, Aunt Saly. The ship docked early in the morning, I left my luggage at the dock and wandered around the town to avoid coming back here too early.
tr: “No, I didn't see anyone, Aunt Sally. The ferry arrived at dawn, and I left my belongings on a ship at the dock and wandered around the town a bit, and then in the countryside; I thought I’d pass the time so I wouldn’t arrive here too early; that’s why I came from the back.”
es: —No, I haven't seen anyone, Aunt Sally. The boat arrived just at dawn, I left my luggage on the dock and went for a walk around the town and also through the countryside to pass the time and not arrive too early; that's why I came in from the back.

en: “Who’d you give the baggage to?”
vi: - Who do you give the luggage to?
tr: “To whom did you leave your belongings?”
es: —To whom did you give the luggage?

en: “Nobody.”
vi: - I didn't send it to anyone
tr: “To no one.”
es: —No one.

en: “Why, child, it’ll be stole!”
vi: - What if someone steals it?
tr: “But they will steal, my nephew!”
es: —But, child, they are going to steal it from you!

en: “Not where I hid it I reckon it won’t,” I says.
vi: - No, I hid it in a very secret place, no one can take it.
tr: "No one can find it where I have hidden it," I said.
es: —No, where I hid it, I don't think so —I said.

en: “How’d you get your breakfast so early on the boat?”
vi: - If you arrive so early, how will you be able to have breakfast?
tr: “So, how did you have breakfast on the ferry so early in the morning?”
es: —How is it that you had breakfast so early on the ship?

en: It was kinder thin ice, but I says:
vi: I was worried about how to respond, but then I replied:
tr: I felt cornered, but I immediately responded:
es: Things were getting difficult, but I responded.

en: “The captain see me standing around, and told me I better have something to eat before I went ashore; so he took me in the texas to the officers’ lunch, and give me all I wanted.”
vi: - The captain saw you standing nearby and took you to the sailors' dining room, where he gave you a lot of food.
tr: “The captain saw me wandering around and told me to eat something before going ashore; he took me to the place where the officers eat in the captain's cabin and I ate everything I wanted.”
es: —The captain saw me up and thought it would be better if I ate something before disembarking, so he took me to the upper cabins, where the officers eat, and gave me everything I wanted.

en: I was getting so uneasy I couldn’t listen good. I had my mind on the children all the time; I wanted to get them out to one side and pump them a little, and find out who I was. But I couldn’t get no show, Mrs. Phelps kept it up and run on so. Pretty soon she made the cold chills streak all down my back, because she says:
vi: I felt restless so I couldn't hear clearly anymore. I just wanted to pull those kids away immediately to inquire about who I am. But Mrs. Phelps kept clinging to me, asking me one thing after another. A moment later, she asked me a question that startled me.
tr: I was so on edge that I couldn't properly understand what was being said. My mind was always on the children; I wanted to pull them aside and press them a bit to find out who I was. But I couldn't find an opportunity. Mrs. Phelps kept talking nonstop. Soon, I shivered from head to toe because she said:
es: I was getting so nervous that I wasn't paying attention. I was thinking about the children all the time; I wanted to take them away to get some information from them to find out who I was. But there was no way. Mrs. Phelps did nothing but talk. After a while, I got chills all over my body because she said:

en: “But here we’re a-running on this way, and you hain’t told me a word about Sis, nor any of them. Now I’ll rest my works a little, and you start up yourn; just tell me everything—tell me all about ’m all every one of ’m; and how they are, and what they’re doing, and what they told you to tell me; and every last thing you can think of.”
vi: - Well, now tell me about your mother and everyone in your family. Whatever you think and remember, just tell me everything.
tr: “But I've been talking for two hours and you haven't said a word about your brother or anyone else. Now let me rest a bit and you tell me; tell me everything... Are they in good health, what are they doing, what did they tell you to convey to me; tell me everything that comes to your mind.”
es: —But here we are talking and you still haven't told me anything about my sister or the others. Now I'll stop talking and it's your turn; tell me everything, tell me how everyone is, down to the last one, how they're doing, what they're up to, what they've told you to tell me, and everything you remember.

en: Well, I see I was up a stump—and up it good. Providence had stood by me this fur all right, but I was hard and tight aground now. I see it warn’t a bit of use to try to go ahead—I’d got to throw up my hand. So I says to myself, here’s another place where I got to resk the truth. I opened my mouth to begin; but she grabbed me and hustled me in behind the bed, and says:
vi: I was speechless. God has abandoned me. Well, I have no choice but to risk it. I opened my mouth to speak, but suddenly she pulled me aside, pushed me behind the bed, and said:
tr: This time I was in a real fix – I was truly stuck. Until that moment, God had been my helper, but from then on, there was no corner left to escape to. There was no point in pretending any longer... It was time to throw in the towel. Here was another situation where I had to risk telling the truth, I said to myself. Just as I was about to open my mouth, the woman grabbed me and pushed me to the back of the bed.
es: Well, I understood that I was in real trouble. Providence had supported me up to that moment, but now it was up to me to manage as best I could. I saw that it was useless to try to start: I had to confess the truth. So I said to myself: "Now I have to risk telling the truth again." I opened my mouth to start speaking, but she grabbed me, hid me behind the bed, and then she says:

en: “Here he comes! Stick your head down lower—there, that’ll do; you can’t be seen now. Don’t you let on you’re here. I’ll play a joke on him. Children, don’t you say a word.”
vi: - Come back here! Lower your head, lower, so you can't see anything. Auntie is teasing you for fun. Kids, don't say anything, okay?
tr: "Here comes your brother-in-law!" "Hide there immediately..." "hah, perfect; now no one can see you." "Don't let on that you're here." "We're going to play a good prank on your brother-in-law now." "Kids, don't let anything slip from your mouths.""
es: —Here he comes! Lower your head more; good, that's fine, now he can't see you. Don't let him notice you're here. I want to play a prank on him. Kids, don't say a word.

en: I see I was in a fix now. But it warn’t no use to worry; there warn’t nothing to do but just hold still, and try and be ready to stand from under when the lightning struck.
vi: Now, I am in a difficult situation, but worrying is useless, the only thing to do is stand still and be ready to die.
tr: I had no way out anymore. But at that moment, there was no point in worrying; there was nothing I could do except stand still where I was, and then I would try to stay standing when the lightning struck:
es: I saw that I was getting myself into another mess, but there was no point in worrying; there was nothing to do but stay quiet and try to escape when the storm broke out.

en: I had just one little glimpse of the old gentleman when he come in; then the bed hid him. Mrs. Phelps she jumps for him, and says:
vi: The old man walked into the house. Blocked by the bed, I couldn't see anything. Mrs. Phelps rushed out and asked:
tr: I saw the elderly gentleman who entered for a moment, then his face remained at the top of the bed. Ms. Phelps jumped towards him excitedly:
es: I could barely see the old man when he entered because the bed blocked my view afterward. Mrs. Phelps jumped and asked:

en: “Has he come?”
vi: - Has it arrived yet?
tr: "Has he/she/it arrived?""
es: —Has he/she arrived?

en: “No,” says her husband.
vi: - Not yet - The husband replied.
tr: “No,” said her husband.
es: —No —her husband replied.

en: “Good-ness gracious!” she says, “what in the warld can have become of him?”
vi: - Or has something bad happened again?
tr: “Wow wow!” said the woman, “I wonder if something happened to him?”
es: —Good heavens! —she said—, what could have happened to him?

en: “I can’t imagine,” says the old gentleman; “and I must say it makes me dreadful uneasy.”
vi: The man replied: - I don't know.
tr: "I don't know," said the old gentleman; "to be honest, I'm very worried."
es: —I can't imagine it —said the old man—, and I must confess that I don't feel at ease at all.

en: “Uneasy!” she says; “I’m ready to go distracted! He must a come; and you’ve missed him along the road. I know it’s so—something tells me so.”
vi: I'm also very worried. - What? I'm going crazy here.
tr: “Are you worried!” said his wife, “I'm about to lose my mind! He should have arrived by now, maybe you didn't see him. I'm sure you didn't see him... A voice inside me says so.”
es: —Calm down! —she said— I'm about to go crazy! He must have arrived, it's just that you didn't see him on the way. I'm sure that's what happened. Something tells me so.

en: “Why, Sally, I couldn’t miss him along the road—you know that.”
vi: It should have arrived by now, or did you not see it on the way?
tr: “There’s no way I can pass by without seeing him, Sally… you know that very well.”
es: —But, Sally, it's impossible that he didn't see it, and you know it.

en: “But oh, dear, dear, what will Sis say! He must a come! You must a missed him. He—”
vi: - Saly, how could you meet and not recognize her? - She will definitely avoid me. She should have arrived here by now. Maybe you just didn't see her. She...
tr: “Oh my God, what will my sister say about this? She should have arrived by now! You must have definitely missed her.”
es: —But, oh my God, my God, what will my sister say? She must have arrived. It must be that you haven't seen her. It must...

en: “Oh, don’t distress me any more’n I’m already distressed. I don’t know what in the world to make of it. I’m at my wit’s end, and I don’t mind acknowledging ’t I’m right down scared. But there’s no hope that he’s come; for he couldn’t come and me miss him. Sally, it’s terrible—just terrible—something’s happened to the boat, sure!”
vi: - Please, don't say anything more. I'm also feeling very anxious right now. But there's no reason for it to have arrived, it can't have arrived without me meeting it. This is terrible, something must have happened on the ship.
tr: “I’m already eating myself up inside, don’t pressure me any more. I really don’t know what I can do. I’ve reached the end of my patience and I’ve been on edge since morning. But there’s no way it could have arrived, because if it had, it wouldn’t have missed me. Sally, this is very terrible… very much so… something definitely happened to the ferry!”
es: —Well, don't worry me more than I already am. I don't know how the hell to understand it. I don't know what to think anymore and I don't mind admitting that I'm terrified. But it's not possible that he arrived because he couldn't have arrived without me seeing him. Sally, this is horrible, simply horrible... Something must have happened to the ship!

en: “Why, Silas! Look yonder!—up the road!—ain’t that somebody coming?”
vi: - Look, Silas, do you see on the road over there, is someone coming?
tr: “Silas! Look over there! Is someone coming down the road?”
es: —Look, Silas! Look over there! On the road! Is someone coming?

en: He sprung to the window at the head of the bed, and that give Mrs. Phelps the chance she wanted. She stooped down quick at the foot of the bed and give me a pull, and out I come; and when he turned back from the window there she stood, a-beaming and a-smiling like a house afire, and I standing pretty meek and sweaty alongside. The old gentleman stared, and says:
vi: He leaned out of the window right above the bed, and at that moment she quickly bent down to the foot of the bed to pull me out. I stepped out, and when he turned back, he saw his wife standing there smiling, her face as red as a stove, while I stood next to her, timid and fearful. He stared at me and then asked:
tr: Adam immediately rushed to the window at the head of the bed, and thus Mrs. Phelps found the opportunity she was looking for. She quickly reached towards the foot of the bed and pulled me out; when the man turned back, Mrs. Phelps was grinning with all her teeth showing, and I was standing beside her obediently and drenched in sweat. The old man stared intently:
es: He jumped to the window next to the head of the bed and gave Mrs. Phelps the opportunity she was looking for. She leaned at the foot of the bed and gave me a tug to pull me out; and when her husband turned from the window, there she was, all smiling and radiant like the sun, and I beside her, quiet and sweaty. The old man looks at me and says:

en: “Why, who’s that?”
vi: - Who is that?
tr: “Who is this?”
es: —But, who is that?

en: “Who do you reckon ’t is?”
vi: - Don't you know who that is?
tr: “Who are you?”
es: —Who do you think he is?

en: “I hain’t no idea. Who is it?”
vi: - Don't you know who that is? - No, I give up.
tr: "I have no idea. Who was it?"
es: —I have no idea. Who is it?

en: “It’s Tom Sawyer!”
vi: - It's Tom Sawyer!
tr: "It's Tom Sawyer himself!""
es: —It's Tom Sawyer!

en: By jings, I most slumped through the floor! But there warn’t no time to swap knives; the old man grabbed me by the hand and shook, and kept on shaking; and all the time how the woman did dance around and laugh and cry; and then how they both did fire off questions about Sid, and Mary, and the rest of the tribe.
vi: I almost fainted and collapsed to the ground. But the man grabbed my hand and kept shaking it, while his wife jumped around, laughing and talking. The couple asked me countless questions about Sid, Mary, and all the relatives.
tr: My God, my knees gave way, I almost fell to the ground. But before I could pull myself together, the old man hugged me and shook my hand; while he was shaking my hand, the woman was jumping around us, both laughing and crying; then both of them started bombarding me with questions about Sid, Mary, and the rest of the tribe.
es: I swear I almost fell to the ground! But I didn't have time to change tactics; the old man grabbed my hand and shook it over and over, and all the while the woman danced around us laughing and crying; then the two of them started asking me loads of questions about Sid and Mary and the rest of the tribe.

en: But if they was joyful, it warn’t nothing to what I was; for it was like being born again, I was so glad to find out who I was. Well, they froze to me for two hours; and at last, when my chin was so tired it couldn’t hardly go any more, I had told them more about my family—I mean the Sawyer family—than ever happened to any six Sawyer families. And I explained all about how we blowed out a cylinder-head at the mouth of White River, and it took us three days to fix it. Which was all right, and worked first-rate; because they didn’t know but what it would take three days to fix it. If I’d a called it a bolthead it would a done just as well.
vi: But if they were happy one-fold, I was happy ten-fold. I felt as if I was born anew, I was joyful because I knew who I was. The past two hours, I was scared out of my wits. I also told them many more things about my family - that is, about Tom Sawyer's family. Then I recounted the story of the boiler explosion on the White River, and how I had to stay there for three days.
tr: They were very happy, but I couldn't contain my joy; because I felt like I was reborn, I was very pleased to learn who I was. They continued with their questions for two hours; finally, my jaw was too tired to speak; I had told them so much about my family – that is, the Sawyer family – that it would have been enough for at least six Sawyer families. I also told them how the cylinder head blew at the mouth of the White River and how they spent three days repairing it. There was no problem here either, in fact, it was quite convincing; because they had no idea whether it would take three days to repair a cylinder head. They would probably have believed me just as much if I had said a bolt had broken.
es: But if they were happy, that was nothing compared to me, because it was like being born again. I was overjoyed to find out who I was. Well, they stuck with me for two hours, and finally, when my tongue was so tired that I could hardly move it, I had already told them more things about my family (I mean the Sawyer family) than could have happened to six Sawyer families combined. And I explained all the details of how a cylinder head had blown at the mouth of the White River and it had taken us three days to fix it. Which was very good and worked wonderfully, because they didn't know if it took three days to fix it. If I had told them that we had blown a bolt, they wouldn't have cared.

en: Now I was feeling pretty comfortable all down one side, and pretty uncomfortable all up the other. Being Tom Sawyer was easy and comfortable, and it stayed easy and comfortable till by-and-by I hear a steamboat coughing along down the river. Then I says to myself, s’pose Tom Sawyer comes down on that boat? And s’pose he steps in here any minute, and sings out my name before I can throw him a wink to keep quiet? Well, I couldn’t have it that way; it wouldn’t do at all. I must go up the road and waylay him. So I told the folks I reckoned I would go up to the town and fetch down my baggage. The old gentleman was for going along with me, but I said no, I could drive the horse myself, and I druther he wouldn’t take no trouble about me.
vi: By this time, I felt quite at ease, but there were still many things to worry about. Playing the role of Tom Sawyer was very easy, but my heart skipped a beat whenever I heard the chugging sound of a boat on the river because what if Tom was on that boat? It can't be left like this. I have to go out on the street to pick it up first. Thinking that, I told everyone that I wanted to go get the luggage. The husband also wanted to go with me, but I refused, as I could drive the carriage myself and didn't want to trouble him.
tr: While on one hand I felt very comfortable, on the other hand I didn't feel comfortable at all. Being Tom Sawyer was very easy and comfortable; this ease and comfort lasted until I heard the sound of a steamboat from the river – but then I said to myself, what if Tom Sawyer is on that steamboat? What if he suddenly appears and says my name before I can even wink at him to keep quiet? I couldn't allow this – then all my plans would be ruined. I had to go up the road and meet him. So I told my aunts that I would go to town and get my things. The big man was going to come with me, but I didn't agree, I could ride the horse by myself, there was no need for him to bother.
es: Now I felt very calm on one hand and very uneasy on the other. Being Tom Sawyer was easy and comfortable for me, and it continued to be so until after a while I heard a steamboat coming down the river. Then I said to myself: "What if Tom Sawyer is on that boat? What if he arrives at any moment and calls me by my name before I can give him a wink to not say anything?" Well, I couldn't let it happen because it would ruin everything. I had to go to the road and stop it in time. So I told those two that I would go to town to fetch my luggage. The old man wanted to come with me, but I told him no, that I could drive the horse myself and that I preferred he didn't trouble himself for me.

en: CHAPTER XXXIII.
vi: Chapter XXXIII
tr: Thirty-Third Chapter
es: Chapter 33

en: So I started for town in the wagon, and when I was half-way I see a wagon coming, and sure enough it was Tom Sawyer, and I stopped and waited till he come along. I says “Hold on!” and it stopped alongside, and his mouth opened up like a trunk, and stayed so; and he swallowed two or three times like a person that’s got a dry throat, and then says:
vi: I drove the horse-drawn carriage to the town. Halfway there, I encountered another carriage coming towards me. It was indeed Tom Sawyer. I stopped the carriage and waited for him to come closer. I shouted: - Stop the car! Tom opened his mouth wide, stood still in silence, swallowed a few times, and then said:
tr: So I jumped into the car and set off towards the town; I had just reached halfway when I saw a car coming from the opposite direction. I immediately recognized Tom Sawyer, stopped where I was, and waited until he approached. When I shouted "Stop!", the driver pulled the reins right beside me. Tom stared with his mouth open, then after swallowing two or three times as if his throat was dry, he managed to speak:
es: SO I SET off towards the town with the cart, and when I was halfway there, I saw another cart coming, and sure enough, it was Tom Sawyer, so I stopped and waited until he arrived. I said to him: "Stop!", and he stopped next to me, opened his mouth wide, and stayed like that; he swallowed two or three times, just like a priest when his throat gets dry, and then he said:

en: “I hain’t ever done you no harm. You know that. So, then, what you want to come back and ha’nt me for?”
vi: - I haven't done anything to harm you. Why do you still come back here to scare me?
tr: "I had never done anything bad to you. You know this. Why did you come back to haunt me now?"
es: —I never did anything bad to you. And you know it. So, why have you started chasing me again?

en: I says:
vi: I said:
tr: “I didn't come back,” I said, “because I never left.”
es: I replied:

en: “I hain’t come back—I hain’t been gone.”
vi: - I didn't die, so why would I come back as a ghost?
tr: “I didn't come back,” I said, “because I never left.”
es: —I haven't returned... I never left.

en: When he heard my voice it righted him up some, but he warn’t quite satisfied yet. He says:
vi: Hearing my voice, it seemed less scared, but still trembling. It said
tr: When he heard my voice, he came to his senses a bit, but he was still not fully convinced.
es: When he heard my voice, he calmed down a bit, but he still wasn't entirely convinced. He said:

en: “Don’t you play nothing on me, because I wouldn’t on you. Honest injun now, you ain’t a ghost?”
vi: - You're not kidding me, are you? You're not a ghost, are you?
tr: “Don't play games with me, have I ever played with you? Tell the truth, are you a ghost or not?”
es: —Don't do anything bad to me, because I wouldn't do it to you. Do you swear that you are not a ghost?

en: “Honest injun, I ain’t,” I says.
vi: - I'm not a ghost.
tr: “I'm telling the truth, I'm not,” I said.
es: —I swear it —I replied.

en: “Well—I—I—well, that ought to settle it, of course; but I can’t somehow seem to understand it no way. Looky here, warn’t you ever murdered at all?”
vi: - But I still don't understand. So, weren't you killed?
tr: “Well then… I… I… now I believe of course; but I still can't understand. Weren't you killed?”
es: —Well... I... Well, of course that should be enough, but the truth is I don't understand anything. Look, have you never been murdered?

en: “No. I warn’t ever murdered at all—I played it on them. You come in here and feel of me if you don’t believe me.”
vi: - No, I have never been killed. Come closer and if you don't believe it, just touch me and see.
tr: Weren't you killed?” "Yo. I wasn't killed... I had arranged everything. If you don't believe me, come and touch me."
es: —No. They never killed me... It was a trick of mine. Come closer and touch me if you don't believe me.

en: So he done it; and it satisfied him; and he was that glad to see me again he didn’t know what to do. And he wanted to know all about it right off, because it was a grand adventure, and mysterious, and so it hit him where he lived. But I said, leave it alone till by-and-by; and told his driver to wait, and we drove off a little piece, and I told him the kind of a fix I was in, and what did he reckon we better do? He said, let him alone a minute, and don’t disturb him. So he thought and thought, and pretty soon he says:
vi: It came close to touch me, realizing it was true, it was so happy but it didn't know what to do yet. And it wanted to know everything immediately, but I told it I would explain later, and for now, to tell the driver to wait. Then I pulled it aside, told it about my dilemma, and asked how to handle it. After thinking for a minute, it said:
tr: When he finally touched me, he believed it, he was so happy to see me again that he didn't know what to do. He immediately wanted me to tell him everything because I had experienced a tremendous and mysterious adventure, which was just his kind of thing. But I said we should leave the talking for later; I asked the driver to wait a bit and took Tom aside. I told him what kind of trouble we were in and asked what the best solution would be. He asked me to leave him alone for a minute and not to disturb him at all. After thinking deeply for a while, he turned to me:
es: That was what he did, and he was convinced, and he was so happy to see me again that he didn't know what to do. He wanted to find out everything immediately, because it was a great mysterious adventure, so it was what he liked. But I told him to leave all that for later and told his coachman to wait, and we moved aside a bit and I told him the problem I had and asked him what he thought was best to do. He said to let him think for a moment and not to tell him anything. So he kept thinking and thinking, and after a moment he goes and says:

en: “It’s all right; I’ve got it. Take my trunk in your wagon, and let on it’s your’n; and you turn back and fool along slow, so as to get to the house about the time you ought to; and I’ll go towards town a piece, and take a fresh start, and get there a quarter or a half an hour after you; and you needn’t let on to know me at first.”
vi: - Alright, I've got a plan. Take my chest, put it in your car and act like it's yours, then you drive back slowly, timing it so you get home just in time. I'll head to the city for a bit and then start back, arriving about fifteen minutes or half an hour after you, and at first, you have to act like you don't know who I am.
tr: “Alright, I found it. Let's put my stuff in your car, and you'll act like it's your stuff. Now go back and slowly head towards home, you should return at the time you are supposed to. I'll first go back to the town, then I'll hit the road again and follow you fifteen minutes or half an hour later.
es: —Alright; I have it now. Put my trunk in your cart and say it's yours; and come back slowly, so you arrive at the house around the estimated time; I will retrace my steps a bit to start over and arrive a quarter or half an hour after you, and at first, you don't have to say that you know me.

en: I says:
vi: I said:
tr: At first, don't let on that you know me.”
es: I replied:

en: “All right; but wait a minute. There’s one more thing—a thing that nobody don’t know but me. And that is, there’s a nigger here that I’m a-trying to steal out of slavery, and his name is Jim—old Miss Watson’s Jim.”
vi: - Wait a minute. There's one more thing. That is, there's a black man here, I'm trying to save him from being enslaved, his name is Jim. Miss Watson's Jim, you know.right
tr: “Alright, but wait a minute,” I said. “There is one more issue… An issue that no one else knows but me. There is a black man here whom I am trying to free from slavery… His name is Jim… he is Miss Watson’s black man.”
es: —Very well, but wait a moment. There is something else: something that no one else knows but me, and that is that there is a black man there whom I want to steal to set him free, and his name is Jim; Miss Watson's old Jim.

en: He says:
vi: It was surprised:
tr: “What did you say?
es: And he goes and says:

en: “What! Why, Jim is—”
vi: - What? Jim?
tr: “What did you say? But Jim…”
es: —What! But Jim already...

en: He stopped and went to studying. I says:
vi: He... he... . I said immediately:
tr: He suddenly fell silent and began to think again. “I know what you're going to say,” I said.
es: He stopped and kept thinking about it, and then I go and say:

en: “I know what you’ll say. You’ll say it’s dirty, low-down business; but what if it is? I’m low down; and I’m a-going to steal him, and I want you keep mum and not let on. Will you?”
vi: - I know what you're going to say. You're going to say this is a bad, despicable thing: but so what? I know it's not good, but I'm going to steal it. You have to keep it a secret and not tell anyone, okay?
tr: “I know what you're going to say,” I said. “You're going to say that this is a very dirty and vile job, but no matter what... I accept its vileness and I will definitely save him, so I want you to stay silent and not let anyone suspect anything. Will you do this?”
es: —I know what you're going to say. You're going to say that it's a dirty and vile matter, but what do I care? I'm vile and I'm going to steal it and I want you to stay quiet and not say anything. Do you want to?

en: His eye lit up, and he says:
vi: Its eyes lit up:
tr: Tom's eyes sparkled.
es: His eyes lit up and he said:

en: “I’ll help you steal him!”
vi: - I will help you steal it back!
tr: "I will help you save him!"
es: —I'm going to help you steal it!

en: Well, I let go all holts then, like I was shot. It was the most astonishing speech I ever heard—and I’m bound to say Tom Sawyer fell considerable in my estimation. Only I couldn’t believe it. Tom Sawyer a nigger stealer!
vi: - I will help you steal it back! What surprised me the most was that I had never heard of it and I am ready to say that Tom deserves a lot of my admiration. But the thing is, I still can't believe it, Tom Sawyer as a person who would steal black people??
tr: I was almost speechless with astonishment. These were the most surprising words that had ever come out of Tom's mouth until that day... Additionally, I must say that Tom Sawyer had significantly fallen in my esteem. But on the other hand, I couldn't believe it. Tom Sawyer, the Negro thief!
es: I was stunned, as if I had been shot. That was the most astonishing thing I had ever heard in my life, and I have to say that Tom Sawyer fell a lot in my esteem. I just couldn't believe it. Tom turned into a thief of black people!

en: “Oh, shucks!” I says; “you’re joking.”
vi: I said: - Stop it, don't joke like that. - I'm being serious.
tr: “No way, you must be joking,” I said.
es: —Well, let's go! —I said—. You're joking.

en: “I ain’t joking, either.”
vi: I said:
tr: “I am not joking at all.”
es: —Joking, nothing.

en: “Well, then,” I says, “joking or no joking, if you hear anything said about a runaway nigger, don’t forget to remember that you don’t know nothing about him, and I don’t know nothing about him.”
vi: - Alright, joke or no joke, if you hear about a runaway black man, you have to remember that you know nothing about him, and I know nothing about him either.
tr: “Anyway, whether it's a joke or not, if you hear talk about a runaway black man, don't let on that you know anything, remember I don't know anything either.”
es: —Well, then —I said—, joke or not, if you hear anything about a runaway black man, don't forget that you know nothing about him and neither do I.

en: Then we took the trunk and put it in my wagon, and he drove off his way and I drove mine. But of course I forgot all about driving slow on accounts of being glad and full of thinking; so I got home a heap too quick for that length of a trip. The old gentleman was at the door, and he says:
vi: He went to get the chest and put it in my car, then he went his way, and I went mine. But somehow I completely forgot to drive slowly, because I was too excited and thinking about many things. As a result, I got home too quickly. Mr. Phelps was standing at the door waiting for me, and when he saw that I had returned, he said:
tr: Then we took the chest and put it in my car, he went his way, and I went mine.
