But of course, I had completely forgotten what he said about driving slowly, I was very happy and my head was full of thoughts; I returned home in an unusually short time for that journey. The old man was standing at the door:
es: Then he took out his trunk and put it in my cart, and he went on his way and I went on mine. But, naturally, I forgot that I had to go slowly because I was so happy and full of ideas, so I arrived home too early for such a long trip. The old man was at the door and says:

en: “Why, this is wonderful! Whoever would a thought it was in that mare to do it? I wish we’d a timed her. And she hain’t sweated a hair—not a hair. It’s wonderful. Why, I wouldn’t take a hundred dollars for that horse now—I wouldn’t, honest; and yet I’d a sold her for fifteen before, and thought ’twas all she was worth.”
vi: - Well, I never expected this horse to run so fast. And yet it doesn't sweat a bit, not a single hair is wet. It's amazing. Now, even if someone offers a hundred dollars, I wouldn't sell it anymore. Yet before, I intended to sell it for just fifteen dollars, thinking that's all it was worth.
tr: “Isn't this wonderful? Who would have guessed that this mare could accomplish such a feat. I thought she was getting old. And she hasn't even broken a sweat, wow. Truly magnificent. Now, I'll sell this horse to anyone who kisses my hand for a hundred dollars; whereas this morning, I was lamenting that she wasn't even worth fifteen dollars and thought I couldn't ask for more.”
es: —Man, what a marvel! Who would have thought that mare was capable of running so much! I wish we had timed her. And she hasn't sweated a drop, not a single drop. She is a marvel. Man, now I wouldn't accept even a hundred dollars for that mare, really, and yet before I would have sold her for fifteen and been quite happy.

en: That’s all he said. He was the innocentest, best old soul I ever see. But it warn’t surprising; because he warn’t only just a farmer, he was a preacher, too, and had a little one-horse log church down back of the plantation, which he built it himself at his own expense, for a church and schoolhouse, and never charged nothing for his preaching, and it was worth it, too. There was plenty other farmer-preachers like that, and done the same way, down South.
vi: He only said maybe. I have never seen an old man as kind and gentle as him. He was originally a landowner and also served as a pastor. He personally spent money to build a church at the end of the plantation, and he preached there without taking any money. In the South, there are many people who are both landowners and pastors like that.
tr: He didn't say anything else. He was the kindest-hearted, most well-intentioned man I had ever seen until that day. But this was not surprising, because he was not only a farmer but also a priest, and he had a tiny church at the back of the plantation. He had paid for the expenses of the church and the classroom out of his own pocket, and despite giving very good sermons, he didn't take a penny from anyone. There are many farmer-priests like him in the South, and they all behave the same way.
es: He didn't say anything else. He was the most innocent and kindest person I have ever seen in my life. But it wasn't surprising, because he was not only a farmer but also a preacher, and he had a small log church at the back of the plantation that he had built out of his own pocket to serve as a church and a school, and he never charged anything for preaching, and the truth was that he did it very well. Down in the South, there were many farmer-preachers like him who did the same thing.

en: In about half an hour Tom’s wagon drove up to the front stile, and Aunt Sally she see it through the window, because it was only about fifty yards, and says:
vi: About half an hour later, Tom's car arrived in front of the door. Aunt Saly also saw it through the window.
tr: About half an hour later, Tom's car appeared on the road in front, and since the road was only about fifty meters away, Aunt Sally immediately noticed:
es: After about half an hour, Tom's cart appeared at the front door and Aunt Sally saw it through the window, because it was only about fifty yards away, and she said:

en: “Why, there’s somebody come! I wonder who ’tis? Why, I do believe it’s a stranger. Jimmy” (that’s one of the children) “run and tell Lize to put on another plate for dinner.”
vi: She said: - Who could it be? It might be a stranger, Jimmy (the name of a child). Go tell Lize to set an extra plate.
tr: “Aaa, someone is coming! I wonder who? It seems to be a stranger. Jimmy (it was the name of one of the children) run and tell Lize to set another plate on the table.”
es: —Well, someone has come! Who could it be? It seems to be a stranger. Jimmy —who was one of their children—, run and tell Lize to set another plate for the meal.

en: Everybody made a rush for the front door, because, of course, a stranger don’t come every year, and so he lays over the yaller-fever, for interest, when he does come. Tom was over the stile and starting for the house; the wagon was spinning up the road for the village, and we was all bunched in the front door. Tom had his store clothes on, and an audience—and that was always nuts for Tom Sawyer. In them circumstances it warn’t no trouble to him to throw in an amount of style that was suitable. He warn’t a boy to meeky along up that yard like a sheep; no, he come ca’m and important, like the ram. When he got a-front of us he lifts his hat ever so gracious and dainty, like it was the lid of a box that had butterflies asleep in it and he didn’t want to disturb them, and says:
vi: Everyone rushed to the front door because it was very rare for strangers to visit here. Tom had reached the fence and was walking into the house, the carriage continued into the village, and we were all standing outside the door. Tom was dressed in ready-made clothes, looking dignified. He was not a timid person like a sheep. As he approached us, he gracefully and politely took off his hat, as if he were holding a lid with butterflies perched and sleeping on it that he didn't want to disturb. He asked:
tr: Everyone rushed to the front door, because it was not common for a stranger to come to the farm. So the arrival of a stranger caused more excitement than the arrival of yellow fever. Tom was coming towards the house, having passed the fences, the car had turned towards the town, and we were all gathered at the front door. Tom was wearing brand new clothes; and there was a large audience in front of him... This was his moment to shine. It was hard to even imagine how he would show off under such circumstances. He was coming not meekly like a lamb, but upright like a ram. The way he took off his hat and greeted us, you would think he was trying not to disturb the delicate butterflies sleeping underneath it.
es: Everyone rushed to the front door because, naturally, strangers don't arrive every year, so they are more interesting than yellow fever. Tom had already crossed the door and was heading towards the house; the cart was turning towards the town and we were all crowded at the entrance. Tom was wearing the clothes bought at the store and had an audience, which was what Tom Sawyer liked most in the world. In such circumstances, it was not difficult for him to put on all the airs he needed. He was not a boy to arrive meek as a lamb; no, he arrived calmly and with an air of importance, like a ram. When he got in front of us, he took off his hat very elegantly and very finely, as if it were the lid of a box inside which butterflies were sleeping and he didn't want to disturb them, and he goes and says:

en: “Mr. Archibald Nichols, I presume?”
vi: - Excuse me, is this the house of Archibald Nichols? Mr. Phen replied: - That's not right.
tr: "Am I honored to meet Mr. Archibald Nichols?" he said.
es: —Mr. Archibald Nichols, I presume?

en: “No, my boy,” says the old gentleman, “I’m sorry to say ’t your driver has deceived you; Nichols’s place is down a matter of three mile more. Come in, come in.”
vi: I'm sorry, but the coachman has deceived you. Mr. Nichols' house is still three miles away from here. Come in first.
tr: “No; my son,” said the old man, “unfortunately, the coachman has deceived you; Nichols's house is three miles down the road. Come inside. Come inside.”
es: —No, boy —said the old man—. I'm sorry to tell you that your driver has deceived you; Nichols' house is about three miles further. Come in, come in.

en: Tom he took a look back over his shoulder, and says, “Too late—he’s out of sight.”
vi: Tom turned around and said: - It's too late, the bus has gone too far.
tr: Tom turned and looked over his shoulder. "Too late... it's out of sight," he said.
es: Tom glanced over his shoulder and says: —Too late, you can't see it anymore.

en: “Yes, he’s gone, my son, and you must come in and eat your dinner with us; and then we’ll hitch up and take you down to Nichols’s.”
vi: - Come in and have dinner with us first, then we will arrange a car to take you to Mr. Nichols' house.
tr: “Yes, he left, my son, you should come and eat with us; after that, we will get in my car and I will take you to the Nichols’ place.”
es: —Yes, he has gone, my son, and you must come in and eat with us, and then we will harness the mare and take you to Nichols' house.

en: “Oh, I can’t make you so much trouble; I couldn’t think of it. I’ll walk—I don’t mind the distance.”
vi: - Oh, I wouldn't dare trouble you both. It's just a short walk to get there.
tr: "Well, I don't want to trouble you that much; absolutely not. I'll walk... It's not very far."
es: —Ah, I can't cause you so much trouble; not even think about it. I'll go on foot... I don't mind the distance.

en: “But we won’t let you walk—it wouldn’t be Southern hospitality to do it. Come right in.”
vi: - But we won't let you walk. Southern people are very hospitable. Just come in here first.
tr: “But I can't let you walk... It wouldn't befit Southern hospitality. Come inside immediately.”
es: —But we are not going to let you go on foot; that would not be Southern hospitality. Just go on.

en: “Oh, do,” says Aunt Sally; “it ain’t a bit of trouble to us, not a bit in the world. You must stay. It’s a long, dusty three mile, and we can’t let you walk. And, besides, I’ve already told ’em to put on another plate when I see you coming; so you mustn’t disappoint us. Come right in and make yourself at home.”
vi: Aunt Saly said: - Please come in, we don't mind at all. You must stay here for now. The road to there is as far as three miles and very dusty, we can't let you walk. Moreover, we have already set extra plates. Make yourself at home, Thompson.
tr: “Please come in,” said Aunt Sally; “it’s no trouble for us at all, it’s nothing really. You must stay for a while. The road is three miles but everything is covered in dust, we can’t let you walk. In fact, when I saw you coming, I told them to set another plate at the table, don’t disappoint us. Come in and make yourself at home.”
es: —Yes, please —said Aunt Sally—; it's no trouble at all. You must stay. It's three long miles and there's a lot of dust; we can't let you go on foot. And besides, I've already told them to set another plate when I saw you coming, so you mustn't disappoint us. Come inside, make yourself at home.

en: So Tom he thanked them very hearty and handsome, and let himself be persuaded, and come in; and when he was in he said he was a stranger from Hicksville, Ohio, and his name was William Thompson—and he made another bow.
vi: So Tom thanked very enthusiastically and skillfully, pretending to reluctantly step into the house; then he said that he was from Ohio and his name was William Thompson.
tr: Tom sincerely and gracefully thanked them, entered without further ado; after entering, he said he was a stranger from Hicksville, Ohio, that his name was William Thompson, and bowed again in greeting.
es: So Tom thanked them very animatedly and courteously and allowed himself to be persuaded; once inside, he said he was from Hicksville, Ohio, and that his name was William Thompson, and made another bow.

en: Well, he run on, and on, and on, making up stuff about Hicksville and everybody in it he could invent, and I getting a little nervious, and wondering how this was going to help me out of my scrape; and at last, still talking along, he reached over and kissed Aunt Sally right on the mouth, and then settled back again in his chair comfortable, and was going on talking; but she jumped up and wiped it off with the back of her hand, and says:
vi: He rambled on endlessly about all the things he made up in Ohio, and I started to feel uneasy and worried about how he intended to help me get out of this difficult situation. Finally, in the middle of the conversation, he suddenly stood up and kissed Aunt Saly right on the mouth, then sat back down properly in his chair and continued talking. Aunt Saly jerked back, wiped her mouth with the back of her hand, and said:
tr: So he went on and on, making up a bunch of things about Hicksville and the people living there; I was starting to get tense. I was wondering how any of this would provide a solution to our situation; finally, without stopping his speech, he leaned over and kissed Aunt Sally on the mouth, then sat back down in his chair and settled in, about to continue his words when Aunt Sally suddenly jumped up, wiped her lips with the back of her hand, and shouted:
es: Well, he didn't stop talking and talking and talking, making up things about Hicksville and all kinds of people that came to his mind, and I was getting nervous and wondering how that was going to help me out of the predicament; finally, while he was still talking, he got up and gave Aunt Sally a kiss right on the mouth and then sat back down in his chair as calmly as ever and was about to continue talking; but Aunt Sally jumped up, wiped her mouth with the back of her hand, and said:

en: “You owdacious puppy!”
vi: - This boy is too rude!
tr: "You shameless dog!"
es: —You insolent, rude person!

en: He looked kind of hurt, and says:
vi: It seemed to be offended, saying:
tr: Tom looked at her as if he were hurt:
es: He seemed to be in pain, and he goes and says:

en: “I’m surprised at you, m’am.”
vi: - Madam, why is it so?
tr: "You surprised me a lot, ma'am." “Surprised? Did I surprise you?
es: —I am surprised, ma'am. —Does it surprise you...

en: “You’re s’rp—Why, what do you reckon I am? I’ve a good notion to take and—Say, what do you mean by kissing me?”
vi: - Who do you think I am? What do you mean by kissing me?
tr: Now I will show you… What are you trying to do?”
es: But, who do you think I am? I really feel like grabbing and... But, what is this about giving me a kiss?

en: He looked kind of humble, and says:
vi: It again made a very polite response:
tr: Tom answered with a modest demeanor:
es: He seemed to shrink, and said:

en: “I didn’t mean nothing, m’am. I didn’t mean no harm. I—I—thought you’d like it.”
vi: -Madam, it doesn't mean anything at all, I thought you liked it that way. Are you crazy?
tr: “Nothing, ma'am. I had no ill intentions. I thought you would like it.”
es: —It wasn't with bad intentions, ma'am. I didn't mean to upset you, I... I... I thought you would like it.

en: “Why, you born fool!” She took up the spinning stick, and it looked like it was all she could do to keep from giving him a crack with it. “What made you think I’d like it?”
vi: - She grabbed the rolling pin intending to hit him with it but managed to restrain herself - Why would you think I would like that?
tr: "Yes, you little fool!" He grabbed the spindle stick, seeming to barely restrain himself from hitting her with it. "What made you think I would like it?"
es: —What an idiot! —he grabbed the spindle of the spinning wheel and it seemed like he was going to hit him with it—. Why would I like it?

en: “Well, I don’t know. Only, they—they—told me you would.”
vi: - I don't know. They said that you like it that way.
tr: "I don't know. But they told me... they told me you would like it."
es: —Well, I don't know. It's just that... It's just that...

en: “They told you I would. Whoever told you’s another lunatic. I never heard the beat of it. Who’s they?”
vi: They said that you like it that way. - Whoever told you that is crazy. I have never heard anyone say something so strange. Who are they?
tr: “So they said that. Whoever said it must be a fool. I've never heard such a thing. Who are you talking about?”
es: They told me it would be like this. —They told you it would be like this. Well, the one who told you is another lunatic. I've never heard anything like it. Who told you?

en: “Why, everybody. They all said so, m’am.”
vi: - Everyone says so, ma'am.
tr: "Well... everyone." "They all said so, ma'am.""
es: —Well, everyone. That's what they said, ma'am.

en: It was all she could do to hold in; and her eyes snapped, and her fingers worked like she wanted to scratch him; and she says:
vi: At this point, Mrs. Saly couldn't stand it any longer, her eyes blinked, her fingers twitched as if wanting to scratch it, and she asked:
tr: Aunt Sally was about to lose herself, her eyes were bulging, her fingers were spread as if she wanted to scratch him.
es: She could barely contain herself, her eyes were blazing with anger, and she moved her fingers as if she wanted to scratch him, and she said:

en: “Who’s ‘everybody’? Out with their names, or ther’ll be an idiot short.”
vi: - Who are all these people? What are their names? Speak quickly, or don't blame me.
tr: "'Everyone' you say, who are they?" "Quickly give their names; otherwise, this world will be short one more fool.""
es: —Who is everyone? Give me their names or there will be one less idiot in this world.

en: He got up and looked distressed, and fumbled his hat, and says:
vi: Tom stood up, pretending to be disappointed, picked up his hat, and said:
tr: Tom stood up gloomily, speaking while playing with his hat:
es: Tom stood up, looking hurried, turning his hat around, and said:

en: “I’m sorry, and I warn’t expecting it. They told me to. They all told me to. They all said, kiss her; and said she’d like it. They all said it—every one of them. But I’m sorry, m’am, and I won’t do it no more—I won’t, honest.”
vi: - I'm sorry. I didn't expect things to turn out this way. They all told me to kiss you because you really like it. From now on, I promise I won't do it again unless you ask me to.
tr: “I'm sorry, I didn't expect it at all. They told me so. They all said so. They said if you kiss her, she will like it. They all said it… every single one of them. But I'm very sorry, ma'am, I won't do it again… I swear.”
es: —I'm sorry, and I didn't expect it. They told me. They all told me. Everyone told me "give her a kiss," and they said she would like it. Everyone said it, to the last one, but I'm sorry, ma'am, and I won't do it again. Really, I won't.

en: “You won’t, won’t you? Well, I sh’d reckon you won’t!”
vi: From now on, I promise I won't do it again unless you ask me to.
tr: "Won't you do it, won't you do it? Just try and let's see!"
es: —So you won't do it again, right? Man, I assure you!

en: “No’m, I’m honest about it; I won’t ever do it again—till you ask me.”
vi: From now on, I promise I won't do it again unless you ask me to.
tr: “No; I swore, I will never do it again. Of course, unless you want me to.”
es: —No, I mean it; I will never do it again until you ask me to.

en: “Till I ask you! Well, I never see the beat of it in my born days! I lay you’ll be the Methusalem-numskull of creation before ever I ask you—or the likes of you.”
vi: - My request? Since I was little, I have never seen anything as strange as this.
tr: "What if I don't want to? I've never seen such rudeness in my life! If you think I'll ask again, you must be the most foolish child ever... especially from someone like you!"
es: —Until I ask you for it! Well, I have never heard anything like it in my entire life! I assure you that you are going to be the dumbest Methuselah in creation before I ask you for anything like that.

en: “Well,” he says, “it does surprise me so. I can’t make it out, somehow. They said you would, and I thought you would. But—” He stopped and looked around slow, like he wished he could run across a friendly eye somewheres, and fetched up on the old gentleman’s, and says, “Didn’t you think she’d like me to kiss her, sir?”
vi: Since I was little, I have never seen anything as strange as this. Especially from someone like you. It looked around, seemingly wanting to meet a friendly gaze, then looked at Mr. Phelps and asked: - Do you think she wants the child to kiss her, sir?
tr: “I am really surprised,” said Tom. “Honestly, I just can't understand it. They said you would like it; I thought you would like it too. But…” He paused and slowly looked around, as if searching for a friendly face; then he asked the old gentleman: “Didn't you think she would like me kissing her, sir?”
es: I assure you that you are going to be the dumbest Methuselah in creation before I ask you for anything like that. .. Neither to you nor to anyone like you. —Well —says Tom—, I am very surprised. I don't know why, but I don't understand it. They said she would like it and I believed it too. But... —he fell silent and slowly looked from side to side, as if trying to find a friendly gaze somewhere, and finally stopped at the old man and asked him—: Didn't you think, sir, that she would like me to kiss her?

en: “Why, no; I—I—well, no, I b’lieve I didn’t.”
vi: - No, I don't think so.
tr: “No way, I… don't think so at all.”
es: —Well, no; I... I... don't think so.

en: Then he looks on around the same way to me, and says:
vi: Then it looked at me again in the same way and asked:
tr: He looked around again with the same expression, this time he asked me:
es: Then he kept looking until he stopped at me and asked:

en: “Tom, didn’t you think Aunt Sally ’d open out her arms and say, ‘Sid Sawyer—’”
vi: - Tom, do you think Aunt Sally will open her arms and call: Sid Sawyer?
tr: “Tom, didn't you think Aunt Sally would open her arms and say 'Sid Sawyer'?””
es: —Tom, didn't you think that Aunt Sally would open her arms and say, "Sid Sawyer..."?

en: “My land!” she says, breaking in and jumping for him, “you impudent young rascal, to fool a body so—” and was going to hug him, but he fended her off, and says:
vi: - Oh my God - Aunt Saly exclaimed and jumped towards him - you little rascal, did you trick me? Just as she was about to hug him, he pushed her away and said:
tr: Aunt Sally exclaimed, "Oh my God!" and rushed towards him, "you little impudent rascal, how dare you deceive me like this?" She wanted to hug him but Tom pulled back.
es: —My God! —she said, interrupting him and jumping towards him—, insolent creature, to deceive her like that... —and she was about to give him a hug but he pushed her away and said:

en: “No, not till you’ve asked me first.”
vi: - No, we have to wait for Auntie's request first!
tr: "It won't happen, not unless you want it.""
es: —No, first you have to ask me for it.

en: So she didn’t lose no time, but asked him; and hugged him and kissed him over and over again, and then turned him over to the old man, and he took what was left. And after they got a little quiet again she says:
vi: So she immediately asked for it, and hugged it tightly, kissing it several times, then turned it towards her husband, who also kissed it for a while. After a while, when everything was quiet, she said:
tr: Aunt Sally wanted to kiss him without further delay; then she hugged him, kissed him repeatedly, then gave him to the old man and took the rest herself. After calming down a bit, she said:
es: So she did not waste any time, but asked for it and filled it with hugs and kisses over and over again, and then handed it to the old man, who did the same. And when they calmed down a bit, she said:

en: “Why, dear me, I never see such a surprise. We warn’t looking for you at all, but only Tom. Sis never wrote to me about anybody coming but him.”
vi: - Auntie has never been so surprised. Your uncle and I thought only Tom was coming. The letter only mentioned that Tom would come. It says
tr: “Oh my God, what a wonderful surprise this is. We were only expecting Tom, we had no idea you were coming. My sister never mentioned anyone else coming.”
es: —But my God, I have never seen such a surprise. We were not expecting you at all, only Tom. My sister never told me that anyone else was coming besides him.

en: “It’s because it warn’t intended for any of us to come but Tom,” he says; “but I begged and begged, and at the last minute she let me come, too; so, coming down the river, me and Tom thought it would be a first-rate surprise for him to come here to the house first, and for me to by-and-by tag along and drop in, and let on to be a stranger. But it was a mistake, Aunt Sally. This ain’t no healthy place for a stranger to come.”
vi: - That’s because aunt only wanted Tom to come, and didn’t want anyone else to come. But I kept asking, and finally, my mom let me go too. After getting off the boat, Tom and I discussed that we should surprise aunt, so he would arrive first and I would pretend to just pass by and drop in, acting like a stranger.
tr: “Because indeed, it was not planned for someone else to come along with Tom,” said our Tom, “but I begged him until he was fed up and at the last minute he allowed me to come too; then while coming down the river with Tom, we thought it would be a great surprise if he came first and then I came and acted like a stranger. But we made a mistake, Aunt Sally. This is not a place where a stranger can come with peace of mind.”
es: —Because he only thought of sending Tom —he said—, but I begged and begged and at the last moment he let me come too; so when we were going down the river, Tom and I thought it would be a great surprise if he arrived at the house first and then I appeared suddenly, pretending to be a stranger. But we were wrong, Aunt Sally. This house is not safe for strangers.

en: “No—not impudent whelps, Sid. You ought to had your jaws boxed; I hain’t been so put out since I don’t know when. But I don’t care, I don’t mind the terms—I’d be willing to stand a thousand such jokes to have you here. Well, to think of that performance! I don’t deny it, I was most putrified with astonishment when you give me that smack.”
vi: - I almost broke my teeth. It's been a long time since I was so shocked. Oh, thinking about the moment you kissed her like that, I was scared to death. We had lunch in the wide corridor connecting the main house with the kitchen.
tr: “No… I have no intention of making those insolent brats comfortable, Mr. Sid. You will learn to sit with decorum, I haven't been this angry in a long time. But it doesn't matter, I don't care how you came here… I can endure thousands of jokes without a word just to see you here. How much of an actor you are! I can't deny that when you kissed me, I was so shocked that my heart nearly stopped.”
es: —No, not even for insolent children, Sid. I should have slapped you; God knows how long it’s been since I’ve had such a surprise. But it doesn’t matter, I don’t care about the form: I’m willing to endure a thousand jokes like this as long as you’re here. What a performance you’ve put on! I won’t deny it, I was almost petrified with astonishment when you kissed me.

en: We had dinner out in that broad open passage betwixt the house and the kitchen; and there was things enough on that table for seven families—and all hot, too; none of your flabby, tough meat that’s laid in a cupboard in a damp cellar all night and tastes like a hunk of old cold cannibal in the morning. Uncle Silas he asked a pretty long blessing over it, but it was worth it; and it didn’t cool it a bit, neither, the way I’ve seen them kind of interruptions do lots of times. There was a considerable good deal of talk all the afternoon, and me and Tom was on the lookout all the time; but it warn’t no use, they didn’t happen to say nothing about any runaway nigger, and we was afraid to try to work up to it. But at supper, at night, one of the little boys says:
vi: The table was set with all sorts of dishes, enough for seven servants to finish, and every dish was hot. Uncle Silas cared a lot about the food and never let it get cold. Throughout that entire afternoon, Tom and I had to be constantly on guard while talking about various things. But no one mentioned the runaway black man, and we were also afraid to bring it up. At dinner, a child asked:
tr: We ate our meal in the wide open passage between the house and the kitchen; there was enough food on the table to feed seven families – and it was all hot; it wasn't the kind of food that had sat all night in a damp cellar cupboard and wilted, looking like cannibal leftovers in the morning. Uncle Silas said a rather long prayer before the meal, but it was worth it; and the food didn't get cold at all, otherwise, I had witnessed many times before how the food got cold because of prayers. In the afternoon, there was hardly any silence; even though Tom and I listened intently, it was of no use, they didn't say anything about a runaway black man, and we were afraid to bring up the subject. But in the evening, at dinner, one of the little children asked:
es: We dined in that wide passageway open between the house and the kitchen, and on the table, there was enough for seven families and everything was hot; none of that fibrous and tough meat that is kept in an icebox in a damp basement all night and in the morning tastes just like a piece of old, cold cannibal. Uncle Silas said a very long grace, but it was worth it, and things didn't get cold one bit, as I've seen happen many times with that kind of interruption. We spent the whole afternoon talking; Tom and I were alert the entire time, but it was all for nothing, because they didn't say a word about the runaway black man and we were afraid to bring up the subject ourselves. But that night, at dinner time, one of the boys goes and says:

en: “Pa, mayn’t Tom and Sid and me go to the show?”
vi: - Dad, can you take Tom, Sid, and me to the theater?
tr: "Dad, can Tom, Sid, and I go to the show?"
es: —Father, can't Tom, Sid, and I go to see the show?

en: “No,” says the old man, “I reckon there ain’t going to be any; and you couldn’t go if there was; because the runaway nigger told Burton and me all about that scandalous show, and Burton said he would tell the people; so I reckon they’ve drove the owdacious loafers out of town before this time.”
vi: - No - the father replied - maybe it won't be performed, and even if it is, you kids won't be able to go, because the runaway black man told Mr. Burton that he would inform everyone, this time they might kick those useless guys out of here.
tr: “No,” said the old man, “and besides, there won't be any show; even if there was, you couldn't go; because the runaway black man told me and Burton everything about that disgraceful show, and Burton went to tell the townspeople; by now, they must have driven those shameless rascals out of town.”
es: —No —answered the old man—. I think there won't be one, and even if there were, you couldn't go, because the runaway black man has told Burton and me everything that happens in that scandalous show, and Burton said he was going to tell the people, so I think we've driven those boastful loafers out of town.

en: So there it was!—but I couldn’t help it. Tom and me was to sleep in the same room and bed; so, being tired, we bid good-night and went up to bed right after supper, and clumb out of the window and down the lightning-rod, and shoved for the town; for I didn’t believe anybody was going to give the king and the duke a hint, and so if I didn’t hurry up and give them one they’d get into trouble sure.
vi: I don't know what to do. Tom and I also slept in the same room upstairs and shared a bed. Using the excuse of being too tired, we asked to go to bed immediately after eating. Then we climbed out the window, slid down the lamppost to the ground, and went into town. Because I didn't believe that anyone here had informed the king and the duke, if I didn't go and inform them, they would be in danger.
tr: Here was Jim mentioned! But there was nothing to be done at that moment. Tom and I were going to sleep in the same room and in the same bed; right after dinner, we said goodnight to everyone, claiming we were very tired, and went to our room, immediately climbed out of the window, slid down the lightning rod, and headed quickly to the town; because I thought no one had informed the king and the duke, so if we didn't hurry and tell them what had happened, they would get into big trouble.
es: That's how things were! But we couldn't do anything. Tom and I had to sleep in the same room and in the same bed, so since we were tired, we said goodnight and went to bed immediately after dinner.

en: On the road Tom he told me all about how it was reckoned I was murdered, and how pap disappeared pretty soon, and didn’t come back no more, and what a stir there was when Jim run away; and I told Tom all about our Royal Nonesuch rapscallions, and as much of the raft voyage as I had time to; and as we struck into the town and up through the the middle of it—it was as much as half-after eight, then—here comes a raging rush of people with torches, and an awful whooping and yelling, and banging tin pans and blowing horns; and we jumped to one side to let them go by; and as they went by I see they had the king and the duke astraddle of a rail—that is, I knowed it was the king and the duke, though they was all over tar and feathers, and didn’t look like nothing in the world that was human—just looked like a couple of monstrous big soldier-plumes. Well, it made me sick to see it; and I was sorry for them poor pitiful rascals, it seemed like I couldn’t ever feel any hardness against them any more in the world. It was a dreadful thing to see. Human beings can be awful cruel to one another.
vi: On the way, Tom told me all about how everyone thought I had been killed, then my father disappeared and didn't come back, and how there was a commotion when Jim ran away. As for me, I told him about the two scoundrels performing in the play "The Royal Nonesuch," and about the journey on the wooden raft from then until now. Around half-past eight, we had reached the middle of the town when we suddenly saw a crowd of people carrying torches, banging pots and pans, and blowing horns. We quickly jumped to the side of the road to let them pass. As they went by, we saw they were leading the king and the duke, who were trapped in an iron bar, their bodies covered in tar and feathers, no longer looking human. Seeing that scene, I felt moved and sorry for those two wretched scoundrels. How can people be so disgustingly cruel to one another?
tr: Tom told me how I was thought to have been murdered, how my father disappeared shortly after and never returned, and the commotion that ensued when Jim escaped; I, in turn, told Tom everything about the Royal Nonesuch con men and our raft journey as much as time allowed; when we reached the town and got to the middle of it, we saw an angry mob coming; they had torches, and they were coming with terrifying shouts and screams, some banging pans, others blowing horns; we immediately threw ourselves aside to let them pass; as the crowd passed by, I saw that the king and the duke were each mounted on a pole – or rather, I realized they were the king and the duke, but they were covered in tar and feathers, they no longer resembled any human beings in this world – they looked more like a pair of gigantic soldier pincushions. I was devastated when I saw them. I felt sorry for these pitiful wretched scoundrels, and I felt that I could never be hard-hearted towards them again. Their condition was truly hair-raising. How cruel people can be to one another.
es: We went out through the window and climbed down the lightning rod to go to town, as I didn't think anyone was going to say a word to the king and the duke, so if I didn't run to warn them, they were surely going to get into a big mess. On the way, Tom told me that everyone had believed the story about my murder, and that father had disappeared immediately and hadn't returned, and the commotion that ensued when Jim escaped. I told Tom the whole story of our scoundrels from "The Peerless Royalty," and everything I had time to tell him about our raft journey. When we reached the town, towards the center (it must have been around eight-thirty), a bunch of people appeared running with torches, shouting and howling, banging pots and blowing horns; we stepped aside to let them pass, and I saw that they were carrying the king and the duke mounted on a rail. That is, I knew they were the king and the duke, although they had been smeared with tar and feathers and didn't look like beings from this world, but rather a kind of monstrous feather dusters. Well, I regretted seeing them and felt sorry for those poor rascals, as if I couldn't hold anything against them anymore. It was horrible to watch. Human beings can be terribly cruel to one another.

en: We see we was too late—couldn’t do no good. We asked some stragglers about it, and they said everybody went to the show looking very innocent; and laid low and kept dark till the poor old king was in the middle of his cavortings on the stage; then somebody give a signal, and the house rose up and went for them.
vi: We know that it is already too late, there's nothing we can do anymore. When asked a few people, they said that everyone went to watch the play, pretending not to know anything. Wait until the king is gesticulating on stage, then someone gives a signal, and the whole theater rushes up to capture him.
tr: We realized that we were very late – there was nothing we could do. We asked passersby what had happened; according to what they said, everyone had gone to the show in seemingly innocent poses, and the poor old king hadn’t shown any sign until the middle of his antics on stage; then, when someone gave a signal, all the spectators rose up and pounced on them.
es: We saw that we had arrived late, that we couldn't do anything anymore. We asked some of the stragglers what had happened and they said that everyone had gone to the performance with innocent faces and had remained so calm and quiet until the poor king was in the middle of his antics on stage; then someone gave a signal and the entire audience stood up and rushed at them.

en: So we poked along back home, and I warn’t feeling so brash as I was before, but kind of ornery, and humble, and to blame, somehow—though I hadn’t done nothing. But that’s always the way; it don’t make no difference whether you do right or wrong, a person’s conscience ain’t got no sense, and just goes for him anyway. If I had a yaller dog that didn’t know no more than a person’s conscience does I would pison him. It takes up more room than all the rest of a person’s insides, and yet ain’t no good, nohow. Tom Sawyer he says the same.
vi: We returned home, and we were no longer as eager as when we left. I felt somewhat to blame even though I had nothing to do with this incident. Whether one does right or wrong, if a person doesn't realize it, it still gnaws at them just the same. Tom Sawyer said the same thing.
tr: We returned home, and now I felt neither cheerful like at the beginning, but base, vile, and guilty – even though I had done nothing. But isn't it always like this; whether you do right or wrong changes nothing, the conscience has no logic, it aches incessantly in any case. If I had a dog as foolish as my conscience, I would poison it immediately. This wretched thing takes up more space inside a person than anything else and serves no purpose. Tom Sawyer thought the same thing.
es: So we went back home, and I no longer felt as proud as before, but rather shrunk and ashamed and as if I were to blame, even though I hadn't done anything. But that's what always happens; it doesn't matter whether one does things right or wrong, because the conscience has no common sense and it always gets on top of you no matter what happens. If I had a yellow dog that wasn't smarter than people's conscience, I would poison it. It takes up more space than everything else, and yet, I don't know why, it's good for nothing. Tom Sawyer says the same thing.

en: CHAPTER XXXIV.
vi: Chapter XXXIV
tr: Chapter Thirty-Four
es: Chapter 34

en: We stopped talking, and got to thinking. By-and-by Tom says:
vi: We stopped talking and started thinking. A moment later, Tom said:
tr: We stopped talking and started thinking. Shortly after, Tom said:
es: WE STOPPED TALKING and started thinking. After a while, Tom says:

en: “Looky here, Huck, what fools we are to not think of it before! I bet I know where Jim is.”
vi: - Hey Huck, we were so dumb. It was possible, but we couldn't think of it. I know where Jim is now.
tr: “Huck, why didn't we think of this before? We were so stupid. I know exactly where Jim is.”
es: —Hey, Huck, we're fools for not having thought of it before! I bet I know where Jim is.

en: “No! Where?”
vi: - where?
tr: “No way! Where is it?”
es: —No! Where?

en: “In that hut down by the ash-hopper. Why, looky here. When we was at dinner, didn’t you see a nigger man go in there with some vittles?”
vi: - in the tent below the ash house. Don't you remember seeing a black man go in there with some food?
tr: "In the cabin near the ash silo. Remember, didn't you see a black man going there with a tray while we were having dinner?"
es: —In that cabin next to the one with the quicklime. Listen to this: when we were eating, didn't you see a black man taking some food?

en: “Yes.”
vi: - Yes.
tr: "I saw it, didn't I."" “Where was that tray going?”” “Probably to a dog.”
es: —Yes.

en: “What did you think the vittles was for?”
vi: - Who do you think he gave it to?
tr: “I thought so too.
es: —Who do you think the food was for?

en: “For a dog.”
vi: - For the dog.
tr: But it wasn't going to the dog.”
es: —For a dog. —Me too.

en: “So’d I. Well, it wasn’t for a dog.”
vi: - I thought so too. But it's not for the dog.
tr: But it wasn't going to the dog.”
es: Well, it wasn't for a dog.

en: “Why?”
vi: - Why?
tr: “Why?”
es: —Why?

en: “Because part of it was watermelon.”
vi: - Because there is a piece of melon in it.
tr: “Because there was also a watermelon on it.”
es: —Because he was also carrying a watermelon.

en: “So it was—I noticed it. Well, it does beat all that I never thought about a dog not eating watermelon. It shows how a body can see and don’t see at the same time.”
vi: - That's right, I noticed that too. But I thought dogs could eat melons, so I didn't suspect anything. - The black man unlocked the door when he entered, locked it again when he left, and then gave the key to Mr. Phelps.
tr: “Of course... I had seen it too. This is what you call intelligence, it never occurred to me that dogs don't eat watermelon. Is there a better proof of human obliviousness than this?”
es: —It's true, I already saw it. Imagine that it didn't occur to me that dogs don't eat watermelons. That shows that one can see things and not see them at the same time.

en: “Well, the nigger unlocked the padlock when he went in, and he locked it again when he came out. He fetched uncle a key about the time we got up from table—same key, I bet. Watermelon shows man, lock shows prisoner; and it ain’t likely there’s two prisoners on such a little plantation, and where the people’s all so kind and good. Jim’s the prisoner. All right—I’m glad we found it out detective fashion; I wouldn’t give shucks for any other way. Now you work your mind, and study out a plan to steal Jim, and I will study out one, too; and we’ll take the one we like the best.”
vi: - The black man unlocked the door when he entered, locked it again when he left, and then gave the key to Mr. Phelps. That means there is someone inside. If it's locked, it means someone is imprisoned. But it doesn't make sense that in this small plantation there would be two people imprisoned, because I see everyone is good. It's clear that Jim is imprisoned. I am determined to find Jim. Now, you come up with a plan to rescue Jim, and I'll think of another plan, then we'll see which one is better and do it.
tr: “The black man unlocked the padlock and went inside, and when he came out, he put the lock back in place. When we got up from the table, he brought my uncle a key... that was the key, I'm sure of it. The watermelon shows there was a person there, and the lock shows they were imprisoned; in such a small plantation, there probably aren't two prisoners, since everyone here gets along just fine. The prisoner is none other than our Jim. Alright... I'm glad we figured this out like detectives, otherwise, it wouldn't be any fun. Now use your brain and come up with a plan to rescue Jim, and I'll come up with one too, and we'll use whichever one we like better.”
es: —Well, the black man opened the padlock when he entered and locked it again when he left. When we got up from the table, he returned a key to the uncle, and I bet it was the same one. The watermelon indicates that he is a man; the lock, that he is imprisoned, and it is unlikely that there are two prisoners on such a small plantation where all the people are so good and so kind. The prisoner is Jim. Very well, I'm glad I figured it out like the detectives; otherwise, I wouldn't like it. Now you have to start thinking about it and come up with a plan to steal Jim; I'll come up with another one and we'll go with the one we like best.

en: What a head for just a boy to have! If I had Tom Sawyer’s head I wouldn’t trade it off to be a duke, nor mate of a steamboat, nor clown in a circus, nor nothing I can think of. I went to thinking out a plan, but only just to be doing something; I knowed very well where the right plan was going to come from. Pretty soon Tom says:
vi: Tom is really clever. If I had a mind like his, I wouldn't have been tormented by the king and the duke for so long. I'm thinking of a plan, but only vaguely. A moment later, Tom asked:
tr: Such a mind in such a little boy! If I had a mind like Tom Sawyer's, I wouldn't give it up even if they made me a duke, or even if they made me a steamboat captain, a circus clown, or anything else that came to mind. I started making a plan, but I was doing it just for the sake of doing something; I knew very well whose mind the right plan would come from. Soon enough, Tom turned to me:
es: What a head for just being a boy! If I had Tom Sawyer's head, I wouldn't trade it for being a duke, a steamboat pilot, a circus clown, or anything else I could think of. I started thinking of a plan, but just to do something. I knew very well where the best plan was going to come from. Right away Tom goes and says:

en: “Ready?”
vi: - Have you finished thinking?
tr: “Are you ready?”
es: —Ready?

en: “Yes,” I says.
vi: - Okay. - I replied.
tr: "Yes," I said.
es: —Yes —I replied.

en: “All right—bring it out.”
vi: - You tell me.
tr: “Alright… let's hear it.”
es: —Well, tell me about it.

en: “My plan is this,” I says. “We can easy find out if it’s Jim in there. Then get up my canoe to-morrow night, and fetch my raft over from the island. Then the first dark night that comes steal the key out of the old man’s britches after he goes to bed, and shove off down the river on the raft with Jim, hiding daytimes and running nights, the way me and Jim used to do before. Wouldn’t that plan work?”
vi: I said: - My plan is like this. We go find Jim, this part is easy. Tomorrow morning, I'll retrieve my canoe hidden at the island. At night, we'll steal his keys after he goes to sleep. Then we'll head straight to the river, get Jim on the raft, hide during the day, and travel at night, just like Jim and I used to do before. Does that sound good?
tr: “Here is my plan,” I said. “We can easily find out if Jim is there or not. Tomorrow night, I'll go get my canoe, go to the island, and bring the raft. On the first moonless night, I'll wait for the old man to fall asleep, then I'll steal the key from his pocket, and Jim and I will go down the river on the raft, hiding during the day and traveling at night, just like Jim and I used to do before. Do you think this plan will work?”
es: —My plan is this —I said—. We can easily find out if it's Jim who is there. Then, tomorrow night I take out my canoe and we bring my raft from the island. On the first dark night we have, we take the key from the old man's pants when he goes to bed and we head down the river with Jim, hiding during the day and navigating at night, like Jim and I used to do before. Wouldn't that plan work?

en: “Work? Why, cert’nly it would work, like rats a-fighting. But it’s too blame’ simple; there ain’t nothing to it. What’s the good of a plan that ain’t no more trouble than that? It’s as mild as goose-milk. Why, Huck, it wouldn’t make no more talk than breaking into a soap factory.”
vi: - Can it be done? Of course it can, but it's like mice biting each other. What kind of plan is this, so simple, nothing thrilling or sensational. If people talk about it later, it will just be in passing. That's really boring. I didn't say anything, because I didn't expect anything different, as his plans were always the best.
tr: “To be useful? Absolutely, it would be as easy as pulling a hair out of butter. But it's too simple, there's no difficulty at all. What good is a plan that doesn't create more challenges? It's as calm as goose milk. This plan is no harder than sneaking into a soap factory, Huck.”
es: —Work? Of course it would work, like two and two make four. But it's too simple; it says nothing. What good is a plan that doesn't pose any problem? It's too bland. Man, Huck, it wouldn't create more sensation than if it were a robbery in a soap factory.

en: I never said nothing, because I warn’t expecting nothing different; but I knowed mighty well that whenever he got his plan ready it wouldn’t have none of them objections to it.
vi: I didn't say anything, because I didn't expect anything different, as his plans were always the best.
tr: I didn't say anything, because I wasn't expecting any other attitude from him. But I knew very well that when he prepared his own plan, there would be nothing to object to.
es: I didn't say anything, because I didn't expect anything different, but I knew very well that when he had his plan ready, none of those objections could be made.

en: And it didn’t. He told me what it was, and I see in a minute it was worth fifteen of mine for style, and would make Jim just as free a man as mine would, and maybe get us all killed besides. So I was satisfied, and said we would waltz in on it. I needn’t tell what it was here, because I knowed it wouldn’t stay the way, it was. I knowed he would be changing it around every which way as we went along, and heaving in new bullinesses wherever he got a chance. And that is what he done.
vi: Indeed. He talked about his plan. After listening, I realized it would take fifteen people like me to come up with it, and only then could Jim become as free as I am. I agreed, and we immediately set out to execute it. I don't need to explain the plan here, as it would change during execution and many other things would need to be added. There is one thing that is most certain: Tom Sawyer was very eager to rescue that black man from slavery. That was beyond my imagination.
tr: It was truly a flawless plan. As soon as he explained it to me, I realized it was fifteen times better than my own plan, plus it adhered to the code and in the end, Jim would be at least as free as I was, and there was also the possibility that all of us might die. I found the plan very satisfying and immediately suggested we implement it. I don't feel the need to explain the plan here because I was sure things wouldn't go according to plan. I knew that once we took action, he would change the plan in any direction and come up with new inventions at every opportunity. And that's exactly what he did.
es: And so it happened. He told me what it was and in a moment I understood that it was worth fifteen of mine in terms of elegance, and that it would leave Jim just as free as my plan, and that it could also get us all killed. So I was very happy and said we could go ahead with it. I don't need to recount here what it was because I knew it would keep changing. I knew he would change it at every moment as we progressed, adding new adventures whenever he had a chance. And so he did.

en: Well, one thing was dead sure, and that was that Tom Sawyer was in earnest, and was actuly going to help steal that nigger out of slavery. That was the thing that was too many for me. Here was a boy that was respectable and well brung up; and had a character to lose; and folks at home that had characters; and he was bright and not leather-headed; and knowing and not ignorant; and not mean, but kind; and yet here he was, without any more pride, or rightness, or feeling, than to stoop to this business, and make himself a shame, and his family a shame, before everybody. I couldn’t understand it no way at all. It was outrageous, and I knowed I ought to just up and tell him so; and so be his true friend, and let him quit the thing right where he was and save himself. And I did start to tell him; but he shut me up, and says:
vi: This was a respectable boy, well-educated, and had a special temperament. But his family was the same. He was outstanding, not dull; he knew various things, not ignorant; he was not bad, but kind-hearted. Yet now, he humbly bowed to do such a thing, something that would bring shame to him and his family before everyone. It was truly disgraceful, and I thought I must tell him that immediately. As his close friend, I had to advise him to abandon that idea, to save himself. I was just about to speak when he stopped me and said:
tr: The only thing that was certain was that Tom Sawyer was serious and would indeed help me steal that black man. Frankly, in my opinion, this boy had crossed the line. Here was a well-bred, respectable boy standing before me; he was definitely a person of character; the other people in his house were also people of character; he was sharp-witted, not a fool; knowledgeable, not ignorant at all; not mean, but kind-hearted; yet he didn't hesitate to get involved in such a terrible deed, as if he didn't care about his honor, reputation, or name, and was willing to embarrass both himself and his family in front of everyone. I absolutely couldn't comprehend what he was doing. He had embarked on an ugly task, and I needed to tell him that; I had to act like a true friend, make him turn back while there was still time, and save himself. I had just started to speak when he silenced me with a gesture and said:
es: Well, there was one thing that was beyond doubt, and that was that Tom Sawyer was serious and indeed was going to help steal the black man to free him. That was what left me astonished. This was a boy who was respectable and well-raised and who had a reputation to lose, and back home he had a family also with a reputation, and he was smart and not a fool, and he knew things, he was not ignorant, and he was not mean but kind, and yet there he was without any pride or sanctimoniousness or feelings, ready to get involved in such a matter and to fill himself with shame and fill his family with shame, in front of everyone. I couldn't understand it at all. It was absurd and I realized that I would have to tell him and show him that I was a good friend of his and let him leave it where it was and save himself. And I started to tell him, but he made me be quiet and replied:

en: “Don’t you reckon I know what I’m about? Don’t I generly know what I’m about?”
vi: - You think I don't know what I'm doing?
tr: “Do you think I am someone who doesn't know what they're doing? Don't I usually act knowing what I'm doing?”
es: —Do you think I don't know what I'm doing? Don't I know what I'm doing in general?

en: “Yes.”
vi: - Yes.
tr: “Yes.”
es: —Yes.

en: “Didn’t I say I was going to help steal the nigger?”
vi: - I told you I would help you get back the black guy, didn't I?
tr: “Didn't I tell you I would help you save the black man?”
es: —Didn't I say I was going to help rob the black man?

en: “Yes.”
vi: - That's right.
tr: “Yes.”
es: —Yes.

en: “Well, then.”
vi: - So, what else are you planning?
tr: “Alright then.”
es: —Well, that's that.

en: That’s all he said, and that’s all I said. It warn’t no use to say any more; because when he said he’d do a thing, he always done it. But I couldn’t make out how he was willing to go into this thing; so I just let it go, and never bothered no more about it. If he was bound to have it so, I couldn’t help it.
vi: It only said maybe, and I said the same. I knew saying more would be useless because when it says something, it will definitely do it. But I still don't understand why it wants to plunge into things like this. I just let it be and didn't bother thinking about it anymore. When we got home, it was already dark and very quiet.
tr: He didn't say anything else, and I didn't raise my voice anymore. There was no point in saying anything else, because if he set his mind on something, he would definitely do it. But I could never understand how he was so willing to do this job; so I left it to fate and didn't think about the matter again. If doing this was written in his destiny, there was nothing I could do.
es: He didn't say anything more, and neither did I. It wasn't worth it anymore, because when he said he was going to do something, he always did it. But even though I didn't understand how he was willing to get involved in something like that, I left it and didn't worry about it anymore. If he was determined to do it, I couldn't stop him.

en: When we got home the house was all dark and still; so we went on down to the hut by the ash-hopper for to examine it. We went through the yard so as to see what the hounds would do. They knowed us, and didn’t make no more noise than country dogs is always doing when anything comes by in the night. When we got to the cabin we took a look at the front and the two sides; and on the side I warn’t acquainted with—which was the north side—we found a square window-hole, up tolerable high, with just one stout board nailed across it. I says:
vi: We made our way to the tent below the ash house to investigate. We went through the yard to see if the dogs would bark loudly. But the dogs recognized us and didn't bark at all. Approaching the tent, looking carefully in front and on both sides, we saw a small square window with a board nailed tightly outside. I said:
tr: When we arrived, it was dark and quiet; so we headed directly to the shack near the ash silo, we wanted to take a look. We went straight through the courtyard to see what the dogs would do. They knew us and made as much noise as shepherd dogs seeing people at night would make. When we reached the shack, we scouted the front and both sides; on the side I hadn't seen before – the north side – we saw a square window that could be considered quite high, with only one thick board nailed over it. “Here is the exit ticket,” I said.
es: When we returned, the house was completely dark and silent, so we went to the cabin next to where the quicklime was to examine it. We crossed the yard to see what the dogs were doing. They already knew us and made no more noise than any country dog would when someone appears at night. When we arrived at the cabin, we looked at the front and both sides, and from the side I didn't know (which faced north), we saw the square hole of a window, quite high, with a single wooden plank nailed over it. I go and say:

en: “Here’s the ticket. This hole’s big enough for Jim to get through if we wrench off the board.”
vi: - This spot is good. This hole is both large and just enough for Jim to fit through if we can remove that plank.
tr: “Here is the exit ticket,” I said. “If we remove the board, this hole will become big enough for Jim to pass through.”
es: —This is very good. That hole is big enough for Jim to get out if we pull off the board.

en: Tom says:
vi: Tom said:
tr: “As easy as playing three stones,” said Tom.
es: And then Tom says:

en: “It’s as simple as tit-tat-toe, three-in-a-row, and as easy as playing hooky. I should hope we can find a way that’s a little more complicated than that, Huck Finn.”
vi: - Well, that's as easy as turning your hand over. I think we could find a way that's even harder than that.
tr: “As easy as skipping school. I hope we can find a way a bit more complicated than this, Huck Finn.”
es: —That's easier than walking and simpler than fooling a fool. I'd say we can find a slightly more complicated way, Huck Finn.

en: “Well, then,” I says, “how’ll it do to saw him out, the way I done before I was murdered that time?”
vi: - Okay, let's saw that plank.
tr: “Alright then,” I said, “How about cutting the wall with a saw to get him out? That's what I did before he was killed.”
es: —Well, then —I replied—. What do you think if we make a hole between the logs like that time I was murdered?

en: “That’s more like,” he says. “It’s real mysterious, and troublesome, and good,” he says; “but I bet we can find a way that’s twice as long. There ain’t no hurry; le’s keep on looking around.”
vi: - That's somewhat acceptable, seems secretive and challenging. But I think we can find a way that takes twice as long, there's no need to rush, so we can look around here first.
tr: “This is better,” he said. “Truly mysterious, challenging, and good,” he said. “But I am sure we can find a way that will take at least twice as long. We are in no hurry, let's keep looking around.”
es: —That's something —he said—. It's mysterious, complicated, and fine, but I'm sure we can find something that lasts at least twice as long. There's no rush, let's keep looking.

en: Betwixt the hut and the fence, on the back side, was a lean-to that joined the hut at the eaves, and was made out of plank. It was as long as the hut, but narrow—only about six foot wide. The door to it was at the south end, and was padlocked. Tom he went to the soap-kettle and searched around, and fetched back the iron thing they lift the lid with; so he took it and prized out one of the staples. The chain fell down, and we opened the door and went in, and shut it, and struck a match, and see the shed was only built against a cabin and hadn’t no connection with it; and there warn’t no floor to the shed, nor nothing in it but some old rusty played-out hoes and spades and picks and a crippled plow. The match went out, and so did we, and shoved in the staple again, and the door was locked as good as ever. Tom was joyful. He says;
vi: Between the tent and the fence, there was a long roof as long as the tent, but narrower, only about one meter. The entrance door was tightly locked. Tom went to the shed, looked around, and brought back an iron bar used to pry open box lids. He used the iron bar to pry open a door. The chain fell down. We opened the door and stepped inside, then closed the door again. Striking a match, we saw that this roof was just leaning against the tent and had no passage through. Inside, there were only a few worn-out shovels and hoes. When the match went out, we stepped out, reattached the iron hook, and the door closed as before. Tom was secretly pleased. He said:
tr: Between the fence and the shed, at the back where the shed's roof eaves met, there was a storage made of planks. It was as long as the shed, but narrow... only two meters wide. The door was at the south end and had a padlock on it. After Tom went over to the soap cauldron and did some investigating, he returned with an iron rod used to lift the lid; with this rod, he pried out one of the nails. The chain fell to the ground and we opened the door and went inside. After closing the door behind us, we lit a match to see around. The storage was only built against the wall of the shed and there was no connection between them; the floor of the storage was dirt, and inside there were only a few rusty hoes, shovels, picks, and a broken plow. When the match went out, we went outside and put the nail back in place, the door was locked as before. Tom was cheerful. “Alright, now it's done,” he said.
es: Between the cabin and the fence, at the back, there was a shed attached to the cabin by the roof and made of wooden planks. It was as long as the cabin, but narrow: only about six meters wide. The door was on the south side and had a padlock. Tom went to the soap cauldron and started searching, and came back with that iron thing used to lift the lid, so he pried off one of the padlock's handles. The chain fell off, we opened the door and went in, closed it, and when we lit a match we saw that the shed was only built next to the cabin, with no passage to it, that it had no floor, and there was nothing but a few rusty hoes and shovels, some picks, and a broken plow. The match went out and we left and put the handle back on, so the door was closed just as well as before. Tom was delighted, and he said:

en: “Now we’re all right. We’ll dig him out. It’ll take about a week!”
vi: - That's settled. We'll dig a hole for him. It will take about a week.
tr: “Alright, now it's done,” he said. “We will dig it out. It will take about a week!”
es: —Now everything is in order. We are going to take him out through a tunnel. It will take us a week!

en: Then we started for the house, and I went in the back door—you only have to pull a buckskin latch-string, they don’t fasten the doors—but that warn’t romantical enough for Tom Sawyer; no way would do him but he must climb up the lightning-rod. But after he got up half way about three times, and missed fire and fell every time, and the last time most busted his brains out, he thought he’d got to give it up; but after he was rested he allowed he would give her one more turn for luck, and this time he made the trip.
vi: Then we went back to the room. I entered through the back door, just had to lift the leather strap to open it, because they didn't tie it. But Tom Sawyer thought that wasn't thrilling enough, so he had to climb up the column. Three times he climbed halfway up and then slid down. The third time he fell so hard it seemed like he might have cracked his head, he decided to give up, but after thinking for a while, he climbed again. This time he made it.
tr: We went out and headed home, I entered through the back door – you just need to pull a leather strap, they don't lock the doors – but for Tom Sawyer, this wasn't romantic enough: He insisted on climbing up the lightning rod. But after climbing halfway up three times and falling, and narrowly avoiding cracking his head open the last time, he started to think he might have to give up; but after resting for a while, he decided to give it one last try, hoping his luck would turn, and this time he succeeded.
es: Then we went to the house and I entered through the back door (you just have to pull a leather cord, because they don't lock the doors there), but Tom Sawyer didn't think it was romantic enough, and the only thing that would do for him was to climb up the lightning rod. But after climbing halfway up three times and failing and falling all three times, and almost breaking his head the last time, he thought it would be better to give up, but after resting he decided he would try one more time to see how it would go, and that time he managed to make it.

en: In the morning we was up at break of day, and down to the nigger cabins to pet the dogs and make friends with the nigger that fed Jim—if it was Jim that was being fed. The niggers was just getting through breakfast and starting for the fields; and Jim’s nigger was piling up a tin pan with bread and meat and things; and whilst the others was leaving, the key come from the house.
vi: The next morning, we got up early and went down to the house of the black people to get acquainted with the black man who always brought food for Jim. They had just finished breakfast and were about to go to the fields, while the black man who usually went to Jim was packing meat pies and other things into an iron pot. When everyone had left, the key was brought down.
tr: We woke up at dawn and went to the negro cabins to both pet the dogs and befriend the negro who fed Jim –that is, if the negro being fed was Jim. The negroes had just had breakfast and were preparing to head out to the fields; the one who fed Jim was placing bread, meat, and other things on a tray; as the others left, the key also came from the house.
es: In the morning we got up at dawn and went down to the cabins of the black people to pet the dogs and make friends with the black person who was bringing food to Jim, if it was Jim he was bringing it to. The black people had just finished breakfast and were starting to go to the fields, and Jim's black person was filling a metal bowl with bread and meat and other things, and while the others were leaving, they brought him the key to the house.

en: This nigger had a good-natured, chuckle-headed face, and his wool was all tied up in little bunches with thread. That was to keep witches off. He said the witches was pestering him awful these nights, and making him see all kinds of strange things, and hear all kinds of strange words and noises, and he didn’t believe he was ever witched so long before in his life. He got so worked up, and got to running on so about his troubles, he forgot all about what he’d been a-going to do. So Tom says:
vi: This black man looks very gentle. His clothes are tied up in several places with strings. That is to ward off evil spirits. He said that in the past few nights, evil spirits have been disturbing him a lot; he saw many strange things, heard all kinds of strange voices and noises, and he couldn't believe that in his life until now he had been so harassed by evil spirits. He spoke very passionately and repeatedly recounted those frightening things, completely forgetting what he was supposed to do now. Tom asked:
tr: This black man was good-natured and had a cheerful face, he had tied his hair in thin strands with strings. He did this to keep witches away. He said that the witches had been bothering him a lot for a few nights, causing him to see strange things and hear strange words and noises; he couldn't remember the witches ever haunting him for this long before. He got really excited and started to list his troubles without stopping, completely forgetting the work he was doing. Tom reminded him:
es: The black man had a friendly face, very smiling, and wore his hair all tied up in curls with pieces of thread. It was to ward off witches. He said that those nights the witches were giving him a hard time and making him see all kinds of strange things and hear all kinds of strange words and noises, and that he believed he had never been bewitched for so long in his entire life. He got so nervous talking about his problems that he forgot everything he had to do. Then Tom said to him:

en: “What’s the vittles for? Going to feed the dogs?”
vi: - What is this food for? To feed the dog?
tr: “What are these foods for? Are you going to feed the dogs?”
es: —Who is that food for? Are you going to feed the dogs?

en: The nigger kind of smiled around gradually over his face, like when you heave a brickbat in a mud-puddle, and he says:
vi: The black man gradually revealed a smile and replied:
tr: A smile slowly spread across the rich man's face, just like waves spreading when a brick is thrown into a swamp.
es: The black man began to smile slowly until his face was filled with it, like when a brick is thrown into a mud puddle, and he said:

en: “Yes, Mars Sid, a dog. Cur’us dog, too. Does you want to go en look at ’im?”
vi: - The dog is very strange. Do you want to go see it?
tr: “Yes, Master Sid, I will feed the dog. And it's a strange dog. Would you like to come and see it?”
es: —Yes, little master Sid, a dog. A very curious dog. Do you want to come see it?

en: “Yes.”
vi: - Of course
tr: “Yes.”
es: —Yes.

en: I hunched Tom, and whispers:
vi: I nudged Tom and whispered:
tr: I nudged Tom with an elbow and whispered:
es: I gave Tom a nudge and whispered to him:

en: “You going, right here in the daybreak? That warn’t the plan.”
vi: - Why is this happening in broad daylight? Wasn't that the plan?
tr: “Are you going to enter the cabin directly at sunrise? That wasn't our plan.”
es: —Are you going there at dawn? That wasn't the plan.

en: “No, it warn’t; but it’s the plan now.”
vi: - It wasn't like that before, but now it has to be.
tr: “It wasn't... but now the plan is this.”
es: —No, it wasn't, but now it is the plan.

en: So, drat him, we went along, but I didn’t like it much. When we got in we couldn’t hardly see anything, it was so dark; but Jim was there, sure enough, and could see us; and he sings out:
vi: We went out, but I didn't like it much. When stepping into the tent, we couldn't see anything because it was too dark. But Jim was indeed in there, Jim saw us and shouted loudly:
tr: Damn it, we followed the black man, but I didn't really like it. When we entered, we couldn't see anything at first, it was very dark; but Jim was definitely there and could see us, he called out excitedly:
es: So, damn it, there we went, but I didn't like it one bit. When we arrived, you could hardly see anything because it was so dark, but there was Jim, without a doubt, and he could see us, and he shouted:

en: “Why, Huck! En good lan’! ain’ dat Misto Tom?”
vi: - Oh, Huck, and Tom too?
tr: "Hey, Huck! My dear friend! And isn't that Mr. Tom next to you?"
es: —But, Huck! My God! Isn't that Tom's place?

en: I just knowed how it would be; I just expected it. I didn’t know nothing to do; and if I had I couldn’t a done it, because that nigger busted in and says:
vi: I knew this would happen sooner or later. What can we do now?
tr: I knew very well what was going to happen, it was exactly as I expected. I was at a loss for what to do, even if I wasn't, there was nothing I could do, because the black man intervened:
es: I knew what was going to happen, it was what I expected. I didn't know what to do, and even if I did, I wouldn't have done it, because the black man appeared saying:

en: “Why, de gracious sakes! do he know you genlmen?”
vi: The black man exclaimed: - Oh Lord, does he know you guys?
tr: "By the morning light! Does this black man know you or what?"
es: —By all the saints! Does he know you, young gentlemen?

en: We could see pretty well now. Tom he looked at the nigger, steady and kind of wondering, and says:
vi: Tom looked at the black man, seemingly astonished, and asked again:
tr: We could now see the inside quite well. Tom turned his head to the black man and looked at him curiously:
es: Now it could be seen quite well. Tom looked at the black man, very intently and as if wondering something, and then he said:

en: “Does who know us?”
vi: - Who knows us?
tr: “Does anyone know us?”
es: —Who knows us?

en: “Why, dis-yer runaway nigger.”
vi: - This black guy.
tr: "There's the runaway black man.""
es: —Well, this runaway black man.

en: “I don’t reckon he does; but what put that into your head?”
vi: - I don't really know.
tr: “I don't think you know him at all, but why do you ask?”
es: —I don't think so; but, why did it occur to you?

en: “What put it dar? Didn’ he jis’ dis minute sing out like he knowed you?”
vi: But why do you think so? - He just called you guys, didn't he?
tr: “Why would I leave? Didn't he just call out to you as if he knew you?”
es: —Why? Didn't you just say that you knew them?

en: Tom says, in a puzzled-up kind of way:
vi: Tom seemed confused and said:
tr: Tom replied, pretending to be surprised:
es: Tom goes and says, seemingly surprised:

en: “Well, that’s mighty curious. Who sung out? When did he sing out? what did he sing out?” And turns to me, perfectly ca’m, and says, “Did you hear anybody sing out?”
vi: - Strange, isn't it? Who's calling? When did they call? How did they call? Then it calmly turned back to me and continued to ask: - Did you hear someone calling?
tr: “This is strange.” “Who called out?” “When did they call out?” “What did they say?” He turned to me very calmly: “Did you hear anyone call out?””
es: —Well, this is certainly curious. Who said anything? When did they say it? What did they say? —and he turns to me, very calmly, and says to me—: Did you hear anyone say anything?

en: Of course there warn’t nothing to be said but the one thing; so I says:
vi: Of course, I couldn't say otherwise and tell:
tr: Of course, there was only one answer that could be given to this question.
es: Naturally, I could only say one thing, so I replied:

en: “No; I ain’t heard nobody say nothing.”
vi: - No, I didn't hear anyone calling.
tr: "No; I didn't hear anyone say anything."
es: —No; I haven't heard anyone say anything.

en: Then he turns to Jim, and looks him over like he never see him before, and says:
vi: Then it turned back to Jim, acting like a stranger, and asked:
tr: Then he turned to Jim and, looking at him as if he were someone he had never seen before in his life, asked:
es: Then he turns to Jim and looks him up and down as if he had never seen him before and asks: "Did you say something?"

en: “Did you sing out?”
vi: - Did you just call us?
tr: "Did you call out to us?""
es: Then he turns to Jim and looks him up and down as if he had never seen him before and asks: "Did you say something?"

en: “No, sah,” says Jim; “I hain’t said nothing, sah.”
vi: Jim replied:
tr: "No, sir," said Jim, "not a single word came out of my mouth, sir."
es: —No, sir —says Jim—; I haven't said anything, sir.

en: “Not a word?”
vi: - No, I didn't call anything.
tr: “Not a single word came out?”
es: —Not a word?

en: “No, sah, I hain’t said a word.”
vi: - No, I didn't call anything.
tr: "No, master, not a single word came out."
es: —No, sir, I haven't said a single word.

en: “Did you ever see us before?”
vi: - Have you ever met us?
tr: “Have you seen us before?”
es: —Have you seen us before now?

en: “No, sah; not as I knows on.”
vi: - Not yet.
tr: "No, sir, I don't remember ever seeing you before."
es: —No, sir; not that I know of.

en: So Tom turns to the nigger, which was looking wild and distressed, and says, kind of severe:
vi: Tom turned around, the black man now frightened and disappointed, spoke in a stern voice:
tr: Thereupon, Tom turned to the black man, who was in a state of shock and worry, and asked very seriously:
es: So Tom turns to the black man, who was all flustered and confused, and says, very sternly:

en: “What do you reckon’s the matter with you, anyway? What made you think somebody sung out?”
vi: - Why do you think someone called?
tr: “What’s wrong with you? Where did you get the idea that someone was calling out?”
es: —But, what's wrong with you? Why did you think someone said something?

en: “Oh, it’s de dad-blame’ witches, sah, en I wisht I was dead, I do. Dey’s awluz at it, sah, en dey do mos’ kill me, dey sk’yers me so. Please to don’t tell nobody ’bout it sah, er ole Mars Silas he’ll scole me; ’kase he say dey ain’t no witches. I jis’ wish to goodness he was heah now—den what would he say! I jis’ bet he couldn’ fine no way to git aroun’ it dis time. But it’s awluz jis’ so; people dat’s sot, stays sot; dey won’t look into noth’n’en fine it out f’r deyselves, en when you fine it out en tell um ’bout it, dey doan’ b’lieve you.”
