vi: - Oh, sir, it's those ghosts haunting me again. If they keep hovering around me like this, I'm afraid I'll die of fright. Please don't tell anyone about this, or Mr. Silas will scold me; he says there are no such things as ghosts.
tr: “Ah, that accursed witch, master, I wish God would take my life so I could be free. She always does this, she kills me, she scares me a lot. Whatever happens, don't tell anyone about this, master, or Master Silas will be angry with me, because he says there's no such thing as a witch. My God, I wish he were here too... then what would happen? Surely this time he couldn't deny their existence. But it always happens like this, those who don't want to believe won't believe; they make excuses and don't learn the truth; and when you tell them, they never believe it.”
es: —Oh, it's those damned witches, young master, and I wish I had died, truly. They're always up to those things, young master, and they almost scare me to death. Please, don't tell anyone, young master, or old Mr. Silas will scold me because he says witches don't exist. I wish he were here now... Let's see what he would say! I'm sure he wouldn't find a way to explain it this time. Stubborn people die of stubbornness; they never want to look at things to see what's really happening, and when someone sees it and tells them, they go and don't believe it.

en: Tom give him a dime, and said we wouldn’t tell nobody; and told him to buy some more thread to tie up his wool with; and then looks at Jim, and says:
vi: Tom gave him a penny and told him not to be afraid, promising not to tell anyone. He also told him to buy more rope to tie up the clothes. Then he turned to Jim and said:
tr: Tom gave her ten cents and told her that we wouldn't tell anyone anything; after advising her to get some more string to tie her hair, he looked at Jim and said:
es: Tom gave him ten cents and told him that we wouldn't tell anyone and that he should go buy more thread to tie his hair, and then he looks at Jim and goes and says:

en: “I wonder if Uncle Silas is going to hang this nigger. If I was to catch a nigger that was ungrateful enough to run away, I wouldn’t give him up, I’d hang him.” And whilst the nigger stepped to the door to look at the dime and bite it to see if it was good, he whispers to Jim and says:
vi: - I don't know if Silas intends to hang this black man or not. If I caught any ungrateful black man running away, I would have to hang him, no mercy. And while the black man stepped outside the door to take a closer look at the half-dollar, raising it up to bite and see if it was good, Tom whispered into Jim's ear:
tr: “Uncle Silas, do you think he will hang this black man?” “If I caught a black man who was unfaithful enough to run away, I would never forgive him, I would hang him right then and there.” While the black man stepped outside into the light to look at the ten cents and bit the coin to see if it was real, Tom leaned over and whispered to Jim:
es: —I wonder if Uncle Silas is going to hang this black man. If I caught a black man ungrateful enough to escape, I wouldn't turn him in; I would hang him myself. And while the black man went to the door to look at the ten-cent coin and bite it to see if it was good, he whispered to Jim in a low voice:

en: “Don’t ever let on to know us. And if you hear any digging going on nights, it’s us; we’re going to set you free.”
vi: - Don't reveal that you know us. At night, if you hear the sound of digging, it's us digging. We will get you out.
tr: "Don't let anyone know that you recognize us. If you hear digging sounds at night, it's us: We will rescue you."
es: —Don't let them find out that you know us. And if you hear digging at night, it's us coming to set you free.

en: Jim only had time to grab us by the hand and squeeze it; then the nigger come back, and we said we’d come again some time if the nigger wanted us to; and he said he would, more particular if it was dark, because the witches went for him mostly in the dark, and it was good to have folks around then.
vi: Jim only had time to grab our hands and squeeze tightly. The black man turned around, and we told him that we would come whenever he needed us. He said he hoped so because ghosts often came to him at night, so having someone around would make him less scared.
tr: Jim only had time to grab and squeeze our hands, the other black man came back and we told him that we could come again if he wanted; he especially wanted us to come when it was dark, because witches mostly came at night and it would be good to have someone with him.
es: Jim had no time other than to grab our hands and squeeze them. Then the black man returned and we said we would come back again if he wanted, and he said yes, especially if it was at night, because the witches attacked him at night, and then it was really convenient for him to have people by his side.

en: CHAPTER XXXV.
vi: Chapter XXXV
tr: Chapter Thirty-Five
es: Chapter 35

en: It would be most an hour yet till breakfast, so we left and struck down into the woods; because Tom said we got to have some light to see how to dig by, and a lantern makes too much, and might get us into trouble; what we must have was a lot of them rotten chunks that’s called fox-fire, and just makes a soft kind of a glow when you lay them in a dark place. We fetched an armful and hid it in the weeds, and set down to rest, and Tom says, kind of dissatisfied:
vi: Almost an hour before breakfast time, we ran into the forest. Tom said we needed light to dig the earth, but using a lamp would be too conspicuous, so we had to gather glowing rotten branches that people call firefly wood. We collected an armful and hid it in the thick grass. While resting, Tom said, looking somewhat dissatisfied:
tr: There was still about an hour until breakfast, so we left and went into the forest; because Tom had said that we would need some light to see ahead while digging, but a lantern would be too much and could get us into trouble; we needed to find some rotten wood called foxfire. When you put this wood in a dark place, it emitted a faint light. We gathered an armful of foxfire and hid it among the grass, then sat down to rest a bit. Tom, still unsatisfied, said:
es: THERE WAS STILL almost an hour left before breakfast, so we went to the forest because Tom said we needed some light to see while we dug, but a lantern gave too much and could get us into trouble, so we needed to gather a bunch of that phosphorescent rotten wood they call "foxfire" that only gives off a kind of soft glow when placed in a dark spot. We gathered a lot, hid it among the grass, and sat down to rest, when Tom suddenly says, sounding displeased:

en: “Blame it, this whole thing is just as easy and awkward as it can be. And so it makes it so rotten difficult to get up a difficult plan. There ain’t no watchman to be drugged—now there ought to be a watchman. There ain’t even a dog to give a sleeping-mixture to. And there’s Jim chained by one leg, with a ten-foot chain, to the leg of his bed: why, all you got to do is to lift up the bedstead and slip off the chain. And Uncle Silas he trusts everybody; sends the key to the punkin-headed nigger, and don’t send nobody to watch the nigger. Jim could a got out of that window-hole before this, only there wouldn’t be no use trying to travel with a ten-foot chain on his leg. Why, drat it, Huck, it’s the stupidest arrangement I ever see. You got to invent all the difficulties. Well, we can’t help it; we got to do the best we can with the materials we’ve got. Anyhow, there’s one thing—there’s more honor in getting him out through a lot of difficulties and dangers, where there warn’t one of them furnished to you by the people who it was their duty to furnish them, and you had to contrive them all out of your own head. Now look at just that one thing of the lantern. When you come down to the cold facts, we simply got to let on that a lantern’s resky. Why, we could work with a torchlight procession if we wanted to, I believe. Now, whilst I think of it, we got to hunt up something to make a saw out of the first chance we get.”
vi: - Everything is too easy and boring. Finding a difficult plan is not easy. There is no guard for the prisoner so I can use the sleeping potion. And Jim is only shackled by one leg to the bed, so all I have to do is lift the bed and pull the chain out. And Uncle Silas gave the key to that foolish black man. Jim could also crawl out through the window hole, but he can't drag the chain far. It's so boring, I find all the arrangements too ordinary, so we have to create all sorts of difficulties. Rescuing him from here must involve many difficulties and dangers to be impressive. If no one causes those difficulties for us, we have to think and create those difficulties ourselves. Ah, I think we could use the saw if we have the chance.
tr: “Damn it, this job is way too easy and it breaks the code. That's why it makes it difficult to come up with a hard plan, damn it. There's no guard to give a sleeping pill to... Yet there should definitely be a guard. There's not even a dog we can give a sleep-inducing mixture to. Also, Jim is chained to the leg of his bed with a three-meter chain, all we have to do is lift the bed and remove the chain. Uncle Silas trusts everyone; he sends the key to that empty-headed black man and doesn't send anyone to watch over him. If Jim wanted, he could have already gotten out of that window hole, though he couldn't go anywhere with a three-meter chain on his foot. I'm getting discouraged, Huck, I've never heard of such a stupid setup before. We'll have to invent all the difficulties ourselves. Anyway, there's nothing else to do, it's best to make do with the materials we have and get this job done as best as we can. The honor of rescuing Jim by facing a lot of difficulties and dangers is great. Moreover, if the people who were supposed to create these difficulties were lazy and you had to create all the difficulties and dangers yourself, you add to your honor. Let's consider the simplest thing, like this lantern. Looking at the solid facts, we have to pretend there's a danger in using the lantern. Yet if we wanted, we could work with a whole parade of lanterns, no one would notice. By the way, we need to make a saw without wasting any time, we need to find suitable materials.
es: —Damn it, all of this is so easy it's disgusting. That's why it's so hard to organize a complicated plan. There's no guard to drug, and there should be a guard. Not even a dog to give something to make it sleep. And then, Jim is chained by one leg, with a ten-foot chain, to the bedpost; but you just have to lift the bed and remove the chain! And Uncle Silas trusts everyone. He sends the key to that scatterbrained black man and doesn't send anyone to watch over him. Jim could have escaped through that window by now, except he can't run with a ten-foot chain on his leg. Damn it, Huck, it's the most absurd system I've ever seen. You have to invent all the difficulties. Well, we can't avoid it, we have to do the best we can with the material we have. In any case, we have something left: it's more honorable to get him out amidst difficulties and dangers when the people who had the obligation to create them didn't, and one had to invent them by their own means. Just think about that lantern thing. If we only see the facts themselves, we simply have to pretend that the lantern thing is dangerous. But we could work with a torch procession if we wanted to, I think! Now that I think about it, we have to find something that can act as a saw as soon as we can.

en: “What do we want of a saw?”
vi: Ah, I think we could use the saw if we have the chance.
tr: “What are we going to do with the saw?”
es: —Why do we need a saw?

en: “What do we want of it? Hain’t we got to saw the leg of Jim’s bed off, so as to get the chain loose?”
vi: - What are you using the saw for? - Saw off the leg of Jim's bed to remove the chain.
tr: “What are we going to do? Don't we need to cut the leg of Jim's bed to remove the chain?”
es: —Why do we need a saw? Don't we have to saw off the leg of Jim's bed to remove the chain?

en: “Why, you just said a body could lift up the bedstead and slip the chain off.”
vi: - So you just said that if we lift the bed, we can pull the chain out right away?
tr: “Why? You just said that lifting the bed and removing the chain would be enough.”
es: —But you said that it's enough to lift the bed and pull the chain...

en: “Well, if that ain’t just like you, Huck Finn. You can get up the infant-schooliest ways of going at a thing. Why, hain’t you ever read any books at all?—Baron Trenck, nor Casanova, nor Benvenuto Chelleeny, nor Henri IV., nor none of them heroes? Who ever heard of getting a prisoner loose in such an old-maidy way as that? No; the way all the best authorities does is to saw the bed-leg in two, and leave it just so, and swallow the sawdust, so it can’t be found, and put some dirt and grease around the sawed place so the very keenest seneskal can’t see no sign of it’s being sawed, and thinks the bed-leg is perfectly sound. Then, the night you’re ready, fetch the leg a kick, down she goes; slip off your chain, and there you are. Nothing to do but hitch your rope ladder to the battlements, shin down it, break your leg in the moat—because a rope ladder is nineteen foot too short, you know—and there’s your horses and your trusty vassles, and they scoop you up and fling you across a saddle, and away you go to your native Langudoc, or Navarre, or wherever it is. It’s gaudy, Huck. I wish there was a moat to this cabin. If we get time, the night of the escape, we’ll dig one.”
vi: - You're as dumb as a cow. You play like a child. Haven't you ever read books? Baron Trenck, Casanova. Benvenuto Cellini, Henry the Fourth, all those heroes, haven't you ever read about them? Has anyone ever rescued a prisoner in such a womanly way? You have to saw the bed leg in half, then erase all traces of sawdust so no one can see, smear some dirt or grease on the sawed part so that even the sharp-eyed warden can't see the cut and thinks the bed leg is intact, then lift the chain off. That's it. Then you just have to place the rope ladder into the loophole, climb out, and slide down into a moat. Down there, horses and servants are ready to help you mount, and then you go; go back to your homeland, Languedoc or Nava, or somewhere else. Oh, it's wonderful. I want a trench leading to that hut. If we have time, we will dig a trench.
tr: “This is just the kind of thing for you, Huck Finn. In some matters, you're such a wimp, man! Have you never read a book before? Have you never heard of Baron Trenck, Casanova, Benvenuto Cellini, IV. Henry, or the other heroes, for God's sake? Where have you ever seen a prisoner being freed using methods fit for old ladies? No, the greatest experts in this field cut the leg of the bed, but leave it in place and swallow the sawdust so it can't be found; they smear mud and grease on the cut so that even the most vigilant guards won't realize it's been cut, thinking the bed leg is completely intact. But on the night you're ready, you give the bed leg a kick, it splits in two; you remove your chain, and that's it. Then all you have to do is tie the rope ladder to the barred windows, climb down, and fall into the ditch and break your leg – because the rope ladder is five or six meters too short – and right in front of you, you'll find your horses and loyal servants, who will grab you, put you on a saddle, and you'll head off to your homeland, Languedoc, Navarre, or wherever it is. How grand it would be, Huck, if only this cabin had a ditch too. If we find the time, let's dig one on the night of the escape.”
es: —Well, that's typical of you, Huck Finn. You come up with the same ideas as a schoolboy. Haven't you ever read a book in your life? The Baron Trenck, or Casanova, Benvenuto Cellini, or Henry IV, or any of those heroes? Who has ever heard of freeing a prisoner in such a simple way? No, the way the best authorities do it is to saw the bed leg in two and leave it like that and eat the sawdust, so they can't find it, and put some dust and grease around the spot, so that not even the sharpest steward perceives the slightest sign that it has been sawed and believes that the bed leg is perfectly fine. Then, the night you're ready, you kick the leg and the bed falls, you take off the chain and that's it. All you have to do is take the rope ladder to the walls, go down it, break your leg in the moat, because rope ladders are always nineteen feet short, you know, and there are the horses and trusted vassals who pick you up, mount you, and take you to your Languedoc or your Navarre or wherever you were born. It's a thrill, Huck. I wish this cabin had a moat. If there's time, the night of the escape we'll dig one.

en: I says:
vi: I asked:
tr: If we find the time, let's dig one on the night of the escape.”
es: And I go and say:

en: “What do we want of a moat when we’re going to snake him out from under the cabin?”
vi: - But we were planning to let it slip out at the foot of the prison cell wall, weren't we? Why do we need to dig a trench?
tr: "Well, but if we're going to get him out from under the shed, what use is the trench?"
es: —Why do we need a pit when we're going to take it out from under the cabin?

en: But he never heard me. He had forgot me and everything else. He had his chin in his hand, thinking. Pretty soon he sighs and shakes his head; then sighs again, and says:
vi: It didn't hear me say anything. It had forgotten that I was sitting there, and forgotten everything. It rested its chin on its hand, thinking. After a while, it sighed and shook its head. Then it sighed again and said:
tr: I asked. But she didn't even hear me. She had forgotten me and everything else. She was thinking with her chin resting in her palm. After a while, she sighed, shook her head from side to side, and then sighed again, saying:
es: But he didn't hear me. He had forgotten about me and everything else. He had his chin resting on his hand and was thinking. After a moment, he sighs and shakes his head; then he sighs again and says:

en: “No, it wouldn’t do—there ain’t necessity enough for it.”
vi: - No, it's not possible, it's not really necessary.
tr: “No, no, that won't do... it's not necessary enough.”
es: —No, that wouldn't be right; it's not entirely necessary.

en: “For what?” I says.
vi: - What did you say you don't need?
tr: "What is it?" I said.
es: —What? —I asked.

en: “Why, to saw Jim’s leg off,” he says.
vi: - Ah, the matter of sawing off Jim's leg.
tr: “Cutting off Jim's leg, of course,” he said.
es: —Man, cut off Jim's leg —he answered me.

en: “Good land!” I says; “why, there ain’t no necessity for it. And what would you want to saw his leg off for, anyway?”
vi: - Oh my God! Why is that? So what are you planning to do by cutting off Jim's leg?
tr: “My God!” I said, “It is definitely not necessary at all. Why do you even want to cut off his leg?”
es: —Darn! —I said—, I don't see any need. And besides, why do you want to cut off his leg?

en: “Well, some of the best authorities has done it. They couldn’t get the chain off, so they just cut their hand off and shoved. And a leg would be better still. But we got to let that go. There ain’t necessity enough in this case; and, besides, Jim’s a nigger, and wouldn’t understand the reasons for it, and how it’s the custom in Europe; so we’ll let it go. But there’s one thing—he can have a rope ladder; we can tear up our sheets and make him a rope ladder easy enough. And we can send it to him in a pie; it’s mostly done that way. And I’ve et worse pies.”
vi: - Some famous people do that. They can't remove the chains, so they just cut off one of their arms. Better to have one leg left than none. But maybe we shouldn't do that. This case doesn't really require it, and besides, Jim is a black man, he wouldn't understand why we would do such a thing. But we can make him a rope ladder. We could tear the bed sheet into strips and make him a rope ladder. And we could hide the rope ladder inside a cake and give it to him.
tr: “Some of the greatest masters did it that way. They couldn't remove the chain, so they cut off their hands and escaped. Cutting off a leg would be even better. But let's skip that for now. In Jim's case, it's not really necessary, plus Jim is a black man and won't understand why it's customary in Europe; so let's not do it this time. But there's something else... A rope ladder could work; we can tear up our sheets and easily make a rope ladder for him. We can send this ladder to him inside a pie, that's usually how it's done. I've eaten the worst pies just...”
es: —Well, that's what some of the most authoritative authors do. They can't tear off the chain, so they cut off the hand and pull. And a leg would be even better. But we will have to give up on that. In this case, there isn't enough need, and besides, Jim is black and wouldn't understand the motives or the European custom, so we'll let it go. But, on the other hand, we can do something else: we can tear the sheets into strips and make a very easy rope ladder for him. And we can send it to him inside a cake; it's almost always done that way. I've eaten worse cakes.

en: “Why, Tom Sawyer, how you talk,” I says; “Jim ain’t got no use for a rope ladder.”
vi: That's how they usually do it.
tr: “What nonsense are you talking about, Tom Sawyer?” I said. “What is Jim going to do with a rope ladder?”
es: —But, Tom Sawyer, what things you say —I commented—; a rope ladder is of no use to Jim.

en: “He has got use for it. How you talk, you better say; you don’t know nothing about it. He’s got to have a rope ladder; they all do.”
vi: And it has to be a really big cake. - What are you talking about? Why would Jim need a rope ladder?
tr: “It is essential to use it. What nonsense are you talking about, you should have said from the beginning that you don't understand these things at all. A rope ladder is indispensable, all the masters use a rope ladder.” “Okay, but what will he do with the rope ladder?”
es: —It has to be worth something to him. More like, what things you say; you don't know anything about this. He needs a rope ladder; it happens to everyone.

en: “What in the nation can he do with it?”
vi: - Do what?
tr: “What will he do?
es: —What the hell is he going to do with her?

en: “Do with it? He can hide it in his bed, can’t he?” That’s what they all do; and he’s got to, too. Huck, you don’t ever seem to want to do anything that’s regular; you want to be starting something fresh all the time. S’pose he don’t do nothing with it? ain’t it there in his bed, for a clew, after he’s gone? and don’t you reckon they’ll want clews? Of course they will. And you wouldn’t leave them any? That would be a pretty howdy-do, wouldn’t it! I never heard of such a thing.”
vi: - Do what? He could hide it in the bed. Everyone does that, so Jim has to do it too. Huck, it seems like you never want to do anything by the rules, you always want to do something new. So you don't think they need to leave any traces?? I said: - Alright, if everyone else is doing it, then we should follow suit to comply with the rules.
tr: “What will he do? He can hide it inside his bed, can't he? They all do that; he has to do it too. Huck, it seems like you don't want to do anything according to the rules, you are intent on discovering everything from scratch. Let's say he didn't use it for anything… Won't it remain as a clue inside the bed after he leaves? Don't you ever consider that they will want a clue? Of course they will want it. And won't you leave them any clue? Does this fit the code at all? I've never heard of such a thing in my life, honestly.”
es: —What to do with it? You can hide it in the bed, can't you? That's what everyone does, and he has to do it too. Huck, it seems like you never want to do things right; you want to make it up every time. Suppose he does nothing with it. Doesn't he have it there in the bed to leave a clue when it's gone? And don't you think they'll look for clues? Of course they will. And, don't you plan to leave them any? That would be great, I assure you! I've never heard anything like it.

en: “Well,” I says, “if it’s in the regulations, and he’s got to have it, all right, let him have it; because I don’t wish to go back on no regulations; but there’s one thing, Tom Sawyer—if we go to tearing up our sheets to make Jim a rope ladder, we’re going to get into trouble with Aunt Sally, just as sure as you’re born. Now, the way I look at it, a hickry-bark ladder don’t cost nothing, and don’t waste nothing, and is just as good to load up a pie with, and hide in a straw tick, as any rag ladder you can start; and as for Jim, he ain’t had no experience, and so he don’t care what kind of a—”
vi: But Tom Sawyer, if we tear the bed sheets into pieces to make a rope ladder for Jim, we'll get into trouble with Aunt Sally. Now I think this, making a ladder out of bark would also keep it hidden. As for Jim, he has no experience, so anything would be fine for him.
tr: “Since the rule is like this and it has to be a rope ladder, fine, let it be; I really don't want to go against any rule; but there's something else, Tom Sawyer... If we tear our sheets to make a rope ladder for Jim, we'll get into big trouble with Aunt Sally, I know this for sure. If you ask me, a ladder made of walnut tree bark is both cost-free and doesn't require wasting anything else, plus it can be put inside a pie or among the straw of the mattress just like rope ladders; besides, Jim has no experience in these matters anyway, so I doubt he'll care what kind of ladder we use...”
es: —Well —I said—, if that's part of the rules and he needs it, then we'll make one for him, because I don't want to break any rules; but I'm telling you one thing, Tom Sawyer, if we start tearing up sheets to make a ladder for Jim, we're going to get into trouble with Aunt Sally, you can be sure of that. It seems to me that a ladder made of walnut bark costs nothing and doesn't ruin anything, and it can be hidden just as well inside a cake and concealed in a straw mattress as any rope ladder, and as for Jim, he has no experience, so he doesn't care what kind of...

en: “Oh, shucks, Huck Finn, if I was as ignorant as you I’d keep still—that’s what I’d do. Who ever heard of a state prisoner escaping by a hickry-bark ladder? Why, it’s perfectly ridiculous.”
vi: - Huck Finn, if I were as dumb as you, I'd rather keep quiet. Has anyone ever heard of someone escaping from prison using a bark ladder? That's utterly ridiculous. - Fine, it's up to you.
tr: “Gene saçmaladın, Huck Finn, cahil cahil konuşup duruyorsun iki saattir… Hiçbir şey bilmiyorsan bari çeneni tutmayı bileydin. Bir mahkûmun ağaç kabuğundan merdivenle kaçtığı da nerede duyulmuş? Böyle gülünç şey olur mu hiç?”
es: —Oh, gosh, Huck Finn, if I were as ignorant as you, I would keep my mouth shut, I assure you. Who has ever heard of a state prisoner escaping with a walnut bark ladder? It's completely ridiculous.

en: “Well, all right, Tom, fix it your own way; but if you’ll take my advice, you’ll let me borrow a sheet off of the clothesline.”
vi: Or maybe we could borrow a bedsheet from the clothesline outside?
tr: “Alright, Tom, let it be as you wish; but listen to me and please allow me to borrow from the hanging laundry.”
es: —Well, alright, Tom, do it as you like, but if you want to take my advice, let him borrow one of the sheets that are hanging out to dry.

en: He said that would do. And that gave him another idea, and he says:
vi: It said that's fine too. But then it came up with another idea:
tr: He did not object to this. In fact, another idea came to his mind:
es: He said he was fine, and that gave him another idea, and he said:

en: “Borrow a shirt, too.”
vi: - Borrow another shirt.
tr: “Also, borrow a shirt.”
es: —Borrow a shirt as well.

en: “What do we want of a shirt, Tom?”
vi: - What for, Tom?
tr: “Well, what are we going to do with the shirt, Tom?”
es: —Why do we want a shirt?

en: “Want it for Jim to keep a journal on.”
vi: - Let Jim write his diary in there
tr: “For Jim to keep a diary.”
es: —So that Jim writes a diary.

en: “Journal your granny—Jim can’t write.”
vi: - Diary my foot, Jim doesn't even know how to write.
tr: "Come on now... Jim can't read or write."
es: —Diary, your grandma... Jim doesn't know how to write.

en: “S’pose he can’t write—he can make marks on the shirt, can’t he, if we make him a pen out of an old pewter spoon or a piece of an old iron barrel-hoop?”
vi: - He doesn't know how to write, but he can scribble a few lines. We can make him a pen out of an iron spoon or a piece of iron from a barrel hoop.
tr: “Let's say he can't write... can't he draw pictures and signs on the shirt either? We can make him a pen from an iron spoon or a piece of barrel hoop.”
es: —Let's suppose he doesn't know... He can make marks on the shirt, can't he? Especially if we make a pen for him with an old pewter spoon or with a piece of an old barrel stave.

en: “Why, Tom, we can pull a feather out of a goose and make him a better one; and quicker, too.”
vi: - Should I pluck a goose feather to make him a pen? It would be quick too.
tr: "Well, but we can pluck a goose's feather and make a much better pen, Tom, and it would be quicker.""
es: —But, Tom, we can pluck a feather from a goose, and it turns out better, and faster, too.

en: “Prisoners don’t have geese running around the donjon-keep to pull pens out of, you muggins. They always make their pens out of the hardest, toughest, troublesomest piece of old brass candlestick or something like that they can get their hands on; and it takes them weeks and weeks and months and months to file it out, too, because they’ve got to do it by rubbing it on the wall. They wouldn’t use a goose-quill if they had it. It ain’t regular.”
vi: How could the imprisoned people see a goose to get goose feathers for making pens, how foolish are you? They always have to use something really hard, really rough, like the bronze leg of a candlestick or something else they can grab in the prison tower to make a pen. Then it takes weeks, even months to make a pen, because they have to grind it against the prison wall at night. Even if they had goose feathers, they wouldn't use them. Because that would not be according to the rules.
tr: “Prisoners in jail don't have geese to pluck feathers from to make pens, you fool. They always make their pens from old brass candlesticks or other hard, rigid, and difficult-to-bend objects they have at hand; making a pen can take weeks, even months, because they have no choice but to rub what they have against the wall to turn it into a pen. Even if they could find goose feathers, they wouldn't use them. It doesn't follow the rules.”
es: —Prisoners don't have geese running around the dungeons to pluck feathers from, you fool. They always make the quills from the hardest, most difficult, and most complicated piece of an old copper candlestick or something they can get their hands on, and it takes them weeks and weeks and months and months to sharpen it, because they have to do it by rubbing it against the wall. They wouldn't use a goose feather even if they had one. It's not right.

en: “Well, then, what’ll we make him the ink out of?”
vi: - Then what will we use for ink?
tr: “Well then, how are we going to make the ink?”
es: —Well, then, what do we use to make the ink?

en: “Many makes it out of iron-rust and tears; but that’s the common sort and women; the best authorities uses their own blood. Jim can do that; and when he wants to send any little common ordinary mysterious message to let the world know where he’s captivated, he can write it on the bottom of a tin plate with a fork and throw it out of the window. The Iron Mask always done that, and it’s a blame’ good way, too.”
vi: - Many people use rust with tears as ink, but that's a common and very feminine style. Famous guys use their own blood as ink. Jim can do that. And whenever he wants to send a small, ordinary but secret letter to let people know where he's imprisoned, he can write it on the bottom of an iron plate, then throw it out the window. The Iron Mask gang often did that, it's really amazing.
tr: “Most prisoners mix rust with their tears; but this is typical of the lower class and women; the experts use their own blood. If Jim can do this and wants to send a simple mysterious message to let the world know where he is being held, he can scratch it onto the back of a tin plate with a fork and throw it out the window. The Man in the Iron Mask always does it that way, and in my opinion, it’s a remarkably good method.”
es: —Many do it with iron rust and tears, but those are the more common prisoners and women; the most authoritative authors use their own blood. Jim can do it, and when he wants to send any ordinary mysterious message so the world knows where he is captive, he can write it on the bottom of a tin plate with a fork and throw it out the window. That’s what the Man in the Iron Mask always did, and besides, it turns out great.

en: “Jim ain’t got no tin plates. They feed him in a pan.”
vi: - How could Jim have a metal plate? They fed him using a pot.
tr: “Jim doesn't have a tin plate. They serve him food on a tray.”
es: —Jim doesn't have any tin plates. They feed him in a bowl.

en: “That ain’t nothing; we can get him some.”
vi: - That doesn't matter.
tr: “It doesn't matter, we'll take him a plate.”
es: —That doesn't matter, we can get some for you.

en: “Can’t nobody read his plates.”
vi: I'll get him a few plates. - But who can read his handwriting?
tr: "No one can read what is written on his plate"
es: —And no one will be able to read what it says on the plate.

en: “That ain’t got anything to do with it, Huck Finn. All he’s got to do is to write on the plate and throw it out. You don’t have to be able to read it. Why, half the time you can’t read anything a prisoner writes on a tin plate, or anywhere else.”
vi: - It's okay. He just needs to write on the disc and throw it out. There's no need to read it. Most people can't read what a prisoner writes on the iron disc.
tr: “This has nothing to do with our topic, Huck Finn. All he has to do is write on the plate and throw it out. We don't need to be able to read it. Half of what a prisoner writes on a tin plate or elsewhere is unreadable anyway.”
es: —That has nothing to do with the matter, Huck Finn. All he has to do is write on the plate and throw it. It doesn't need to be read. But half the time, you can't read anything that state prisoners write on a tin plate, or anywhere else.

en: “Well, then, what’s the sense in wasting the plates?”
vi: - It's such a waste of a disc.
tr: “So why are we wasting the plates then?”
es: —Well, then, what's the point of ruining those dishes?

en: “Why, blame it all, it ain’t the prisoner’s plates.”
vi: - It's not a prisoner's plate to worry about wasting.
tr: “What difference does it make, they are not the prisoner's plates.”
es: —But, damn it, they are not the prisoner's dishes.

en: “But it’s somebody’s plates, ain’t it?”
vi: - So, it's someone's plate, right?
tr: “But it's someone's plate, isn't it?”
es: —But they belong to someone, don't they?

en: “Well, spos’n it is? What does the prisoner care whose—”
vi: - So, it's someone's plate, right? - Well, let's say it belongs to someone, but why should the prisoner care?
tr: “Let's say it is so, so what? Why would the prisoner care about who the plate belongs to…”
es: —Well, let's suppose so. What difference does it make to the prisoner?

en: He broke off there, because we heard the breakfast-horn blowing. So we cleared out for the house.
vi: It suddenly stopped talking because we had heard the bell calling us for breakfast. We hurried back home.
tr: He fell silent here, because we had heard the breakfast bell ring. Thus, we headed home.
es: And then he stopped because we heard the breakfast horn sounding. So we went to the house.

en: Along during the morning I borrowed a sheet and a white shirt off of the clothes-line; and I found an old sack and put them in it, and we went down and got the fox-fire, and put that in too. I called it borrowing, because that was what pap always called it; but Tom said it warn’t borrowing, it was stealing. He said we was representing prisoners; and prisoners don’t care how they get a thing so they get it, and nobody don’t blame them for it, either. It ain’t no crime in a prisoner to steal the thing he needs to get away with, Tom said; it’s his right; and so, as long as we was representing a prisoner, we had a perfect right to steal anything on this place we had the least use for to get ourselves out of prison with. He said if we warn’t prisoners it would be a very different thing, and nobody but a mean, ornery person would steal when he warn’t a prisoner. So we allowed we would steal everything there was that come handy. And yet he made a mighty fuss, one day, after that, when I stole a watermelon out of the nigger-patch and eat it; and he made me go and give the niggers a dime without telling them what it was for. Tom said that what he meant was, we could steal anything we needed. Well, I says, I needed the watermelon. But he said I didn’t need it to get out of prison with; there’s where the difference was. He said if I’d a wanted it to hide a knife in, and smuggle it to Jim to kill the seneskal with, it would a been all right. So I let it go at that, though I couldn’t see no advantage in my representing a prisoner if I got to set down and chaw over a lot of gold-leaf distinctions like that every time I see a chance to hog a watermelon.
vi: That morning, I borrowed a bedsheet and a shirt from the clothesline, found an old bag, stuffed those things in it, then went downstairs to get some rotten firewood and put everything into the bag. I called it borrowing because my father usually called it that. But Tom said it wasn't borrowing, it was stealing. He said that the two of us were representing the imprisoned; and for the imprisoned, any way to get them supplies was acceptable, and no one would blame them for it. For a prisoner, taking what they need to escape is not a crime, it's their right, Tom said. So if we were representing the imprisoned, we had every right to steal anything on their behalf, at least anything that could be used to escape from prison. He also said that if we weren't prisoners, then it would be a different story, and if someone who wasn't a prisoner stole, they would just be a very bad person. Therefore, we thought we could steal anything we could get our hands on. Yet, one day, I stole a watermelon from the black man's garden to eat, and he scolded me harshly, then he gave the black people a dime without saying what it was for. Tom said that we should only steal things we needed. I said that I needed a watermelon. He said we didn't need a watermelon to escape from prison. He said if I could hide a knife and give it to Jim so he could kill the warden, that would be very good. I had to agree, although I thought it was pointless to be so far-fetched, and I'd rather just eat a watermelon.
tr: That morning, I borrowed a sheet and a shirt from the hanging laundry; I found an old sack and put both inside, then we went to find the foxfire and put it in the sack as well. I said borrowed because my father always said so; but Tom said it wasn't borrowing, it was stealing. According to him, we were representing prisoners; prisoners didn't care how they got something and no one blamed them for it. Tom said it wasn't a crime for a prisoner to steal what he needed to escape; it was his right, so as long as we were representing a prisoner, we had every right to steal even the least of what we needed to free ourselves from prison. If we weren't prisoners, everything would be different, if someone who wasn't a prisoner stole, he could only be a common person. So, we said we could steal anything that came our way. Yet, when I stole and ate a watermelon from the negroes' garden in the following days, he got very angry with me. "Go give the negroes ten cents and don't tell them why," he said. This time, Tom said we could only steal what we needed. "But I needed that watermelon," I said. But he said I didn't need the watermelon to escape from prison, that was the difference. If I sent the watermelon with a knife inside to Jim to kill the head guard, there was no problem. So I gave in, but if I had to sit and split hairs like this every time I got a chance to swipe a watermelon, there was no advantage to representing a prisoner at all.
es: That morning I borrowed a sheet and a white shirt from the clothesline and found an old sack to put them in; we went down to get the "fox fire" and put that in the sack too. I said that it was borrowing, because that's what father always called it, but Tom said it wasn't borrowing, it was stealing. He said we were pretending to be prisoners and that prisoners don't care how they get things as long as they get them and that no one minds. It's not a crime for a prisoner to steal what he needs to escape, Tom said; it's his right, and as long as we were pretending to be prisoners, we had every right to steal anything around if it helped us get out of jail. He said that if we weren't prisoners it would be very different, and that it was mean and low to steal when you weren't a prisoner. So we agreed to steal anything that would be useful to us. And yet, one day after that, he made a huge fuss when I stole a watermelon from the negroes' garden and ate it, and he made me go give the negroes ten cents without explaining why. Tom said that what he meant was that we could steal anything we needed. "Well," I said, "I needed the watermelon." But he said I didn't need it to get out of jail; that was the difference. He said that if I had wanted to hide a knife inside it and pass it to Jim to kill the guard with, that would have been fine. So I let it go, though I didn't see the point of pretending to be a prisoner if I had to think about such difficult distinctions every time I saw a chance to take a watermelon.

en: Well, as I was saying, we waited that morning till everybody was settled down to business, and nobody in sight around the yard; then Tom he carried the sack into the lean-to whilst I stood off a piece to keep watch. By-and-by he come out, and we went and set down on the woodpile to talk. He says:
vi: Then, that morning, after waiting for everyone to go out to the fields, Tom took the sack to the back of the hut while I stayed behind to keep watch. A little later, he came out, and the two of us sat down on the logs to talk. He said:
tr: Anyway, as I said, we waited until everyone started to get busy with their own work that morning, and by then no one was visible in the courtyard anymore; while Tom was carrying the sack to the storeroom, I kept watch from a bit of a distance. After a while, he came out again, and we went and sat on a pile of wood and started talking.
es: Well, as I was saying, that morning we waited until everyone went to work and no one was seen in the yard. Then Tom took the sack to the shed while I stayed a few steps behind to keep watch. After a while, he came out and we sat down to talk on the woodpile. He goes and says:

en: “Everything’s all right now except tools; and that’s easy fixed.”
vi: - Everything is done, only the tools are missing, but this is not too difficult.
tr: “Everything is ready now,” said Tom, “but only the tools are left; we can easily take care of that.”
es: —Now everything is in order, except for the tools, and that's easy.

en: “Tools?” I says.
vi: - What tool?
tr: “The tools?”
es: —Tools? —I asked.

en: “Yes.”
vi: - I asked.
tr: “Yes.”
es: —Yes.

en: “Tools for what?”
vi: - Tools for digging, what else would they be for?
tr: “What are the tools for?”
es: —Tools for what?

en: “Why, to dig with. We ain’t a-going to gnaw him out, are we?”
vi: - Tools for digging, what else would they be for? Aren't we planning to dig in there to pull him out?
tr: “Of course, to dig. We won't be gnawing at the soil to get it out, I suppose.”
es: —Man, to dig. We aren't going to make a tunnel with our teeth, right?

en: “Ain’t them old crippled picks and things in there good enough to dig a nigger out with?” I says.
vi: Aren't we planning to dig in there to pull him out?
tr: "Won't the old pickaxes inside be enough to get a black man out?""
es: —Don't we have enough with those old picks and shovels to dig out a black man?

en: He turns on me, looking pitying enough to make a body cry, and says:
vi: It turned to look at me with a pitying expression that could make one cry, then said:
tr: He turned and looked at me with such pity that I could have cried at that moment.
es: He turned towards me, with a face so sorrowful it made you want to cry, and then he says:

en: “Huck Finn, did you ever hear of a prisoner having picks and shovels, and all the modern conveniences in his wardrobe to dig himself out with? Now I want to ask you—if you got any reasonableness in you at all—what kind of a show would that give him to be a hero? Why, they might as well lend him the key and done with it. Picks and shovels—why, they wouldn’t furnish ’em to a king.”
vi: - Huck Finn, have you ever heard of a prisoner having a pickaxe to dig with? Why not just give him the key to make it easier? I said:
tr: “Huck Finn, have you ever heard of a prisoner with a pickaxe and a shovel, a prisoner who fills his locker with all modern tools to dig his way out? If you have even a little bit of sense in your head, I ask you, how will he become a hero if he escapes this way? We might as well just hand him the key. A pickaxe and a shovel… they wouldn't even give such tools to kings.”
es: —Huck Finn, have you ever heard in your life of a prisoner who has picks and shovels and all those conveniences in the closet to make a tunnel? What I want to ask you, assuming you still have a minimum of reason, is what motive would that be to make him a hero. Man, they could also lend him the key and be done with it. Picks and shovels... But they wouldn't even give those to a king.

en: “Well, then,” I says, “if we don’t want the picks and shovels, what do we want?”
vi: - Well, if we don't need hoes and shovels, then what do we need?
tr: “Alright, let's say we don't want pickaxes and shovels, then what do we want?”
es: —Well, then —I said—, if we don't need picks and shovels, what do we need?

en: “A couple of case-knives.”
vi: - A few knives.
tr: "Two pocketknives.""
es: —A pair of kitchen knives.

en: “To dig the foundations out from under that cabin with?”
vi: - Can you really dig it up??
tr: "To pierce through the foundations of the cabin?"
es: —To make a tunnel underneath that cabin?

en: “Yes.”
vi: - Yes
tr: “Yes.” "Oops!
es: —Yes.

en: “Confound it, it’s foolish, Tom.”
vi: - I think this is crazy. - I need to know.
tr: But this is very silly, Tom."
es: —Damn it, Tom, that's nonsense.

en: “It don’t make no difference how foolish it is, it’s the right way—and it’s the regular way. And there ain’t no other way, that ever I heard of, and I’ve read all the books that gives any information about these things. They always dig out with a case-knife—and not through dirt, mind you; generly it’s through solid rock. And it takes them weeks and weeks and weeks, and for ever and ever. Why, look at one of them prisoners in the bottom dungeon of the Castle Deef, in the harbor of Marseilles, that dug himself out that way; how long was he at it, you reckon?”
vi: In my opinion, that's the proper way to do it. There's no other way. I haven't heard of any other way. I've read all the books about these matters. They always dig with a knife, and you should remember that it's not just digging soil, but often digging through stone as well. And that takes countless weeks. Do you know how long it took a prisoner to dig the Deep Castle in Marseille?
tr: “Whether it is foolish or not, this is the truth… the one that complies with the rules. So far, I haven't heard of any other way, despite reading all the books that provide all kinds of information on such matters. They always dig with a knife… not the soil; they usually drill the rock with a knife. They work for weeks, it almost takes forever. One of the prisoners lying in the dungeon at the bottom of Deef Castle in the port of Marseille escaped by drilling the rock with a knife; guess how long it took?”
es: —It doesn't matter if it's nonsense, it's the right thing to do and it's how things are done. There is no other way that I know of, and I've read all the books that provide information about these things. They always do it with a knife, and not by digging in the ground, mind you; usually, it's in stone. It takes them weeks and weeks and weeks, and all the time without stopping and without stopping. You only have to look at one of those prisoners from the underground dungeons of Deef Castle, in the port of Marseille, who made a tunnel that way; how long do you think he spent digging?

en: “I don’t know.”
vi: - I don't know.
tr: "I don't know."
es: —I don't know.

en: “Well, guess.”
vi: - Try to guess.
tr: "Then guess.""
es: —Well, then make a guess.

en: “I don’t know. A month and a half.”
vi: - Try to guess. - A month and a half at most.
tr: "How should I know. A month and a half?"
es: —I don't know. A month and a half.

en: “Thirty-seven year—and he come out in China. That’s the kind. I wish the bottom of this fortress was solid rock.”
vi: - Thirty-seven years, then he crawled all the way to China. Just like that. If only this foundation were made of hard stone, it would be so much better.
tr: "Thirty-seven years... it came all the way from China. This is the rule of this matter. I wish the base of this castle was also rock."
es: —Thirty-seven years... And it came out in China. That's what is right. I wish the foundation of that fortress were made of stone.

en: “Jim don’t know nobody in China.”
vi: - Jim doesn't know anyone in China, does he?
tr: "Jim doesn't know anyone in China."
es: —Jim doesn't know anyone in China.

en: “What’s that got to do with it? Neither did that other fellow. But you’re always a-wandering off on a side issue. Why can’t you stick to the main point?”
vi: - What does that have to do with anything? The other person is the same. But you're straying from the point, let's get back to the main topic.
tr: “But what does this have to do with anything? That man didn't know anyone either. But you always get hung up on trivial things. Why do you stray away from the main issue?”
es: —What does that have to do with anything? Neither does that guy. But you always go off on tangents. Why don't you talk about the main issue?

en: “All right—I don’t care where he comes out, so he comes out; and Jim don’t, either, I reckon. But there’s one thing, anyway—Jim’s too old to be dug out with a case-knife. He won’t last.”
vi: - Alright, I don't need to know where he gets to, as long as he gets outside. The only thing is, Jim is too old and weak to dig his way out with a knife. He won't live to see that day!
tr: “Alright, well… it doesn't matter where it came from, it has emerged in the end; it probably doesn't matter for Jim either. However, there is one problem… Jim is too old to be removed with a knife. He doesn't have enough time left.”
es: —Well... I don't care where he comes out, as long as he comes out; and I reckon Jim doesn't either. But anyway, there's another thing: Jim is too old to hold out until we make a tunnel with a knife. He won't last that long.

en: “Yes he will last, too. You don’t reckon it’s going to take thirty-seven years to dig out through a dirt foundation, do you?”
vi: - Yes, it's possible to live. You probably think it would take thirty-seven years to dig through this foundation, don't you?
tr: “Don't worry, he has enough life left. You don't really think it will take thirty-seven years to dig the soil, do you?”
es: —Well, it will last. You don't think it's going to take us thirty-seven years to make a tunnel in the ground, do you?

en: “How long will it take, Tom?”
vi: - So how long does it take?
tr: “Well, how long will it take, Tom?”
es: —How long will it take us, Tom?

en: “Well, we can’t resk being as long as we ought to, because it mayn’t take very long for Uncle Silas to hear from down there by New Orleans. He’ll hear Jim ain’t from there. Then his next move will be to advertise Jim, or something like that. So we can’t resk being as long digging him out as we ought to. By rights I reckon we ought to be a couple of years; but we can’t. Things being so uncertain, what I recommend is this: that we really dig right in, as quick as we can; and after that, we can let on, to ourselves, that we was at it thirty-seven years. Then we can snatch him out and rush him away the first time there’s an alarm. Yes, I reckon that’ll be the best way.”
vi: - We can't let it drag on for too long, because if it takes too long, Uncle Silas down in New Orleans might hear that Jim is no longer there and make a fuss. Exactly, we would need several years, but we can't do that. So, we dig straight in, dig really fast, then we leave it and just think that we've been digging for thirty-seven years. Then we pull him out, and when there's an alarm, we push him away immediately. In my opinion, that's the best way.
tr: “Of course, we can't expect it to last as long as it normally would, because it won't take long for Uncle Silas to get news from New Orleans. He will find out that Jim is not from there. Then maybe he will put ads in the newspapers for Jim or do something similar. We can't risk getting him out in the necessary time. If you ask me, it would probably take a few years, but we can't wait that long. Since things are so uncertain, I suggest this: Let's dig as fast as we can, and then we can pretend we've reached the end of thirty-seven years whenever we want. That is, as soon as we sense things are changing, let's get him out and escape immediately. Yes, I think this is the best.”
es: —Well, we can't risk taking as long as we should, because maybe Uncle Silas won't take that long to receive news from New Orleans. He will find out that Jim is not from there. Then what he will do is put up a notice about Jim, or something like that. So we can't risk taking as long in the tunnel as we should. To do it right, I figure we would need to take a couple of years; but we can't. With things so up in the air, what I recommend is that we start digging for real as fast as we can and then we can tell ourselves that it took thirty-seven years. Then we can get him out and take him away quickly as soon as there's an alarm. Yes, I figure that's the best.

en: “Now, there’s sense in that,” I says. “Letting on don’t cost nothing; letting on ain’t no trouble; and if it’s any object, I don’t mind letting on we was at it a hundred and fifty year. It wouldn’t strain me none, after I got my hand in. So I’ll mosey along now, and smouch a couple of case-knives.”
vi: - Yeah, what you said sounds reasonable. Imagining it doesn't cause any trouble anyway. You can imagine that you'll dig for a hundred and ten years if you want. Alright, let me go get a few knives.
tr: “Now you've said something wise,” I said. “There's no harm in pretending we've reached the end, and we won't get into trouble; if we have a purpose, I don't even mind pretending to dig for a hundred and fifty years. Once the job is done, it won't be a problem for me. The best thing now is for me to go and find two knives.”
es: —Well, it makes sense —I said—. Pretending it was thirty-seven years is no trouble; there's no problem, and if necessary, I don't mind pretending it took us one hundred and fifty years. It's no effort for me if I set my mind to it. So I'm going to go get a couple of kitchen knives.

en: “Smouch three,” he says; “we want one to make a saw out of.”
vi: It said: - Take three back, I need one to make a saw.
tr: “Find three,” he said, “we will make a saw from one of them.” “Tom, if it is not against the rules and ungodly, I will suggest something,” I said.
es: —Find yourself three —he says—; we need one to turn it into a saw.

en: “Tom, if it ain’t unregular and irreligious to sejest it,” I says, “there’s an old rusty saw-blade around yonder sticking under the weather-boarding behind the smoke-house.”
vi: I said: - Tom, if you don't give it to me, it's against the rules, then I'll tell you there's a rusty saw blade stuck on the roof behind the kitchen.
tr: “I had seen the tip of a rusty saw under the cover of the trench behind the smokehouse.”
es: —Tom, if it doesn't go against the rules or against the religion that I suggest it to you —I said—, there is an old and rusty saw half-covered under the shed that is behind the meat smoker.

en: He looked kind of weary and discouraged-like, and says:
vi: It seemed bored and disappointed, and replied to me:
tr: Tom said in a weary and disheartened tone:
es: He looked at me as if tired and discouraged and said:

en: “It ain’t no use to try to learn you nothing, Huck. Run along and smouch the knives—three of them.” So I done it.
vi: - I don't know how to teach you anymore. Just go and bring back three knives, remember, three of them. So I ran away.
tr: “There’s no use in trying to teach you anything, Huck. Quickly go and bring three knives… three of them.” I did as he said.
es: —You can't be taught anything, Huck. Go get the knives, and make it three —and so I did.

en: CHAPTER XXXVI.
vi: Chapter XXXVI
tr: Chapter Thirty-Six
es: Chapter 36

en: As soon as we reckoned everybody was asleep that night we went down the lightning-rod, and shut ourselves up in the lean-to, and got out our pile of fox-fire, and went to work. We cleared everything out of the way, about four or five foot along the middle of the bottom log. Tom said he was right behind Jim’s bed now, and we’d dig in under it, and when we got through there couldn’t nobody in the cabin ever know there was any hole there, because Jim’s counter-pin hung down most to the ground, and you’d have to raise it up and look under to see the hole. So we dug and dug with the case-knives till most midnight; and then we was dog-tired, and our hands was blistered, and yet you couldn’t see we’d done anything hardly. At last I says:
vi: That night, we waited until everyone had gone to sleep, then climbed down the lamppost, ran to the porch, took out the fireflies, and began our work. We moved all the clutter away, clearing an area of about a meter in the middle of the ground. Tom said that spot was right behind Jim's bed, and we would dig from there into the cell. Once we dug through, no one on the other side would know there was a hole because the bedspread of Jim's bed hung down close to the ground; you would have to lift it up and look down to see the hole. So we took out our daggers and dug, digging until nearly midnight. Eventually, we were exhausted, our hands blistered, and still, we hadn't made much progress. Finally, I said:
tr: That night, at a moment when we thought everyone was asleep, we slid down the lightning rod, entered the shed, closed the door behind us, took out our foxfire pile, and started working. We cleared everything around to open up a one to one and a half centimeter space in the middle of the log at the bottom. Tom said we were exactly behind Jim's bed, we were going to dig right under his bed, and when we got there, no one entering the cabin would realize there was a hole there, because the cover of Jim's bed almost reached the floor, and to understand there was a hole underneath, you would have to lift the cover. So we dug and dug with our knives until midnight; finally, we were as tired as dogs, our palms were blistered, but still, we had hardly done anything. Finally, I said:
es: THAT NIGHT, as soon as we calculated that everyone had fallen asleep, we climbed down the lightning rod, locked ourselves in the shed, took out our pile of "foxfire," and got to work. We cleared everything around us, about four or five feet along the bottom of the trunk. Tom said we were right behind Jim's bed and that we would dig underneath, and when we got there no one would notice there was a hole, because Jim's quilt hung almost to the floor and you would have to lift it to look underneath to see it. So we started digging with the knives until almost midnight, when we felt extremely tired, with our hands full of blisters, and yet you could hardly notice what we had done. Finally, I said:

en: “This ain’t no thirty-seven year job; this is a thirty-eight year job, Tom Sawyer.”
vi: - Tom Sawyer, this is not a thirty-seven-year job, but a thirty-eight-year job.
tr: "Tom Sawyer, this job will last not thirty-seven years, but even thirty-eight years."
es: —This is not going to last thirty-seven years; this job is for thirty-eight years, Tom Sawyer.

en: He never said nothing. But he sighed, and pretty soon he stopped digging, and then for a good little while I knowed that he was thinking. Then he says:
vi: It didn't say anything but just sighed, then after a moment, it stopped digging. I knew what it was thinking. It said:
tr: He didn't make a sound. But he sighed deeply and a little later he put down the pickaxe; in the ensuing silence, I could feel that he was thinking.
es: He said nothing. But he sighed and immediately stopped digging, and then I saw that he was thinking for a while. Then he said:

en: “It ain’t no use, Huck, it ain’t a-going to work. If we was prisoners it would, because then we’d have as many years as we wanted, and no hurry; and we wouldn’t get but a few minutes to dig, every day, while they was changing watches, and so our hands wouldn’t get blistered, and we could keep it up right along, year in and year out, and do it right, and the way it ought to be done. But we can’t fool along; we got to rush; we ain’t got no time to spare. If we was to put in another night this way we’d have to knock off for a week to let our hands get well—couldn’t touch a case-knife with them sooner.”
vi: - It's useless, Huck. Doing it this way won't get us anywhere. If we were prisoners, we could take as many years as we wanted, no need to hurry, just spend a few minutes each day digging. But we don't have that much time. If we plan to do another night like this, we would need to rest for a week to let our hands heal, otherwise, we won't be able to hold the knife to dig right away.
tr: “It's no use, Huck,” he said. “It won't work. If we were prisoners, it would work, because then we would have as many years as we wanted, we wouldn't be in a hurry; moreover, we could dig for just a few minutes a day, when the guards change shifts, so our hands wouldn't blister; since we would continue for years, we would follow the rules and do this job the right way. But we don't have time to waste, we must hurry; this job must be finished soon. If we work like this for one more night, we will have to wait a week for our hands to heal... Soon we won't be able to hold the knife.”
es: —This isn't working, it's not going to work. If we were prisoners it would work, because we would have all the years we wanted without any rush, and we could only dig for a few minutes a day, while the guard changed, so we wouldn't get blisters on our hands, and we could keep going constantly, year after year, and do it well, the way things should be done. But we can't waste time, we have to hurry; we don't have that much time. If we spend another night like this, we would have to rest for a week for our hands to heal; it would take us all that time to touch a kitchen knife again.

en: “Well, then, what we going to do, Tom?”
vi: - So what should we do, Tom?
tr: “Well, what are we going to do then, Tom?”
es: —So, what are we going to do, Tom?

en: “I’ll tell you. It ain’t right, and it ain’t moral, and I wouldn’t like it to get out; but there ain’t only just the one way: we got to dig him out with the picks, and let on it’s case-knives.”
vi: Let me tell you something. I don't want to give up, because that would be wrong and unethical. But the only way left is for us to dig with a hoe and put the knife away.
tr: “I will tell you. Actually, it is neither right nor moral... I didn't want such words to come out of my mouth; but there is only one way left; we will dig with a pickaxe and pretend we dug with a knife.”
es: —I'm going to tell you. It's not right, and it's not moral, and I wouldn't like it to be known, but it's the only way: we have to take it out with the picks and pretend they are kitchen knives.

en: “Now you’re talking!” I says; “your head gets leveler and leveler all the time, Tom Sawyer,” I says. “Picks is the thing, moral or no moral; and as for me, I don’t care shucks for the morality of it, nohow. When I start in to steal a nigger, or a watermelon, or a Sunday-school book, I ain’t no ways particular how it’s done so it’s done. What I want is my nigger; or what I want is my watermelon; or what I want is my Sunday-school book; and if a pick’s the handiest thing, that’s the thing I’m a-going to dig that nigger or that watermelon or that Sunday-school book out with; and I don’t give a dead rat what the authorities thinks about it nuther.”
vi: I said: - See that? Your mind is clearer now, Tom Sawyer. Whether it's moral or not, using a hoe is still right. When I set out to steal a black man, or a watermelon, or a book from the monastery school, I don't care whether it's moral or not. What I need is my black man, what I need is my watermelon, or what I need is the book from the monastery school, and if the hoe is the most convenient, then I use the hoe. I take the hoe to dig out that black man, that watermelon, or that book, and I don't give a damn about what the reputable people think about it!
tr: “Now it's done!” I said, “Your brain works better every time, Tom Sawyer. Whether it's moral or immoral, the best way is to dig; and if you ask me, I don't care about morality at all. Once you start stealing a black person, a watermelon, or a hymn book, I don't think it matters how you do it. I want my black person, I want my watermelon, or I want my hymn book; if the easiest way to get it is by digging, then I'll dig out the black person, the watermelon, or the hymn book; I don't give a damn about what the experts say on this matter.”
es: —That's the way to talk! —I said—. You're thinking better and better, Tom Sawyer. What matters are the picks, whether they are moral or not, and as for me, I don't give a damn about morality. When it occurs to me to steal a black person, or a watermelon, or a Sunday school book, I don't care much about how as long as I do it. What I want is my black person or my watermelon or my Sunday school book, and if the best thing is a pick, then that's what I'm going to use to get that black person, or that watermelon, or that Sunday school book, and I don't give a damn what the most authoritative authors say about it.

en: “Well,” he says, “there’s excuse for picks and letting-on in a case like this; if it warn’t so, I wouldn’t approve of it, nor I wouldn’t stand by and see the rules broke—because right is right, and wrong is wrong, and a body ain’t got no business doing wrong when he ain’t ignorant and knows better. It might answer for you to dig Jim out with a pick, without any letting on, because you don’t know no better; but it wouldn’t for me, because I do know better. Gimme a case-knife.”
vi: It says - In this case, using a hoe and discarding the knife is also acceptable. If not, then I wouldn't accept that and would definitely not stand still and watch the rules being distorted. For you, you can use the hoe instead of the knife without any hesitation because you have no other choice. But I'm different because I know better ways. Give me the knife!
tr: “There is a valid reason for using picks and considering them as knives here,” he said. “If it weren't so, I would never approve, and I can't just stand by while rules are being violated... Because right is right; wrong is wrong, and if a person is not ignorant, if they know they shouldn't do it, they won't do wrong. Getting Jim out using a pick without any pretense might be a solution for you, that's how much you know about these things, but it's not a solution for me, because I know it's wrong. Give me a knife.”
es: —Well —he goes and says—, there is an excuse to use the picks and pretend they are something else in a case like this; otherwise, I wouldn't approve it, nor would I allow the rules to be broken, because what is right is right and what is wrong is wrong, and one doesn't have to do things wrong when one is not ignorant and knows what is right. It would be fine for you to get Jim out with a pick, without pretending it's something else, because you don't know what is right, but it wouldn't be right for me to do it, because I do know. Pass me a kitchen knife.

en: He had his own by him, but I handed him mine. He flung it down, and says:
vi: It was already holding a knife, but I still handed it my knife. It threw it down and said:
tr: He had his own knife in his hand, and I gave him my own knife. He threw the knife to the ground and repeated:
es: He had his next to him, but I handed him mine. He threw it on the ground and said:

en: “Gimme a case-knife.”
vi: - Give me the knife.
tr: “I am asking you to give me a pocketknife.”
es: —Give me a kitchen knife.

en: I didn’t know just what to do—but then I thought. I scratched around amongst the old tools, and got a pickaxe and give it to him, and he took it and went to work, and never said a word.
vi: I didn't know what to do, but then I figured it out. I rummaged through the old stuff, took out a hoe, and handed it to him. He took it and started working without saying anything.
tr: At first, I didn't know what to do... But then I thought. I reached for the old tools, took an old pickaxe and gave it to him, he took the pickaxe and started working without saying a single word.
es: I didn't know what to do, but then I thought about it. I searched among the old tools and found a pickaxe, handed it to him, and he grabbed it and started working without saying a word.

en: He was always just that particular. Full of principle.
vi: It's still the same, very principled.
tr: That's how meticulous he was. He was a man of principles.
es: It was always that special. Everything beginnings.

en: So then I got a shovel, and then we picked and shoveled, turn about, and made the fur fly. We stuck to it about a half an hour, which was as long as we could stand up; but we had a good deal of a hole to show for it. When I got up stairs I looked out at the window and see Tom doing his level best with the lightning-rod, but he couldn’t come it, his hands was so sore. At last he says:
vi: I picked up a shovel, and both of us toiled for half an hour and dug a fairly large hole. When I went upstairs and looked out the window, I saw Tom trying hard to climb the lamp post again, but he couldn't manage it because his hands were too sore. Finally, he said:
tr: Upon this, I also took a shovel, and then we dug the soil using the pickaxe and the shovel in turns. We worked for another half hour, then we couldn't stand the sleeplessness anymore; but by then, we had already opened a fairly large hole. I went upstairs, and when I looked out the window, I saw Tom desperately trying to climb the lightning rod, but he couldn't manage it because his palms were blistered. “It's no use, it's impossible to do this,” he said finally.
es: Then I grabbed a shovel and we started digging with the pick and shovel, taking turns, like madmen. We continued like this for about half an hour, which was all we could endure; but in return, we had made a good hole. When I went upstairs, I looked out the window and saw that Tom was doing everything he could with the lightning rod, but he couldn't climb because his hands were so cracked. Finally, he said:

en: “It ain’t no use, it can’t be done. What you reckon I better do? Can’t you think of no way?”
vi: - It's useless, we can't climb. Do you have any other way?
tr: “It's no use, it's impossible to do this,” he said finally. “Do you think I have any other choice? Can you think of a way?”
es: —It's useless, I can't. What do you think I should do? Can't you think of anything?

en: “Yes,” I says, “but I reckon it ain’t regular. Come up the stairs, and let on it’s a lightning-rod.”
vi: - Yes, but I'm afraid you might say it's not according to the rules. You should take the stairs up.
tr: "He's coming," I said, "but it doesn't seem to follow the rules. Go up the stairs and pretend you came out of the lightning rod."
es: —Yes —I said—, but I suppose it's not in the regulations. Go up the stairs and pretend they are a lightning rod.

en: So he done it.
vi: So it did as I told it to.
tr: That's exactly what he did.
es: That's what he did.

en: Next day Tom stole a pewter spoon and a brass candlestick in the house, for to make some pens for Jim out of, and six tallow candles; and I hung around the nigger cabins and laid for a chance, and stole three tin plates. Tom says it wasn’t enough; but I said nobody wouldn’t ever see the plates that Jim throwed out, because they’d fall in the dog-fennel and jimpson weeds under the window-hole—then we could tote them back and he could use them over again. So Tom was satisfied. Then he says:
vi: The next day, Tom stole a tin spoon and a brass candlestick from the house to make a pen for Jim, along with six tallow candles. As for me, I went down to the black people's quarters to find an opportunity to steal three iron plates. Tom said that wasn't enough. But I thought no one would see the plates Jim threw out. That way, we could pick them up and use them again. Tom agreed. He said:
tr: The next day, Tom stole a tin spoon and a brass candlestick from home; we were going to make a pen for Jim with these, and he also got six candles; I hung around the negro cabins and found an opportunity to steal three tin plates. Tom said these weren't enough; but I said no one would see the plates Jim threw, because they would fall among the dog daisies and hawthorns under the window – we could collect the plates and use them again. Tom was satisfied. “Now we need to figure out how to get the necessary things to Jim,” he said.
es: The next day, Tom stole a pewter spoon and a copper candlestick from the house to make some pens for Jim, as well as six tallow candles, and I stayed around the cabins of the black people waiting for an opportunity and stole three tin plates. Tom said it wasn't enough, but I replied that no one would ever see the plates Jim threw, because they would fall among the bushes and weeds under the window, so we could retrieve them to be used again. Then Tom was convinced. Afterwards, he goes and says:

en: “Now, the thing to study out is, how to get the things to Jim.”
vi: - Now, how to get those things to Jim.
tr: “Now we need to figure out how to get the necessary things to Jim,” he said.
es: —Now what we have to study is how to get things to Jim.

en: “Take them in through the hole,” I says, “when we get it done.”
vi: I said: - Now that we've finished digging, we can put it in that hole.
tr: "After completing the hole, we pass them through the hole," I said.
es: —We will give them to them through the hole —I said—, when we have finished it.

en: He only just looked scornful, and said something about nobody ever heard of such an idiotic idea, and then he went to studying. By-and-by he said he had ciphered out two or three ways, but there warn’t no need to decide on any of them yet. Said we’d got to post Jim first.
vi: It seemed to not accept my opinion and was deep in thought. A moment later, it said it had found two or three ways, but there was no need to decide on any of them yet. First of all, we must inform Jim.
tr: After sarcastically looking and saying that no one had ever heard such a foolish idea, he began to think. After a while, he said that he had found two or three ways, but for now, it was not necessary to decide on any of them. First, we should reach Jim.
es: He looked at me disdainfully and said something like he had never heard such a stupid idea, and then he started to study it. After a while, he announced that he had already discovered two or three ways, but it was not yet necessary to decide on one. He said that first we had to inform Jim.

en: That night we went down the lightning-rod a little after ten, and took one of the candles along, and listened under the window-hole, and heard Jim snoring; so we pitched it in, and it didn’t wake him. Then we whirled in with the pick and shovel, and in about two hours and a half the job was done. We crept in under Jim’s bed and into the cabin, and pawed around and found the candle and lit it, and stood over Jim awhile, and found him looking hearty and healthy, and then we woke him up gentle and gradual. He was so glad to see us he most cried; and called us honey, and all the pet names he could think of; and was for having us hunt up a cold-chisel to cut the chain off of his leg with right away, and clearing out without losing any time. But Tom he showed him how unregular it would be, and set down and told him all about our plans, and how we could alter them in a minute any time there was an alarm; and not to be the least afraid, because we would see he got away, sure. So Jim he said it was all right, and we set there and talked over old times awhile, and then Tom asked a lot of questions, and when Jim told him Uncle Silas come in every day or two to pray with him, and Aunt Sally come in to see if he was comfortable and had plenty to eat, and both of them was kind as they could be, Tom says:
vi: That night, around ten o'clock, we climbed down the lamp post again, bringing a candle with us, and listened at the window hole to hear Jim snoring. We threw the candle in, but Jim still didn't wake up. We then started digging and shoveling the earth, and after about two and a half hours, we were completely done. We crawled under Jim's bed into the cell, found the candle, lit it, and stood looking at Jim for a while. He was still as gentle and healthy as usual. We gently shook him awake. Seeing us, Jim was overjoyed, almost crying, and called us with all the affectionate names he could think of. He wanted us to find a piece of iron to saw off the chain on his leg and then escape immediately, without delay. But Tom thought that wasn't according to the rules and sat down to tell Jim a series of plans. Jim happily agreed. Tom also asked Jim a lot of questions. Jim said that Mr. Silas came to pray with him every few days, and Aunt Sally also came to check if he was eating well and properly, and that both of them were kind to him.
tr: That night, shortly after ten o'clock, we came down from the lightning rod and took one of the candles with us; when we stood under the window, we heard Jim snoring; we threw the candle inside, but he didn't wake up. After working with the pickaxe and shovel for about two hours, we had completed half the job. First, we went under Jim's bed, then into the cabin, felt around and found the candle, and lit it. We stood over Jim for a while; he looked quite lively and healthy; we woke him up slowly. He was so happy to see us that he almost cried; he called us "my dear" and said all the affectionate words he could think of; he asked us to find a chisel to cut the shackle on his leg, and then we would escape without wasting any time.
