But Tom told him how against the rules that was, sat down and explained our plan from start to finish, and said that we could change everything in a minute in case of an emergency; there was no need for him to be afraid because we would definitely ensure his escape. Jim said it was no problem, we sat together for a while and talked about the old days, then Tom asked many questions. Jim told him that Uncle Silas came almost every day to pray with him, and Aunt Sally also came to check if he was comfortable and had plenty of food; they both treated him very well.
es: That night we climbed down the lightning rod shortly after ten, with one of the candles, we listened under the window and heard Jim snoring, so we threw it inside and didn't wake him up. Then we started digging with the pick and shovel, and after about two and a half hours we had finished the job. We got into the cabin under Jim's cot and searched until we found the candle and lit it, and we stared at Jim for a while to check his strong and healthy appearance, and then we woke him up slowly and gently. He was so happy to see us that he almost started to cry and called us his children and all the affectionate things he could think of, and he asked us to find a chisel to take the chain off his leg immediately so he could leave without wasting time. But Tom showed him that wouldn't be proper and sat down to explain our plans and how we could change them in a moment if there was any alarm and that he shouldn't worry, because we would make sure he escaped, no doubt. Then Jim said that was fine and we stayed chatting for a while about the old times, and then Tom asked a lot of questions, and when Jim told him that Uncle Silas came daily or every two days to pray with him and that Aunt Sally visited to see if he was comfortable and had enough food and that they were both very kind, Tom said:

en: “Now I know how to fix it. We’ll send you some things by them.”
vi: Tom said: - Alright, we will send you the items through them.
tr: “Now I have found a way to handle this,” said Tom. “We will send you some things with them.”
es: —Now I know how to organize it. We will send you some things with them.

en: I said, “Don’t do nothing of the kind; it’s one of the most jackass ideas I ever struck;” but he never paid no attention to me; went right on. It was his way when he’d got his plans set.
vi: I said: - Don't do that, I've never seen anyone so foolish before. But Tom didn't bother to listen. When he already had an intention in his mind, he always did things that way.
tr: “We could never do such a thing in life,” I said. “This is the most foolish idea I’ve ever heard.” But he didn’t even listen to me, he continued speaking. It was always like this when he made his plans.
es: —Don't even think about it; it's one of the dumbest ideas I've ever heard in my life —I said, but he ignored me and went ahead. That's what happened when he had made a plan.

en: So he told Jim how we’d have to smuggle in the rope-ladder pie and other large things by Nat, the nigger that fed him, and he must be on the lookout, and not be surprised, and not let Nat see him open them; and we would put small things in uncle’s coat-pockets and he must steal them out; and we would tie things to aunt’s apron-strings or put them in her apron-pocket, if we got a chance; and told him what they would be and what they was for. And told him how to keep a journal on the shirt with his blood, and all that. He told him everything. Jim he couldn’t see no sense in the most of it, but he allowed we was white folks and knowed better than him; so he was satisfied, and said he would do it all just as Tom said.
vi: It told Jim that we would secretly slip the rope ladder and many other things into a cake brought by Nat, the black man who still brought food for Jim. It also reminded Jim not to let Nat see him open those things. But the small items, we would put them in Uncle Silas's coat pocket and Jim had to steal them from there; we would tie the odds and ends to Aunt Sally's apron strings or put them in her kitchen apron pocket, if there was an opportunity, and tell Jim what those things were for. Then it told Jim how to use his blood to write a diary on the shirt, etc... Although Jim didn't understand anything, Tom said that white people should know more than Jim. So Jim agreed and said he would follow everything Tom told him.
tr: He explained to Jim that we had to send the rope ladder and other big things through the black man Nat, who brought him food; Jim had to always be alert, not look surprised, and not cause Nat to open them; we would put some small things in uncle's coat pockets, and Jim would steal them from there; we would tie some things to aunt's apron strings or put some in her apron pocket if we got the chance; he also explained what these things were and what they would be used for. He also explained how to keep a diary with his blood on the shirt and other things. He listed everything one by one. Jim didn't understand the reason for most of it, but he said that we were white and would know better; he was satisfied and would do everything exactly as Tom said.
es: Then he told Jim that we would have to pass him the cake with the rope ladder and other sizable things through Nat, the black man who brought him food, and he had to be alert and not be surprised or let Nat see him when he opened them, and that we would put the small things in the uncle's jacket pockets and he had to steal them, and that if we had the chance we would tie things to the aunt's apron strings or put them in the apron pocket, and he told him what they would be and what for. He also asked him to keep a diary written in blood on his shirt and all those things. He told him everything. Jim didn't understand most of it, but he acknowledged that since we were white we knew more than he did, so he was quite happy and stated that he would do everything just as Tom had told him.

en: Jim had plenty corn-cob pipes and tobacco; so we had a right down good sociable time; then we crawled out through the hole, and so home to bed, with hands that looked like they’d been chawed. Tom was in high spirits. He said it was the best fun he ever had in his life, and the most intellectural; and said if he only could see his way to it we would keep it up all the rest of our lives and leave Jim to our children to get out; for he believed Jim would come to like it better and better the more he got used to it. He said that in that way it could be strung out to as much as eighty year, and would be the best time on record. And he said it would make us all celebrated that had a hand in it.
vi: Jim has many wooden pipes, and also tobacco. So we sat down and had a very pleasant conversation. After that, we crawled back through the hole and returned to the sleeping quarters. Our hands were all bruised, but Tom was very pleased. He said it was the most interesting and clever game, and he wished to continue it for the rest of his life, even extending eighty years into the future, to the time of our grandchildren. And surely we would become famous figures.
tr: Jim had plenty of corncob pipes and tobacco; so the conversation lasted quite a while; then we crawled out of the hole, went home, and lay down in our beds, our hands looking like they had been chewed and spat on. Tom was so delighted, you can't imagine. He said this was the most fun and most contemplative event of his life; if he could find a way, we could spend the rest of our lives on this, and then leave it to our children to get Jim out, because he thought Jim would like it more as he got used to it. Maybe we could extend the rescue to eighty years and achieve the longest duration ever. Moreover, everyone involved in this would become famous.
es: Jim had plenty of corn cob pipes and tobacco, so we had a great time in his company; then we crawled out on all fours through the hole and went to bed, with our hands raw. Tom was very excited. He said it was the most fun and the most intellectual thing in his life, and that if he could manage it, we would spend our lives doing it and leave Jim for our children to rescue, because he believed Jim would like it more and more as he got used to it. He said that if we kept going like this, it would last at least eighty years and break all time records. And he added that it would make all of us who had been involved in it famous.

en: In the morning we went out to the woodpile and chopped up the brass candlestick into handy sizes, and Tom put them and the pewter spoon in his pocket. Then we went to the nigger cabins, and while I got Nat’s notice off, Tom shoved a piece of candlestick into the middle of a corn-pone that was in Jim’s pan, and we went along with Nat to see how it would work, and it just worked noble; when Jim bit into it it most mashed all his teeth out; and there warn’t ever anything could a worked better. Tom said so himself. Jim he never let on but what it was only just a piece of rock or something like that that’s always getting into bread, you know; but after that he never bit into nothing but what he jabbed his fork into it in three or four places first.
vi: In the morning, we went to the woodpile and chopped the brass candlestick into several pieces, then Tim put them into his pocket along with some spoons. We went down to the black people's house; while I distracted Nat, Tom slipped a piece of the candlestick into the bread in the pot of food meant for Jim and then followed Nat. When Jim bit into the bread, it felt like his teeth were going to break. Jim didn't complain, he just said that it was a common grit that often got mixed into the bread. After that, Jim didn't bite directly into the bread anymore but used a fork to poke three or four spots to check first.
tr: In the morning, we went to the woodpile and cut the brass candlestick into suitable pieces, Tom put these and the iron spoon in his pocket. Then we went to the negro cabins, and when Nat was distracted, Tom slipped a piece of the candlestick into a piece of cornbread in Jim's pan, then we went to Nat to see if it would work, and indeed our plan worked very well; when Jim bit into the bread, he almost broke all his teeth; it was really hard to come up with a plan that would work better than this. Tom said this himself. Jim didn't show any reaction, he acted as if a piece of stone had come out of his bread as usual; but after that, he didn't bite into anything without poking it three or four times with his fork.
es: In the morning we went to the woodpile, broke the copper candlestick into several more manageable pieces, and Tom put them in his pocket along with the pewter spoon. Then we went to where the cabins of the black people were, and while I distracted Nat, Tom put a piece of the candlestick in the middle of the cornbread that was in the bowl for Jim, and we went with Nat to see how it would turn out, which worked wonderfully; when Jim took a bite, he almost broke all his teeth, and that was a sign of how well everything was going. Tom himself said so. Jim didn't say what it was about, but he pretended it was a little stone or one of those things that always get into the bread, you know; but from then on, he never took a bite of anything without first stabbing it with a fork three or four times.

en: And whilst we was a-standing there in the dimmish light, here comes a couple of the hounds bulging in from under Jim’s bed; and they kept on piling in till there was eleven of them, and there warn’t hardly room in there to get your breath. By jings, we forgot to fasten that lean-to door! The nigger Nat he only just hollered “Witches” once, and keeled over on to the floor amongst the dogs, and begun to groan like he was dying. Tom jerked the door open and flung out a slab of Jim’s meat, and the dogs went for it, and in two seconds he was out himself and back again and shut the door, and I knowed he’d fixed the other door too. Then he went to work on the nigger, coaxing him and petting him, and asking him if he’d been imagining he saw something again. He raised up, and blinked his eyes around, and says:
vi: While we were standing in the dim light, suddenly two dogs crawled out from under Jim's bed, followed by others one after another, making a total of eleven dogs crowding the entire room. Oh no, we forgot to lock the door. The black man Nat only had time to shout "Ghost!" before he staggered and collapsed on the floor, groaning as if he were about to die. Tom forcefully pushed the door open, threw a piece of meat from Jim's food supply outside, and the pack of dogs rushed out. Tom ran out after them, then came back and did not forget to close the door. Tom sweetly coaxed the black man and asked him what he had seen. He sat up, blinked for a while, and said:
tr: While we were standing there in the dim light, a pair of dogs came out from under Jim's bed, followed by other dogs, and eleven dogs entered, leaving no room to breathe. Oh no, we had forgotten to close the shed door. Black Nat collapsed among the dogs after shouting "Witches!" just once and began to moan as if he were dying. Tom immediately opened the door and threw out a slice of meat that had come to Jim; the dogs followed it out. Tom disappeared for two seconds but then came back and closed the door, and I realized he had closed the other door as well. Then the old black man started working on him, trying to cheer him up, pampering him, and asking if he had seen the same thing again. The man lifted his head, blinked his eyes as he looked around, and said:
es: And while we were standing in that dim light, two of the dogs that had crawled into the hole under Jim's cot appeared and kept coming and coming until there were eleven of them and there was hardly any room left to breathe. Heck, we had forgotten to close the shed door! Black Nat only screamed "Witches" once and then knelt on the ground among the dogs and began to moan as if he were dying. Tom flung the door open, threw a piece of Jim's meat through it, and the dogs rushed out to get it. In two seconds, he was out, back in, and had closed the door, and I realized he had also closed the other one. Then he started talking to the black man, very understanding and affectionate, asking him if he had imagined seeing something again. The black man lifted his head, blinked, and said:

en: “Mars Sid, you’ll say I’s a fool, but if I didn’t b’lieve I see most a million dogs, er devils, er some’n, I wisht I may die right heah in dese tracks. I did, mos’ sholy. Mars Sid, I felt um—I felt um, sah; dey was all over me. Dad fetch it, I jis’ wisht I could git my han’s on one er dem witches jis’ wunst—on’y jis’ wunst—it’s all I’d ast. But mos’ly I wisht dey’d lemme ’lone, I does.”
vi: - Sid, you might think I'm crazy, but I really just saw a million dogs, or demons, or something. I thought I could die right then and there. I was so scared, they all jumped at me. But at that moment, I couldn't do anything. I just wanted them to leave me alone.
tr: “Master Sid, you call me a fool, but I almost saw a million dogs, or were they devils? Let me be a dog if I'm lying, may I not be blessed to go from one place to another. Master Sid, it seems to me... It seems to me that they all fell upon me. Oh, if I could catch one of them, if I could catch just one of those witches, I wouldn't want anything else... just for a moment... that's all I want. But most of all, I want them to leave me alone.”
es: —Mr. Sid, you may think I'm a fool, but may I die right here if it didn't seem like I saw almost a million dogs, or devils, or something. I assure you, Mr. Sid. I touched them... I touched them, young master; they were everywhere. Damn it, I wish I could get my hands on one of those witches just once, just once, that's all I ask. But above all, I wish they would leave me alone, that would be the best.

en: Tom says:
vi: Tom said:
tr: “Hmm, let me tell you what I think,” said Tom.
es: Tom goes and says:

en: “Well, I tell you what I think. What makes them come here just at this runaway nigger’s breakfast-time? It’s because they’re hungry; that’s the reason. You make them a witch pie; that’s the thing for you to do.”
vi: - Ah, simple. They came in here again while this black man on the run was having breakfast because they were hungry, maybe. You have to make a separate cake for the devil.
tr: “Hmm, let me tell you what I think,” said Tom. “What could be bringing them here exactly at the breakfast time of this runaway negro? If you ask me, they are hungry, that's why they are coming. You should make them a witch pie, I think that's the best remedy for your problem.”
es: —Well, I'm going to tell you what I think. Why do they come here precisely at the time of this runaway black man's breakfast? It's because they're hungry, and nothing more. You have to make them a witch's pie. That's it.

en: “But my lan’, Mars Sid, how’s I gwyne to make ’m a witch pie? I doan’ know how to make it. I hain’t ever hearn er sich a thing b’fo’.”
vi: - Oh, Sid, I don't know what cakes for ghosts are. I've never heard of that before.
tr: “Oh Great God, help me, Lord Sid, am I going to make a witch beetle? I haven't even heard of it before.”
es: —But, for God's sake, Sid, how am I going to make them a witch pie? I don't know how to make one. I've never heard of anything like it in my life.

en: “Well, then, I’ll have to make it myself.”
vi: - Then let me do it.
tr: “Alright, alright, it seems I will have to do it myself.”
es: —Well, then I'll have to do it myself.

en: “Will you do it, honey?—will you? I’ll wusshup de groun’ und’ yo’ foot, I will!”
vi: - That's very kind. I will kneel down at your feet and bow.
tr: “Are you really going to do it? My dear, are you saying it's true? I'll kiss your hands and feet, please just do it!”
es: —Will you do it, my boy? Will you really? I'll kiss the ground you walk on, truly!

en: “All right, I’ll do it, seeing it’s you, and you’ve been good to us and showed us the runaway nigger. But you got to be mighty careful. When we come around, you turn your back; and then whatever we’ve put in the pan, don’t you let on you see it at all. And don’t you look when Jim unloads the pan—something might happen, I don’t know what. And above all, don’t you handle the witch-things.”
vi: - Because you were kind enough to show us the runaway black man. But you must be very careful. When we put it in the pot, you must not look into it. When Jim takes the food out of the pot, you must not look, and especially not touch it, in case something happens, I won't know what to do.
tr: “Alright, I will do it; after all, you have a special place; you treated us very well and showed us the runaway black man. But you must be very careful. When we come back, turn your back; no matter what we put in your pan, do not look at what it is. Also, do not look while Jim is taking things from your pan… I don't know what will happen if you look. Above all, do not touch the witch's items.”
es: —Very well, I will do it for you because it is about you and because you have behaved well with us and have shown us the runaway black man. But you have to be very careful. When we appear, you have to turn your back, and then, whatever we put in the bowl, you have to act like you don't see it. And you must not look when Jim empties the pot, because something might happen. I don't know what. Above all, do not touch the witches' things.

en: “Hannel ’m, Mars Sid? What is you a-talkin’ ’bout? I wouldn’ lay de weight er my finger on um, not f’r ten hund’d thous’n billion dollars, I wouldn’t.”
vi: - Not allowed to touch? Then even if you give me millions of dollars, I wouldn't bother touching it.
tr: “Touch it, Mr. Sid? What are you saying? Even if they gave me fourteen hundred billion dollars, I wouldn't touch it.”
es: —Touch them, Mr. Sid? What are you saying? I wouldn't lay a finger on them, even if I had a hundred billion dollars, truly.

en: CHAPTER XXXVII.
vi: Chapter XXXVII
tr: Chapter Thirty-Seven
es: Chapter 37

en: That was all fixed. So then we went away and went to the rubbage-pile in the back yard, where they keep the old boots, and rags, and pieces of bottles, and wore-out tin things, and all such truck, and scratched around and found an old tin washpan, and stopped up the holes as well as we could, to bake the pie in, and took it down cellar and stole it full of flour and started for breakfast, and found a couple of shingle-nails that Tom said would be handy for a prisoner to scrabble his name and sorrows on the dungeon walls with, and dropped one of them in Aunt Sally’s apron-pocket which was hanging on a chair, and t’other we stuck in the band of Uncle Silas’s hat, which was on the bureau, because we heard the children say their pa and ma was going to the runaway nigger’s house this morning, and then went to breakfast, and Tom dropped the pewter spoon in Uncle Silas’s coat-pocket, and Aunt Sally wasn’t come yet, so we had to wait a little while.
vi: Everything was already arranged. We went to the pile of trash in the backyard, rummaged around, and found an old tin washbasin, patched up the holes to steal some flour and fill it up. After that, we went back to the house, had breakfast, and picked up a few boat nails. Tom said those were very good for prisoners to use to write their names and their sufferings on the prison bed. We put one nail into Aunt Sally's kitchen apron pocket hanging on the chair, and the other nail into Uncle Silas's hatband on the desk, because we heard the kids say their parents would visit the runaway slave this morning. I also put a spoon into Uncle Silas's outer coat pocket. Aunt Sally hadn't arrived yet, so we had to wait for a while. A moment later, Aunt Saly arrived, her face flushed red.
tr: Everything was arranged. Thus, we went to the pile in the backyard where old boots, rags, broken bottles, useless pots and pans, and other junk were found. After some searching, we found an old and deep pan, patched up its holes as best as we could to bake a pie in it, then took it to the cellar and filled it to the brim with flour. While preparing for breakfast, we also found two small nails. Tom said these would be suitable for the prisoner to carve his name and sufferings into the dungeon walls. Then he put one in Aunt Sally's apron pocket, which was hanging on a chair, and the other into the band of Uncle Silas's hat, which we saw on the drawer at that moment, because we had heard the children talking about their parents going to the runaway negro's house this morning. After that, we went to breakfast, and Tom put the tin spoon into Uncle Silas's coat pocket. Since Aunt Sally hadn't arrived yet, we waited at the table for a while.
es: THAT WAS SETTLED. Then we went to the dump in the backyard, where they have old boots, rags, broken bottles, and worn-out things and all that, and we searched until we found an old tin basin, patched the holes as best as we could to make the pie in it and took it down to the basement to fill it with stolen flour, and when we were going to have breakfast we found a couple of nails that, according to Tom, would be very useful for a prisoner to write his name and sorrows on the dungeon walls, and we left one of them in Aunt Sally's apron pocket, which was hanging on a chair, and we stuck the other one in the ribbon of Uncle Silas's hat, which was on the desk, because we heard the children say that their father and mother were planning to go that morning to see the runaway negro, and then we went to have breakfast and Tom left the pewter spoon in Uncle Silas's jacket pocket, but since Aunt Sally hadn't arrived yet, we had to wait a while.

en: And when she come she was hot and red and cross, and couldn’t hardly wait for the blessing; and then she went to sluicing out coffee with one hand and cracking the handiest child’s head with her thimble with the other, and says:
vi: One hand pouring coffee, the other knocking on the head of the nearest child, and said:
tr: When Aunt Sally arrived, she was bright red, her eyebrows were furrowed, and she barely waited for the prayer; then, while pouring coffee with one hand, she started hitting the nearest child's head with the thimble on her other hand's finger, saying:
es: When she arrived, she was all hot, flushed, and in a bad mood, and she could hardly wait for the blessing of the table, so she started serving coffee with one hand and thimbling the head of the nearest child with the other, while saying:

en: “I’ve hunted high and I’ve hunted low, and it does beat all what has become of your other shirt.”
vi: - I searched all over the house but couldn't find a single shirt.
tr: “I searched upstairs, I searched downstairs, it's nowhere to be found, what happened to your other shirt?”
es: —I have searched everywhere and I don't understand what happened to your other shirt.

en: My heart fell down amongst my lungs and livers and things, and a hard piece of corn-crust started down my throat after it and got met on the road with a cough, and was shot across the table, and took one of the children in the eye and curled him up like a fishing-worm, and let a cry out of him the size of a warwhoop, and Tom he turned kinder blue around the gills, and it all amounted to a considerable state of things for about a quarter of a minute or as much as that, and I would a sold out for half price if there was a bidder. But after that we was all right again—it was the sudden surprise of it that knocked us so kind of cold. Uncle Silas he says:
vi: My heart seemed to drop, the piece of cake stuck in my throat and caused a cough, the piece of cake shot out, flew across the table, hit the eye of the child sitting in front of me, and stuck there. The child let out a scream. As for Tom, his face turned pale for a moment, but then returned to normal. Then another event made us all shiver. Uncle Silas said:
tr: I felt like I had slipped and fallen between my heart, lungs, and liver, then a hard piece of cornbread met a cough on its way down my throat and shot out of my mouth, exploding in the eye of one of the kids across the table. The child let out something like a war cry and writhed like a fishing worm, while Tom had turned almost purple up to his ears. Moreover, all of this happened in about a quarter of a minute. The breakfast table had become such a dangerous place that if there had been an auction at that moment, I would have sold myself at half price to escape. But after that, we pulled ourselves together – what had shaken us so much was the suddenness of the situation. “Extremely unusual and strange, I can't understand it at all,” said Uncle Silas.
es: My heart sank between my lungs and livers and all that, and a hard piece of corn husk got stuck in my throat, so I started coughing, spat it all over the table, and hit one of the kids in the eye, making him squirm like a worm on a hook and let out a scream like an Indian on the warpath. Tom turned as red as a poppy, and then there was a big mess for about a quarter of a minute or so, and I would have confessed everything right then and there at the first opportunity. But then everything settled down again, because the surprise had caught us all off guard. Uncle Silas said:

en: “It’s most uncommon curious, I can’t understand it. I know perfectly well I took it off, because—”
vi: - Strange, I clearly remember taking off my shirt because... - I know you took it off, because yesterday it was still on the clothesline, I saw it myself.
tr: “Extremely unusual and strange, I can't understand it at all,” said Uncle Silas. “I know very well where I took it off, because…”
es: —It is most curious. I cannot understand it. I know perfectly well that I took it off, because...

en: “Because you hain’t got but one on. Just listen at the man! I know you took it off, and know it by a better way than your wool-gethering memory, too, because it was on the clo’s-line yesterday—I see it there myself. But it’s gone, that’s the long and the short of it, and you’ll just have to change to a red flann’l one till I can get time to make a new one. And it’ll be the third I’ve made in two years. It just keeps a body on the jump to keep you in shirts; and whatever you do manage to do with ’m all is more’n I can make out. A body ’d think you would learn to take some sort of care of ’em at your time of life.”
vi: - I know you took it off, because yesterday it was still on the clothesline, I saw it myself. But now it's gone. Just go get another shirt to wear, and I'll make you a new one. You must take better care of your clothes.
tr: “Because there was only one on it. Do you hear what you're saying? I know you took it off, and I have a much more reliable source than your hazy memory because I hung it on the clothesline yesterday... I saw it there with my own eyes. But it's gone now... there's no ifs or buts about it, the only thing we can do is for you to wear your red undershirt until I sew a new one. Moreover, this will be the third one in two years; one has to be constantly on guard so you don't go without a shirt; I can never understand how you manage to ruin so many shirts. All I can do is hope that at some point in your life you'll learn to take care of your shirts.”
es: —Because now you only have one shirt. What things you say! I already knew that you had taken it off and I remember it better than you, because yesterday it was on the clothesline and I saw it myself. But it has disappeared and there's nothing more to say, so you'll have to wear a red flannel one until I find the time to make you another. And it will be the third one I've made for you in two years. I spend half my time just sewing shirts for you, and what I don't understand is what the devil you do with them. Logically, at your age, you should have already learned to take care of them a little.

en: “I know it, Sally, and I do try all I can. But it oughtn’t to be altogether my fault, because, you know, I don’t see them nor have nothing to do with them except when they’re on me; and I don’t believe I’ve ever lost one of them off of me.”
vi: - I know, Saly, but that is not entirely my fault. I haven't seen that shirt except when I wear it, and if I wear it, there's no reason for it to get lost.
tr: “I know, Sally, believe me, I'm doing my best. But it can't be entirely my fault, because you know that when they're not on me, I neither see them nor have anything to do with them; moreover, I don't think I could lose them at a moment when they're not on me.”
es: —I already know, Sally, and I try as much as I can. But it can't all be my fault, because you know I don't see them or have anything to do with them except when I'm wearing them, and I don't think I've lost any while wearing them.

en: “Well, it ain’t your fault if you haven’t, Silas; you’d a done it if you could, I reckon. And the shirt ain’t all that’s gone, nuther. Ther’s a spoon gone; and that ain’t all. There was ten, and now ther’s only nine. The calf got the shirt, I reckon, but the calf never took the spoon, that’s certain.”
vi: - Well, it's not your fault if you don't know. And it's not just about losing one shirt. That's not all. Ten spoons, now there are nine. Maybe the calf took the shirt, but a calf would never take a spoon. That's for sure.
tr: “If you can't do it, it's not your fault, Silas… if you could, you would, surely. Moreover, the only thing missing isn't just the shirt. A spoon has gone missing, even other things have disappeared. There were ten spoons, but now there are only nine. Let's say the calf took the shirt, but calves definitely don't steal spoons, that's for sure.”
es: —Well, that's not your fault; you would have lost them if you could, I think. Besides, it's not just the shirt that's missing. A spoon is also missing, and that's not all. There were ten and now there are only nine. Maybe the calf ate the shirt, but what I can assure you is that the calf didn't eat the spoon.

en: “Why, what else is gone, Sally?”
vi: - What else is lost, Saly?
tr: “What else is gone, Sally?”
es: —What else is missing, Sally?

en: “Ther’s six candles gone—that’s what. The rats could a got the candles, and I reckon they did; I wonder they don’t walk off with the whole place, the way you’re always going to stop their holes and don’t do it; and if they warn’t fools they’d sleep in your hair, Silas—you’d never find it out; but you can’t lay the spoon on the rats, and that I know.”
vi: - Six more candles are missing, it could be that mice took them away. But I don't understand how they got in, because you always seal the holes, and they shouldn't be able to get in. If they could get in, they might even crawl into your hair while you sleep.
tr: “Six candles are missing... the candles are gone. Sometimes the mice take the candles away, I guess that's what happened this time too; anyway, I don't know how they don't take everything we have, you were supposed to block their holes, but you didn't; if they weren't so stupid, they would make a nest in your hair, Silas... you wouldn't even notice; but look, you can't blame the mice for the spoon, I know this for sure.”
es: —Six candles are missing, that's what's missing. The rats could have eaten the candles, and I reckon that's what happened; I wonder why they don't just take everything already, because you spend your life saying you're going to plug the holes and you never do, and if they weren't idiots, they'd sleep on your head, Silas, and you wouldn't even notice; but you can't blame the rats for the spoon, I'm sure of that.

en: “Well, Sally, I’m in fault, and I acknowledge it; I’ve been remiss; but I won’t let to-morrow go by without stopping up them holes.”
vi: - Alright, I know it's my fault. I've been too careless lately, starting tomorrow I won't leave any gaps unfilled.
tr: “Alright, Sally, my fault, I admit it; I was careless; but tomorrow I will definitely close those mouse holes.”
es: —Well, Sally, it will be my fault and I admit it; I have let it slide, but I assure you that tomorrow I will plug all the holes.

en: “Oh, I wouldn’t hurry; next year’ll do. Matilda Angelina Araminta Phelps!”
vi: - Oh, there's no rush, next year is fine... The sound of a hand slapping the table, the child who was dipping their finger into the sugar bowl quickly pulled it out.
tr: "No way, don't rush at all, you can do it next year. Matilda Angelina Araminta Phelps!"
es: —There's no rush; as long as you cover them next year, it's enough. Matilda Angelina Araminta Phelps!

en: Whack comes the thimble, and the child snatches her claws out of the sugar-bowl without fooling around any. Just then the nigger woman steps on to the passage, and says:
vi: The sound of a hand slapping the table, the child who was dipping their finger into the sugar bowl quickly pulled it out. At that moment, a black woman walked in and said:
tr: The thimble came down on the head and the child had to pull his empty claws out of the candy jar. Just then, the black woman entered the passage:
es: Thimble tap and the girl takes her fingers out of the sugar bowl without saying a word. Just then, the black woman arrives at the passage and says:

en: “Missus, dey’s a sheet gone.”
vi: - Madam, a bedsheet is also missing.
tr: “Madam, one sheet is missing.”
es: —Ma'am, a sheet is missing.

en: “A sheet gone! Well, for the land’s sake!”
vi: - Missing bed sheet! How strange?
tr: “Are we missing a sheet! For God's sake, what's happening?”
es: —A sheet is missing! Well, what's going on here!

en: “I’ll stop up them holes to-day,” says Uncle Silas, looking sorrowful.
vi: Uncle Silas with a sad expression: - I will go and seal the holes today. - Stop it, sir.
tr: “I will plug the holes right away today,” said Uncle Silas with sadness.
es: —Today I will cover the holes —says Uncle Silas, with a remorseful look on his face.

en: “Oh, do shet up!—s’pose the rats took the sheet? Where’s it gone, Lize?”
vi: What mouse would carry off a bedsheet? Where did it go missing? Lize!
tr: “Woman, be quiet!.. Do you think the mice took the sheet? Where could the sheet have gone; Lize?”
es: —Come on, shut up! Do you think the rats took the sheet? Where has it disappeared to, Lize?

en: “Clah to goodness I hain’t no notion, Miss’ Sally. She wuz on de clo’sline yistiddy, but she done gone: she ain’ dah no mo’ now.”
vi: - Madam, I don't know. Yesterday, it was still on the clothesline, but now it's gone, no longer there.
tr: "I have no idea, Miss Sally. Yesterday it was on the clothesline, but now it's not there."
es: —I swear to God I have no idea, Miss Sally. Yesterday it was on the clothesline but it has disappeared; it's not there anymore.

en: “I reckon the world is coming to an end. I never see the beat of it in all my born days. A shirt, and a sheet, and a spoon, and six can—”
vi: - This is complete chaos. I've never seen anything like this before, from childhood until now, shirts, then bed sheets; then spoons; then... A boy walked in from somewhere:
tr: “The end of the world has come, I guess. I have never seen such nonsense in my life until today. A shirt, a sheet, a spoon, and six candles...”
es: —This looks like the end of the world. I've never seen anything like this. A shirt, a sheet, a spoon, and six ve...

en: “Missus,” comes a young yaller wench, “dey’s a brass cannelstick miss’n.”
vi: - Madam, another brass candlestick is missing.
tr: A young maid burst in, calling out, "Madam, one of the brass candlesticks is missing."
es: —Sita —says a light-skinned black woman as she arrives—, a bronze candelabrum is missing.

en: “Cler out from here, you hussy, er I’ll take a skillet to ye!”
vi: - Get out of here, you damn idiot, or I'll beat you up right now.
tr: "Get out of here quickly, you shrew, or I'll smash the pot on your head!"
es: —Get out of here, shameless, or I'll hit you with a frying pan!

en: Well, she was just a-biling. I begun to lay for a chance; I reckoned I would sneak out and go for the woods till the weather moderated. She kept a-raging right along, running her insurrection all by herself, and everybody else mighty meek and quiet; and at last Uncle Silas, looking kind of foolish, fishes up that spoon out of his pocket. She stopped, with her mouth open and her hands up; and as for me, I wished I was in Jeruslem or somewheres. But not long, because she says:
vi: Aunt Saly was boiling with anger. I sat silently praying, planning to sneak outside to go into the forest and wait until the atmosphere calmed down a bit. Everyone was silent, fearful. Finally, Uncle Silas was dumbfounded to find the spoon in his pocket. Aunt Saly stood still, raised her hand, and opened her mouth wide. As for me, I just wanted to sink into the ground. Aunt Saly said:
tr: Aunt Sally had completely lost her mind. I started looking for an opportunity to slip away; I could wander in the forest until the weather softened a bit and then come back. Aunt Sally had lost control and was ranting while everyone else in the house was silent and looking down; finally, Uncle Silas reached into his pocket and pulled out the spoon with a somewhat bewildered expression. Aunt Sally froze with her mouth open and hands in the air; if you ask me, I wished I could be in Jerusalem or somewhere at that moment. But her state didn’t last long, because she said:
es: Well, she was furious. I started to wait for an opportunity. I thought it was best to go to the forest until the weather improved. She kept shouting, organizing an insurrection all by herself, while the rest of us were meek and quiet, until Uncle Silas, looking very surprised, pulled the spoon out of his pocket. Aunt fell silent, with her mouth open and raising her hands, and as for me, I wished I had been in Jerusalem or anywhere else. But not for long, because she goes and says:

en: “It’s just as I expected. So you had it in your pocket all the time; and like as not you’ve got the other things there, too. How’d it get there?”
vi: - I knew it right away. So you still kept it in your coat pocket. There might even be other things in that pocket too. How did it get in there?
tr: “Just as I expected. So it was in your pocket all along, I wonder if the other missing items are there too. How did the spoon get in there?”
es: —I was expecting that. So you had it in your pocket, and surely you have all the other things. How did it get there?

en: “I reely don’t know, Sally,” he says, kind of apologizing, “or you know I would tell. I was a-studying over my text in Acts Seventeen before breakfast, and I reckon I put it in there, not noticing, meaning to put my Testament in, and it must be so, because my Testament ain’t in; but I’ll go and see; and if the Testament is where I had it, I’ll know I didn’t put it in, and that will show that I laid the Testament down and took up the spoon, and—”
vi: - I really don't know. Maybe while having breakfast, because I was so engrossed in reading the Bible, I put the spoon in my pocket thinking it was the holy book.
tr: “I really don’t know, Sally,” he said apologetically, “otherwise I would tell you, you know. Before breakfast, I was working on Acts 17. I don’t know how it happened, but I must have unknowingly put it in my pocket thinking it was the Bible; it must be so, because the Bible is not in my pocket, but let me go and check, if the Bible is still in its previous place, I will be sure that I didn’t put it in my pocket, then I will put the Bible and take the spoon and put it in my pocket...”
es: —I really don't know, Sally—he says, as if making excuses—, or you know very well that I would tell you. I was studying my text from Acts 17 before breakfast and I figure I put it there, without realizing it, when what I wanted was to put my New Testament, and it must be that because what I don't have is the New Testament, but I'll check, and if the New Testament is where it was before, I'll know that I didn't put it away and that will prove that I left the New Testament on the table and grabbed the spoon and...

en: “Oh, for the land’s sake! Give a body a rest! Go ’long now, the whole kit and biling of ye; and don’t come nigh me again till I’ve got back my peace of mind.”
vi: Let me go check if the Bible is still there or not. Maybe I put the Bible down and picked up the spoon, and... - Oh no, everyone please go away, don't let anyone come near me while I'm in a rage.
tr: “Ah, for God's sake! Be quiet already! Get out, all of you, children and everyone, get out, and don't come near me until I get my head straight.”
es: —Well, for the love of God! Leave me alone! Now everyone out and don't come near me again until I've calmed down a bit.

en: I’d a heard her if she’d a said it to herself, let alone speaking it out; and I’d a got up and obeyed her if I’d a been dead. As we was passing through the setting-room the old man he took up his hat, and the shingle-nail fell out on the floor, and he just merely picked it up and laid it on the mantel-shelf, and never said nothing, and went out. Tom see him do it, and remembered about the spoon, and says:
vi: If she had only whispered to herself, I would have heard it already, let alone shouting like this; even if I were dead, I would have risen to listen. We walked past the bedroom and saw my uncle putting away his hat, the boat nail stuck in his hat fell to the floor. He just quietly picked it up and placed it on the coat rack, said nothing, and walked out. Seeing that, Tom remembered the spoon. He said:
tr: Even if he didn't speak loudly and said it to himself, I would still hear it; even if I were dead, I would immediately get up and obey. As we passed through the living room, the old man dropped the nail while taking his hat; he just bent down, picked up the nail, and placed it on the mantelpiece, then left without saying a word. Tom had seen what he did, and thinking about the spoon issue, he said:
es: I would have heard her even if she were talking to herself, and even more so because she said it out loud, and I would have gotten up to obey her even if it had killed me. As we passed through the room, the old man grabbed the hat and the nail fell out, but he simply picked it up and left it on the shelf without saying a word, and left. Tom saw it, remembered the spoon, and said:

en: “Well, it ain’t no use to send things by him no more, he ain’t reliable.” Then he says: “But he done us a good turn with the spoon, anyway, without knowing it, and so we’ll go and do him one without him knowing it—stop up his rat-holes.”
vi: - Well, maybe we can't trust him to send things through him anymore. But he did us a favor regarding the spoon that the other guy didn't know about, so we should thank him by sealing up the mouse holes.
tr: “There is no point in sending anything with him anymore, he is not reliable.” Then he continued: “But he was very useful with the spoon, even without realizing it; so we should go and do something useful for him without his knowledge – let's plug the mouse holes.”
es: —Well, it's no use sending things with him anymore, because he's not trustworthy —and he added—, but in any case, he did us a favor with the spoon, without knowing it, so let's do him one without him knowing: let's cover the rat holes.

en: There was a noble good lot of them down cellar, and it took us a whole hour, but we done the job tight and good and shipshape. Then we heard steps on the stairs, and blowed out our light and hid; and here comes the old man, with a candle in one hand and a bundle of stuff in t’other, looking as absent-minded as year before last. He went a mooning around, first to one rat-hole and then another, till he’d been to them all. Then he stood about five minutes, picking tallow-drip off of his candle and thinking. Then he turns off slow and dreamy towards the stairs, saying:
vi: In the basement, there were many rat holes, so it took us an hour to seal them all, but we did it very carefully. Suddenly, there were footsteps on the stairs, and we quickly turned off the lights and hid. Uncle Silas came, holding a candle in one hand and some tools in the other, looking dazed. He went around from one rat hole to another. Then he stood up and paused for a few minutes, thinking. He walked towards the stairs in a trance, mumbling:
tr: There were indeed a lot of mouse holes in the cellar; we spent almost an hour, but in the end, we did a perfect job and tightly sealed all of them. Just as we finished our work, we heard someone coming down the stairs to the cellar, and we immediately turned off our light and hid; the old man was coming down absentmindedly with a candle in one hand and sealing materials in the other. He went from one mouse hole to another, visiting all the holes. Then, fiddling with the dripping parts of the candle in his hand, he stood there thinking for about five minutes. Finally, he slowly and dreamily murmured as he headed towards the stairs:
es: There were heaps of them in the basement and it took us a whole hour, but we did the job well, without forgetting anything. Then we heard footsteps on the stairs, turned off the light, hid, and the old man appeared, with a candle in one hand and a bunch of tow in the other, as distracted as ever. He started searching everywhere, first one of the holes and then another, until he saw them all. Then he stood still for about five minutes, removing the tallow from the candle and thinking, until he slowly and pensively turned towards the stairs saying:

en: “Well, for the life of me I can’t remember when I done it. I could show her now that I warn’t to blame on account of the rats. But never mind—let it go. I reckon it wouldn’t do no good.”
vi: - I don't remember when I plugged these holes. I have to go tell Saly right now, and that way I won't be blamed for the mice. But never mind, saying it wouldn't help anyway.
tr: “I never remember when I did it. He now accepts that I am not guilty about the mice. But anyway… It's best to let it be. The other way wouldn't benefit anyone anyway.”
es: —Well, the truth is that I don't remember when I did it. Now I could prove to you that the rat problem is not my fault. But it doesn't matter: let's leave it at that. I figure it wouldn't be worth anything.

en: And so he went on a-mumbling up stairs, and then we left. He was a mighty nice old man. And always is.
vi: As he just went up the stairs, we sneaked out after him. He is always nice.
tr: He went up the stairs saying such things, and we followed him. He was a very charming old man. He always remained that way.
es: He went up the stairs talking to himself, and then we left. He was a very nice old man, and he still is.

en: Tom was a good deal bothered about what to do for a spoon, but he said we’d got to have it; so he took a think. When he had ciphered it out he told me how we was to do; then we went and waited around the spoon-basket till we see Aunt Sally coming, and then Tom went to counting the spoons and laying them out to one side, and I slid one of them up my sleeve, and Tom says:
vi: Tom was very worried about how to get a spoon. After thinking for a while, he told me what to do now. We went to wait at the place where the spoon basket was until Aunt Saly arrived. Tom counted the spoons and set one aside, then slipped one into his sleeve. Then Tom said:
tr: Tom was very worried about what we would do with the spoon, but we had to take it. So he sat down and started to think. After forming the plan in his mind, he told me what we would do; then we went and waited around the spoon basket until Aunt Sally came, Tom was counting the spoons and setting aside the ones he counted, I slipped one of the spoons into my cuff, Tom turned to him:
es: Tom was very worried about how to find another spoon, because he said we needed it; so he started thinking. When he made up his mind, he told me what we had to do; then we went to wait where the basket of spoons was until we saw Aunt Sally coming, and Tom started counting the spoons and setting them aside while I hid one in my sleeve, and Tom goes and says:

en: “Why, Aunt Sally, there ain’t but nine spoons yet.”
vi: - Saly, there are only nine spoons here.
tr: “Aunt Sally, there are still only nine spoons here.”
es: —Hey, Aunt Sally, there are still only nine spoons.

en: She says:
vi: She said:
tr: “Go play with Git, don't disturb my peace,” said Aunt Sally.
es: And she responds:

en: “Go ’long to your play, and don’t bother me. I know better, I counted ’m myself.”
vi: - Please, don't bother your aunt anymore. Your aunt knows already, she counted it herself.
tr: “Go play with Git, don't disturb my peace,” said Aunt Sally. “I know how many there are, I counted them myself.”
es: —Come on, keep playing and don't bother me. I know what there is. I've counted them myself.

en: “Well, I’ve counted them twice, Aunty, and I can’t make but nine.”
vi: - Auntie, I counted twice and still only see nine.
tr: “But I counted them all twice, Aunt, there were nine.”
es: —Well, I counted them twice, Aunt, and I only get nine.

en: She looked out of all patience, but of course she come to count—anybody would.
vi: She seemed to be unable to bear the impatience any longer, but she counted again.
tr: He seemed to have completely lost his patience, but of course, he still came to count – anyone would have come.
es: She seemed to lose her patience, but naturally came to count them, as anyone would have done.

en: “I declare to gracious ther’ ain’t but nine!” she says. “Why, what in the world—plague take the things, I’ll count ’m again.”
vi: After finishing counting, she said: - There really are only nine - How strange, let me count again.
tr: “Damn it, there are only nine here!” he said. “Why, damn your spoon-like... may your name be cursed, let's count again, it's for the best.”
es: —For heaven's sake, there are only nine! —he said—. But, what the devil, what is going on with these things? I'm going to count them again.

en: So I slipped back the one I had, and when she got done counting, she says:
vi: I gently let go of the spoon I was holding, then only spoke after she finished counting:
tr: I placed the spoon back among the others and when he finished counting, he said:
es: Then I put back the one I had hidden, and when he finished counting, he said:

en: “Hang the troublesome rubbage, ther’s ten now!” and she looked huffy and bothered both. But Tom says:
vi: - Here are ten! She was both delighted and worried. But then Tom said:
tr: “God, give me patience, and now I have ten more!” He looked both angry and worried at the same time. But Tom intervened:
es: —By all the demons, now there are ten! —she said, very irritated and uneasy at the same time. But Tom goes and says:

en: “Why, Aunty, I don’t think there’s ten.”
vi: - No, auntie, how could there be ten?
tr: "No, Auntie, I don't think there are ten.""
es: —But, aunt, I don't think there are ten.

en: “You numskull, didn’t you see me count ’m?”
vi: - Didn't you see that I just counted?
tr: “You idiot, didn't you see what I just counted?”
es: —Don't be silly, didn't you see me counting them?

en: “I know, but—”
vi: - I know, but...
tr: “I know, but…””
es: —I know, but...

en: “Well, I’ll count ’m again.”
vi: - Okay, count again.
tr: “Alright, let's count again then.”
es: —Well, I'm going to count them again.

en: So I smouched one, and they come out nine, same as the other time. Well, she was in a tearing way—just a-trembling all over, she was so mad. But she counted and counted till she got that addled she’d start to count in the basket for a spoon sometimes; and so, three times they come out right, and three times they come out wrong. Then she grabbed up the basket and slammed it across the house and knocked the cat galley-west; and she said cle’r out and let her have some peace, and if we come bothering around her again betwixt that and dinner she’d skin us. So we had the odd spoon, and dropped it in her apron-pocket whilst she was a-giving us our sailing orders, and Jim got it all right, along with her shingle nail, before noon. We was very well satisfied with this business, and Tom allowed it was worth twice the trouble it took, because he said now she couldn’t ever count them spoons twice alike again to save her life; and wouldn’t believe she’d counted them right if she did; and said that after she’d about counted her head off for the next three days he judged she’d give it up and offer to kill anybody that wanted her to ever count them any more.
vi: I counted again, and after finishing, I still only saw nine like before. That made her so angry she was about to go crazy. But she kept counting over and over, counting inside the basket and then outside the basket, sometimes it was enough, sometimes it was missing. Too frustrated, she grabbed the spoon basket and threw it into the corner of the house, hitting the cat lying there, and then yelled at us to get out so she could have some peace. So we took the spoon and put it into her kitchen apron pocket while she was shouting at us to leave. By near noon, Jim had received both the spoon and the nail. We found the whole thing very amusing. He said that after she counted like that for three more days, she would give up, and if anyone asked her to count again, she might even kill them.
tr: Upon this, I took one of them, and when she counted, there were still nine spoons. Aunt Sally was now completely out of her mind... She was trembling and had gone mad. But she counted again, and again, until she got so dizzy that she started counting wrong. If the count was correct three times, it was wrong three times. Upon this, she couldn't take it anymore, grabbed the basket and threw it, managing to hit the cat; she immediately disappeared and asked us to leave her alone for a while, saying that if we bothered her until dinner, she would skin us alive. Thus, we had secured that single spoon; while she was giving us the marching orders, I slipped the spoon into the pocket of her apron; thus, Jim was able to get both the spoon and the nail before noon. Because of this, we were very pleased with ourselves, and Tom said we had been rewarded for our trouble twice over, because even if they took her life, his aunt would never count those spoons again. No matter how many times she counted, she wouldn't believe she had counted correctly. Later, he said that his aunt couldn't pull herself together for the next three days, and if anyone asked her to count again, she would be ready to commit murder.
es: So I swiped one and only nine came out, just like the last time. She got extremely nervous and started trembling all over because she was so angry. But she kept counting and counting until she got so confused that she even counted the basket as if it were a spoon, so three times she got the count right and three times she got it wrong. Then she grabbed the basket, threw it to the other side of the room, kicked the cat, and said we should leave her alone and that if we bothered her again, she would skin us alive. So we kept the missing spoon and left it in the pocket of her apron while she ordered us to leave, and Jim got it along with the nail before noon. We were very happy with all that, and Tom said it was worth twice the trouble it had caused us, because now she wouldn't be able to count the spoons twice without getting confused even if her life depended on it; and even if she counted them right, she wouldn't believe it, and he said that when her head got tired of counting, she would give up and threaten to kill anyone who asked her to count them again.

en: So we put the sheet back on the line that night, and stole one out of her closet; and kept on putting it back and stealing it again for a couple of days till she didn’t know how many sheets she had any more, and she didn’t care, and warn’t a-going to bullyrag the rest of her soul out about it, and wouldn’t count them again not to save her life; she druther die first.
vi: That night, we again hung the bed sheet over the wire as usual and stole another one from the closet. Then we left it, then took it away, repeatedly for several days, until she no longer knew how many sheets there were and didn't bother to count them anymore.
tr: Upon this, that night we hung the sheet back on the clothesline and stole a sheet from Aunt Sally's closet; for a few days, we kept putting it back and stealing it again; finally, she lost count of how many sheets she had and said she didn't care, wouldn't wear out her soul over it, and would rather die than count the sheets again.
es: So that night we put the sheet back on the clothesline and stole one from the closet, and we kept putting it in and taking it out for a couple of days until she no longer knew how many sheets she had and didn't even care because she wasn't going to let it ruin her life or count them again even if it cost her life; she would rather die first.

en: So we was all right now, as to the shirt and the sheet and the spoon and the candles, by the help of the calf and the rats and the mixed-up counting; and as to the candlestick, it warn’t no consequence, it would blow over by-and-by.
vi: Now we were at ease. At ease about the shirt, the sheet, and the candles, thanks to the story of the little girl, the mouse, and the mixed-up counting, but nothing was mentioned about the brass candlestick.
tr: Thanks to the calf, the mice, and the counting confusion, our problems with shirts, sheets, spoons, and candles were resolved; as for the candlestick, it didn't cause much of a fuss and would eventually be forgotten over time.
es: So now everything was in order regarding the shirt and the sheet, the spoon and the candles, with the help of the veal; the rats and the accounts that didn't add up, and as for the candelabrum, it didn't matter, in time they would forget about it.

en: But that pie was a job; we had no end of trouble with that pie. We fixed it up away down in the woods, and cooked it there; and we got it done at last, and very satisfactory, too; but not all in one day; and we had to use up three wash-pans full of flour before we got through, and we got burnt pretty much all over, in places, and eyes put out with the smoke; because, you see, we didn’t want nothing but a crust, and we couldn’t prop it up right, and she would always cave in. But of course we thought of the right way at last—which was to cook the ladder, too, in the pie. So then we laid in with Jim the second night, and tore up the sheet all in little strings and twisted them together, and long before daylight we had a lovely rope that you could a hung a person with. We let on it took nine months to make it.
vi: But surely it would come out eventually. But making the cake was really a whole project. We encountered one difficulty after another before we could finish that cake. We took it into the forest, cooked it there, and were very pleased when it was done. But it wasn't something that could be done in a single day. We had to use three bowls full of dough, got burns all over our bodies, and our eyes stung. Finally, we figured out that we had to stuff the entire rope ladder into the cake first. The next night, we crawled over to Jim's place, tore the bed sheet into small strips and twisted them together, and by dawn, we had made a very nice rope that could support the weight of a person. By late morning, we went out into the forest, but we couldn't fit it into the cake.
tr: But making börek was a troublesome task, it seemed like we would never get rid of the trouble of baking that börek. We set up our arrangement somewhere deep in the forest and started baking the börek; in the end, we managed to bake it, and it turned out quite well, but it took more than a day; we had to use three pans full of flour, and while working on it, we burned ourselves in many places and our eyes were scorched by the smoke; because what we really needed was the outside of the börek and we couldn't get it right, every time the top would collapse inward. But in the end, we managed to get it right, that is, we finally figured out to bake the ladder inside the börek. For this, we went to Jim's place the second night, tore the sheet into small strips and tied them together, and by the time we had made a very nice rope long enough to hang a man, it was still far from morning. But we pretended that preparing the rope took nine months.
es: But the cake gave us a lot of work; it only caused us problems. We prepared it in the forest and cooked it there, and finally, we had it done and very satisfactory; but it took us more than a day and we had to use three basins full of flour before finishing it, and we got burned all over and the smoke got into our eyes; because the thing is, we only wanted to get a crust and we couldn't get it to hold well, because it always collapsed. But, naturally, we finally came up with something that would work, which was to cook the ladder with the cake as well. So that night we went to see Jim, tore the sheet into strips and twisted them all together, and before dawn, we had a great rope that would be enough to hang someone. We pretended it had taken us nine months to braid it.

en: And in the forenoon we took it down to the woods, but it wouldn’t go into the pie. Being made of a whole sheet, that way, there was rope enough for forty pies if we’d a wanted them, and plenty left over for soup, or sausage, or anything you choose. We could a had a whole dinner.
vi: By late morning, we went out into the forest, but we couldn't fit it into the cake. A rope made from an entire bed sheet would require forty cakes to hold it all, and there would still be leftovers to put in soup and sauces.
tr: We took the rope and went to the forest before noon, but we couldn't fit it into the pastry. Since we made it from a large sheet, we had enough rope to fit into forty pastries if we wanted; moreover, there was plenty left for soup, sausages, or any other meals we preferred. This rope would be enough for a large dinner.
es: In the morning we took her to the forest, but she wouldn't fit into the pie. Since she was made from an entire sheet, there was enough rope for forty pies if we had wanted, and there would still be some left for soup, sausages, or whatever one might want. We could have used her for an entire dinner.

en: But we didn’t need it. All we needed was just enough for the pie, and so we throwed the rest away. We didn’t cook none of the pies in the wash-pan—afraid the solder would melt; but Uncle Silas he had a noble brass warming-pan which he thought considerable of, because it belonged to one of his ancesters with a long wooden handle that come over from England with William the Conqueror in the Mayflower or one of them early ships and was hid away up garret with a lot of other old pots and things that was valuable, not on account of being any account, because they warn’t, but on account of them being relicts, you know, and we snaked her out, private, and took her down there, but she failed on the first pies, because we didn’t know how, but she come up smiling on the last one. We took and lined her with dough, and set her in the coals, and loaded her up with rag rope, and put on a dough roof, and shut down the lid, and put hot embers on top, and stood off five foot, with the long handle, cool and comfortable, and in fifteen minutes she turned out a pie that was a satisfaction to look at. But the person that et it would want to fetch a couple of kags of toothpicks along, for if that rope ladder wouldn’t cramp him down to business I don’t know nothing what I’m talking about, and lay him in enough stomach-ache to last him till next time, too.
vi: But we didn't need that. All that was necessary was to stuff enough into the cake, and we discarded the rest. We didn't cook anything in the bowl, for fear that the tin would melt. But Uncle Silas had a copper warming pan that we treasured, as it was an heirloom with a wooden handle, sent from England. He had hidden it in the attic along with a lot of jars, bottles, and other valuable items. Actually, it is not highly valued, but because it is an antique, it is considered important. We took it out to the forest, the first cake we cooked got burnt, but the next one turned out fine. We took it out, cleaned it, rubbed it with flour, placed it on the charcoal stove, then added some scraps of paper, put a wet lump of dough, covered it, and put glowing charcoal on the lid. Then we stood more than a meter away, holding a long, cool handle, and fifteen minutes later, we had a very beautiful-looking cake. But anyone who eats that cake will suffer from a stomachache and be bedridden.
tr: But we didn't need that much. We only needed enough rope to fit into the pie, so we threw the rest away. Fearing that the metal would melt, we didn't make the pie in the pan we found; instead, we used Uncle Silas's beautiful brass bed warmer. He valued this warmer greatly because this long-handled bed warmer, belonging to his ancestors, had come over with William the Conqueror on the Mayflower or one of the first ships, and it was stored in the attic along with a lot of old pots and other valuable things; their value, of course, came not from their monetary worth but from being heirlooms; so we took this bed warmer and went to the woods, but we failed with the first pies because we didn't quite know how to do it, but on the last try, it rose beautifully. To cook it properly, we first spread the dough on the bottom of the warmer, placed it on the coals, and then put the rope ladder on top of the dough. After spreading another layer of dough on top and closing the lid, we placed pieces of coal on top; thanks to the long handle, we comfortably held the pan about a meter and a half away without being affected by the heat, and after fifteen minutes, we had an appetizing pie. But anyone who tried to eat the pie would need a few boxes of toothpicks. Because if swallowing the rope ladder inside the pie isn't hard, then I don't know what I'm talking about. Also, the person eating it would be writhing in stomach pain.
es: But we didn't need that much. The only thing we needed was enough for the cake, so we threw the rest away. We didn't bake any of the cakes in the basin, because we feared the welded part would melt, but Uncle Silas had a wonderful copper heater that he valued greatly, because it had belonged to one of his ancestors, and it had a long wooden handle that had come from England with William the Conqueror on the Mayflower or one of those pilgrim ships and was hidden in the attic, with a bunch of old pots and valuable things, not because they were worth anything, which they weren't, but because they were like relics, you know, and we secretly took it out and brought it to the woods, but it failed us on the first cakes because we didn't know how to use it well, although it worked great on the last one. We put dough around all the edges, filled it with a rope of rags and then covered it all with dough and closed the lid, and on top we put some embers and stepped back five feet, with the long handle, so calm and comfortable, and after fifteen minutes we got a cake that was a pleasure to see. But whoever ate it would have to take a couple of barrels of toothpicks, because if that rope ladder didn't clog all their teeth, then I don't know what I'm talking about, and on top of that, they would have a stomach ache for the rest of their life.

en: Nat didn’t look when we put the witch pie in Jim’s pan; and we put the three tin plates in the bottom of the pan under the vittles; and so Jim got everything all right, and as soon as he was by himself he busted into the pie and hid the rope ladder inside of his straw tick, and scratched some marks on a tin plate and throwed it out of the window-hole.
vi: When we placed that devilish cake into the pot to bring it to Jim, Nat didn't dare to look. Then we put three iron plates at the bottom of the pot, beneath the other food. So Jim had everything he needed. As soon as he received those items, Jim immediately broke the cake to take the string and hid it in the straw, then made a few marks on the iron plates and threw them out through the window.
tr: When we placed the witch pie on Jim's tray, Nat wasn't looking; we had also placed three iron plates right under the pie; that way, Jim could take everything, and the moment he was alone, he opened the pie and hid the rope ladder inside the straw mattress, carved some marks on the iron plate, and threw it out the window hole.
es: Nat didn't look when we put the witch pie in Jim's bowl and placed the three tin plates at the bottom of the kettle under the bowl, so everything reached Jim perfectly, and as soon as he was alone, he broke the pie and hid the rope ladder in the straw mattress, scribbled on a tin plate, and threw it out the window hole.

en: CHAPTER XXXVIII.
vi: Chapter XXXVIII
tr: Thirty-Eighth Chapter
es: Chapter 38

en: Making them pens was a distressid tough job, and so was the saw; and Jim allowed the inscription was going to be the toughest of all. That’s the one which the prisoner has to scrabble on the wall. But he had to have it; Tom said he’d got to; there warn’t no case of a state prisoner not scrabbling his inscription to leave behind, and his coat of arms.
vi: Jim said that engraving was the hardest of all. But Tom insisted that Jim had to write.
tr: Making the pens was a difficult job that required a lot of effort, as was making the saw; but Jim said the hardest part would be carving writing into the walls. But these were things that the prisoner absolutely had to write on the wall. No matter what, they had to be written; Tom said he was obliged to do it; there wasn't a single case where prisoners didn't carve writing and their coat of arms into the wall before leaving.
es: PREPARING THE FEATHERS was a very difficult job, just like with the saw, and Jim said that the inscription was going to be the hardest part of all. It was what the prisoner had to engrave on the wall. But it was necessary; Tom said he had to do it; there wasn't a single case of a State prisoner who didn't leave an inscription, along with his coat of arms.

en: “Look at Lady Jane Grey,” he says; “look at Gilford Dudley; look at old Northumberland! Why, Huck, s’pose it is considerble trouble?—what you going to do?—how you going to get around it? Jim’s got to do his inscription and coat of arms. They all do.”
vi: The prisoner had to leave his handwriting on the wall for posterity, along with his emblem. Jim said:
tr: “Look at Lady Jane Grey,” he said; “Look at Gilford Dudley, at old Northumberland! What does it matter if doing this is harder than making a camel jump through a hoop? What are we going to do then? Are we going to beat around the bush? Jim has to carve his inscription on the wall, engrave his coat of arms. Everyone is doing it.”
es: —Look at Lady Jane Grey —he goes and says—; look at Gilford Dudley; look at that Northumberland! But, Huck, let's say it's a lot of work. What are you going to do about it? How are you going to manage? Jim has to leave his inscription and his coat of arms. It's what everyone does.

en: Jim says:
vi: Jim said:
tr: "But Master Tom, I don't have a master," said Jim.
es: And Jim goes and says:

en: “Why, Mars Tom, I hain’t got no coat o’ arm; I hain’t got nuffn but dish yer ole shirt, en you knows I got to keep de journal on dat.”
vi: - Uncle Tom, I don't have any personal badge at all, just this shirt you gave me and I have to write my diary on it.
tr: "In fact, I don't have anything other than these pots and pans and an old shirt, and I need to use them for daily writing anyway."
es: —But, Mr. Tom, I don't have a coat of arms; I have nothing but this old shirt and you know that I have to write the diary on it.

en: “Oh, you don’t understand, Jim; a coat of arms is very different.”
vi: - You don't understand anything, Jim, the badge is different, it's not like that.
tr: “Ah, you just don't understand, Jim, a coat of arms is something very different.”
es: —Well, Jim, it's just that you don't understand; a coat of arms is very different.

en: “Well,” I says, “Jim’s right, anyway, when he says he ain’t got no coat of arms, because he hain’t.”
vi: I said: - Jim is right. He doesn't have any badges.
tr: “Still, Jim is right in saying he doesn't have a coat of arms,” I said, “because he really doesn't have one.”
es: —Well —I said—, in any case, Jim is right when he says he doesn't have a coat of arms, because he doesn't.

en: “I reckon I knowed that,” Tom says, “but you bet he’ll have one before he goes out of this—because he’s going out right, and there ain’t going to be no flaws in his record.”
vi: Tom replied:
tr: “We probably know,” said Tom, “but there will be one before this is over… because he does everything right and there won't be the slightest flaw in his record.”
es: —I already knew that —says Tom—, but I bet you he will have it before he leaves here, because he is going to leave as he should, without any blemish on his record.

en: So whilst me and Jim filed away at the pens on a brickbat apiece, Jim a-making his’n out of the brass and I making mine out of the spoon, Tom set to work to think out the coat of arms. By-and-by he said he’d struck so many good ones he didn’t hardly know which to take, but there was one which he reckoned he’d decide on. He says:
vi: - I know, but Jim needs to have a badge before leaving this place. So Tom sat down, wracking his brain to come up with a badge for Jim. After a while, he said he had thought of many but didn't know which one to choose. Finally, he picked one design and said:
tr: Jim and I started sharpening the pencils on a piece of brick; Jim was making his out of brass, and I was using the spoon. Meanwhile, Tom was lost in thought about the coat of arms. A little later, he said that he had come up with a lot of beautiful coats of arms and couldn't decide which one to choose, but he would probably settle on one eventually. “The crest will be curved or on the right side.
es: So while Jim and I were sharpening the feathers on a brick, Jim his with the copper and I mine with the spoon, Tom started working on thinking about the coat of arms. After a while, he said that so many had occurred to him that he didn't know which one to choose, but there was one that seemed to be his favorite. He goes and says:

en: “On the scutcheon we’ll have a bend or in the dexter base, a saltire murrey in the fess, with a dog, couchant, for common charge, and under his foot a chain embattled, for slavery, with a chevron vert in a chief engrailed, and three invected lines on a field azure, with the nombril points rampant on a dancette indented; crest, a runaway nigger, sable, with his bundle over his shoulder on a bar sinister; and a couple of gules for supporters, which is you and me; motto, Maggiore fretta, minore atto. Got it out of a book—means the more haste, the less speed.”
vi: - On that coat of arms, a circle is drawn around it, with a yellow cross in front, depicting a dog lying down, showing subservience, with a chain at the dog's feet, then a place to record achievements in green, with serrated edges, a green V shape at the top of the emblem, and three slanted lines on a blue background with many dots.
tr: Inside the band surrounding the crest, there will be a dark red diagonal stripe and an outstretched dog representing the people. Under the dog's paw, there will be a solid chain representing slavery. At the top, there will be a green ornament and three vertical lines on a sky blue background with dots spread in the middle of a deliberate zigzag mark. At the top, a picture of a runaway black man: Pitch black, with a bundle on his shoulder over the mark indicating illegitimacy. There are two red lines supporting him, which represent you and me. At the very bottom, a curved crest band. There is an inscription on it: Maggiore fretta, minore otto. I saw it in a book... it means the more you hurry, the slower you go.”
es: —On the shield, we will place a gold bar on the dexter base, a purple saltire on the falcon, with a dog, couchant, in franchise, and under the foot, an embattled chain, for—slavery, with a green chevron with a dented point and three vector lines on a field of azure, with the points of the teeth rampant in a dancette; as a crest, a fugitive black man, sable, with a bundle on his shoulder over a bar of bastardy, and a pair of gules of support, which are you and me; as a motto, Maggiore fretta, minore atto. I got it from a book; it means that no matter how early you get up, it doesn't make the sun rise any sooner.

en: “Geewhillikins,” I says, “but what does the rest of it mean?”
vi: - On that coat of arms, a circle is drawn around it, with a yellow cross in front, depicting a dog lying down, showing subservience, with a chain at the dog's feet, then a place to record achievements in green, with serrated edges, a green V shape at the top of the emblem, and three slanted lines on a blue background with many dots.
tr: “Wow, so what does the rest mean?” I asked.
es: —Damn it —I said—, but what does all the rest mean?

en: “We ain’t got no time to bother over that,” he says; “we got to dig in like all git-out.”
vi: - On that coat of arms, a circle is drawn around it, with a yellow cross in front, depicting a dog lying down, showing subservience, with a chain at the dog's feet, then a place to record achievements in green, with serrated edges, a green V shape at the top of the emblem, and three slanted lines on a blue background with many dots.
tr: “We don't have time to waste on this, we need to start digging immediately.”
es: —We don't have time to waste on that —he goes and says—; we need to start digging like the condemned.

en: “Well, anyway,” I says, “what’s some of it? What’s a fess?”
