vi: - On that coat of arms, a circle is drawn around it, with a yellow cross in front, depicting a dog lying down, showing subservience, with a chain at the dog's feet, then a place to record achievements in green, with serrated edges, a green V shape at the top of the emblem, and three slanted lines on a blue background with many dots.
tr: “Couldn't you at least tell me the meaning of some of them? For example, what is a strip?”
es: —Well, in any case —I asked—; at least tell me something, what is a falquín? —A falquín... A falquín is...

en: “A fess—a fess is—you don’t need to know what a fess is. I’ll show him how to make it when he gets to it.”
vi: - On that coat of arms, a circle is drawn around it, with a yellow cross in front, depicting a dog lying down, showing subservience, with a chain at the dog's feet, then a place to record achievements in green, with serrated edges, a green V shape at the top of the emblem, and three slanted lines on a blue background with many dots.
tr: "Strip... strip thing... you don't need to know what it is. I'll show you how to do it, and then you'll do it."
es: You don't need to know what a falquín is. I'll teach you how to make one when the time comes.

en: “Shucks, Tom,” I says, “I think you might tell a person. What’s a bar sinister?”
vi: - On that coat of arms, a circle is drawn around it, with a yellow cross in front, depicting a dog lying down, showing subservience, with a chain at the dog's feet, then a place to record achievements in green, with serrated edges, a green V shape at the top of the emblem, and three slanted lines on a blue background with many dots.
tr: “Don't break me, you can tell any person, can't you, Tom? What is the sign indicating illegitimacy?”
es: —Damn, Tom —I said—; I thought you could tell it. What is a bar sinister?

en: “Oh, I don’t know. But he’s got to have it. All the nobility does.”
vi: A symbol of a black man running away carrying a bundle of luggage, and another symbol of two guys following to help, meaning you and me. So it resolved the matter about the badge, now it was finishing the remaining part, which was to draft a farewell letter, saying that Jim must have such a letter, as it was mentioned in the book.
tr: “You are asking unnecessary questions. It just has to be there. All the nobles have it.”
es: —Ah, I don't know. But it is necessary. All the nobility has it.

en: That was just his way. If it didn’t suit him to explain a thing to you, he wouldn’t do it. You might pump at him a week, it wouldn’t make no difference.
vi: So it resolved the matter about the badge, now it was finishing the remaining part, which was to draft a farewell letter, saying that Jim must have such a letter, as it was mentioned in the book.
tr: This was just right for her. If she didn't feel like explaining something to you, she wouldn't explain it. Even if you nagged her for a week, you wouldn't get a single word out of her.
es: That's how he was. If it didn't suit him to explain something, he wouldn't explain it. You could spend a week asking him about it, and it wouldn't matter.

en: He’d got all that coat of arms business fixed, so now he started in to finish up the rest of that part of the work, which was to plan out a mournful inscription—said Jim got to have one, like they all done. He made up a lot, and wrote them out on a paper, and read them off, so:
vi: So it resolved the matter about the badge, now it was finishing the remaining part, which was to draft a farewell letter, saying that Jim must have such a letter, as it was mentioned in the book. It wrote it down on a piece of paper, then read it aloud:
tr: After completely deciding on the weapon matter, he turned to the remaining part of the work, namely planning our sorrowful inscription. Like all prisoners, Jim should also have such an inscription. He made up a bunch of words and wrote them down on a piece of paper, then read them aloud:
es: Since he had everything arranged regarding the coat of arms, he began to finish that part of the task, which consisted of planning a very sad inscription, because it said that Jim had to leave, just like everyone else had done. He invented many, which he wrote on a paper, and when he read them, they said:

en: 1. Here a captive heart busted.
vi: 1) Here, a captive heart is breaking.
tr: 1. A captive heart withered away here.
es: 1. Here, a captive's heart was broken.

en: 2. Here a poor prisoner, forsook by the world and friends, fretted out his sorrowful life.
vi: 2) Here, a pitiable prisoner, abandoned by life and friends, must live withering away, deteriorating.
tr: 2. A poor prisoner, separated from the world and his friends, spent his miserable life here.
es: »2. Here a poor prisoner, abandoned by the world and friends, suffered a life of sorrows.

en: 3. Here a lonely heart broke, and a worn spirit went to its rest, after thirty-seven years of solitary captivity.
vi: 3) Here, a lonely heart breaks, a spirit has grown weary after thirty-seven years of solitary confinement.
tr: 3. A completely lonely heart was broken here, a worn-out soul found peace after thirty-seven years of complete solitary captivity.
es: »3. Here a lonely heart was broken and a shattered spirit departed to its eternal rest, after thirty-seven years of solitary captivity.

en: 4. Here, homeless and friendless, after thirty-seven years of bitter captivity, perished a noble stranger, natural son of Louis XIV.
vi: 4) Here, the child of Louis the Fourteenth died homeless, without close friends, after thirty-seven years of imprisonment.
tr: 4. Homeless and friendless, after thirty-seven years of arduous captivity, the noble stranger who found peace here is the true son of Louis XIV. Louis XIV's own son.
es: »4. Here, without home or friends, after thirty-seven years of bitter captivity, perished a noble foreigner, the natural son of Louis XIV.»

en: Tom’s voice trembled whilst he was reading them, and he most broke down. When he got done he couldn’t no way make up his mind which one for Jim to scrabble on to the wall, they was all so good; but at last he allowed he would let him scrabble them all on. Jim said it would take him a year to scrabble such a lot of truck on to the logs with a nail, and he didn’t know how to make letters, besides; but Tom said he would block them out for him, and then he wouldn’t have nothing to do but just follow the lines. Then pretty soon he says:
vi: When reading those sentences, Tom's voice trembled with emotion. After finishing reading, he didn't know which sentence to choose for Jim to write on the wall because they all seemed good; in the end, he decided to let Jim write all of them. Jim said it would take him about a year to finish writing all those words, so Tom would write them outside, and Jim would just trace them on the wall. Then he said:
tr: Tom's voice was trembling as he read these, he was almost about to cry. After finishing reading, he couldn't decide which one Jim should carve into the wall, they were all equally good; but finally, he said he would allow him to carve all of them. Jim reminded him that carving so many words into the logs with a nail would take at least a year, and besides, he didn't even know how to write the letters; but Tom said he would draw the letters himself beforehand and all Jim had to do was follow the lines and carve. But he soon changed his mind:
es: Tom's voice trembled as he read it, and he almost started to cry. When he finished, there was no way he could decide which one Jim should write on the wall, because they were all great, but he finally decided to let him write them all. Jim said it would take him a year to write so many things on the logs with a nail, because he didn't know how to make letters; but Tom promised to draw them for him so that Jim would only have to follow the drawing. And shortly after, he said:

en: “Come to think, the logs ain’t a-going to do; they don’t have log walls in a dungeon: we got to dig the inscriptions into a rock. We’ll fetch a rock.”
vi: - Writing on wood won't work, because there are no wooden walls in the tower prison. We have to carve the letters into stone instead.
tr: “I thought about it, logs won't do; there can't be log walls in dungeons: We need to carve the inscription into a rock. Let's bring a rock.”
es: —Now that I think about it, those logs are no good; in the dungeons, you don't have logs; we have to make the inscriptions on a stone. We have to bring a stone.

en: Jim said the rock was worse than the logs; he said it would take him such a pison long time to dig them into a rock he wouldn’t ever get out. But Tom said he would let me help him do it. Then he took a look to see how me and Jim was getting along with the pens. It was most pesky tedious hard work and slow, and didn’t give my hands no show to get well of the sores, and we didn’t seem to make no headway, hardly; so Tom says:
vi: Jim said that carving on stone is even harder than on wood, so it would be a long time before he could finish and escape. But Tom said he would let me help. Then he looked to see how far Jim and I had written. Doing this was really a very difficult and slow task, my hands were already hurting and hurt even more, but the work seemed to make no progress. Tom said:
tr: Jim immediately interjected, saying that carving into the rock would be even harder than carving into the log. It would take so long to carve those words into a rock that it would never see the light of day again. But Tom said he would allow me to help him. Then he looked at what Jim and I had done to the pens. It was an extremely slow and laborious task, and it not only prevented my hands from healing but also made it seem like we had made almost no progress.
es: Jim said that the stone was worse than the logs; that it would take him so much time to write on the stone that he would never escape. But Tom said he would let me help him. Then he took a look to see how Jim and I were doing with the feathers. It was the most tedious, hard, and slow work, it didn’t help at all to get rid of the blisters on my hands, and we hardly seemed to make any progress, so Tom goes and says:

en: “I know how to fix it. We got to have a rock for the coat of arms and mournful inscriptions, and we can kill two birds with that same rock. There’s a gaudy big grindstone down at the mill, and we’ll smouch it, and carve the things on it, and file out the pens and the saw on it, too.”
vi: - I have an idea. We need to find a stone to make a badge and write on it. There is a large grinding stone in the workshop below, we will bring it up here and write things on it, and we can also use it to sharpen pens and saws.
tr: “I know how we will do it,” said Tom. “We need to find a rock for the coat of arms and the mournful inscription, then we can kill two birds with one stone with that rock. Inside the mill, there is a large and impressive millstone, we will take it, engrave everything on it, and sharpen the pens and saw on it as well.
es: —I know how to fix it. We need a stone for the coat of arms and the melancholic inscriptions, and we can kill two birds with one stone. Where the mill is, there is a huge grinding stone that we can bring to write things on it and also sharpen the quills and the saw.

en: It warn’t no slouch of an idea; and it warn’t no slouch of a grindstone nuther; but we allowed we’d tackle it. It warn’t quite midnight yet, so we cleared out for the mill, leaving Jim at work. We smouched the grindstone, and set out to roll her home, but it was a most nation tough job. Sometimes, do what we could, we couldn’t keep her from falling over, and she come mighty near mashing us every time. Tom said she was going to get one of us, sure, before we got through. We got her half way; and then we was plumb played out, and most drownded with sweat. We see it warn’t no use; we got to go and fetch Jim. So he raised up his bed and slid the chain off of the bed-leg, and wrapt it round and round his neck, and we crawled out through our hole and down there, and Jim and me laid into that grindstone and walked her along like nothing; and Tom superintended. He could out-superintend any boy I ever see. He knowed how to do everything.
vi: It was a bizarre idea, but we thought we could do it. It wasn't yet midnight, we went outside and headed down to the workshop, leaving only Jim to do his work. We carried the stone outside and rolled it home, but it was so heavy, several times it almost crushed our feet. Tom said that someone was bound to have the stone fall on their foot before we got it home. Halfway there, we were exhausted, staggering, and drenched in sweat. We had to call Jim, Jim got up and unhooked the chain from the bedpost, crawled out of the hole to where the stone was, Jim and I lifted the stone, moving as if it were nothing, while Tom directed us. He could command any other kid. He could do all sorts of things.
tr: This wasn't a bad idea. It was truly a tough millstone; still, we felt we could bring it. It wasn't midnight yet, so we left things to Jim and set off towards the mill. We removed the millstone from its place and started rolling it towards home, but this was really beyond us. Despite doing our best, we couldn't prevent it from toppling over from time to time, and each time we narrowly escaped being crushed underneath it. "By the time we get there, one of us will definitely be stuck under this stone," said Tom. We got it halfway, but we were too exhausted to take another step, we were about to drown in our own sweat. We realized we couldn't manage this, we had to go and get Jim. Jim lifted the bed and freed the chain from the bedpost, then wrapped the chain around his neck and we crawled out through the hole together. We went with Jim, easily lifted the millstone, and started carrying it, while Tom supervised us. He surpassed all the children I had seen in supervising. He knew how everything should be done.
es: It wasn't a bad idea, and it wasn't a bad grinding stone either, but we decided to give it a try. It wasn't midnight yet, so we went to the mill and left Jim with his work. We grabbed the stone and started rolling it home, but it was extremely difficult. Sometimes, no matter what we did, we couldn't stop it from falling, and at any moment it was about to crush us. Tom said it would surely take one of us out before we managed to finish. We got halfway and were already exhausted and almost drowning in sweat. We saw there was nothing else to do; we had to go get Jim. So he lifted the bed, took the chain off the leg of the cot, put it around his neck, and we crawled through the hole to where the stone was, and Jim and I started pushing it and made it roll quite easily, while Tom supervised. He was the best supervisor in the world. He knew how to do everything.

en: Our hole was pretty big, but it warn’t big enough to get the grindstone through; but Jim he took the pick and soon made it big enough. Then Tom marked out them things on it with the nail, and set Jim to work on them, with the nail for a chisel and an iron bolt from the rubbage in the lean-to for a hammer, and told him to work till the rest of his candle quit on him, and then he could go to bed, and hide the grindstone under his straw tick and sleep on it. Then we helped him fix his chain back on the bed-leg, and was ready for bed ourselves. But Tom thought of something, and says:
vi: The hole we dug was quite large, but the rock still couldn't fit through, so Jim took the pickaxe and dug it wider. Tom took a nail and marked the rock, telling Jim to chisel along the lines he had drawn. He told Jim to work until the candle went out, then hide the rock under the bed and sleep on top of it. We helped Jim reattach the chain to the bed leg, then we also prepared to go to sleep. But suddenly, Tom said:
tr: Our hole was quite wide, but still not big enough to pass the millstone through. However, Jim took the pickaxe and soon enlarged the hole. Then Tom used a nail to carve letters onto the stone and stood over Jim to make sure he continued; instead of a chisel, he would use the nail, and instead of a hammer, he would use an iron bar we found among the odds and ends in the storeroom. He told him to work until the remainder of his candle was used up, and then he could go to bed, but he had to place the millstone under his mattress and sleep on it. Afterwards, we helped Jim reattach the chain to the bed leg, and we were ready to go to bed ourselves. But it seemed like Tom had come up with something new.
es: Our hole was already quite large, but not large enough to fit the stone through it; then Jim grabbed the pickaxe and immediately made it bigger. Afterwards, Tom drew the phrases on it with the nail and put Jim to work, with the nail serving as a chisel and a bolt as a hammer; he said to work until the candle was used up and then he could go to bed and hide the millstone under the mattress and sleep on top of it. Then we helped him put the chain back on the leg of the cot and got ready to go to bed. Tom thought of something, and he goes and says:

en: “You got any spiders in here, Jim?”
vi: - Are there any spiders in here, Jim?
tr: "Are there any spiders here, Jim?" he asked.
es: —Ah, are there spiders here?

en: “No, sah, thanks to goodness I hain’t, Mars Tom.”
vi: - No, there isn't, buddy.
tr: “No, master, thank God, no, Master Tom.”
es: —No, sir, thank God, no, Mr. Tom.

en: “All right, we’ll get you some.”
vi: - Okay, let me go get some for you.
tr: “Okay, we will bring it to you.”
es: —Very well, we will bring you some.

en: “But bless you, honey, I doan’ want none. I’s afeard un um. I jis’ ’s soon have rattlesnakes aroun’.”
vi: - Okay, let me go get some for you. - Oh, I'm very scared. I'd rather have snakes than spiders.
tr: “Oh, live long, my flower's corner, I don't want spiders. I'm already scared of spiders. If they come, then rattlesnakes will follow.”
es: —But, for God's sake, my child, I don't want spiders. They scare me. I even prefer rattlesnakes.

en: Tom thought a minute or two, and says:
vi: Tom thought for a few minutes and then said:
tr: After thinking for a minute or two, Tom said:
es: Tom stayed thinking for a moment, and then he says:

en: “It’s a good idea. And I reckon it’s been done. It must a been done; it stands to reason. Yes, it’s a prime good idea. Where could you keep it?”
vi: - A good idea. So where did you put it?
tr: “Actually, it's a good idea. I think it can be done. In fact, it must be done; it seems reasonable. Yes, this is a top-notch idea. Where can you hide it?”
es: —It's a good idea. And I reckon it has been done before. It must have been done; it makes sense. Yes, it's a phenomenal idea. Where would you have it?

en: “Keep what, Mars Tom?”
vi: - What to leave, Tom?
tr: “What will I hide, Master Tom?”
es: —Have what, little Tom?

en: “Why, a rattlesnake.”
vi: - A snake, what else?
tr: “A rattlesnake, of course.”
es: —Man, a rattlesnake.

en: “De goodness gracious alive, Mars Tom! Why, if dey was a rattlesnake to come in heah I’d take en bust right out thoo dat log wall, I would, wid my head.”
vi: - My God, if a snake crawls in here, I will immediately have to squeeze through that hole in the wall and run away.
tr: “Trust me, you follow me, Master Tom! If a rattlesnake comes out of the grass, I'll jump out of this log with my bare head.”
es: —By all the saints in heaven, Tom! But if I see a rattlesnake come in here, I'll fly through that log wall, even if I have to break it with my head.

en: “Why, Jim, you wouldn’t be afraid of it after a little. You could tame it.”
vi: - Oh, Jim, don't be so scared. Can you conquer it?
tr: "But Jim, after a while, you won't be afraid of it at all. You can tame it."
es: —Man, Jim, after a while you wouldn't be afraid of her anymore. You could tame her.

en: “Tame it!”
vi: - Conquer?
tr: “Tame it?”
es: —Tame her!

en: “Yes—easy enough. Every animal is grateful for kindness and petting, and they wouldn’t think of hurting a person that pets them. Any book will tell you that. You try—that’s all I ask; just try for two or three days. Why, you can get him so, in a little while, that he’ll love you; and sleep with you; and won’t stay away from you a minute; and will let you wrap him round your neck and put his head in your mouth.”
vi: - Yes, it's easy. Any animal that you love will be grateful and will never harm you. Just try it. Then it might let you wrap it around your neck and even tuck its head into your mouth.
tr: “Yes… very easy. All animals feel gratitude towards kindness and caresses, and they wouldn't even think of harming the people who caress them. Every book says so. You try it… I don't want anything else; just try for two or three days. Shortly after you take it, it will love you, sleep with you, not stay away from you for even a moment, allow you to wrap it around your neck and put its head in your mouth.”
es: —Yes, it's easy. All animals appreciate gestures of affection and caresses; it would never occur to them to harm a person who caresses them. You can see it in any book. Try it, that's all I'm saying; try it for two or three days. You can make it so that in a short time it loves you, sleeps with you, and doesn't leave your side for a moment; that it lets you put it around your neck and stick your head in its mouth.

en: “Please, Mars Tom—doan’ talk so! I can’t stan’ it! He’d let me shove his head in my mouf—fer a favor, hain’t it? I lay he’d wait a pow’ful long time ’fo’ I ast him. En mo’ en dat, I doan’ want him to sleep wid me.”
vi: - I beg you, I don't dare to listen! Will it let me put its head into my mouth? Never. Moreover, I don't want it to sleep with me.
tr: “Don’t say such things, Master Tom… I can’t stand it anymore! Letting him stick his head into my mouth… for the sake of kindness, is that it? It would take forever to ask him for that. Besides, I don’t even want him to sleep with me.”
es: —Please, Mr. Tom... Don't say such things! I can't stand it! You would let me put your head in my mouth, as a favor, right? I bet you'd have to wait a long time before I'd ask you for that. And besides, I don't want you to sleep with me.

en: “Jim, don’t act so foolish. A prisoner’s got to have some kind of a dumb pet, and if a rattlesnake hain’t ever been tried, why, there’s more glory to be gained in your being the first to ever try it than any other way you could ever think of to save your life.”
vi: - Jim, don't be so foolish. A prisoner must have an animal to befriend. Until now, no one has ever kept a snake, so being the first to do so would be even more glorious.
tr: “Don't act so foolishly, Jim. It is mandatory for prisoners to have a quiet pet; if no one has had a rattlesnake before, the honor of being the first person to try this, instead of other conceivable ways to save their life, is greater.”
es: —Jim, don't be silly. A prisoner has to have a pet, and if it's never been tried with a rattlesnake, you can achieve more glory by being the first to try it than in any other way you can think of to save your life.

en: “Why, Mars Tom, I doan’ want no sich glory. Snake take ’n bite Jim’s chin off, den whah is de glory? No, sah, I doan’ want no sich doin’s.”
vi: - Tom, I don't want that glory. The snake will bite me. No, I don't want to do that.
tr: "But Master Tom, I don't want such a big reputation. If the snake bites Jim's jaw, what good is the reputation to Jim then? No, master, I don't want to do such things."
es: —But, Tom, I don't want that glory. The snake goes and bites Jim on the chin, and then, where's the glory? No, sir, I don't want to do any of that.

en: “Blame it, can’t you try? I only want you to try—you needn’t keep it up if it don’t work.”
vi: - Damn it, can't you just try it? I just want you to try it. If you don't like it, you don't have to keep it forever!
tr: “You are something else, what do you have to lose by trying? I just want you to try… If it doesn't work, you don't need to keep feeding it.”
es: —Damn it, can't you try? I just want you to try... You don't need to keep going if it doesn't go well.

en: “But de trouble all done ef de snake bite me while I’s a tryin’ him. Mars Tom, I’s willin’ to tackle mos’ anything ’at ain’t onreasonable, but ef you en Huck fetches a rattlesnake in heah for me to tame, I’s gwyne to leave, dat’s shore.”
vi: - But while I was trying, it bit me already. Tom, I don't want to do those things. If Huck brings a snake in here, I'll leave immediately, definitely.
tr: “But while I was trying to tame it, it would finish me off on the street. I'm willing to do almost anything that makes sense to me, but if Huck and you bring me a rattlesnake and ask me to tame it, I'll leave immediately, there's no other way.”
es: —But the problem ends if the snake bites me while I'm trying. Tom, I'm willing to try almost anything that seems reasonable, but if you and Huck bring me a snake to tame, I'm out of here, I assure you of that.

en: “Well, then, let it go, let it go, if you’re so bull-headed about it. We can get you some garter-snakes, and you can tie some buttons on their tails, and let on they’re rattlesnakes, and I reckon that’ll have to do.”
vi: - Well, never mind then. We'll find you a few non-venomous snakes instead.
tr: “Alright then, if you are so stubborn, let it be as you say. We will bring you a few small snakes, you can put buttons or something on their tails and pretend they are rattlesnakes, this should be sufficient.”
es: —Well, then leave it, leave it, since you're being so stubborn. We can get you some snakes and tie some buttons to their tails and pretend they are rattlesnakes; I suppose we'll have to settle for that.

en: “I k’n stan’ dem, Mars Tom, but blame’ ’f I couldn’ get along widout um, I tell you dat. I never knowed b’fo’ ’t was so much bother and trouble to be a prisoner.”
vi: - I can't stand it either, Tom. I'm telling you the truth, I've never felt so worried and miserable like this.
tr: “I can endure it with ten, Master Tom, but without ten, I will be much more comfortable, don't forget that. Being a prisoner is such a hard and troublesome job, my friend.”
es: —I could put up with that, said Tom, but damned if I couldn't manage without them, I assure you. I had never understood that being imprisoned was such a hassle.

en: “Well, it always is when it’s done right. You got any rats around here?”
vi: I'm telling you the truth, I've never felt so worried and miserable like this. - So, are there any mice here?
tr: “Of course it is, but only if you do it right. So, is there a mouse here?”
es: —Well, it always is when things are done right. Are there rats around here?

en: “No, sah, I hain’t seed none.”
vi: - No, I didn't see any.
tr: “No, master, I have never buried a child.”
es: —No, sir, I haven't seen any.

en: “Well, we’ll get you some rats.”
vi: - Well, then we'll find you some mice...
tr: “Alright, we will bring you a few.”
es: —Well, we will bring you some rats.

en: “Why, Mars Tom, I doan’ want no rats. Dey’s de dadblamedest creturs to ’sturb a body, en rustle roun’ over ’im, en bite his feet, when he’s tryin’ to sleep, I ever see. No, sah, gimme g’yarter-snakes, ’f I’s got to have ’m, but doan’ gimme no rats; I hain’ got no use f’r um, skasely.”
vi: - I don't need mice, Tom. They are the most annoying creatures, always bothering people, climbing on them, biting their feet and preventing them from sleeping. I'd rather you put in regular snakes than bring mice in here. I have no use for mice.
tr: “Master Tom, I don't want any rats. They are very troublesome creatures, they disturb people, when you're trying to sleep they crawl over you and bite your feet. No, master, if you must bring something, just bring snakes, I don't want rats, they are of no use to me anyway.”
es: —But, Tom, I don't want to have rats. They are the most disgusting creatures there are, and they climb on you and bite your feet when you're trying to fall asleep. No, sir, I prefer snakes, if necessary, but no rats; I don't like them at all, and I mean it.

en: “But, Jim, you got to have ’em—they all do. So don’t make no more fuss about it. Prisoners ain’t ever without rats. There ain’t no instance of it. And they train them, and pet them, and learn them tricks, and they get to be as sociable as flies. But you got to play music to them. You got anything to play music on?”
vi: - But you must have mice. Don't worry, everyone does it that way. Prisoners never have mice, they train them with many tricks, and then those mice become as familiar as flies. And you also have to play music for them. Do you have anything to play music with?
tr: “But Jim, you have to have mice... everyone has mice. So stop complaining already. Is there such a thing as a prisoner without mice? I've never heard of such a thing in my life. In fact, they train the mice, pet them, teach them tricks, and develop a bond with them. But you should play music for them. Do you have the necessary instruments for that?”
es: —But, Jim, there have to be rats... It says so in all the books. So don't make a fuss about it. Prisoners never lack rats. There isn't a single case. And they tame them, pet them, and teach them tricks, and thus they learn to be very sociable. But you have to play them some music. Do you have something to play music?

en: “I ain’ got nuffn but a coase comb en a piece o’ paper, en a juice-harp; but I reck’n dey wouldn’ take no stock in a juice-harp.”
vi: - I only have a broken comb and a piece of paper to make a plucking instrument. But I am sure they don't like plucking instruments.
tr: “I only have a mountain and a piece of paper, and also a mouth harmonica, but whether you want to listen to the mouth harmonica, I don't really think so.”
es: —I only have a wooden comb, a piece of paper, and a berimbau, and I don't think they'll like a berimbau very much.

en: “Yes they would. They don’t care what kind of music ’tis. A jews-harp’s plenty good enough for a rat. All animals like music—in a prison they dote on it. Specially, painful music; and you can’t get no other kind out of a jews-harp. It always interests them; they come out to see what’s the matter with you. Yes, you’re all right; you’re fixed very well. You want to set on your bed nights before you go to sleep, and early in the mornings, and play your jews-harp; play ‘The Last Link is Broken’—that’s the thing that’ll scoop a rat quicker ’n anything else; and when you’ve played about two minutes you’ll see all the rats, and the snakes, and spiders, and things begin to feel worried about you, and come. And they’ll just fairly swarm over you, and have a noble good time.”
vi: - Yes, they do. They don't differentiate between types of music. Plucking the zither is good enough for the mice. All animals like music, and in prison, they like it even more, especially sad music. The mice love it. They will come out to see what strange thing you have. At night, before going to sleep, and early in the morning when you wake up, you have to sit on the bed for a while and play that zither. If you play for about two minutes, you will see all kinds of mice, snakes, spiders, etc., feeling sad for you and gathering around you.
tr: “Is that possible? Of course, they listen. They don't care what kind of music it is. A mouth harp is perfectly suitable for a mouse. All animals love music… especially in a prison environment, they adore it. Particularly sad music, and anyway, a mouth harp doesn't produce any other kind of music. It always catches their interest; they get up to see what is troubling you. Yes, now it's right, you're in a very good state now. At night before going to bed, in the early morning hours, you want to sit in your bed and play the mouth harp; play 'The Last Ring Broke'... it's the piece that interests the mice the most: After playing for about two minutes, you'll see that all the mice, snakes, spiders, and other things are worried about you and come to you. They will literally climb all over you and have a great time.”
es: —Surely, yes. They don't care about the type of music. A berimbau is phenomenal for a rat. All animals like music, and in prisons, they love it. Especially sad music, and with a berimbau, it's the only music you can play. They are always interested; they come out to see what's happening to you. Yes, it's going to go very well for you, you have everything. What you need to do is sit on the bed at night before you go to sleep, and in the morning do the same and play the berimbau; play "The Last Link is Broken," which is what rats love, and after playing for two minutes, you'll see that all the rats, snakes, and spiders and all that start to worry about you and come out. And they will all come to keep you company, and they will have a great time.

en: “Yes, dey will, I reck’n, Mars Tom, but what kine er time is Jim havin’? Blest if I kin see de pint. But I’ll do it ef I got to. I reck’n I better keep de animals satisfied, en not have no trouble in de house.”
vi: -Yes, I think so too. But right now I don't understand anything, I will try to follow if I have to. I will make those animals satisfied and there will be no trouble in the house.
tr: “Ten years is a long time, Master Tom, but how will Jim spend that time? I don't understand what good this will do. But if I must, I will do it. Probably the best thing is to keep the animals happy so that there won't be any trouble.”
es: —Yes, I suppose they will, said Tom, but how is Jim going to handle it? Hang me if I understand it. But if it's necessary, I'll do it. I reckon it's better to keep the animals happy and not have problems at home.

en: Tom waited to think it over, and see if there wasn’t nothing else; and pretty soon he says:
vi: Tom thought for a moment longer to see if there was anything else, then he said:
tr: Tom thought for a while longer, but it seemed like nothing else came to mind. Suddenly, he started speaking again:
es: Tom stayed thinking if something was missing, and after a moment he goes and says:

en: “Oh, there’s one thing I forgot. Could you raise a flower here, do you reckon?”
vi: - There is one more thing I forgot. Can you leave the flowers here?
tr: “Hah… I forgot something. Do you think you can grow flowers here?”
es: —Ah, I forgot something. Do you think you could grow a flower here?

en: “I doan know but maybe I could, Mars Tom; but it’s tolable dark in heah, en I ain’ got no use f’r no flower, nohow, en she’d be a pow’ful sight o’ trouble.”
vi: - I don't know, but maybe. But it's very dark in here, and I don't need flowers, it just adds more trouble.
tr: "I don't know, maybe I can manage, Master Tom; but the ox is very stubborn, and the flowers can't help me with my work.
es: —I don't know, but maybe yes, said Tom, although it's quite dark here and a flower isn't much use to me, and it would be very difficult for me.

en: “Well, you try it, anyway. Some other prisoners has done it.”
vi: - You should give it a try. The other prisoners also grow flowers.
tr: It's very difficult." "Still, you should give it a try. Some prisoners have managed to do it."
es: —Well, try it anyway. Some other prisoners have already done it.

en: “One er dem big cat-tail-lookin’ mullen-stalks would grow in heah, Mars Tom, I reck’n, but she wouldn’t be wuth half de trouble she’d coss.”
vi: - here you can probably see cattail flowers, but planting them is not worth the effort.
tr: “A huge catfish might grow here too, Master Tom, but it's not worth the trouble, I'm telling you from the start.”
es: —I reckon one of those cat-tail plants could grow here, said Tom, but it wouldn't be worth half the effort it would take.

en: “Don’t you believe it. We’ll fetch you a little one and you plant it in the corner over there, and raise it. And don’t call it mullen, call it Pitchiola—that’s its right name when it’s in a prison. And you want to water it with your tears.”
vi: - Don't think that way. We will find you a sapling, and you will plant it in that corner of the house over there. Don't call it a cat's tail flower, you must call it Pitchiola. And you must water it with tears.
tr: "Don't think like that. We'll bring you a small one, you can plant it in that corner over there, and it will grow and thrive. Also, don't call it mullein, call it Pitchiola... that's its real name when it's in prison. And you need to water it with your tears."
es: —Don't believe it. We'll bring you a tiny one and you plant it in that corner and cultivate it. And don't call it barbasco, but pitchiola, which is a name that sounds very nice in a prison. The best thing is to water it with your tears.

en: “Why, I got plenty spring water, Mars Tom.”
vi: - What's wrong? I have plenty of rainwater here.
tr: "Why, there's plenty of water in this, Tom."
es: —But I have plenty of water from the fountain, said Tom.

en: “You don’t want spring water; you want to water it with your tears. It’s the way they always do.”
vi: - You cannot water it with rainwater, you must water it with tears. Everyone does it that way.
tr: “You didn't want to use water, you should have watered it with your tears instead. This is always done this way.”
es: —You don't need water from the fountain; what you need is to water it with your tears. That's what everyone does.

en: “Why, Mars Tom, I lay I kin raise one er dem mullen-stalks twyste wid spring water whiles another man’s a start’n one wid tears.”
vi: - Uncle Tom, then that flower will surely die, because I rarely cry.
tr: “But Master Tom, can I use water for a big plant, and for another one, can I grow it with tears, is that okay?”
es: —But, Uncle Tom, I can grow a barbasco this big with water from the fountain, whereas with tears it will barely grow.

en: “That ain’t the idea. You got to do it with tears.”
vi: - Uncle Tom, then that flower will surely die, because I rarely cry.
tr: "That's not what's important. It must be watered with your tears."
es: —It's not about that. It must be done with tears.

en: “She’ll die on my han’s, Mars Tom, she sholy will; kase I doan’ skasely ever cry.”
vi: - Uncle Tom, then that flower will surely die, because I rarely cry.
tr: “But the flower died because of me, Master Tom, yes, it definitely died; because I don't cry easily.”
es: —He will die on me, Uncle Tom, I'm sure of it; because I almost never cry.

en: So Tom was stumped. But he studied it over, and then said Jim would have to worry along the best he could with an onion. He promised he would go to the nigger cabins and drop one, private, in Jim’s coffee-pot, in the morning. Jim said he would “jis’ ’s soon have tobacker in his coffee;” and found so much fault with it, and with the work and bother of raising the mullen, and jews-harping the rats, and petting and flattering up the snakes and spiders and things, on top of all the other work he had to do on pens, and inscriptions, and journals, and things, which made it more trouble and worry and responsibility to be a prisoner than anything he ever undertook, that Tom most lost all patience with him; and said he was just loadened down with more gaudier chances than a prisoner ever had in the world to make a name for himself, and yet he didn’t know enough to appreciate them, and they was just about wasted on him. So Jim he was sorry, and said he wouldn’t behave so no more, and then me and Tom shoved for bed.
vi: Tom was at a loss for words. But after a moment of thinking, he told Jim to rub an onion in his eyes to produce tears. He promised to pick an onion and secretly put it into Jim's coffee pot in the morning. Jim said that would make the coffee smell like onions, and then Jim complained about Tom's plans, such as planting cattail flowers, playing music for the mice, petting snakes and spiders, sharpening pencils, carving letters into stone, writing a diary, and so on. It was really troublesome and annoying. He talked for a while, making Tom discouraged. Tom said that he had come up with all those things just to make Jim famous, but Jim's complaints made it all seem like a waste of effort. Hearing that, Jim felt regretful and promised not to behave that way anymore. After that, Tom and I went back to our room to sleep.
tr: Tom was cornered. But after thinking for a bit, he told Jim that he should do his best to make his eyes water by cutting an onion. He promised to go to the black cabins in the morning and secretly put an onion in Jim's coffee pot. Jim said he preferred us to send tobacco in his coffee; he didn't like any of the tasks asked of him; raising cow tails, playing music to mice with a mouth harp, feeding and petting snakes and spiders or other animals were not sensible tasks; besides, he was already busy with pens, inscriptions, and diaries, which had made being a prisoner the most challenging, worrying, and responsible job he had ever seen. Hearing this, Tom completely lost his patience; he told Jim that he had been given more chances to become famous as a prisoner than he could ever have, but he didn't know how to appreciate these chances and didn't deserve them. Jim regretted what he said, promised not to behave like that again, and we went out to sleep.
es: So Tom didn't know what to do. But he thought about it and said that Jim would have to cry as much as he could with an onion. He promised that he would go to the black people's cabins and secretly put one in Jim's coffee in the morning. Jim said he would prefer tobacco in the coffee, and he made so many problems with that, and with the work and the issue of growing the barbasco, the jew's harp and the rats and petting the snakes and spiders and everything else, on top of what he had to do with the feathers and the inscriptions and the diaries and all that, that he said being a prisoner was the hardest thing he had ever done in his life, until Tom lost his patience with him and told him that he had received more opportunities than any prisoner in the world to become famous and yet he didn't know how to appreciate it, and that with him it was nothing but a waste of time. So Jim said he was sorry and that he wouldn't behave the same way again, and then Tom and I went to bed.

en: CHAPTER XXXIX.
vi: Chapter XXXIX
tr: Chapter Thirty-Nine
es: Chapter 39

en: In the morning we went up to the village and bought a wire rat-trap and fetched it down, and unstopped the best rat-hole, and in about an hour we had fifteen of the bulliest kind of ones; and then we took it and put it in a safe place under Aunt Sally’s bed. But while we was gone for spiders little Thomas Franklin Benjamin Jefferson Elexander Phelps found it there, and opened the door of it to see if the rats would come out, and they did; and Aunt Sally she come in, and when we got back she was a-standing on top of the bed raising Cain, and the rats was doing what they could to keep off the dull times for her. So she took and dusted us both with the hickry, and we was as much as two hours catching another fifteen or sixteen, drat that meddlesome cub, and they warn’t the likeliest, nuther, because the first haul was the pick of the flock. I never see a likelier lot of rats than what that first haul was.
vi: The next morning, we went to the village to buy a mouse trap and then brought it down to the house. Within about an hour, we had caught up to fifteen big ones. Then we carefully stored them under Aunt Saly's bed. But while we were out looking for spiders, little Tomas Phelps saw the mouse trap there and opened it to take a look. All the mice ran out in a frenzy, just as Aunt Saly walked in. When we got back, we saw her standing on the bed, screaming loudly, while the mice were running for their lives. She took a stick and gave the two of us a good beating.
tr: In the morning, we went to the village and bought a mouse trap in the shape of a wire cage, reopened the best of the holes we had blocked, and caught about fifteen of the largest mice in about an hour; then we took the cage and hid it under Aunt Sally's bed, thinking it was safe. But when we went out to hunt spiders, Thomas Franklin Benjamin Jefferson Alexander Phelps, you found the cage, got curious if the mice would come out, opened the lid, and the mice got out, and then didn't Aunt Sally come into the room... When we came back, she was on top of the bed screaming her head off, and the mice were doing their best to keep her entertained. So she gave us all a good beating, and because of that meddlesome kid, we had to spend almost two extra hours catching another fifteen or sixteen mice, and the ones we caught weren't much to look at, because the first ones we caught were the finest of the bunch. I had never seen such robust mice together as the ones we caught the first time.
es: IN THE MORNING we went to the village, bought a wire mousetrap, brought it home and uncovered the best of the rat holes, and after about half an hour we had already caught fifteen of the best in the mousetrap; then we grabbed it and put it safely under Aunt Sally's bed. But while we were looking for spiders, little Thomas Franklin Benjamin Jefferson Elexander Phelps found it and opened the door to see if the rats would come out, and they did, and when we came back Aunt Sally was up on the bed raising all kinds of hell while the rats did everything they could to keep her entertained. Then she shook us with the stick and it took us at least another two hours to catch another fifteen or sixteen, because of that silly kid, and they weren't the best either, because the first batch had been unbeatable. In my life I have never seen a better group of rats than that first batch.

en: We got a splendid stock of sorted spiders, and bugs, and frogs, and caterpillars, and one thing or another; and we like to got a hornet’s nest, but we didn’t. The family was at home. We didn’t give it right up, but stayed with them as long as we could; because we allowed we’d tire them out or they’d got to tire us out, and they done it. Then we got allycumpain and rubbed on the places, and was pretty near all right again, but couldn’t set down convenient. And so we went for the snakes, and grabbed a couple of dozen garters and house-snakes, and put them in a bag, and put it in our room, and by that time it was supper-time, and a rattling good honest day’s work: and hungry?—oh, no, I reckon not! And there warn’t a blessed snake up there when we went back—we didn’t half tie the sack, and they worked out somehow, and left. But it didn’t matter much, because they was still on the premises somewheres. So we judged we could get some of them again. No, there warn’t no real scarcity of snakes about the house for a considerable spell. You’d see them dripping from the rafters and places every now and then; and they generly landed in your plate, or down the back of your neck, and most of the time where you didn’t want them. Well, they was handsome and striped, and there warn’t no harm in a million of them; but that never made no difference to Aunt Sally; she despised snakes, be the breed what they might, and she couldn’t stand them no way you could fix it; and every time one of them flopped down on her, it didn’t make no difference what she was doing, she would just lay that work down and light out. I never see such a woman. And you could hear her whoop to Jericho. You couldn’t get her to take a-holt of one of them with the tongs. And if she turned over and found one in bed she would scramble out and lift a howl that you would think the house was afire. She disturbed the old man so that he said he could most wish there hadn’t ever been no snakes created. Why, after every last snake had been gone clear out of the house for as much as a week Aunt Sally warn’t over it yet; she warn’t near over it; when she was setting thinking about something you could touch her on the back of her neck with a feather and she would jump right out of her stockings. It was very curious. But Tom said all women was just so. He said they was made that way for some reason or other.
vi: We caught a bunch of spiders, bedbugs, frogs, and insects; we even wanted to take a hornet's nest, but we didn't succeed. The whole family of hornets was still in the nest. We kept waiting, intending to tire them out and then catch them. But instead, we went looking for snakes and caught a few dozen grass snakes, put them in a bag, and brought them back to the room. Just then, it was time for dinner. But the bag wasn't tied tightly at the top, so the snakes all crawled out. Every now and then, a snake would fall from the ceiling. And it would fall into the food dish, onto our backs, or onto our necks. Each one looked beautiful, but it was different for Aunt Saly. She was terribly disgusted by snakes. Every time a snake fell, she would scream and run away. I've never seen a woman so afraid of snakes. It took about a week for all the snakes to leave the house. Aunt Saly was still scared. It's really strange, but Tom said that all women are like that.
tr: We had a magnificent collection of spiders, insects, frogs, caterpillars, and similar things; we even thought of finding a beehive, but we couldn't manage that. The bee family was fully at home. We didn't give up immediately, we lingered there as long as we could, either they would get tired and leave, or we would. In the end, we gave up. We applied andiz powder to the places they stung us, we felt a bit relieved, but for a while, we couldn't sit comfortably on our bottoms. Then we went snake hunting, caught a few dozen small snakes, put them in a sack, and then hid the sack in our room; by then, it was dinner time, we had worked hard all day and were starving. But when we returned, we couldn't find a single snake in the room – we had left the sack's mouth loose, and the snakes had found a way out. It didn't really matter, though, because they were still somewhere in the house. We thought we could catch some of them again. For a while, there was never a shortage of snakes in the house. From time to time, you could see them falling from the roof beams and other places; they generally fell onto your plate or slid down your neck, meaning they mostly appeared in the places you least wanted them to. They were very beautiful and striped snakes, even if a million of them came, they wouldn't harm you; but it didn't matter to Aunt Sally, she was disgusted by snakes of any kind, she couldn't stand them at all; if one of them fell on her, she would drop whatever she was doing and dash outside. I had never seen a woman like her. Moreover, her screams could reach the heavens. The poor woman couldn't even hold the snakes with tongs. When she opened her bed and found a snake inside, she would throw herself outside and scream so loudly that you would think the house was on fire. Aunt Sally disturbed the peace of the big man so much that he got to the point where he wished snakes had never been created. Even a week after the last snake was thrown out of the house, Aunt Sally still hadn't recovered; she didn't even seem like she would recover; if you touched her neck with a feather while she was sitting and thinking about something, she would jump three meters into the air. It was a very strange thing. But Tom said all women were like that. For some reason, they were created that way.
es: We managed to get a splendid variety of spiders, beetles, frogs, and caterpillars, among other things, and we almost took a wasp nest, but we didn't succeed. The family was at home. We didn't give up immediately, but endured as much as we could, because we tried to tire them out or let them tire us out, which is what happened in the end. Then we went to put some ointment on the stings and almost got better, although we couldn't sit comfortably. Then we went out to look for snakes and caught a couple of dozen water snakes and house snakes and put them in a sack in our room, which brought us to dinner time after a whole day of work; were we hungry? No, of course not! When we returned, there wasn't a single damn snake left; we hadn't tied the sack well and somehow they had found their way out and left. But it didn't matter much, because they had to be somewhere in the house. So we thought we would find them again. No, for many days snakes were not scarce in that house. You could see them hanging from the beams and other times tucked away somewhere, and they generally fell onto someone's plate or crawled down their neck, almost always where it wasn't pleasant. Well, they were all very pretty with their stripes and all, and even if there were a million of them, they wouldn't have harmed anyone, but Aunt Sally didn't care about that; she was disgusted by snakes, no matter what kind they were, and she couldn't stand them in any way, and every time one fell on her, no matter what she was doing, she would stop and run away. I've never seen a woman like that; you could hear her screams all the way to Jericho. She couldn't even grab one with tongs. If she turned around and found one in the bed, she would run and start screaming as if the house was on fire. It annoyed the old man so much that he said he almost wished snakes had never been created. But man, even after there hadn't been a single one in the house for a week, Aunt Sally still hadn't recovered; she was still so scared that when she was sitting thinking about something, if you touched her on the neck with a feather, she would jump out of her shoes. It was very curious. But Tom said all women were the same. He said that for some reason or another they were made that way.

en: We got a licking every time one of our snakes come in her way, and she allowed these lickings warn’t nothing to what she would do if we ever loaded up the place again with them. I didn’t mind the lickings, because they didn’t amount to nothing; but I minded the trouble we had to lay in another lot. But we got them laid in, and all the other things; and you never see a cabin as blithesome as Jim’s was when they’d all swarm out for music and go for him. Jim didn’t like the spiders, and the spiders didn’t like Jim; and so they’d lay for him, and make it mighty warm for him. And he said that between the rats and the snakes and the grindstone there warn’t no room in bed for him, skasely; and when there was, a body couldn’t sleep, it was so lively, and it was always lively, he said, because they never all slept at one time, but took turn about, so when the snakes was asleep the rats was on deck, and when the rats turned in the snakes come on watch, so he always had one gang under him, in his way, and t’other gang having a circus over him, and if he got up to hunt a new place the spiders would take a chance at him as he crossed over. He said if he ever got out this time he wouldn’t ever be a prisoner again, not for a salary.
vi: Every time a snake crawled past her place, we would get a beating. I wasn't afraid of the beatings because they didn't hurt at all. I just dreaded having to catch more snakes. I've never seen a room as lively as Jim's when all those creatures crawled out to listen to the music and gathered around Jim. Jim couldn't even blink in peace; when the snakes slept, the mice would come out, and when the mice went back in, the snakes would come out to stand guard, so there was always a group at his feet and another at his head. When Jim tried to find another place to lie down, the spiders would crawl over. He said if he got out this time, he would never want to be a prisoner again, even if they paid him.
tr: Whenever Aunt Sally saw a snake, we would get a beating; moreover, she said that if we filled the house with snakes again, the beatings would be nothing compared to what she would do. I didn't mind the beatings much because they hardly hurt, but catching another sack of snakes was no easy task. Still, we caught more snakes and completed the others. There was no place as lively as Jim's cabin anymore; all the animals would flock to Jim to listen to music. Jim couldn't warm up to the spiders, and the spiders couldn't warm up to him. They attacked him at every opportunity and made his life miserable. Additionally, Jim complained that there was no place for him to sleep between the mice, snakes, and millstones; even if he managed to squeeze in and lie down, he couldn't sleep because there was constant movement in the bed; since the creatures didn't all sleep at the same time, they took turns using the bed, so while the snakes slept, the mice would be running around; when the mice slept, the snakes would take over. One gang was always under Jim while the other was holding a circus on top of him, and if he tried to find another place to sleep, the spiders would attack him while he walked. He said that if he ever got out, he would never be a prisoner again, even if they paid him.
es: He would give us a beating every time he encountered one of the snakes, and he said that was nothing compared to what he would do to us if we filled the house with them again. The beatings didn't bother me, because they were really nothing, but I did care about how difficult it was for us to find another bunch. But we got them, along with the other critters, and in your life, you have never seen a cabin as lively as Jim's when they all came out to hear the music and approached him. Jim didn't like spiders and the spiders didn't like Jim; so they would wait and then make his life impossible. And he said that between the rats and the snakes and the mill wheel, he hardly had any room left on the cot, and in what little space he had, he couldn't sleep, because it never stopped, and it never stopped because they never all slept at the same time, but took turns, so when the snakes slept, the rats were on guard, and when the rats went to bed, it was the snakes' turn to be on guard, so he always had a bunch of critters underneath him and another bunch making a circus on top, and if he got up to find a new spot, the spiders would pounce on him during the change. He said that if he ever escaped, he would never be a prisoner again, not even if they paid him a salary.

en: Well, by the end of three weeks everything was in pretty good shape. The shirt was sent in early, in a pie, and every time a rat bit Jim he would get up and write a little in his journal whilst the ink was fresh; the pens was made, the inscriptions and so on was all carved on the grindstone; the bed-leg was sawed in two, and we had et up the sawdust, and it give us a most amazing stomach-ache. We reckoned we was all going to die, but didn’t. It was the most undigestible sawdust I ever see; and Tom said the same.
vi: Three weeks later, everything was fine. The shirt had been brought in first, each time a rat bit it, Jim would get up and write a line in the diary; when the ink was still wet, the pen was done, the letters and symbols were engraved on the grindstone; the bed legs had been sawed in half, and we had to eat all the sawdust.
tr: At the end of three weeks, everything had finally fallen into place. The shirt had been sent in the pie ahead of schedule, and Jim would get up and write in his journal while the ink was still fresh every time a rat bit him; the pens were made, the inscription and others were carved on the millstone; we had cut the bed leg in two and eaten the sawdust, after which we were struck with a terrible stomachache. We all thought we were going to die, but nothing happened. In my life, I had never seen sawdust so hard, sitting in one's stomach like a stone; Tom said the same thing.
es: Well, after three weeks everything was in perfect shape. The shirt had arrived right away inside a cake, and every time a rat bit Jim, he would get up and write something in the diary while the ink was fresh; the pens were made, the inscriptions and everything else had already been engraved on the stone; the bed leg was sawed in two and we had eaten the sawdust, which gave us a terrible stomachache. We thought we would all die, but we didn't. It was the most indigestible sawdust I've seen in my life, and Tom said the same.

en: But as I was saying, we’d got all the work done now, at last; and we was all pretty much fagged out, too, but mainly Jim. The old man had wrote a couple of times to the plantation below Orleans to come and get their runaway nigger, but hadn’t got no answer, because there warn’t no such plantation; so he allowed he would advertise Jim in the St. Louis and New Orleans papers; and when he mentioned the St. Louis ones it give me the cold shivers, and I see we hadn’t no time to lose. So Tom said, now for the nonnamous letters.
vi: After finishing that, we had such severe stomachaches that we thought we were going to die. Uncle Silas had written several letters to the plantation down in Orleans to inform them to send someone to take the black man back, but there was no reply, because there was no such plantation down there. Finally, he said he would post a notice about Jim in the St. Louis and Orleans newspapers. When he mentioned St. Louis, it made me shiver all over. At that moment, Tom decided to write an anonymous letter.
tr: But as I said, we had finally finished all the work, and we were all exhausted, but Jim was almost pickled by now. The old man wrote letters several times to the plantation south of Orleans, asking them to come and get their runaway Negro, but received no reply, because there was no such plantation; he then said he would place an ad for Jim in the St. Louis and New Orleans newspapers; when he mentioned the St. Louis newspapers, my hair stood on end, we had no time to lose. Upon this, Tom said it was time for the anonymous letters.
es: But he also said that we had finally finished all the work, even though we were all exhausted, especially Jim. The old man had written twice to the plantation south of Orleans to come and get his runaway black man, but he had received no response, because that plantation didn't exist, so he said he would put an ad about Jim in the Saint Louis and New Orleans newspapers, and when he mentioned the Saint Louis ones, I got chills and saw that we had no time to lose. Tom said it was time for the anonymous letters.

en: “What’s them?” I says.
vi: - What is it?
tr: "Oh really?" I said.
es: —What is that? —I asked.

en: “Warnings to the people that something is up. Sometimes it’s done one way, sometimes another. But there’s always somebody spying around that gives notice to the governor of the castle. When Louis XVI. was going to light out of the Tooleries, a servant-girl done it. It’s a very good way, and so is the nonnamous letters. We’ll use them both. And it’s usual for the prisoner’s mother to change clothes with him, and she stays in, and he slides out in her clothes. We’ll do that, too.”
vi: - I asked. - It's to let people know what's happening. In the past, when Louis XVI planned to escape from prison, there was a maid who did that. Usually, the mother of the prisoner would exchange clothes with her child; the mother would stay behind, while the child would disguise themselves in the mother's clothes to escape. We will do the same.
tr: “Warnings to people that something is going to happen. Some give their warnings this way; some give them that way. But there is always someone who spies and sends a warning to the castle's chief. XVI. When Louis was about to escape from the Tuileries, a maid did this. I think it's a very good method, anonymous letters too. We will use both. Also, it is customary for the prisoner's mother to switch clothes with him; thus the mother stays inside and the prisoner leaves in his mother's clothes. We will do that too.”
es: —Warnings to people that something is going to happen. Sometimes it is done in one way and other times in another. But there is always some spy who warns the governor of the castle. When Louis XVI was going to escape from the Tuileries, it was a maid. That's very good, and anonymous letters too. We will do both things. Normally, the prisoner's mother changes clothes with them and stays inside the castle, and he goes out dressed in the mother's clothes. We are going to do that too.

en: “But looky here, Tom, what do we want to warn anybody for that something’s up? Let them find it out for themselves—it’s their lookout.”
vi: - But we have to inform them. Whoever knows, let them be.
tr: “But Tom, why would we want to warn people that something is going to happen? Let them find out for themselves… after all, they are the ones keeping watch.”
es: —But, listen, Tom, why do we want to warn anyone that something is going to happen? Let them find out on their own, it's their business.

en: “Yes, I know; but you can’t depend on them. It’s the way they’ve acted from the very start—left us to do everything. They’re so confiding and mullet-headed they don’t take notice of nothing at all. So if we don’t give them notice there won’t be nobody nor nothing to interfere with us, and so after all our hard work and trouble this escape ’ll go off perfectly flat; won’t amount to nothing—won’t be nothing to it.”
vi: Whoever knows, let them be. - I know already, but if we don't inform them, then no one and nothing will interfere with us. So all the hard and difficult work has no value, no meaning at all??
tr: “I know that too, but you can't trust them. It has been like this from the very beginning... They left everything for us to do. They are so naive and thick-headed that they don't realize anything. That's why if we don't warn them, there will be no one or nothing to intervene with us, after working so hard and suffering so much, this escape will work perfectly: It will have no meaning... There will be no place left to remember.”
es: —Yes, I already know. But you can't count on them. It's what they've done from the beginning: they've let us do everything ourselves. They are so confident and so oblivious that they don't even notice us. So if we don't warn them, there will be nothing and no one to interfere, and after all the work and all the worry we've put into this escape, it will go off as if nothing happened; it will have no value... It won't draw any attention!

en: “Well, as for me, Tom, that’s the way I’d like.”
vi: - I like it that way.
tr: “If you ask me, this would be the best, Tom.”
es: —Well, as far as I'm concerned, Tom, that's the best thing.

en: “Shucks!” he says, and looked disgusted. So I says:
vi: It looked at me with disdain. - Don't speak anymore, please. I said:
tr: "Oh, come on, you too," he said, grimacing.
es: —Darn! —he exclaimed, with a look of displeasure, so I said to him:

en: “But I ain’t going to make no complaint. Any way that suits you suits me. What you going to do about the servant-girl?”
vi: I don't object, you can do it however you want. So where did you find that maid?
tr: “I'm not complaining,” I said. “If you think it's appropriate, it's fine with me too. But how will you handle the maid issue?”
es: —But I am not going to complain. What you decide is fine with me. Where are we going to find the maid?

en: “You’ll be her. You slide in, in the middle of the night, and hook that yaller girl’s frock.”
vi: - You will be the maid. In the middle of the night, you sneak in and put on that yellow dress.
tr: “You will be the maid. You will sneak in late at night and steal that half-breed girl's dress.”
es: —That's your job. You sneak in the middle of the night and take the dress from that fair-skinned girl.

en: “Why, Tom, that’ll make trouble next morning; because, of course, she prob’bly hain’t got any but that one.”
vi: - That's fine, but if I'm wearing my clothes like this, I can still deliver the letter, can't I?
tr: “But Tom, we'll get into trouble in the morning, the girl probably doesn't have any other clothes.”
es: —But, Tom, then he will have problems in the morning, because he might not have another one.

en: “I know; but you don’t want it but fifteen minutes, to carry the nonnamous letter and shove it under the front door.”
vi: - That's fine, but if I'm wearing my clothes like this, I can still deliver the letter, can't I?
tr: “I know, but you will take the dress for only fifteen minutes; all you have to do is take the anonymous letter and throw it inside under the front door.”
es: —I know, but you only need a quarter of an hour to take the anonymous letter and slip it under the main door.

en: “All right, then, I’ll do it; but I could carry it just as handy in my own togs.”
vi: - That's fine, but if I'm wearing my clothes like this, I can still deliver the letter, can't I?
tr: “Alright then, I'll do it; but I could have carried the letter just fine with my own clothes too.”
es: —Then, very well, agreed; but I could still take her without changing my clothes.

en: “You wouldn’t look like a servant-girl then, would you?”
vi: - In that case, you won't be a close maid anymore.
tr: “But then you won't look like a servant girl, will you?”
es: —Then you wouldn't look like a maid, would you?

en: “No, but there won’t be nobody to see what I look like, anyway.”
vi: - But who is looking at me?
tr: "No, but there won't be anyone to see what I look like anyway."
es: —No, but anyway, no one is going to see what I seem or stop seeming.

en: “That ain’t got nothing to do with it. The thing for us to do is just to do our duty, and not worry about whether anybody sees us do it or not. Hain’t you got no principle at all?”
vi: - It's okay. I'm doing this because it's my duty, not because I worry about whether anyone sees me or not. Don't you understand anything?
tr: “This has nothing to do with the matter. What is important for us is to do our duty and not to care whether others see us or not. Can't you act a bit more principled?”
es: —That has nothing to do with it. What matters is that we fulfill our duty and not worry about whether someone sees us doing it or not. Don't you have any principles?

en: “All right, I ain’t saying nothing; I’m the servant-girl. Who’s Jim’s mother?”
vi: - Alright, I am the maid, so who is Jim's mother? - I am Jim's mother.
tr: “Alright, okay, I didn't say anything; I am a maid. Who is Jim's mother then?”
es: —Very well, I won't say anything; I am the maid. Who is Jim's mother?

en: “I’m his mother. I’ll hook a gown from Aunt Sally.”
vi: - I am Jim's mother. I will wear Aunt Saly's shirt.
tr: "Her mother is me. I will swipe one of Aunt Sally's dresses."
es: —I am the mother. I will put on one of Aunt Sally's dresses.

en: “Well, then, you’ll have to stay in the cabin when me and Jim leaves.”
vi: - Alright, so when Jim and I escape, you have to stay behind in that prison cell.
tr: “Alright, then when Jim and I escape, you will need to stay in the cabin.”
es: —Well, then you'll have to stay in the cabin when Jim and I leave.

en: “Not much. I’ll stuff Jim’s clothes full of straw and lay it on his bed to represent his mother in disguise, and Jim ’ll take the nigger woman’s gown off of me and wear it, and we’ll all evade together. When a prisoner of style escapes it’s called an evasion. It’s always called so when a king escapes, f’rinstance. And the same with a king’s son; it don’t make no difference whether he’s a natural one or an unnatural one.”
vi: - It's not just that. I will stuff straw into Jim's clothes and put it on the bed to pretend to be his mother. Jim will wear Aunt Sally's clothes that I bring, and the three of us will escape together. When a famous prisoner escapes, it's called a jailbreak.
tr: “Not really. I will fill Jim’s clothes with straw and lay them in bed to represent his disguised mother, and Jim will take a woman’s dress from me and wear it, and we will all retreat together. Retreating is what you call the escape of a prisoner with honor. For example, when a king escapes, he retreats. The same applies to the king’s son; whether he is legitimate or illegitimate does not change anything.
es: —Not much time. I will stuff Jim's clothes with straw and leave them on the bed to represent his disguised mother; Jim will take off my dress, put it on, and we will escape together. When a fine prisoner escapes, it is called an evasion. For example, that's what they always say when a king escapes. And the same goes for the son of a king; it doesn't matter if he is a legitimate or illegitimate son.

en: So Tom he wrote the nonnamous letter, and I smouched the yaller wench’s frock that night, and put it on, and shoved it under the front door, the way Tom told me to. It said:
vi: Then Tom wrote an anonymous letter, and that night I put on a woman's yellow dress, took the anonymous letter, and slipped it under the door, just as Tom instructed. The letter says:
tr: Thereupon, Tom wrote the anonymous letter, I stole the mulatto girl's dress, and that night I wore the dress and slipped the letter under the front door as Tom instructed. The letter said:
es: So Tom wrote the anonymous letter and that night I stole the light-colored girl's dress, put it on, and slipped under the front door what Tom had told me. It said:

en: Beware. Trouble is brewing. Keep a sharp lookout. UNKNOWN FRIEND.
vi: Attention: Something big is about to happen. Pay close attention. The anonymous friend.
tr: Attention. Trouble is coming. Keep your eyes wide open. A FRIEND
es: "Careful." "Trouble is approaching." "Stay very alert." "AN UNKNOWN FRIEND"

en: Next night we stuck a picture, which Tom drawed in blood, of a skull and crossbones on the front door; and next night another one of a coffin on the back door. I never see a family in such a sweat. They couldn’t a been worse scared if the place had a been full of ghosts laying for them behind everything and under the beds and shivering through the air. If a door banged, Aunt Sally she jumped and said “ouch!” if anything fell, she jumped and said “ouch!” if you happened to touch her, when she warn’t noticing, she done the same; she couldn’t face noway and be satisfied, because she allowed there was something behind her every time—so she was always a-whirling around sudden, and saying “ouch,” and before she’d got two-thirds around she’d whirl back again, and say it again; and she was afraid to go to bed, but she dasn’t set up. So the thing was working very well, Tom said; he said he never see a thing work more satisfactory. He said it showed it was done right.
vi: The next night, we pasted a picture that Tom drew, with blood, of a human skull with two crossed bones on the front door. And the following night, we pasted another picture on the back door, this time of a coffin. The whole family was terrified. The door slamming shut even startled Aunt Saly. She was too scared to sleep but didn't say anything.
tr: The next night we pasted Tom's drawing of a skull and crossbones made with blood on the front door; the following night we pasted a picture of a coffin on the back door. I had never seen a family so worried before. If the house were haunted, with ghosts jumping out from behind everything, from under the beds, flying in the air, they wouldn't be this scared. If a door slammed, Aunt Sally would jump and scream "Oh!", if something fell, she would immediately jump and scream "Oh!", if you touched her absentmindedly, she would do the same; she couldn't feel at ease no matter which way she turned, because she constantly thought something was behind her – so she frequently spun around suddenly and screamed "Oh!" and before she could settle down, she would turn the other way and scream again; she was afraid to go to bed, but she was also afraid to sit down. So our plan is working very well, said Tom; he said he had never seen a plan work so perfectly. All of this showed how correctly we had done everything.
es: The next night we nailed a drawing of a skull and crossbones that Tom made with blood on the front door, and the following night we nailed another drawing of a coffin on the back door. I had never seen a family so scared. They couldn't have been more frightened even if the house had been filled with ghosts waiting for them behind every piece of furniture and under the beds or floating in the air. If a door slammed, Aunt Sally would jump and say "oh!", and if something fell, she would jump and say "oh!", and when someone touched her before she realized it, she would do the same; she couldn't look to one side and feel satisfied, because she said there was always something behind her, so she spent her time turning around suddenly and saying "oh!", and before she finished turning around, she would twist again and say the same thing, and she was afraid to go to bed, but she didn't dare to stay sitting either. So things were going very well, Tom said; according to him, he had never seen anything go so well. He commented that this showed things were well done.

en: So he said, now for the grand bulge! So the very next morning at the streak of dawn we got another letter ready, and was wondering what we better do with it, because we heard them say at supper they was going to have a nigger on watch at both doors all night. Tom he went down the lightning-rod to spy around; and the nigger at the back door was asleep, and he stuck it in the back of his neck and come back. This letter said:
vi: So the plan was going very well. Early the next morning, just as dawn was breaking, we finished writing another letter and marveled at how clever we were. By dinner time, they said that the black men would stand guard all night at both the front and back doors of the house. Tom slid down the lamp post, pasted the letter on the back of one of the black men, and climbed back up. The letter read as follows:
tr: According to what Tom said, it was time to set off the big bomb! The next morning at dawn, we prepared another letter and started thinking about how to deliver it, because we had heard at dinner that they would station a black man at each door all night. Tom slid down the lightning rod to scout around and, finding the black man at the back door asleep, slipped the letter down his neck and returned. This letter read as follows:
es: So, he said, let's get everything going! So the next morning, just at dawn, we prepared another letter, and we were thinking about the best way to deliver it, because at dinner time we had heard them say that they were going to put a black man on guard at each door all night. Tom went down the lightning rod to see how things were, and since the black man at the back door was asleep, he slipped it into his shirt from behind and came back. The letter said:

en: Don’t betray me, I wish to be your friend. There is a desprate gang of cutthroats from over in the Indian Territory going to steal your runaway nigger to-night, and they have been trying to scare you so as you will stay in the house and not bother them. I am one of the gang, but have got religgion and wish to quit it and lead an honest life again, and will betray the helish design. They will sneak down from northards, along the fence, at midnight exact, with a false key, and go in the nigger’s cabin to get him. I am to be off a piece and blow a tin horn if I see any danger; but stead of that I will BA like a sheep soon as they get in and not blow at all; then whilst they are getting his chains loose, you slip there and lock them in, and can kill them at your leasure. Don’t do anything but just the way I am telling you, if you do they will suspicion something and raise whoop-jamboreehoo. I do not wish any reward but to know I have done the right thing.
vi: "Do not betray me, I want to be your friend. Currently, there is a very dangerous gang of murderers who will steal your runaway black man, and they advise you not to stop them. I am one of them, but I want to leave them and live an honest life, so I want to inform you. They will come down from the North, through the fence, at exactly midnight, carrying a fake key to enter the black man's room and steal him away. I will stand nearby, if I see any danger, I will blow a whistle. When they get close, I will not blow the whistle but will bleat like a sheep.
