Then, while they are unchaining him, you should come and lock them inside and you can kill them however you wish. Do not do anything other than what I have told you above; otherwise, they will suspect something and will howl to call the whole gang to rescue them. I do not ask for any reward, but just know that I have done a righteous deed."
tr: Don't turn me in, I want to be your friend. A bloodthirsty gang from the Indian Territory is going to steal your runaway negro tonight, they were trying to scare you into staying home and not interfering with them. I am also part of the gang, but I am a religious person and I want to leave the gang and live an honest life again, so I decided to inform you of this diabolical plan. At exactly midnight, they will come from the north, jump over the fence, and unlock the negro's cabin with a skeleton key to take him away. I will supposedly stand a bit far away and if I see any danger, I will blow a horn; but actually, I will bleat like a sheep when they get inside and won't blow the horn at all; while they are unchaining the negro, you can quietly approach and lock them all inside, then kill them at a suitable time. Do not disobey my words, if you act on your own, they will suspect something and turn the place into hell. I don't want any reward, all I want is to do the right thing.
es: "Do not betray me, I wish to be your friend. There is a desperate band of murderers from Indian territory who are going to steal your fugitive black man tonight, and they have tried to scare you into staying home and not bothering them. I am from the band, but I have repented and want to leave it and lead an honest life again and I want to betray their infernal plans. They will arrive at exactly midnight from the north, by the fence, with a false key, and will go to the black man's cabin to take him away. I have to stay behind and blow a horn if I see danger, but what I will do is bleat like a sheep as soon as they arrive and not blow the horn; then, while they are removing the chains, you can go and lock them up and kill them whenever you want. Do nothing more than what I tell you; because if not, they will surely suspect something and create a disaster. I do not desire any reward, but to know that I have acted rightly.

en: UNKNOWN FRIEND
vi: The Anonymous Friend
tr: A FRIEND
es: "AN UNKNOWN FRIEND"

en: CHAPTER XL.
vi: chapter xl
tr: Chapter Forty
es: Chapter 40

en: We was feeling pretty good after breakfast, and took my canoe and went over the river a-fishing, with a lunch, and had a good time, and took a look at the raft and found her all right, and got home late to supper, and found them in such a sweat and worry they didn’t know which end they was standing on, and made us go right off to bed the minute we was done supper, and wouldn’t tell us what the trouble was, and never let on a word about the new letter, but didn’t need to, because we knowed as much about it as anybody did, and as soon as we was half up stairs and her back was turned we slid for the cellar cupboard and loaded up a good lunch and took it up to our room and went to bed, and got up about half-past eleven, and Tom put on Aunt Sally’s dress that he stole and was going to start with the lunch, but says:
vi: After breakfast, we felt refreshed and went to the river to pull up the boat and then went fishing, bringing along lunch as well. It wasn't until nearly evening that we returned, finding the whole family very worried. After dinner, they urged us to go to bed, but halfway up the stairs, seeing Aunt Saly had already turned away, we sneaked down to the cupboard to grab some cold food and dollars, brought them back to the room, and went to sleep until one-thirty. Tom wore Aunt Saly's dress that he had just stolen and took the food away. He told me:
tr: After breakfast, we were feeling very good, we took our lunch with us and went fishing on the river with my canoe, we had a great time, we went and checked the raft and saw that it was in good condition, then when we returned late for dinner, we found them anxious and worried, not knowing what to do. Right after dinner, they sent us to our beds and definitely did not tell us what the problem was. The last letter was not mentioned at all, but there was no need for that, because we knew as much as everyone else, after climbing the stairs halfway, when Aunt Sally turned her back, we quietly went to the cupboard in the cellar, took quite a bit of food, went up to our room, and lay in our beds; at half-past eleven, we got up again, Tom immediately put on the dress he had stolen from Aunt Sally and just as he was about to leave with the food, he stopped:
es: AFTER BREAKFAST we felt so good that we took out the canoe to go fishing in the river, with some sandwiches, and we had a lot of fun; we went to where the raft was, saw that it was fine, and got home late for dinner, and we saw them so scared and worried that they didn't even know where to look and made us go to bed as soon as we finished dinner without telling us what was going on, not a word about the new letter, but it wasn't necessary, because we were more informed than anyone, and as soon as we went up half the stairs and Aunt Sally turned around, we went to the basement pantry, took out plenty of food, brought it up to our room, and went to bed. Around eleven-thirty we got up and Tom put on Aunt Sally's dress that he had stolen to go with the food, but he said:

en: “Where’s the butter?”
vi: - Where is the butter?
tr: "Where is the butter?"
es: —Where is the butter?

en: “I laid out a hunk of it,” I says, “on a piece of a corn-pone.”
vi: - I put a big piece into the bread already.
tr: “I had taken a mold,” I said, “I had put it on the cornbread.”
es: —I got a good piece —I said— on a slice of cornbread.

en: “Well, you left it laid out, then—it ain’t here.”
vi: - Why isn't there?
tr: “So, you must have taken it out but didn't put it in the bag,” he said, “because it's not here.”
es: —Well, you left it there; it's not here.

en: “We can get along without it,” I says.
vi: - It's okay without butter.
tr: "We can manage without butter," I said.
es: —We can do without her —I replied.

en: “We can get along with it, too,” he says; “just you slide down cellar and fetch it. And then mosey right down the lightning-rod and come along. I’ll go and stuff the straw into Jim’s clothes to represent his mother in disguise, and be ready to ba like a sheep and shove soon as you get there.”
vi: - You go downstairs and get it. I'll go stuff straw into Jim's clothes to pretend to be his mother, then I'll be ready there to bleat like a sheep. As soon as you arrive, just come right in.
tr: “We would manage better if we had butter,” he said; “all you have to do is go down to the cellar and get it. Then you come down from the lightning rod. Now I'm going to go and stuff Jim's clothes with straw, pretending to be his disguised mother; when you get there, be ready to bleat like a sheep and run away immediately.”
es: —We can also go with her —he said—, so go back to the basement and bring her. Then slide down the lightning rod and come over. I'm going to put the straw in Jim's clothes so he can pretend to be his disguised mother and be ready to bleat like a sheep and take off as soon as you arrive.

en: So out he went, and down cellar went I. The hunk of butter, big as a person’s fist, was where I had left it, so I took up the slab of corn-pone with it on, and blowed out my light, and started up stairs very stealthy, and got up to the main floor all right, but here comes Aunt Sally with a candle, and I clapped the truck in my hat, and clapped my hat on my head, and the next second she see me; and she says:
vi: Then it went out, and I went down to the basement. I took a piece of bread, turned off the light, and sneaked through the lower house. Suddenly, Aunt Saly appeared holding a candle, and I quickly put the piece of bread into my hat and put it on my head. Seeing me, she asked:
tr: So he went outside, and I went down to the cellar. The butter pat, the size of a fist, was still where I had left it. I took it along with the bread underneath, turned off my light, and started to quietly climb the stairs. I reached the ground floor without any issues, but there Aunt Sally suddenly appeared with a candle. I quickly stuffed what I was holding into my hat and put the hat on my head. At that very moment, she saw me:
es: So he left and I went to the basement. The piece of butter, the size of a fist, was where I had left it, so I took the piece of cornbread where I had placed it and went up to the main floor, but Aunt Sally appeared with a candle and I stuffed everything into my hat and put it on my head. When she saw me, she immediately said:

en: “You been down cellar?”
vi: - Did you come up from the basement?
tr: “Had you gone down to the cellar?”
es: —Have you gone down to the basement?

en: “Yes’m.”
vi: - Yes... sir.
tr: “Yes.”
es: —Yes, ma'am.

en: “What you been doing down there?”
vi: - What are you doing down there?
tr: “What were you doing there?”
es: —What were you doing there?

en: “Noth’n.”
vi: - Not doing anything, sir.
tr: "Nothing."
es: —Nothing.

en: “Noth’n!”
vi: - Right?
tr: "Nothing at all, you say!"
es: —Nothing!

en: “No’m.”
vi: - That's correct.
tr: “Yes.”
es: —No, ma'am.

en: “Well, then, what possessed you to go down there this time of night?”
vi: - So what are you going down there for in the middle of the night?
tr: “Alright, what came to your mind at this hour of the night that made you come down, let's see?”
es: —Well, then, what has made you come down at this hour of the night?

en: “I don’t know ’m.”
vi: - Sir ... I don't know.
tr: “I don't know.”
es: —I don't know.

en: “You don’t know? Don’t answer me that way. Tom, I want to know what you been doing down there.”
vi: - Don't know? Don't answer me like that, Tom. I want to know what you were doing down there?
tr: "Don't you know? Don't give me such answers, Tom, I want to know what you're doing down there."
es: —Don't you know? Don't tell me those things, Tom. I want to know what you were doing down there.

en: “I hain’t been doing a single thing, Aunt Sally, I hope to gracious if I have.”
vi: - I didn't do anything, Aunt Saly, I swear.
tr: “I wasn't doing anything, Aunt Sally, I swear, I wasn't doing anything.”
es: —I wasn't doing anything, Aunt Sally. May I die if it's not true.

en: I reckoned she’d let me go now, and as a generl thing she would; but I s’pose there was so many strange things going on she was just in a sweat about every little thing that warn’t yard-stick straight; so she says, very decided:
vi: I thought she would let it go, because she usually did so. But perhaps lately there have been many unusual things happening in the house, so she pays attention to every little thing. She spoke very firmly.
tr: If it were any other time, he would probably let me go, but I guess because there were too many strange things going on, even the slightest thing that didn't seem right was worrying him; so he said with a very determined expression:
es: I figured that now she would let me go, and generally that's what she would have done, but I guess so many strange things were happening that anything that wasn't crystal clear made her nervous, so she goes and says, very determined:

en: “You just march into that setting-room and stay there till I come. You been up to something you no business to, and I lay I’ll find out what it is before I’m done with you.”
vi: - Go into the room and don't wait there. Let me see how things are first, then we'll talk.
tr: "Go straight to the living room and wait until I come." "You definitely did something naughty, and you can't go anywhere until I find out what it is.""
es: —Go into the room and stay there until I come back. You went and did something you shouldn't have, and I bet I'll find out what it was before I'm done with you.

en: So she went away as I opened the door and walked into the setting-room. My, but there was a crowd there! Fifteen farmers, and every one of them had a gun. I was most powerful sick, and slunk to a chair and set down. They was setting around, some of them talking a little, in a low voice, and all of them fidgety and uneasy, but trying to look like they warn’t; but I knowed they was, because they was always taking off their hats, and putting them on, and scratching their heads, and changing their seats, and fumbling with their buttons. I warn’t easy myself, but I didn’t take my hat off, all the same.
vi: - She left, and I opened the door and stepped into the living room. To my surprise, a crowd was in the room. Fifteen people were camping, each holding a gun in their hands. I plopped down. They were whispering to each other, everyone looking annoyed and uncomfortable, but still pretending as if nothing was wrong. But I knew, because I saw them repeatedly taking off and putting on their hats, standing up and sitting down, and fiddling with their coat buttons. I was also impatient, but I didn't take off my hat like they did.
tr: When I opened the door and entered the living room, he moved away. My God, it was so crowded inside! There were fifteen farmers, each holding a rifle. Suddenly, I felt faint and barely managed to collapse into a chair. While sitting and waiting in the room, some were chatting in low voices, all of them were restless and nervous, but they tried to appear otherwise; I could tell their state from the way they kept taking off and putting back on their hats, scratching their heads, changing places, and fiddling with their buttons. I wasn't comfortable either, but I couldn't take off my hat.
es: So he left while I opened the door and entered the room. My God, how many people were there! Fifteen farmers, and each one of them with a weapon. I felt terrible, I let myself fall into a chair and sat down. They were also seated, some talking a little, in low voices, and all of them restless and nervous, trying to pretend they weren't; but I knew they were because they kept taking off their hats and putting them back on, scratching their ears and changing seats and buttoning and unbuttoning. I wasn't calm either, but in any case, I didn't take off my hat.

en: I did wish Aunt Sally would come, and get done with me, and lick me, if she wanted to, and let me get away and tell Tom how we’d overdone this thing, and what a thundering hornet’s-nest we’d got ourselves into, so we could stop fooling around straight off, and clear out with Jim before these rips got out of patience and come for us.
vi: I hope Aunt Sally comes to kick me out so I can run out and tell Tom that we have made too big a deal of it and now we have to run away with Jim before those people get angry and catch us, which would be disastrous.
tr: I wish Aunt Sally had come in right away and finished with me; she could have beaten me if she wanted to, but she should have let me go as soon as possible because I needed to tell Tom how far we had gone and how we had stirred up a hornet's nest. We needed to stop dawdling and get Jim out before these men lost their patience and stormed the cabin.
es: What I felt like was for Aunt Sally to arrive and give me the beating to get it over with, if she wanted, and let me go to tell Tom how we had exaggerated everything and what a mess we had gotten ourselves into, so that we could stop fooling around and take off with Jim before those bumpkins ran out of patience and came after us.

en: At last she come and begun to ask me questions, but I couldn’t answer them straight, I didn’t know which end of me was up; because these men was in such a fidget now that some was wanting to start right now and lay for them desperadoes, and saying it warn’t but a few minutes to midnight; and others was trying to get them to hold on and wait for the sheep-signal; and here was Aunty pegging away at the questions, and me a-shaking all over and ready to sink down in my tracks I was that scared; and the place getting hotter and hotter, and the butter beginning to melt and run down my neck and behind my ears; and pretty soon, when one of them says, “I’m for going and getting in the cabin first and right now, and catching them when they come,” I most dropped; and a streak of butter come a-trickling down my forehead, and Aunt Sally she see it, and turns white as a sheet, and says:
vi: Then a moment later, she came and asked me many questions, but I couldn't answer right away because I didn't know how to respond. But the other person was impatient and wanted to start immediately. They looked like they were going crazy. They said there were only a few minutes left until midnight. A few others said to wait, to listen for the bleat of the sheep as a signal. Meanwhile, Aunt Saly kept pressing me with questions, I was so scared that I started trembling and felt like I was about to collapse. The room was getting hotter by the minute. The butter in my hat began to melt, dripping down past my ears and running down my neck. Suddenly, someone said: - Let me go there first, wait for them to arrive and then catch them. I almost collapsed, a streak of butter running down my forehead. Aunt Saly saw it, her face turned pale, and she exclaimed:
tr: Finally, Aunt Sally arrived and started asking me questions, but I couldn't answer her questions properly; my mind was elsewhere because the men were getting quite restless. Some of them wanted to start immediately and finish off the bandits, saying there were only a few minutes left until midnight; others were trying to hold them back and wait for the sheep to bleat. Meanwhile, Aunt Sally was bombarding me with questions like rain. I started trembling and was scared to death. Meanwhile, the inside of the house was getting warmer and warmer. The butter had started to melt, running down my neck and behind my ears. A little later, when one of the men said, "I say we go to the cabin first, let's go out right now and catch them when we get back," I almost fainted. At that moment, the melted butter started running down my forehead, and when Aunt Sally saw this, she turned as white as a sheet:
es: He finally arrived and started asking me questions, but I couldn't answer them properly and didn't know what to say, because those men were so nervous that some wanted to start immediately and pounce on those bandits, because as they said, there were only a few minutes left until midnight, while others tried to hold them back and wait for the signal; meanwhile, there was Aunt Sally, asking questions non-stop, and I was trembling all over and about to faint from fear, and it was getting hotter and hotter and the butter was starting to melt and run down my neck and behind my ears, until one of them goes and says: —I am about to go to the cabin immediately and catch them there when they arrive. I almost fainted and a stream of butter dripped down my forehead. When Aunt Sally saw it, she turned as white as a sheet, and she goes and says:

en: “For the land’s sake, what is the matter with the child? He’s got the brain-fever as shore as you’re born, and they’re oozing out!”
vi: -Oh my God, what's wrong with the boy? It looks like he has meningitis, his brain is leaking out here.
tr: “For God's sake, what happened to this child! I'm sure he had brain fever, moreover, his brain started to ooze!”
es: —For heaven's sake, what's wrong with this boy? He surely has brain fever and his brains are coming out!

en: And everybody runs to see, and she snatches off my hat, and out comes the bread and what was left of the butter, and she grabbed me, and hugged me, and says:
vi: Everyone ran over to see. She lifted the hat off my head, the piece of cake fell down, and the remaining butter stuck to my head; then she grabbed me and shook me while saying:
tr: Everyone came running, and when Aunt Sally took off my hat, the rest of the bread and butter fell with a plop. When Aunt Sally saw this, she hugged me and said:
es: Everyone came running to see what was happening, she took off my hat and with it came out the bread and what was left of the butter; then she hugged me, saying: —You gave me such a scare! And I'm so glad it's nothing worse, because we have nothing but problems, and misfortunes never come alone, and when I saw that I thought you were going to die, because I imagined from the color that it was as if your brains were going to...

en: “Oh, what a turn you did give me! and how glad and grateful I am it ain’t no worse; for luck’s against us, and it never rains but it pours, and when I see that truck I thought we’d lost you, for I knowed by the color and all it was just like your brains would be if—Dear, dear, whyd’nt you tell me that was what you’d been down there for, I wouldn’t a cared. Now cler out to bed, and don’t lemme see no more of you till morning!”
vi: - Oh, you scared me. It's really fortunate that it's not as bad as I thought. Why didn't you tell me right away to stop me from worrying? Now go to sleep, don't show your face here again from now until morning.
tr: “Ah, how you scared me! I am so glad that nothing bad happened, thank God; we have a terrible misfortune over our heads these days. When I saw what was oozing from your forehead, I almost died of fright, because when I saw its color and consistency, it seemed to me that your brain was leaking... My dear, why didn't you tell me why you went down to the basement, I wouldn't have been angry with you. Now go to your bed, I don't want to see you around here again until morning!”
es: My God, my God, why didn't you tell me what you had gone down to get? I wouldn't have minded. Now go to bed and don't let me see you again until tomorrow!

en: I was up stairs in a second, and down the lightning-rod in another one, and shinning through the dark for the lean-to. I couldn’t hardly get my words out, I was so anxious; but I told Tom as quick as I could we must jump for it now, and not a minute to lose—the house full of men, yonder, with guns!
vi: In just a second, I jumped upstairs, slid down the black pole, and slipped into the darkness heading towards the porch. I was so worried that I couldn't say anything more. But I quickly told Tom that he had to get out immediately, not to delay even a minute, as the house was full of people, and they were carrying guns.
tr: In one second, I reached the stairs, in the next, I slid down the lightning rod and quickly reached the shed in the dark. I was so anxious that words barely came out of my mouth, but I quickly explained everything to Tom as best as I could; we had to leave immediately, there wasn't a minute to lose... The house was filled with men, all of them armed with rifles!
es: I went up the stairs in a second, went down the lightning rod in another, and searched for the shed in the middle of the darkness. I could barely speak because I was so worried, but I told Tom as quickly as I could that we had to get out without wasting a minute: the house was full of armed men!

en: His eyes just blazed; and he says:
vi: Its face lit up, it asked:
tr: Tom's eyes sparkled.
es: His eyes shone brightly, and he goes and says:

en: “No!—is that so? Ain’t it bully! Why, Huck, if it was to do over again, I bet I could fetch two hundred! If we could put it off till—”
vi: - Oh, really? Huck, if we perform this trick again, I think we could draw up to two hundred people. How about we postpone until... I interrupted it:
tr: “No way!.. Really? Isn't it amazing? If I had the chance to do it again, I could bring two hundred men, Huck! Actually, if I waited a bit longer...”
es: —No! Really? Man, Huck, if we had to do it again, we would surely bring two hundred! If we could postpone it...

en: “Hurry! hurry!” I says. “Where’s Jim?”
vi: - We have to go right away. Where is Jim?
tr: "Hurry up!" "Hurry! I said." "Where is Jim?""
es: —Quick! Quick! —I replied—. Where is Jim?

en: “Right at your elbow; if you reach out your arm you can touch him. He’s dressed, and everything’s ready. Now we’ll slide out and give the sheep-signal.”
vi: - Next to you, just reach out and you'll touch it. Jim has finished putting on his clothes. Now let's sneak outside and signal.
tr: "Right behind your elbow, if you extend your arm, you can touch it. She put on her dress, everything is ready. Now let's go outside and you can bleat like a sheep."
es: —Right there next to you; if you stretch out your arm, you can touch it. He's already dressed and everything else is ready. We can go and give the signal of the bleat.

en: But then we heard the tramp of men coming to the door, and heard them begin to fumble with the pad-lock, and heard a man say:
vi: At that moment, we heard the sound of everyone's footsteps thundering, then the sound of a lock being opened, and someone said:
tr: But at that moment, we heard the men approaching the door, and while they were trying to open the padlock by feel, we heard a man speaking:
es: But then we heard the footsteps of the men approaching the door and the noise they made when opening the padlock, and one of them said:

en: “I told you we’d be too soon; they haven’t come—the door is locked. Here, I’ll lock some of you into the cabin, and you lay for ’em in the dark and kill ’em when they come; and the rest scatter around a piece, and listen if you can hear ’em coming.”
vi: - I said it was still too early; they haven't arrived yet, the door is still locked. A few people went inside to hide in the dark, ready to kill them as soon as they arrived, while the others spread out a bit and listened carefully.
tr: “I told you we came early; they haven't arrived yet… the door is still locked. Some of you will be locked inside the cabin and will wait in the dark to kill them when they arrive; the rest should spread out and stay alert.”
es: —I told you it was too early; they haven't arrived: the door is closed. Come on, some of you go to the cabin, wait for them in the dark, and kill them when they arrive, and the rest of you spread out and pay attention to hear them coming.

en: So in they come, but couldn’t see us in the dark, and most trod on us whilst we was hustling to get under the bed. But we got under all right, and out through the hole, swift but soft—Jim first, me next, and Tom last, which was according to Tom’s orders. Now we was in the lean-to, and heard trampings close by outside. So we crept to the door, and Tom stopped us there and put his eye to the crack, but couldn’t make out nothing, it was so dark; and whispered and said he would listen for the steps to get further, and when he nudged us Jim must glide out first, and him last. So he set his ear to the crack and listened, and listened, and listened, and the steps a-scraping around out there all the time; and at last he nudged us, and we slid out, and stooped down, not breathing, and not making the least noise, and slipped stealthy towards the fence in Injun file, and got to it all right, and me and Jim over it; but Tom’s britches catched fast on a splinter on the top rail, and then he hear the steps coming, so he had to pull loose, which snapped the splinter and made a noise; and as he dropped in our tracks and started somebody sings out:
vi: They stepped in, but in the darkness, they couldn't see us. They almost stepped on us while we were crawling under the bed. But we managed to crawl through and quietly slipped out. Jim went out first, then me. Tom went out last. That was according to Tom's orders. We crawled towards the door, Tom told us to stop and look through the crack of the door first, but it was too dark to see anything. He nudged Jim with his elbow to signal him to crawl forward. He went last. He then pressed his ear against the crack to listen, still hearing footsteps rustling outside. After that, he nudged us, and we crawled stealthily, holding our breath, without making a sound, and continued towards the fence like the Indians. Jim and I climbed over, but Tom got his clothes caught on the top of the post and was stuck there for a while. Suddenly, hearing footsteps approaching, he had to yank hard, breaking the post with a loud snap. He just managed to run after us when a voice shouted:
tr: They entered, but they couldn't see us in the dark. They almost stepped on us as we scrambled under the bed. But we got under the bed without anything happening to us, quickly crawled out through the hole – according to Tom's orders, Jim went first, then me, and finally Tom. Now we were inside the storeroom, and we could hear people moving around outside. We crawled towards the door, Tom stopped us and peered through a crack to look outside, but he couldn't see anything, it was too dark; then he turned to us and whispered that he would wait for the footsteps to fade away; when he gave the signal, Jim would go first, and he would go last. This time he put his ear to the crack and listened, listened, listened, but there were always people walking outside; finally, he gave us the signal and we quietly slipped out, not even breathing, moving stealthily towards the fences. We moved in a single file and reached the fence, Jim and I climbed over it, but Tom's pants got caught on a splinter at the top of the fence at the last moment, and we heard someone approaching; then Tom forced the pants and the splinter snapped with a crack; as he started following us, we heard someone shout:
es: So they came in, but in the darkness they couldn't see us and almost all of them stepped on us while we tried to get under the bed. But we managed to get in there and out through the hole, quickly but without making any noise. Jim first, then me, and Tom last, which was what Tom had ordered. We were already in the shed and we heard the footsteps of those walking nearby. So we crawled to the door and Tom stopped us there and started looking through the crack, but he couldn't see anything because it was so dark, and he whispered to us that he would listen until the footsteps moved further away, and when he nudged us, Jim had to go out first and he would go last. So he put his ear to the crack and listened, listened, and listened, and the footsteps kept circling nearby all the time; finally, he nudged us and we left bent over, without breathing or making the slightest noise, sneaking in single file towards the fence until we got there and Jim and I jumped over it; but Tom got his pants caught on a splinter in the top log, so he had to pull to free himself, causing the splinter to break and make a noise, and when he dropped down to follow us, someone shouted:

en: “Who’s that? Answer, or I’ll shoot!”
vi: - Who's there? Answer quickly, or I'll shoot!
tr: “Who is there? Answer; otherwise, I will shoot!”
es: —Who goes there? Answer or I'll shoot!

en: But we didn’t answer; we just unfurled our heels and shoved. Then there was a rush, and a bang, bang, bang! and the bullets fairly whizzed around us! We heard them sing out:
vi: We didn't answer, just kept our heads down and ran. A group of people rushed over. Bang, bang, bang! Bullets whizzed around us. They shouted:
tr: But we did not answer, instead, we spread our compasses and started to run away quickly. There was a commotion behind us, bam, bam, bam! and bullets whizzed around us! One of them was heard shouting:
es: But we didn't respond; we stood up and started running. Then we heard some running and a bang, bang, bang!, and how the bullets whistled! We heard them shout:

en: “Here they are! They’ve broke for the river! After ’em, boys, and turn loose the dogs!”
vi: - Here they are! They're running to the riverbank! Brothers, chase after them. Release them quickly!
tr: “There they are! They are heading towards the river! Follow them, gentlemen! Release the dogs!”
es: —There they are! They're going to the river! Let's follow them, boys, and release the dogs!

en: So here they come, full tilt. We could hear them because they wore boots and yelled, but we didn’t wear no boots and didn’t yell. We was in the path to the mill; and when they got pretty close on to us we dodged into the bush and let them go by, and then dropped in behind them. They’d had all the dogs shut up, so they wouldn’t scare off the robbers; but by this time somebody had let them loose, and here they come, making powwow enough for a million; but they was our dogs; so we stopped in our tracks till they catched up; and when they see it warn’t nobody but us, and no excitement to offer them, they only just said howdy, and tore right ahead towards the shouting and clattering; and then we up-steam again, and whizzed along after them till we was nearly to the mill, and then struck up through the bush to where my canoe was tied, and hopped in and pulled for dear life towards the middle of the river, but didn’t make no more noise than we was obleeged to. Then we struck out, easy and comfortable, for the island where my raft was; and we could hear them yelling and barking at each other all up and down the bank, till we was so far away the sounds got dim and died out. And when we stepped onto the raft I says:
vi: They rushed in. We could hear them clearly because they wore boots and shouted, while we neither wore boots nor shouted. We turned onto the small path leading to the workshop. When they ran close behind us, we stepped aside and hid in the bushes to let them pass, then stepped out and ran behind them. The dogs came running, barking loudly as if there were a million of them. We stood still, waiting for the dogs to reach us. They were all domestic dogs, so when they saw us, they wagged their tails happily and then ran ahead following the people who were rummaging and shouting. Then we turned back up towards the river, whistling casually behind them; we walked near the workshop and then turned into the bushes where my boat was tied. We all jumped into the boat and rowed to the middle of the river, trying not to make too much noise. So we rowed away, gently and comfortably, heading towards the island where I had hidden the raft. We could still hear people shouting and dogs barking along the riverbank. It wasn't until we had gone far that those sounds gradually faded and disappeared completely. Once on the raft, I said:
tr: They were all coming after us at once. We could hear them because they had boots on and were shouting, but we didn't have boots, and we weren't shouting. We were on the road to the mill, and when they got close enough, we dove into the bushes and waited for them to pass, then continued on the road behind them. They had silenced the dogs so they wouldn't scare off the robbers, but now someone had let them loose, and here they were coming, barking madly, but they were our dogs; so we waited for them to catch up to us, and when they saw us, all their excitement died down; after a few murmurs, they continued barking and running towards the shouting ahead; we started running after them and almost reached the mill, at one point diving into the bushes and getting to where my canoe was tied, we got into the canoe and started paddling towards the middle of the river with all our might, but we were definitely not making more noise than necessary. We proceeded comfortably towards the island where my raft was hidden; we could hear those behind us shouting and barking on the shore, but then we got quite far away and the sounds gradually faded. When we got onto the raft, I said:
es: So they started running at full speed. We could hear them well because they were wearing boots and shouting, but we neither wore boots nor shouted. We were heading towards the mill, and when they got very close, we hid among the bushes, let them pass, and then got behind them. They had kept the dogs very quiet so as not to scare the thieves, but now they had let them loose and they were making so much noise it was as if there were a million of them, but they were ours, so we stopped until they reached us, and when they saw that it was just us and that we offered no adventure, they simply greeted us and ran off towards where the noises and shouts were coming from, and we went back up towards the river, running behind them until we almost reached the mill and then we came out from the bushes where my canoe was tied, got into it and started rowing like mad towards the middle of the river, making no more noise than necessary. Then we calmly set the bow towards the island where my raft was and heard them shouting and barking at each other up the riverbank, until we were so far that the noises faded and disappeared. When we reached the raft, I went and said:

en: “Now, old Jim, you’re a free man again, and I bet you won’t ever be a slave no more.”
vi: - Jim, you are free now, and you will probably never have to be a slave again.
tr: "Now you are a free man again, big Jim, and you will never be a slave to anyone again."
es: —Now, old Jim, you are free again, and I bet you will never be a slave again.

en: “En a mighty good job it wuz, too, Huck. It ’uz planned beautiful, en it ’uz done beautiful; en dey ain’t nobody kin git up a plan dat’s mo’ mixed-up en splendid den what dat one wuz.”
vi: We were all very delighted.
tr: "You did a very good job, Huck. It was a very nice plan, everything went very well; no one else could come up with such a complex and real plan."
es: —And you did very well, Huck; it was very well planned and very well executed, and there is no one in the world who can make a plan as complicated and splendid as this one.

en: We was all glad as we could be, but Tom was the gladdest of all because he had a bullet in the calf of his leg.
vi: But Tom was the most delighted because he got a bullet in his calf.
tr: We were all very content with our situation, but the most content among us was Tom, because he had taken a bullet to his calf.
es: We were all very happy, but Tom was the happiest of all because he had been shot in the calf.

en: When me and Jim heard that we didn’t feel so brash as what we did before. It was hurting him considerable, and bleeding; so we laid him in the wigwam and tore up one of the duke’s shirts for to bandage him, but he says:
vi: Jim and I heard it and couldn't be happy anymore. The wound hurt him a lot, and there was a lot of blood. We put him in the tent and tore one of the duke's shirts that was left there to bandage him. But he said:
tr: When Jim and I heard this, the joy we felt for being saved was short-lived. He was in a lot of pain and was bleeding; we laid him inside the shelter and tore one of the duke's shirts to bandage his wound.
es: When Jim and I found out, we didn't feel as happy as before. It hurt him a lot and he was bleeding, so we laid him down in the wigwam and tore one of the duke's shirts to bandage him, but he goes and says:

en: “Gimme the rags; I can do it myself. Don’t stop now; don’t fool around here, and the evasion booming along so handsome; man the sweeps, and set her loose! Boys, we done it elegant!—’deed we did. I wish we’d a had the handling of Louis XVI., there wouldn’t a been no ‘Son of Saint Louis, ascend to heaven!’ wrote down in his biography; no, sir, we’d a whooped him over the border—that’s what we’d a done with him—and done it just as slick as nothing at all, too. Man the sweeps—man the sweeps!”
vi: - Let me do it. Don't stop here, that's the only way the escape will succeed. Let the raft go! We did it very skillfully, truly skillfully. I think we have the talent of Louis the Sixteenth, no, we have surpassed that. We did it as easily as playing. Alright, let's go, hurry up.
tr: “Give me the cloths, I can do it myself,” he said. “Don’t stop; there’s no point in lingering here any longer, this retreat news will echo everywhere soon; to the helm, untie the rope! We did a very neat job, kids!.. It was really very neat. XVI. If only they had given us the responsibility for Louis XVI’s escape, his biography wouldn’t say, “The son of Saint Louis ascended to heaven!”; no, sir, we would have whisked him across the border in no time… that’s how we would have made him retreat… as easily as pulling a hair out of butter. To the helm… To the helm!”
es: —Give me those strips; I can do it myself. Now don't stop, don't stay around here, with an escape going so well. To the oars and let's go! Boys, it turned out great! Really, it did. I wish we had been in charge of Louis XVI's escape, and then in his biography they wouldn't have written that "Son of Saint Louis, ascend to heaven"; no, sir; we would have made him cross the border, that's what we would have done with him and with great ease: to the oars... to the oars!

en: But me and Jim was consulting—and thinking. And after we’d thought a minute, I says:
vi: Jim and I looked at each other thoughtfully. A minute later, I said
tr: But Jim and I were talking on one hand and thinking on the other. “Tell me, Jim,” I said after about a minute.
es: But Jim and I were consulting each other, and thinking, and after a minute or so I go and say:

en: “Say it, Jim.”
vi: - Jim, speak up!
tr: “Tell me, Jim,” I said after about a minute.
es: —You say it, Jim.

en: So he says:
vi: Jim said:
tr: He started to speak:
es: And he says:

en: “Well, den, dis is de way it look to me, Huck. Ef it wuz him dat ’uz bein’ sot free, en one er de boys wuz to git shot, would he say, ‘Go on en save me, nemmine ’bout a doctor f’r to save dis one?’ Is dat like Mars Tom Sawyer? Would he say dat? You bet he wouldn’t! Well, den, is Jim gywne to say it? No, sah—I doan’ budge a step out’n dis place ’dout a doctor; not if it’s forty year!”
vi: - I think this way, Huck. Suppose you were the one being rescued, and one of your rescuers got injured, would you have the heart to leave that injured person to wait for death? Probably not! And Jim wouldn't do that either. If there is no doctor, Jim definitely won't leave this place even if he has to wait for forty more years. I, Jim, am speaking very sincerely. I told Tom to let me go find a doctor.
tr: “Let me tell you this from my own perspective, Huck. If we had caught Tom and someone got hurt, wouldn't we have said, 'Don't waste time trying to catch me, go find a doctor'? Is this something Master Tom Sawyer would say? Would he say such a thing? He would never say that! Well then, would Jim say such a thing? No, master... if a doctor isn't found, I won't take a step from here, even if it takes forty years!”
es: —Well, this is what it seems to me, Huck: if it were him we were freeing and one of the boys got shot, would he say: "Go ahead, save me and don't think about a doctor to save that other one"? Would Tom Sawyer do that? Would he say that? You can bet he wouldn't! Well then, are you going to say it, Jim? No, sir, I won't take a step out of here without a doctor; even if it takes forty years.

en: I knowed he was white inside, and I reckoned he’d say what he did say—so it was all right now, and I told Tom I was a-going for a doctor. He raised considerable row about it, but me and Jim stuck to it and wouldn’t budge; so he was for crawling out and setting the raft loose himself; but we wouldn’t let him. Then he give us a piece of his mind, but it didn’t do no good.
vi: I told Tom to let me go find a doctor. He insisted on not listening; but Jim and I also wouldn't give in. He tried to crawl out from the raft's side, but we didn't let him do that either. He grumbled for a while, then stopped.
tr: I knew deep down that he was white and I had predicted that he would say so – in this situation, there was nothing to be done, so I told Tom that I would go and bring a doctor. He objected a lot, yelled and screamed, but Jim and I absolutely did not change our minds; upon this, he tried to crawl and untie the raft, but we did not allow that either. He tried to give us advice – but that didn’t work either.
es: I already knew that inside he was white and I figured he was going to say what he had said, so now everything was fine and I told Tom that I was going to look for a doctor. He started to make a fuss, but Jim and I stood firm and didn't want to give in; so he said he would get off and untie the raft by himself; but we didn't let him. Then he scolded us, but it was to no avail.

en: So when he sees me getting the canoe ready, he says:
vi: Seeing that I had prepared the room, it said:
tr: When he saw that I was preparing the tea, he called out from where he was lying:
es: So when he saw me preparing the canoe, he said:

en: “Well, then, if you’re bound to go, I’ll tell you the way to do when you get to the village. Shut the door and blindfold the doctor tight and fast, and make him swear to be silent as the grave, and put a purse full of gold in his hand, and then take and lead him all around the back alleys and everywheres in the dark, and then fetch him here in the canoe, in a roundabout way amongst the islands, and search him and take his chalk away from him, and don’t give it back to him till you get him back to the village, or else he will chalk this raft so he can find it again. It’s the way they all do.”
vi: - Fine, if you are determined to go, I will tell you what needs to be done when you enter the village. You close the door, blindfold the doctor, and tie him up tightly. Tell him he must remain silent, then place a bundle of gold in his hand, take him through all the shortcuts and alleys in the dark, then lead him down to the boat and take a round trip around the islands. You must search all his pockets, not letting him keep a single piece of chalk, otherwise he will use the chalk to mark this raft and later find his way back. I promise to do exactly that, while Jim must hide in the forest until he sees the doctor come and leave the raft before returning.
tr: “Since you say you will go, let me tell you what to do when you reach the town. When you enter, close the door and immediately blindfold the doctor, then make him swear to take our secret to the grave and leave a pouch of gold in his hand, then take him down to the shore through dark back alleys and deserted roads, put him in a canoe and bring him here by navigating through the islands, search him and if he has chalk in his pocket, take it, and do not give it back until you take him back to the town, otherwise he will mark this raft with chalk to find it later. They always do this.”
es: —Well, then, if you have to go, I'm going to tell you what you should do when you get to the village. You close the door and blindfold the doctor very well and make him swear that his lips are sealed; you give him a bag full of gold coins and then take him out and lead him around all the alleys in the dark. Then you bring him here in the canoe, turning between the islands, search him and take the chalk away from him and don't give it back until he has returned to the village, because if not, he will mark the raft with chalk to find it again. That's what everyone does.

en: So I said I would, and left, and Jim was to hide in the woods when he see the doctor coming till he was gone again.
vi: I promise to do exactly that, while Jim must hide in the forest until he sees the doctor come and leave the raft before returning.
tr: I walked away, saying I would do exactly as told, and Jim would hide among the trees when he saw the doctor coming, then reappear once he left.
es: So we told him we would do it and left, and Jim had to hide in the forest when he saw the doctor coming until he left again.

en: CHAPTER XLI.
vi: Chapter XLI
tr: Chapter Forty-One
es: Chapter 41

en: The doctor was an old man; a very nice, kind-looking old man when I got him up. I told him me and my brother was over on Spanish Island hunting yesterday afternoon, and camped on a piece of a raft we found, and about midnight he must a kicked his gun in his dreams, for it went off and shot him in the leg, and we wanted him to go over there and fix it and not say nothing about it, nor let anybody know, because we wanted to come home this evening and surprise the folks.
vi: The doctor is an elderly person and seems kind. I woke him up and told him that my brother and I were on the Spanish island hunting since yesterday afternoon on a raft. In the middle of the night, unfortunately, I accidentally pulled the trigger while dreaming. The gun went off and hit my leg. So I invited the doctor to come and treat it, and not to say anything about this, not to let anyone know, because tonight we want to return home and surprise our family.
tr: The doctor was an old man; more precisely, he was an extremely polite and chubby old man when I woke him up. I told him that my brother and I had set up camp on a raft we found while hunting on Spanish Island yesterday afternoon, that he had kicked his rifle in his sleep at midnight, and that the rifle had gone off and shot him in the leg; we wanted him to come and treat my brother and not tell anyone, because we intended to return home this evening and surprise our folks.
es: THE DOCTOR WAS OLD; a very nice and kind old man. When I woke him up, I told him that my brother and I were on Española Island hunting yesterday afternoon and had camped on a piece of raft we found, but that, around midnight, I must have hit the shotgun while dreaming, because it went off and hit him in the leg. We wanted him to go treat it without saying anything or telling anyone, because we intended to go home that afternoon to surprise the family.

en: “Who is your folks?” he says.
vi: He asked: - Who are your family members?
tr: "Who are your people?" he asked.
es: —What family are you from? —he asks.

en: “The Phelpses, down yonder.”
vi: - The Phelps house, down there.
tr: “The Phelpses who live down there.”
es: —From the Phelps family, down the river.

en: “Oh,” he says. And after a minute, he says:
vi: - Ah, I see. Later, he asked again:
tr: “Haa,” he said. A minute later, he asked, “How did you say he was shot?”
es: —Ah —he says, and after a minute he repeats—:

en: “How’d you say he got shot?”
vi: - How did you say your friend got injured?
tr: A minute later, he asked, “How did you say he was shot?”
es: How did you say he shot himself?

en: “He had a dream,” I says, “and it shot him.”
vi: - He was sleepwalking and then got shot.
tr: “He kicked in his dream,” I said, “and the rifle went off.”
es: —He had a dream and shot himself —I replied to him.

en: “Singular dream,” he says.
vi: - Strange!
tr: “So, in his dream,” he said.
es: —Strange dream —he commented.

en: So he lit up his lantern, and got his saddle-bags, and we started. But when he sees the canoe he didn’t like the look of her—said she was big enough for one, but didn’t look pretty safe for two. I says:
vi: Then the doctor lit the lamp, grabbed his medicine bag, and went out. But when he saw the boat, he didn't like it, saying that it was too small, just enough for one person, and not safe for two people. I said:
tr: He lit his lantern, took his bag, and we set off. But when he saw the canoe, his face fell – he said that the canoe would be enough for one person, but it didn't look very safe for two. "You have nothing to worry about, sir, it carried the three of us comfortably," I said.
es: So he lit the lantern, grabbed the first aid kit, and we set off. But when he saw the canoe, he didn't like it; he said it was fine for one person, but it didn't seem safe for two. And I go and say:

en: “Oh, you needn’t be afeard, sir, she carried the three of us easy enough.”
vi: - Don't worry, sir, the three of us are still sitting comfortably.
tr: "You have nothing to worry about, sir, it carried the three of us comfortably," I said.
es: —Ah, don't be afraid, sir, he took all three of us with ease.

en: “What three?”
vi: - Why are there three people?
tr: “Three?”
es: —What three?

en: “Why, me and Sid, and—and—and the guns; that’s what I mean.”
vi: - Me, Sid, and... and... the gun makes three.
tr: “Ben, Sid and… and… rifles; I meant rifles.”
es: —Well, for me and Sid... and... and the shotguns; that's what I meant to say.

en: “Oh,” he says.
vi: - Oh, really?
tr: “Haa,” he said.
es: —Ah.

en: But he put his foot on the gunnel and rocked her, and shook his head, and said he reckoned he’d look around for a bigger one. But they was all locked and chained; so he took my canoe, and said for me to wait till he come back, or I could hunt around further, or maybe I better go down home and get them ready for the surprise if I wanted to. But I said I didn’t; so I told him just how to find the raft, and then he started.
vi: He stepped onto the side of the boat, tested it, then shook his head and said he would have to find a bigger boat, but all the boats were chained and locked. So he climbed back into my boat and told me to wait for him to return.
tr: But she put her foot on the gunwale and gave the canoe a little test; shaking her head, she said we needed to find a bigger one. However, all the canoes were locked and chained; so she took my canoe and told me to wait until she returned, suggesting that I could either fish a bit more or go home and prepare our folks for a surprise. But I said I wouldn't go anywhere, described to her how to find the raft, and she set off.
es: But he put his foot on the gunwale and made it move, shook his head, and said he would look for a bigger one. But they were all chained and locked, so he got into my canoe and said to wait until he came back, or that if I couldn't keep looking, or maybe it would be better to go home and prepare the family for the surprise, if that's what I wanted. But I told him no, so I explained how to find the raft and he set off.

en: I struck an idea pretty soon. I says to myself, spos’n he can’t fix that leg just in three shakes of a sheep’s tail, as the saying is? spos’n it takes him three or four days? What are we going to do?—lay around there till he lets the cat out of the bag? No, sir; I know what I’ll do. I’ll wait, and when he comes back if he says he’s got to go any more I’ll get down there, too, if I swim; and we’ll take and tie him, and keep him, and shove out down the river; and when Tom’s done with him we’ll give him what it’s worth, or all we got, and then let him get ashore.
vi: I suddenly had an idea. I told myself: what if he can't cure Tom's leg right away? What if it takes three or four days to heal? What would we do? Wait there until he finishes? What should I do then? I will wait, and whenever he comes back, if he says he won't go anymore, I will go down there, swim down if necessary, we will capture and tie him up, then take him down there, and after he finishes treating Tom, we will reward him with everything we have. Then we will let him go ashore.
tr: Before long, I started to have second thoughts. What if Tom couldn't finish treating his leg in one go, what if it took three or four days? What would we do then? Were we supposed to wait until the doctor raised a fuss? No sir, I knew exactly what I was going to do. I would wait, and if he said he needed to come back when he arrived, I would swim after him the second time; then I would trick him, tie him up, and we would take the raft and set off; once Tom was done with him, we would pay him whatever he asked, even give him everything we had in our pockets, and leave him on the shore.
es: Then an idea occurred to me. I said to myself: "What if he can't fix his leg in a jiffy, as the saying goes? What if it takes him three or four days? What are we going to do? Wait around until he tells someone? No, sir; I know what I'm going to do. I'll wait, and when he comes back, if he says he has to return, I'll go with him even if I have to swim, we'll tie him up and take him down the river, and when Tom is healed we'll pay him whatever it takes, or everything we have, and then we'll let him disembark."

en: So then I crept into a lumber-pile to get some sleep; and next time I waked up the sun was away up over my head! I shot out and went for the doctor’s house, but they told me he’d gone away in the night some time or other, and warn’t back yet. Well, thinks I, that looks powerful bad for Tom, and I’ll dig out for the island right off. So away I shoved, and turned the corner, and nearly rammed my head into Uncle Silas’s stomach! He says:
vi: Then I lay back on the pile of wood nearby to take a quick nap. When I woke up, I saw the sun was directly overhead. I jumped up and ran straight to the doctor's house, but they said the doctor had left the night before and hadn't returned yet. I thought to myself, this is really bad for Tom. I have to go to the island right away. I turned around, and at the corner of the road, I bumped right into Uncle Silas's stomach. He asked:
tr: So, I leaned my back against a pile of wood and fell asleep; when I woke up, the sun had already risen! I immediately rushed to the doctor's house, but they told me he had gone to see a patient at night and hadn't returned yet. That means Tom's condition is very bad, I thought, so I should go to the island immediately. I set off right away and turned the corner, but I almost headbutted Uncle Silas in the stomach! “Tom!
es: So I got into a pile of firewood to sleep a bit, and when I woke up, the sun was already quite high. I ran to the doctor's house but they told me he had left at night and hadn't come back yet. “Well,” I thought, “it seems like Tom is doing poorly, so I'm heading straight to the island.” And I set off, but when I turned the corner, I almost ran straight into Uncle Silas. He goes and says:

en: “Why, Tom! Where you been all this time, you rascal?”
vi: - Oh, Tom, where have you been all this time?
tr: “Tom! Where have you been for hours, you rascal?” he said.
es: —Hey, Tom! Where have you been all this time, rascal?

en: “I hain’t been nowheres,” I says, “only just hunting for the runaway nigger—me and Sid.”
vi: - I'm not going anywhere, Sid and I are chasing the runaway black man.
tr: “I was nowhere,” I said, “I was just after that runaway black man... me and Sid.”
es: —I haven't been anywhere —I said—, except hunting the runaway black man with Sid.

en: “Why, where ever did you go?” he says. “Your aunt’s been mighty uneasy.”
vi: - Where have you been? Your aunt is worried sick about you.
tr: "So where did you go?" he asked. "Your aunt was almost going to lose her mind."
es: —Well, where have you been? —he asks—. Your aunt was worried.

en: “She needn’t,” I says, “because we was all right. We followed the men and the dogs, but they outrun us, and we lost them; but we thought we heard them on the water, so we got a canoe and took out after them and crossed over, but couldn’t find nothing of them; so we cruised along up-shore till we got kind of tired and beat out; and tied up the canoe and went to sleep, and never waked up till about an hour ago; then we paddled over here to hear the news, and Sid’s at the post-office to see what he can hear, and I’m a-branching out to get something to eat for us, and then we’re going home.”
vi: I replied - Auntie, don't worry, we're fine. We ran after the people with the dogs, but they ran too fast, and we got lost. Then we thought we heard them by the river, so we took the boat to chase them and crossed to the other side of the river, but we still couldn't find them. Then we went ashore to rest, we were so tired, we tied the boat and took a nap, we just woke up an hour ago. After that, we rowed the boat back here to get some news. Sid ran to the post office to gather information, and I came here to find something to eat before we head home.
tr: “There was no need to panic,” I said, “because we are both fine. We followed the men and the dogs, but they were faster than us, so we lost them after a while; at one point, we thought the sounds were coming from the river, so we got into a canoe and went after them, we went across but saw no one; we tried to come back up the river, but we were exhausted; we tied the canoe somewhere and fell asleep and woke up just an hour ago, then came here to find out what happened, Sid went to the post office thinking someone might have heard something, and I was going to get something to eat, then we were going to come home.”
es: —Well, there was no reason —I said—, because it was very good. We followed the men and the dogs, but they ran faster than us and we got lost, but we thought we had heard them in the water, so we took out a canoe, followed them and crossed to the other side, but we didn't see them; then we followed the riverbank upstream until we got tired, tied up the canoe and fell asleep, and we haven't woken up until an hour ago; then we came rowing to see what was happening and Sid has gone to the post office to see if he finds out anything and I'm walking around to see if I can get something to eat before going home.

en: So then we went to the post-office to get “Sid”; but just as I suspicioned, he warn’t there; so the old man he got a letter out of the office, and we waited a while longer, but Sid didn’t come; so the old man said, come along, let Sid foot it home, or canoe it, when he got done fooling around—but we would ride. I couldn’t get him to let me stay and wait for Sid; and he said there warn’t no use in it, and I must come along, and let Aunt Sally see we was all right.
vi: So both of them went to the post office to look for Sid. But I knew, of course, that Sid wasn't there. My uncle received a new letter that had just arrived. We waited a little longer without seeing Sid. He said we should go home to let Aunt Sally know we were okay, and that Sid would find his way back on his own.
tr: Upon this, we went to the post office to find "Sid"; but just as I "suspected", he wasn't there; the old man received a letter from the post office, we waited a bit longer but Sid didn't show up; then the old man suggested that we leave, Sid could walk home or come down by canoe after dawdling enough, but we would go by horse. He didn't let me stay and wait for Sid; he said it wouldn't be of any use; I had to go with him and tell Aunt Sally that we were both fine.
es: So we went to the post office to look for "Sid," but as I suspected, he wasn't there; so the old man picked up a letter that had arrived for him and we waited a while longer. Since Sid didn't show up, the old man said we should leave and that Sid could walk home, or take the canoe, when he finished fooling around in town, but that we would return in the cart. I couldn't get him to let me stay to wait for Sid, because he said it wouldn't do any good, and I had to go back with him so Aunt Sally could see that we were all right.

en: When we got home Aunt Sally was that glad to see me she laughed and cried both, and hugged me, and give me one of them lickings of hern that don’t amount to shucks, and said she’d serve Sid the same when he come.
vi: When we got home, Aunt Sally was overjoyed, half laughing, half crying, hugging me tightly, giving me a delicious cake, and she said Sid would get the same when he returned.
tr: Aunt Sally was so pleased to see me when we arrived that she hugged me while both laughing and crying at the same time, then gave me a good spanking, but it almost didn't hurt at all. She said she would do the same to Sid when he arrived.
es: When we got home, Aunt Sally was so happy to see me that she started laughing and crying at the same time while hugging me and giving me one of those beatings of hers that you couldn't even feel, and then she said she would do the same to Sid when he got home.

en: And the place was plum full of farmers and farmers’ wives, to dinner; and such another clack a body never heard. Old Mrs. Hotchkiss was the worst; her tongue was a-going all the time. She says:
vi: The house was crowded with people, they were eating, drinking, and talking noisily. Mrs. Hotchkiss kept chattering incessantly.
tr: The inside of the house was filled with farmers who had come for dinner and their wives; there was more chatter than I had ever heard in my life. The worst was old Mrs. Hotchkiss, her tongue never stopped working:
es: The house was full of farmers and their wives who had come to eat and wouldn't stop talking. The worst was old Mrs. Hotchkiss, who was chattering away like there was no tomorrow. She goes and says:

en: “Well, Sister Phelps, I’ve ransacked that-air cabin over, an’ I b’lieve the nigger was crazy. I says to Sister Damrell—didn’t I, Sister Damrell?—s’I, he’s crazy, s’I—them’s the very words I said. You all hearn me: he’s crazy, s’I; everything shows it, s’I. Look at that-air grindstone, s’I; want to tell me’t any cretur ’t’s in his right mind ’s a goin’ to scrabble all them crazy things onto a grindstone, s’I? Here sich ’n’ sich a person busted his heart; ’n’ here so ’n’ so pegged along for thirty-seven year, ’n’ all that—natcherl son o’ Louis somebody, ’n’ sich everlast’n rubbage. He’s plumb crazy, s’I; it’s what I says in the fust place, it’s what I says in the middle, ’n’ it’s what I says last ’n’ all the time—the nigger’s crazy—crazy ’s Nebokoodneezer, s’I.”
vi: - Ms. Phelps, I went to see that cell, and I found that black man really strange. I also told Ms. Damrell the same thing, didn't I, Ms. Damrell? Well, it's really bizarre. Just look at that grinding stone and you'll see. Things like a broken heart, living miserably for thirty-seven years, then the child of Louis... so many things. This black man is really bizarre!
tr: “I turned that cabin upside down, Brother Phelps, I had no doubt that the Negro was insane. I was just telling Brother Damrell… didn't I say so, Brother Damrell?.. I was saying he was truly mad… I said it exactly like that. You all heard me: I said he was a lunatic; everything points to it. Looking at the state of that millstone, no sane creature would write such nonsensical, crazy things on a millstone, I said. No sir, this man's heart is broken, no sir, he's been there for thirty-seven years… he was even the son of someone named Louis, and a lot more nonsense. Look at the trouble of the madman, I realized it from the very beginning, I said the same thing there, and I'm saying it now… that Negro is a lunatic… even crazier than Nebuchadnezzar.”
es: —Well, Sister Phelps, I've searched that cabin everywhere and I think the black man was crazy. I told Sister Damrell, didn't I, Sister Damrell? I said, he's crazy, with these very words. You've all heard me: he's crazy, that's what I say; and it shows in everything. Just look at that millstone, that's what I say; no one can tell me that someone who goes and writes all those crazy things on a millstone isn't crazy, that's what I say. Here this person had their heart broken, and that one suffered for thirty-seven years, and all that: natural son of Louis something-or-other, and all those nonsense. He's nuts, that's what I say and I say it to begin with, in the middle, and to end with: that black man is crazy; he's crazy; crazier than Nebuchadnezzar, that's what I say.

en: “An’ look at that-air ladder made out’n rags, Sister Hotchkiss,” says old Mrs. Damrell; “what in the name o’ goodness could he ever want of—”
vi: Mrs. Damrell said:
tr: “That cloth ladder he made, Hotchkiss Brother,” said old Mrs. Damrell, “For God's sake, what could he have made it for?..”
es: —If you only need to look at that ladder made of rags, Sister Hotchkiss —says old Mrs. Damrell—; why on earth would anyone want...

en: “The very words I was a-sayin’ no longer ago th’n this minute to Sister Utterback, ’n’ she’ll tell you so herself. Sh-she, look at that-air rag ladder, sh-she; ’n’ s’I, yes, look at it, s’I—what could he a-wanted of it, s’I. Sh-she, Sister Hotchkiss, sh-she—”
vi: Mrs. Damrell said: - But that ladder made entirely of rags, I wonder what it uses that for?
tr: “I was just telling Brother Utterback the same thing, look, ask him if you want, he will tell you. I took a look at that rope ladder… yes, I looked carefully and wondered why he made it. Ask Mrs. Hotchkiss, she will tell you…”
es: —The same thing I was saying a moment ago to Sister Utterback, and if not, let her say so. She has seen that rag ladder, that's what I say; yes, look at it, that's what I say; what was I going to do with it? Sister Hotchkiss says...

en: “But how in the nation’d they ever git that grindstone in there, anyway? ’n’ who dug that-air hole? ’n’ who—”
vi: - But how did it manage to bring the millstone in there? Who dug that hole? - I was just about to ask that.
tr: “So how did they get that huge millstone in there? Who dug that hole? Who…”
es: —But, how the heck did they get that millstone in there? And, who made the hole? And, who...?

en: “My very words, Brer Penrod! I was a-sayin’—pass that-air sasser o’ m’lasses, won’t ye?—I was a-sayin’ to Sister Dunlap, jist this minute, how did they git that grindstone in there, s’I. Without help, mind you—’thout help! Thar’s wher ’tis. Don’t tell me, s’I; there wuz help, s’I; ’n’ ther’ wuz a plenty help, too, s’I; ther’s ben a dozen a-helpin’ that nigger, ’n’ I lay I’d skin every last nigger on this place but I’d find out who done it, s’I; ’n’ moreover, s’I—”
vi: How on earth did he manage to bring that millstone in there? Did he carry it all by himself? There must have been someone helping him, no, a lot of people helping; it must have taken more than a dozen people to help that black guy. If I find out who they are, I'll skin all the black people in this area! Damn! - More than a dozen people?
tr: “That's what I said, Brother Penrod! I told you… you went through that hole, didn’t you?.. I was just telling Brother Dunlap that, how did they get that big millstone there, I said. And without any help… without anyone helping! That's the issue. It's obvious that someone from outside helped, and what help it was, at least a dozen people helped that black man, if I were in your place, I would skin every black person here if necessary to find out who helped, in fact, if it were up to me…”
es: "That's what I say, brother Penrod!" "I was saying, pass me that little plate of molasses, please, I was saying to sister Dunlap a minute ago, how did they get that mill wheel in there?" "And without help, mind you, without help!" "That's the point." "Don't tell me, I say; they had help, I say, and a lot of help, that's what I say; heaps of help, I say; a dozen helped that black man, and as for me, I'd whip all the blacks here until I found out who they were, that's what I say; and, furthermore, I say..."

en: “A dozen says you!—forty couldn’t a done every thing that’s been done. Look at them case-knife saws and things, how tedious they’ve been made; look at that bed-leg sawed off with ’m, a week’s work for six men; look at that nigger made out’n straw on the bed; and look at—”
vi: Even forty people couldn't finish all that stuff. Look, just try to look at that pile of knives, saws, hoes, and shovels.
tr: “You say a dozen!.. To do that much work, at least forty people would be needed. Look at this saw made from a pocket knife, how meticulously they worked; see how the leg of the bed was cut, that job would take six people a week to finish; didn't you see what they put on the bed made of straw?..”
es: —A dozen, you say! Not even forty could have done so many things. Just look at those saws made from kitchen knives and everything else, the care with which they are made; just look at the leg of that cot sawed with them, which is a week's work for six men... Just look at that black doll made of straw on the bed and just look at...

en: “You may well say it, Brer Hightower! It’s jist as I was a-sayin’ to Brer Phelps, his own self. S’e, what do you think of it, Sister Hotchkiss, s’e? Think o’ what, Brer Phelps, s’I? Think o’ that bed-leg sawed off that a way, s’e? think of it, s’I? I lay it never sawed itself off, s’I—somebody sawed it, s’I; that’s my opinion, take it or leave it, it mayn’t be no ’count, s’I, but sich as ’t is, it’s my opinion, s’I, ’n’ if any body k’n start a better one, s’I, let him do it, s’I, that’s all. I says to Sister Dunlap, s’I—”
vi: Look, just try to look at that pile of knives, saws, hoes, and shovels. It's exhausting, and then there's the bed leg that's been sawed off, it would take six people a whole week to finish, and the black man made of straw placed on the bed, and then the...
tr: “Well, that's right, you said it, Brother Hightower! I was just telling Brother Phelps the same thing. What do you say, Brother Hotchkiss? I wonder what Brother Phelps thinks? When he sees the bedpost cut like that? Just think about it; that's how I see it, whether you accept it or not; maybe no one will accept it, but still, that's my opinion, if anyone has a better idea, let them come forward and say it. I told Brother Dunlap...”
es: —You are absolutely right, Brother Hightower! That's what I was telling Brother Phelps here. He says, "What do you think of all this, Sister Hotchkiss?", he says. What do I think of what, Brother Phelps?, I say. "What do you think of the bed of that cot being sawed like that?", he says. What do I think?, I say. What I think is that it didn't saw itself, I say; someone did it, I say; that's my opinion, for what it's worth; maybe it's worth nothing, I say, but whether it's worth something or not, it's my opinion, I say, and if someone has a better one, I say, let them say it, I say, and that's all. I tell Sister Dunlap, I say...

en: “Why, dog my cats, they must a ben a house-full o’ niggers in there every night for four weeks to a done all that work, Sister Phelps. Look at that shirt—every last inch of it kivered over with secret African writ’n done with blood! Must a ben a raft uv ’m at it right along, all the time, amost. Why, I’d give two dollars to have it read to me; ’n’ as for the niggers that wrote it, I ’low I’d take ’n’ lash ’m t’ll—”
vi: - Strange, he has to have a group of black people in there every night, working for four weeks to get that much, Mrs. Phelps. Look at that shirt, every inch of it has a secret sign written in blood by Africans! There must always be a group there, no doubt about it. I'd pay two dollars right away to anyone who can read those secret words to me, and any black person who writes for me also has to explain what it means...
tr: “Oh, goodness gracious, Brother Phelps, for four weeks there were probably a houseful of black people there every night, only just managing to get all that work done. Look at this shirt… every inch of it is covered with secret African writings in blood! It must have been a raft full of black people coming to work. I'll pay two dollars to have this writing read; as for the black people who wrote it, I know exactly what I'll do to them…”
es: —Well, hang me, there must have been a whole gang of blacks who spent every night for four weeks to have done so much work, sister Phelps. Just look at that shirt; it's completely covered inch by inch with that secret African writing done in blood! There must have been a bunch of them all the time, or almost. Man, I'd give two dollars for someone to read it to me, and as for the blacks who wrote it, I'd whip them until...

en: “People to help him, Brother Marples! Well, I reckon you’d think so if you’d a been in this house for a while back. Why, they’ve stole everything they could lay their hands on—and we a-watching all the time, mind you. They stole that shirt right off o’ the line! and as for that sheet they made the rag ladder out of, ther’ ain’t no telling how many times they didn’t steal that; and flour, and candles, and candlesticks, and spoons, and the old warming-pan, and most a thousand things that I disremember now, and my new calico dress; and me and Silas and my Sid and Tom on the constant watch day and night, as I was a-telling you, and not a one of us could catch hide nor hair nor sight nor sound of them; and here at the last minute, lo and behold you, they slides right in under our noses and fools us, and not only fools us but the Injun Territory robbers too, and actuly gets away with that nigger safe and sound, and that with sixteen men and twenty-two dogs right on their very heels at that very time! I tell you, it just bangs anything I ever heard of. Why, sperits couldn’t a done better and been no smarter. And I reckon they must a been sperits—because, you know our dogs, and ther’ ain’t no better; well, them dogs never even got on the track of ’m once! You explain that to me if you can!—any of you!”
vi: - Someone helped it, I'm sure you all would think the same if you stayed in that room for a while. They can steal everything, even if you're standing next to it. They steal the shirt right off the clothesline. And the bed sheet they used as a rope, who wouldn't say they could steal that? Then flour, candles, candlesticks, spoons, even the old feather duster, and a thousand other things I can't remember; then my cloth shirt. So then Silas, Sid, Tom, and I spent all day guarding. There!
tr: “Someone must have been helping them, that's for sure, Brother Marples! If you had been living in this house for a while, you would think the same. They stole everything they could get their hands on… Even while we were constantly on watch. They took that shirt straight from the clothesline! I can't even remember how many times they stole the sheet they used to make the rope ladder; plus flour, candles, candlesticks, spoons, an old bed warmer, and a thousand other things I can't even think of right now, and now my new calico dress is gone; Silas, Sid, Tom, and I were on watch day and night, I told you, not one of us caught them, we didn't even see or hear them; so at the last minute, you might not believe your ears but they passed right under our noses; they tricked us; and not just us, they tricked the robbers from the Indian Territory too; in fact, they escaped quite comfortably with that black man, even though there were sixteen men and twenty-two dogs behind them! This beats all the stories I've heard so far. Ghosts couldn't have done better, couldn't have been more cunning. Actually, I'm afraid they might be ghosts… You know our dogs, there's none better; even those dogs couldn't find their tracks! Someone explain this to me if they can!.. Anyone!”
es: —People who helped him, Brother Marples! Well, you could be sure of that if you had been in this house for some time now. But they stole everything they could, and that's with us being vigilant all the time. They stole that shirt from the clothesline! And as for the sheet they used to make the ladder, God knows how many times they stole it; and flour and candles and candlesticks and spoons and the old heater and almost a thousand things I can't even remember, my new calico dress, and that's with me and Silas and my Sid and my Tom watching all day and all night, as I was telling you, and none of us could see or hear anything they were doing, and now, at the last minute, they escape right under our noses and fool us, and not only fool us but also the Indian Territory thieves, and they go and escape with that black man without anyone laying a hand on them, and that's with sixteen men and twenty-two dogs chasing them just as they were escaping! I'm telling you, I've never heard anything like it in my life. Not even spirits could have done it better or with more intelligence. And I reckon they must have been spirits, because you know your dogs and there are none better; and those dogs didn't pick up their trail even once! Let someone who understands it explain it to me! Let's see who would be able to understand it!

en: “Well, it does beat—”
vi: Like I said, none of us saw or heard anything.
tr: “True, there's really no one better...”
es: —Well, the truth is that...

en: “Laws alive, I never—”
vi: Yet suddenly, it passed right under our noses and made a mess of us; not only that, but there was a whole gang of red-skinned thieves too, and now it has taken the black man away and even sixteen people with twenty dogs chasing couldn't catch it!
tr: "I have never heard such a thing in my life...""
es: —For God's sake, never...

en: “So help me, I wouldn’t a be—”
vi: Even the devil couldn't do something more terrifying and quick than that.
