tr: “Then help me, how can it be that...”
es: —God bless me, I wouldn't have believed it...

en: “House-thieves as well as—”
vi: Our dogs, you know, yet the whole pack couldn't find any trace...
tr: “They have both robbed the house and also...”
es: —House burglars, in addition to...

en: “Goodnessgracioussakes, I’d a ben afeard to live in sich a—”
vi: - Creepy, I've never...
tr: “My Almighty Lord, I would be afraid to live in such a place...”
es: —By God and all the saints, I would be scared to live in a... —Fear of living!

en: “’Fraid to live!—why, I was that scared I dasn’t hardly go to bed, or get up, or lay down, or set down, Sister Ridgeway. Why, they’d steal the very—why, goodness sakes, you can guess what kind of a fluster I was in by the time midnight come last night. I hope to gracious if I warn’t afraid they’d steal some o’ the family! I was just to that pass I didn’t have no reasoning faculties no more. It looks foolish enough now, in the daytime; but I says to myself, there’s my two poor boys asleep, ’way up stairs in that lonesome room, and I declare to goodness I was that uneasy ’t I crep’ up there and locked ’em in! I did. And anybody would. Because, you know, when you get scared that way, and it keeps running on, and getting worse and worse all the time, and your wits gets to addling, and you get to doing all sorts o’ wild things, and by-and-by you think to yourself, spos’n I was a boy, and was away up there, and the door ain’t locked, and you—” She stopped, looking kind of wondering, and then she turned her head around slow, and when her eye lit on me—I got up and took a walk.
vi: - It's really scary! Terrifying, I don't dare to sleep, don't dare to lie down, don't dare to sit. I keep praying to God, hoping it won't steal anyone from my family! During the day, I almost go crazy, there are two nephews sleeping upstairs, I have to lock the door tightly. Who wouldn't be scared? Every day it gets more terrifying, then ghosts and spirits haunt me, making me do foolish things. Then, I think if I were the child lying up there, and saw the door wasn't locked then...
tr: “So you were scared!.. I was so scared that I couldn't lie down, I couldn't get up, I couldn't stretch out, I couldn't sit, Brother Ridgeway. Do you know what they stole… My God, you can't imagine how panicked I was when I returned to bed in the middle of the night. Still, thank God, with this courage, they could have stolen a family member too! I was out of my mind, my mind had stopped working. Now it sounds very silly, I mean in the daytime; but I say to myself, the poor two children are sleeping all alone in the room upstairs, God is my witness, I was so disturbed that I went upstairs and locked their door! I really did that. Anyone would have done the same thing. Because if a person is scared and the things that scare them continue, even if things are getting worse, they feel like they are losing their mind and start doing ridiculous things; you find yourself putting yourself in a child's place, far away upstairs, and the door is not locked…” He suddenly stopped, as if something had come to his mind, slowly turned his head, and finally, we made eye contact – I immediately got up and went for a walk.
es: Man, I was so scared that I hardly dared to lie down, stretch out, or sit down, Sister Ridgeway. But they were even stealing... My God, you can imagine the state I was in at midnight yesterday. I swear I was afraid they would take someone from the family! I had reached a point where I couldn't even reason anymore. Now in the daytime, it seems silly, but I was saying to myself: "There are my two poor little boys sleeping, all alone upstairs, in that room," and I truly tell you I was so scared that I went up the stairs and locked them in. That's what I did, and what anyone would do. Because, you know, when one is so scared it gets worse because the head starts to stop working, the most absurd things come to mind, and over time one begins to think: "Suppose I were a boy and I was up there with the door unlocked and it was..." —She fell silent with a somewhat astonished air, then slowly turned her head, and when she looked at me... I got up and went for a walk.

en: Says I to myself, I can explain better how we come to not be in that room this morning if I go out to one side and study over it a little. So I done it. But I dasn’t go fur, or she’d a sent for me. And when it was late in the day the people all went, and then I come in and told her the noise and shooting waked up me and “Sid,” and the door was locked, and we wanted to see the fun, so we went down the lightning-rod, and both of us got hurt a little, and we didn’t never want to try that no more. And then I went on and told her all what I told Uncle Silas before; and then she said she’d forgive us, and maybe it was all right enough anyway, and about what a body might expect of boys, for all boys was a pretty harum-scarum lot as fur as she could see; and so, as long as no harm hadn’t come of it, she judged she better put in her time being grateful we was alive and well and she had us still, stead of fretting over what was past and done. So then she kissed me, and patted me on the head, and dropped into a kind of a brown study; and pretty soon jumps up, and says:
vi: Then, I think if I were the child lying up there, and saw the door wasn't locked then... Aunt stopped, looked around, and when her eyes saw me, I stood up and walked outside immediately. She pulled me back, kissed me, and patted my head. Sitting there lost in thought, suddenly she startled, her voice filled with panic:
tr: This morning I can explain better why we weren't in that room, but first I need to retreat to a corner and think about it, I said to myself. I moved a little away. But I didn't go too far, otherwise he might have sent someone after me. After hours had passed and everyone had left, I went into the house and told Aunt Sally that "Sid" and I woke up to the noise and gunshots at night; the door was locked, we didn't want to miss the fun, so we came down from the lightning rod and got hurt, we would never try such a thing again. Then I went on to tell Uncle Silas the story I had told him before; upon which he said he forgave us, maybe everything was alright; what could one expect from two boys, as far as he knew, all boys had their heads in the clouds; so, since no one was harmed, it was better to be thankful that we were alive and healthy, still with him, rather than worrying about what had happened before. He kissed me, patted my head, and after a while, he got lost in thought, but soon he suddenly jumped up:
es: I said to myself: "I will be able to explain better why we weren't in the room this morning if I go aside and think about it for a bit," and so I did. But I didn't dare go too far, because I had been sent for. As it got late, everyone left and then I went in and told her that Sid and I had been woken up by the screams and noises, and since the door was closed and we wanted to see what was happening, we climbed down the lightning rod and both of us got a bit hurt, so we couldn't do it anymore. Then I went to tell her everything I had told Uncle Silas before, and then she said she forgave us and that it was logical and to be expected from boys, because all boys were crazy, as far as she knew, and as long as nothing had happened to us, she thought it was better to feel grateful that we were alive and well and to keep loving us, instead of worrying about things that had already happened. She kissed me, stroked my head, became very thoughtful and after a moment she jumped up and said:

en: “Why, lawsamercy, it’s most night, and Sid not come yet! What has become of that boy?”
vi: - It's almost dark and Sid still hasn't come back! Did something happen to him?
tr: “My Almighty Lord, it's almost getting dark, Sid still hasn't come! Did something happen to the child?”
es: —God bless me, it's almost night and Sid still hasn't arrived! What could have happened to that boy?

en: I see my chance; so I skips up and says:
vi: I felt so lucky, I suddenly stood up and said:
tr: I should have taken advantage of this opportunity; I immediately jumped up and said:
es: There I saw my opportunity, so I also jumped and said:

en: “I’ll run right up to town and get him,” I says.
vi: I felt so lucky, I suddenly stood up and said:
tr: "I'll quickly run to the town and find him.""
es: —I'm going to the village to bring it —I say.

en: “No you won’t,” she says. “You’ll stay right wher’ you are; one’s enough to be lost at a time. If he ain’t here to supper, your uncle ’ll go.”
vi: - No, don't go anymore. Isn't one missing child enough? If it doesn't come back by mealtime, let me go look for it.
tr: "No way," he said. "Stay where you are, it's enough that one of you is missing. If he doesn't come back by dinner, your brother-in-law will go look for him."
es: —No, no way —she says—. You stay where you are; it's enough that one gets lost. If he doesn't arrive by dinner time, your uncle will go.

en: Well, he warn’t there to supper; so right after supper uncle went.
vi: By dinner time, he still hadn't returned. So after eating, Uncle Silas left immediately.
tr: Tom didn't come to dinner either, so after the meal, my brother-in-law went to check on him.
es: Well, he didn't arrive at dinner time, so immediately afterward the uncle went out.

en: He come back about ten a little bit uneasy; hadn’t run across Tom’s track. Aunt Sally was a good deal uneasy; but Uncle Silas he said there warn’t no occasion to be—boys will be boys, he said, and you’ll see this one turn up in the morning all sound and right. So she had to be satisfied. But she said she’d set up for him a while anyway, and keep a light burning so he could see it.
vi: By ten o'clock, he returned, looking sad, because there was no sign of Tom anywhere. Aunt Sally was very worried; but Uncle Silas said it was nothing to worry about, and that he would be back by morning. Aunt Sally felt somewhat reassured, but she still sat there, keeping the light on so that Tom could see it and find his way back. Later, I went upstairs.
tr: She came back around ten o'clock, a little worried, having not encountered Tom anywhere. Aunt Sally was now quite anxious; but Uncle Silas said it was nothing important... "He's just a child, after all," he said, "you'll see, he'll turn up safe and sound in the morning." Aunt Sally had to be content with this. But she said she would stay up for a while and keep the light on, as she wanted to see him if he came back.
es: He returned around ten a little uneasy: he hadn't found a trace of Tom. Aunt Sally is very uneasy; but Uncle Silas said there was no reason to be, that it was just boys being boys and that he would show up in the morning safe and sound. So she had to keep quiet, but she said that in any case she would stay up waiting for him and leave a light on so he could see it.

en: And then when I went up to bed she come up with me and fetched her candle, and tucked me in, and mothered me so good I felt mean, and like I couldn’t look her in the face; and she set down on the bed and talked with me a long time, and said what a splendid boy Sid was, and didn’t seem to want to ever stop talking about him; and kept asking me every now and then if I reckoned he could a got lost, or hurt, or maybe drownded, and might be laying at this minute somewheres suffering or dead, and she not by him to help him, and so the tears would drip down silent, and I would tell her that Sid was all right, and would be home in the morning, sure; and she would squeeze my hand, or maybe kiss me, and tell me to say it again, and keep on saying it, because it done her good, and she was in so much trouble. And when she was going away she looked down in my eyes so steady and gentle, and says:
vi: She also brought the candle up, led me into the room, and comforted me so much that I felt embarrassed and didn't dare to look her in the face anymore. Then she sat down beside the bed and talked to me for a long time, saying that Sid was really a clever boy. From time to time, she asked me if he might be lost somewhere, or injured, or drowned, or where he might be lying at that moment. Then her tears quietly fell, and I had to tell her that Sid was still safe and that he would surely be back by morning. After that, she held my hand tightly, perhaps kissed me too, and told me to keep repeating those words to reassure her because she was very worried. Then she stepped out, turned back to look at me affectionately, and said:
tr: Then, as I was going to bed, she took her candlestick and went upstairs with me, tucked me in, and mothered me so well that I began to wish the ground would swallow me up; I was too ashamed to even look at her face. She sat on the edge of the bed and talked to me for a long time, telling me how extraordinary a child Sid was, as if she never wanted to stop talking about him. From time to time, she asked me questions, wondering if he was lost, injured, or even drowned. She was worried that he might be suffering somewhere or lying lifeless, and tears streamed down her face because she couldn't be there to help him. I told her that Sid was fine and that he would definitely come home in the morning; then she squeezed my hand, even kissed my cheek, and asked me to say it again, to keep saying it, because it made her feel better and she was very worried. As she was leaving, she looked straight into my eyes and said in a very calm and sweet voice:
es: And then, when I went to bed, she came up with me and brought her candle, tucked me in, and treated me so well that I felt like a scoundrel, as if I couldn't look her in the eyes. She sat on the bed to chat with me for a long time and said what a splendid boy Sid was; it seemed as if she didn't want to stop talking about him, constantly asking me if I thought he might have gotten lost or hurt, or maybe drowned, and that he could be suffering somewhere right now, or dead, without her there to help him, while silent tears fell, and I told her that Sid was fine and that he would surely be home by morning. She would squeeze my hand, or give me a kiss, and ask me to repeat it and not stop, because it did her so much good and she was having such a hard time. When she was about to leave, she looked me in the eyes very intently and affectionately, and then she said:

en: “The door ain’t going to be locked, Tom, and there’s the window and the rod; but you’ll be good, won’t you? And you won’t go? For my sake.”
vi: - Auntie didn't lock the door, Tom. There's a window over there, near the lamppost, but you have to be good, okay, don't go anywhere. You must love Auntie!
tr: "The door will not be locked, Tom; besides, there is the window and the lightning rod; but you will behave, won't you? You won't go, will you? For my sake?"
es: —Tom, I'm not going to lock the door, and there's the window and the lightning rod, but you're going to be good, right? And you're not going to leave? Do it for me.

en: Laws knows I wanted to go bad enough to see about Tom, and was all intending to go; but after that I wouldn’t a went, not for kingdoms.
vi: I was anxious and just wanted to see how Tom was doing. He was about to get up and go, but then he didn't.
tr: God knows, I was dying to go, I was worried about Tom's situation, I was ready to leave immediately, but after he said those things, I couldn't go even if they took my life.
es: God knows how much I wanted to go out and see what was happening with Tom, and that I had no other intention; but after that, I wouldn't have left even if they had given me entire kingdoms.

en: But she was on my mind and Tom was on my mind, so I slept very restless. And twice I went down the rod away in the night, and slipped around front, and see her setting there by her candle in the window with her eyes towards the road and the tears in them; and I wished I could do something for her, but I couldn’t, only to swear that I wouldn’t never do nothing to grieve her any more. And the third time I waked up at dawn, and slid down, and she was there yet, and her candle was most out, and her old gray head was resting on her hand, and she was asleep.
vi: But I still thought about Aunt Saly, thought about Tom tossing and turning, unable to sleep. Twice I slid down the lamppost and went outside, then turned back to look at the candle in the window and saw Aunt Saly's eyes looking out onto the street, tears streaming down, and I thought I had to do something for her, but I couldn't do anything. The third time, I got up at dawn, went downstairs, and saw Aunt Saly still sitting there, she had fallen asleep on her hand.
tr: If Aunt Sally was on my mind, so was Tom; that's why I couldn't sleep at all. Twice I climbed down the lightning rod, wandered around the front in the dark of the night, and saw Aunt Sally waiting by the candlestick at the window, her eyes fixed on the road, shedding tears; I wished I could do something for her, but I couldn't, the only thing I could do was to swear that I would never do anything to upset her again. On the third time, I woke up at dawn and went down. She was still there, the candle in her candlestick was almost out, and her gray-haired old head had fallen onto her arms, she had fallen asleep.
es: But I couldn't stop thinking about her and Tom, so I slept very restlessly. That night I climbed down the lightning rod twice and went to the main entrance, and there I saw her sitting with her candle at the window, looking at the road and crying nonstop, and I thought that I wished I could do something for her, but I couldn't, except swear that I would never do anything to make her sad again. The third time I woke up was at dawn, I climbed down the lightning rod and there she was, with the candle almost finished, with her old head resting on her hand; she had fallen asleep.

en: CHAPTER XLII.
vi: chapter xlii
tr: Chapter Forty-Two
es: Chapter 42

en: The old man was uptown again before breakfast, but couldn’t get no track of Tom; and both of them set at the table thinking, and not saying nothing, and looking mournful, and their coffee getting cold, and not eating anything. And by-and-by the old man says:
vi: Uncle Silas went looking for Tom before breakfast but returned without any trace of him. The couple sat at the table, thinking silently, looking very sad. Their coffee had gone cold, but they still had no appetite to eat. After a while, he said:
tr: The old man went to town again before breakfast, but once again he couldn't find any trace of Tom; now both of them were sitting at the table, lost in deep thought, not uttering a word and looking very sorrowful; their coffee was getting cold, and they weren't eating anything. After a while, the old man said:
es: THE OLD MAN RETURNED to the village before breakfast, but he found no trace of Tom, and the two sat at the table, thinking without saying anything, with a very sad air while their coffee grew cold, and without eating anything. After a while, the old man goes and says:

en: “Did I give you the letter?”
vi: Have I given the letter to her yet?
tr: “Did I give you the letter?”
es: —Have I given you the letter?

en: “What letter?”
vi: - Which letter?
tr: “What letter?””
es: —What letter?

en: “The one I got yesterday out of the post-office.”
vi: - The letter I received at the post office yesterday.
tr: “The letter I got from the post office yesterday.”
es: —The one they gave me yesterday at the post office.

en: “No, you didn’t give me no letter.”
vi: - No, you didn't give me any letter.
tr: “You didn't give me a letter.”
es: —No, you haven't given me any letter.

en: “Well, I must a forgot it.”
vi: - Maybe I forgot.
tr: “So, I must have forgotten.””
es: —Well, I must have forgotten.

en: So he rummaged his pockets, and then went off somewheres where he had laid it down, and fetched it, and give it to her. She says:
vi: He searched in his pocket but couldn't find it, then went somewhere to get the letter and handed it to her. She said:
tr: The old man searched his pockets, then got up and looked for the place where he had put the letter, finally found it, and gave it to him. “Ah, from St. Petersburg...
es: He started searching in his pockets and then went somewhere to find where he had left it, brought it, and gave it to her. She goes and says:

en: “Why, it’s from St. Petersburg—it’s from Sis.”
vi: - The letter from Petersburg has arrived, it's her letter.
tr: From my sister...”
es: —But it's from Saint Petersburg, from my sister.

en: I allowed another walk would do me good; but I couldn’t stir. But before she could break it open she dropped it and run—for she see something. And so did I. It was Tom Sawyer on a mattress; and that old doctor; and Jim, in her calico dress, with his hands tied behind him; and a lot of people. I hid the letter behind the first thing that come handy, and rushed. She flung herself at Tom, crying, and says:
vi: I thought to myself that perhaps it would be better to go outside and play for a while. But Aunt Sally hadn't had time to open the letter when she suddenly dropped it and ran out. There was Tom lying on a padded stretcher, then the doctor, then Jim, dressed in cloth clothes, his hands tied in front of him with a bunch of people following behind. I quickly picked up the letter and hid it. Aunt Sally rushed to Tom, crying and saying:
tr: It would have been good to go for a new walk, but I couldn't move from my place. Fortunately, Aunt Sally dropped the letter just as she was about to open it and started running – because she had seen something. I saw the same thing. Tom Sawyer was on a bed; that old doctor was beside him; Jim was standing behind them with his hands tied, wearing a calico dress; and there were many other people as well. I hid the letter in the first suitable place and dashed outside. Aunt Sally collapsed onto Tom, crying.
es: I decided that another walk would do me good, but I couldn't even move. Before she could open it, she dropped it and started running, because she had seen something. And so did I. It was Tom Sawyer lying on a mattress, and the old doctor and Jim in her calico dress, with his hands tied behind his back, and a bunch of people. I hid the letter behind the first thing that came to mind and ran out. She rushed towards Tom, crying, and goes and says:

en: “Oh, he’s dead, he’s dead, I know he’s dead!”
vi: - Oh, it's dead, I knew it...
tr: “Ah, he left, he left. He left us!”
es: —Oh, he's dead, he's dead, surely he's dead!

en: And Tom he turned his head a little, and muttered something or other, which showed he warn’t in his right mind; then she flung up her hands, and says:
vi: Tom turned his head and whispered something, and then Aunt Saly raised both her hands again.
tr: Tom turned his head slightly and muttered something, apparently not in his right mind, then Aunt Sally raised her arms:
es: Tom turned his head slightly and said something that showed he wasn't right in the head, and she raised her hands to the sky and said:

en: “He’s alive, thank God! And that’s enough!” and she snatched a kiss of him, and flew for the house to get the bed ready, and scattering orders right and left at the niggers and everybody else, as fast as her tongue could go, every jump of the way.
vi: - Oh, dear God, it's still alive! It's you. Then she kissed him, rushed into the house to prepare the bed, and shouted orders that made the black people flustered.
tr: "He's alive; thank God! This is enough for me now!" She planted a kiss on Tom's cheek and hurriedly went home to prepare the bed, all the while rapidly giving orders to the black people and everyone else around her as best as she could.
es: —He's alive, thank God! And that's enough for me! She gave him a kiss and ran to the house to prepare the bed, giving orders left and right to the black servants and everyone, as fast as she could and with every step she took.

en: I followed the men to see what they was going to do with Jim; and the old doctor and Uncle Silas followed after Tom into the house. The men was very huffy, and some of them wanted to hang Jim for an example to all the other niggers around there, so they wouldn’t be trying to run away like Jim done, and making such a raft of trouble, and keeping a whole family scared most to death for days and nights. But the others said, don’t do it, it wouldn’t answer at all; he ain’t our nigger, and his owner would turn up and make us pay for him, sure. So that cooled them down a little, because the people that’s always the most anxious for to hang a nigger that hain’t done just right is always the very ones that ain’t the most anxious to pay for him when they’ve got their satisfaction out of him.
vi: I followed the group to see what they would do with Jim while the doctor and Uncle Silas followed Tom into the house. The people seemed angry, some wanted to hang Jim immediately as an example for other black people, but others said they shouldn't do that because he wasn't a local black person, and what if his owner came to claim compensation. Hearing that, they calmed down a bit. They cursed Jim terribly.
tr: I followed the men to see what they would do to Jim; the old doctor and Uncle Silas also went into the house after Tom. The men were very aggressive and some wanted to hang Jim, so that he would be an example to the other negroes living there, and they wouldn't try to escape like Jim, causing a lot of trouble, terrifying a whole family for days and nights. But others didn't want to hang him; it wasn't a solution, after all, he wasn't our negro and his owner could come and demand money for the negro. Upon this, the men calmed down a bit, because those who are most eager to hang negroes who want to do something wrong are always the least willing to pay the money after dealing with him.
es: I followed the men to find out what they were going to do with Jim, and the old doctor and Uncle Silas followed Tom to the house. The men were furious and wanted to hang Jim to set an example for all the other blacks in the area, so they wouldn't try to escape like Jim had done or cause so much commotion and have an entire family almost scared to death for days and nights. But the others said, "No, that can't be done; that black man isn't ours, and surely the owner will show up and make us pay for him." So they cooled down a bit, because the people who are most eager to hang a black man who has done something are always the same ones who don't want to pay for him once he has served their purpose.

en: They cussed Jim considerble, though, and give him a cuff or two side the head once in a while, but Jim never said nothing, and he never let on to know me, and they took him to the same cabin, and put his own clothes on him, and chained him again, and not to no bed-leg this time, but to a big staple drove into the bottom log, and chained his hands, too, and both legs, and said he warn’t to have nothing but bread and water to eat after this till his owner come, or he was sold at auction because he didn’t come in a certain length of time, and filled up our hole, and said a couple of farmers with guns must stand watch around about the cabin every night, and a bulldog tied to the door in the daytime; and about this time they was through with the job and was tapering off with a kind of generl good-bye cussing, and then the old doctor comes and takes a look, and says:
vi: Every now and then, someone would kick Jim. But Jim didn't say anything and acted as if he didn't know who I was. Then they locked Jim back in the old cell, dressed him in old clothes, chained him to the large plank on the floor, chained both his hands and feet, and said they would only give him bread and water until his owner came or he was sold at auction. Then they sealed the hole we had dug and assigned two people to stand guard with guns every night; during the day, they tied a fierce dog at the door. Once everything was done, they were about to leave, bidding Jim farewell with a curse when the doctor arrived, took a quick look, and said:
tr: Nevertheless, they cursed and swore at Jim, hit him a few times, but Jim didn't utter a word, nor did he show any sign of knowing me. They took him to the same cabin, dressed him in his own clothes, and chained him again, this time not to the bedpost but to a large ring attached to a log. They chained his hands and feet as well. From then on, until his owner came or he was sold at auction, he would be given nothing but bread and water. They closed the hole we had opened. Additionally, every night, a few armed farmers would stand guard around the cabin, and during the day, a guard dog would be tied to the door. They had almost finished their work and were leaving with final curses when the old doctor came in, took a look, and said:
es: They called Jim all sorts of names and hit him on the head from time to time, but Jim didn't say anything; he never let slip that he knew me. They took him to the same cabin, put his own clothes on him, and chained him up again, but this time not to the leg of a cot, but to a huge ring nailed to the lower trunk, and they also chained his hands and both legs and said they wouldn't give him anything to eat but bread and water until his owner showed up or they sold him at an auction, if he didn't show up after a certain time, and they filled in the hole we had made and said that every night there would be a couple of farmers with shotguns guarding the cabin and with a bulldog at the door. By then they had finished their work, and were about to leave with a sort of general curse of farewell when the old doctor appeared, who saw all that and goes and says:

en: “Don’t be no rougher on him than you’re obleeged to, because he ain’t a bad nigger. When I got to where I found the boy I see I couldn’t cut the bullet out without some help, and he warn’t in no condition for me to leave to go and get help; and he got a little worse and a little worse, and after a long time he went out of his head, and wouldn’t let me come a-nigh him any more, and said if I chalked his raft he’d kill me, and no end of wild foolishness like that, and I see I couldn’t do anything at all with him; so I says, I got to have help somehow; and the minute I says it out crawls this nigger from somewheres and says he’ll help, and he done it, too, and done it very well. Of course I judged he must be a runaway nigger, and there I was! and there I had to stick right straight along all the rest of the day and all night. It was a fix, I tell you! I had a couple of patients with the chills, and of course I’d of liked to run up to town and see them, but I dasn’t, because the nigger might get away, and then I’d be to blame; and yet never a skiff come close enough for me to hail. So there I had to stick plumb until daylight this morning; and I never see a nigger that was a better nuss or faithfuller, and yet he was risking his freedom to do it, and was all tired out, too, and I see plain enough he’d been worked main hard lately. I liked the nigger for that; I tell you, gentlemen, a nigger like that is worth a thousand dollars—and kind treatment, too. I had everything I needed, and the boy was doing as well there as he would a done at home—better, maybe, because it was so quiet; but there I was, with both of ’m on my hands, and there I had to stick till about dawn this morning; then some men in a skiff come by, and as good luck would have it the nigger was setting by the pallet with his head propped on his knees sound asleep; so I motioned them in quiet, and they slipped up on him and grabbed him and tied him before he knowed what he was about, and we never had no trouble. And the boy being in a kind of a flighty sleep, too, we muffled the oars and hitched the raft on, and towed her over very nice and quiet, and the nigger never made the least row nor said a word from the start. He ain’t no bad nigger, gentlemen; that’s what I think about him.”
vi: - Everyone, don't treat him so badly, because he is not a bad black man. When I came to find that boy, I had no one to help me to extract the bullet. And I couldn't leave the boy there, as he was getting more critical by the minute. He went crazy, absolutely refused to let me come near, and told me that if I drew chalk on the raft, he would kill me. I felt there was nothing I could do with him. Suddenly, at that moment, this black man crawled out from somewhere and said he would lend a hand. Of course, I immediately thought he was the runaway black man. So I had to stay there for a whole day and night. It was really a tight spot! At home, I had some patients waiting, I wanted to run back to check on them, but I couldn't, because I was also afraid that if the black man ran away, I would be blamed; and at that time, there were no boats passing by to call for help. So I had to wait until this morning. And I have never seen a black man more skillful and loyal than him; he even sacrificed his freedom to do that. He was also very tired. I could clearly see that he must have been working a lot recently. A black man like that is worth a thousand dollars, and deserves to be treated better. Then I saw some people coming by boat, luckily the black man was sitting on the plank, head down on his knees, fast asleep. I signaled the boat to come closer, they jumped up and held the black man tightly and tied him up, so it wasn't too difficult for us. As for the boy, he also fell asleep. We moved the oars to the raft, rowed gently, then docked and tied the raft. From start to finish, this black man did not show any sign of wanting to move or say a word. He is not a bad black man, that's what I think.
tr: “Do not treat him badly for no reason, because he is not a bad negro. When I found the child, I realized I couldn't remove the bullet without help, but the child was in such bad shape that he couldn't be left alone to find help; his condition was gradually worsening, and after a considerable amount of time, he lost consciousness and wouldn't let me approach him anymore, saying he would kill me if I chalked the raft, he babbled such nonsense for a long time that I thought I couldn't be of any help to him; so, I said I needed to find help somehow; as soon as I said this, that negro suddenly appeared and said he would help, and indeed, he helped very well. Of course, I realized he was a runaway negro, but what could I do? Moreover, I had to wait there all day and night. I thought I was in trouble! I had a few patients with colds, I wanted to go back to town to see them too, but I couldn't go, then the negro would escape and I would be blamed; besides, no boats were passing by nearby. I stayed on the raft until dawn this morning, and I must say I have never seen a negro take such good care of a patient, so faithfully, he risked his freedom to help me, moreover, he could barely lift his arm, it was clear he had been worked very hard recently. I was very pleased with the negro's behavior; such a negro is worth a thousand dollars, gentlemen… He also deserves to be treated well. He found everything I needed, and made the child as comfortable as if he were at home… Maybe even more comfortable, since it was very quiet around; but I was in a bad state, both of them were on my mind; I had to wait there until this morning; then a boat approached and by chance, the negro was sitting at the helm with his head between his knees, sleeping; I signaled to the people on the boat to approach quietly, before the negro knew what was happening, they grabbed him tightly and tied his hands and feet, there was no trouble at all. The child was also sleeping, we tied the raft to the boat and quietly pulled it to a safe place; meanwhile, the negro didn't make any fuss from the beginning, he didn't even say a word. He is not a bad negro, gentlemen; that is my opinion.”
es: —Do not treat him worse than necessary, because he is not a bad black man. When I arrived where I found the boy, I saw that I couldn't remove the bullet without some help and that he wasn't in a condition to be left alone while I went to get it, and he kept getting worse and worse, and after a while, he lost his mind and wouldn't let me get close; he said that if I marked the raft with chalk, he would kill me and all sorts of absurd things. When I saw that I couldn't do anything for him, I said to myself: "I need someone to help me," and just then that black man appeared out of nowhere and said he would help me, and he really did help me. Of course, I thought he must be a runaway black man, but that's how things were, and I had to stay there all the rest of the day and all night. I assure you it has been difficult! I had a couple of patients with fevers and naturally, I would have liked to go to town to see them, but I didn't dare because the black man could escape and then it would be my fault; however, not a single skiff came close enough for me to call. So I had to stay there until dawn this morning, and I have never seen a black man who knew better how to take care of a sick person or was more faithful, even though he had to put his freedom at risk, and on top of that, he was exhausted and it was clear that he had had a lot to do recently. That's why I liked that black man; and I assure you, gentlemen, that a black man like that is worth a thousand dollars and should be treated well. I didn't have everything I needed and the boy was recovering just as if he were at home, and maybe better because it was very quiet, but there I was with both of them in my hands, and I had to stay there until dawn; then some men appeared in a skiff, and luckily the black man was sitting next to the mattress with his head resting on his knees, sleeping like a log; so I signaled to them silently, and they approached, grabbed him, and tied him up without him realizing what was happening, and we haven't had any problems. Since the boy was also half asleep, we wrapped the oars with some cloths, hooked up the raft, and towed it silently, and the black man didn't make any fuss or say a word from the beginning. He is not a bad black man, gentlemen; that's what I have to say about him.

en: Somebody says:
vi: Someone said:
tr: "By God, it sounds good, doctor," said someone.
es: Someone said:

en: “Well, it sounds very good, doctor, I’m obleeged to say.”
vi: - Yes, I think so too.
tr: "By God, it sounds good, doctor," said someone.
es: —Well, that says a lot about him, doctor, it must be said.

en: Then the others softened up a little, too, and I was mighty thankful to that old doctor for doing Jim that good turn; and I was glad it was according to my judgment of him, too; because I thought he had a good heart in him and was a good man the first time I see him. Then they all agreed that Jim had acted very well, and was deserving to have some notice took of it, and reward. So every one of them promised, right out and hearty, that they wouldn’t cuss him no more.
vi: Then the others also calmed down a bit. I silently thanked that old doctor for speaking up for Jim; he was an exceptionally kind person. Everyone agreed that Jim had done very well, deserving praise and a reward. So everyone sincerely promised that they would not scold Jim anymore.
tr: Then the others softened a bit too; I was grateful to the old doctor for doing this kindness for Jim, and I was also very pleased that I was not mistaken about him; from the very beginning, from the moment I first saw him, I had thought he was a kind-hearted man. Then they all decided that Jim had behaved very well and therefore deserved better treatment; he should be rewarded for his kindness. They each sincerely swore that they would never curse at him again.
es: Then the others also softened a bit, and I was very glad that the old doctor behaved so well with Jim, and also that it matched what I had thought of him, because it seemed to me that he was a man of good heart since I first saw him. Then everyone decided that Jim had acted very well and deserved some compensation. So everyone promised, immediately and wholeheartedly, that they would not curse him again.

en: Then they come out and locked him up. I hoped they was going to say he could have one or two of the chains took off, because they was rotten heavy, or could have meat and greens with his bread and water; but they didn’t think of it, and I reckoned it warn’t best for me to mix in, but I judged I’d get the doctor’s yarn to Aunt Sally somehow or other as soon as I’d got through the breakers that was laying just ahead of me—explanations, I mean, of how I forgot to mention about Sid being shot when I was telling how him and me put in that dratted night paddling around hunting the runaway nigger.
vi: Then they went out, locked Jim in there, and locked the door. I wished someone would say that they could remove some of the chains for Jim because those chains were too heavy, and give Jim vegetables, meat with bread, and water.
tr: Then they went outside and locked the door behind them. I had hoped they would remove some of my chains because they were very heavy, or maybe they would give meat and vegetables along with bread and water, but it never crossed their minds. I thought it best not to get involved in this matter, but I had to relay what the doctor said to Aunt Sally, of course, I would do this as soon as I got past the massive waves rising right in front of me. That is, as soon as I made the explanations, because they would want to know why I forgot to tell how Sid was shot while we were going by canoe that night to find the runaway slave.
es: Then they went out and locked him up. I hoped they would say they could remove one or two of the chains, because they were very heavy, or that he could eat some meat and vegetables with the bread and water, but it didn't occur to them, and I figured it was better not to get involved in the matter, but rather to tell Aunt Sally the doctor's story as best I could once the storm that was coming over me passed; I mean the explanations of how I had forgotten to mention that Sid had been shot when I started to tell how he and I had spent that night rowing between the islands in search of the runaway black man.

en: But I had plenty time. Aunt Sally she stuck to the sick-room all day and all night, and every time I see Uncle Silas mooning around I dodged him.
vi: But no one thought of that at all. Aunt Sally was on duty in the sick room day and night, and whenever I saw Uncle Silas hanging around there, I would avoid him.
tr: But I had plenty of time. Aunt Sally spent the whole day and night in the sick room; and whenever I noticed Uncle Silas looking around, I would disappear.
es: But he had plenty of time. Aunt Sally stayed with the sick person all day and all night, and every time she saw Uncle Silas with that long face, I would escape from him.

en: Next morning I heard Tom was a good deal better, and they said Aunt Sally was gone to get a nap. So I slips to the sick-room, and if I found him awake I reckoned we could put up a yarn for the family that would wash. But he was sleeping, and sleeping very peaceful, too; and pale, not fire-faced the way he was when he come. So I set down and laid for him to wake. In about half an hour Aunt Sally comes gliding in, and there I was, up a stump again! She motioned me to be still, and set down by me, and begun to whisper, and said we could all be joyful now, because all the symptoms was first-rate, and he’d been sleeping like that for ever so long, and looking better and peacefuller all the time, and ten to one he’d wake up in his right mind.
vi: The next morning, seeing Tom was better, and Aunt Sally went to sleep for a while, I sneaked into the sick room, if he was awake, we would come up with a reasonable story together. But he was still asleep, his face pale, not rosy like the day he first arrived. I sat down, waiting for him to wake up. About half an hour later, Aunt Sally walked in, startling me. She told me to be quiet, then sat down beside me. She seemed happy that Tom had returned to normal.
tr: I heard the next morning that Tom was much better, and they said Aunt Sally had gone to get some sleep. I sneaked into the sickroom, thinking that if I found Tom awake, we could come up with a story to fool the whole family. But he was sleeping, and he was sleeping peacefully; his face was pale, not flushed like when he arrived. So I sat down and waited for him to wake up. About half an hour later, Aunt Sally quietly slipped in, and there she had caught me again! She signaled me to be quiet and sat down next to me, then started whispering. We could all be happy now because Tom was doing very well, and he had been sleeping like this for a long time, looking healthier and more peaceful by the minute; he would probably wake up soon, feeling much better.
es: The next morning I found out that Tom was doing much better, and they said that Aunt Sally had gone to take a nap. So I went to the room and, if I found him awake, I figured we could come up with a story that the family would believe. But he was asleep and very peaceful, and pale, not with his face all flushed like when he arrived. So I sat down and waited for him to wake up. After about half an hour, Aunt Sally arrived quietly and there I was, in trouble again! She motioned for me not to say anything and sat down next to me, and started whispering that now we could all be happy, because all the symptoms were improving and he had been sleeping for a long time, getting better and more peaceful, and she bet ten to one that when he woke up he would have regained all his senses.

en: So we set there watching, and by-and-by he stirs a bit, and opened his eyes very natural, and takes a look, and says:
vi: Then we sat there watching. A moment later, he stirred, opened his eyes very naturally. He looked around and then said:
tr: Upon this, we sat down and began to watch it; it slowly started to move, then naturally opened its eyes, and looked around:
es: We stayed there watching him, and after a while, he moved a little, opened his eyes quite naturally, looked around, and said:

en: “Hello!—why, I’m at home! How’s that? Where’s the raft?”
vi: - Why am I at home? Where is the raft?
tr: “Hello! But I'm at home! How did this happen? Where is Sal?”
es: —Hello! But I'm at home! How did it happen? Where is the raft?

en: “It’s all right,” I says.
vi: - Everything is calm now - I replied.
tr: "In very good condition," I said.
es: —Everything is going well —I replied.

en: “And Jim?”
vi: - What about Jim?
tr: “What about Jim?”
es: —And Jim?

en: “The same,” I says, but couldn’t say it pretty brash. But he never noticed, but says:
vi: - Same here - I replied, my voice not very calm. It spoke again:
tr: “The same,” I said, but I had said it a bit hesitantly. He didn't notice at all:
es: —Same —I said, but without much conviction. But he didn't notice and said:

en: “Good! Splendid! Now we’re all right and safe! Did you tell Aunty?”
vi: - That's great! Did you tell Auntie? I was about to answer when Aunt Saly interrupted and asked
tr: “Very good! Wonderful! Now we are all safe and sound! Did you tell my aunt?” I was just about to say yes when Aunt Sally interrupted:
es: —Great! Splendid! Now we are in order and safe! Have you told Auntie?

en: I was going to say yes; but she chipped in and says: “About what, Sid?”
vi: - About what, child?
tr: "What was he going to say, Sid?"
es: I was about to say yes, but she intervened and goes and says: —What, Sid?

en: “Why, about the way the whole thing was done.”
vi: - About everything that has happened.
tr: “How did we accomplish this great task?”
es: —Man, how we organized everything.

en: “What whole thing?”
vi: - What's the matter?
tr: “Which big task?”
es: —What do you mean by everything?

en: “Why, the whole thing. There ain’t but one; how we set the runaway nigger free—me and Tom.”
vi: - What's the matter? - The story of us releasing the black man...
tr: “Big deal. It's not just one thing, first of all, how we saved the runaway black man… me and Tom.”
es: —Man, everything that has happened. It's the only thing to tell; how Tom and I set the black man free.

en: “Good land! Set the run— What is the child talking about! Dear, dear, out of his head again!”
vi: - What? Release the black man ... This kid, what is he saying? He’s babbling again.
tr: "My Almighty Lord! Save? What is this child talking about! For God's sake, he lost himself again!"
es: —My God! What did you put him in ...? What is this boy talking about! My God, my God, he's lost his mind again!

en: “No, I ain’t out of my HEAD; I know all what I’m talking about. We did set him free—me and Tom. We laid out to do it, and we done it. And we done it elegant, too.” He’d got a start, and she never checked him up, just set and stared and stared, and let him clip along, and I see it warn’t no use for me to put in. “Why, Aunty, it cost us a power of work—weeks of it—hours and hours, every night, whilst you was all asleep. And we had to steal candles, and the sheet, and the shirt, and your dress, and spoons, and tin plates, and case-knives, and the warming-pan, and the grindstone, and flour, and just no end of things, and you can’t think what work it was to make the saws, and pens, and inscriptions, and one thing or another, and you can’t think half the fun it was. And we had to make up the pictures of coffins and things, and nonnamous letters from the robbers, and get up and down the lightning-rod, and dig the hole into the cabin, and made the rope ladder and send it in cooked up in a pie, and send in spoons and things to work with in your apron pocket—”
vi: - No, I didn't dream it. It was Tom and I who set him free... So it began to tell the story, while Aunt Saly sat quietly listening to it. As for me, I felt that interrupting would be pointless. - We had to put so much effort into it, weeks, hours, nights when the whole family was asleep. Then we stole candles, bed sheets, aunt's clothes, then spoons, iron plates, daggers, incubators, millstones, flour, and all sorts of other things. You can't imagine what those saws, pens, and those markings were for; and you couldn't imagine the fun of it. Then we also drew coffin shapes, wrote anonymous letters from the robbers, we kept sliding up and down the lamp post; then dug a hole in the prison, made a rope ladder, then baked a cake and stuffed the rope ladder into it, then put spoons and other things into your kitchen apron pocket.
tr: "No, I haven't lost myself; I know exactly what I'm saying. We saved him... me and Tom. We planned for a long time and finally succeeded. And in a very stylish way." Tom was excited, Aunt Sally no longer stopped him, she just sat and watched his speech with a stern look, I realized there was no point in interrupting. "You can't imagine how hard we worked, Aunt... We struggled for weeks... Every night while you were sleeping, we worked for hours. We had to steal the candles, the sheet, the shirt, and your dress, the spoons, the tin plates, the knives, the bed warmer, the millstone, the flour, and many other things; you would be amazed at how long it took to prepare the saw, the pens, the inscriptions, and other things, and you could never guess how much fun it was. We made coffin pictures and sent anonymous letters from robbers, constantly went up and down the lightning rod, made that hole in the cabin, made a rope ladder and sent it inside a pie, put the spoons and such in your apron pocket..."
es: —No, I haven't lost my mind; I know perfectly well what I'm saying. Yes, Tom and I did set him free. We decided to do it and we did it. And we did it with a lot of style. —It had started moving and she couldn't stop it; she just sat there watching and watching and let it go on. I realized that it made no sense for me to intervene—. But, auntie, it took us a tremendous amount of work, whole weeks, hours and hours every night, while you all slept. We had to steal candles and the sheet and the shirt and your dress and the spoons and the tin plates and the kitchen knives and the heater, the grindstone and the flour and all sorts of things, and you can't imagine the work it took us to make the saws and the pens and the inscriptions and everything else; you have no idea how much fun we had. We had to draw the coffins and the rest, the anonymous letters from the thieves, and go up and down the lightning rod, and make the hole in the cabin and the rope ladder and bake it into a cake and send him spoons and things to work with, which we put in the pockets of your apron...

en: “Mercy sakes!”
vi: - Oh Lord! - Aunt Saly exclaimed. -... .
tr: “For God's sake!”
es: —God help me! —...

en: “—and load up the cabin with rats and snakes and so on, for company for Jim; and then you kept Tom here so long with the butter in his hat that you come near spiling the whole business, because the men come before we was out of the cabin, and we had to rush, and they heard us and let drive at us, and I got my share, and we dodged out of the path and let them go by, and when the dogs come they warn’t interested in us, but went for the most noise, and we got our canoe, and made for the raft, and was all safe, and Jim was a free man, and we done it all by ourselves, and wasn’t it bully, Aunty!”
vi: Then we brought mice and snakes in there to keep Jim company; then aunt kept Tom here for so long that the butter on his hat melted and almost ruined our plans. Then we were chased, I got stuck and got shot. We hid by the roadside to let them pass, then took the canoe to the raft. Everything went well, and Jim was free. Do you find it exciting?
tr: “… also, we filled the cabin with mice, snakes, and such to accompany Jim; then you kept Tom here with butter on his hat for so long that you almost ruined everything, because before we could get out, the men came to the cabin, we had to hurry, they heard our voices and shot at us, I got hit, we went off the road while escaping, and they passed us; when the dogs came, they didn't do anything to us, they followed the noise, we jumped into our canoe and reached the raft, we were safe now, and Jim was free, we did it all by ourselves, isn't it wonderful, Aunt!””
es: And filling the cabin with rats and snakes and everything else to keep Jim company, and then you made Tom stay here so long with the butter inside his hat that you almost ruined everything, because the men arrived before we had left the cabin and we had to run out and they heard us and shot at us and I got hit, and we moved off the path and let them pass, and when the dogs came they didn't find us interesting, but went where there was more noise; we took out the canoe and went to the raft and we were safe and Jim was a free man, and we did it all by ourselves and it was great, Aunt!

en: “Well, I never heard the likes of it in all my born days! So it was you, you little rapscallions, that’s been making all this trouble, and turned everybody’s wits clean inside out and scared us all most to death. I’ve as good a notion as ever I had in my life to take it out o’ you this very minute. To think, here I’ve been, night after night, a—you just get well once, you young scamp, and I lay I’ll tan the Old Harry out o’ both o’ ye!”
vi: - Since the day I was born, I've never heard of such a strange story. So it turns out you brats caused all this trouble, making everyone frantic and scared to death. Do you really enjoy making me suffer every night? You little devils, I'll give you a lesson to stop playing such mischievous pranks.
tr: “If I've ever heard such a thing in my life, may I be damned! So it was you, you little rascals, you caused all those troubles, you drove everyone out of their minds, you scared us to death. Now I feel like giving you a good beating. When I think about what I went through here night after night... oh, just wait until you get better, you brat, then I'll skin both of you alive!”
es: —Well, in my life I've never heard anything like it! So it was you, rascals, who organized all this commotion and left us all not knowing what to think, almost scared to death. It makes me more eager than ever to make you pay for it right now. To think that I've spent night after night here... wait until you're fully recovered, scoundrel, and you'll see how I beat the devil out of you!

en: But Tom, he was so proud and joyful, he just couldn’t hold in, and his tongue just went it—she a-chipping in, and spitting fire all along, and both of them going it at once, like a cat convention; and she says:
vi: But Tom was very delighted. He kept chattering non-stop. Aunt Sally was both annoyed and amused. She said:
tr: Aunt Polly was so proud and cheerful that she couldn't contain herself and kept on talking – Aunt Sally was also fuming now and then, and they were both talking at the same time like a chorus of cats. Aunt Sally said at one point:
es: But Tom was so proud and so happy that he couldn't stop, and he kept on talking while she intervened and spat fire all the time, both at once, like a meeting of cats, and in the end she says:

en: “Well, you get all the enjoyment you can out of it now, for mind I tell you if I catch you meddling with him again—”
vi: - Now you all have had your fun, but if I catch you having any more dealings with it...
tr: "Well, for now, enjoy yourself as much as you want because if I catch you around him again...""
es: —Well, have as much fun as you can now, because I assure you that if I catch you talking to him again...

en: “Meddling with who?” Tom says, dropping his smile and looking surprised.
vi: - Relationship with whom? - Tom asked, laughing, looking very surprised.
tr: "Around whom?" Tom's smile suddenly froze, he was very surprised.
es: —Talking to whom? —asks Tom, stopping his smile and looking surprised.

en: “With who? Why, the runaway nigger, of course. Who’d you reckon?”
vi: - With whom? The black guy who ran away, of course. Who else do you think?
tr: “Who? The runaway black man, of course? Who did you think?”
es: —With whom? Well, with the runaway black man, of course. What did you think?

en: Tom looks at me very grave, and says:
vi: - Tom looked at me very seriously and asked:
tr: Tom's face suddenly clouded over and he turned to me.
es: Tom looked at me very seriously, and then he said:

en: “Tom, didn’t you just tell me he was all right? Hasn’t he got away?”
vi: - Tom, why did you just tell me that everything is fine? Has he escaped yet?
tr: “Tom, didn't you just tell me that he was fine? Hadn't he escaped?”
es: —Tom, didn't you just tell me that he was fine? Hasn't he escaped?

en: “Him?” says Aunt Sally; “the runaway nigger? ’Deed he hasn’t. They’ve got him back, safe and sound, and he’s in that cabin again, on bread and water, and loaded down with chains, till he’s claimed or sold!”
vi: Sister Saly asked: - The black man who ran away? Of course not yet. They have caught him and locked him back in that room, only giving him bread and water, carefully chained, waiting until someone comes to claim or sell him.
tr: “Is it him?” said Aunt Sally; “The runaway black man? He didn't escape at all. They caught him tight and brought him back, put him in his cabin again, only give him bread and water, and chained him from all sides; he will stay that way until his owner comes or he is sold!”
es: —Him? —says Aunt Sally— The runaway black man? Of course not. They've brought him back here safe and sound, and he's in the same cabin, on bread and water, and loaded with chains until someone comes to claim him or we sell him!

en: Tom rose square up in bed, with his eye hot, and his nostrils opening and shutting like gills, and sings out to me:
vi: Tom was lying on the bed when he suddenly sat up, his eyes bloodshot, his nostrils flaring like a fish's gills, then he looked at me and shouted:
tr: Tom sat up in his bed with sparks flying from his eyes, his nostrils flaring like gills, and shouted in anger:
es: Tom sat up abruptly in bed, with his eyes wide open and flaring his nostrils as if they were gills, and he shouts at me:

en: “They hain’t no right to shut him up! Shove!—and don’t you lose a minute. Turn him loose! he ain’t no slave; he’s as free as any cretur that walks this earth!”
vi: - They have no right to capture Jim. You run away immediately, set him free! He is not a slave, he is as free as anyone on this earth!
tr: "They have no right to shut it down! They have no right to push it around at all!.. Don't waste a single minute. Set it free! It is not a slave, it is as free as everyone living in this world!"
es: —You have no right to keep him locked up! Get out, and don't waste a minute. Let him go! He is not a slave. He is as free as anyone else!

en: “What does the child mean?”
vi: -This kid talks strangely, doesn't he?
tr: “What is this child trying to say?”
es: —What is this boy talking about?

en: “I mean every word I say, Aunt Sally, and if somebody don’t go, I’ll go. I’ve knowed him all his life, and so has Tom, there. Old Miss Watson died two months ago, and she was ashamed she ever was going to sell him down the river, and said so; and she set him free in her will.”
vi: - Aunt Sally, everything I said is true. Both Tom and I know him well. Miss Watson has been dead for two months now, and she was very ashamed of planning to sell him down South. She said that she agreed to let him be free.
tr: "I mean everything I said, Aunt Sally, if no one goes and frees him, I will go myself. I've known him since I can remember, and Tom knows him too. Old Miss Watson died two months ago, and she was so ashamed of thinking about selling him down the river that she freed him in her will."
es: —I mean it, Aunt Sally, and if no one goes, I will. I've known him all my life just like Tom here. Old Miss Watson died two months ago and felt ashamed for having intended to sell him down the river and said so, and she granted him freedom in her will.

en: “Then what on earth did you want to set him free for, seeing he was already free?”
vi: - You know that it is already free, so what freedom are you planning to return to it?
tr: “Alright, but why were you trying to save him, my child? He was already free!”
es: —So, why the hell did you want to set him free if he was already free?

en: “Well, that is a question, I must say; and just like women! Why, I wanted the adventure of it; and I’d a waded neck-deep in blood to—goodness alive, AUNT POLLY!”
vi: - That's the real issue. It's just that I like adventure, and I had to plunge into blood and fire to do it. Oh my God! Aunt Polly!
tr: “This is exactly the kind of question a woman would ask! Of course, I saved it for the adventure. I was even willing to risk drowning in my own blood for this. Oh my God, Aunt Polly!”
es: —Well, that is indeed a question, I must say, typical of a woman! Man, well, because I wanted to try the adventure, and I would have been capable of getting into blood up to my neck for... Good heavens, AUNT POLLY!

en: If she warn’t standing right there, just inside the door, looking as sweet and contented as an angel half full of pie, I wish I may never!
vi: At that moment, I seemed to see Aunt Polly standing inside the doorway, gentle and majestic like a fairy.
tr: Indeed, Aunt Polly was there, standing like an angel in front of the door with her usual sweet cheeks and kind face, looking at us.
es: May I die right now if he wasn't there, right next to the door, with an air as complacent and satisfied as an angel who had just gorged on cake!

en: Aunt Sally jumped for her, and most hugged the head off of her, and cried over her, and I found a good enough place for me under the bed, for it was getting pretty sultry for us, seemed to me. And I peeped out, and in a little while Tom’s Aunt Polly shook herself loose and stood there looking across at Tom over her spectacles—kind of grinding him into the earth, you know. And then she says:
vi: Aunt Saly ran out and hugged Aunt Polly tightly, almost bumping her head into her, then started crying, while I slipped under the bed. I peeked out, and in a moment, Tom's Aunt Polly came in, staring at him through her glasses as if she was about to crush him. Then she said:
tr: Aunt Sally immediately rushed towards him, hugged him around the neck, and started crying, and in the meantime, I slipped under the bed because things were starting to get heated for us. When I looked surreptitiously, I saw that Tom's Aunt Polly had freed herself from her sister's arms and was looking at Tom over her glasses – as if she was going to bury him into the ground. Then she said:
es: Aunt Sally jumped towards her and almost took her head off with a hug. She started crying with her, and I found a good spot under the bed, because I had the feeling that things were getting pretty tough for us. I looked from underneath and after a while Aunt Polly let go and stood there looking at Tom over her glasses, you know, as if she were tearing him to pieces. And then she goes and says:

en: “Yes, you better turn y’r head away—I would if I was you, Tom.”
vi: - Tom, you'd better turn away. If it were me, I would do the same.
tr: “You'd really do well to turn your head... If I were you, I'd do the same, Tom.”
es: —Yes, you'd better look the other way; it's what I would do in your case, Tom.

en: “Oh, deary me!” says Aunt Sally; “is he changed so? Why, that ain’t Tom, it’s Sid; Tom’s—Tom’s—why, where is Tom? He was here a minute ago.”
vi: Aunt Saly exclaimed: - Oh, hey, it's not Tom, it's Sid, Tom! Tom! Where has Tom run off to, he was just here!
tr: “Oh my God!” said Aunt Sally, “Has he changed that much? This isn't Tom, Sid; Tom is… Tom is… Where did Tom go now? He was here a second ago.”
es: —Oh my God! —says Aunt Sally— Has he changed that much? But that's not Tom, it's Sid; Tom is... but, where is Tom? He was here just a moment ago.

en: “You mean where’s Huck Finn—that’s what you mean! I reckon I hain’t raised such a scamp as my Tom all these years not to know him when I see him. That would be a pretty howdy-do. Come out from under that bed, Huck Finn.”
vi: - Do you mean to say that Huck Finn is somewhere around here? Is it possible that I've been raising that kid for so many years and still wouldn't recognize him? Huck Finn, come out from under the bed!
tr: “I suppose you mean where Huck Finn is… because you are talking about him! After raising and growing up a rascal like Tom, I would certainly recognize him when I see him. It would indeed be very strange. Come out from under the bed, Huck Finn.”
es: —You mean where Huck Finn is... that's who you mean! I reckon I haven't raised a rascal like my Tom all these years not to recognize him when I see him. That would be good. Come out from under the bed, Huck Finn.

en: So I done it. But not feeling brash.
vi: I crawled out, but it wasn't as natural as before.
tr: I came out from under the bed, feeling shy and embarrassed.
es: That was what I did. But I didn't feel very happy.

en: Aunt Sally she was one of the mixed-upest-looking persons I ever see—except one, and that was Uncle Silas, when he come in and they told it all to him. It kind of made him drunk, as you may say, and he didn’t know nothing at all the rest of the day, and preached a prayer-meeting sermon that night that gave him a rattling ruputation, because the oldest man in the world couldn’t a understood it. So Tom’s Aunt Polly, she told all about who I was, and what; and I had to up and tell how I was in such a tight place that when Mrs. Phelps took me for Tom Sawyer—she chipped in and says, “Oh, go on and call me Aunt Sally, I’m used to it now, and ’tain’t no need to change”—that when Aunt Sally took me for Tom Sawyer I had to stand it—there warn’t no other way, and I knowed he wouldn’t mind, because it would be nuts for him, being a mystery, and he’d make an adventure out of it, and be perfectly satisfied. And so it turned out, and he let on to be Sid, and made things as soft as he could for me.
vi: Aunt Sally was in a state of panic, and Uncle Silas, upon hearing everything, was no less panicked. That night, he called the whole family to pray so that he could regain his composure. Then Tom's Aunt Polly recounted everything about who I was, what I was like, and I had to stand up and explain everything from the beginning. Aunt Sally interrupted: - You can just call me Aunt Saly, I'm used to it, no need to change it. Aunt Polly said that Tom was right, Miss Watson had set Jim free. That's it.
tr: I had never seen a person as bewildered as Aunt Sally before, but then I did: When Uncle Silas, to whom they were telling the story, came in, his state was even more dire. He was practically dead drunk, wandered around in a daze for the rest of the day, and became incredibly famous because of the sermon he gave that night, as even the oldest folks couldn't understand a single word he said. Thus, Tom's Aunt Polly explained everything about who I was and what I had done, and then I tried to explain how difficult it was for me when Mrs. Phelps thought I was Tom Sawyer – but she interrupted me: "Oh, alright, just call me Aunt Sally again, I'm already used to it, no need to say anything else – I had to accept my fate when Aunt Sally mistook me for Tom Sawyer – there was no other way, besides, I knew Tom wouldn't object, because he loved such things, he liked mysterious affairs, would immediately turn them into an adventure, and then he would be happy. So, he accepted being Sid and tried to make things easier for me.
es: Aunt Sally became one of the people who understood the least of anything I have ever seen in my life, except for one, and that was Uncle Silas, when he came and they told him everything. You could say it was as if he got drunk, and he spent the rest of the day not understanding anything. That night he preached a sermon at the church meeting that gave him a phenomenal reputation, because not even the oldest person in the world would have understood it. So Aunt Polly told everyone who I was, and I had to confess that I was in such a bad situation that when Mrs. Phelps took me for Tom Sawyer... —and then she intervened and said: "Come on, come on, call me Aunt Sally, I'm used to it and there's no need to change things"—, that when Aunt Sally took me for Tom Sawyer I had to accept it, because I couldn't do anything else, and I knew Tom wouldn't mind, on the contrary, he would love it because it was a mystery and he would turn it all into an adventure and be very happy. That's how things turned out, and he pretended to be Sid and made everything as easy as he could for me.

en: And his Aunt Polly she said Tom was right about old Miss Watson setting Jim free in her will; and so, sure enough, Tom Sawyer had gone and took all that trouble and bother to set a free nigger free! and I couldn’t ever understand before, until that minute and that talk, how he could help a body set a nigger free with his bringing-up.
vi: Tom took upon himself all the hardships and struggles to free a black man who was already free! And it wasn't until now that I understood why someone as educated as Tom would join me in freeing a black man.
tr: Aunt Polly confirmed what Tom had said about Mrs. Watson's will freeing Jim; so our Tom Sawyer had indeed gone through all that trouble to rescue a free black man! Until that moment when the conversation took place, I hadn't understood how someone as well-bred as him could have freed a black man.
es: His Aunt Polly said that Tom was right in what he had said about old Miss Watson having declared Jim free in her will, so, of course, Tom Sawyer had gotten into all that mess and all that adventure to free a black man who was already free, and that’s why I couldn’t understand until that moment and that conversation how Tom could help someone to set a black man free with the way he had been brought up.

en: Well, Aunt Polly she said that when Aunt Sally wrote to her that Tom and Sid had come all right and safe, she says to herself:
vi: Then Mrs. Polly said that Aunt Sally had written her a letter saying that Tom and Sid had arrived safely; and she had told herself:
tr: Anyway, Aunt Polly said to herself this time when she received Aunt Sally's letter confirming that Tom and Sid had arrived safely:
es: Well, Aunt Polly said that when Aunt Sally wrote to her that Tom and Sid had arrived safe and sound, she had said to herself: "Well, well!"

en: “Look at that, now! I might have expected it, letting him go off that way without anybody to watch him. So now I got to go and trapse all the way down the river, eleven hundred mile, and find out what that creetur’s up to this time; as long as I couldn’t seem to get any answer out of you about it.”
vi: - When I let it go alone without anyone accompanying it, I didn't think this situation would happen. Now I have to struggle and travel over a thousand miles down there to see if there's anyone else named Sid. And when I asked, she didn't respond at all.
tr: "Here comes trouble! What else could happen if I let him wander all that way without anyone to watch over him? Well then, now go down the river for eleven hundred miles and find out what our rascal is up to this time if you have nothing better to do; and on top of that, I keep sending letters to my brother but he never replies."
es: Well, Aunt Polly said that when Aunt Sally wrote to her that Tom and Sid had arrived safe and sound, she had said to herself: "Well, well!" It was to be expected, for having let him go alone without anyone to watch over him. So now I have to go all the way down the river, eleven hundred miles, and find out what the boy is up to this time, because there was no way you could answer me."

en: “Why, I never heard nothing from you,” says Aunt Sally.
vi: Aunt Saly said:
tr: “But I haven't seen any of your letters,” said Aunt Sally.
es: —But we didn't get any news from you here —says Aunt Sally.

en: “Well, I wonder! Why, I wrote you twice to ask you what you could mean by Sid being here.”
vi: - I haven't received any news from you? - I wrote to you twice asking what it means that Sid is there?
tr: “Yeah, I wonder why! I wrote to you twice and asked what you meant by saying Sid was there.”
es: —Wow, how strange! But I wrote to you twice to ask what you meant by saying that Sid had arrived.

en: “Well, I never got ’em, Sis.”
vi: - I did not receive any letter from you.
tr: "No, I didn't receive any letter, sister."
es: —Well, sister, but they never arrived for me.

en: Aunt Polly she turns around slow and severe, and says:
vi: - It's you again, Tom!
tr: Aunt Polly slowly turned to Tom with a stern expression on her face.
es: Aunt Polly turned around very slowly and sternly, and then said:

en: “You, Tom!”
vi: - It's you again, Tom!
tr: "Tom, you did it!""
es: —You, Tom!

en: “Well—what?” he says, kind of pettish.
vi: - What did you say?
tr: “What have I done?” Tom asked meekly.
es: —Well... what? —he replies, sounding angry.

en: “Don’t you what me, you impudent thing—hand out them letters.”
vi: - It replied, mischievously. - Don't ask me anything else.
tr: “Don't tell me what I've done, you shameless one, you... Take out the letters, let's see.”
es: —Don't come asking me what, insolent; give me those letters.

en: “What letters?”
vi: Hand over the letter! - Which letter?
tr: "Which letters?"
es: —What letters?

en: “Them letters. I be bound, if I have to take aholt of you I’ll—”
vi: - What letter? I'm really annoyed now, if you keep lying, I will...
tr: “Those letters. If you don't give them to me right away, if I have to find them myself, then...”
es: —Those letters. I assure you that if I have to lay a hand on you, I'm going to...

en: “They’re in the trunk. There, now. And they’re just the same as they was when I got them out of the office. I hain’t looked into them, I hain’t touched them. But I knowed they’d make trouble, and I thought if you warn’t in no hurry, I’d—”
vi: - Yes, it's in that box. It's still exactly as it was when I picked it up from the post office. I haven't looked at it, nor have I touched it. But I guessed there would be some trouble, so I...
tr: "The letters are in the chest. Yes, there. I definitely didn't touch them, they are just as I received them from the post office. I didn't open or even touch them. But I knew the letters would cause trouble, and I thought you weren't in a hurry..."
es: —They are in the trunk. That's already been said. And they are just as they were when they were given to me at the post office. I haven't seen them. I haven't touched them. But I knew they were going to cause problems and I thought they weren't urgent for you and that...

en: “Well, you do need skinning, there ain’t no mistake about it. And I wrote another one to tell you I was coming; and I s’pose he—”
vi: - I will definitely skin you alive. I also wrote another letter, informing her that I am about to come down here, or maybe it also...
tr: "You're itching to skin me alive, huh? I have no doubt about that anymore. Also, I had sent another letter informing you that I would come here, and I believe Tom..."
es: —Well, you deserve a beating, there's no doubt about that. I wrote you another one to tell you that I was going to come, and I suppose that...

en: “No, it come yesterday; I hain’t read it yet, but it’s all right, I’ve got that one.”
vi: - That letter just arrived yesterday; I haven't read it yet, but I have already put it away.
tr: "No, it arrived yesterday; I haven't read it yet, but there's no problem. It's with me."
es: —No, it arrived yesterday; I haven't read it yet, but it arrived fine, I have that one.

en: I wanted to offer to bet two dollars she hadn’t, but I reckoned maybe it was just as safe to not to. So I never said nothing.
vi: I want to bet two dollars right now that Aunt Saly doesn't have that letter, but on second thought, I realized it would be better to stay silent. So I didn't say a word.
tr: I would bet two dollars that the letter is not with Aunt Sally, but it seemed wiser to keep quiet at that moment. I didn't say anything.
es: I would have bet two dollars that it wasn't, but I figured it might be safer not to bet. So I didn't say anything.

en: CHAPTER THE LAST
vi: The Final Chapter
tr: Final Chapter
es: Last Chapter

en: The first time I catched Tom private I asked him what was his idea, time of the evasion?—what it was he’d planned to do if the evasion worked all right and he managed to set a nigger free that was already free before? And he said, what he had planned in his head from the start, if we got Jim out all safe, was for us to run him down the river on the raft, and have adventures plumb to the mouth of the river, and then tell him about his being free, and take him back up home on a steamboat, in style, and pay him for his lost time, and write word ahead and get out all the niggers around, and have them waltz him into town with a torchlight procession and a brass-band, and then he would be a hero, and so would we. But I reckoned it was about as well the way it was.
vi: As soon as I got a chance to meet Tom alone, I immediately asked him what he thought during the escape? How would he plan if the escape was successful and how would he restore freedom to Jim? He said that if we managed to rescue Jim safely, we would let him sit on a raft drifting downstream, and together we would venture all the way to the river's mouth. At that point, we would tell him that he was free, then put him on a steamboat home, reward him, gather all the black folks around to dance and escort him into town with a proper parade, complete with drums and trumpets; he would become a hero, and so would the two of us. But I think we've almost done just that already.
tr: When I first caught Tom alone, I asked him what idea he had in mind during the escape.
